Magnavox Names Doyle Dane Agency
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has been named agency for the Magnavox line of audio and video products produced by the NAP Consumer Electronics Corporation.

title: Police Honor 3
description: The city honored three police officers yesterday for not missing a day of work in two decades.

title: Required Reading Howls From the White House
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, in a statement on the floor of the House of Representatives, May 9, 1984:

title: Posturing Over Pretoria
description: The Politics of Old Bones

title: IRAQ WARNS IRAN ON LAND ATTACKS
description: Iraq said today that its forces would destroy Iran's main oil export terminal at Kharg Island if Iranian forces began a new land offensive and continued to reject a peaceful resolution of the war.

title: BROOKLYN UPLIFT: HOTEL REBORN AS APARTMENT HOUSE
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music had good reason to be distressed for many years about the character of properties across the street from its main entrance on Lafayette Street.

title: Joseph P. Farley, Executive, Rear Admiral and Swimmer
description: Joseph P. Farley, a real-estate executive who as a rear admiral in the Naval Reserve served as chief of staff of the New York State Division of Military and Naval Affairs from 1965 to 1973, died Tuesday at his home in Kinderhook, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: TAX DOLLARS FOR 'LIBERALISM'S PRIESTHOOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SWEET AND SOUR
description: In January CBS News aired a three-part report about a new low-calorie sweetener, trade-named NutraSweet, which is rapidly replacing saccharin among the diet-conscious. The CBS telecast raised questions about the safety of the product, based on the research of a nutritionist at Arizona State University.

title: 3 ACCUSED AS INSIDERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed an amended complaint yesterday, adding three names to its March filing charging the use of inside information about proposed tender offers.

title: Lawyer Asserts School Kept Log of Beatings
description: Accounts of hunger, isolation and beatings with plastic pipes and wooden sticks emerged today in the investigation of a fundamentalist boarding school whose operators have been charged with kidnapping and neglect.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Federated Stores
description: Shareholders of Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store operator, approved several antitakeover moves at the annual meeting in Cincinnati. Among them was an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 100 million, from 70 million, and staggered terms for board members.

title: Article 231804 -- No Title
description: The House of Representatives approved tonight a $207 billion Pentagon authorization bill for fiscal year 1985, incorporating into it strong arms control measures on major weapons. The vote was 298 to 98.

title: Pisani Jury Retires Without a Verdict
description: The jury in the fraud trial of State Senator Joseph Pisani of New Rochelle, N.Y., failed to reach a verdict again last night, and Judge David N. Edelstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan admonished jurors because two of them did not want to meet over the weekend.

title: INFORMANT TESTIFIES ABOUT BARGAINING AT DELOREAN TRIAL
description: A Government informer testified today that he never considered the possibility that John Z. DeLorean was ''conning'' him when the auto maker talked about getting money purportedly to invest in narcotics.

title: CINDY HILL LEADS L.P.G.A. BY 4 SHOTS
description: Cindy Hill did not join the Ladies Professional Golf Association until she was 31 years old, in 1979. Then she almost quit the tour last year when a back ailment caused her so much pain she could not play for months.

title: U.S. Journalists' Toll In Latin Wars Now 6
description: Linda Frazier was the sixth journalist from the United States killed in the military conflicts in Central America since 1979, according to Carol Drake, a spokesman for the Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based nonprofit organzation.

title: No Headline
description: -Michele Alboreto of Italy, driving a Ferrari, captured the provisional pole position today, the first of two days of qualifying for Sunday's Monaco Grand Prix.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $249,000 for the quarter and $451,000 for the 6 months.

title: Brazil Steel Ruling
description: Imports of government-subsidized steel from Brazil threaten to do major harm to American steel companies, the United States International Trade Commission ruled today, opening the way to the imposition of import duties. The Commerce Department will shortly order the imposition of duties ranging from 17 percent to 62 percent of the value of Brazilian steel products, the I.T.C. staff said. The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, had brought the complaint, which involved carbon steel plate and sheet used in construction, shipbuilding and home appliances.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRAE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THREE-NIGHT JAZZ FESTIVAL SET
description: An ambitious, bargain-price festival of jazz and improvised new music is taking place this weekend, with quintuple bills tonight, tomorrow and Sunday. The Sound Unity Festival was organized by the German bassist Peter Kowald to bring together European, Asian and American musicians and dancers who work with jazz and other improvised music.

title: MCENROE GAINS IN PARIS
description: With John McEnroe and Martina Navratilova leading the way, the top-seeded players in the French Open tennis championships advanced easily today into the third round.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. PAROLE UNIT TO SEEK TESTIMONY FROM VICTIM
description: Crime victims will have a voice in parole decisions about Federal prisoners convicted of victimizing them, under new rules announced today by the United States Parole Commission.

title: Boros, Himself
description: When Steve Boros was dismissed as manager of the Oakland A's on May 24, comment ran that he was an intelligent, low-keyed man with a pleasant personality but that the A's needed strong leadership and a change of chemistry.

title: LINEUP SHIFTS FRUSTRATE YANKS
description: The Yankees, not adjusted to losing but unaccustomed at this point to winning, are tired of defeat and unconvinced by victory.

title: Zola Budd Eligible
description: Zola Budd , the South African-born running sensation who recently became a British subject, received official confirmation yesterday that she is eligible to compete for Britain at the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer. The go-ahead came from the British Olympic Association, which in turn had consulted with the International Olympic Committee.

title: PHILS TOP CUBS
description: Mike Schmidt drove in three runs with two singles, and Von Hayes had three hits, two runs batted in and three runs scored as the Philadelphia Phillies moved into first place in the National League East tonight with a 10-2 rout of the Chicago Cubs.

title: PASTORA A LONER AMONG REBELS
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader who was wounded in a bomb blast Wednesday, is in every sense a maverick, first falling out with the Sandinista regime that he helped to install and then preferring to fight alone rather than join other opposition groups linked to the ousted Somoza regime.

title: NOTED MEXICAN JOURNALIST SHOT DEAD
description: Manuel Buendia, one of Mexico's best-known and most-read journalists, was shot dead Wednesday night as he entered a parking lot here.

title: PONDEROSA SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to May 17
CHEMICAL AND CONSERVATION GROUPS FORM TOXIC CLEANUP UNIT
description: The chemical industry joined with several environmental groups today to form an organization intended to help speed the cleanup of the nation's toxic waste dumps.

title: Bolivia Seeking to Halt Sale of Guevera Diaries
description: Bolivia, saying it has been robbed of part of its history, announced today that it would try to stop the last diaries of the revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara from being auctioned in London.

title: PHOENIX CANADA OIL CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A FIGHTER FOR ROGHTS
description: Barely two weeks into her job as head of New York City's Human Rights Commission, Marcella Maxwell has not had time to put books on the shelves or even to hang a picture on the wall of her sixth-floor office at 52 Duane Street. Her days have been consumed with developing plans for the future.

title: Victim Describes Harlem Stabber
description: The Associated Press

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: A place for friends to get together.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ROY HAYNES AT DRUMS IN VILLAGE

title: A NEGOTIATED PEACE IN LONG UNC FIGHT
description: UNC Resources Inc., a small manufacturing and natural resources concern that filed suit eight and a half years ago to break up what it called an international uranium cartel, said yesterday that it had agreed to accept about $300 million to settle out of court.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Dwight Gooden, right behind Nolan Ryan and Fernando Valenzuela for the National League lead in strikeouts, starts for the Mets against a revived Joaquin Andujar. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After a loss of $341,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Quebec Man Acquitted
description: A Quebec hunting lodge operator who said he shot and killed his common-law wife after he had mistaken her for a bear was acquitted Wednesday of second-degree murder. Gilles Goulet explained in Quebec Superior Court that he mistakenly shot his wife, Renee Sigouin, as she walked near their country cabin, wearing a green poncho. He said that when he saw what he thought was a bear, he checked the target through the telescopic sights of his rifle before firing.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
STOCKS REGISTER A SMALL GAIN
description: Stock prices posted a small advance yesterday in less active trading, with some takeover candidates posting the biggest gains.

title: U.S. GIVES ARGENTINA MORE TIME
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today gave Argentina a new extension, of 15 days, to meet the terms he offered in March to tide the country through an immediate debt-payment crisis.

title: APPLIED DATA COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Neutral Sites Set For Soccer Finals
description: Scattered fan violence that left 42 people injured Wednesday, when Liverpool defeated Roma here in the European Cup championship game, has led international soccer officials to decide that all final games in major European tournaments next year will be played at neutral sites.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Youthful Raves

title: BROADWAY
description: 'Harrigan & Hart' due at Goodspeed in Chester, Conn.

title: REIGNS AND RUNOFFS;  Intermittent Plastic We have a friend who has worn her raincoat literally to rags. The epaulet is off the right shoulder and the fabric is in shreds. Her boots are O.K. though, not like the ones we saw on the subway this week: yellow, patched with the kind of tape plumbers wrap around pipes. We've also seen booties - clear plastic bags string-tied at the ankles. We have seen large trash bags too, with slits for head and arms. The best-looking were in dark green and the best-accessorized came with a hat made of a white plastic bag (tall kitchen size) shaped and folded into something quite fetching.
description: We've also seen several cleaners' bags, likewise slit at head and arm, but they didn't make much of a fashion statement. And the woman who was wearing a cleaners' bag over her head wasn't trying at all.

title: Carpenter New Devil Coach
description: Through losing season after losing season, from the days when they were the Kansas City Scouts and then the Colorado Rockies, they have been characterized by constant changes in head coaches. Today, the Devils named yet another one, the 12th in the 10-year history of the franchise, to succeed Tom McVie.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $239,998, or 20 cents a share.

title: BRIEFING
description: And Have a Nice Day

title: Police Still Seek Brooklyn Rapist
description: The police said yesterday that a man who was charged Tuesday for a rape on April 20 was not, as they had thought, responsible for a series of rapes in the Flatbush and Kensington Park sections of Brooklyn.

title: Eagleburger Is Joining Kissinger Associates
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who earlier this month retired as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, has been elected president of Kissinger Associates Inc., the strategic consulting concern headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. The appointment is effective July 1.

title: THE T-SHIRT IS THE MESSAGE
description: ''Is that what it's all come down to - no philosophy that can't be printed on a T-shirt?''

title: Fight Aftermath
description: Mario Soto, the Cincinnati pitcher who made physical contact with an umpire during the big dispute last Sunday in Chicago, had to wait four days to learn what Chub Feeney, the National League president, thought of his behavior. Feeney's opinion, announced yesterday: a fine and a five- day suspension.

title: 5 ON REAGAN TRANSITION TEAM SAID TO HAVE RECEIVED FUNDS
description: A private foundation established in 1980 to help President-elect Reagan's transition to office made sizable payments to five campaign aides who later received administration jobs, according to sources familiar with the situation.

title: A PIPELINE TO THE RESCUE OF PERSIAN GULF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Revlon Stock Up In Heavy Trading
description: Revlon Inc.'s shares jumped $1.75, to $37.625, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange following reports that an investor group, including Revlon's former executive vice president, Martin E. Revson, had approached the company with a plan for a leveraged buyout offer. Volume totaled 841,300 shares.

title: THEATER: MARATHON '84, 3 MORE ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: SOMETHING strange is afoot in Hiley Bedsel's funeral parlor in Grayson, Mo. Tombstones are carved with the date of death, weeks before the Grim Reaper arrives. Clearly, Mr. Bedsel is a seer and, perhaps, a deux ex machina. As played by Bill Cwikowski in Katharine Long's ''Ariel Bright'' - the high point of the fourth and final evening in the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '84 - he is as amiably spectral a figure as one is likely never to meet.

title: Polish Mother Charges Cover-Up in Son's Death
description: The mother of a young Solidarity supporter who was beaten to death in police custody accused Communist authorities today of covering up police involvement in the slaying.

title: Partisan Clashes in Congress
description: The partisan warfare that has been echoing through the House of Representatives for two weeks erupted again today, as Republicans and Democrats angrily accused each other of unfair and unbecoming conduct.

title: ART: ANTHONY CARO, COMMUTING BRITISH SCULPTOR
description: OF all the British artists - and they were many - who in the 1960's aspired to mid-Atlantic status, the sculptor Anthony Caro was always the most gifted. He is also the one who has best known how to pace himself, when to switch from one set of materials to another and - not least important - how often to cross the Atlantic and how long to stay here.

title: AT READER'S DIGEST, A FIGHT OVER PHILOSOPHY
description: At the headquarters of the Reader's Digest Association Inc. on a serene hillside in Westchester County, the usual tranquillity has been in short supply in recent months. The intensely private company has undergone upheaval at the top, dramatically affecting its leadership, its editorial philosophy and control of the nation's largest magazine.

title: Pact for McMahon
description: Fearing that their young and strong-armed quarterback, Jim McMahon, would jump to the United States Football League, the Chicago Bears signed him yesterday to a five- year, multimillion-dollar contract. Details were not disclosed, but General Manager Jerry Vainisi said that the new salary for McMahon, who had had one year remaining on a two- year pact, would compare to those of other top quarterbacks in the National Football League.

title: THE ADDED DIMENSIONS OF HENRY MOORE OUTDOORS
description: THE installation of 25 bronze sculptures by the celebrated English sculptor Henry Moore across the five boroughs of New York City is unprecedented in the recent history of New York public art. For the next nine months, the familiar bumpy and hollow men and women of Henry Moore will be feeding, tumbling, dancing and resting in the parks and gardens of the city, which many of us thought we shared only with ducks, sun bathers, picnickers and nature.

title: Kohl Asserts Political Unity Should Be Aim of Europeans
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called today for a ''United States of Europe,'' saying that the Continent meant more than just a free trade zone.

title: DISSENSION IN PAKISTAN: POWER CAN'T PROTECT SECT
description: Of all the Indian subcontinent's myriad religious groups, few are considered more influential in the secular world for their size than an energetic, tightly organized group that calls itself the Ahmadiya.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Wackenhut Buyout Talks
description: The Wackenhut Corporation said an investor group was discussing a $24-a-share, or $93.6 million, buyout of the security services company, based in Coral Gables, Fla. The group, led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, would include the company's founder and chairman, George R. Wackenhut, and his wife, who beneficially own 53.3 percent of the 3.9 million shares outstanding.

title: RAIN ENDS, MET SLIDE DOESN'T
description: Despite three days and three nights of rain, the Mets did not begin building an ark. They might need one, though, to keep themselves from drowning in a steady stream of losses.

title: ONCE AGAIN, SOFT TURF FOR THE RED SMITH
description: Eight horses are set to contest the Red Smith Handicap tomorrow at a mile and a quarter on the grass at Belmont Park. The race, known as the Edgemere from 1960 through 1981, has already developed under its new name a tradition that will continue this year: testing the ability of grass horses to negotiate a slow and rain-soaked turf course.

title: MONARCH INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: TWYLA THARP CELEBRATION
description: THE American Ballet Theater honored Twyla Tharp on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with an all-Tharp program that filled the theater with affectionate excitement. It was a rare gesture. And Miss Tharp clearly has a special relationship with Ballet Theater, which has four of her ballets in its repertory, all of which were performed on Wednesday. One of the evening's nicest aspects was a program insert in which Miss Tharp thanked Susan Jones, the company's young regisseur, for her ''passion for detail and commitment to the spirit of the Tharp works.''

title: E.I.L. INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DEMOCRATS SHOULD BE DEMOCRATS
description: It is fashionable now, as the first phase of the Democratic Party's long nominating process comes to a close, to complain about the whole nominating system. It places an inhuman burden on the surviving candidates; it gives inordinate influence to a relatively few financial contributors; it contrives differences among candidates where few exist; it magnifies the importance of the press and television; it trivializes issues; and it ultimately fatigues voters into an unwelcome choice. In fact, for all its faults and failures, the process is working and will continue to do so if it is not aborted by attempts to create a premature party ''unity.''

title: 5-Day Ban for Soto
description: Mario Soto , scheduled to pitch tonight in one of Cincinnati's two games against Atlanta, instead will begin a five-day suspension imposed yesterday by the National League.

title: CARE PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company commenced operations in November 1983.

title: TWO BILLS TO HELP COLLECT OVERDUE CHILD SUPPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennsylvania Bell To Buy Back Debt
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, a unit of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said it had authorized the repurchase of some or all of the $150 million principal amount of its outstanding 40-year, 15 1/8 percent debentures, due April 5, 2021.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Methodist Anniversary

title: BEST OF TIMES FOR CARTER, SHOT-PUTTER
description: Michael Carter is 23 years old, and he says life has never been better.

title: Economic Scene; T.V.A. at 50: New Criticism
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE the heated debate that has erupted periodically over the Tennessee Valley Authority, most Americans have come to regard this grand experiment in planned economic growth as a big, nearly unqualified success.

title: Midland Plant Cost Study
description: Completing the Consumers Power Company's Midland nuclear plant would cost $24.3 billion more than scrapping it, and would result in the loss of at least 8,170 jobs, according to a study released today.

title: FOSSIL DISPUTE MAY BRING APARTHEID DENUNCIATION
description: The American Museum of Natural History has tentatively agreed to post signs denouncing apartheid at an exhibition that includes fossils from South Africa, according to Bess Myerson, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, and Herbert Kurz, the manager of public affairs for the museum.

title: FILM: LATEST IN THE 'STAR TREK' SERIES
description: ''STAR TREK III: The Search for Spock'' finds the same old gang in a gloomy mood. Spock is dead (or at least he would appear to be, to anyone who hasn't seen his likeness on movie posters all over town). The Starship Enterprise is ready for mothballs. Even the crew's 23d-century leisure suits are beginning to seem passe. It's not hard to feel, while watching the opening sections of this latest in the ''Star Trek'' series, that you're getting a little too old for this kind of thing - and that

title: Discord on Drugs Threatens Plan
description: Hurdles apparently remain in the path of a final owner-player agreement on how major league baseball is to deal with drug dependency.

title: A SUMMER CAMP THAT'S JUST FOR DOLLS
description: Dr. Sanford Stein usually earns his living fixing people's teeth. But this summer he will alternate wearing his white dentist's coat with a T-shirt when he becomes director of a camp for Cabbage Patch dolls.

title: Virginia Boy, 13, Wins Spelling Bee
description: A young computer expert, 13-year-old Daniel Greenblatt of Sterling, Va., won the 57th annual National Spelling Bee today when he correctly spelled ''luge,'' a racing sled.

title: Advertising; Showtime Gets New Campaign
description: THE J. Walter Thompson Company has created a new advertising campaign for Showtime, the pay cable network, with the theme ''We Make Excitement.'' And it is intended to impress the cable operators as much as subscribers and potential subscribers.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Rarefied Parking Problem

title: MORRISON PETROLEUMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
29 Indicted in Chicago On Smuggling Yugoslav s
description: Twenty- nine people have been indicted for illegally smuggling thousands of Yugoslavs into the United States in what a Federal prosecutor said today might have been the biggest scheme ever to bring aliens from outside the Western Hemisphere into the country.

title: SAMUEL SWERDLOFF
description: Samuel Swerdloff, a fund-raiser and public-relations consultant who was active in cultural and civic affairs, died of cancer Monday at University Hospital.

title: Wrong Turn
description: Dave Kingman , the big gun in the lineup of the Oakland A's, has been sidelined with a knee injury that he apparently suffered while carrying on a running quarrel with an American League umpire. Kingman hurt the knee in a game against the Detroit Tigers Tuesday when he tripped and fell as he turned, apparently to taunt the home-plate umpire, while running out a single.

title: PHILHARMONIC: HORIZONS '84 FESTIVAL
description: DEPENDING on how you figured it, the New York Philharmonic's Horizons '84 new-music festival got under way either Wednesday night or last night. On Wednesday at the Lincoln Center Library, five panelists struggled to bring clarity to the theme of this year's festival, ''The New Romanticism - A Broader View.'' And last night, at Avery Fisher Hall, the first program of actual music took place.

title: FILM: 'ONCE UPON A TIME INAMERICA'
description: SERGIO LEONE, the Italian director who gave class to the term ''spaghetti western,'' has made some weird movies in his day but nothing to match ''Once Upon a Time in America,'' a lazily haullucinatory epic that means to encapsulate approximately 50 years of American social history into a single film.

title: U.S. NOTES AND BONDS STAGE PRICE REBOUNDS
description: After declining sharply earlier in the week, prices of Treasury notes and bonds rebounded yesterday and closed with gains of as much as 1 1/4 points.

title: I.B.M. Offers Europe Plan
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has made a new proposal to the European Economic Community aimed at resolving the trade bloc's antitrust case against the computer maker, John R. Opel, chairman of I.B.M., said today. Its future investment in Europe may be at stake, he told a meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce here.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE interior garden of the I.B.M.

title: STOCK SALES IS CANCELED
description: Gifford-Hill & Company said yesterday that it had canceled plans to sell 1.25 million new shares of its common stock, citing the recent decline in the price of its stock.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS TIES WITH SOVIET ARE PARAMOUNT
description: President Reagan said today that the United States and its NATO allies recognized that there was ''no more important consideration than the development of a better working relationship with the Soviet Union.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 1, 1984

title: Two Veterans Plead Guilty in Temple Fire
description: Two Vietnam veterans pleaded guilty today to the firebombing of a Buddhist temple on New Year's Eve to call attention to stress that they say veterans suffer from the war.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Mountains Then and Now

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS OFF IN MAY
description: Prices farmers receive for their crops fell 1.4 percent in May from April's record level, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: D'Arcy Sets Restructuring
description: Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide, announced with relief yesterday that he had completed his financial restructuring with the naming of John B. Balson, 42 years old, to be chief operating officer, North America, of the worldwide agency. Mr. Balson, who began his business career at Grey Advertising, was until this week president of K & E Holdings, parent company of Kenyon & Eckhardt. A Chicago native, he is a graduate in hotel management of Cornell University and has an M.B.A. from Harvard.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about an Iranian oil price reduction yesterday incorrectly reported prices of heating oil futures for June delivery. In trading Wednesday, the price rose to 81.35 cents a gallon but closed at 80.80 cents, compared with a final quote Tuesday of 80.55 cents.

title: Jefferson Smurfit In Southwest Bid
description: Jefferson Smurfit Group Ltd. said it is seeking to acquire Southwest Forest Industries. Southwest, a Phoenix- based maker of wood products, said Wednesday that it planned to hold talks with Jefferson about ''a possible transaction.''

title: ; MAYAS CELEBRATED AND MAYAS PERSECUTED
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: No Noise, No Pain

title: Diplomat Takes Post At Nabisco
description: Kenneth D. Taylor, who as Canada's Ambassador to Iran sheltered six American diplomats and arranged their escape from Teheran in January 1980, has been appointed senior vice president for corporate-government relations of Nabisco Brands Inc.

title: MINERAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect prior period adjustment of exploration expenditures.

title: SCREEN: 'STREETS OF FIRE'
description: IF Walter Hill has directed any of

title: DAVID K. LANGSTAFF
description: David K. Langstaff, a writer and public-relations consultant who served with the United States Information Agency in Europe after World War II, died May 23 at Long Island College Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Bush Sees Little Peril Of War in 'Stinger' Deal
description: Vice President Bush said Wednesday that the United States was probably further away from the prospect of war now than in recent years, despite this country's transfer of 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia in the war-torn Persian Gulf.

title: SCHWARZ NAMED MOSTLY MOZART MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: Gerard Schwarz, the conductor and trumpeter who has served for two seasons as musical adviser to the Mostly Mozart Festival, has become the festival's music director. The new appointment was announced this week by Mostly Mozart's administrative director, William W. Lockwood Jr., along with the program plans for the festival's 18th annual summer season.

title: DISCLOSURE BILL ON COLLEGE AID SENT TO CUOMO
description: Colleges in New York State would have to disclose conditions attached to gifts of more than $100,000 from any foreign source under a bill given final legislative approval by the Assembly today.

title: Stockbrokers Reach Record
description: The number of full-time producing registered representatives increased 16.8 percent in 1983, to a record high of 69,960, according to an annual survey of member firms conducted by the New York Stock Exchange and made public this week. The number of sales offices also increased in 1983, to a record 5,876, up 13.5 percent from the previous year, the exchange said yesterday. Since the end of the year, however, the securities industry has been suffering from a slowdown in business, with some brokerage firms laying off both support staff and brokers with low productivity.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net loss

title: AFTER THE PRIMARIES
description: Whatever happens in the final round of state primaries, the Democrats appear likely to choose a Presidential candidate who has been badly wounded by the long and strangely indecisive nominating campaign.

title: No Headline
description: FaNotebyFather

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Hot Dog in Bow - Wow!

title: MOSCOW CALLS NATO'S PLEA ON TIES 'ULTIMATE HYPOCRISY'
description: The Soviet press said today that the statement issued by NATO foreign ministers after their meeting in Washington was ''imbued with the spirit of bellicosity'' and dismissed calls for East-West talks as ''the ultimate in hypocrisy.''

title: Wolf Younin, 76, Yiddish Poet, Lyricist and Playwright, Dies
description: Wolf Younin, known in the Yiddish-speaking world as poet, playwright and lyricist, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Canberra Eases Quotas
description: The Australian Government announced increases today in most textile, clothing and footwear import quotas for 1985. John Button, Minister for Industry and Commerce, said the increases reflected expected market growth, improved production and sales of textile, clothing and footwear products this year.

title: CRUZ WINS 800-METERS AT N.C.A.A. MEET
description: Of the 1,003 men and women competing here in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 63d annual outdoor track and field championships, none may be more talented than Joaquim Cruz of Oregon. None may have a better chance of an Olympic gold medal this summer in Los Angeles than the 21- year-old sophomore from Brazil.

title: AN IRISH VILLAGE BRACES FOR PRESIDENTIAL ROADSHOW
description: The publicity, a village resident said, ''is a bloody disgrace, and it's very bad for Ballyporeen's cultural image.''

title: CLOGGED WHEELS OF JUSTICE
description: Only the address was different. The State Racing and Wagering Board moved its Manhattan offices last winter from luxurious World Trade Center suites overlooking the harbor to a renovated Broome Street house overlooking an alley favored by Bowery drunks. But the faces in the board's hearing room yesterday morning were the same: the jockeys, the lawyers, the reporters and the racing commissioners who are still slogging through a New York race-fixing scandal that is nearly a decade old.

title: Von Karajan Cancels Concert in Salzburg
description: Herbert von Karajan will boycott a June 11 Salzburg appearance with the Berlin Philharmonic in the latest round of a dispute with the orchestra over a 24- year-old clarinetist, according to an orchestra spokesman.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Jailed Man Freed InLook-AlikeCase
description: A man who spent 16 months in the Nassau County Jail awaiting trial on a bank robbery charge was freed today after a look-alike confessed to the crime.

title: OLYMPIC ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS IN L.A.
description: Pina Bausch Wuppertaler Tanztheater, the controversial West German dance company that mingles dance and theater on stages it has covered with leaves or sodden earth, opened the 10-week-long Los Angeles Olympic Arts Festival tonight before a capacity crowd of 3,000 at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. It was the company's American debut.

title: Bridge: Foreign Visitor Makes Final
description: Foreign visitors have frequently played in the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Teams, but in 54 years none of them have won. A breakthrough may be made this year, however.

title: DANCE: COAST TROUPE
description: Five choreographers were represented on the program that ODC/San Francisco offered Tuesday night in the Joyce Theater, and all five appeared to be fascinated by jogging crowds of people. The result was an evening of stylistically similar dances that proved to be dismayingly monotonous in their total effect.

title: NORTHWEST TELEPRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSTEAD, CALL IT WASTEWAY
description: With or without the striped bass, Westway is a fraud on New York's taxpaying and voting public. This multibillion-dollar landfill and real estate project for Manhattan's lower West Side waterfront, disguised as an interstate highway, is a plan whose time has long since come - and gone. It is a politician's delight, a speculator's dream, a city planner's mirage and John Q. Citizen's nightmare. It deserves to be renamed Wasteway.

title: ZULUS APPEAL TO THE QUEEN: PLEASE SAVE OUR LAND
description: The descendants of Zulus who received farmland in 1904 from King Edward VII have petitioned Queen Elizabeth II to help them keep their land, saying the South African authorities plan to evict them summarily in the near future.

title: Brown Advances To Rowing Final
description: Brown, Syracuse and California-Berkeley won their repechage, or second chance, heats today on Lake Onondaga.

title: THE PROM IS BACK IN FASHION
description: A cavalcade of silver and ebony limousines idled outside the Waldorf- Astoria on a recent Friday. In some places, they were three deep around the block, and their passengers waited as long as 20 minutes for the moment when they could pull up and make a grand entrance.

title: A NEW CHILD-CENTERED GUIDE FOR NURTURING PARENTS
description: Babies today are widely understood to be aware, alert and responsive from birth, in contrast to earlier views of babies as unformed protoplasm to be left alone between feedings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Letter: On Bankruptcy Labor's Stake in Corporate Survival To the Editor:
description: Your editorial ''Bankruptcy Is Not a Weapon'' (May 24) continues your persistent pattern of twisting logic to bring every issue to an anti-labor conclusion.

title: BRAMBLE TAKES MANCINI'S TITLE
description: At the end, he was standing helpless, his hands at his side, his nearly closed eyes seemingly looking for help. But not even his big heart or the judges' benevolent scoring could save Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini tonight.

title: IRAN PRICE CUT SAID TO LURE TANKERS
description: At least six large tankers have loaded oil at Iran's Kharg Island terminal in the last two days or are in the process of doing so, taking advantage of Iran's sizable discounts while risking an attack by Iraq, oil industry traders and analysts said yesterday.

title: JETS' PROSPECT DEALS WITH AN AILMENT
description: When teammates look at him with admiration and say, ''Did you really cut all your hair off?'' Gene Giles smiles and answers, ''Sure, I shaved it off.''

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TEXAS DEMOCRATS TO CHOOSE SENATE NOMINEE
description: The two survivors of one hard-fought Democratic primary for the United States Senate kept fighting down to the wire today while Democrats prepared to go to the polls once again Saturday to choose between them.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA DEMOCRATS TO VOTE ON TUESDAY
description: South Dakota Democrats will decide in their primary Tuesday how to award 15 of the state's 19 delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Political experts have commented on the fact that Walter F. Mondale has not visited the state or set up a headquarters here.

title: MONDALE'S ALLIES CAMPAIGN IN JERSEY
description: In the final weekend before the Democratic primary Tuesday in New Jersey, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is calling on friends and allies in the party to campaign for him in areas where they are expected to have a special appeal.

title: 2 AIDES DID NOT DISCLOSE TRANSITION FUND INCOME
description: Two of five officials in the 1980 Reagan campaign who received payments from a private trust established to help finance planning for the transition to office did not report the payments accurately on their financial disclosure forms.

title: Sears Halts Sales Of Coleco's Adam
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company disclosed that it had suspended sales of Coleco Industries' Adam home computer system about a month ago, for reasons it would not specify. ''We are trying to tell the consumer that at this point we prefer that they wait'' before buying the system, a Sears spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Invitation to Dine

title: GETTING ON THE TEAM
description: I'm sick and tired of being impersonated by law-enforcement agents. Every Tom, Dick and Harry with a badge thinks he can cross-dress as a reporter. So I'm going to do something drastic about it.

title: AMERICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $45,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. , a machine tools company, said it had agreed to sell its U.S. Printed Circuit Board Materials division to Etherington Industries, a private Connecticut- based holding company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: LIFELONG FOE OF DICTATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVARD'S 'CORE' DEAN GLANCES BACK
description: When Henry Rosovsky helped develop Harvard University's pioneering core curriculum in the mid-1970's, he remembers, The Harvard Crimson attacked it as a ''counterrevolution.''

title: C.I.A. HEAD REPORTS TRADINGS IN STOCK
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, engaged in 40 stock transactions totaling more than $1 million last year, according to Mr. Casey's 1983 financial disclosure statement.

title: CARACAS TAKES IN WOUNDED REBEL CHIEF
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the anti-Sandinista leader who was wounded in a bomb attack on his jungle headquarters in Nicaragua on Wednesday night, was flown from Costa Rica to Venezuela today aboard a hospital plane sent by the Venezuelan Government.

title: THE REGION ; ;  O'Neill Signs Bill On A-Plant Costs
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has signed into law a bill to prevent the state's two major utilities from passing along losses from the suspended Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant to customers, the Governor's office announced today.

title: DOW SOARS BY 19.50, TO 1,124.35
description: Stock prices posted their biggest daily gain in more than seven weeks yesterday as rising bond prices and optimism over interest rates halted a two-week market slump.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Airline Pact Averts Strike
description: Frontier Airlines and the Association of Flight Attendants reached a tentative agreement tonight on a new contract, averting a strike that had been scheduled for 10:01 P.M. The agreement came after a nine-hour bargaining session.

title: Politics Called a Factor In Future Olympic Site
description: The President of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said today that in the future the committee would have to consider political factors when seeking a site for the Games.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Continue Higher;  Treasury Bill Rates Up
description: The gloom that has enveloped the bond market since mid-January was lifted yesterday, at least temporarily, as Treasury bond prices rose strongly for the second consecutive day.

title: Private Group to Seek More Voting by Military
description: The American Defense Foundation, a private organization formed to support military spending, announced Thursday that it would lobby state legislatures to give overseas military personnel enough time to vote by absentee ballot in future elections.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a stock dividend distributed in September 1983.

title: SOME SENIORS SHUN POPULARITY AND MAKE OWN PATH
description: Nadine Weidman is famous at Great Neck South High School for not talking in class. There are people who claim to never have heard her voice in four years.

title: Face the Inevitable in Copper
description: American copper producers, mauled by low world prices, say they need protection from imports to become profitable again. The industry is asking the U.S. International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, to recommend quotas to the White House that would cut imports by half.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
;  Comings and Goings The Cincinnati Reds said they would not appeal a five-day suspension imposed on their star pitcher,
description: Mario Soto , which runs through next Tuesday. . . . The Texas Rangers have asked waivers on Jim Bibby , the 29-year-old righthander who has a 111-101 career record with five teams. In 16 innings this year, Bibby had a 4.41 earned-run average and no decisions. . . . Mike Guess , a defensive back, and Ricky Simmons , wide receiver, will remain on the club's active roster, the Washington Federals announced, pending investigation by the team and the U.S.F.L. office of their arrests in Washington Thursday night on misdemeanor counts of cocaine and marijuana possession.

title: MONTREAL CITY & DISTRICT SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14.

title: EUROPEANS TO ASK DEBT RESCUE MOVE
description: European leaders will urge President Reagan at next week's London summit meeting to support joint action to head off a possible new financial crisis next year, when some $250 billion of third-world debt starts to fall due, according to officials preparing for the talks.

title: 12.7% Jobless in Britain
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted unemployment total rose to its highest level ever in May - 3,028,600, or 12.7 percent of the work force, the Employment Department announced today. Under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government, unemployment is at its highest level since the 1930's Depression. But inflation has dropped from 21 percent in May 1980 to just over 5 percent this year.

title: Kennedy Still Says He'll Be Neutral in July
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has said again that he will not take sides in the Democratic race for President, that he does not expect the convention to be deadlocked and that he will refuse the Presidential nomination if the party seeks to draft him at its convention in July.

title: EUROPE ON PRESIDENT: MIXED REVIEWS
description: For much of President Reagan's three years in the White House, many Western Europeans have expressed mistrust of his style and actions and have regarded his successes with a mixture of envy, bewilderment and contempt. But they have also recently caught the sense of a reinvigorated United States under Mr. Reagan, and have compared it with what often seems to be the stagnation, both psychic and economic, of their own countries.

title: Santo (Mr. Tailgate) Pecora; Jazz Trombonist for 50 years
description: Santo (Mr. Tailgate) Pecora, a jazz trombonist who performed across the country with his band, the Tailgate Ramblers, and played in bands led by Harry James and Tommy Dorsey during a 50-year career, died here Tuesday.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Head of Illegal School Freed
description: The head of an unaccredited church school was released from jail today after his attorney posted bail of $10,000. It had been raised from dozens of churches nationwide. The Rev. Everett Sileven, jailed April 26 for contempt of court for operating the unapproved Faith Christian School in Louisville, Neb., said he planned to go home to his family.

title: Miller-Wohl Stake
description: A group of companies controlled by Ivan Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission it had acquired 670,300 common shares of the Miller-Wohl Company, or 5.2 percent of the total outstanding.

title: C.F.A. Unveils Plan for Telecasts
description: ABC and CBS would retain telecast rights for college football games next season under a contingency plan unveiled today at the opening of the annual meeting of the College Football Association.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, a light kindles in the long night of horror that El Salvador has lived in. No one, because I will not permit it, will say that this Government has violated the fundamental rights of my people.'' - President Jose Napoleon Duarte in his inaugural address.(3:1.)

title: Record Registration In California Reported
description: A record number of people have registered for California's upcoming Presidential primary, which is viewed as critical in selecting a Democratic nominee.

title: CLOSE-UP OF JOHN BELUSHI
description: Wired: The Short Life and Fast Times of

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CHINA TRADE The weekend stroller eager to walk through the city's past had best direct his footsteps to the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400).

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays , at Toronto. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) Tigers vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Detroit. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.)

title: TIGERS ROUT ORIOLES
description: Alan Trammell, Chet Lemon and Lance Parrish hit home runs to back the combined seven-hit pitching of Dan Petry and Doug Bair as the Detroit Tigers routed the Baltimore Orioles, 14-2, tonight.

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: UNC '84 Income Aided by Suit
description: UNC Resources Inc. told its shareholders that the $300 million that the company will receive in a settlement of a suit with the General Atomic Company will contribute $200 million to UNC's pretax income for 1984.

title: No Headline
description: $16 Million Awarded To Family in Accident

title: State Treasurer of Kentucky Indicted in Misconduct Case
description: State Treasurer Frances Jones Mills was accused today of theft by deception, misuse of state employees and official misconduct in a 25-count indictment by a Franklin County grand jury.

title: HBO MOVES UP SHOWING OF 'SAKHAROV' TO JUNE 20
description: Dealing with what its executives call both human rights and commercial considerations, Home Box Office has revised its schedule to present a made-for-television movie about the Soviet dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, on June 20.

title: Israeli General Censured In Deaths of Hijackers
description: Israel's Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Moshe Levy, has reprimanded the head of the army's southern command, Maj. Gen. Moshe Bar-Kochba, who was in overall charge of the area where two Arabs who had helped hijack a passenger bus were beaten to death by Israeli security men last month.

title: AS ALLIES RECALL D-DAY, RUSSIANS SAY IT WAS JUST A SIDESHOW TO THEIR WAR
description: As Western Allies prepare to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the D-day landings in Normandy, the Soviet Union is pressing a counteroffensive aimed at showing that the invasion was of relatively minor significance when compared with the Red Army's battles against the Germans and the Soviet drive to Berlin.

title: Downtown Deco' Tour
description: The Art Deco Society of New York will conduct a ''Downtown Deco'' walking tour today at 2 P.M. It starts at the old Custom House at the intersection of Broadway and Bowling Green, with stops at the Barclay- Vesey Telephone and Irving Trust buildings, the American Stock Exchange and other Ralph Walker designs. Admission is $5. Reservations: 758-9447.

title: 2 OF 6 ESCAPEES SNARED BY PHONE TAP
description: Lawmen, alerted by a telephone tap, rushed into a downtown coin laundry and convenience store today and captured two of the six inmates who staged a bomb hoax the night before to flee Virginia's ''escape-proof'' death row.

title: DOWN AT 'THE DUMP,' THE HEALING POWER OF ART
description: Six of New York's big white street sweepers have been to dance classes and, given an empty street, can glide gracefully - two by two, like ballroom dancers, their gutter brooms touching lightly - through spins and turns, serpentine movements, figure eights, crisscrosses and other steps.

title: Investors Named In Revlon Bid
description: Six individuals and two groups were identified yesterday as the investors who are preparing a revised leveraged buyout proposal to present, possibly as early as next week, to Revlon Inc., the large cosmetics and medical care company. The investors' request for ''unpublished financial information'' on Revlon, intended as a basis for a leveraged buyout, was rejected earlier this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JUNE 2, 1984
description: Markets

title: HOLDS IN NEW YORK CITY AND STATE
description: Unemployment rates in New York City and the state remained essentially unchanged last month, while the jobless rate in New Jersey dropped by more than a percentage point, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: LEGAL SERVICES OFFICIAL QUITS, CITING REAGAN AIDES
description: The director of the Legal Services Corporation's regional office in Philadelphia has resigned, protesting the way he and the legal aid program have been treated under President Reagan's appointees.

title: BETSY KING LEADS L.P.G.A. BY 2 SHOTS
description: Betsy King says she does not really mind being followed by only 10 to 20 fans, while Nancy Lopez, JoAnne Carner, Jan Stephenson and other big attractions on the L.P.G.A. tour draw hundreds and even thousands.

title: DUTCH CABINET DECIDES TO DELAY A DECISION ON DEPLOYING MISSILES
description: The Dutch Cabinet voted today to delay a decision on deploying cruise missiles in the Netherlands and to link any deployment to progress in the stalled Soviet-American arms talks.

title: GIVE AUNTS A DAY
description: Mother's Day is over; Father's day is yet to come. At this season, we are troubled by the knowledge that someone has been left out.

title: STUTTGART'S WITTY NEW ART CENTER
description: This city was much bombed during the war and was rebuilt in neo-Bauhaus haste afterward. Now it has an arresting art museum - at once monumental and witty - that spans past and present and peeks into the future.

title: MAN IS CHARGED IN THE STABBINGS OF 2 IN HARLEM
description: A 38-year-old man who the police said was angry because he had been given some cocaine that made him sick was arrested yesterday and charged with stabbing to death one man and wounding another in Harlem on Sunday.

title: LABORATORY AND CITY AGREE ON PLAN TO DELAY SHIPPING OF RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island would wait until the beginning of 1985 before shipping radioactive waste through New York City, under an agreement announced by city officials yesterday.

title: Seabrook Utility Will Issue Notes Rate Between 19% and 21%
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday won permission from the New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission to issue up to $135 million in short-term notes in an attempt to ease the credit problems caused by the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: THE REGION ; ;  YonkersAid Seen as Unlikely
description: The state will probably not give Yonkers the $21 million it needs to help close a budget gap, Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello said today.

title: JAZZ:HYMAN AND KELLAWAY
description: Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway, two pianists who are playing their fourth Michael's Pub engagement together, are musicians so thoroughly in tune with one another's musical thinking that there are moments in their dual performances when the inspiration seems to flow from a single mind. In their current three-week engagement, the emphasis is on ''honky tonk'' piano stylings.

The Office of Government Inventions and Patents in the Department of Commerce offered licenses this week on more than 100 federally owned inventions. A notice published in the Patent Official Gazette listed inventions of the Departments of Agriculture, Commerce, Health and Human Services, Air Force, Army and Interior, besides the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Security Agency and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: IF A UTILITY CUTS OFF SERVICE
description: THE woman, a lawyer, came

title: Work at Reactor May End Soon
description: The Consumers Power Company will end work on its Midland nuclear plant unless it reaches an agreement with opponents of the project within about two weeks, officials of the company said today.

title: U.S. TAKES OPTIMISTIC VIEW OF DUTCH MISSILE DECISION
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were only mildly disappointed by the Dutch Cabinet's decision to delay final action on the deployment of new United States missiles.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: SOME FEAR BALLOT WILL BEWILDER CALIFORNIA VOTERS
description: In union halls here, 128 supporters of Vice President Walter F. Mondale plan to spend much of this weekend on the telephone, not only urging union members to vote Tuesday for Mr. Mondale but also teaching them how to do it.

title: NEW ORLEANS FILES LIEN AGAINST FAIR
description: The city filed a lien against the world's fair today in a dispute over unpaid taxes, causing payments to be stopped on the fair's checks. However, a compromise was reached so the paychecks of the fair's workers would be good, according to fair officials.

title:
PATENTS;
 Wire Christmas Tree
description: An artificial Christmas tree of simple construction was patented this week for a Canadian company. According to patent 4,451,510, artificial trees now being made with the wire- wrap technique resemble natural trees to the point of confusion. Jean- Daniel Papst and another inventor assigned the patent to Barcana Ltd., a Quebec company, which is manufacturing the trees and selling them in the United States.

title: Hambro Life Tie To Charterhouse
description: A full financial merger between Hambro Life Assurance P.L.C. and Charterhouse J. Rothschild P.L.C. would likely be valued at less than the sum of its two parts and would not be in the best interests of shareholders, the companies said in a joint statement. The two are confident, however, that operational benefits can be achieved through joint initiatives based on the financial structure that already exists between them, they said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Proposal for Grand Central

title: A Po New Subway Cars
description: The Transit Authority took its 20 new Japanese subway cars out of service temporarily last night after a flaw in their circuitry caused some doors on one train to open without warning, transit officials said.

title: REAL-ESTATE REALITIES CLAIMING 'FARM' IN 'VILLAGE'
description: Its owner calls it Amos Farm, and the little garden at Hudson and West 10th Streets seems almost a mirage in Greenwich Village - a miniature estate, with a fountain at the center and its own snug red cottage.

title:
PATENTS;
 Training Dummy
description: A torso and head section of a human dummy have been invented in Switzerland for medical training purposes.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HOLLINGER ARGUS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
SATURDAY, JUNE 2, 1984 International
description: George P. Shultz flew to Nicaragua from El Salvador to confer with officials of the Sandinista Government, which the Reagan Administration has been trying to undercut. The Secretary of State met in private at the Managua airport with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of Nicaragua's governing junta, in a surprise trip that the White House said Mr. Shultz made at President Reagan's direction. (Page 1, Column 6.) Eden Pastora Gomez was flown to Venezuela aboard a hospital plane sent by Caracas after Costa Rican leaders asked him to leave their country. As he departed, the anti-Sandinista leader blamed the C.I.A. for an explosion Wednesday that killed several of his soldiers and two journalists and wounded him and more than 20 soldiers and journalists as he was holding a news conference just inside the Nicaraguan border. (3:4-6.)

title: 17th Bomb Discovery Leads to Midwest Alerts By The Associated Press
description: A janitor found a bomb in a Chicago building and a passerby spotted another explosive in downtown Milwaukee yesterday, bringing to 17 the number of homemade bombs discovered in three states in a week.

title: WHEN ICE CREAM WASN'T HAUTE
description: Standing in line for the privilege of purchasing a single scoop of ice cream for $1.60 on one of the few warm days we've had this spring, I thought of how the ice-cream business has changed since the days I cajoled my mother out of a penny to buy a lemon ice. Who knew about butterfat or cared about brand names? We bought whatever the corner drugstore sold or chased a Good Humor truck, if we were lucky enough to have one come into our neighborhood.

title: PANEL APPROVES THE RELEASE OF GENES ALTERED BY SCIENCE
description: The chief Federal advisory committee on gene- splicing policy today approved two proposals from biotechnology companies to conduct experiments that would release certain genetically modified organisms into the environment in strictly controlled field tests.

title: Ampex License
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Ampex Corporation announced that Ampex, based in Redwood City, Calif., had been granted licenses to use Matsushita's patents and technology to make a new generation of thin-film, high-density video recording tapes.

title: PISANI IS GUILTY ON 18 COUNTS, ACQUITTED OF 11
description: A Federal jury last night convicted State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of income-tax evasion and of embezzling money from his campaign funds and his law firm.

title: FANNIE MAES IN SMALL UNITS
description: backed securities to the small investor gets under way within the next 60 days or so with a pilot program involving their sale in increments as low as $1,000 by thrift institutions and banks.

title:
PATENTS;
IMPROVING YIELDS OF OIL WELLS
description: WASHINGTON A PROCESS that uses microorganisms to improve oil recovery from existing wells was patented this week for the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla. Donald O. Hitzman, a staff research associate in biotechnology, is the inventor.

title: METS FALL TO .500 AS CARDS GET 4 IN NINTH
description: The Mets' fans roared each time Dwight Gooden struck out a St. Louis batter, and they roared when Hubie Brooks singled to center field in the seventh inning, giving him a club record 24-game hitting streak.

title: A FIT BART CONNER IS READY FOR TIRALS
description: It wasn't until a few days ago, Bart Conner said, that the gymnastics rings began to look like Olympic rings once again and the pommel horse and parallel bars no longer were intimidating, as they can be when a gymnast thinks he is losing his grip. It's just a feeling, Conner added, but one that has convinced him his tribulations have ended, and not a day too soon, since the Olympic Trials began tonight.

title: PATENTS ; Synthetic Human Scent Repels Wild Animals
description: A means of repelling deer and similar animals is offered in patent 4,451,460.

title: SPARKMAN PRODUCING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
;  Eisenreich Out
description: Jim Eisenreich , the outfielder who has been sidelined most of his major- league career because of a nervous disorder, has played his last game for the Minnesota Twins, Manager Billy Gardner said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on May 5 of Glen H. Taylor, who was the running mate of Henry A. Wallace in the 1948 Presidential election, incorrecly stated the number of votes received by their Progressive Party ticket. It was more than 1.1 million.

title: ;  Charitable Appeal
description: Three service organizations in Portland, Ore., have asked Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association to give them the $250,000 fine he imposed on the Blazers for improper contact with two college stars.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
EAST-WEST 'SELF-INDULGENCE' IN IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT STARTS HIS TRIP TO EUROPE
description: President Reagan, arriving in the country of his ancestors for the start of his European trip, appealed today for universal recognition of ''the rights of individual liberty'' and for ''tolerance and reconciliation'' among Roman Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland.

title: CITY ESTIMATE BOARD URGES ADDING 1,500 TO THE POLICE FORCE
description: Seven members of the city's Board of Estimate yesterday proposed that 1,500 new police officers be hired next year, 500 more than Mayor Koch wants but 1,000 fewer than the City Council has proposed.

title: FIGURING THE TOTAL COST OF AUTOMOBILE RENTALS
description: Two budget-conscious beachgoers rented a car from the Olins Rent- a-Car outlet on West 76th Street in Manhattan one morning last week and drove off into the sun. They chose Olins, a medium-size rental chain, because its advertised rate of $29.95 included unlimited free mileage.

title: THE REGION ; ;  2 Drag-Racers Get Terms in Death
description: Two young men convicted of killing a woman while drag-racing in Levittown last year were sentenced today to either a year in jail or six months in jail and 600 hours of community service.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Rules Are Rules

title: BEDTIMES FOR BONZOS
description: Mrs. S. H. of Brooklyn is curious about President Reagan's sleeping accommodations. In a recent news conference at the White House, she writes, he was asked if Americans had ''any cause for concern'' about Soviet missile-carrying submarines lying off our coastlines. He replied:

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a charge of $562,000 for the quarter and 9 months for the closure of a plant.

title: When Does Workfare Work?
description: Should welfare recipients be required to work in order to qualify for their benefits? Of course, according to conservative credo. Well, yes, in some situations, according to liberal students of social programs.

title: M.T.A. IS URGED TO SEEK TALKS TO CHANGE MANAGER'S STATUS
description: The city's Transit Authority could accomplish its goal of removing all 5,000 supervisors from union jurisdiction without legislation in Albany, according to a report to Governor Cuomo released yesterday.

title: Article 232718 -- No Title
description: Carol Ripani, whose 2-year-old Doberman pinscher was stolen from her yard on Wednesday, paid a $1,000 ransom for the dog's safe return, the police said.

title: Kuwaitis Are Disputed By the U.S. on Missiles
description: A Kuwaiti official said today that the United States had given ''initial approval'' to the shiekdom's request to buy Stinger anitaircraft missiles, according to reports reaching here. But a spokesman for the Defense Department said no decision had been made on whether to sell the missiles to Kuwait.

title: Repelling the Moped Invasion
description: Block Island is a small, bald piece of real estate 12 miles off New England that was discovered by the Italians, charted by the Dutch and colonized by the English. For centuries it has been part of Rhode Island, but after June 5 it may be up for grabs. That's when the island's 620 year-round residents gather for a town meeting to vote on secession. Should the vote be yes and should the Rhode Island Legislature agree to let Block Island go, Connecticut and Massachusetts would be only too willing to take it in.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Late Bloomers

title: BELL SPLIT-UP A BOON TO JAPAN
description: The breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and other steps to deregulate the American telephone business have opened the market to competition, as they were intended. But the opportunities are proving just as inviting to foreign companies - notably the Japanese - as to American ones.

title: Rationing Coupons Shredded
description: The Energy Department is shredding 4.8 billion gasoline rationing coupons that were printed but never used in the Arab oil embargo a decade ago, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Exotic Animals Sold At Auction in Atlanta
description: Exotic animals, from llamas to lions, were put on the auction block today, drawing breeders, ranchers and game park operators from around the country. Protesters who charged the animals were being exploited also attended.

title: TEXT OF DUTCH STATEMENT ON DELAY IN DEPLOYING OF MISSILES
description: Following is a text of the Dutch Cabinet's statement today on the deployment of cruise missiles, as translated by Reuters:

title: CONNECTICUT IS DRYING OUT AS SWOLLEN RIVERS HIT CREST
description: The most severe flooding along the Connecticut River in almost half a century began cresting here today as other parts of Connecticut and the metropolitan area started to dry out after four days of heavy rain.

title: U.S. Arms Negotiator Offers To Resume Talks With Soviet
description: Paul H. Nitze, the chief American negotiator at the suspended talks on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe, said yesterday that the United States was ready to resume the talks at the first hint of a willingness on the part of the Soviet Union to do so.

title: Riggs-AP Bank
description: Riggs National Bank has completed its acquisition of AP Bank Ltd. of London from Norwich Union Life Insurance Society of Norwich, England, for $34.6 million, officials announced.

title: IN SURPRISE VISIT, SHULTZ HAS TALKS WITH NICARAGUANS
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel wounded by a bomb, was flown to Venezuela after Costa Rica asked him to leave. Page 3.

title: Striking British Miners Clash With the Police
description: Thousands of striking miners clashed with the police today outside a coking plant in Yorkshire, in the fourth consecutive day of violence in a coal strike that has lasted three months.

title: Nate Nelson, 52, Lead Singer With Platters for 2 Decades
description: Nate Nelson, a lead singer of the Platters for most of two decades, died of heart disease today, a day after his wife made a plea to his fans to find a heart for her ailing husband.

title: LEVITZ AND DALFORT IN MERGER TALKS
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation and the Dalfort Corporation announced yesterday that preliminary talks between the two concerns were under way on a possible merger. Under the transaction being discussed, a company controlled by Dalfort, and including members of Levitz's management, might acquire the Miami-based furniture retailer at a cost of about $273 million.

title: THE REGION ; ;  'Oldest' Whale Dies at Age 25
description: Alex, said to be the oldest whale ever held in captivity, died early today at Mystic Marinelife Aquarium after suffering from a number of ailments and ''plain old age,'' the aquarium announced.

title: Data Coding Unit
description: A new data coding system developed by Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation will hamper high-tech computer data thieves, a company spokesman said. With a price tag of about $1,300, the encoding device is about one-fifth the cost of one now being used by the United States Government and American companies to safeguard computer data, the spokesman said. It will be attractive to banks and other companies that need to protect numerous individual cash dispensers and terminals, he said.

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PLANE HITS RADIO POLE IN DENVER
description: A United Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner, taking off from Denver Thursday, struck a radio installation 15 feet off the ground when a sudden wind change robbed the plane of its ability to make a normal climb.

title: HOUSE MILITARY BILL SETS STAGE FOR A STRUGGLE WITH SENATE ON ARMS CONTROL
description: When the House approved a military budget bill with stern arms control provisions Thursday night, the Democratic-controlled body set up a contentious committee conference with the Senate later this year.

title: CBS RECORDS REPORTED NEAR MTV VIDEO PACT
description: Neither company would confirm or deny yesterday that such a accord was in the works. If completed, however, an exclusivity agreement would give MTV, already the dominant video-music channel, a virtually insurmountable edge in the growing business of airing music videos.

title: DeJohnette Quintet
description: The drummer Jack DeJohnette and his quintet, Special Edition, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note (475-8592), 131 West Third Street, at the Avenue of the Americas. Sets begin at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M. tonight, and at 10 P.M. and midnight tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, and a $5 cover and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Carter Nephew Surrenders
description: William Carter Spann, a nephew of former President Jimmy Carter, surrendered Thursday at the Butte County Jail, from which he had escaped Tuesday night.

description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKEFELLER OUTLAYS STIR WEST VIRGINIA CONCERN
description: In his 20 years in West Virginia, the question that Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th has learned to dislike the most is roughly this: Can a young aristocrat, heir to America's first billion-dollar industrial fortune, find success and fulfillment of purpose in the impoverished hills and hollows of Appalachia? And can he rise from it to national political prominence?

title: ACCORD MAY LEAD TO CHEAPER DRUGS
description: After months of negotiations, two feuding trade associations in the drug industry have endorsed compromise legislation that could double the number of cheaper generic drugs on the market over the next three to five years and cut the cost of many popular drugs in half or more.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Wednesday on Hawaii's appeal for a ruling upholding its land reform statute misidentified the court in which Laurence H. Tribe successfully argued the state's case. It was the United States Supreme Court.

description: Six thousand nurses went on strike today at nearly half the area's hospitals while supervisors and nonunion nurses handled emergency cases.

title: ;  McKay Is Retained
description: Hardly a year goes by, according to John McKay , that he doesn't criticize himself after the season and offer to resign as coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. And just as regularly, Hugh Culverhouse , the club's owner, tells him to stay on.

title: ABC MAY WIN TV SWEEPS
description: ABC won the Nielsen ratings sweeps in May thanks to strong performances by its made-for-television movies and mini-series. CBS and NBC finished a far second and third, respectively.

title: G.E. to Merge Its Cable Unit
description: The General Electric Company has agreed to merge its cable television subsidiary into the cable division of United Artists Communications Inc., the two companies announced. In return for the cable division, General Electric Cablevision Corporation, G.E. will receive $132 million in cash plus 37 percent of the merged company, the United Artists Cablesystems Corporation.

PARTS PURCHASING REFORM IS WORKING OUT, U.S. REPORTS

title: SCOUTING;

title: PERILING APARTMENT DWELLERS
description: Shortly after World War II, as a veteran and graduate student at Columbia University, I rented a small apartment in Hell's Kitchen, the only area of the city at a time of acute rental shortage that I could afford. Now, almost exactly 40 years later, although better situated on the economic ladder, I find myself facing the loss of an apartment on the Upper East Side that I have rented for the past 10 years. If I must leave this pleasant building, facing the East River, with a pretty but rather pathetic fountain playing in the center of its driveway (''Miami East'' one cab driver called it), I may be out on the street and there may not be, even in the upgraded western confines of Hell's Kitchen (now known as Clinton), any apartment within my means.

title: FONTENOT POUNDED AS YANKEES LOSE
description: The Yankees were reminded tonight of what it is like to do everything right. They saw booming home runs, dashing base running, sterling fielding and excellent pitching. They saw the other team, the Blue Jays, do all of this and beat them, 10-2.

title: MARK'S WORK WEARHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
MORE TESTING
description: In the wake of a drug testing program that resulted in suspensions to several players last season, the University of Georgia will begin testing its football players for alcohol abuse as well, Coach Vince Dooley said yesterday. Dooley admitted for the first time that several suspensions at Georgia last season were drug-related, ''marijuana, primarily.''

title: THE UPS AND DOWNS OF NO SMOKING
description: Federal commissions and boards are supposed to be autonomous, but as the events surrounding the zigs and zags over cigarettes on airplanes shows, the members of those panels are just as susceptible to staff advice and Congressional pressure as any other part of the Washington establishment.

title: DUARTE IS INAGURATED IN EL SALVADOR AND PROMISES TO CURB ABUSES
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte was inaugurated as President of El Salvador today.

description: Three Transit Authority police officers were arrested yesterday on an indictment charging them with manslaughter in the death of a 25- year-old Brooklyn man who prosecutors said had died after a police beating.

description: Gov. Joe Frank Harris now has a good chance of becoming the chairman of Georgia's delegation to the Democratic National Convention, the state party chairman, Bert Lance, said Thursday.

description: Dr. Fred V. Cahill Jr., professor emeritus of political science at North Carolina State University, died May 23 at Rex Hospital in Raleigh, N. C., after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Raleigh.

description: The writer of this dispatch covered the Allied landings in Normandy in 1944 for The New York Times and has been military correspondent for The Times since 1970.

description: The nation's unemployment rate, which dropped rapidly in 1983 and then remained unchanged in February, March and April, fell three-tenths of a point in May, to 7.4 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Cameras for Coast Courts
description: California's Judicial Council today approved the use of cameras and radio recording equipment in California courtrooms. The order limits coverage to one camera and one ''still'' photographer with not more than two cameras and four lenses. The courts would be covered on a pool basis.

title: Republic Air Pay Cuts End
description: Republic Airlines has failed to reach an agreement with three of its six unions that would have extended 15 percent wage concessions. The concessions expired yesterday.

title: HOWE WON'T RETURN UNTIL '85
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodger pitcher suspended a year by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for repeated dependency on cocaine, has settled his grievance against the punishment and agreed to miss the rest of the season. The settlement allows his return next year, as long as he does not again engage in drug use.

description: Howard K. Smith told students at Long Island University's 54th annual commencement yesterday that, although the United States remained imperfect, ''we have created the nearest thing to a meritocracy on earth.''

title: NRBQ at Bottom Line
description: The unpredictable rock band NRBQ will perform tonight at 9 and midnight at the Bottom Line (228- 7880), 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street. Jake and the Family Jewels will open the show. Tickets are $8.50.

title: CONSTRUCTION OUTLAYS UP 0.2%
description: Spending on new construction in the United States edged up just two- tenths of 1 percent in April, a much smaller gain than in the previous three months, the Commerce Department said today.

description: John McEnroe, upset by the court, the crowd and the photographers, was warned and penalized today before he defeated Mel Purcell, a fellow American, in the third round of the French Open tennis championships.
