The Senate subcommittee on the Constitution has scheduled for next week the first hearing on a proposed amendment that would designate English as the official language of the nation. The measure, lost thus far in the legislative hopper, has been fashioned as a postscript to the words of the Founding Fathers because some see a threat of bilingualism growing in the land.

These two players - Pavin, a rookie in his second PGA Tour event, and Purtzer, a veteran of 10 years on the tour - were tied for the lead in the Phoenix Open at that moment.

title: Tall Ships Parade Is Delayed
description: Poor weather forced cancellation of a parade of tall ships in Boston Harbor today, but officials said the Coast Guard has given permission to close the harbor Sunday for the event, weather permitting. Officials said about 20 ships, some traveling from as far as Germany, had managed to make the trip to Boston but about 40 more had not and some had to turn back because of bad weather.

title: COOKING
description: Perhaps the most eagerly awaited cookbook of the season is ''Chef Paul Prudhomme's Louisiana Kitchen,'' if only for the appearance of Mr. Prudhomme's recipe for blackened red fish, a specialty of his New Orleans restaurant, K-Paul's. Mr. Prudhomme is a good teacher as well as a good cook and although his book's color pictures are generally dull, there is one fine series of teaching illustrations for making roux, the flour and water mixture that is the basis of Louisiana cooking. The author defines Louisiana cooking by lumping together Creole, or New Orleans style, and Cajun, country home style, because, he says, there is so little difference in what is served in restaurants today. He describes how he derives such a variety of tastes from so few seasonings: ''I often call for the same combinations of vegetables, such as onions, celery and bell peppers, or onions, celery, bell peppers and garlic. The secret of getting different tastes from these same combinations is in the amount of each you use.'' And he says, ''Something else I like to do with these particular vegetables is to add a portion of them in the early stages of cooking and then add the rest later; when you do this, you achieve levels of taste and texture.'' Mr. Prudhomme's recipes - the now famous blackened red fish and sweet potato pecan pie, or New Orleans Bread Pudding with its remarkable lemon sauce - lure cooks into the kitchen, even if it's too hot to cook.

title: APARTMENT-STYLE LIFE IN THE COUNTRY

title: AFTER 86 YEARS, IT'S STILL JANE'S THAT BLESSES THE FLEETS
description: Early in 1897 a relatively obscure 32-year-old British writer on naval affairs named Frederick T. Jane sat down to put together an album of information describing nearly every armored fighting ship then afloat in the world's navies. He called the result ''Jane's All the World's Fighting Ships.'' Its title now shortened to ''Jane's Fighting Ships,'' the annual volume has become the leading reference book for people seeking to keep abreast of such strategic matters as the naval competition between the United States and the Soviet Union. Other authoritative military annuals followed Jane's first volume. Since January, professionals and amateurs have not had to wait a year to find out what the world's military establishments are up to. Jane's Defence Weekly, published in London but circulated widely, has been among the first to report such things as Iraq's use of mustard gas against Iran and the Soviet bombardment of Afghan guerrillas with liquid firebombs.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

description: Auction catalogues serve as important tools for people who buy and sell coins. They can also be collectibles and this will be dramatized on June 15, when key elements of the Lester Merkin library will be sold at public auction in New York.

title: DEMOCRATS MAY HAVE A LONG WAIT FOR UNITY
description: After a wearying week of coast-to-coast campaigning, the three Democratic Presidential candidates are awaiting a critical verdict on Tuesday from the voters of California, New Jersey, South Dakota, New Mexico and West Virginia. A strong run through this final round of primaries probably would seal the nomination for Walter F. Mondale. A weak performance could spark what Robert S. Strauss, the former party chairman, called a period of ''hand to hand combat'' for delegates all the way to the national convention in San Francisco next month.

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 3, 1984 International
description: President Reagan assailed Moscow in Galway, Ireland for mounting ''a strong and aggressive military machine that prohibits fundamental freedoms.'' In a speech at the University College at Galway, Mr. Reagan defended his policies on his second day in Ireland as protesters demonstrated nearby. He asserted that it was the Soviet Union, not the United States, that had refused to engage in talks to reduce the threat of nuclear arms. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: DIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA ELECTORATE POSES A CHALLENGE FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Californians, whose Presidential primary comes so late in the campaign that it is often an anticlimax, will have a real opportunity to help choose a Presidential nominee Tuesday.

title: VINTAGE GEDDA AND EARLY GERHARDT
description: The elegant Swedish tenor Nicolai Gedda is no longer a fixture at the Metropolitan, where he is a veteran of hundreds of performances over the past quarter century; nowadays his specialty in New York is to show up for Carnegie Hall concert performances of rare operas, in which he gives singing lessons to everyone within hearing. Mr. Gedda also holds the distinction of being the world's most-recorded tenor, and at 58 he shows no sign of ceding that title. His newest major project has been a large-scale survey of his homeland's art song literature, modeled on Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's comprehensive traversals of the German. These records are produced by the Swedish Bluebell label and distributed here by Polygram Special Imports. So far eight installments have appeared, and the most interesting is the latest, Bell 151, which concentrates on composers active in the early and mid- 19th century.

title: 3-HITTER BY DAVIS TOPS TIGERS
description: Storm Davis, supported by two-run upperdeck home runs from both Ken Singleton and Wayne Gross, pitched a three-hitter today as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Detroit Tigers and the pitcher Jack Morris, 5-0.

title: Laura Laughlin, T. W. J
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. Laughlin of Darien, Conn., and Fishers Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Bailey Laughlin, to Thomas West Johnson, a son of Mrs. Wynant D. Vanderpool Jr. of Washington and the late Stuart H. Johnson Jr. A September wedding is planned.

title: CHINA'S GROWING EXPORT: ITS WORKERS
description: When the Ethiopian Government wanted a 180-mile- long highway cut through rugged mountains, it looked to the Chinese after no one else would undertake it.

title: CONSERVATIVE HOLDS LEAD IN TEXAS SENATE PRIMARY
description: Representative Kent Hance, a folksy West Texas conservative Democrat who co-sponsored President Reagan's tax package, held a slim lead for the Democratic nomination to the Senate in a runoff primary in Texas tonight, but the outcome remained in doubt.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Berry , the former Montreal Canadien coach, has emerged as the likely successor to Lou Angotti as head coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins, but club officials declined to verify published reports that Berry has already accepted the job. . . . Len Matuszek, the Philadelphia Phillies' first baseman, turned in a record performance against the Chicago Cubs Friday night, but it didn't take much effort. All he did through nine innings in the field was pound his fist into his mitt as he became only the eighth first baseman in major league history to go through a full game without recording a putout. . . . Tug McGraw , the 39-year-old reliever, was placed on the Phillies' 21-day disabled list because of inflammation of the left shoulder. . . . Jerry Pate has withdrawn from the United States Open at Winged Foot June 14-17 because of continuing problems with a pinched nerve near his collarbone. . . . Hank Greenberg , the 73-year-old former Detroit Tiger slugger, and 46-year-old Willie McCovey , who did his slugging for the San Francisco Giants, have been named honorary captains for the American and National League teams in the 1984 All-Star Game in San Francisco July 10.

title: HISPANIC VOTERS ARE AT THE RIGHT TIME AND PLACE
description: ''The hands that historically have picked the lettuce in this country, and the hands that picked the cotton in this country, are the hands that can pick the next President of this country.'' With these words, Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico joined other Hispanic leaders almost a year ago in announcing a drive to make the ''Hispanic vote'' the pivotal vote in the 1984 Presidential elections. On Tuesday, they will have a chance to show how succesful they have been, at least in helping to choose the Democratic nominee. The Democratic candidates have been devoting much of their attention to two populous industrial states, California and New Jersey, that hold primary elections Tuesday. Voters in West Virginia, New Mexico and South Dakota also go the polls. In California, where 306 seats at the Democratic Convention will be at stake day after tomorrow, it appears that the ''Hispanic vote'' - if in fact there is a homogeneous Hispanic vote - could be especially important. Hispanic registered voters in the state may exceed 1.2 million, or more than 10 percent of the total number of registered voters. The proportion is expected to grow sharply in coming years as the young Hispanic population - median age 23, versus 31 for the statewide average - reaches voting age.

title: CALIFORNIANS WILL DECIDE TUESDAY ON LIMITING LEGISLATURE'S POWERS
description: California voters will be asked in the primary election Tuesday to decide whether the rules of the California Legislature are fair and whether the Legislature should have its fiscal wings clipped.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: This week's new music focus is on the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons'' concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, but smaller pockets of activity will also be generating performances of contemporary work. Sunday evening at 8, the Manhattan Composers' Cooperative, a new organization, plays music of Seletsky, Rothenberg, Crosswell, Hollister and others at St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village, while Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, the new music project called Musicians' Accord offers a mixture of 20th-century classics by Schoenberg, Varese and Debussy plus music by Kaminsky, Bouchard, Froom and Kassel.

title: THERE'S NOTHING RETIRING ABOUT JONATHAN MILLER
description: Without flinching, he calls Broadway a ''sewer.'' Working for Peter Hall at Britain's National Theater was like ''working for Nixon.'' Television has done ''a terrible disservice to literature.'' And, as for the movies, a forthcoming film based on a literary masterpiece, is ''a Thalidomide abortion.'' Acerbic as well as opinionated, Jonathan Miller has courted controversy as if she were a duchess. As a result - and partly by choice - he has endangered his own employability. In a career just short of 25 years, he has responded by becoming peripatetic, batting back and forth among the arts and between England and America. Against odds, he has maintained a position as a director of classics on stage, in opera houses and on television, and also as an author, lecturer and television host of the popular medical series, ''The Body in Question.''

title: SANTA FE FOLK ART, FUNNY AND FEROCIOUS
description: Wood carving has a long history in the American Southwest. Native metals and other resources were relatively scarce there, but clumps of cottonwood trees dotted the barren landscape. For centuries the soft, sturdy roots of the cottonwood trees provided raw material for local carvers. The Hopi and Navajo used the roots to make their kachina dolls, the small figures representing native American gods that were used for teaching religion. Learning from the Indians, the Spanish settlers worked the porous wood into santos - primitive religious images - for their homes and churches. Today's folk carvers still use cottonwood, but they no longer pick it from nearby river beds. The local supply has, not surprisingly, gotten pretty thin. Carvers now rely on commercial distributors.

title: JOHNSON'S LONDON THEN AND NOW
description: Most people's mental picture of Samuel Johnson is totally urban. They see him rolling majestically down Fleet Street on his way to preside over a circle of friends in a tavern or (less often) somebody's drawing room. In fact, he was country-bred and did not see London till he was 28; he always liked the countryside and in the last 20 years of his life (this year is the bicentenary of his death), after his pension from George III had released him from grinding poverty, he enjoyed an annual trip, his ''summer jaunt,'' which took him out of town for weeks, sometimes a couple of months, at a time. He also loved Oxford and had, I believe, at one time some thought of making his home there.

title: VHS RECORDERS WITH STEREO SOUND ARE ALMOST WITHIN EARSHOT
description: Shortly after the Civil War, Congress briefly considered a proposal to shut down the Patent Office because, according to the sponsors of the measure, everything that could possibly be invented already had been. This argument, however, could not be proved, and invention was officially allowed to continue. Which is just as well, for otherwise we might have had to make do without the telephone, electric lights, the radio, motion pictures, television, airplanes and automobiles, to name just a few relatively recent attainments of technology.

title: JOURNALISM SCHOOLS ARE LONG ON STUDENTS, SHORT ON RESPECT
description: When the nation's leading newspaper editors wanted to find out which journalism schools offered the best programs, they did what journalists often do - they took a poll. James W. Carey, the dean of the College of Communications at the University of Illinois, immediately went on the attack. Polls, he told the editors, are ''a dubious instrument through which to conduct our politics, our athletics or our moral life. I cannot imagine them an instrument for the evaluation or improvement of education.'' Polls are a staple of daily journalism, a source of information and analytical detail that newsgathering has embraced over the last 15 years. The attack by Dean Carey, who is a leading journalism educator, was typical of the tension that often characterizes relations between the people who practice journalism and the people who teach it. That tension is a key element in the new unrest over how journalism should be taught. In purely numerical terms, journalism education is a success. This academic year there were 75,000 undergraduate and graduate students in more than 80 programs, up from 15,000 two decades ago. The enrollment totals, however, can be misleading. Half the journalism students will go into public relations or advertising, and a quarter will drop out of communications work entirely. Of the students committed to journalism, there are substantial differences in needs and ambitions between those interested in broadcasting and those who want careers in print.

title: AN APOSTATE QUESTIONS MODERNIST PIETIES WITH GUSTO
description: Apostates are dangerous people. Having lived inside the fortress of a creed, they know where it is most vulnerable and can aim deadly blows at its softest spots. Even the most savage foreign enemy is easier to deal with than the renegade who speaks the defender's language and possesses a detailed map of his fortifications. George Rochberg is such a renegade, a composer who served his time as a respected soldier within the walls of Modernism but who deserted the citadel 20 years ago and has worked to undermine its dogmas ever since. His chief weapon in this effort has been his own purposely eclectic music, which sets out to make peace with the past and to contradict at every point the pseudoscientific systems on which most contemporary music is based. Not surprisingly, his later works have attracted automatic hostility from critics and fellow composers who set themselves up as defenders of the Modernist faith or one of its subcreeds, such as Serialism.

title: TRAVEL
description: LITERARY LANDSCAPES OF THE BRITISH ISLES. By David Daiches and John Flower. 288 pp. (Facts on File. $14.95.) Facts on File has also reissued ''Literary Landscapes of the British Isles,'' first published in 1979, ''a narrative atlas'' intended to show the effect of time and place on various British writers. The essays - on Chaucer, Shakespeare, Dr. Johnson, Dickens, Virginia Woolf, among others - are by David Daiches, and the maps - of, for example, Bront"e country, Hardy's Wessex and the travels of the Romantic Poets abroad - are by John Flower. Lovers of English literature will find the approach scholarly but fairly lively. Not all the writers are British. Friedrich Engels, on the condition of the English working class, is included. There is also a chapter on the Dublin of Yeats and Joyce. Dublin? The British Isles? Protest marches will surely be organized. No, it's fair enough. Ireland didn't acquire so much as dominion status until 1922. Yeats and Joyce were well formed by then.

title: THE SOUNDS OF THREE RUSSIANS
description: Prokofiev, Rachmaninoff and Shostakovich: three Russian composers whose lives followed three different courses after the upheavals of World War I and the 1917 revolution. Sergei Prokofiev left Russia during the war and lived in Paris from 1922 to the early Thirties, when he returned home to become an important figure in Soviet music. Sergei Rachmaninoff departed in the year of the revolution and spent the remainder of his life in the West, dying in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 1943. Dmitri Shostakovich stayed through all the artistic vicissitudes of the Soviet era, inevitably affected by them but maintaining his own, impressive musical voice.

title: A HEALTHY SPURT FOR THE MARKET
description: The United States trade deficit soared 18 percent in April to a record $12.2 billion. The figures pointed up the difference in the pace of recovery in the United States economy compared with the rest of the world. With the dollar maintaining its strength on the world market and interest rates increasing, imports are relatively cheap, so more goods are being imported than exported. That hurts such domestic industries as steel and clothing, which have been struggling against cheaper imports. Some analysts blame the Federal budget deficits for driving up interest rates, adding to the trade deficit, but others point out that the cheaper foreign goods hold inflation in check. The deficit has been widening since the recession ended in November 1982.

title: 'DISCIPLE' FINDS TEMPLE OF SUPERMARKET
description: WHEN I say that I have fallen in love with my local supermarket you must understand that for years I only set foot inside it under duress. It was a place, it seemed to me, for frazzled young mothers and fragile old widows, for the atavists who still did their own cooking, not for young professionals who worshiped raw fish and corned beef sandwiches.

title: NEW SERVICE PROPOSES TO MAKE PHONES THE SERVANTS OF USERS
description: Betty Johnson works for the telephone company, and she has always enjoyed her work, but that did not mean she always had to like its instrument.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: : The Sorcery of War

title: Milton Looks to Make Name In Breland's Long Shadow
description: MAYBE if Mark Breland did not exist, people would pay a lot of attention to Dennis Milton. Both are amateur boxers, but Breland is a world champion. Milton has won four national tournaments and four New York Golden Gloves championships. Breland, who lives in Brooklyn, has won five Gloves titles, more than anyone. Milton lives with his family in the Fordham section of the Bronx, perhaps the only neighborhood in the city where he is better known than Breland, ''the amateur boxer,'' Milton says, ''who everybody knows.''

title: Borzoi Captures World Title
description: In this ancient metropolis, a borzoi was proclaimed world champion last Sunday of the 53- nation Federation Cynologique Internationale.

title: A MUSIC MASTER TAKES FLIGHT
description: again - and he seems troubled. ''Do I smile?'' he asks. ''Flying airplanes is a serious business, isn't it?'' He grins.

title: SHERPA
description: The word conjures up images of a rugged, agile Tibetan guide leading adventuresome British climbers up the face of Mount Everest. In the world of modern economics, however, the term has taken on a more genteel meaning.

title: Ramapo Gains, Beating Montclair State, 14-7
description: Ramapo unleashed a 17-hit attack to score a 14-7 victory today over another New Jersey team, Montclair State, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III World Series.

title: THE MAKING OF A DECATHLON CHAMPION
description: Skip Rozin is a New York- based freelance writer. AIN BEATS at the lone figure forcing himself around the track. Rain and sweat soak his close- cropped Afro and his thick black mustache. He will run three laps around the 400-meter track, just fast enough to cause pain. He will allow himself exactly 10 minutes to recover; then he will do it again, and again and again.

title: THE ORDEAL
description: DR. MICHAEL H. PICARD, A SECond-year resident in internal medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston - tired-looking, slender, aiming to be both a cardiologist and a designer of public-health policy - talks about the discovery of the doctor's ultimate impotence in the face of death. ''Learning that we really do have a finite life span - coming to grips with that, for me, was very difficult.'' Dr. Kimberly Stearns, third-year resident in family practice at West Virginia University Medical Center in Morgantown - tall and athletic, long black hair parted in the middle, her face and arms alive with earnest expression - talks about exhaustion: ''When I was on call every other night, and I had six hours at home every two days to sleep, I was out of my mind.''

title: No Headline
description: House Approves Missiles With Strings Attached

title: THE WORLD ;
description: A Coal Strike Turns Violent

title: WHERE THE CHINESE GARDEN BLOOMS
description: A garden is a garden except in China, where it has been refined into an art form over more than 2,000 years. Western gardens, with their tidy rows of flowers or vegetables, hold little fascination for the Chinese. Grassy lawns are deemed best fit for grazing livestock, and spraying fountains disrupt the concept of water as a medium of tranquillity. A Chinese garden employs illusion and discovery to transform available space into a microcosm of the world, not merely as it is but as it should be.

title: MAKING PARTNER IN AMERICA'S LAW FIRMS
description: ONE of the things that most concerns young lawyers just entering the law firm world is their likelihood of making partner, especially since gossip has it that the major New York law firms are getting increasingly stingy with their partnership offers.

title: A TOUR OF OLD SHANGHAI
description: Travelers to China rarely regard Shanghai as one of the highlights of their trip: ''Too big, too busy, and too Westernized,'' is the usual refrain. ''It's not the real China,'' they say. But there are so many different Chinas, each one exceedingly real in its own distinctive way. Among the diverse attractions that Shanghai has to offer, four are outstanding: the art museum; numerous opera houses that specialize in South China opera; the zoo in Hsi Chiao Park, and the Shanghai Arts and Crafts Institute. The last two, alas, are infrequently visited by tourists. The Shanghai Museum of Art, centrally situated at 16 Yanan Road, is arguably the best in China. The primary reason is the extraordinary quality and diversity of the collections. Secondary reasons: objects are carefully presented, without clutter; rooms are well lighted (not common in China), and, although there is no guide book, many of the displays have English-language labels.

title: Correction
description: An article May 20 about the retail industry incorrectly described a recent merger.

title: PLANT TO OFFICES
description: The need for modern office space for small users in downtown Bloomfield, N.J., will be eased late this summer when work is completed on the conversion of a factory building where fire-extinguisher parts were once made.

title: WASTE DISCHARGE: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT
description: TRENTON THE vice chairman of the Assembly's Agriculture and Environment Committee, Stephen Adubato Jr., Democrat of Montclair, said last week that he would ask for an investigation into the reported failure of the state's Department of Environmental Protection to regulate pollution discharges into waterways and the ocean.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHER/PRINTER/CALLIGRAPHER'S WORK IN RETROSPECT
description: MADISON ROBERT HAAS is most often called a calligrapher, but that rather humble appellation gives no indication of the dash and spunk that imbue his art. Mr. Haas also is a photographer and a printer of fine limited-edition books.

title: No Headline
description: 52 Food Outlets Listed For Health Violations

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Samuel Todd
description: At about 2 A.M. on the first day of 1984, Samuel Todd disappeared without a trace. Mr. Todd, a 24-year-old student at Yale Divinity School, was attending a party at 271 Mulberry Street in Manhattan, his third party of the night, when he told his brother Adam that he had drunk too much and his head was spinning.

title: FOCUS ON A FUND
description: Naphtali Lavie, the Consul General of Israel in New York since 1981, will speak at a dinner-dance tonight in the Rye Town Hilton at 699 Westchester Avenue in Rye Brook. The fete will honor Andrew P. O'Rourke, the County Executive, and Zahava Burack, a civic leader from Harrison. Mr. O'Rourke and Mrs. Burack will receive the Tree of Life Humanitarian Award of the Jewish National Fund, the dinner's sponsor, for furthering Jewish-Christian relations.

title: FAERIE TALE THEATER
description: 'Thumbelina' and 'Beauty and the Beast' CBS/Fox Video 60 minutes each; $39.98 each

title: Parents Get Permission To Evict Their Son, 43
description: A jury took 10 minutes Friday to decide that a retired couple living on pension benefits had a right to evict their 43- year-old son.

title: PROSECUTORS SET SIGHTS ON THE KLAN
description: In most ways, the Ku Klux Klan is only a pale shadow of what it was in the 1920's and 1930's, when it was a political force to be reckoned with in the South. Businessmen and civic leaders in many small Southern communities are now openly hostile to the Klan, and have gone so far as to try to bar them from holding public marches, as the Chickasaw, Ala., City Council unsuccessfully attempted last year. ''The Klan is just plain bad for business,'' said Chicasaw Mayor J.C. Davis Jr.

title: MULTIPLE LISTINGS FOR MANHATTAN
description: When the founders of Citilist were doing research before setting up Manhattan's only multiple-listing service, they discovered that 72 percent of a residential broker's time is spent getting listings. Even so, they learned, no more than 10 to 15 percent of the listings are ever sold by the agency.

title:
DINING OUT;
A HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: SAWPIT has been a fixture in Port Chester for almost half a century and, judging from the last five years at least, surprisingly little has changed. The clientele is still composed largely of regular customers who make it their dining room away from home, coming in at least once a week, often with their families. The menu continues to list Italian steakhouse fare; and the prices, while not quite holding the old line, show only a modest increase compared with other restaurants that offer similar amenities.

title: A GUIDE TO THE NEW 'POINT AND SHOOT' MODELS
description: There is a new breed of cameras, popularly called ''point and shoot,'' which has taken the guesswork out of picture-taking. Most of them fit into the palm of a hand and are packed with ''intelligent'' electronics which automatically set lens openings and shutter speeds. They range in price from $50 to $500. Nearly every manufacturer is turning them out by the tens of thousands.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Tea and Crumpets And Markdowns
description: Behind the red doors at The Talbots along Route 22 in Scarsdale/Eastchester and in Chappaqua where Route 120 meets Route 117 there will be an open house Thursday through Sunday, with iced tea, lemonade, crumpets and cookies to herald the bathing suit season and the approach of the semiannual sale.

title: Susanne Reney Becomes Bride
description: At Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church in Chatham, Mass., yesterday Susanne Dolan Reney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Reney Jr. of Worcester and Dennis Port, Mass., was married to K. McNeill Taylor Jr. a son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Smithfield, N.C. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. Brendan Nally, assisted by the Rev. John L. Ryberg, a Baptist minister.

title: MUSIC: 'NEW VERTUOSITY'
description: In deciding to take ''A Broader View'' of ''The New Romanticism,'' the New York Philharmonic hasn't just added a few powerful modernists to its collection of midtown new-tonalists. It has also gone ''downtown'' with a laudable enthusiasm, offering two programs, one Friday night and one coming up on Tuesday, devoted to what it calls ''The New Virtuosity.'' This amounts to a minisurvey of American nonorchestral experimental music.

title: Jane Walker Is Bride Of Dean Craig Sperry
description: The marriage of Jane Inman Walker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Granville Walker of New Canaan, Conn., to Dean Craig Sperry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sperry of Middlebury, Vt., took place yesterday. The Rev. William Eddy performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: FREE-MARKET BELIEVER
description: ONE of George P. Shultz's first moves when he became Secretary of State in late June 1982 was to appoint W. Allen Wallis to a key position in the department. That should have been no surprise. The two economists had developed a fast friendship in the mid-50's, when Mr. Wallis, then dean of the Chicago Graduate School of Business, hired Mr. Shultz to be a professor of industrial relations.

title: Tottenville Girls Take P.S.A.L. Track Crown
description: Tottenville High School of Staten Island won the team title for the third time in the last four years yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League girls outdoor track and field championships.

title: Lawyer Wed To Miss Saul
description: The marriage of Sharon Elizabeth Saul, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. Francis Saul 2d of Chevy Chase, Md., to Peter Lanning Bain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. St. John Bain of Cincinnati, took place yesterday at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington. Msgr. W. Louis Quinn performed the ceremony.

title: THE PHILIPPINES' UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: MANILA IN the tropical heat outside the office of Northwest Placement Inc.,

title: RACEWAY SALE LINKED TO TAX DEBATE
description: THE fate of Roosevelt Raceway, which is up for sale, may be decided in the next month in an unusual forum - a Senate and House conference committee in Washington.

title: POLLUTION IN WELLS LAID TO HUNTINGTON
description: THE wrangling between the Towns of Huntington and Smithtown over culpability for contaminated private wells in the Fort Salonga area appears to be over, with two government agencies saying that responsibility now rests on Huntington's East Northport landfill.

title: THE ART OF THE MAYAS SLOWLY COMES TO LIGHT
description: The Rio Azul site in the remote Peten jungle of Guatemala, where the major discovery of an unlooted Mayan tomb was made on May 15, is currently the newsiest of what are now some 300 identified Mayan centers containing formal architecture. They occur all over Guatemala, southeastern Mexico, Belize, and parts of Honduras and El Salvador. And there appear to be hundreds of others, under mounds of earth and foliage, that will certainly yield works of esthetic interest.

title: FINES AND TRAINING ADD MUSCLE TO PITTSBURGH'S NEW LITTER LAW
description: Businesses, individuals and pigeon-feeders have begun to feel the wrath of city policemen and meter maids who are vigorously enforcing the city's anti-littering law.

title: MOBY-DICK IS ALIVE AND WELL IN A REST HOME ON CAPE COD
description: Martin Levin, who has edited 10 anthologies, is at work on his first novel.

title: ACROSS THE CENTURIES, MAYAN ARTISTRY EXPERTS ITS SPELL
description: From Albrecht D"urer, painter and engraver, to Alexander von Humboldt, universal scientist, and D. H. Lawrence, poet and novelist, the relics of pre-Columbian civilization have never ceased to fascinate the great spirits of the West.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: For Those Lost In Vietnam

title: RED KNOTS RETURN FOR ANNUAL FEAST
description: REEDS BEACH THERE may be no free lunch for most of the world, but not for a couple of hundred thousand shore birds that drop in each year at Reeds Beach, along the Delaware Bay shore of Cape May County.

title: COMPUTERS ADAPTED FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: WITH the help of a computer and a special keyboard with enlarged letters and recessed keys, Bassim Sayegh is learning how to type.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Pelham's own Joseph Russillo returns to New York this week from Toulouse, France, where his dance company is based, after an absence of 11 years. During those years, Mr. Russillo has become a leading modern-dance choreographer in France.

title: Coe Wins in 1,500 He says he is far from Olympic condition, but
description: Sebastian Coe was as fit as he needed to be yesterday as he won his first major 1,500-meter event of the season. Coe, an Olympic and world champion who has been battling a blood disorder, turned in a time of 3 minutes 43.11 seconds as he won the final of the Southern Counties Championships at London's Crystal Palace.

title: THE APPEAL OF ONE CANDIDATE
description: collar Passaic County city, the highlight of the Memorial Day weekend came and went before the holiday even began.

title: AMERICAN FARE, HISTORIC SETTING
description: ON balance, it probably makes more sense for the authentically historic George Washington Manor in Roslyn to be run by the people who own the Milleridge Inn in Jericho than for it to be turned into a Franco-Mexican restaurant serving pizza, as it was a few years ago. The Milleridge Inn style preserves the Colonial integrity, although in theme park fashion.

title: A Rematch Lingers On Mancini's Mind
description: It was the first thing he said when he got to the hospital. Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini wants a rematch.

title: GENERALS FACE TEST AGAINST THE BANDITS
description: The Generals, with a gaudy but deceiving 11-3 record, will find out how good they are Sunday when they play the Tampa Bay Bandits at Tampa Stadium. This will be the first of four tests for the Generals, who have stumbled and bumbled for the past three weeks, in a month when playoff berths will be determined.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''While the Reagans were not numbered amongst the famous tribes of Galway, you, as President of the United States, the adopted country of so many tribes, fittingly represent all of them.'' - Mayor Michael Leahy of the Borough of Galway. (1:6.)

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
JUNE ARTS JUBILEE
description: If it's June, it must be time for the annual June Arts Jubilee at the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts. The weekly Sunday festival through June 24 opens today at 1 P.M. with the customary potpourri of visual and performing arts, including a concert by the Training Orchestra, sessions of children's ''Art Happenings,'' an interpretive nature walk and dancing to Squeeky Clean, a rockabilly band. It all lasts through 6 P.M. at the center off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor and is free, but bring your own seating and picnic lunches. ART OUTDOORS

title: BIBLE IS CITED TO DEFEND BEATINGS AT CHURCH SCHOOL
description: Sheriff's deputies who raided a church-operated boarding school 40 miles south of here and charged school administrators with mistreating students say four young children cried with relief and hugged them after the school was closed. But, in interviews, many older boys have defended disciplinary practices at the school by quoting Scripture and giving testimonials about their salvation from what they said were lives of drugs and crime.

title: PASTORA DECLARES HE WON'T GIVE UP
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader who is recovering in a Caracas clinic from wounds received in a bomb attack, said today that he would never give up his struggle for democracy in Nicaragua.

title:
THE DEBT CRISIS: NOT ALL BLEAK;
NEW FUNDAMENTALS HAVE BOUGHT TIME
description: MUCH concern has been expressed over the past two years regarding the inability of some developing countries to service their debt. But there has been little emphasis on the changes in economic fundamentals that have occurred since the summer of 1982 - changes that have bought much- needed time to develop more sensible, and permanent, solutions than the frequent debt reschedulings that so dominate the news.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GOING SOLO AT AN EARLY AGE
description: A lot has been written about adults traveling with children, but what about children who travel alone? More and more are doing so, and with summer at hand their number is especially high.

title: Canter's Dream Comes True
description: Dan Canter is the first of the generation of young American-born soccer players who watched and idolized the Cosmos to play for the five-time champions of the North American Soccer League.

title: EUROPEAN INTELLECTUALS --
description: I am a young German woman who has been active in the peace movement against the deployment of American cruise and Pershing 2 missiles.

title: No Headline
description: Amy R. Miles Is Married

title: TRADITION BY THE SEA
description: When media meteorologists predict the weather for ''Boston, the Cape and the Islands,'' folks in Gloucester, Rockport, Essex and Manchester relax as if given a reprieve. They care about their weather, of course. But let the forecasters look south to Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket. Let Cape Ann - that 55- square-mile fist of land jutting eight miles into the Atlantic 40 miles north of Boston - keep its pleasant life secret.

title: THE BIG SLEEP
description: Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall, Martha Vickers, John Ridgely; directed by Howard Hawks, 1946 CBS/Fox Video 114 minutes. $49.98

title: NEW RULES ON WEST SIDE MAY ALTER MIX OF UNITS
description: Most of the discussion of the new zoning for the Upper West Side that the Board of Estimate approved on May 24 has focused on how it will affect the appearance of new buildings. The consensus is that buildings produced under the regulations will be shorter and bulkier than the typical postwar aprtments produced on the East Side.

title: THE NATION
description: South Pressured On Voting Rules

title: Growing With The Islanders
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SUMMER IS WONDERFUL-ISN'T IT?
description: MY friend Harriet called to tell me the good news about summer's arriving soon on Long Island. Harriet is a sun person, and just the thought of the season causes her skin to take on a gorgeous golden hue. She has been known to look at the calendar and become the color of toast.

title: 'GREAT BOOKS' WE NEVER FINISHED READING
description: Most readers at one time or another have felt guilty about not having been able to finish a book recognized as ''important.'' The Book Review asked a number of writers to tell of such experiences.

title: SPORTS
description: DUMMY HEADBaseball dominates this season's crop of sports books, as it does at this time every year. The springtime hope that bubbles up in the dugouts of perennial also-rans infects publishing houses as well - the yearning for a best seller is as hard to suppress as a Chicago Cub fan's dream of just one more National League pennant. This year's harvest comes from as close as Yankee Stadium and as far away as Tokyo.

title: Rookie Key to Jet Pass Rush
description: It was only a minicamp for rookies and free agents, but it yielded clues to the way the new Jets' defensive line could look.

title: STEALING ETERNAL LIFE
description: Gerald Jonas reviews science fiction for The New York Times Book Review. WELCOME, CHAOS

title: NEON SIGNS TAKE ON A FLASHY NEW LOOK
description: UNTIL a few years ago, the only neon signs in Old Saybrook were scattered vacancy signs at motels or beer signs at bars.

title: Credibility damage
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexander Heads Delegates
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander today was named chairman of Tennessee's 46-member delegation to the Republican National Convention. He said President Reagan was ahead of any possible Democatic Presidential nominee in the state.

title: IT'S NOT JUST GRAPES, IT'S IRISH BERRIES
description: QUAFFED any Tsingtao beer from China lately? What about Raffo, a brew imported from Italy? To answer yes is to have taken part in one of the latest chapters in the evolution of the Monarch Wine Company Inc., which has spent most of the half century since its founding in 1934, a year after Repeal, winning renown as the source of a more familiar drink: Manischewitz wine.

title: BURNING THE MIDNIGHT OIL
description: FOR lawyers who want to know

title: CONSUMER RATES

GARDENING ;
PROS AND CONS OF A COOL, WET SPRING
description: ONE would be hard-pressed to describe a normal spring for the Northeast. However, this has been an exceptionally cool and wet season, which has had an impact on the timetable of the garden and the modus operandi of the gardener.

title: EFFICIENCY DRIVE FOR PRISON GUARDS FAILED TO MEET GOALS, AUDIT SAYS
description: A State Corrections Department program designed to reduce overtime by prison guards and deploy them more efficiently has failed to meet its goals, according to a state audit.

title: LOCKED AND UNLOCKED DOORS
description: WHEN out from a book flutters a photograph of the brownstone in Brooklyn where I lived until I was 5, I feel very strange - as if struck by an idea of ghosts. I envision myself in the photograph, there outside the house my grandfather owned, as a little girl in a stiff organdy dress, unlocking the gate, climbing the stoop, peering into the hall.

title: IN CULTURE, THE COST DISEASE IS CONTAGIOUS
description: If you think the price of theater tickets has

title: THE GAIN IS MUTUAL IN FRESH AIR FUND
description: CALVIN COOKS was the only person in his family to attend college. The 23-year-old native of Manhattan's Harlem neighborhood says he owes much of that accomplishment to the Pfaff family of Stamford, who first welcomed him to their home 17 years ago as part of the Fresh Air Fund program.

title: Susan N. Blackstock Weds Edward F. Dugan Jr.
description: Susan N. Blackstock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Blackstock of Lowell, Mass., and Edward F. Dugan Jr., a son of Anna V. Dugan of River Edge, N.J., and the late Mr. Dugan, were married yesterday by the Rev. Gary P. Fertig at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: HONORING A MODERN DANCE PIONEER
description: Fifty years ago this summer, four strong-willed dance innovators converged on Bennington College in Bennington, Vt., for an historic undertaking. The four choreographers - Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, all Americans, and Hanya Holm, a disciple of the German modern dance pioneer Mary Wigman - belonged, to varying extents, in warring camps. But it was an important step toward alliance in a scattered, warily independent young art. New dances were created at Bennington that later became classics. And Bennington trained a generation of young practitioners who went out across the country and the world to create and teach modern dance.

title: K.G.B. Offers Prizes to Works Glorifying Soviet Intelligence
description: The Soviet Union's State Security Committee, apparently in an effort to improve its image, has offered prizes for the best books, motion pictures and television movies that deal with its internal security and foreign intelligence activities.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: A Shot at Preventing Chicken Pox

title: THE SEAFOOD IS THE FRESHEST
description: '' AN oldie and a goodie'' is how one reader recommended the Ocean Sea Grill in downtown Bridgeport. Old it is - its square, functional, Art Deco facade a reminder of Bridgeport's better days 50 years ago, when the restaurant first opened its doors. As for ''good,'' that is a relative matter. Seafood is always a test in Connecticut restaurants. At the Ocean Sea Grill the operative word is fresh and the preparation is essentially simple. Those are two giant pluses right from the start.

title: Data Bank; June 3, 1984

FIGHTING WORDS Cachinnation We know what to do at a square dance when the caller hollers ''Allemande left! Allemande right!'' But we didn't know how to spell it until we read how a youngster got it wrong in the National Spelling Bee. Perusing the list of words that stumped 149 of the 150 contestants, we found plenty we couldn't spell, or even define.
description: What should one do in a purga? Stay indoors. It's a bad snowstorm.

title: Thais Say Vietnamese Shell Cambodian Foes
description: Heavy fighting continued today in western Cambodia near the border with Thailand as Vietnamese troops shelled Cambodian guerrillas harassing their positions, Thai military officials reported.

title: European Intellectuals
description: John Vinocur's article ''Europe's Intellectuals and American Power'' (April 29) inspired a sense of

title: Miss Witter Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Virginia Ann Witter, a daughter of Susan R. Witter and William D. Witter, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Harrison Woods, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Woods of Stanley, N.Y. The Rev. Ann B. Jones performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: FEWER JERSEY STUDENTS FOUND USING MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL
description: The proportion of students in New Jersey high schools who say they use marijuana and alcohol regularly has dropped significantly in the last three years, according to a state study.

title: MONDALE AND HART RETURNING TO JERSEY
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart plan to visit New Jersey on Monday for their final round of campaigning before Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: DAIRY HOARDS 500 TONS OF ICE FOR THE SUMMER
description: Although it is springtime in this Buffalo suburb, there is still a huge reminder of winter in the backyard of the Kutter Cheese Factory on Route 5 - nearly 500 tons of ice.

title: Buying Fish In Freeport
description: I have been a customer of the St. Peter, in Freeport at the docks, for 10 years. I have bought from every fish market and every boat on the Nautical Mile and have been well served, in different ways, by both (''Fish Sales Embroil Freeport,'' May 6).

title: GIFTS AT THE GATE, A PIG IS LEFT
description: THERE is not much about last April 29 to preserve for

title: Vacation Reading
description: This selective list of paperbacks was chosen from the New & Noteworthy column since the Christmas issue of 1983. It includes autobiography, biography, letters, plays, novels, stories, diaries, memoirs, essays, history, social science and poetry.

title: Waterways Law And Asharoken Cove
description: In the article ''Sliver of Land is a Point of Contention'' (May 6), Mayor William H. Kelly reportedly stated that Henry Morgan had never asked the village to enforce the waterways ordinance in Coast Guard Cove. That is not true.

title: GULF TENSIONS RISE AS IRAN REJECTS U.N. CRITICISM
description: Iran and Iraq exchanged threats and insults today after the approval Friday of a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning air attacks on Gulf shipping.

title: REAGAN'S 'MAGIC' --
description: The tone of Steven Weisman's article is altogether too admiring. Instead, he should be alarmed at the ability of Mr. Reagan to ''distance'' himself from his actions.

title: Miss Hardin Wed To Peter Watkins
description: The marriage of Mary Welby Scott Hardin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hardin of Upperville, Va., and Peter Thornton Watkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. August Dorr Watkins of Middleburg, Va., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard T. C. Peard performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville.

title: EAST HARLEM STUDY SHOWS HUNGER WORSENS
description: Food emergencies'' are occurring with increased frequency in East Harlem because poor people have been taken off welfare rolls for administrative reasons, according to a study of hunger conducted by a private group.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; 'Drowned' Boy
description: For more than 20 minutes, 4-year- old Jimmy Tontlewicz lay submerged under the icy waters of Lake Michigan. He had fallen into the lake last Jan. 15 in Chicago in a sledding accident, and when he was pulled from the water ''there was no pulse and no breathing,'' Steve Baumgart, a paramedic, said at the time.

title: Blast Defeats Steamers To Lead Series by 2-1
description: Joe Fink scored three goals and Mike Stankovic added two to lead the Baltimore Blast to a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Steamers in the third game of the Major Indoor Soccer League championships.

title: Lebanese to Reopen 2 Beirut Crossings
description: The new coalition Government in Lebanon said today that it would reopen two crossings between West Beirut's Moslem and East Beirut's Christian sectors despite continuing warfare between rival militia forces.

title: JACK TEAGARDEN'S BRILLIANCE IS UNDIMMED BY TIME
description: It is, apparently, sheer concidence

title: WHERE HE LABORED, WHERE HE RELAXED
description: When Samuel Johnson first came to London in 1737, people started the day with a glass of ale or gin because the water was often too dangerous to drink. But within a few years tea drinking was the rage, adopted first by the upper classes and then by all of London. Johnson was by his own description a ''hardened and shameless tea drinker . . . whose kettle has scarcely time to cool, who with tea amuses the evening, with tea solaces the midnight, and with tea welcomes the morning.''

title: THE LITERARY PRESENT
description: Robert Atwan is a freelance writer and critic. PRIZE STORIES 1984

title: FROM OUR PREP SCHOOLS: THE GOOD NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Opposition At Odds Over Duarte
description: The Salvadoran rebel radio said today that President Jose Napoleon Duarte has ''demagogic plans'' and his tenure is unlikely to ease the nation's strife.

title: Miss Phipps Wed to W. L. Maguire Jr.
description: Martha Stone Phipps and Walter L. Maguire Jr. were married yesterday at the bride's home in Old Westbury, L.I., by the Rev. Thomas F. Pike, rector of Calvary-St. George's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: WHITE HOUSE IS AT THE MERCY OF EVENTS
description: HERBERT STEIN'S fine book, ''Presidential Economics,'' provides trenchant criticism of the economic policies followed by all the Presidents of our time, from the liberal policies of Democratic Presidents to the ''supply-side'' economics of today's conservative Republican incumbent, and even those practiced by Richard Nixon, whom he served as chief economic adviser.

CABLE TV NOTES;
GETTING ON THE MINI-SERIES BANDWAGON
description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on the cable TV scene.

title: Connors, Lendl and Mrs. Lloyd Advance
description: Ivan Lendl, bidding to win his first Grand Slam title, moved into the final 16 of the French Open tennis championships today with a 6-1, 7-5, 6-4 victory over Paul McNamee of Australia.

description: Yonkers Man Is Killed In a West Side Garage

title: SUMMER OFFERINGS: A DIVERSE RANGE

title: Kevin John Lally Wed To Nancy Joy Fellman
description: Nancy Joy Fellman and Kevin John Lally were married yesterday by the Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn.

title: REHABILITATION UNIT UPSETS NEIGHBORS
description: WHEN Camille Abbatecola with her 4-year-old son, Tommy, joined 23 other residents of Oakdale on a picket line outside Skills Unlimited Inc. recently, it marked a first for her and many of the other protestors. They had never picketed or protested anything before.

title: ; A WAR THAT MAKES POLITICS GO IN CIRCLES
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA AND FRANCE NEAR NUCLEAR ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China said today that France and China were close to agreement on a contract for the construction of a nuclear power plant in Canton and announced that the two countries had concluded accords designed to ease French investment in China.

title: GARDENING
description: Regular followers of Allen Lacy's garden columns in The Wall Street Journal will not be fooled by his prefatory disclaimer that ''this is not a practical book on horticulture.'' Those fans know what new readers will quickly discover - that Mr. Lacy cannot avoid imparting information, and in a most engaging manner at that.

title: Laid Back, at the Summit
description: If only there were a hidden agenda for the economic summit in London this week. The public agenda promises little more than another pledge to reduce trade barriers, and no action on limp growth, rising interest rates and the ''debt bomb'' in the third world.

title: Miss Sheehan Leads in L.P.G.A. by 9
description: Patty Sheehan rolled in a 30-foot eagle putt on the 18th green today to complete a record round of nine- under-par 63 and establish a nine-shot lead after three rounds of the 30th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship. This virtually assured the 27-year-old Miss Sheehan of becoming only the second player to win two consecutive L.P.G.A. Championships.

title: GIVING YOUNG PERFORMERS A SHOWCASE
description: MARIA was in a quandary an unusual quandary for someone ''6 1/2, but going on 7.''

title: POLISH TRADITION
description: From a speech by Prof. Thomas E. Bird, a language professor, at the recent Long Island Studies Conference held both at Queens College in Flushing and at the college's environmental studies center at Caumsett State Park:

title: Paterno on Lectern Television seemed to be the topic on everybody's lips at the College Football Association's three-day meeting in Dallas this weekend, but that's not what was on
description: Joe Paterno 's mind when he addressed the group yesterday. ''Although television is important and something we have to eventually solve,'' the Penn State coach said, ''it is more easily solved than some of the other problems we have out there.''

title: 'CARMMEN' A LA BORGE IN THE CIVIC CENTER
description: HARTFORD THE Connecticut Opera will return to the Hartford Civic Center on June 9 for a concert-style production of ''Carmen'' in the same coliseum where it has previously staged elaborate productions of ''A"ida,'' ''Hansel and Gretel'' and ''Turandot.''

title: POLAND'S COMMUNIST CHIEFS SEEK TO IMPROVE TIES TO WORKERS
description: Poland's Communist Party leaders opened a two-day meeting today that was intended to strengthen what they view as their inadequate links with the nation's workers.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PICTURES THAT REVEAL NATURE-OR DO THEY?
description: Although Gyorgy Kepes is undoubtedly a modern photographer, and though he has spent most of his working life in the United States, he is not a modern photographer in the American tradition. His artistic roots are in a Europe that no longer exists, and his work as a photographer is markedly different in style and technique, if not in significance, from the work of a Walker Evans or a Harry Callahan, two distinguished American photographers who were born within five years of him.

title: MEDLEY OF 'RETROSPECTIVES' AT THE THORPE
description: ''SPANNINGS,'' at Sparkill's Thorpe Intermedia, is a show to upset normal viewing routines, as the artists in it are each represented by selections spanning their careers - hence the title. A medley of miniature retrospectives is what this is and, depending on the age of the participant, they cover from one to almost five decades. The show - the last of the season at the Thorpe, which is in the Dominican Convent on Route 340 in Rockland County - remains on view through June 24.

title: NICARAGUA POLICY IS AFFIRMED BY U.S. AFTER SHULTZ TRIP
description: President Reagan will pursue his request for more military aid for Nicaraguan rebels even as he plans additional talks with the Nicaraguan Government, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: CASE OF RAPE TESTS PRIVACY LAW
description: ROBERT H. BOONE, news editor of The Manchester Journal Inquirer, said that he was ''not looking for a fight'' when he printed the name of a woman who testified last month that she had been raped.

title: OWNERS DONATING 'GIVEAWAY' LAND
description: LAND that is recognized today as part of a unique wilderness of ecological rarity was given away in the 1950's to people who sold a quota of encyclopedias or magazine subscriptions door-to-door. Because the bonuses were small lots, 20 by 100 feet, and were surrounded by thousands of acres of ''barren'' wilderness - unreachable by any road and worthless for development - the deeds were often filed away or left in drawers to be forgotten.

title: JAPAN HAS A LONG WAY TO GO TO REACH CENTER STAGE
description: TOKYO I T has become standard for Japanese political leaders to say that Japan should cast off its accustomed docility and assume a diplomatic role

title: THE WORLD;
description: Dealing With Arab Terrorism

title: MAILBAG
description: WHAT IS TRAGEDY?

title:
GARDENING ;
PROS AND CONS OF A COOL, WET SPRING
description: -pressed to describe a normal spring for the Northeast. However, this has been an exceptionally cool and wet season, which has had an impact on the timetable of the garden and the modus operandi of the gardener.

title: Jill Aber Marries
description: Jill Ellen Aber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Aber of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Harlan Hudesman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hudesman of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Stephen Goodman performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. The bride is a clinical audiologist in private practice with her father in Livingston and Montclair, N.J. Mr. Hudesman is executive vice president for sales and marketing of the Empire Shirt Trimming Company and the Aluma Form Corporation, both in Brooklyn. His father is president of the two concerns.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
COUNTY FAIR
description: YONKERS ''AT the county fair you show your wares,'' Virginia Parr was saying. ''You show your pigs, you show your pies. But in Westchester we don't have pigs and pies. We have chiropractors.''

title: P. J. Ratte, Executive, Married to Gail Doyle
description: Gail Cathleen Doyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Doyle of Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Pierre Jacques Ratte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Ratte of New York and Haverstraw, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas Gartland performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In ''A Bistro Lover's Choice'' (March 25) the Metro stop listed for Ty Coz is incorrect; the correct stop is Notre-Dame de Lorette on the No. 12 Line (Mairie d'Issy-Porte de la Chapelle).

title: Saturday Review to Be Sold To 10 Kansas City Investors
description: Ten Kansas City investors agreed Friday to buy the Saturday Review magazine from its publisher, Jeffrey Gluck, who also publishes The St. Louis Globe- Democrat.

title: OUTDOORS ; ; Tougher Controls Limiting P.C.B.'s
description: THE Food and Drug Administration's recent announcement that it will soon further restrict the allowable concentrations of polychlorinated biphenyls (P.C.B.'s) in fish and shellfish involved in interstate commerce has clearly ended any possibility that commercial harvesting of the Hudson River's striped bass will resume next year.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: NOW THAT DUARTE HAS POWER HIS FIRST TASK IS TO KEEP IT
description: When Jose Napoleon Duarte received the blue and white presidential sash from the head of the Legislative Assembly last week, it was a moment of personal triumph for himself and an historic one for his country. He was elected once before, in 1972, only to have the military prevent him from taking power. This time he became the first president in 52 years not to be hand picked by the armed forces.

title: LONGTIME PROSECUTOR IN CITY
description: Silvio J. Mollo, first assistant district attorney in Manhattan and formerly a Federal prosecutor in the city for more than three decades, died Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Kept Drone
description: An advanced drone aircraft that was recovered by the crew of a Soviet intelligence ship early last month was held for two days before being dismantled and dumped into the ocean, the United States Navy said Friday.

title: 55 FACTORY-BUILTS
description: The ''construction site'' for much of the work done on the homes going up in a Brewster, N.Y., development is miles away in Selingsgrove, Pa. The town is the location of Penn Lyon Homes, a company that manufactures prefabricated modular housing.

title: Kentuckian Firm in Plan For Uncommitted Bloc
description: Gov. Martha Layne Collins has turned down a request from Walter F. Mondale that she consider releasing Kentucky's uncommitted delegates.

title: THE REGION;
description: Bid to Raise Drinking Age Fails in Albany

title: IN ST.-LO, A MAJOR'S NAME SYMBOLIZES TIDES OF WAR
description: The writer of this dispatch covered the Allied landings in Normandy in 1944 for The New York Times and has been military correspondent for The Times since 1970.

title: THE UNRAVELING OF A 'BILLIONAIRE'
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN the Denver Gold scored two quick touchdowns against the Los Angeles Express in a pro game recently, J. William Oldenburg flew into a rage. ''He began beating on the walls of his private box, and his fury spilled outside as the quarter ended,'' The Denver Post reported. That vivid sports page account had Mr. Oldenburg stomping off to the Express's locker room shouting that heads would roll on the team he had acquired just a few months before.

title: Official and Parent Defend Little League
description: I was appalled by the innuendoes and falsehoods about the Little League in the May 6 Personally Speaking article by Ethel Bernard.

title: EVEN HITS CAN IMPROVE, DIRECTOR FINDS
description: WHEN you have a hit, you have a hit, and it would be understandable to simply let it be, rare as it is, and rest with the royalties.

title: Yorkshire
description: To the Editor:

title: SEARCH FOR 4 VIRGINIA FUGITIVES COVERS TWO STATES
description: Police hunted through a railyard of antique trains today for a fugitive believed to have abducted a cabdriver at gunpoint, while officers looked for three other death row fugitives over hundreds of square miles of North Carolina countryside.

title: DANCE: VISION OF HOME
description: Dance for its own sake is not a novel proposition anymore. In fact, it has become so familiar that one can recognize in simple physical movement a ''conversation'' between dancers. That takes a certain amount of choreographic and performing sophistication to bring off. But Anna Leo, Ron Lybeck and Nancy Nasworthy did just that in Miss Leo's ''Home, or Some Memories'' on Thursday at the SoHo Center for Visual Artists.

title: L.I. CASES OF AIDS REPORTED ON RISE
description: THE AIDS hot line at the State University of New York at Stony Brook has been in operation only three months, but the calls are confirming what health professionals on the Island have known for a long time - that the disease is not limited to homosexuals and intravenous drug users in the big cities.

title: August Wedding For Miss Kenny
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kenny 3d of Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Lee Kenny to Christopher Charles Burchfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Burchfield of Hopewell, N.J. The wedding is planned for August.

title: HOMOSEXUAL, A U.S. RESIDENT 19 YEARS, FACES DEPORTATION
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service will begin immediate deportation proceedings against a businessman who did not acknowledge his homosexuality when he was admitted to the United States in 1965, the director of the agency's local office says.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS SOVIET IN ADDRESS AT IRISH COLLEGE
description: President Reagan, defending his policies as protesters demonstrated nearby, assailed the Soviet Union today for mounting ''a strong and aggressive military machine that prohibits fundamental freedoms.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The composer and librettist Gian Carlo Menotti's original Festival of Two Worlds, in Spoleto, Italy, proved such a success that seven years ago a North American edition was created in Charleston, S. C. On Monday night at 9, ''Festival! Spoleto U.S.A.,'' a documentary compiled from the performing and visual arts events of last spring's festival, will receive an encore presentation on Channel 13's ''Great Performance'' series.

title: REFUGE FOR THE TRAVEL-WEARY
description: It would be entirely understandable in Tiznit, Morocco, but even in the middle of

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: As a graduate student of history at Oxford University I recently had the great fortune of touring Northumbria during spring vacation. Accompanying me on my travels were the informative articles on the region by R. W. Apple Jr. and Sheila Gruson, which were forwarded by my family in the United States.

title: MILWAUKEE'S 'SYLPHIDE' TAKES RISKS-AND SUCCEEDS
description: Last year, American Ballet Theater mounted a new staging, by Erik Bruhn, of ''La Sylphide,'' an August Bournonville ballet of 1836 that is not only one of the masterpieces of Denmark's greatest choreographer, but a major example of balletic Romanticism. That production has been offered again by Ballet Theater this season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Miss Coe Is Wed To Baird Gourlay
description: J. Michelle Coe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Griffin Coe of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Baird St. Clair Gourlay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Barron Gourlay of Lyme, Conn., and Waitsfield, Vt. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: THE GULF: WORRY, WORLD
description: The industrial world seems, somewhat dangerously, to be underestimating the potential crisis brewing in the Persian Gulf.

title: DIANA VREELAND: A BRAVURA STYLE
description: Nobody tells stories better than Diana Vreeland. Or, it should be added, with as much verve (a good old-fashioned word that the former editor in chief of Vogue used more than once in that magazine). Indeed, in ''D.V.,'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $15.95), her delightfully zany memoir in which she tells her life story to two silent listeners, Chris Hemphill and George Plimpton, we learn in only 196 pages that Mrs. Vreeland was, as she says, ''always where the action was.''

title: Headliners Temple of Cash
description: Movie fans who think ''Indiana Jones'' could not possibly have left a swash unbuckled or a cliff unhung should turn their attention to the accountants' ledgers. The whip- toting archeologist, a character created by Harrison Ford in the popular ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' is currently on view as the hero of ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.''

title: Philadelphia Police Raise Is Delayed by Panel
description: A board of three arbitrators today approved a pay increase of 8 percent in the second year of a two-year contract but no raise in the first year.

description: TUMBLING prices have sent both the stock

title: KEEPING WATCH ON WAVES
description: SCOTT RIEGEL, a self-proclaimed lifetime beach bum and a lifeguard for seven years, prefers the ocean in the wintertime. It is then, he said, that he can breathe in the crispness of sea air, without the smell of cocoa butter, and he can hear the sounds of the gulls, without the blare of radios.

title: U.S. TO DROP EXAM BIAS CHARGES AGAINST GEORGIA
description: In return for pledges that the state will do more to help students at three historically black schools in Georgia, Federal officials have agreed to drop charges that a statewide college graduation examination was racially biased.

title: GETTING EVEN FOR THE MUNICH MASSACRE
description: Ken Follett's most recent book is ''On Wings of Eagles.'' VENGEANCE

title: GALWAY'S MOOD FOR REAGAN SUBDUED
description: The thing you noticed today in Galway was the police - at least 1,400 of them, packed into a few square blocks at the center of a city that has a population of only 27,000 - a huge presence of men in blue trenchcoats.

title: CAROLINA INDUSTRIALIZATION: FACTORIES AMID FIELDS
description: -SALEM, N.C. - North Carolina is the nation's 10th largest state by population and one of the most industrialized in the South. Unlike most other large states, however, no single city dominates. Most of its factories are dispersed in rural areas and small towns, along with much of the state's population.

description: King Hussein's Delicate Balance

description: To the Editor:

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS RETRYING PISANI ON 10 OPEN CHARGES IS UNLIKELY
description: United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his office was unlikely to retry State Senator Joseph R. Pisani on 10 criminal counts that were left unresolved late Friday by a jury that convicted the legislator on charges of tax evasion and mail fraud.

title: Commission Urged In Garbage Problem
description: Hempstead Resource Recovery Center - a white elephant. Multi-Town - a $9 million fiasco. Oyster Bay Resource Recovery and Garbage Collection Plan running into fierce public opposition because of site location and possible contamination of underground water aquifers. Babylon - the dump grows skyward. Huntington - the landfill must shut down by 1986. Islip traveling in many directions, going nowhere. Hempstead trucking garbage to Goshen. Smithtown going it alone. Meanwhile the garbage flows on and on, and our politicians diddle - they turn their noses away.

title: FILM: LELOUCH'S 'EDITH AND MARCEL'
description: She was a singer from the streets who became the toast of all France. He was a prizefighter whose fists conquered all Europe and, briefly, all the world. They met, fell heedlessly, rapturously in love, joined their legends and, ultimately, became a movie, which is all-awful.

title: Dr. Sharon Kiely Married To Dr. Michael A. DeVita
description: Dr. Sharon Cabrina Kiely and Dr. Michael Anthony DeVita were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Monmouth, N.J., by Msgr. Robert T. Bulman.

title: MAILBAG
description: WHAT IS TRAGEDY?

title: PROSPECTS
description: Savings Aren't Enough

title: ROUGHING IT IN STYLE
description: The Adirondacks have long been a playground for the discreetly rich. There was a time when roughing it for the fortunate few simply meant traveling from a sumptuous Fifth Avenue setting to an equally sumptuous bucolic setting.

title: CONFUCIUS TAUGHT HERE
description: The passage of history is marked in some places by ruins, in others by legends,and in still others by the symbolic importance assigned to them by later generations. But there are a few - the Assisi of St. Francis and Benares in India are among them - whose very air seems suffused with the quiet force of time. The sleepy Shandong province city of Qufu (pronounced chu-FU) is such a place. Spent years set the mood of its streets like the summer haze that spreads across the flat plains of northern China.

title: BRENNER DEFEATS CARTER IN SHOT-PUT
description: Mike Conley of Arkansas became the second longest triple jumper in American history. Joaquim Cruz of Oregon and Brazil won the men's 1,500-meter run from Marcus O'Sullivan of Villanova and Ireland, with both running their fastest ever. Joetta Clark of Tennessee gained her fifth national title, and Randy Givens of Florida State won her third and fourth gold medals in two days.

title: BRIDGING THE GENERATIONS
description: HEN PROFESSIONAL arbiters of fashion speak, thousands of women listen. But, closer to home, what effect to these same doyennes of style have on their own daughters? How four New York women - all with high-visibility careers that allow them to have some influence on what American women wear - have been able to guide their daughters and at the same time give them enough freedom to develop individual styles illustrates the point.

title: FEWER HOUSEHOLDS FORMED, CENSUS REPORTS
description: Reversing a trend of the 1970's, the number of young Americans setting up housekeeping dropped last year, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: THE GENERAL VS. THE NETWORK
description: Arthur R. Miller is a professor at Harvard Law School and the host of the nationally syndicated television program ''Miller's Court.'' A MATTER OF HONOR

WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A TEACHER MOVES ON
description: The following article, by an English teacher who plans to leave Rye High School this month, was originally written for the school's newspaper, Garnet and Black.

title: JOURNEY TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD
description: There were only 100 yards to go but I could barely breathe. I could no longer feel my frozen toes and I thought my head would explode from the altitude-induced headache. It was becoming increasingly difficult to negotiate the steep, boulder-laden trail after the six and a half hours of strenuous trekking that had started at 4 that morning.

title: Eisenreich to Be Listed By the Twins as Retired
description: Officials of the Minnesota Twins said today that the outfielder Jim Eisenreich, who has been sidelined most of his major league career because of a nervous disorder, would be placed on the retired list.

title: U.N. CHIEF HEADING TO MIDEAST TODAY
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary General of the United Nations, is to leave on Sunday on a 10-day trip to the Middle East, hoping to fill what he called a ''diplomatic vacuum'' in the area.

title: JAIL BRACING FOR INFLUX OF PRISONERS
description: NASSAU COUNTY officials and the Legal Aid Society are in the midst of intensive talks to resolve their decade-old dispute concerning the problem of overcrowding at the Nassau County jail.

title: 4-DAY GREEK FESTIVAL
description: Souvlaki, gyros and bouzouki music are but a few of the treats promised at ''A Touch of Greece,'' a four-day festival of Greek food and music in Trenton, starting Thursday.

title: FASTER, HIGHER, STRONGER

title: Hero's Honor Wins In Smith Handicap
description: Mack Miller says he came within an inch of scratching Hero's Honor when the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday was switched from the grass to the dirt because the colt ''is strictly a grass horse.'' But he decided to run him anyway, and Hero's Honor rewarded that choice with a seven-length victory.

title: RETIREMENT: FACING THE UNKNOWN
description: '' I'LL have to do something, not for economic reasons, but to keep alive,'' he told a group of couples who, like himself, had recently retired.

description: Duvalier Quells Food Riots

title: Oklahoma State Tops Maine in World Series
description: Pete Incaviglia and Randy Whisler drove in three runs each as Oklahoma State overcame a 4-0 deficit and beat Maine tonight, 9-5, in the first-round of the College World Series.

title: TEACHERS LEARNING COMPUTER METHODS
description: A NEW certificate program at Pace University to train teachers in the use of computers and qualify them to teach computer use to their students will begin tomorrow.

title: Police Foil Attack in Ulster
description: The police said today that they had foiled a plan to stage a mortar attack on a British Army base in Northern Ireland. A police spokesman said a truck containing mortars and a launching device was intercepted on a road near the border with Northern Ireland. The spokesman said several men were arrested and the police believe the men planned to drive across the border and attack the British Army base at Middletown in County Armagh.

title: QUESTIONS STILL LINGER IN STOUFFER'S FIRE
description: THREE years ago, soon after J. Radley Herold had agreed to assist in the defense of Luis Marin in the Stouffer's arson and murder case, the White Plains lawyer decided he should explain to his family the ramifications of what would probably a complicated trial.

title: Anne Tod Morris Weds Timothy Beal
description: The marriage of Anne Tod Morris to Timothy Donovan Beal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Beal of Bristol, R.I., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Morris Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edward R. Danks of the Noroton (Conn.)

title: NATURE AND OUTDOORS
description: Being a small-game, back-stoop nature-watcher, I've been reading these four books while glassing the garden for bird and bug. They will take you from the minute (snow flea) to the massif, packing - and backpacking - much flora and fauna, geologica and ecologica, in between. If you like your Nature dry but colorful, read the Sierra Club guide to the ''Desert Southwest.'' If you like it wooded and wildflowered, read ''The Field Guide to U.S. National Forests.'' If you like it vast but handy, read ''A Guide to Observing Insect Lives.'' And if you'd just like a fairly quirky, soul-stirring sermon on what really matters in your own small geological speck in time, read ''The Complete Walker III.'' The author of ''Walker,'' Colin Fletcher, states that ''The way to see important things (is) to walk.'' Each book describes important natural things. Now start walking. DUMMY HEADTHE COMPLETE WALKER III: The Joys and Techniques of Hiking and Backpacking. Even as the technology for packing your back gets lighter, Colin Fletcher's classic how-to-walk book gets more Falstaffian. ''This bloated third edition,'' Mr. Fletcher says, is a 75 percent ''old-new book,'' indeed a ''genuine, organic revision.'' He's ''restruggled'' to bring everything up to date - ''prices, practices, even prejudices.'' He's resucceeded. Mr. Fletcher, who in his no-tech soul maintains that walking is a ''simple, delightful, intended-to-be-liberating-from-the-straight-line-coordinates-of-civilizationpastime,'' finds himself in something of a peeve about ''the wilderness industry'' which has recently undergone both capitalism

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE APATHETIC DON'T DESERVE TO VOTE
description: AS THE late, great Will Rogers said: ''I don't belong to any organized political party. I'm a Democrat.''

title: WORTHY PROVING TO BE CELTICS' NEMESIS
description: No, James Worthy says, he did not hear the ghost of Fred Brown chuckling over the din of the Boston Garden crowd when his lazy cross-court pass was stolen and converted into the tying basket by the Celtics' Gerald Henderson in the final moments of the game Thursday night.

title: NONESUCH RETURNS TO NEW YORK
