description: Another transcontinental move is ahead for Nonesuch Records, back to New York once more. But the move means more than just a change of venue, for the man who has headed the label since it moved to California from New York several years ago, Keith Holzman, will no longer be the guiding light.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SINCE last year's Sag Harbor Cup Suffolk's race against drug abuse - raised more than $22,000 for the county's drug abuse services, this year's activities on Saturday have been expanded with an eye toward doubling the take.

title: PRIMARIES: ITS ALL OVER BUT THE VOTING
description: TRENTON THE Democratic Presidential primary may be the most closely watched race nationally, but it is not the only one in which New Jersey voters will be casting ballots on Tuesday.

title: TOMORROW'S PROGRAMMING-BUSINESS AS USUAL?
description: With the timeless grandeur of the Canadian Rockies providing nearby perspective, the Banff Television Festival has been developing into a singularly impressive programming competition. Set in the vicinity of Alberta's Banff National Park, some 150 miles north of Calgary, the festival concluded its fifth annual gathering last weekend. There was the usual flourish of awards - called, of course, the Rockies - for assorted programs, this year culled from 375 entries submitted by 21 countries. While the programs reflected something of the overall quality of the past year, seminars throughout the week grappled with the future, including areas such as marketing and distribution. As always, the tenuous and often strained relations between commerce and art became readily apparent.

title: No Headline
description: California Elder Voted Head of Presbyterians

title: MONDALE CAMP: LATE-NIGHT PLANNING
description: Walter F. Mondale decided Monday to make two additional campaign stops in New Jersey the next day before flying off to California.

title: NICARAGUA CALLS TALKS 'FRANK AND CONSTRUCTIVE'
description: The Nicaraguan Government has described the meeting between Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the junta coordinator, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Managua on Friday as ''frank and constructive.'' But it suggested the United States show its good will by altering its policies in Central America.

title: IN SCARSDALE, SPECIAL PATROLMEN FIND REWARDS AS VOLUNTEERS
description: IT is Friday and a full moon hangs over Scarsdale. The shoppers and commuters have

title: Susan Papst Wed To D. P. Bowman
description: Susan Jean Papst, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Papst of Columbus, Ga., and David Parker Bowman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Bowman of Southbury, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Douglas J. Wigner Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn.

title: Strawberry Determined to End Slump Opposing pitchers have been messing with Darryl Strawberry's batting production, but he doesn't want a flood of suggestions about how he could thwart their success against him. Suggestions could lead to thinking, and thinking could get a fellow into even worse trouble.
description: ''I don't want to be thinking instead of doing,'' Strawberry said before the Mets tried to end their longest losing streak of the season last night against St. Louis. ''Whenever you're in the situation where you're thinking too much, it confuses your mind. The game's tough enough not to let my mind get confused.''

title: THE GULF: PERHAPS A CHARADE
description: The clashes in the Persian Gulf may amount to nothing more than an international game of charades. The attacks, first by Iraq and then by Iran, on oil tankers and cargo ships are not convincing. This does not look like an all-out attempt to close off the flow of oil from the Gulf.

title: THE PROPER CARE OF SEPTIC TANKS
description: ALTHOUGH most urban homes and many suburban homes have long since been connected up to a municipal sewage disposal system, there are still a great many suburban and rural homeowners who will have to depend on their own private sewage disposal systems for many years to come - usually a septic tank that is connected to a drainage field or seepage pit of some kind. A well-designed system will last almost indefinitely if properly maintained, but if it is neglected for too long a time, it can back up and clog the drainage field, calling for an expensive excavation and replacement of drain pipes that could cost thousands of dollars.

title: Dana Cook, Therapist, Marries Andrew Stone
description: Dana Lynn Cook, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Cook of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., and Andrew Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stone of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: 'LITTLE FOXES' STAGED POWERFULLY
description: LILLIAN HELLMAN's well crafted melodrama, ''The Little Foxes,'' is one of the stalwarts of the American stage. It opened on Broadway 45 years ago with Tallulah Bankhead triumphant in the role of Regina Giddens.

title: Cornelia McLane Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Cornelia Gibb McLane, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. McLane of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to William Wulfhorst Burchfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Burchfield of Hopewell, N.J. The Rev. Calvin C. Adams performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: Under this heading
description: The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE PRIMARIES
description: At the end of the Presidential primary elections - the spring training and exhibition season of politics - some things are obvious:

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: Cart Dana Rex Mays 200, at Milwaukee. (Television - ESPN 2:50 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Mike Torrez, making his seventh start, is still trying to win his first game. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. Phil Niekro goes after his eighth victory. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.)

title: OPERAS: MOZART'S 2D AND VERDI'S 4TH
description: George Jellinek is host of the syndicated radio program ''The Vocal Scene.''

title: CON EDISON TESTS A PRUNING-BATTLE TACTIC
description: AT times it seems that the county is filled with tree-worshiping Druids. Early one morning last month, Jeannie Triol, forester for Alpine Tree Care Inc., drilled six holes in a tree on LaSalle Drive in Yonkers. Suddenly a woman dressed in a bathrobe and carrying a 7-month-old baby rushed from her house. ''You're not going to chop down my tree?'' she demanded, pointing to a maple that was clearly outside her property.

title: EX-MINISTER, FACING PRISON, 'AT PEACE'
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y. AS THE first trial of antinuclear protesters on Federal charges of sabotage wound up its second week here, a former Montclair minister who is a defendant said he was ''at peace'' with the possibility that he might go to prison for as long as 25 years.

title: EPHANIE'S GHOST
description: Alice Hoffman's most recent novel is ''White Horses.'' THE WOMAN WHO OWNED THE SHADOWS

title: HERE COMES THE NEW EQUIPMENT
description: The doors open this morning on what may well prove to be the greatest trade fair eve held in the field of electronics. The Consumer Electronics Show - CES for short - held in Chicago each June has long been the main forum for parading the latest advances in audio, video and home computers. But with the balmy climate of an economic upswing and with new technologies sproutng like dandelions, this year promises to be something special. More than 90,000 eager members of the trade and the press are expected to jam McCormick Place, Chicago's lakeside exhibition center, and overflow into every square inch of available hotel space in the Loop and along the Gold Coast.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: Some New Rows to Hoe

title: SHOULD PESTICIDE USE BE MORE STRICTLY REGULATED? ; LET'S NOT REPEAT MISTAKES WE NOW REGRET
description: CAVALIER attitudes toward pesticide use in New Jersey and throughout the country bear a frightening resemblance to the slipshod mentalities held not too long ago concerning hazardous waste. We have since come to realize the terrible environmental mistakes that were made as a result of mismanagement and poor planning in that arena.

title: Gerald Alan Blackburn Marries Susan Hodge
description: Susan Adams Hodge, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gameel Byron Hodge of Spartanburg, S.C., was married there yesterday to Gerald Alan Blackburn, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Nobles Blackburn of Houston. The Rev. Henry Causey Barton, assisted by Dr. Blackburn, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS RETTON LEADS GYMNASTICS TEAM
description: The familiar sound of the Olympic theme filled the Coliseum here as eight American women entered for a curtain call, waving to the crowd as they marched to the center of the arena floor. Dianne Durham, who probably would have been among them, sat on a folding chair instead, her left leg propped and covered with ice, her face in her hands. The theme had become her Olympic dirge.

title: Corrections
description: In the issue of May 13, in And Bear in Mind, the publisher of Kristin Luker's ''Abortion and the Politics of Motherhood'' was given incorrectly. The University of California Press published the book.

title: STANDING TALL ON FIRST
description: Nearing completion at the corner of First Avenue and East 68th Street is an 11-story apartment house that replaces a five-story commercial and residential structure destroyed by fire two years ago.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Some real film surprises continue to pop up on cable, like ''The Wedding Party'' (1969). Remember it? Nobody does - except perhaps Brian De Palma, who co-wrote, directed and produced, Jill Clayburgh and Charles Pfluger (as bride and groom) and, billed 10th, a lad named Robert De Niro.

title: TRADERS WELCOME PRICE RISE
description: The Treasury note and bond market flirted with yields as high as 14 percent before a sharp rally late last week raised prices and reduced yields to about 13 1/2 percent for issues due in more than five years.

title: Party Will Not Disavow Jackson, Chairman Says
description: Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today he did not believe the party would disavow the Rev. Jesse Jackson despite a warning that failure to do so could cost the party Jewish votes in the Presidential election.

title: FROM ASHES OF TRAGEDY, SELF-HELP GROUPS
description: Each of them has suffered personal tragedy, each losing a child under violent circumstances. Out of their individual grief, their desire for vengeance or their need to take action, these four women, mothers, have created organizations designed to help others whose lives have been similarly struck by trauma.

title: Spahn, Sain and No Rain
description: Warren Spahn and Johnny Sain, the pitching mainstays for the 1948 Boston Braves, pitched two shutout innings each to help the National League defeat the American League, 7-0, in an old-timers' game Saturday night in the Superdome.

title: Czech Press Says Russians Could Have Won War on Own
description: A weekly published by the Czech Communist Party says the Soviet Union could have defeated Nazi Germany alone, the official Czech press agency reported today. The agency reported on an article in the weekly Tribuna that suggests the final Western drive on the European front was launched only after it became clear Germany would lose World War II.

title: Cubs 11, Phillies 2
description: Bob Dernier knocked in the winning run with a fifth-inning single and Chicago used four runs in both the eighth and ninth innings to rout Philadelphia.

title: 150 Stricken in Jersey After School Banquet
description: About 150 Hoboken High School athletes, cheerleaders and coaches suffered food poisoning after a sports awards banquet and more than a dozen remained hospitalized today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Liggett Chief Sees Gains After Buyout

title: FAIR FIELD, NO FAVOR
description: Only a month ago, auto executives were being castigated for giving themselves ''obscene bonuses'' in an industry that was being partly protected from Japanese competition.

title: Demurrer From Brooklyn
description: ''A more economically and technologically powerful Peking will only make this Communist power a formidable foe of ours in the 21st century and a greater threat to our allies on Taiwan,'' reads part of a resolution critical of President Reagan's reaching out to China.

title: Debt Problem Downplayed
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the world debt problem had been blown out of proportion and had caused exaggerated concerns about the health of many United States banks.

title: Abrahams Joining Dutton
description: William Abrahams will join E.P. Dutton July 1 as senior editor (West Coast) and editor of William Abrahams Book. Mr. Abrahams is currently a senior editor at Holt, Rinehart & Winston, where since 1982 he has had his own imprint. He is the author of several books, including two about George Orwell, and he is writing a biography of Lillian Hellman. The first Dutton book under the Abrahams imprint will be ''Solstice'' by Joyce Carol Oates, to be published next January.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUBA EVER ALERT FOR 'ENEMY'
description: After 25 years of Communist rule, this city, which was once one of the liveliest capitals in the Caribbean, has become subdued, orderly and distinctly faded.

title: No Headline
description: -E-A What makes an alliance? Forty years ago, on the eve of D-Day, the question was easier to answer. With Europe ruled by a wholly evil empire, necessity helped forge what Churchill called ''the Grand Alliance.'' A common enemy brought the Western democracies and the Soviet Union together for the specific purpose of defeating Hitler.

title: BONN SHARPENS ITS CRITICISM OF DUTCH ON NATO MISSILES
description: The West German Government today sharpened its criticism of a Dutch move to delay a decision on deploying cruise missiles.

title: ;  Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer New Forecast For Economy
description: WASHINGTON T HE Reagan Administration's economists and

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: NORMAN COASTS TO KEMPER OPEN VICTORY
description: Greg Norman's lead was never challenged today as he scored a five- stroke victory in the Kemper Open, his first triumph on the PGA Tour.

title: ALLEN PLANS YEAR-ROUND JAZZ PLAYING
description: The New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra, a jazz septet led by the clarinetist Woody Allen, is now in its 13th year at Michael's Pub in what may be the longest-running jazz gig in town. For most of those years, Mr. Allen has torn himself away from writing, acting and directing to be at the band's Monday-night-only sessions for nine months each year. From now on, however, he intends to be there year-round.

title: Prost Captures Rain-Cut Prix
description: Alain Prost of France scored his third Formula One auto victory of the season today, winning a bizarre Monaco Grand Prix that was halted after an hour because of dangerous conditions caused by rain.

title: Ramapo Captures National Title, 5-4
description: Jim Buntzen and John Spazante hurled Ramapo College of New Jersey to a 5-4 victory over Marietta for the national Division III baseball title today.

title: Avis Navarro Marries Paul Aaronson
description: The marriage of Avis Hedges Navarro, an assistant vice president of the Bank of Boston International in New York, to Paul Richard Aaronson, an associate with the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, took place yesterday. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the Center for Inter-American Relations in Manhattan.

title: YOUNG MINDS UNREADY TO BE PUSHED AHEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: ILLINOIS 'LONE RANGERS' VIE FOR SENATE
description: It was the top of the third inning at Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs were playing the Cincinnati Reds, and Senator Charles H. Percy was shaking hands with fans walking through the turnstiles when an announcement was made over the public address system that the White House was trying to reach him.

title: AFTER PACKING WHILE PLAYING, CIRCUS QUIETLY LEAVES TOWN
description: The clowns drove around the arena in a bright red firehouse on wheels, flopping their oversized shoes, grinning their oversized smiles and drawing choruses of laughter from the Madison Square Garden crowd.

title: FACTS? LET THEM EAT DOCUDRAMA
description: As members of President Reagan's Cabinet leave office, they currently can impose greater secrecy on some of their Government papers than will be available to Mr. Reagan when he departs the White House.

title: COSTS OF PREVENTING NEONATAL HERPES
description: Genital herpes transmitted to infants during childbirth kills one-third of them and causes retardation in another third, but the cost of preventing such transmission is high both in risk to mother and child and in dollars, medical researchers say.

title: IRAQ JET ATTACKS TURKISH TANKER IN PERSIAN GULF
description: Iraq attacked and hit a Turkish oil tanker today 50 miles south of the Iranian oil export terminal at Kharg Island. Fire engulfed the vessel and forced the crew to abandon ship, according to the official Iranian press agency.

title: No Headline
description: 2 New Home Computers Planned

title: Market Place; Summer Hope, Election Effect
description: A RE better days ahead for the stock market this month? One thing is certain: stock prices got off to a roaring start on Friday, the opening session of the month. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 19.50 points, the best daily increase in more than six weeks.

title: Grace Annette Dupre,Portrait Painter, Dies
description: Grace Annette Dupre, an artist noted for her portraits of prominent Americans, died Saturday in a nursing home in her native Spartanburg, S.C., after a long illness. Miss Dupre, a former resident of New York City, was 90 years old.

title: CAMPAIGN TACTICS FOCUS OF DEBATE AS PRIMARIES NEAR
description: In the final debate of the Presidential primary season, Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart last night continued their pattern of criticizing President Reagan's policies but reserved their strongest denunciations for each other.

title: NO TRUE CHAMPION IN BELMONT
description: More divisional champions have won the Belmont Stakes than the Kentucky Derby or the Preakness. This year, however, ''The Test of the Champion,'' as Belmont bills the race, seems more a test of whether any of these 3-year-olds are even of championship caliber.

title: DANCE: GROUP FROM INDIA
description: -drama was developed during the 16th century in the state of Kerala, on the southwest coast of India. But time and space were bridged on Saturday night at Asia Society when 17 Kathakali performers from the Kerala Kalamandalam presented an unforgettably immediate evening of theater.

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC HORIZONS '84, Avery Fisher Hall, What's the Score? - Meet the Composers, 6:45; concert: American Composers Orchestra, Charles Wuorinen, conductor, 8. FRANK SINATRA with BUDDY RICH AND BAND, Carnegie Hall, 8.

title: SAFETY, COMFORT AND CONVENIENCE; Signs of Progress
description: The signs on New York City lampposts that give the latitude, say, 29th Street, and longitude, say, Fourth Avenue, are starting to bloom again after many blighted seasons. The Department of Transportation managed to install 11,200 street signs in 1983, up from 7,500 in 1982 and 0 in 1981.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1984 International
description: The Indian Army began patrolling the violence-torn state of Punjab in an attempt to quell the two-year-old terrorist campaign by radical Sikhs demanding greater autonomy. The army took control of the security of the state on Saturday. Train and bus services were suspended, all traffic, even bicycles and animal-drawn carts, was banned, and a 36-hour curfew was imposed on almost the entire state. Despite this, terrorists killed 13 more people. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iraq attacked a Turkish oil tanker 50 miles south of Iran's Kharg Island oil export terminal. An Iraqi military spokesman said its aircraft struck ''two large naval targets'' in Iraq's unilaterally declared war zone near Kharg Island. There was no independent confirmation of a second successful strike. (A1:5.)

title: JAZZ: PETER KOWALD QUARTET
description: THE Peter Kowald Quartet hurtled through a set of explosive free jazz Saturday at the Sound Unity Festival. Mr. Kowald, a bassist, organized the five- day festival.

title: Jessica M. Weber Marries Alan Peckolick in Amenia
description: Jessica Margot Weber, the daughter of Mrs. William R. Weber of New York and the late Mr. Weber, was married yesterday to Alan Jay Peckolick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Peckolick of Tamarack, Fla. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the couple's summer home in Amenia, N.Y.

title: 'MR. CONSERVATION'
description: When Russell E. Train was introduced on Thursday as chairman of Clean Sites Inc., a new industry-environment group to speed cleaning up of toxic waste dumps, he was described as ''Mr. Conservation.'' The title is merited. Now president of World Wildlife Fund- U.S., devoted to the preservation of animal life, Mr. Train has held diverse conservation and environmental posts in the public and private sectors.

title: Funds for Housing Retrieved
description: The Housing and Urban Development's Inspector General's office says it has recovered about $33 million in improperly spent funds from October to March, the first half of the current fiscal year.

title: FOCUS ON TREASURY BILLS THIS WEEK
description: This week's Treasury financings are confined to the bill market, with auctions scheduled today for new issues due in three and six months, to be followed Wednesday by the sale of new bills due in one year.

title: YALE CREW WINS
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew, in a near-repetition of last year's result, defeated Harvard by 13.59 seconds today in their 119th race, America's oldest intercollegiate rivalry.

title: MUSIC: MILTON NASCIMENTO OF BRAZIL
description: MILTON NASCIMENTO, the celebrated Brazilian pop singer, gave his first concert performance in the United States Saturday at midnight in Carnegie Hall. Many of the listeners in the sold-out hall had been waiting more than 10 years to see the man whose albums have long been among Brazil's most prized exports, and they seemed almost deliriously elated. For Mr. Nascimento is more than a pop singer. He is a remarkable vocal improviser and stylist, with a range of several octaves, and an innovative musical craftsman.

title: JOHNSON SETS MARK BY MAKING 21 ASSISTS
description: The fast break of the Los Angeles Lakers creates, as the forward Kurt Rambis aptly said, ''electricity.'' Today, it shocked the Boston Celtics.

title: 18 MISSING, 1 DEAD AND 9 RESCUED AS TALL SHIP IS LOST NEAR BERMUDA
description: A 117-foot British square-rigged ship racing from Bermuda to Halifax, Nova Scotia, was abandoned by her 28 crew members and passengers in heavy seas and was lost in the North Atlantic yesterday, the Coast Guard reported.

title: BATTLE OF THE WESTWAY: BITTER 10-YEAR SAGA OF A VISION ON HOLD
description: No sign identifies the site. No reference can be found on New York City's official street map.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article Saturday on the invasion of Normandy misspelled the name of one of the three beaches where the British Second Army landed. It was Juno Beach.

title: MRS. LESTER MARKEL
description: Meta Markel, the widow of Lester Markel, who was Sunday editor of The New York Times from 1923 to 1964, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: 'EUREKA STOCKADE' FROM AUSTRALIA
description: THE Australian film industry has been flourishing artistically for the last few years but if ''Eureka Stockade'' is any indication, Australian television still has a way to go. Based on a true story surrounding what the press releases describe as ''the only armed insurrection by free men in Australia's history,'' the four-hour ''Eureka Stockade'' is being shown on WNEW/ Channel 5 in two parts, tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. There will be a rebroadcast next Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1984

title: UTIILITES CHANGE NAMES IN BIDS FOR NEW IMAGES
description: Investors can no longer buy common stock in the Virginia Electric and Power Company, although the public utility still sells securities and serves 1.5 million customers. To investors, the 59-year-old company is now Dominion Resources and its familiar stock symbol, VEL, has been replaced by the letter D.

title: KEITH HERNANDEZ: BEST MET EVER
description: ED LYNCH remembers the day they traded his friend, Neil Allen. It was June 15, 1983, and trade rumors were buzzing around the Met clubhouse. Suddenly, Allen was summoned to the manager's office.

title: Jane Levinsohn Is Married To Carl Zucker, a Director
description: Jane Levinsohn, a marketing manager for Coty cosmetics, and Carl M. Zucker, an independent assistant director and unit manager for feature films and commercials, were married yesterday.

title: Scientist Is Wed To Dr. Blacksin
description: Dr. Marcia F. Blacksin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Blacksin of Oceanside, L.I., and Dr. James A. Brown, the son of Rear Adm. J. Andrew Brown, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Brown, of Portsmouth, Va., were married yesterday. Rabbi Irving Block performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: Carterites in Panama
description: Jimmy Carter's aides don't seem to

title: 1,000 Drawings Put Up For Hirschfeld Show
description: A retrospective of the drawings of Al Hirschfeld, who this year received the first Brooks Atkinson Award for lifetime theater achievement, opens today at the Margo Feiden Galleries, 51 East 10th Street, and continues through June 29.

title: SAKHAROV FAMILY WAITING FOR WORD
description: While various rumors and reports circulated abroad about the fate of Andrei D. Sakharov, his supporters and relatives in Moscow reported no new information about his whereabouts or condition.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Long Term Rates

title: Jane Ellen Mogel Weds Peter Pitts in Connecticut
description: Jane Ellen Mogel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mogel of New York and Redding, Conn., and Peter J. Pitts, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pitts of Woodmere, L.I., were married in Redding yesterday. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony at the Mogel home.

title: Dozens Wounded as Police Disperse March in Uruguay
description: Dozens of people were wounded in central Montevideo today when antiriot policemen dispersed a banned march of thousands of people demonstrating for political amnesty and freedom of the press, witnesses said.

title: Jill B. Berkelhammer Weds Jonathan Zorn
description: Jill Barbara Berkelhammer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Berkelhammer of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Zorn, the son of Mr. and Mr. Bruce Zorn of Brooklyn. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Berkelhammer home.

title: NOW, WHO WILL RUN SALVADOR'S MILITARY
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte's inauguration Friday as President of El Salvador leaves a major question unanswered: Who is in control of the armed forces? Will it be Mr. Duarte, the Commander in Chief, or will the armed forces continue to careen along their murderous path to disaster?

title: VIDMAR WINS GYMNAST TRIALS
description: They are friends and teammates, but they are also the competition. Thus, for the gymnasts from U.C.L.A. and those from Nebraska, all the handclasping, backslapping and bearhugging during the Olympic trials were tempered by the knowledge that at stake was not a victory in a dual meet but their individual standings and perhaps even a place on the Olympic team.

title: 4- WHEEL DRIVE USED AS LURE
description: Audi, the luxury car division of Volkswagen, is trying to change the image of four- wheel-drive cars, from ungainly vehicles best suited for off-road use to sleek, sure-footed boulevard cruisers.

title: GUTS AND WISDOM YIELD 400 FAST METERS
description: In March, Antonio McKay won the 400- meter dash in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships in Syracuse. Saturday, he won the 400-meter dash in the outdoor championships here.

title: SURGING COFFEE PRICES THREATEN QUOTA SYSTEM
description: Stubbornly high coffee prices, which threaten to disrupt the stability of the world market, have forced the 73-nation International Coffee Organization to call a special meeting of its executive board today in London.

title: SEARCH FOR DOCK ADDS TWIST TO SEARCH FOR LOBSTER
description: Alexander Ferent is a tall, bulky man with powerful arms who catches lobsters for a living. He also lives in Boston, and that's his problem.

title: TELEVISION KEY TO CALIFORNIA POLITICS
description: The other afternoon, with smog hanging over the endless, low-slung architecture of west Los Angeles, William Zimmerman sat in his office and reflected on the vast scale that governs the political battle in this state between Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart.

title: SHULTZ TRIP: A SERIOUS BID FOR PEACE?
description: Administration officials said today that an overriding purpose of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's mission to Nicaragua Friday was to signal Sandinista leaders there was a possibility in the next few months for negotiating an end to the conflict in Central America before it widened and risked a more direct American military involvement.

title: 'BANDITBALL' BEATS THE GENERALS, 40-14
description: Steve Spurrier, the coach of the Tampa Bay Bandits, told his players before today's game to forget last week's unexpected loss to the Memphis Showboats. ''Go out and play Banditball,'' said Spurrier. ''Let's have some fun.''

title: Brenda Gruss Is Wed To Daniel Otto Hirsch
description: Brenda Gruss, a trial lawyer with the criminal division of the Department of Justice in Washington, and Daniel Otto Hirsch, a staff lawyer with the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, were married yesterday at the Oxon Hill (Md.) Manor in a Jewish ceremony read by Peter A. Geffen, principal of the Park Avenue Synagogue High School in New York.

title: INDIA BANS TRAVEL IN PUNJAB IN BID TO HALT VIOLENCE
description: The Government today suspended transportation and clamped a 36-hour curfew over most of Punjab state in an effort to quell violence by radical Sikhs agitating for greater autonomy. Soldiers began patrolling the state's cities and towns.

title: THE LEBANON DEBACLE
description: On June 6, 1982, Israeli forces invaded Lebanon. Their announced purpose was to clear P.L.O. forces from a zone 25 miles north of the border: a limited operation that would take less than a week and involve few Israeli casualties. When the 25-mile line was reached, Prime Minister Begin said on June 8, ''All the fighting will end.''

title: Braniff Air Adds Service
description: Braniff Inc., citing substantial gains in air traffic, has added its first new destination since resuming operations on March 1.

title: OUTDOORS: HINTS FOR SAFE TRAVEL AND EXTRA COMFORT
description: D ECADES of mucking about in the outdoors have made me truly expert in nothing but the art of tinkering, of modifying gear or devising ways to better deal with some of the little probems one encounters when afloat or afield. A few such suggestions follow.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:LNearEnd

title: RIVALS ASSAULT AN ISRAELI RABBI
description: About 50 Hasidic Jews raided a synagogue in Jerusalem Saturday and assaulted a rabbi who is a leading representative of the Orthodox Agudat Israel Party. The violence was related to pre-election disputes over the party's nominations for Parliament.

title: Futures/Options; Commodity Index and Inflation
description: W ITH supplies of most of the important agricultural and industrial commodities abundant for the past decade, why has the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices been rising in recent weeks? And why does it now appear poised for an equally sharp decline?

title: Bank Closed In California
description: State regulators closed the Garden Grove Community Bank Friday night. The action came only after a radio station reported a rumor that a seizure was likely, which caused a run on the bank.

title: FEW INJURIES COULD BE TREATED IN WAR, U.S. SAYS
description: The Defense Department's senior medical officer has told Congress that American military forces could care for only 20 percent of the estimated casualties in a large-scale battle, a situation that could force the United States to surrender in conventional warfare.

title: LEGISLATOR GAINS SLIM LEAD IN TEXAS SENATE RACE
description: State Senator Lloyd Doggett led United States Representative Kent Hance by a razor- thin margin today after a heated runoff primary for the Democratic nomination for the seat being vacated by United States Senator John Tower.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Terrace of Plenty
description: ''I love that rain -

title: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Handling Smith-Corona
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been named the ad agency for the Smith-Corona Group of the SCM Corporation, a major manufacturer of electronic and electric typewriters.

title: 8.3% GAIN IN VOLUME FOR CITY'S RETAILERS
description: Sales at seven major retailers in New York City rose an average of 8.3 percent in May over the period a year before, a monthly survey has found, but several of the retailers failed to achieve their planned sales because of a combination of cool weather and consumer-buying sluggishness.

title: COMPLICATED RULES GOVERN VOTING IN THE JERSEY PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY
description: The closely contested Democratic primary in New Jersey is open to the state's 1.2 million registered Democrats and the 1.6 million registered voters who have not declared a party preference.

title: GOLDEN TEMPLE IN AMRITSAR: SIKHISM'S MOST SACRED SHRINE
description: Throughout the 22 months of curfews, riots and terrorist attacks in the recent Sikh drive for greater autonomy, the Indian Government has never taken one step that some think would be appropriate: to storm the Golden Temple in Amritsar and flush out the militant Sikhs who are hiding there.

title: ISRAEL NAMES 2 OFFICERS CHARGED IN TERRORISM
description: Two Israeli Army officers accused of involvement with Jewish terrorists who planted bombs in and near the cars of Arab Mayors were identified in court today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which National Basketball Association teams have reached the championship series with losing records in the regular season? Did any of them win the championship?

title: GROWING SECURITY-GUARD INDUSTRY UNDER SCRUTINY
description: With a silver badge pinned to his blue uniform shirt and clutching a night stick, Don Vega keeps a lookout for muggers and burglars as he patrols the lobby of an apartment building on Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens.

title: THE TRIALS OF COUNTRY WEEKENDS
description: ON Monday, May 28, as the long holiday weekend was waning, a jitney from the Hamptons arrived in Manhattan after five hours in traffic. A woman alighted, carrying an overnight bag and a rhubarb pie. She looked stunned. ''I want to get down on my knees and kiss the dirty pavement,'' she said.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY ENDORSES 2 WAIVERS OF SAFETY RULES, PROMPTING CRITICISM
description: The Labor Department's safety and health agency has endorsed two unusual exemptions from safety rules in the workplace, and critics say the variances amount to human experimentation for the sake of corporate convenience.

title: SAFETY, COMFORT AND CONVENIENCE; Public Decency New York City can host an annual marathon race, accommodate any number of street fairs, even toss an enormous birthday party for the Brooklyn Bridge. Why can't it provide decent public restrooms? One reason is that so many have been vandalized. Five years ago, for instance, only 60 percent of the Parks Department's 744 comfort stations were usable. Today 74 percent are open, but more than 100 have had to be closed permanently. This fall, the department is trying out a new model at 17th Avenue and Shore Park Drive in Brooklyn. It's made of tough materials (brick, granite and stainless steel), has a louvered roof for light and ventilation, grilles for doors and doesn't require an attendant. An enthusiastic spokesman for the department called it ''elegant.'' If its practicality lives up to its looks, the department wants to replicate it all over the city.
description: Let's hope it succeeds. Meanwhile, an apple to the department for making the effort.

title: REUNION: COMMUNE IS RECALLED
description: Nearly 50 years ago, 200 unemployed Jewish garment workers - most of them from New York's Lower East Side - each scraped together $500 and brought their families here for a federally sponsored experiment in communal living.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Ogilvy Officer Shifts to Ingalls

title: Japanese Protest Missiles
description: About 19,000 people demonstrated outside United States bases today to protest the installation of Tomahawk cruise missiles on ships of the Pacific Fleet, the police said. About 16,000, some snake-dancing while others pushed a papier-m^ache tank, marched past a base at Yokosuka that is headquarters for the United States Seventh Fleet, while 3,000 demonstrated at Iwakuni, site of a United States Marine Air Station, the police said.

title: STOP LETTING GEORGE DO IT
description: New York City ought to take over the New York Yankees.

title: WRONG COMBINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadline Passes; 132 in Olympics
description: The deadline to accept invitations to the Olympic Summer Games here passed early today with a record 132 nations having announced plans to attend.

title: Eruption of Volcano in Japan Covers Southern City in Ash
description: Mount Sakurajima volcano erupted today, blanketing the southern Japanese city of Kagoshima with volcanic ash, officials said.

title: Researchers Plan to Return Rare Falcons to Maine Nests
description: Peregrine falcons are returning to Maine for the first time since the pesticide DDT killed most of them off 20 years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Make no mistake about it, no Government can allow violence and terrorism any premium in the settlement of issues.'' - Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. (A1:6.)

title: YANKEES SENSE CALM BEFORE STORM
description: Based on the quiet profiles of the owner and general manager, expectations have emerged among the Yankee players that something will happen any day, any moment - something that will shake up the team.

title: MUSIC: 'HORIZONS '84'
description: WORLD, United States and New York premieres by Robert Beaser, Thea Musgrave and Donald Erb, respectively, made the burden of Saturday's installment of ''Horizons '84,'' the New York Philharmonic's festival of new music.

title: SCRAMBLE OVER PAIN RELIEVERS
description: The drug market has been thrown into a competitive frenzy by the Food and Drug Administration's approval on May 18 of a popular prescription pain reliever, ibuprofen, for over-the- counter sale.

title: Schools Need More Than Relief
description: The New York City Board of Education's selection of Anthony Alvarado as Chancellor last spring was reason for universal relief after a rending racial-political fight. But relief turned to dismay with revelations about his messy personal finances, which caused him to resign. In choosing Nathan Quinones, the Acting Chancellor and a veteran of the school system, to succeed Mr. Alvarado, the board has now found quick new relief.

title: Coca-Cola Switching Tab Account to SSC&B
description: The Coca-Cola Company is moving its Tab business from McCann-Erickson to SSC&B.

title: ADELINE LOTITO
description: Adeline Lotito, a former dancer and the widow of Louis A. Lotito, who was president of a group of Broadway theaters, died in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday of a brain tumor.

title: ;  Noble Affiliates Names Successor to President
description: George J. McLeod, 54, has assumed the title of president and chief executive of Noble Affiliates Inc., the company has announced.

title: MCENROE TESTED, AS IS MRS. LLOYD
description: John McEnroe and Chris Evert Lloyd struggled on center court at Roland Garros Stadium today, but moved into the quarterfinals of the French Open tennis championships.

title: A STEERING EXPERIMENT
description: Four-wheel-drive cars are still relatively uncommon, but the long- range thinkers at the Mazda Motor Company are testing an even more exotic approach to driving - four- wheel steering.

title: No Headline
description: Dividend Meetings

title: Guatemalan Refugees Are Shifted by Mexico
description: Some 230 Guatemalan refugees arrived in a temporary camp as part of the Mexican Government's program to move them from camps on the southern border with Guatemala, a Government agency said today.

title: NEIL SIMON TAKES HIS HONORARY LL.D. WITH GRAIN OF SALT
description: Neil Simon, the playwright, today questioned the value of an honorary degree after receiving one at the Williams College commencement.

title: SHELTERING OF SALVADORANS IS DEBATED
description: The congregation of the Riverside Church debated yesterday whether to provide shelter for a family of illegal aliens from El Salvador, a move that would put the church in conflict with the United States Government and with its own boards of trustees and deacons.

title: A Gift Triumphs
description: Gift made his first start on the grass a winning one yesterday with a 1 1/4-length victory in the $72,800 Hill Prince Handicap for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park. The winner, owned by Taylor Asbury and trained by Joe Cantey, paid $10.80 for $2 to win.

title: Unopposed Icelandic Leader Is Certain of Election Again
description: President Vigdis Finnbogadottir was assured Saturday of re-election for another four-year term when the deadline for registering passed without any candidates filing to challenge her.

title: ORIOLES DOWN TIGERS,2-1, TO TAKE SERIES
description: Mike Flanagan pitched a seven-hitter and Cal Ripken delivered a sacrifice fly in a two-run sixth inning as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Tigers, 2-1, today.

title: MISS BUDD'S LEGS SPEAK FOR HER
description: LONDON F OR all but about a few seconds more than four minutes last week, Zola Budd, the running star from South Africa, has seemed to be in the grip of forces beyond her control.

title: SAN FRANCISCO HOMOSEXUALS FIND DEMOCRATS NOW LISTEN
description: The annual dinner of the Harvey Milk Gay Democratic Club, one of this city's most powerful political groups, usually draws a large turnout of local political luminaries.

title: SAFETY, COMFORT AND CONVENIENCE; Taming the Wild Bikes
description: Why should a bicycle messenger heed the traffic laws? He's paid by the job, and that means time is money. Traffic lights and clumsy pedestrians erode his daily pay.

title: Catholic Priest Says Church Statue Weeps
description: It has been five years since the last big crowd of worshipers filled the old St. John of God Roman Catholic Church. But 2,000 people attended Ascension Thursday mass to see a statue of the Virgin Mary reported to have wept real tears.

title: SCHOOL TRACK TITLE TO BROOKLYN TECH
description: Ed Zarowin's final appearance as coach at Brooklyn Tech was a successful one yesterday as the Engineers won the team trophy at the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championship meet at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ''. . .AND LADIES OF THE CLUB.'' By Helen Hooven Santmyer. 1,176 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Freehold Races May Resume Soon
description: Freehold Raceway, devastated by a grandstand fire last month, could begin holding races again by early July, according to Brian McLoone, publicity director for the 131-year-old track.

title: 586 GRADUATED FROM JOHN JAY
description: Aldous Huxley wrote that there are really only two satisfactory professions,'' the author and criminologist Norval Morris said at the graduation ceremonies of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice yesterday. ''Medicine, because you could persuade yourself that you are doing good, and astronomy, because you could be damned sure you were doing no harm.''

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Science Tells All There you were, wondering why such a high scorer as Wilt Chamberlain was such a poor free-throw shooter, trying to figure why the protruding side wings on Indianapolis cars were flat on top and curved on the bottom, and scratching your head over the apparent impossibility of a somersaulting high diver, with nothing to push against, suddenly initiating a twist in mid-air.

title: ; Ex-Leader of May Co. Heads HRT's Zody's
description: Edwin G. Roberts, a longtime retailing executive, has been named president of Zody's discount stores, the biggest division of HRT Industries Inc., the Los Angeles-based retailer said.

title: YANKS GET 18 HITS, ROUT JAYS, 15-2
description: On the final day of their odyssey, the Yankees crammed their offense, heretofore missing, into four innings and defeated the Blue Jays, 15-2, today.

title: AMERICAN 'GO-GO BANKING' IN NEED OF BRAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKRUPTCY AND LABOR CONTRACTS: A BURDEN FAIRLY SHARED
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR VILLAGE, IT'S 'GOOD THE YOUNG KNOW'
description: The writer of this dispatch covered the Allied landings in Normandy in 1944 for The New York Times and has been military correspondent for The Times since 1970.

title: IRELAND'S PREMIER CHIDES PRESIDENT
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland implicitly rebuked the United States for its policy in Central America tonight in a speech at a gala state banquet at Dublin Castle in honor of President and Mrs. Reagan.

title: Katherine Straus Is Married
description: Katherine Louise Straus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Blair Charles Caple, the son of Elyse Caple of Kingston, N.Y., and Stanley Caple of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Mark Golub performed the ceremony in the Cottage on the Park at the Hampshire House.

title: Advertising; Dearfoams Scheduling A TV Test
description: -slipper circles, should become still bigger as a result of its first major advertising campaign, which breaks in the fall.

title: Bolivia Quits Olympics, Citing Poor Economy
description: The Bolivian Government said today that it would not send a team to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles because of the country's economic difficulties.

title: Fasolino at Ross Roy
description: Ross Roy-Colarossi Griswold is going to do the ads for Fasolino Foods, a 66-year-old Jersey City pasta maker. Its last major agency, a year ago, was Bozell & Jacobs of Newark. The budget this year is expected to be about $2 million.

title: BEHIND THE BARBS OF LAWYER AND INFORMER IN DELOREAN'S TRIAL
description: The tortured unfolding of testimony in recent days from James Timothy Hoffman, a Government informer who came from the narcotics underworld, has shown, among other things, what a tight little universe that is. In court the other day, Howard L. Weitzman, the criminal lawyer defending John Z. DeLorean against charges of conspiring to distribute cocaine, slyly revealed that Mr. Hoffman approached him for legal advice after being indicted in September 1981 on a charge of conspiracy to import cocaine.

title: Philip Morris Tobacco Chief
description: Philip Morris Inc. said this weekend that Frank E. Resnik had been named president of Philip Morris U.S.A., its tobacco unit. Mr. Resnik, 55 years old, joined Philip Morris as a chemist in 1952.

title: Conservatives Talk Of New Political Party By United Press International
description: Richard Viguerie, publisher of Conservative Digest, may be getting closer to his dream of starting a political party that he says would more closely reflect his views than the Republican Party does.

title: WHAT'S TO SUCCESS THE AGE OF REASON?
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 2 'CINDERELLAS'
description: MAGALI MESSAC and Cheryl Yeager made their New York debuts in the title role of ''Cinderella'' at weekend performances by American Ballet Theater in the Metropolitan Opera House. Their interpretations were equally valid, although they differed considerably in emphasis. Yet, despite the fact that they starred in a ballet about magic, neither dancer could change the leaden choreography by Mikhail Baryshnikov and Peter Anastos into gold.

title: Maine Worm Diggers Strike for Cent More
description: Saying they can barely survive on what they earn, some of Maine's worm diggers are striking to get 1 cent more a worm from shippers.

title: TORREZ 0-5 AS METS DROP 1-0 DECISION
description: About an hour after the Mets lost a 1-0 decision to the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium yesterday, Mike Torrez, the losing pitcher, sent word by way of the team publicist that he would not talk about his performance.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Maize-Products Co., Stamford, Conn., a diversified company, has named Patric J. McLaughlin president of the Corn Processing division.

title: REAGAN FINDS 'CONTENTMENT' IN ANCESTRAL VILLAGE
description: An elated President Reagan walked the narrow streets and prayed in the old stone church of his Irish forebears today and declared that the experience ''has given my soul a new contentment.''

title: VOTE NEARS IN BYPASSED NEW MEXICO
description: The visitor to New Mexico might not guess there will be a Presidential primary here Tuesday. The highways that cut past the state's stunning red-rock mesas, buttes and canyons are unmarred by political billboards and there are almost no ads on television or radio.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES' DEBATE IN CALIFORNIA
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a Democratic Presidential debate yesterday in the NBC studios in Burbank, Calif., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of NBC News.

title: CHICAGO JUDGE'S PAYOFF TRIAL POPULAR AS THEATER
description: -Chicagoans have been riveted by testimony in a Federal trial describing how for years, in the words of the United States Attorney, they were ''defrauded of their right to have cases handled honestly and fairly'' in the vast Cook County Circuit Court system.

title: Arthur Bell, 51, a Columnist, Homosexual Rights Activist
description: Arthur Bell, a columnist for The Village Voice and a homosexual rights activist, died Saturday night at St. Vincent's hospital of complications arising from diabetes. He was 51 years old.

title: Walesa Says Solidarity 'Is Indestructible'
description: The founder of Solidarity, Lech Walesa, celebrated the feast of his namesake, St. Lech, by attending a special mass in Gdansk today, and told 10,000 supporters that the outlawed union was indestructible.

title: THE EXPECTED BOOM IN HOME COMPUTERS FAILS TO MATERIALIZE
description: A year ago it seemed certain that inexpensive home computers would soon be found in half of America's homes, an indispensable tool for families to use in planning, keeping financial records, playing games and preparing their children for life in a computerized world.

title: Aversion to Computers Worries Bonn
description: Not long ago, during an exhibition meant to help initiate West Germans into the mysteries of computer technology, 10 masked intruders wielding sledgehammers smashed $40,000 worth of computer hardware in the trim northern town of G"utersloh.

title: MATH SCORES RISE IN CITY SCHOOLS FOR 3D YEAR
description: Students in New York City's public schools improved in mathematics this school year for the third consecutive year, according to preliminary results of a standardized test.

title: OPERA: 'ARIADNE' BY STRAUSS
description: What a joy to see and hear ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' in a small theater! This most intimate of the early operas of Richard Strauss was staged at the century- old, 463-seat Dock Street Theater here Saturday night, as part of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.

title: SASKATCHEWAN WOOS OILMEN
description: Until recently, this prairie province was known mainly for its endless horizons and socialist Government.

title: Lucas Sentenced to Die
description: Henry Lee Lucas, who has said he killed 360 people across the country, received his first death sentence Friday, in the 1979 slaying of a hitchkiker. State District Judge John Carter ordered that Mr. Lucas be put to death by injection.

title: HISTORIAN ADDRESSES WESLEYAN
description: David C. McCullough, the writer and historian, today urged Wesleyan University's graduating seniors to remember the importance of history ''as a guide to navigation in perilous times.''

title: Warner Is Nominated To Return to Senate
description: Republicans nominated Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, for a second term Saturday at their state convention.

title: 25 Die in Taiwan Storms
description: Torrential rains set off landslides, killing 25 people, and flooded vast areas of farmland in northern Taiwan today, the police reported. The weather bureau said the downpour, which lasted almost eight hours, was Taipei's heaviest in 11 years.

title: World War II Spy Named in London
description: A British newspaper said today that it had identified the double agent who tricked the Germans into believing that the landings at Normandy were only a diversionary feint to be followed by a real invasion near Calais.

title: A PROUD CLUB'S TROUBLED TIMES
description: BOSTON W HEN Jim Rice considers the current plight of the Boston Red Sox, he is hard-pressed to list any positive things that have happened this season and is forced to cast back a half- dozen years for the source of the negative things.

title: Theresa's, Blues Center Of Chicago, Is Back
description: Theresa Needham, known as ''the mother of the blues'' here, is back.

title: DUARTE IS NOT PLANNING INQUIRY ON NUNS
description: The President of El Salvador said today that he would not actively investigate the question of whether high military officials tried to cover up military involvement in the killings of four United States churchwomen in 1980.

title: Kosher, Sort of
description: It's something that could only have

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Griffith Reassured

title: SEABROOK EFFECTS STUDIED
description: By undertaking conservation measures and increasing imports from Canada, New England could maintain adequate supplies of electricity in the next few years even if both of the troubled Seabrook nuclear reactors were to be canceled, according to a study by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S MOST UNDERPAID LAWYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS WIN, 4-1, TO GAIN CHALLENGE CUP
description: The Cosmos erupted for four goals after a scoreless first half and captured the fifth annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today with a 4-1 victory over Udinese of Italy.

title: LANDLORDS SEEK A 12% INCREASE IN SOME LEASES
description: The major organization of city landlords said yesterday that it wanted a 12 percent rent increase on new one-year leases for tenants in rent-stabilized apartments who now pay at least $400 a month.

title: GOLF TARGETS OR TORTURES
description: ON the first green at Winged Foot in the first round of the 1974 United States Open, Jack Nicklaus tapped his 20-foot putt. But when the ball caught a slope, it rolled and rolled until it stopped 25 feet from the cup. Suddenly the Golden Bear was farther from the hole on his second putt than he had been on his first. In remembering that moment now, Ted Horton snickered.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CENSORED The big new exhibition ''Censorship: 500 Years of Conflict,'' just opened at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street (869-8089), has nearly 300 books, manuscripts, documents, newspapers, pamphlets and drawings. The magnitude of this impressive and well-designed display is too much to absorb in one trip. One could perhaps make it a walk-through summer course, taking in parts of each of the six sections on separate visits. In addition, the library is offering a number of auxiliary features to accompany the exhibition itself.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today June 4, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PURCHASERS CITE SLOWER GROWTH
description: The economy continued to expand in May, but at a slower pace, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS'S HOPES FOR SUMMIT TALKS
description: Business executives in Europe, the United States and Japan do not see the economic summit meeting that begins here Thursday as a policy-making session. Rather, many said in interviews this past week, they expect problems that affect them to be discussed, but do not anticipate the conference to result in any decisions that will have a direct impact on those problems.

title: Rumanian Is Reported Under Fire by Soviet
description: On the eve of a visit to Moscow by President Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania's official press said today that Mr. Ceausescu had come under Soviet fire for dissenting on key foreign policy issues.

title: 'REAL THING' AND 'LA CAGE' DOMINATE THE TONY AWARDS
description: ''LA CAGE AUX FOLLES'' and ''The Real Thing'' - shows about love, both homosexual and heterosexual - dominated the 1984 Tony Awards last night at the Gershwin Theater.

title: Hounds Search Marsh Near Carolina Border
description: Searchers tried today to intercept two men believed to be among four wanted killers, following bloodhounds to the Virginia state line nearly three days after the fugitives escaped from that state's death row.

title: CUOMO TO FILL VACANCY ON PUBLIC SERVICE PANEL
description: Since taking office 17 months ago, Governor Cuomo has allowed the chairman of the Public Service Commission to continue serving, but without the official endorsement of the Governor. For the past eight months Mr. Cuomo has left vacant one of the seven seats on the commission, which regulates telephone, electric and other utilities in the state.

title: Big Turnout in Madrid For Anti-NATO March
description: More than 100,000 people marched through the center of Madrid today to demand that Spain withdraw from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and scrap an agreement leasing four military bases to the United States.

title: Amid Cheers, Cable Cars Return to San Francisco
description: Cable cars returned to the city's streets today after a 20-month absence for a $75 million restoration, lurching up and down hills on California Street to cheers, firecrackers and dancing lions and dragons.

title: William Ehrlich Marries Mrs. Borg at Her Home
description: Frances Borg of White Plains, widow of John Simon Borg, and William Ehrlich of New York were married yesterday.

title: EMILY POST'S VERY OWN
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees entertain their first visitor from the American League East for the month of June, a month of intradivision battles. (Television - Sports Channel 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 8 P.M.).

title: OPERA: 'ICARUS' GIVEN U.S. PREMIERE
description: ''Icarus,'' a self-described sky opera by Paul Earls with a text by Ian Strasfogel derived from Greek myth, received its first United States performance at Kresge Auditorium here tonight.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Blind Golfers You've heard the one about the arrogant golfer who is introduced to a blind player at the country club bar and refuses to believe the man could be a serious competitor. ''I'll give you a stroke a hole and pay you $1,000 for every one you win,'' challenges the braggart. ''Just say when.''

title: PROPOSED RULE BRINGS BATTLE ON ACCESS TO HOSPITAL DATA
description: A proposed change in Federal policy would, for the first time, give the public detailed information comparing medical care around the nation, including surgical mortality rates for individual hospitals.

title: SPECIAL CHALLENGES FOR TV COMPOSERS
description: When ABC-TV announced recently that it would film Herman Wouk's World War II novel, ''War and Remembrance,'' one of the people who responded most ecstatically to the news was Bob Cobert, who composed the music for the story's predecessor, ''The Winds of War.'' The producer- director Dan Curtis has tagged Mr. Cobert to return and write the music for the 20-hour, $60 million sequel.

title: L.P.G.A. Title Won By Patty Sheehan
description: Patty Sheehan was never challenged, as she turned Saturday's sure bet into today's fait accompli. She easily won the 30th Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship by a record score of 16-under-par 272 and by a record margin of 10 shots over Pat Bradley and Beth Daniel.

title: Exxon Oil Find
description: The Exxon Corporation said this weekend it had made a ''significant oil and gas discovery,'' believed to be more than 100 million barrels, in the Gulf of Mexico. The discovery was made about 60 miles southwest of Venice, La., in a well 13,253 feet deep.

title: Debt Issues
description: Citicorp is offering $150 million of 3-year extendable notes with final maturity of June 1, 1996, as 13 3/4's at par.

title: Pope Speaks of the Press
description: Pope John Paul II called today on several thousand people gathered in St. Peter's Square to pray that the communications media serve the truth. ''Pray so that the world of social communications carries out with fidelity its function to serve the truth, liberty, the promotion of man,'' John Paul said during his weekly blessing.

title: IN IRELAND,A HOST OF PROBLEMS
description: In a poster welcoming international travelers to Dublin Airport, the Republic of Ireland sells its youth. Pictured are four clean-cut students strolling across the cobblestone courtyard of Trinity College; the caption reads, ''We're the young Europeans.''

title: Dutch Masters CigarsReturning to Magazines
description: Those readers of the June Playboy who get past the centerfold and move on to the full-page, four-color ad for Dutch Masters cigars will be seeing a bit of history.

title: FACTORY TAKEOVER WEIGHED BY A CITY
description: The Mayor of New Bedford said today that the city was prepared to use eminent domain to buy a local 120-year-old manufacturing operation if that would keep the plant functioning.

title: AS IRELAND VISIST ENDS, 5,000 PROTESTERS MARCH
description: Five thousand anti-Reagan demonstrators paraded through the meandering, largely treeless streets of central Dublin today, culminating three days of protests against the President's visit to Ireland and his foreign policies, particularly in Central America.

title: Stars Clinch Tie
description: Chuck Fusina drilled a 5-yard touchdown pass to Willie Collier with 3 minutes 50 seconds left tonight to lift the Philadelphia Stars to their 12th straight victory, a 23-17 decision over the Pittsburgh Maulers. The Stars (14-1) clinched a tie for the Atlantic Division title. The Maulers fell to 3-13.

title: CANCER SOCIETY AIDE'S WORDS WITH TOBACCO CONCERN'S TWIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 239739 -- No Title
description: The Cole National Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing a deal with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists, under which Cole shareholders would receive $39 a share.

title: GENERALS LOOKING FOR LOST OFFENSE
description: Walt Michaels, the Generals' coach, who can be intractable, said today he was ''debating'' what to do about his football team, which was dominated in a 26-point loss to the Tampa Bay Bandits on Sunday.

title: SEA BURIAL REJECTED AS DISPOSAL OPTION FOR RETIRED A-SUBS
description: The Navy has concluded it would be best to bury defueled nuclear engine compartments from retired submarines on Government-owned land rather than scuttling the entire submarines in ocean deeps, it announced today.

title: Data General
description: The rating on long-term debt of the Data General Corporation was upgraded to Baa-1, from Baa-2, by Moody's Investors Service yesterday. Moody's said a higher rating was warranted for the company's $120 million of debt outstanding because of improved operating results, successful new products, and diversification into products for office automation and small businesses. The company is based in Westboro, Mass.

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $305,000 for the quarter and $381,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $195,000. d-After a $446,000 tax credit.

title: BRANIFF'S BUSINESS PICKING UP
description: Patrick Foley, vice chairman of Braniff Inc., said yesterday that his airline's business, after a disappointing start, had picked up so strongly that Braniff might show a profit by September.

title: Scientists Clone Bits of Genes Taken From Extinct Animal
description: Fragments of genes from an extinct animal, a relative of the zebra and the horse, have been found and reporoduced in the laboratory, scientists of University of California at Berkely reproted yesterday. They said the gene fragments are the first to be extracted from any vanished animal speceies.

title: Cafeteria Closed In Food Poisoning
description: The Hoboken High School cafeteria was closed today as health officials took food samples to determine the cause of food poisoning that affected about 150 people at a banquet last week.

title: AGENTS BREAK UP TWO COCAINE RINGS
description: Federal narcotics agents here have broken up two rings handling more than half a billion dollars worth of cocaine a year, officials said today.

title: Beverly Hills SavingsFills Its Top Positions
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association, which has been involved in a takeover fight since last summer, yesterday named a lawyer, Michael P. Flaherty, to be its president and chief executive officer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: TRAVELERS ALERT The very streets of New York are theaters, each one with a different cast and a different plot. In winter, the backdrops remain but the casts are more often backstage. Now, the warm time is upon us and theater al fresco, formal and informal, is open for all comers, in street, in park, in plaza.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I reports earnings for As of May 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: BATTLING FOR LUXURY WATCHES
description: The battle of the high-priced watches has been joined.

title: TALKING BUSINESS/WITH JOHN PAULUS OF MORGAN STANLEY ; HOW TO CALM CREDIT MARKETS
description: Inflation and interest rates tend to move in tandom; the higher the inflation, the larger the return demanded by investors. But recently, while inflation has remained relatively low, interest rates have skyrocketed, creating new costs for businesses, consumers and debt-burdened developing countries as well as depressing bond prices.

title: EVENING DRESS: TAKING IT EASY
description: The snug-bodice dresses with tiny waistlines and doorway-wide skirts, which haven't changed that much since the days of Scarlett O'Hara or Marie Antoinette, have been relegated to the back of the closet. The traditional ball gown, that most enduring style, has been overshadowed for fall and winter by another breed of evening fashion. The new crop is casual, though the styles can be glittery - gold lame and black velvet are given equal value - if that doesn't seem to be a contradiction in terms.

title: INFECTION LINKED TO SEX SURPASSES GONORRHEA
description: -known, often misdiagnosed and mistreated infection, is causing a national epidemic of venereal disease. It now far surpasses gonorrhea as the leading cause of sexually transmitted disease in the United States.

title: CAUGHT UP IN AN OIL RUSH, A CANADIAN TRIBE REELS
description: Summer Joe, a 62-year-old trapper who spends much of his life in the bush, says he used to kill four or five moose each winter. This year, he did not get any and has taken to eating bologna.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After currency losses of $104,000 for the quarter and $122,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $473,000 for the quarter and $2,165,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. d-After a currency loss of $12,000.

title: INDICATIONS POINT TO IRANIAN ATTACK SOON
description: American intelligence officials said today that signs were accumulating that Iran might finally launch its long-expected ground offensive against Iraqi positions around the key city of Basra.

title: U.S. Informs Kuwait It Can't Have Missiles
description: The Reagan Administration has told the Government of Kuwait that its request for Stinger antiaircraft missiles will not be granted under present circumstances, Administration and Congressional sources said today.

title: United Brands To Y.&R. Unit
description: The United Brands Company, which has Young & Rubicam serving its Chiquita Brand bananas in nine European countries, has retained that agency in the United States after an absence of about nine years. Actually, the assignment is going to Cato Johnson/Y&R, and it expects the client to spend between $2.5 million and $3 million for advertising and promotion. When United Brands left Y.&R. it went to W.B. Doner & Company, which it left May 1.

title: High Court Upholds Jersey Reapportionment
description: The Supreme Court, acting on the eve of the New Jersey primary, today upheld the latest redistricting plan for the state's 14 Congressional districts.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
FINAL OLYMPICS LIST HAS 142 COUNTRIES
description: Ten countries joined the final list of nations that will be participating in the Summer Olympics here, raising the total to a record 142, the organizers said today.

title: G.M. Military Plan
description: The General Motors Corporaton said it was creating a Military Vehicles Operation to develop products and expand the company's role as a military supplier. The new effort will be based at G.M.'s Technical Center in Warren, Mich., with additional facilities at the Allison Gas Turbine division in Indianapolis and at the Delco Systems Operation in Santa Barbara, Calif., the company said in a statement. G.M. now makes a commercial utility cargo vehicle for the Army. Its contract calls for delivery of more than 53,000 trucks over three years, with options for the Army to double that number.

title: PICTURES FROM AN EXHIBITION ON WAR
description: They were young artists then, three men assigned by the Navy to record the landing of American, British and Canadian troops on the beaches of Normandy.

title: Toy Sales Rise; Mattel in Black
description: Mattel Inc. reported a profit yesterday, citing improved toy sales.

title: Author's Offer
description: One author to another, Louis S. Auchincloss wrote to Governor Cuomo about Mr. Cuomo's new book: ''If you ever want a 'blurb,' I am happy to offer you this one: 'The Governor had better watch out! A diary so soul-searching, composed in the heat of a bitterly contested political campaign, just

title: INTERVIEWS THAT SHOULD BE DONE
description: On an hourlong segment last week of his wonderful series, ''A Walk Through the 20th Century,'' on PBS, Bill Moyers, the host and executive editor, said that ''no one puts the heartbeat into history like a good witness.''

title: BEAUMONT AGREEMENT IS REACHED
description: THE boards of Lincoln Center and the Vivian Beaumont Theater, which have engaged in a public feud for more than a year, yesterday announced a reconciliation.

title: PREMATURE PRONOUNCEMENTS ABOUT MEESE
description: To the Editor:

title: SURVIVORS TELL OF SHIP'S CAPSIZING
description: A rogue wind ''from out of nowhere'' capsized the sailing ship Marques early Sunday north of Bermuda, leaving 1 crew member dead and 18 missing, just after the crew believed they had successfully weathered an Atlantic storm, the 9 known survivors said yesterday.

title: FUEL LOBBY TOPS LIST IN SPENDING
description: With fuel companies leading the field, lobbyists spent at least $43.3 million last year trying to influence Congress.

title: JOHNSON OF CELTICS SAYS HE'S IN A SLUMP
description: What little drama there had been in the overwhelming victory by the Los Angeles Lakers over the Boston Celtics on Sunday afternoon was long gone. So was Dennis Johnson.

title: A MONK WHO GAINED INFLUENCE FROM WRITINGS
description: PORTRAYING a writer on film is a formidable task even in the drama-filled life of an author such as Hemingway. When the subject is a monk who remained in silent seclusion most of his adult life, the challenge is far greater.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Regular Partners Separate For Goldman and Finish 1-2

title: CONTROL OF GUNS AND RIVALS' VIEWS
description: The emotional issue of gun control, which arose in a debate Sunday night and persisted in campaigning yesterday, has long posed problems for Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Triangular Bats
description: When William Merritt kept popping up in a pickup softball game three summers ago, he became frustrated.

title: GET- TOUGH CURE FOR SCHOOLS LACKS A PARENTAL INGREDIENT
description: -PAGE article in The Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald last month was headlined ''Minneapolis Holds Back 11% of Its Kindergartners.''

title: Field Corporation
description: Marshall Field, former chairman of Field Enterprises, which was dissolved in March, said he had formed a new company, the Field Corporation, to acquire businesses on his behalf. Mr. Field said the new company would be capitalized by funds obtained from the liquidation of Field Enterprises, which last year sold The Chicago Sun- Times to Rupert Murdoch for about $100 million. He also said the new company would manage some of his assets, including Manistique Papers Inc., a maker of newsprint and specialty paper.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Armed Man Takes Woman Hostage
description: A 21-year-old Queens man armed with a handgun and a sawed-off shotgun invaded an 11th-floor office on Fifth Avenue yesterday and took a former girlfriend hostage, according to the police.

title: HEAVY FIGHTING REPORTED AT SHRINE IN PUNJAB
description: Army troops and Sikh terrorists reportedly clashed in several areas of Punjab today, with casualties on both sides. Heavy fighting was reported between Sikh terrorists inside the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion and security forces outside.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 5, 1984

title: THE 38TH TONY AWARDS
description: THE season may have been a bit threadbare, but the television show turned out to be reasonably diverting. Sunday night's live broadcast on CBS of Broadway's ''The 38th Annual Tony Awards'' even came close to staying within its always elusive timetable target of two hours but then went beyond 11 P.M. by about 15 minutes. Not helping matters was Joseph Papp, the producer, accepting a special award for ''A Chorus Line'' and reading a long, curious speech that offered a personal review of that show, complete with quotable quotes.

title: CONTINENTAL DISCLOSES TERMS OF LOAN
description: The directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and its holding company, the Continental Illinois Corporation, agreed to resign if the F.D.I.C. asked them to. The conecssion, disclosed by the holding company in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commision, was part of the agreement under which the bank received an emergency loan of $2 billion from the F.D.I.C.

title: Zimbabwe Warns Press On 'Distorted' Reports
description: The Government said today that it will use its emergency powers to prosecute correspondents who write ''distorted or twisted'' reports about the country.

title: CUOMO PICKS NOMINEE FOR P.S.C.
description: Governor Cuomo today appointed Gail Garfield Schwartz, an economist, to fill a vacancy on the state's Public Service Commission.

title: 'End of the World' Closes
description: ''End of the World,'' the play by Arthur Kopit, closed after last Saturday evening's performance at the Music Box Theater. Directed by Harold Prince and starring John Shea, Barnard Hughes and Linda Hunt, the drama ran for 13 previews and 33 regular performances.

title: Woodward Sues Dissident Holders
description: Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington, D.C., department store chain, said it filed a countersuit in Federal District Court against several shareholders who oppose the company's proposed $220 million merger with Taubman Holdings Inc. The countersuit charged that the group had violated sections of the Securities and Exchange Act in forming a shareholders' committee.

title: ; EAST VS. WEST BEYOND THE RHETORIC
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTLOOK IN THE GULF: A WIDENING WAR
description: News Analysis

title: STAGE: 2 NEW PLAYS FROM AUSTRALIA
description: Although the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. is primarily devoted to music and dance, this year it presented the American premieres of two new Australian plays, performed by the original companies. The Sydney Theater Company offered ''The Perfectionist,'' an investigation of modern marriage by David Williamson. The Handspan Theater of Melbourne made its debut with a sound-and-light show called ''Secrets.'' Despite the high-tech electronic effects of ''Secrets,'' it was the traditional play ''The Perfectionist'' that proved to be the more venturesome dramatic work.

title: MERIDIAN TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $255,000 for the latest year and $226,000 for the previous year.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Diesel Car Sales Down
description: Worldwide sales of diesel automobiles fell 14.2 percent in 1983, with most of the decline in the United States, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: BREZENOFF GIVES ADDRESS TO BROOKLYN GRADUATES
description: Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff called on Brooklyn College graduates yesterday to help rebuild New York City, which he said had been ravaged by the recession and by the ''fierce and acrimonious competition'' for a ''share of the smaller pot.''

title: Extension for Howser The Kansas City Royals announced yesterday that Manager
description: Dick Howser 's contract has been extended two years through the 1986 season. Howser, 48, was in the final year of a three- year contract and was given the extension following a 10-game trip in which the Royals won seven games to improve their record to 23-26. Howser has an overall record of 212-194 with the Royals since taking over for Jim Frey Aug. 31, 1981.

title: Fire Guts Duluth Landmark
