description: Fire has gutted the 84-year-old Duluth Curling Club and Skating Rink, once the largest curling club in the world but closed eight years ago, officials said. The fire, believed to have been set, began about 2 A.M. Sunday in the landmark, which was used as a shelter by transients and plagued by vandalism and fire since it was shut.

title: Man Sentenced In TV Stabbing
description: A Buffalo man was sentenced today to a year's probation for stabbing a man he said had sexually assaulted his 10- year-old daughter. The incident was recorded by a television news camera.

title: REAGAN PROPOSAL IS CALLED POLITICS
description: Administration officials characterized President Reagan's proposal today to discuss a pledge against using force in Europe with the Soviet Union as a serious exercise in public diplomacy and politics.

title: For Palmer, Open Is Shut
description: Arnold Palmer failed to qualify for the 1984 United States Open today, meaning that he will miss the tournament for the first time since 1952. Palmer, 54 years old, has been in 31 straight Opens, tying him with Gene Sarazen for the most consecutive appearances.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Pulitzer Fountain's Plight
description: Fountains are bubbling, spurting,

title: DOW GAINS 7.22 TO 1,131.57
description: Stock prices rose broadly for the second consecutive session yesterday, buoyed by heavy trading as declining interest rates again sparked the advance.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT GIVEN DOCUMENT BY YESHIVA U.
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, yesterday was awarded Yeshiva University's first honorary degree in absentia for his commitment to human rights.

title: TSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in June 1983.

title: MORE WOMEN HAVE CHILDREN OUTSIDE MARRAGE, STUDY SAYS
description: The proportion of women in the United States who either have a child before marriage or are pregnant at the time they marry has doubled since World War II, a Census Bureau study shows.

title: 'EISENHOWER AND D-DAY
description: -DAY, the Allied invasion of Nazi-occupied France, took place 40 years ago tomorrow. It is commemorated tonight on ''D-Day and Eisenhower,'' a rebroadcast, slightly edited, of a CBS program first shown in 1964. It was a fine piece of television then; 20 years have given it a new patina. It will be shown on CBS-TV at 8 tonight.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES CLIMB AGAIN
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply for the third consecutive day yesterday even though government securities dealers said demand came mostly from speculators and other securities firms, not investors.

title: Mitterrand Will Visit Moscow at End of June
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France will visit the Soviet Union later this month, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: AMID THE GRAVES OF 11,167 GERMAN DEAD, TWO GENERATIONS PONDER DEFEAT
description: They came from West Germany, the old man and the high school class. And they walked here today in the cemetery of the defeated army.

title: Regan's View of Dollar
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the strong dollar, criticized by European nations, may not begin to weaken until 1987.

title: IMPERILED 'LIFELINE' FOR SOVIET CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today June 5, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Impostor Is a Suspect In Nicaragua Bombing
description: A man posing as a Danish journalist when a bomb explosion wounded Ed en Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, and killed eight others carried a false passport and is a prime suspect in the assassination attempt, Denmark's Foreign Ministry said today.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER PLAN FOR COPING WITH OIL CRISIS
description: President Reagan has taken to the economic summit meeting a United States plan calling for joint allied action in case of a major oil disruption in the Persian Gulf, a State Department official disclosed today.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 50 percent stock split in the form of a dividend effective April 18.

title: Sterling Drug Unit
description: A unit of Sterling Drug Inc. has agreed to pay more than $1 million to settle claim that it misrepresented price information and charged excessive prices in contracts awarded by the General Services Administration for disinfectants, Federal officials said.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $105,000 for the quarter and $855,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Reuters Raises $309.8 Million
description: The initial public offering of Reuters Holding P.L.C. - the first in memory occurring simultaneously in New York and London - raised $309.8 million yesterday from investors around the world.

title: BUDGET TALKS IN LAST-MINUTE SNAG OVER ADDITIONS TO KOCH PROPOSAL
description: As the deadline for adoption approached, negotiations on New York City's next budget hit an unusual snag yesterday, with the City Council and the Board of Estimate pushing for far more service improvements than the Koch administration would accept.

title: Chinese Official to Visit U.S.
description: Defense Minister Zhang Aiping is scheduled to leave Tuesday for a trip that is to include a United States visit designed to improve relations ''between the two countries and the two armies,'' the Defense Ministry said today. Mr. Zhang is reciprocating for Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's visit here last September. Full details of Mr. Zhang's itinerary were not disclosed.

title: Senoir Golfers Defy Time in Title Bids
description: In 1904 Horace L. Hotchkiss, a retired businessman who was a member of the Apawamis Club, proposed a golf tournament for friends over the age of 60. The response was meager, and the tournament was postponed to 1905, with its age limit lowered to 55.

title: PLAN WOULD LET AIRLINES SELL FLIGHT TIME SLOTS
description: The Federal Government yesterday proposed new rules that would allow airlines to sell or trade landing and takeoff time slots allotted to them in the busiest hours at the ''high-density'' airports in New York, Chicago and Washington.

title: Topics ; For the Record
description: License, Not Liberty

title: HOSPITALS SEEK WAYS TO MAKE INTENSIVE CARE MORE EFFICIENT
description: WASHINGTON THE young patient lies dozing in the hospital's intensive care unit after brain surgery. Every hour a nurse checks her eyes to make sure her pupils are functioning properly. The advanced monitoring machines above her bed are turned off.

title: ART ON A GRAND SCALE
description: It seems logical that what was billed

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. , a company engaged in insurance, has named Robert H. Moore to the new position of vice president of corporate relations.

title: STINGER MISSILE MIGHT PROVE INEFFECTIVE IN GULF, STUDY SAYS
description: The Army's Stinger antiaircraft weapon may not be effective in defense of shipping in the Persian Gulf, according to a report by the Congressional Research Service.

title: CITY OPERA AND UNION HAVE PACT
description: The New York City Opera yesterday announced a five-year labor settlement with the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the company's soloists, stage directors, dancers and chorus. Guild units ratify by groups, and yesterday's announcement followed the last ratification vote - by the soloists - yesterday morning.

title: Exxon Gas Well
description: The Exxon Corporation said that a new well nearly five miles deep in the Permian Basin of west Texas is a ''prolific gas producer,'' with a flow of 128 million cubic feet of natural gas daily.

title: Nuclear Optical Fiber
description: Japanese scientists said today that they had developed a radiation-resistant optical fiber that could transmit signals to robots in nuclear power plants and nuclear waste disposal units. A spokesman for the Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation said the fiber was up to 10,000 times more resistant to radioactivity than present fibers. He said the company planned to develop robot arms that would receive instructions through the fibers for operations in highly radioactive areas.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS HOLDING JUVENILES TO PREVENT CRIME
description: The Supreme Court, reversing two lower Federal courts, today reinstated a New York law, similar to laws in all 50 states, under which juveniles charged with delinquency may be held before trial to prevent them from committing additional crimes.

title: Nixon's Views
description: Former President Richard Nixon's interest in sports is well known. In a recent interview, he expressed some thoughts on the decision by the Soviet Union not to participate in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: DANCE: PHYLLIS LAMHUT
description: PHYLLIS LAMHUT'S ''Collapsing Spaces, Tilting Times,'' the new work that the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company presented last Thursday night in St. Mark's Church, could have restored a cynic's faith in human nature. For nearly an hour, members of a large cast danced harmoniously together and revealed themselves to be joyous, loving and lovable. And all this was accomplished without sentimental gush or rhetorical bluster.

title: Air Base Protests Result in Arrests
description: Oneida County deputies arrested 17 people today on trespassing charges and 61 more were detained by Air Force security guards in a protest in behalf of seven defendants charged with damaging military equipment at Griffiss Air Force Base here.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $6.3 million. c-Net loss after a net loss of $22,561,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NAKASONE SAYS JAPAN WILL MAKE EFFORTS TO END PERSIAN GULF WAR
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that Japan would make ''further positive efforts'' to seek an end to the fighting between Iran and Iraq.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Runner May Retire
description: Jarmila Kratochvilova of Czechoslovakia, the world-record holder in the 400-meter and 800-meter runs, plans to retire in late summer, the Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K. reported yesterday. ''Last year, I achieved everything I set out to do, perhaps 200 percent of what I wished for,'' Miss Kratochvilova, who set both records last year, was reported as having said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS BY REHNQUIST AND MARSHALL ON THE NEW YORK LAW
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding the New York preventive detention law for juveniles. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the opinion. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote the dissenting opinion, which was joined by Associate Justices William J. Brennan Jr. and John Paul Stevens.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEADED SOTHEBY'S IN LONDON
description: Peter C. Wilson, the architect of international art-auctions in the post- World War II period and of the growth of Sotheby's, the London art-auction house that he headed for 22 years, died Sunday in Paris at the age of 71. Mr. Wilson, who had diabetes for many years, was said to have been in a coma in a Paris hospital for a week before his death.

title: CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to May 18
Continental IllinoisRatings Lowered
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has announced lower ratings for securities of Continental Illiois Corporation, the Chicago-based holding company of the Contintental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. Senior debt was reduced Friday to a speculative rating of BB, from BBB; preferred stock was reduced to Bx, from BB, and commercial paper was lowered to B, from A-2.

title: No Headline
description: John B. Fournet, 88; Top Louisiana Judge

title: ADVANCED ENERGY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRIEFING
description: A Man for OSHA

title: Chrysler Extends Mitsubishi Pact
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had extended through 1995 its agreement to import and sell vehicles made by the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan.

title: Ulurp Offers a Voice, Not a Veto In 1975
description: New York City's charter was changed to include a provision called Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, or Ulurp. It was intended to open a ''meaningful dialogue'' about decisions to permit development of city land by requiring city agencies to submit land use proposals to community boards for comment.

title: GHR Energy Files Plan to Pay Debts
description: The GHR Energy Corporation filed a reorganization plan today with the Federal District Court here under which it maintains it can pay $1.2 billion of debt within five to seven years.

title: Amputee Begins Run To Aid Cancer Society
description: A 21-year- old Connecticut man who lost his leg to cancer began a cross-country run today to show the abilities of the disabled and to raise money for the American Cancer Society.

title: Socal Names Executive To Smooth Gulf Merger
description: Kenneth T. Derr, president of the Standard Oil Company of California's Chevron U.S.A. unit, will head a program to put the merger of Socal and the Gulf Oil Corporation into effect, the San Francisco-based company announced yesterday.

title: King Brothers To Teach in Italy
description: After opposing each other six times during the National Basketball Association season, Bernard King of the Knicks and Albert King of the Nets, will join forces next month to teach some teen-age Italians the ABC's of basketball. The King brothers and their wives will spend a week in Salsonaggiore, a town of about 20,000 near Milan.

title: UPHEAVALS MOSCOW DID NOT INSPIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ecuador Debt Halt
description: Ecuador said today that it had suspended payments on $247.5 million of debts to foreign governments and banks falling due between now and the end of 1985.

title: Riegel Buyout Is Canceled
description: The Riegel Textile Corporation said that its proposed $35-a-share leveraged buyout involving a private investment concern had been canceled ''by mutual consent.'' Riegel, based in Greenville, S.C., agreed in principle last month to sell its 3.7 million shares outstanding for about $130 million to a newly formed corporation controlled by key Riegel managers and the Wesray Corporation of Morristown, N.J. The new company's option to purchase 690,000 shares of Riegel common and authorization to vote by proxy about 25 percent of Riegel shares in favor of the proposal have also been terminated, the company said.

title: No Headline
description: Chess:Karpov Wins the First Prize In the Phillips&Drew Event

title: WASHINGTON EDITOR WILL DIRECT NIEMAN PROGRAM
description: Howard A. Simons, managing editor of The Washington Post, has been selected as the new curator of the Nieman Foundation, the mid-career program for journalists at Harvard University, school officials said today.

title: Yonkers Is Sued Over Hiring Bias
description: The Federal Government filed suit yesterday against Yonkers Raceway, accusing track officials of discrimination in the hiring and recruitment of blacks, Hispanics and women over the last decade.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox , at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The Yankee rookie Jose Rijo goes for his second victory against four losses in the second of the three-game series.

title: NEWS REPORTS PAINTED SUSPECT AS AN AVENGER
description: Last week, the police hunted a man who had stabbed two Harlem drug users, killing one and seriously wounding the other.

title: Soviet-Rumanian Relations
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, told Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania at a dinner in the Kremlin today that there was room for improvement in relations between the two countries ''in the political, ideological, economic, cultural and other fields.''

title: METS TRIUMPH; YANKEES 8, RED SOX 3
description: Yogi Berra, managing the same way as he does on nights when the Yankees score only a few runs or none, was rewarded once again last night with a display of the Yankees' latent explosiveness.

title: 350 Try to Block Routes To Arms Plant in Illinois
description: About 350 protesters today tried to block bridges to Arsenal Island, home of the Federal Government's largest conventional weapons plant, but employees got to work unhampered and more than 100 demonstrators were arrested.

title: Toll at 31 in Taiwan Floods
description: Six more bodies were found in the aftermath of flooding caused by torrential rains in northern Taiwan over the weekend, pushing the death toll to 31, a police spokesman said today.

title: SHUTTLE TRIPS ARE PLANNED OVER 5 YEARS
description: A new five- year space shuttle schedule lists 98 flights on which hundreds of men and women will engage in routine and not-so-routine satellite deployments, payload repairs and secret military work.

title: Horner Out for Year
description: Bob Horner , the Atlanta Braves' third baseman, has a broken right wrist and is expected to miss the rest of the season, Dr. Robert Wells , the team physician, said yesterday.

title: EMPTY TRIUMPHS
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans' I.B.M. Action
description: The European Commission is continuing to prepare a legal decision against the International Business Machines Corporation in a long-running antimonopoly case despite new proposals made by I.B.M. aimed at securing a negotiated settlement, commission sources said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $275 million financing by the Southern California Public Power Authority was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 11 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2017, according to underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The borrowing includes $75 million of notes due in 1987 tentatively priced to yield 7 3/4 percent; serial bonds yielding from 8 3/4 percent in 1990, to 11 percent in 2000, and 11 1/4 percent bonds due in 2004 offered at 99 1/2 to yield 11.31 percent.

title: HORIZONS: COMPUTER PROGRAMS
description: THE major innovation of this year's New York Philharmonic Horizons festival is a three concert mini-festival devoted to computer music and coordinated by the composers Roger Reynolds and Charles Wuorinen. In addition, there were two symposiums on Friday devoted to the illustration and discussion of the field, and other programs have included works that involved computers in their composition (Hans Werner Henze's ''Tristan'' on Thursday) or performance (George Lewis's ''Rainbow Family'' on Friday).

title: ITT Wins Order
description: The Turkish Government said it would award the ITT Corporation a $300 million order for advanced telephone switching equipment, ending weeks of doubt about the transaction. Veysel Atasoy, Minister for Transportation and Communications, told a parliamentary committee that ITT's switch was less expensive and more technically advanced than those of two competitors for the contract.

title: No Headline
description: A New Something in Managua For all its fortuitous timing, George Shultz's surprise stopover in Nicaragua is just what the Secetary of State called it - ''constructive.'' Direct contacts of themselves won't end a bitter dispute. But if pursued, they can at least impel antagonists to stop shouting and start talking about settlement terms. In Central America especially, that's something - and for the Reagan Administration, that would be something new.

title: Indian Aircraft Decision
description: The Indian Government plans to announce in a month its decision on whether to buy Boeing or Airbus Industrie aircraft for Air India, the international carrier, and Indian Airlines, a domestic company, an Indian Airlines official said today. The contract is worth about $2 billion.

title: MEXICO AID SAID TO GET BACKING
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave his support today to a plea by the head of the International Monetary Fund that the world's leading banks lower the interest rates they charge on loans to Mexico and give that country more time to repay its debts, according to banking sources.

title: Elizabeth Peer, Senior Writer For Newsweek, Is Dead at 48
description: Elizabeth Peer, a senior writer for Newsweek, was found dead last Friday in her Manhattan apartment. She was on sick leave, but the cause of her death has not been determined.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: STERIVET LABS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income All amounts are in Canadian funds.

title: SOVIET, REACTNG TO RUMORS, DENIES SAKHAROV DIED
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass said today that Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife were ''in good health and not starving.'' It described reports abroad about Dr. Sakharov's death as ''nothing more than invention.''

title: Another Pipe Bomb Found
description: A detonated pipe bomb was found today in a park near the lakefront, and the police said it was similar to 18 homemade bombs found in three Middle Western states since Memorial Day weekend. The bomb, which was found about 1 P.M. at the Daley Bicentennial Plaza, was the third found in Chicago since Thursday. No injuries were reported.

title: CAMPAIGNING WITH MONDALE IN 'FOOTBALL GAME'S FIFTH INNING
description: With jet engines to carry him, and cameras waiting at each airport stop to transmit his presence, a candidate's day now is limited only by his money, endurance and will. And so Walter F. Mondale raced eastward all Sunday night, and westward all this day, carrying his campaign from California to New Jersey and back again - in 25 numbing hours.

title: STOP-LOSS ORDER'S USES
description: MANY investors lament that they failed to sell stocks soon enough - either to limit losses or to preserve profits - during the protracted market decline of the last 12 months.

title: Estelle Ekstrand of Sweden; A Leader of the Girl Scouts
description: Estelle Manville Bernadotte Ekstrand, a leader in the International Red Cross and Girl Scout movements, died May 28 in Uppsala, Sweden, after a long illness. She was 79 years old and lived in St.-Paul-de-Vence, a village near Nice, France.

title: Toyota-ASC Deal
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it had agreed to jointly produce Toyota Celica GT-S convertible models with ASC Inc. of Southgate, Mich.

title: THE REAL VILLIAN IN YANKEE DRAMA
description: ''Well, I'm still here,'' Yogi Berra volunteered when the first wave hit the beach four hours before game time.

title: OPERA: 'ABELARD AND HELOISE' BY ROBERT WARD
description: A GREAT subject is a dangerous thing for any but the greatest composers of opera: It can evoke such stirring associations for the listener that the music affixed to it seems trivial, even offensive, unless it is music on the order of Wagner's for Iseult or Mozart's for Don Juan. Robert Ward's opera on the great love of Abelard and Heloise, given its local premiere last Thursday in concert form by the New York Opera Repertory Theater, in the City Center, is well written in many ways, but pales and withers before its story.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NIGHTMARE OF REASON: A Life of Franz Kafka. By Ernst Pawel. 466 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.50.

title: A CLOSER LOOK AT COMPUTER MONITORS
description: THE one element of computing that seems to generate no fear is the monitor. To a generation nurtured by television, electronic images are as familiar as the breakfast cereal often consumed in front of them. So it comes as a surprise to many people that a video display, the picture window into the computer, is a relatively new addition to the machine.

title: CHERNENKO DESERVES TO BE AT NORMANDY
description: Tomorrow, President Reagan will stand with Queen Elizabeth I, Francois Mitterrand, Pierre Elliott Trudeau and other Western Allied leaders on the beaches of France to commemorate D-Day. Konstantin U. Chernenko will not be there. And that is the story of a missed opportunity.

title: Nancy Teeters Gets Post With I.B.M.
description: Nancy H. Teeters, the first woman to serve as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, was named yesterday to be director of the economics department at the International Business Machines Corporation. She succeeds Alvin J. Karchere, who retired from I.B.M. last November.

title: Hance Calls for Recount In Texas Senate Race
description: Representative Kent Hance called today for a recount of the Democratic Senate runoff, after official figures showed him losing to State Senator Lloyd Doggett by 467 votes out of almost a million cast.

title: SHOULD TRADE IN ANCIENT ARTIFACTS BE RESTRICTED?
description: Have foreign museums and collectors the same moral right to the ownership of archeological artifacts as the countries in which they are found?

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 5, 1984 International
description: NATO'S possible renunciation of the use of force could be discussed with Moscow if the Kremlin agreed to a specific set of measures to limit the risk of military confrontation in Europe, according to a proposal by President Reagan. In a speech to Ireland's Parliament, Mr. Reagan also said Washington wanted to ''reach out'' to Moscow to reduce world tensions. (Page A1, Column 6.) Little Irish excitement was stirred by President Reagan's three-day visit despite all the preparation and the considerable publicity that preceded it. Almost everywhere, the public response was lukewarm. (A12:1-3.)

title: WHAT ARE THE RUSSIANS UP TO?
description: A test of wills is taking place between the White House and the Kremlin - a test that the United States cannot afford to lose. Vascillating enemies get nothing but contempt from the Russians. Yet an enemy who staunchly refuses to treat them with respect cannot expect to get much from them either.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 13
description: Year-ago second quarter ended April 30, 1983.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CUOMO BACKS STATE PENSION RISE
description: Governor Cuomo and the leaders of the Legislature said today that they would support a cost-of- living increase to raise the pensions of retired public employees.

title: TIGERS BEAT BLUE JAYS ON HOMER IN 10TH
description: Dave Bergman belted a three-run homer with two out in the 10th inning tonight to lift the Detroit Tigers to a 6-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays in the first game of a four-game series.

title: REAGAN GIVEN BIG BILLING IN IRELAND, BUT PEOPLE'S RESPONSE IS LUKEWARM
description: Despite all the preparation and ballyhoo, President Reagan's three-day trip to Ireland stirred little public excitement.

title: RULING ON JUVENILE DETENTION: PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: Law enforcement officials hailed yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding New York State's preventive detention statute as a victory for law enforcement and the juvenile-justice system nationwide. To advocates of juvenile rights, however, the ruling in the case, Schall v. Martin, was a fresh reminder that a system initially designed to insulate young people from the harshest elements of the criminal-justice system was in fact being used to deprive them of vital constitutional safeguards to which they would otherwise be entitled.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE merchandising of Michael

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in October 1983.

title: 4 Injured on Six Flags Ride
description: A mechanical problem caused a roller coaster at the Six Flags Over Georgia amusement park to stop abruptly, sending four people to a hospital Sunday in the second incident in a week at the tourist attraction. Ron Ebert, the park's maintenance director, said the ride was repaired and put back into service with no more problems. On the previous Sunday, 34 passengers on the park's ''Great Air Race'' ride were injured after a computer malfunction caused the ride's cables to drop the planes out of position.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Gretzky Named M.V.P.
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers was named the winner of the Hart Trophy last night as the National Hockey League's most valuable player for a record fifth consecutive year. Only Bobby Orr won it three times, in 1970-72.

title: D-Day Joins the Lexicon
description: -day is the day on which a military attack or other important operation is to take place, and especially refers to June 6, 1944, when the Allied invasion of Western Europe started during World War II. After an operation begins, subsequent days are termed, for example, D plus 2, D plus 3. The expression was not widely used until World War II.

title: Another Carrier Will Relieve Kitty Hawk Near Persian Gulf
description: The United States aircraft carrier America is en route to the Indian Ocean to replace another carrier, the Kitty Hawk, which has been patrolling the approach to the Persian Gulf, Defense Department officials said today.

title: METS TRIUMPH; METS 4, PIRATES 2
description: Batting slumps, as ball players often say, will come and go. But, as Darryl Strawberry can testify, they often leave such deep emotional scars that they're seldom, if ever, forgotten.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Catchy Quote
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter's

title: No Headline
description: OF all human relationships, perhaps none has as much potential for intimacy as that of therapist and client.

title: RAYMOND I. DWIER
description: Raymond I. Dwier, a former Mayor of Hamilton Township, died Saturday in Hamilton Hospital.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY REAGAN IN IRELAND
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address today to Ireland's Parliament, as made available by White House officials:

title: No Headline
description: NEW YORK

title: Dog Walkers Lose A Legal Loophole
description: The State Legislature voted today to close a loophole in the law requiring people who walk dogs in New York City and Yonkers to clean up after them.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ed Emory , the football coach at East Carolina, removed his name from consideration for the vacant head coaching job at Miami of Florida. . . . Doug Williams , the quarterback for the Oklahoma Outlaws, underwent arthroscopic surgery on both knees yesterday and will miss the final three games of the season.

title: A PITCHER WHO LIKES TO HIT
description: Of the dozens of telephone calls made to the Pacillo residence in Rutherford, N.J., yesterday morning, noon and night, the one that will be remembered the longest is the one that occurred some time after 1 P.M. The receiver was handed to Pat Pacillo, a right-handed pitcher and outfielder from Seton Hall University who had been waiting at home in the hope of hearing the news. Pacillo did not have to wait very long.

title: PICK A NUMBER, ANY POLITCALLY POWERFUL NUMBER
description: Numbers. Capitol Hill feeds on numbers, some authoritative, some spurious, to buttress arguments and gain votes. Even when the numbers are conflicting, they often become the focus of a debate in Congress, setting its perimeters and sometimes determining the outcome.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
Boxing Bans
description: Roy Johnson, the chief inspector for the New Jersey Athletic Commission, has recommended that three boxers managed by Don White of Spartanburg, S. C., not be allowed to fight again in New Jersey until their skills have improved enough to gain the approval of the commission. All three were stopped in less than three rounds in fights May 28 at the Playboy Club and Casino in Atlantic City.

title: BEER AND MEMORIES OF THE FIRST SUCCESS OF D-DAY
description: The Navy assigned three artists to record the Normandy landing. An exhibit of their works opens Wednesday in Washington.

title: LABOR 'HURTING' IN HUNGTINGTON, W.VA.
description: The men make railroad cars, and many of them have just been called back to work after long layoffs. What they had to say at a lunch break the other day could make Walter F. Mondale a bit nervous as the contest Tuesday for West Virginia's delegates to the Democratic National Convention approaches.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II reports earnings for As of May 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The year-earlier period's inception was Sept. 1, 1983.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Children, by definition, are not assumed to have the capacity to take care of themselves.

title: Three Governorships,6 Senate Seats on Ballots By The Associated Press
description: Six United States Senate seats and three governorships are on primary ballots around the nation today.

title: U.S. Electronics Branch
description: The American Electronics Association opened its first overseas branch in Tokyo today, seeking to stimulate sales of American electronics products in Japan, officials announced. The association, which is partly financed by the United States Department of Commerce, will collect information on Japanese electronics industries and send it to member companies.

title: JACKSON BATTLING TO WIN MORE HISPANIC SUPPORT
description: With his opposition to a proposed change in the immigration laws and his trip to Mexico last week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has been running hard to make more real the Hispanic component of his ''rainbow coalition.''

title: Arthur Bell, 51, a Columnist, Homosexual Rights Activist
description: Arthur Bell, a columnist for The Village Voice and a homosexual rights activist, died Saturday night at St. Vincent's Hospital of complications arising from diabetes. He was 51 years old.

title: NEW ASSAULT ON TAX SHELTERS
description: Tax shelters - investments much favored by movie stars, sports figures, top business executives, politicians and other high- income taxpayers seeking to cut their tax bills - are expected to come under siege again when Senate and House conferees begin deliberations this week, possibly Wednesday, on a compromise tax bill.

title: Bombs Away at Graduation
description: Three teen-agers buzzed Concord High School's graduation ceremony in a Cessna 172 on Sunday and bombed the audience with tennis balls, officials said today. The authorities would not release the names of the three 19-year-olds, but the pilot, a 1983 graduate of the school, surrendered his pilot's license today. The pilot could be fined up to $10,000, Federal officials said, and the state police were considering charges of reckless endangering.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: VIDEO CASSETTE DEVICES: BOOM BRINGS WARINESS
description: Buoyed by strong consumer demand and a Supreme Court decision in January that legitimized home taping of television programs, sales of video cassette recorders have soared this year. Some manufacturers say there could be a shortage by year's end.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOR STALLED WESTWAY, A TIME OF DECISION
description: Just south of Pier 40, above the Holland Tunnel, a gray-hulled survey vessel named the Atlantic Twin rocked gently in the Hudson. A green net ringed with orange floats was hauled aboard. The catch: 16 striped bass, 1 white perch, 1 winter flounder and 1 blue crab.

title: CINEMAX CAMPAIGN BY BATES
description: WHEN the National Cable Television Association got down to the serious business of its annual convention in Las Vegas yesterday, those among the 15,000 in attendance who take their chocolate chip cookies seriously made for the booth that Cinemax shares with its big brother, Home Box Office.

title: Debt Issues
description: Bank of England announced further segments of four existing government bonds covering the full maturity range.

title: VOTING IN CALIFORNIA AND IN JERSEY TODAY IS VIEWED CRITICAL
description: The Democratic Presidential aspirants pressed their primary election campaigns yesterday with appeals to the New Jersey and California voters who can determine whether the nomination struggle is effectively ended today or continues to the convention in July.

title: MICRO GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Net income.

title: Czechoslovakia Expels 2 British Diplomats
description: Czechoslovakia has ordered two British diplomats to leave the country within two weeks for ''activities incompatible with their mission.''

title: CANADIAN ANSWER TO A HYDROPOWER ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STEEL'S LONG ROAD BACK
description: David M. Roderick's controversial strategy for the United States Steel Corporation - heavy layoffs and plant closures in its money-losing steel operations while diversifying into other areas, notably petroleum - is finally beginning to pay off.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE WOULD DISCUSS NONUSE OF FORCE
description: President Reagan told the Irish Parliament today that he would be willing to discuss with the Soviet Union the possibility of a NATO renunciation of the use of force if Moscow would agree to a specific set of measures to limit the risk of military confrontation in Europe.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF THE 'WILD MAN' OF CHINA
description: WUHAN, CHINA ONE evening last April in Cangyuan County north of China's border with Burma, a schoolteacher named Li Mingzhi heard the village dogs bark. He took his hunting rifle, thinking a wild animal was prowling about, and went out into the bright moonlight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Amerace Corp., a hose and hydraulic products company, said a group led by the New York City investor Ivan Boesky had sold its 5.7 percent holding in the company, which the group said had been bought for investment purposes.

title: REAGAN REBUFFED IN SOVIET REACTION
description: In a prompt Soviet comment on President Reagan's speech in Dublin, a Soviet writer said today that he had found ''nothing new'' in the offers of new talks and better relations with Moscow.

title: 13 ARE INJURED IN A FLASH FIRE IN A RESTAURANT
description: Thirteen people were injured yesterday, two seriously, when a propane gas tank used to heat a food cart caused a flash fire and touched off a panic among diners in a busy Chinatown restaurant near the end of the lunch hour.

title: Berry to Penguins
description: Bob Berry , who was dismissed in February as the coach of the Montreal Canadiens, was named coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins yesterday. The 40-year-old Berry replaced Lou Angotti , who coached the Penguins to only 16 victories last season.

title: LARGEST NURSE STRIKE AFFECTS A 16TH HOSPITAL IN MINNESOTA
description: The largest nurses' strike in the nation's history spread to a 16th hospital in the metropolitan area today, and most hospitals performed only emergency surgery.

title: POPULATION BOOM SPURS TUCSON GROWTH DEBATE
description: When Rowena Sinclair Weeks came here about 30 years ago, Old Spanish Trail was still a dirt road winding from the city's east side into the Saguaro National Monument, a park devoted to Arizona's famous snake-armed cactuses.

title: Family Media Unit
description: Family Media, publisher of The Ladies' Home Journal, 1,001 Home Ideas, Health and The Homeowner, has established a subsidiary called Family Media Communications.

title: 7 Boats Turn Back Seven of the 92 boats that left Plymouth, England, Saturday at the start of the single-handed trans-Atlantic race to Newport, R.I., had to return to port. Three retired from the 3,000- mile race; two were making repairs and planned to re-start, and the two others rejoined the race yesterday.
description: -year-old Briton sailing the 40-foot trimaran Bachelor's Sweet Pea, was capsized in rough seas off Cornwall within 10 hours of the start. She was treated at a hospital for exposure. Her boat was lost.

title: U.N. UNIT TO HEAR APPEAL TODAY FOR SAKHAROV
description: Relatives of Andrei D. Sakharov will testify on Tuesday before a working group of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to seek assistance in determining the whereabouts of the Soviet dissident and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of May 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: No Headline
description: Speeding Up the Toxic Cleanup The Superfund program to clean up abandoned toxic dump sites has not been a startling success. Of the nation's 550 worst sites, only 6 have been cleaned up, while many more have been added to the list. Can the cleanup go faster? Yes, according to an interesting new proposal made by the chemical industry and two environmental groups.

title: Special Provisions On Utility Bonds
description: Several investor-owned electric utilities are arranging sales of tax-exempt pollution control revenue bonds with special provisions that allow investors to recover their principal by selling the bonds back to the issuer after three years.

title: CONSUMERS REBUFFED ON RIGHT TO CHALLENGE 'MARKET ORDERS'
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Congress did not give consumers the right to go to court to challenge the prices for raw agricultural commodities set by the Department of Agriculture in hundreds of ''market orders.''

title: OUTFIELDER IS TOP PICK OF METS
description: Shawn Abner was a guest of the Mets at Shea Stadium over the weekend. The 17-year-old outfielder from Mechanicsburg High School in Pennsylvania sat in a box seat behind the dugout with his parents and younger brother, Chris, and watched the Mets beat the St. Louis Cardinals Saturday and then lose to them on Sunday. He spent some time in the locker room, speaking with players and team officials.

title: RENT-RISE HEARING IS A SHOUTING MATCH
description: The Rent Guidelines Board heard arguments, pleas, catcalls and obscenities in two languages yesterday from landlords and tenants in a hearing to determine what increases should be allowed on rent-stabilized apartments.

title: RECORD SET IN SECRET RACE
description: Two Middle Westerners who raced by car from Boston to San Diego at an average speed of 86 miles an hour said today that they had not received a single speeding ticket. At least six other drivers in the cross-country run were arrested on New York parkways.

title: U.S. ARRESTS 6 SUSPECTS IN FLORIDA IN NATIONWIDE MONEY LAUNDERING
description: Federal agents have arrested six people and are seeking eight others in a nationwide money- laundering organization based here that officials said passed millions of dollars through Miami banks.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Year to March 25
description: b-Net loss.

title: COUNTRYSIDE IS SEARCHED IN VAIN FOR FOUR PRISONERS
description: Searchers, armed with shotguns, dashed about the countryside near the Virginia-North Carolina line today responding to reported sightings of four killers who broke out of death row. The searchers came up empty-handed each time.

title: RCA Sues Esprit
description: Esprit Systems Inc. said the RCA Corporation had filed suit against Esprit in Federal District Court in Delaware charging patent infringement relating to the company's sale of video display terminals.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Thomson-Leeds Tie To BBDO Is Postponed
description: The acquisition of Thomson-Leeds by BBDO International has been posponed because the two companies cannot get together on the purchase details, BBDO announced yesterday.

title: ALASKA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW PLASTIC IS CONDUCTOR OF ELECTRICITY
description: RESEARCHERS at the Los Alamos National Laboratory have developed a plastic that has the highest conductivity of any known polymer and is able to carry electricity almost as efficiently as metal.

title: Charlotte Curtis
description: THORNTON and Josie Wilson's big formal dinner party the other night was their last here until fall. It was also a reminder that despite the new waves of money and power seeping into New York's upper echelons the city still has a gracious, old order.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: West Germany's gross national product rose 3.6 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today. Investment in machinery, equipment and construction was up, as was export demand, the office said.

title: A Suit Is Blocked On Agent Orange
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a suit seeking to compel the Veterans Administration to provide a ''uniform system'' of ''complete medical care'' for veterans and their families who said they had suffered harm from the use by the United States of Agent Orange in Vietnam.

title: NOTED EDUCATOR FORESEES RESURGENCE IN TEACHING
description: AFTER 10 years as president of the Teachers College of Columbia University, Lawrence A. Cremin is stepping down this summer to return to full-time teaching and research. Among his projects will be the third volume of his Pulitzer Prize-winning historical study, ''American Education.'' Mr. Cremin talked with The Times about teaching and teacher education. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Agreement Is Reached On World's Fair Taxes
description: City and World's Fair negotiators reached a preliminary agreement today in their dispute over millions of dollars in unpaid fair taxes, officials said.

title: U.S. COLONEL DOUBTS SALVADOR REBELS CAN OPEN MAJOR DRIVE
description: The head of the American military advisers here said today that if the Salvadoran Army remains on the attack there ''is a good chance'' the leftist insurgents will be unable to launch the major offensive Washington officials have predicted for the fall.

title: No Headline
description: Ivan Lendl, seeking his first Grand Slam title, powered his way past Anders Jarryd of Sweden, and Jimmy Connors overcame first-set trouble to rout Emilio Sanchez of Spain in the French Open today. Both winners moved into the quarterfinals.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months reflect a nonrecurring charge of $707,000 for litigation expenses incurred in the second quarter.

title: MAN CHARGED IN FLATBUSH RAPES
description: A 26-year-old unemployed man was charged last night with six rapes and robberies in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and is a suspect in five other rapes there, the police said last night.

title: Turkish Cypriot Move Called 'Unhelpful' by U.S.
description: The United States said today that Turkish Cypriots had been allowed to settle in an uninhabited area of Famagusta and called the action ''unhelpful'' to finding a solution of the Cyprus dispute.

title: Bechtel Seeks U.S. Aid For Iraq-Jordan Pipeline
description: The Bechtel Group Inc. has asked the Export-Import Bank for financing help in the construction of a $1 billion oil pipeline from Iraq to Jordan, officials said today.

title: INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONIC HARDARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
LITERATURE LESSONS
description: Grendel's Family

title: Of Roots and the Grange
description: The Rev. Ellen Barrett's great-

title: Claim on Lion By Bradford
description: The vice president of the Bradford Trust Company in Manhattan testified before an Assembly committee today that his bank had exclusive claim to $46 million in government securities desposited there by the Lion Capital Group, a small investment house that declared bankruptcy last month.

title: Peru's Debt Rescheduled
description: Western governments have agreed to reschedule Peru's payments on $1.046 billion in debt falling due in the next 13 months, Peru's Prime Minister, Sandro Mariategui, said today.

title: 'Moon' to Close Saturday
description: ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' the revival of the Eugene O'Neill play, will close after Saturday evening's performance at the Cort Theater. Directed by David Leveaux and co-starring Kate Nelligan and Ian Bannen, the drama will have run for 19 previews and 40 regular performances.

title: Alfa Romeo Narrows Loss
description: Alfa Romeo S.p.A., parent company of Italy's state-owned auto maker, said today that it had narrowed its loss to the equivalent of $15.9 million in 1983 from $44.5 million in 1982.

title: DANCE: SUSAN JAFFE AS 'CINDERELLA'
description: SUSAN JAFFE made her local debut in the title role of American Ballet Theater's ''Cinderella'' Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, presumably the last of the company's dancers to do so this season.

title: MESA DEAL WITH PENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Corporation and the Mesa Petroleum Company agreed yesterday to exchange notes and securities in a transaction valued at more than $1.1 billion.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: VAGINAL yeast infections are probably the most common plague of women in their childbearing years, and to judge from various indicators they are becoming more so.

title: Chesebrough Posts Big Stock Gain
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said that the sharp rise in its stock on the New York Stock Exchange was not the result of any corporate action. Responding to a rumor linking it with Revlon Inc., the company said it had had ''no contact'' with Revlon.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss The year-earlier results were restated to reflect a retroactive change in accounting policy from the worldwide full-cost method of accounting with respect to oil and gas activities, to the more generally accepted country-by-country full-cost method. Westburne said that the accounting change required a $10.6 million charge against previously reported 1983 earnings of $8.7 million, or 83 cents a share.

title: DANCE:'EVENT OF YEAR,' THE PRIDE OF D'AMBOISE
description: JACQUES D'AMBOISE created the world anew and filled it with happy dancing children. The occasion was the National Dance Institute's annual ''Event of the Year'' in the Felt Forum.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption Thursday with an article about flooding in New Jersey incorrectly identified the area from which people were leaving their homes by boat. It was in an area of Lincoln Park flooded by the Pompton River.

title: BRIEFING
description: The State of State

title: REAGAN'S IRISH LUCK
description: The Soviet Union says there is ''nothing new'' in President Reagan's latest proposals for reducing tension between Moscow and the NATO allies, but as usual it's got him wrong.

title: IN TRANQUIL GUADELOUPE, A CHALLENGE TO PARIS
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe - The inhabitants of this island in the French West Indies converse in French spiced with a melodious Creole patois. They purchase goods with the franc, read of world events in Paris newspapers and enhance their lives with French social services.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our sovereignty was violated and we reacted, as we said we would all along, in a defensive manner.

title: ;  People
description: * Hank Shafran has joined Cone & Company as partner and executive vice president.

title: 500,000 AFGHANS ARE REPORTED TO FACE STARVATION
description: About 500,000 people in Afghanistan are in imminent danger of starvation, according to a report released yesterday in Manhattan by an independent British group that is urging the United Nations to provide aid.

title: TERRELL STOPS HIS SLIDE
description: An evening after the Mets' most important power hitter hit his first home run in more than a month, the pitcher the team most depends upon ended a five-week-long losing streak in extraordinary fashion tonight.

title: Homeless Get Vote In District of Columbia
description: The city's Board of Elections and Ethics has decided that some people who live in the streets may vote.

title: Philadelphia to Hire 151 Blacks as Firemen
description: The Fire Department has agreed to fill 12 percent of its next 1,250 positions with black firefighters, ending a 10- year-old civil rights suit.

title: ON VERSE AND VERVE: 2 AMERICANS CHARM CHINESE
description: One recent afternoon, more than 200 Chinese students and teachers jammed a classroom at Hebei Normal University to spend a couple of hours listening to two American scholars read the poetry of Edgar Lee Masters and Ezra Pound, of Robert Frost and Archibald MacLeish.

title: PBS OFFERS 'MIKADO' TONIGHT
description: ''MODIFIED rapture'': how often has a critic borrowed that ironic exclamation in response to a flawed but enjoyable Gilbert and Sullivan production? The show from which it comes is ''The Mikado,'' which ends this season's schedule for the PBS ''Compleat Gilbert and Sullivan'' series tonight at 9 o'clock. The production's success is, well, modified - but it's well worth seeing for some delectable solo performances.

title: ;  Accounts
description: * Banco de Ponce to Badillo/Compton.

title: MONDALE TOPS HART IN WEST VIRGINIA POPULAR VOTE
description: Walter F. Mondale easily won the nonbinding popular vote in West Virginia's Democratic Presidential primary today.

title: Austerity In Philippines
description: President Ferdinand Marcos announced a tough economic recovery package today that raises taxes, cuts the budget and effectively devalues the peso by allowing it to float against the dollar.

title: Top Ride for Cauthen
description: Steve Cauthen , the American jockey who has been competing in Britain, has received one of the top riding assignments there.

title: CONTINENTAL: CANS AND MORE
description: The Continental Group, the diversified can company, has spent several years reshaping itself. In 1977, it acquired several insurance companies, and two years later, an oil and gas company. Last year, it shed part of its paper operations and bought back a large chunk of its stock.

title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE ; MOVE BY A BANK TO DOWNTOWN ALBANY
description: Many a mayor of an aging city has watched in frustration as major companies abandoned downtown offices to move to the suburbs.

title: 2 IRANIAN FIGHTERS REPORTED DOWNED BY SAUDI AIR FORCE
description: Two Saudi Arabian fighter pilots shot down two American-built Iranian F-4 fighters today, Saudi and United States officials said.

title: KEY LEADERS IN ALBANY AGREE ON REQUIRING SEAT-BELT USE
description: Key legislators have agreed that New York should require motorists to wear seat belts.

title: SITE NEAR SHEA FAVORED FOR DOMED STADIUM
description: A 179-acre area adjoining Shea Stadium in Queens is the leading choice as the site for a domed sports stadium in New York City, the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: MERRILL'S CHIEF WILL STEP DOWN
description: In a surprise move, Roger E. Birk, chairman and chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch & Company, the parent of the world's largest securities firm, announced yesterday that he plans to retire as chief executive officer July l. William A. Schreyer, currently president of the holding company, will become chief executive as well. Mr. Birk plans to remain working full time as chairman until July 14, 1985, his 55th birthday.

title: END TO SUSPENSION ASKED BY VASQUEZ
description: Jacinto Vasquez took the witness stand yesterday to deliver an angry tirade about his innocence and the injustice of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. The appearance came at a hearing in which his attorneys argued that new evidence they presented should overturn the jockey's one-year suspension from racing.

title: Economic Scene; Latin Appeals To Ease Debts
description: THAT celebrated cynic, the Count de la Rochefoucauld, once observed, ''With what fortitude we bear the misfortunes of others.''

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 13
Chairman Resigning Chicago Options Post
description: Robert Cruikshank, the top elected official of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, said yesterday that he would resign his exchange post and quit the options business as soon as he could close out his trading positions, a task that he estimated would take a ''few weeks.''

title: LONGER THAN EONS
description: I guess you kids didn't think it was ever going to happen, did you? I was that way myself once. I remember my granddaddy - oh, this was way, way back there - and the old fellow saying, ''Now you ain't going to believe this, Jasper, but you're going to live to see the end of these here Democratic primaries.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Key Executives Quit at Paramount
description: Two top marketing executives in the motion pictures division at Paramount Pictures resigned yesterday in disputed circumstances.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fernando Zobel, 60, Painter;Founded a Museum in Spain
description: Fernando Zobel, a painter who founded a contemporary art museum in the provincial Spanish town of Cuenca, died of a heart attack last Saturday while on holiday in Rome. He was 60 years old.

title: ADMINISTRATION TELLS NEW DOUBTS ON PLAN TO STRENGTHEN BIAS LAWS
description: Reagan Administration officials expressed new concern today about legislation designed restore the Government's power to enforce civil rights laws at schools and colleges receiving Federal aid.

title: GAC LIQUIDATING TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.N. PANEL ON MISSING PEOPLE URGED TO TAKE SAKHAROV CASE
description: Aleksei I. Semyonov, a stepson of Andrei D. Sakharov, told a human rights panel today that the disappearance of the physicist and rights advocate was ''an attempt to silence him forever, one way or another.''

title: BARK'S SURVIVOR TELLS OF FREAK 'KILLER SQUALL'
description: ''It meant to kill us,'' said John Ash, a 23-year-old survivor of the British bark Marques that sank Sunday with the apparent loss of 18 lives. ''It was a killer squall. There was nothing we could do.''

title: An Ex-Champion Will Stay Retired
description: He was tripping over his feet, unsure of himself, but the worst thing was that the punches hurt more than he remembered. Thus, Danny (Little Red) Lopez, the popular former World Boxing Council featherweight champion, will leave well enough alone and remain retired.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Is Off 6.68 as Volume Declines
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in less active trading after advancing sharply in the two previous sessions.

title: WINE TALK
description: It's a few minutes before 10 A.M. on a typical spring day and the first tour buses are pulling into the parking lot at the Sebastiani Winery in this town 60 miles north of San Francisco. The passengers alight. They are elderly women in blue-rinsed hair and pastel pants suits, their male counterparts in sport shirts and bolo ties.

title: THE FORGOTTEN FRONT: FOR SOLDIERS WHO TOOK ROME, GLORY WAS FLEETING
description: Herbert Mitgang of The New York Times served as an Army correspondent in North Africa and Italy during World War II.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates at Pittsburgh. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: OUR ERA OF PUZZLING LEADERSHIP CHOICES
description: To the Editor:

title: NED McDAVID
description: Ned McDavid, former president of McDavid/Sykes Associates Inc., a New York public-relations concern that later merged with Booke & Company, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in Grayton Beach, Fla. He was 56 years old.

title: TRIED AND FAILED PATH TO ARAB-ISRAELI PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: 90 WORKS BY PAUL KLEE DONATED TO MET MUSEUM
description: Ninety works by the Swiss master Paul Klee, one of the most popular and elusive modern artists, have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Heinz Berggruen, a leading collector and retired art dealer who lives in Geneva.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Scott Humbled After Boasting
description: ''I think,'' Byron Scott once bragged, ''I can be another Norm Nixon.''

title: CONCERT: FRANK SINATRA AT CARNEGIE BENEFIT
description: AMID the hoopla that inevitably surrounds Frank Sinatra's concerts, like the 13- night stand at Carnegie Hall that started Monday with a black-tie benefit for the hall, the singer himself has become disarmingly low-key.

title: THE MARCH OF DIMES PAYS TRIBUTE TO A PRIME FUND-RAISER
description: THE squab breasts came from Chicago, along with the sauce rouennaise, while the puff pastry that encased them was flown in from Philadelphia. The shrimp, which were caught Sunday in the Gulf of Mexico, arrived in New York to be bathed in a Belle Creole sauce that had been made in New Orleans, while the cr eme de moules aux quenelles a la moelle was taxied over from the combined kitchens of La C^ote Basque and Lut ece.

title: Freighter Seized With Drugs
description: Eight men were arrested Sunday aboard a freighter carrying 17 tons of marijuana, the Coast Guard said Monday. The four Colombians, three Dominicans and an Ecuadoran and their 156- foot freighter, Mrs. White, were turned over to the Federal and local authorities, according to the Coast Guard. The freighter was about 140 miles east of Miami when she was stopped by the Coast Guard cutter Liban.

title: HOUSE VOTE ADOPTS MEASURE TO PROTECT AIRLINE PASSENGERS
description: The House today passed legislation to extend consumer protection that sponsors of the bill suggested might be lost when the Civil Aeronautics Board closes up shop at the end of the year.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Theodore D. Cohn, P

title: No Headline
description: Replacement Is Named For Deputy at U.S.I.A.

title: FOR DANCERS, A BATTLE OF CALORIES VS. ART
description: ''MY dream dinner would be a pizza with pepperoni, a baked potato with sour cream and scallions, and for dessert a white chocolate mousse,'' the New York City Ballet dancer Heather Watts said recently. ''I'm not very disciplined so I don't know what I'd do if I put on weight. I couldn't starve to dance.''

title: No Headline
description: In a record performance tonight by the teams and the fans at the College World Series, Arizona State defeated Oklahoma State, 23-12. It was the highest scoring game in the tournament's history and it was played before a record 15,678 fans.

title: PIZZA KING AND HIS TIGERS
description: DETROIT The two best records in baseball

title: POP:JOHNNY MERCER TRIBUTE
description: IN a brilliant coda to this season's

title: Dog Dies, and Auburn Is Next Heir in Line
description: The death of Musketeer, the last of 150 stray dogs that lived off the $12 million estate of an eccentric oil company heiress, has cleared the way for Auburn University to inherit the fortune.

title: LED CONSERVATIVE JEWISH UNIT
description: Rabbi Bernard Segal, a leading figure in Conservative Judaism, died Monday in a convalescent home in Jerusalem. He was 76 years old and had lived in Jerusalem since 1977.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO BID ALLIES ACT AGAINST TERRORISM
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher conferred today amid indications that they would press other Western leaders this week for a commitment to improve efforts to combat terrorism.

title: UNITED WESTBURNE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
Bank Is Closed By Venezuela
description: The Venezuelan Government said today that it was closing the nation's seventh-largest bank, the state-owned Banco Nacional de Descuento, after efforts to save it failed. ''In view of the critical financial situation facing the B.N.D., the national executive has been forced to suspend its activities,'' the Government said in a brief statement.

title: SIKHS' DRIVE: WHAT IT'S FOR, HOW IT BEGAN
description: The drive for Punjabi political autonomy and Sikh religious rights, now overshadowed by terrorist violence, opened peacefully enough nearly two years ago. But its roots go back to the partition in 1947 when the Sikhs found themselves stranded between Hindus and Moslems.

title: Aerospace Merger Talk
description: Britain's General Electric Company has emerged as the favorite in a possible bidding war for British Aerospace P.L.C. following the announcement Friday that General Electric's Lord Weinstock had discussed the acquisition with Sir Austin Pearce, Aerospace's chairman.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cherry and Dara In Friday's 'On Time'
description: A suggested warmup to get the ears in shape for the coming Kool Festival Jazz overload: the ''On Time'' concert series taking place Fridays at the Village Gate. This week's show will provide a rare chance to hear two of the most original trumpet stylists of the new jazz, Don Cherry (performing in a duo with the drummer Ed Blackwell) and Olu Dara, appearing with his Okra Orchestra. Doors open at 10:30 P.M. and there are two shows nightly; admission is $10.

title: A MUSICAL FEAST, ACCOMPANIED BY BRIE
description: ONE night last week at the invitation of Kitty Benton (violin, B) and Dr. John Austin (violin, viola, A; double bass, B), nearly 50 amateur string players gathered on a barge at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn for an evening of eating and playing music. The occasion was the anniversary of the Amateur Chamber Music Players, a nonprofit organization whose 6,000 members in more than 50 countries are linked by a passion for playing music and a directory that lists their names, addresses, instruments and self-imposed ratings.

title: PRESBYTERIAN LEADER SINCE '66 DEFEATED BY SOUTHERN CLERIC
description: William P. Thompson, whose work on the National and World Council of Churches has made him one of the world's most influential religious leaders, was defeated today by the Rev. James Andrews of Atlanta for the leadership of the newly reunified Presbyterian Church (U.S.A).

title: CLASH EXPECTED ON TAX BILLS
description: The House and the Senate meet in conference Wednesday to begin working out the differences in their tax bills, but it is already pretty much assured that consumers will face major tax increases.

title: VERSATILE SCARFS, CHILD'S BRUSH
description: 1.*Tahitian Inspiration

title: WATKINS-BRELAND A 'NATURAL'
description: There are some boxers in the 147-pound class who would have sympathized with Mylon Watkins about the luck of the draw, patted him on the back and told him to keep his guard up.

title: OPERA: RALEIGH'S STORY
description: ''Raleigh's Dream,'' a new opera with words and music by Iain Hamilton, received its world premiere here Sunday night as part of a two-week British-American Festival at Duke University.

title: DAYBREAK ON D-DAY WAS CALM; SUDDENLY THERE WAS A ROAR
description: Following are excerpts from a letter written by an 82-year-old retired Army colonel, who lives in Garrison, N.Y., to his 7-year-old grand nephew, Peter Martin Campion, of Brookline, Mass., who had written him a letter that said: ''We are going to Normandy in France. My Dad says you did fighting there? What did you do, Unk?''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 6, 1984

title: GOODBYE AND FAREWELL, THUNDER AND LIGHTNING
description: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Republican of upstate New York, will retire at the end of this year. Mr. Conable has been in Congress for 20 years and is the senior Republican on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Commmittee. Following are his thoughts on the eve of his last tax conference to work out the differences in the $49.8 billion tax increase approved in the House and the similar $47.6 billion bill approved in the Senate:

title: METHOD OF POLLS IN TWO STATES
description: The New York Times/CBS News exit poll in New Jersey is based on questionnaires completed by 2,018 Democratic voters as they left polling places in 74 randomly selected precincts in all parts of the state.

title: No Headline
description: The Israeli Army said today that four Arab guerrillas had been captured in the southern part of the Golan Heights after having broken through the fence on the Syrian border.

title: Hostage Released After 16 Hours
description: A 21-year-old Queens man surrendered to the police yesterday morning after holding a former girlfriend hostage at gunpoint in a Manhattan office for more than 16 hours, the police reported.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. , a company engaged in insurance, has named Robert H. Moore to the new position of vice president of corporate relations.

title: Article 241804 -- No Title
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, offered informally yesterday to buy the Continental Group, formerly called the Continental Can Company, for $50 a share, or at least $2.1 billion in cash.

title: MUSIC: THIRD IN SERIES OF COMPUTER WORKS
description: -music programs set in the middle of this year's Horizons festival grew bigger with each concert. The first, Sunday afternoon, was devoted to pieces for computer alone or with a single instrument; the second, Sunday evening, offered chamber forces with computers, and the third, Monday night, like the others, in Avery Fisher Hall, was for computers with orchestra.

title: CRESTBROOK FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BATTER PREVAILS IN A 13-PITCH DUEL
description: DETROIT Lance Parrish, who was on second

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JACK GASNICK is forever looking for ''a bit of country'' in the city, and one place he found it is in the stream beneath the basement of his hardware and plumbing supply company at 992 Second Avenue in Manhattan. The stream came to light many years ago when hurricane waters flooded the basement, washing away an iron grate in the dirt floor. The first thing Mr. Gasnick did, on seeing the stream, was to reach for his fishing pole and pull in a three-foot carp.

title: 1,500 in Bonn Protest South African's Visit
description: The police clashed today with some 1,500 demonstrators protesting the visit of Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa. At least nine people were arrested in the scuffles.

title: OFFICE ALLOWED ON HISTORIC SITE IN BOSTON AREA
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has agreed to allow a high- technology company to build its headquarters on a historic farm within metropolitan Boston, drawing praise from businessmen and bitter criticism from some environmentalists.

title: 'THE LIONS OF ETOSHA,' WILDLIFE DOCUMENTARY
description: ''THE LIONS OF ETOSHA: King of the Beasts'' is about as good a wildlife documentary as you will see on television and almost certainly a better film about lions than you are likely to see again. It tell us everything we wanted to know about lions except, perhaps, how dangerous they are to people. Blame this on the film makers' enthusiasm for their subject. The one-hour documentary will be seen on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: B C PACKERS reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New H.U.D. Notes Sold In Book-Entry Form
description: The sale of tax-exempt securities in book-entry form, with electronic records of ownership rather than traditional certificates, was given a boost yesterday when the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development auctioned $448.5 million of housing project notes in book-entry form. It was the first-ever sale of notes in book-entry form.

title: Staring at Immigration
description: ''I am committed,'' said House Speaker O'Neill last month, to bringing the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill to the floor right after the California primary. This is the day after the California primary and, despite past wobbles, Mr. O'Neill now looks to be as good as his word.

title: Effect on Beatrice Of Esmark Deal
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said it expects its pending acquisition of Esmark Inc. to accelerate its marketing plans by five years. James L. Dutt, chairman, said at the annual meeting that the chief objective of the Chicago-based company would be to reduce the debt incurred to finance the acquisition, noting that divestiture of a number of units yet to be determined is expected to reduce debt by ''at least $1 billion.''

title: REPORT CRITICIZES THE ROLE OF WESTWAY CONSULTANTS
description: New York State's ''total surrender of responsibility'' for the Westway to private consultants led to legal challenges that have delayed the project for several years, the State Commission of Investigation said in a report released yesterday.

title: THE BUS PROBLEM
description: In his first week as president of the Transit Authority, David L. Gunn made a decision that seemed to put one of the authority's most nagging problems to rest. After almost four years of finding cracks and other defects in the authority's 851 Grumman Flxible buses, Mr. Gunn announced that the buses were coming off the streets for good because they were unsafe.

title: JETS TAKE GILL
description: The Giants took three players now with the Los Angeles Express; the Jets chose two quarterbacks, one of whom is scheduled to play for the Montreal Concordes this season, and the Generals had six players drafted by six different teams in the National Football League.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL ARMS SALE TO SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration's emergency shipment of 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia came under attack today from Democratic and Republican members of a key Senate committee.

title: AN ISSUE INAPPROPRIATE FOR THE WORLD COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: The Canadian Government said it was issuing $850 million of bonds, including a 13 percent issue due 1987; 13.25 percent bonds due 1989; 13.50 percent bonds due 1994, and 13.75 percent bonds due 2007.

title: SUPERPOWERS' OPTION SUPERIOR TO 'STAR WARS'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Die in Jet Crash In Connecticut
description: A courier jet crashed while landing at Bradley International Airport and burst into flames, killing all three men aboard, officials said today.

title: 4 BLUE JAYS HOMERS TOPPLE TIGERS, 8-4
description: Home runs by Lloyd Moseby, Willie Aikens, Ernie Whitt and Alfredo Griffin keyed an 11-hit Toronto barrage, and the Blue Jays scored six runs in the fourth inning to beat the Detroit Tigers tonight, 8-4.

title: COURT RULES NARROWLY IN AN IMMIGRATION CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that an alien seeking political refugee status must demonstrate a ''clear probability'' of persecution in his home country to avoid imminent deportation.

title: Market Place; Stauffer's Steady Decline
description: Analysts attribute the drop in Stauffer's stock to earnings disappointments, high inventories in dealer hands, changes in farming practices, increasing competition and even wet weather.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Circus in the Park
description: A family circus act from France

title: Bridge: Greenberg Holds a Big Lead In the Knockout Team Final
description: It is rare indeed for a major final to be decided, effectively, by the first set of deals. But it happened Monday night in the Reisinger Knockout Team final at the Cavendish Club. In 16 deals Alan Greenberg, Jim Cayne, Jim Rosenbloom, Zia Mahmoud and Matt and Pam Granovetter overwhelmed their opponents, 74-1, in terms of international match points.

title: Levi Closings Set
description: Levi Strauss & Company said it plans to close plants in Georgia and New Mexico as part of a consolidation program. The company said it would close its jeans plant in Macon, resulting in the layoff of 470 workers, and a plant in Albuquerque, where 210 employees will be laid off. Last month the company said it would be closing a number of domestic plants and increasing production at others to eliminate surplus capacity.

title: A MONUMENT IS UNVEILED TO FALLEN ON UTAH BEACH
description: The writer of this dispatch covered the Allied landings in Normandy in 1944 for The New York Times and has been military correspondent for The Times since 1970.

title: PRINCETON CLASS TOLD TO SHUN ELITISM
description: William G. Bowen, the president of Princeton University, told the largest graduating class in the university's history today to ''avoid elitism of attitude'' and ''help this country be more than just a haven for those of us so fortunate as to live comfortably.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FOREIGN BODIES. By Barbara Grizzuti

title: Husky Oil Project
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said it planned to build a $3.5 billion (Canadian) crude-oil upgrading plant in Saskatchewan, the largest Canadian energy project in five and one-half years. Company officials declined to give further details of the project, but industry sources said it would be supported by more than $1 billion in Government-guaranteed loans. The plant will process 50,000 barrels of heavy crude oil a day into high-grade crude.

title: SHOREHAM PLAN IS BEING SOUGHT BY REAGAN AIDE
description: The White House science adviser, who is playing a key role in the Reagan Administration's decisions on the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, thinks that a ''clear, practical and responsible'' emergency evacuation plan can be devised for the plant.

title: INDIANS REPORT DAYLONG BATTLE AT SIKH TEMPLE
description: Army troops sent to quell violence in Punjab continued to trade fire today with Sikh terrorists firing mortars and machine guns from inside a Sikh shrine in Amritsar after a daylong battle Tuesday, the Government said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Hall of Famers
description: Bernie Parent , goaltender, and Phil Esposito and Jacques Lemaire , centers, have been selected to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Danny Gallivan , a Montreal broadcaster and chairman of the selection committee, made the announcement yesterday in Toronto. . . . The Olympic champions Harold Connolly , Randy Matson and Madeline Manning-Mims , and a longtime coach, Joe Yancey , have been elected to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame by members of a nationwide panel of writers, officials, current champions and Hall of Fame members.

title: NEW MAN AT TOP AT CHANGING GIANT
description: Soon after William A. Schreyer was elected to succeed Roger E. Birk as the chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch & Company, he was chatting with William P. Rogers, a senior partner at the law firm of Rogers & Wells, and a member of Merrill Lynch's board. As Mr. Rogers, a former Secretary of State, recounts it: ''He told me, 'I've never faced such a task since a customer asked me to get him into a growth stock with high dividends, no risk, tax-free and no down payment. He added, make it something without a lot of paperwork.' ''

title: Rose Back on First
description: Pete Rose, the Montreal Expos' left fielder, who has been relegated to the role of pinch-hitter since May 19 because of an inflamed elbow, is expected to return to the starting lineup in a few days, but not in left field.

title: FILM:BASQUE 'ESCAPE FROM SEGOVIA'
