description: IMANOL URIBE takes a crisply

title: SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: BANKS PLAN CONCESSION TO MEXICO
description: The world's leading international banks announced today that they would soon begin negotiating a long-term solution to Mexico's debt problem. Similar talks, they added, are expected to open with Brazil next fall.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: I.R.S. TO SEEK CLUES FROM STATES' DATA
description: The Internal Revenue Service, in a drive to prosecute tax cheats, has developed a plan to collect information from the states about people who, for example, register expensive automobiles or obtain licenses to be plumbers.

title: Police in Northeast Seek 11 Fugitives
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and eight Northeastern state police forces said today that they were forming a group of agents to find 11 fugitives linked to bombings, bank robberies and the murder of a New Jersey state trooper.

title: JURY SELECTION BEGINS IN BEATING DEATH OF CHINESE-AMERICAN
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of two men accused of violating the civil rights of a Chinese-American man by beating him to death after a barroom quarrel.

title: VICTIMS OF PARENTAL POLITICAL STATEMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDALE'S STRENGTH CUTS ACROSS JERSEY
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale showed strength in the suburbs and the cities yesterday in winning a substantial victory in New Jersey's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: BRADSHAW WEIGHS ANOTHER OPERATION
description: Terry Bradshaw, the quarterback who guided the Pittsburgh Steelers to four Super Bowl championships, said today that he would probably undergo elbow surgery that would likely end his playing career.

title: ;  New Pennsylvania Issue Yields 10.7%
description: A $115 million issue of Pennsylvania general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in December 1984, to 9 1/2 percent in 1994 and 10.70 percent in 2003 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The shares outstanding were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983. The company said that the results include the contributions of the 59 Bakers Square Restaurants, purchased as Poppin Fresh Restaurants from the Pillsbury Co. in May 1983 and 71 Dinnerhouse Restaurants acquired from a wholly owned unit of the Ralston Purina Co. on Feb. 17, 1984.

title: Output Rises 0.2% in E.E.C.
description: Industrial production in the European Economic Community rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, and was 6 percent above the level of March 1983, the trade bloc's statistics agency, Eurostat, said today.

title: Miami Selects Johnson
description: Jimmy Johnson of Oklahoma State accepted the head football coaching position at the University of Miami today, taking on the challenge of the team ranked No. 1 in the nation last season. Johnson replaces Howard Schnellenberger, who resigned two weeks ago to take a lucrative offer with the Miami-bound Washington Federals of the United States Football League.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Air Florida Option
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said its option to purchase up to 55 percent of the common stock of Air Florida System Inc. had been extended to Dec. 31, from Aug. 31.

title: REPORTED FELONIES ARE ON RISE IN CITY'S SUBWAYS
description: Reports of serious crime in the subways rose 13.4 percent in the first four months of this year, fueled partly by a 15.9 percent increase in April alone, the transit police said yesterday.

title: FOR CAKES AND COOKIES
description: FOR every cooking challenge, whether it is slicing mushrooms, timing soft-cooked eggs or dicing parsley, it seems there is some culinary tinkerer working on a gadget that will ease the chore. One of the more ingenious devices to come to my attention recently was designed by Isaac Garb, who, with his wife, Francine, owns a restaurant in East Quogue, L.I. His invention is called the Layer Maker.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fred Bullard , owner of the Jacksonville Bulls, who charged onto the field and repeatedly berated the officials during a game against the Houston Gamblers on May 25, was fined and barred from the sidelines for the rest of the season by Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League. The team said the fine was $2,500. However, a league source, who asked not to be identified, said the fine was $5,000.

title: I.C.C. Rule For Trucks Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today strengthened the power of the Interstate Commerce Commission to enforce the antitrust laws. The Court ruled, 5 to 4, that the I.C.C. could penalize trucking companies for antitrust violations by rescinding freight tariffs already in effect and ordering the carriers to make refunds.

title: LAY-CLERICAL TEAM IN CONNECTICUT IS A FIRST
description: In a striking departure from Roman Catholic tradition, a pastoral team made up of clerical and lay members has been named to lead a new parish in this Hartford suburb.

title: NEW COMPUTER LIKELY TO AID WEATHER FORECASTING
description: The weather forecast for last weekend was for sunny skies and warm temperatures. Instead, to the surprise of picnickers and weather forecasters alike, New York City was drenched in another downpour.

title: MORE CITY WORKERS WILL BE HIRED AS $98 MILLION IS ADDED TO BUDGET
description: A budget agreement that provides for adding 2,000 police officers, 400 street sweepers, three firehouses and money for libraries and schools was reached early yesterday by Mayor Koch, the City Council and the Board of Estimate.

title: World Shipbuilding
description: World shipbuilding orders fell in the first quarter to 31.45 million gross tons from 32.62 million tons in the previous quarter, but were up from 26.6 million tons a year earlier, Lloyd's Register of Shipbuilding Returns said today. The order books of most leading shipbuilding nations fell from the previous quarter. Japan remains the biggest builder, followed by South Korea, Brazil, China and Taiwan.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $54,961, or 2 cents a share, from the settlement of a debt.

title: 'LOST' FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT HOUSE IS FOUND
description: It is not easy to lose an entire building. But a house by Frank Lloyd Wright, long thought to have been demolished in 1954, has turned up, in pieces, in a basement storeroom in Westchester County.

title: 3 SENATORS FORESEE A THREAT IN ANTITERRORISM BILL
description: Two conservative Republican Senators and a liberal Democrat agreed at a hearing today that an antiterrorism bill proposed by President Reagan was so broadly worded that it might threaten civil liberties.

title: SEVERE DROUGHT HITS SOUTHWEST
description: For the second straight year, severe drought is parching large areas of the Southwest, ruining crops and forcing ranchers to sell breeding stock.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $239,998, or 20 cents a share.

title: Finnish Party Ousts Pro-Soviet Faction
description: Independents have ousted a pro-Soviet faction from the leadership of Finland's Communist Party in a move intended to end 15 years of internal dispute and strengthen the party's influence among Finns.

title: CABINET CHANGED AFTER HAITI RIOTS
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 1 - After food riots in central and northern Haiti, the 13-year-old Government of President Jean-Claude Duvalier announced the biggest Cabinet change in three years Thursday and made nearly a clean sweep of the local administration in one of the centers of the disturbances, the town of Gona"ives.

title: Mecom Firm on Saints Denying rumors that he was in financial trouble and had put the New Orleans Saints up for sale,
description: John Mecom Jr. , the reclusive Houston businessman who owns the club, said that he had no intention of selling it and every intention of keeping it in New Orleans. ''There ain't enough money and power in Louisiana to run me off,'' he said. Mecom acknowledged that his hotel properties had been suffering and that he was trying to syndicate the holdings, but he denied reports that the hotel losses and taxes on his father's estate had put him in a bind.

title: IF YOU'RE A JOGGER, HEAVYHANDS ARE IN
description: SEE Dick and Jane. See Dick and Jane run. See Dick and Jane run with their Heavyhands, Lace Weights, weight vest, watch-wallet and Polarbands, while listening, on a Sony Walkman, to a cassette of run-motivating music. Don't, however, look for Spot. While running, Dick and Jane have shooed him away with their laminated wood Joystks (''Run without fear,'' say the ads.)

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Computer Account To Fredericks Kullberg

title: Insider Accord In Atari Case
description: A second senior officer of Atari Inc. has decided not to fight insider-trading charges and has agreed to give up $154,184 and 2,925 common shares in Warner Communications Inc., the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. Without admitting or denying guilt, Dennis D. Groth, now president of Atari's international division, also agreed to surrender to Warner stock option rights on 13,333 Warner shares.

title: Harlem Photographer Among Four Honored
description: Austin Hansen, who has photographed Harlem events and personalities for 40 years, was one of four winners of the fifth annual International Black Photographers awards.

title: China-Europe Trade Ties
description: China is prepared to open its markets further to imports and investment and wants to strengthen its economic and technical relations with the Common Market, its Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, said here today.

title: PLAN APPROVED TO HOUSE 1,800 OF THE HOMELESS
description: A $25 million plan to house about 1,800 homeless people, both families and individuals, over the next three years was approved by city officials yesterday morning as part of the new capital budget.

title: SENATORS CALL FOR EXEMPTIONS IN WEAPONS GUARANTEE LAW
description: A coalition of Senators announced today that they had reached agreement on revisions in a 1983 law that required manufacturers of military weapons to guarantee their products. Some advocates of the original law described the proposed changes as seriously weakening the concept of guarantees.

title: THIS IS SACKPIG, AND IT MAY NEVER END
description: In a Government where acronyms and pseudo-acronyms are the very lifeblood of speech, not any is perhaps more graceless than that given to a very important group dealing with ultimate survival. The acronym belongs to the Senior Arms Control Policy Group, or SACPG, or ''Sackpig,'' as it is inevitably pronounced within the bureaucracy.

title: Block Island Residents Seek State Referendum
description: Residents of Block Island voted early today to ask Rhode Island for the authority to either regulate the use of mopeds on the 11-square mile island or allow it to secede from the state.

title: ; A SOCIETY'S - AND TV'S- WINNING COMBINATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Year to March 25
description: b-Including a tax credit of $353,000 and insurance proceeds of $310,000. c-Including a tax credit of $149,000 and a gain of $48,000 on the sale of property.

title: FIRE FORCES HART PLANE TO LANDING
description: Fire broke out in one of the engines of Senator Gary Hart's campaign plane today, forcing the chartered Boeing 720 to return to the Philadelphia International Airport, but no injuries were reported.

title: ABNER FAMILY FIELDS NEW CELEBRITY FLAWLESSLY
description: When Carol Abner's boys were small, they played baseball on a field right behind the family's split-level house here on Beechwood Drive. That spared Mrs. Abner ferrying Ben Jr., Shawn and Chris to far-flung playing sites, but it gave her a different sort of job in wet weather.

title: Computer Mail Effort Abandoned
description: The board of governors of the Postal Service today voted to quit the computer mail business and turn it over to a private contractor if possible.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a stock distribution in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 3, 1982 and also the sale of 612,000 shares of common stock on Dec. 29, 1982.

title: Stores Damaged By Fire in Elmont
description: A fire today destroyed a florist's shop, severely damaged an adjoining jewelry store and a Nassau County youth center, and caused water and smoke damage to three other stores.

title: MARKS & SPENCER CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $11,000 for store closure costs.

title: CHARGES FLY AT ALANTA'S ZOO AFTER ELEPHANT DIES
description: When Twinkles the elephant died last month, officials at Atlanta's city-run zoo reported that she had succumbed on a farm in rural Georgia, where she had been put to pasture to rest her crippled legs.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Overland Chief Adds Job
description: William F. Hagerman, founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Overland Express Inc., said yesterday that he had assumed the presidency following the resignation of James B. Aronson as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Hagerman, who owns 37 percent of the company's stock, attributed the resignation to differences in management philosophy. Overland, based in Minneapolis, operates as a nationwide long-haul general commodities carrier without regular routes.

title: Salvadoran Rightist Leader Granted U.S. Visitor's Visa
description: The State Department said today that it had granted permission for Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist leader, to make a private visit to the United States.

title: Deloitte Fills No. 2 Position
description: J. Michael Cook has been named managing partner and chief operating officer of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the Big Eight international accounting and consulting firm announced yesterday. Mr. Cook, 41 years old, succeeds Howard Kast, who is retiring.

title: A Political 'Four-fer'
description: With quotas of this and that group

title: CAR SALES JUMPED 19.1% IN LAST 10 DAYS OF MAY
description: New-car sales in the last 10 days of May rose 19.1 percent from the 1983 period on a daily selling rate basis, the major manufacturers reported here today. The daily rate of 37,582 was the highest for the period since 1978.

title: INDUSTRY IS SAID TO SLOW RISE IN ITS HEALTH COSTS
description: Corporate executives told Congress today that they had substantially reduced the rate of increase in employee health costs without reducing the quality of medical care.

title: Streak Ends for a 16-Year-Old
description: On a day when such giants of the game as John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors, Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova advanced to the semifinals, Melissa Brown of Scarsdale, N.Y., a 16-year- old amateur, was finally eliminated from the French Open tennis championships.

title: Family Businesses
description: This week has been proclaimed film

title: U.S. Attorney Is Ill
description: For the last month, illness has kept

title: STATE TIES DEATH OF 10 PATIENTS TO AN AIR FILTER
description: The deaths of 10 patients in a bone marrow transplant unit at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo in 1982 and 1983 were linked to an antiquated air filtration system, according to a report issued today on an investigation by the State Health Department.

title: Czech Dissident Sentenced
description: A Czechoslovak dissident's four-year prison term was extended by 14 months because he gave what was called ''false testimony'' about being beaten by guards, an emigre source said today. The dissident, Jiri Gruntorad, a founder of the Charter 77 human rights movement, was arrested in June 1981 on charges of publishing antistate pamphlets.

title: Sri Lanka Guerrillas Kill 3 Police Officers
description: Separatist guerrillas ambushed a police jeep with bombs today, killing an inspector and two constables, officials said.

title: Israeli Attache Is Shot In the Hand in Egypt
description: An Israeli diplomat was wounded in the hand by unidentified assailants who fired from a car, an Israeli Embassy spokesman said today.

title: MUSIC:HERMAN VAN VEEN
description: HERMAN VAN VEEN, the Dutch musician and mime who has been a European star for over a decade, is a hybrid music hall entertainer and performance artist who would like to be a Chaplinesque multimedia virtuoso. In his sparsely attended Carnegie Hall concert on Friday, Mr. van Veen sang in three languages, played the piano and violin, danced and clowned.

title: ILLINOIS PANEL ENDORSES CHANGE IN BANKING LAW
description: A State Senate committee tentatively endorsed legislation today to change Illinois laws and allow an out- of-state bank to buy the troubled Continental Illinois Corporation.

title: ;  A Record Texaco Bond Financing
description: In the largest bond financing ever underwritten by a single securities firm, Texaco Capital Inc. is offering $500 million of 13 1/4 percent extendible notes at a price of 99.8 to yield 13.34 percent to 1987 through Salomon Brothers Inc. Rather than arranging a syndicate group of securities dealers to help place the notes with investors, Salomon Brothers is acting as sole underwriter.

title: FOR REAGANS IN LONDON, LUNCH WITH THE QUEEN
description: President and Mrs. Reagan went to lunch at Buckingham Palace today with Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh. It was a cozy occasion devoid of the pomp and circumstance that will surround them when they return for a state banquet Saturday at the end of the seven- nation economic conference this week.

title: A Gloomy Mariner
description: Gorman Thomas, the Seattle Mariners' expensive outfielder who has been sidelined with a shoulder injury since May 17, says he will not return to the lineup this year and may never play again. ''This could be the end of my career, even with surgery,'' said Thomas. He said doctors had told him that a tear of his rotator cuff was so severe that next spring would be the earliest he might be able to play again.

title: Hanson Trust Profits Up 90%
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British industrial conglomerate that recently acquired U.S. Industries, said today that pretax profits rose 90 percent in the six months ended March 31, to $89.5 million, from $47.1 million in the period a year earlier.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $186,000. c-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $400,000.

title: The 'Benefits' of Jailing Kids
description: ''Preventive detention,'' once an unmentionable subject in American law, now turns out to be good for children. The Supreme Court, upholding New York's pretrial detention law for juveniles, finds that locking up young people accused but not convicted of crime protects not only society but accused youngsters as well.

title: WINDSOR INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $150,000 adjustment from certain financing agreements and a $54,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Long-Term Bond Yields Up
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with yields for most long-term bonds rising modestly while rates for three- and six-month Treasury bills fell by an eighth of a percentage point or more.

title: Red Sox Shuffle The general partners of the Boston Red Sox, their intramural ownership battle behind them by way of a court order favorable to
description: Jean Yawkey and Haywood Sullivan , met yesterday and changed the titles of some executives. The meeting marked the first time since the court battle began that Mrs. Yawkey and Sullivan were able to join in outvoting the third general partner, Edward (Buddy) LeRoux . Mrs. Yawkey remains president of the club and LeRoux, the team's former trainer, remains executive vice president.

title: SMITH IS ENJOINED ON GEARHART OFFER
description: Gearhart Industries won a major battle today in its fight against an unwanted takeover by Smith International Inc. when a Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction preventing Smith from proceeding with its $31-a-share tender offer.

title: Careers; Becoming A College President
description: SMITH COLLEGE is looking for a new president. New York University is looking for a new dean for its graduate school of business administration. Throughout the country, the game of academic musical chairs goes on.

title: A GUIDE TO COMPLETE COOKING ON THE OUTDOOR GRILL
description: THERE are two axioms of outdoor grilling this time of year: (A) The fire is always at its peak 15

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Pontiac Dealers Group To Get Presentations

title: ALO-SCHERER HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The results have been restated to reflect the company's 70 percent stake in a company acquired in September 1983.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Named Haywood Sullivan chief operating officer. Promoted Lou Gorman from vice president and assistant general manager to general manager.

title: Indonesian Oil Output
description: Indonesia's oil production fell by 1.3 percent in 1983, to 454.5 million barrels, while exports fell 7.8 percent, the Ministry of Mining said today. But production of condensate, hydrocarbon liquids such as butane and propane, rose 29.7 percent, to 36 million barrels, the ministry said.

title: ;  G.E. Credit Unit's Eurobond Issue
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $600 million face amount of zero coupon Eurobonds due in 1996 at a price of 25.55 to yield 122.04 percent through underwriters led by the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.

title: Advertising; Ingalls Names President
description: AT one point in his career, pipe- smoking David I. Weiss wanted to be the best account manager in New York. And for all you know, he might be.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Lenny Dibari likes to wait. ''I really don't mind at all,'' he said cheerfully, standing in a line that horrified, disgusted and maddened others who arrived at the Department of Motor Vehicles bureau yesterday. ''I kind of enjoy it.''

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anderson, Clayton & Co. , a food and insurance company in Houston, said it had completed the purchase of the Gaines Pet Foods division of General Foods Corp. for $156.8 million in cash and the assumption of $30 million of debt.

title: ADMINISTRATION DEBATING ANTITERRORIST MEASURES
description: Three and a half years after announcing that combatting terrorism would be President Reagan's first national-security priority, officials say a debate on the subject is still going on in the Administration and that it will be taken up at the economic summit conference this week.

title: Abortion Rights Group Aims at Reagan Defeat
description: Supporters of the right to abortion said Monday that beating President Reagan was their top political priority for 1984 and that they saw ''strong opportunities for pro-choice victories'' in four key Senate races.

title: ISRAEL EXPECTING A CLOSE ELECTION
description: Israel's election campaign is about to get under way amid expectations that the two main parties will run a close race in their fight for voters in the center of the political spectrum.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Shops of 'Little India'

title: West German Jobless
description: The unemployment rate in West Germany fell to 8.6 percent in May from 9.1 percent in April, the Federal Labor Office said today. It was the first time since November 1983 that the jobless rate was below 9 percent. Unemployment reached a postwar record of 10.2 percent in January.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 6, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CLASH IS SEEN AS WIDENING THE GULF WAR
description: Saudi Arabia's air attacks against two Iranian fighter planes today and the larger air skirmish that followed marked a signicant widening of the war in the Persian Gulf, Western and Arab officials said.

title: Hall of Fame Ball
description: Dave Kingman may not wind up in baseball's Hall of Fame, but a ball that he hit into the roof of the Metrodome in Minneapolis on May 4 is there.

title: Ballesteros Having A Lonely Season
description: Based on his performances this year, it may be difficult for Seve Ballesteros to defend his title in the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, which starts at the Westchester Country Club Thursday.

title: NEW JERSEY AND CALIFORNIA: A DAY OF CONTRASTS IN VOTER TRENDS
description: Walter F. Mondale rolled to an easy primary victory in New Jersey yesterday on an insurmountable base of support gained early in the campaign among white, regular Democrats and on Gary Hart's failure to galvanize the independent and ''new generation'' voters who helped him win elsewhere, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. But in California, Senator Hart mounted a powerful challenge to the former Vice President with a strong finish among that state's late- deciding voters and the breadth of appeal that enabled him to carry the contest for the Democratic nomination into the final round of primaries.

title: MARY MOCHARY IS G.O.P. VICTOR IN JERSEY VOTING
description: Mary V. Mochary, the Mayor of Montclair, was the victor yesterday over Robert Morris in the New Jersey race for the Republican nomination for United States Senate.

title: THERMODYNETICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $114,547 for the latest year and $31,813 for the earlier year.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months results reflect the $10 million reserve for inventory valuation at the TRE semiconductor division.

title: MAYOR LEADS IN JERSEY IN CONGRESSIONAL RACE
description: The Democratic Mayor of Mount Holly and a veteran New Jersey Republican legislator took strong early leads last night in crowded primary contests in the state's 13th Congressional District.

title: A FEAST IN CELEBRATION OF CAREME'S BIRTHDAY
description: His name was Antonin Car^eme, and he was a man of such genius that George IV of England and Czar Alexander I of Russia both tried in vain to hire him permanently.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YANKS LEAVE 15 AND LOSE BY 1
description: The Yankees, who scored 31 runs in their previous three games, put enough runners on base last night to score nearly that many runs in one game. Twenty-two runners - 16 with hits, 5 with walks and 1 on an error - reached base against Boston. However, 15 were left on base and 3 were eliminated in double plays.

title: Mississippi May Pick A Black Congressman
description: State Representative Robert Clark took a step closer to becoming Mississippi's first black member of Congress since Reconstruction by defeating a white segregationist and two other foes in the state's Second Congressional District in the primary today.

title: NETWORKS MARK D-DAY
description: Using resources worthy of the Normandy invasion itself, ABC, NBC and CBS are commemorating the 40th anniversary of D-Day with a barrage of programs recalling both the battle's impact on the generation that fought it, and its remoteness to the generation that followed it.

title: Australian Output Up
description: Australia's gross domestic product rose 2.3 percent, seasonally adjusted, in the first quarter from the previous quarter and was up 7.9 percent from the period a year earlier, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said today. It was the third consecutive increase in the G.D.P., which measures output of goods and services minus exports, confirming the country's strong recovery from last year's recession, analysts said.

title: Article 242801 -- No Title
description: The Cole National Corporation and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company signed a definitive agreement under which a group of investors led by Kohlberg, Kravis would acquire Cole for $39 a share, or a total of about $308 million. The stock of Cole, a Cleveland-based retailer, rose 12.5 cents, to $36.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: DELOREAN WITNESS TELLS OF EFFORT TO ADD A HEROIN DEALER TO CASE
description: James Timothy Hoffman, an undercover informer, testified today that at one point in the Government's investigation of John Z. DeLorean there were plans to get heroin from a source in Thailand so it could become part of the narcotics Mr. DeLorean is charged with conspiring to bring into the country.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UPTOWN DOWNTOWN Starting today, there's a link other than the AA train that connects uptowners and downtowners and, what's more, it's all art and entails no waiting. This instant transport is in the category called video-sculpture and it is Wendy Clarke's two-way piece named ''The Link.''

title: SELLARS HEADS ANTA AND KENNEDY
description: Peter Sellars, the precocious 26-year-old theater and opera director who because of his controversial productions has been known as the enfant terrible of American theater since graduating from Harvard in 1980, was named today as the artistic director and chief operating officer for plays to be produced jointly by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the American National Theater Academy.

title: Training Shift
description: Stu Mittleman, the fitness consultant from Manhattan who ran second to Siegfried Bauer of New Zealand last year in the first New York Six- Day Run, has decided the proper approach to this year's renewal of the event is to conclude heavy training about a month before the July 2 start and devote the final four weeks to resting for the grueling test.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CALIFORNIA VOTERS ARE SPLIT
description: Walter F. Mondale won overwhelmingly in the Democratic Presidential primaries in New Jersey and West Virginia yesterday, claiming victories that his strategists said would enable him to gain the majority of delegates that is needed for the nomination.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO OVERSPEND ITS BUDGET ON NICARAGUA
description: The House Intelligence Committee will meet Wednesday to discuss evidence obtained by its staff indicating that the Central Intelligence Agency has spent more than the $24 million allocated for covert activities in Nicaragua in the current fiscal year, two committee members said today.

title: TURKS HALT IRAN OIL PICK-UPS
description: The Government has decided not to send tankers to Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf until it receives guarantees from Iraq, a Turkish official was quoted as having said today, two days after Iraq attacked a Turkish tanker near the terminal.

title: Wes Ellis Jr., Leading Golfer In New Jersey Many Years
description: Wes Ellis Jr., who dominated golf in New Jersey for many years and won three professional tour events, died at Holy Name Hospital Monday. He was 52 years old and had been suffering from kidney disease.

title: Hill Samuel Buys Brokerage Stake
description: Hill Samuel P.L.C., one of Britain's leading merchant banks, will acquire a 29.9 percent stake in Wood MacKenzie & Company, one of the country's largest stock brokerage firms, the companies announced.

title: TNew Shankar Album Adds To Jazz-Indian Fusion
description: L. Shankar, the violinist from India, has been exploring common elements in Indian music and jazz since his adventurous work with the guitarist John McLaughlin in the mid-1970's. Much modern-jazz improvisation involves superimposing a succession of modes or scales over a static harmonic backdrop, much as an Indian musician does when improvising on a raga.

title: SCREEN:'THE GUEST,' LIFE OF MARAIS
description: TAKING as his source material a few months in the life of Eugene Marais (1871-1936), the South African poet, naturalist and morphine addict, Athol Fugard has written a vivid, austere screenplay that, although it has nothing to do with race relations, is a nearly perfect analogue for such prize-winning Fugard plays as ''Master Harold and the Boys'' and ''A Lesson from Aloes.''

title: American Medical Deal
description: American Medical International Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire the St. Joseph Hospital in Omaha from the Creighton Omaha Regional Healthcare Corporation for about $100 million. The facility includes a 418-bed medical/surgical hospital and a 121-bed psychiatric unit.

title: U.S. and Italy Planning Effort to Combat Drugs
description: Attorney General William French Smith and Italy's Interior Minister, Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, met here today to plan a joint working group for coordinating American and Italian attacks on organized crime and drug trafficking.

title: TELEPHONE SUPPORT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE rules of blending and contrasting food flavors are universal, although ingredients may vary from place to place. For instance, almost every country has a sweet-and-sour combination, whether it be Chinese pork or fish with a sugar, ketchup and vinegar sauce; French aigre-doux sauce, which appears in many preparations involving game (currant jelly is the sweet addition), and sweet-and-sour cabbage, which can be found in almost all Western kitchens.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 6, 1984 International
description: Saudi jets shot down two Iranian jets, Saudi and United States officials said. They said that two Saudi fighter pilots were flying American-built F-15's and had help from United States aerial tanker and surveillance planes in shooting down the two American- built Iranian F-4 fighters. A Middle Eastern diplomat said the aerial fight occurred in Saudi airspace. Meanwhile, the Pentagon announced that three additional Air Force Awacs surveillance aircraft are being sent to Saudi Arabia. (Page A1, Cols. 1-2.) Indian Army troops exchanged fire with Sikh terrorists firing mortars and machine guns from inside the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion in a daylong battle, the Government said. Two people outside the shrine were reported killed. No information on casualties inside the fortified temple grounds was available. (A1:2.)

title: 14 Salvadoran Sailors Are Killed in Ambush
description: Leftist rebels killed 14 Government sailors in an ambush in the swampy lowlands of southeastern El Salvador, a military spokesman said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Required Reading Of Firsts and Bests
description: I, like you, attended a woman's college where I learned that women need not adhere to male stereotypes in order to lead, to be assertive, to forge consensus, to act. After an all-female education I took for granted women's competence and wanted to show my own.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
'DECOY' ALBUM, THE OLD MILES DAVIS
description: ''DECOY'' (Columbia), the new album from Miles Davis, is the first disk since his middle- and late-1970's ''retirement'' that amounts to more than a string of bluesy solos and riff patterns. Mr. Davis's stylings used to be billed as ''Directions in Music,'' and ''Decoy'' lives up to that designation by molding individual solos, themes, backgrounds, and overall sound into a coherent whole greater than the sum of its parts.

title: Prosecution Rests In Brink's Trial
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the murder and robbery trial of the last Brink's defendant, Samuel Brown, with testimony from Rockland County's Chief Medical Examiner that the three victims had died of wounds from a high velocity weapon such as an M-16.

title: Women Win Out
description: Female Olympic athletes have made a greater impression than men on the consciousness of American sports fans, according to a recent survey of opinion.

title: Bliss Discloses Deal and Inquiry
description: A. T. Bliss & Company said it intends to sell its four million common shares of the Nationwide Power Corporation for about $30 million.

title: LATE RALLY PUSHES DOW UP BY 8.95
description: A late rally, fueled by some of the blue-chip issues, enabled stock prices to close moderately higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: Dunning to Manage A.B.T.
description: Gary Dunning has been named general manager of the American Ballet Theater. He has held a number of administrative posts with Ballet Theater, which he joined in 1978. He succeeds Charles Dillingham, who became the executive director.

title: PANEL OF ECONOMISTS PROPOSES U.S. TAX SPENDING
description: A team of economists from the Brookings Institution today proposed cutbacks in Social Security payments, substantial tax increases and stringent new controls on Government spending as part of a comprehensive program to eliminate the Federal budget deficit by 1989.

title: Belzbergs' Blue Bell Stake
description: A Canadian investment group led by the Belzberg family said it might buy up to 49 percent of Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-largest apparel maker after Levi Strauss & Company. The Belzberg group already controls 9.2 percent of Blue Bell's 9.9 million common shares outstanding.

title: CALENDAR: TOURING CLINTON HILL'S HISTORY
description: Clinton Hill Homes: 1984 Tour, the

title: WILANDER, LENDL IN SEMIFINALS
description: Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander advanced today to the semifinals of the French Open tennis championships.

title: MONDALE TO CALL HIS TWO RIVALS FOR NOMINATION
description: An exuberant Walter F. Mondale, announcing he had gathered enough delegates to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that he would telephone Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the next few days to seek party unity.

title: Mercantile Deal
description: Federal regulators have agreed to allow the Mercantile Texas Corporation to complete its $953.8 million merger with Southwest Bancshares Inc. of Houston, creating one of the state's largest bank holding companies. The bank merger, which would be the largest in Texas, would create a holding company with 69 subsidiary banks, $19.2 billion in assets and $14.7 billion in deposits. The company will be called the Mercantile Southwest Corporation.

title: Another Pact Reached In Las Vegas Strike
description: Striking musicians reached a tentative agreement tonight with the city's resort hotels, leaving only one union, Stagehands Local 720, still without an agreement in the 67-day-old walkout that has cost this city millions of dollars.

title: SIKHS IN THE U.S. ARE ANGERED OVER GOLDEN TEMPLE ASSAULT
description: American Sikhs expressed anger today over the assault of the Golden Temple complex in Amritsar and indignation that Sikhs at the temple are being described as extremists and terrorists.

title: Average Salesman Call Cost $205.40 Last Year
description: Since 1942, McGraw-Hill Research has been figuring on an every-other- year basis the cost of the average salesman's call.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said its board had agreed to meet June 15 in a special session to determine the course of construction at its Midland nuclear power plant. The utility noted that its board, in a meeting today, reaffirmed its commitment to completing Unit 2 at the Midland plant.

title: E.P.A. TO SEEK LIMIT ON RADIATION FROM TV AND RADIO TRANSMITTERS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to recommend that the Federal Government for the first time limit the strength of radiation from the antennas of radio and television transmitters because of possible human health risks.

title: 18 Dali Paintings Stolen From Gallery
description: Burglars tunneled into the Signature Gallery here and stole 18 Salvador Dali paintings valued at $538,000, spoiling a display honoring the surrealist artist's 80th birthday.

title: Fluke Are Plentiful
description: 1 Margate N.J.: There is excellent fluke-fishing round Great Egg and Absecon inlets and the back bays between Atlantic City. There are 3- to 5-pound bluefish to be had within a mile of the beaches using spoons, feathers and ponytails, and sharks are starting to be caught at the 28-mile wreck. Barnegat, N.J.: Some bluefish, 3 to 4 pounds, can be found along the beach, and there are plenty of fluke in the bay and some along the beach. Seaside Park, N.J.: Some small bluefish, 1 1/2 to 2 pounds, were pulled in on poppers in the bay, but the cool water has not lured them.

title: U.S. Doubts Legality Of Hart Charter Service
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that flights run by a Columbus, Ohio, flying club for the Hart-for- President campaign, including the flight Tuesday that was cut short by an engine fire, were illegal.

title: KUOMINTANG LEADER LEFT CHIANG IN 1954
description: Dr. K. C. Wu, the former mayor of Shanghai and Nationalist Chinese official who broke with Chiang Kai-shek in 1954 after calling Mr. Chiang's Government undemocratic, died yesterday at his home in Savannah, Ga. Dr. Wu was 80 years old.

title: Colonial Penn Talks To Possible Buyer
description: The Colonial Penn Group, a Philadelphia-based insurer that specializes in direct-mail sales, said yesterday that it was talking with a possible buyer.

title: CANADIAN COMMERCIAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: No Headline
description: Democratic Primary Results

title: MONDALE'S STRUGGLE TO CLINCH CONTEST: POLLS SHOW TROUBLES IN HOMESTRETCH
description: The difficulty that Walter F. Mondale had in nailing down enough delegates to clinch the Democratic nomination reflects his broader problems in swinging late-deciding voters in such key primary states as California, Ohio and Indiana into his camp. In those states, polls by The New York Times and CBS News show that in the homestretch Senator Gary Hart cut into the basic Mondale constituencies - union voters, the elderly, the economically worse off and regular white Democrats - thereby delaying Mr. Mondale's drive for the nomination.

title: NBC Gets 8 Programs In Top 10 for the Week
description: For the first time in nearly four months, NBC, with the superhit ''The A-Team'' in the vanguard, captured the lion's share of the top 10 programs for the week ended June 3 and tied ABC for first place in Nielsen ratings.

title: Carter to Shut Down His Fund-Raising Panel
description: A political action committee set up to help former President Jimmy Carter campaign for other candidates will be shut down, probably after the Democratic National Convention, a Carter aide said Tuesday.

title: Rooney Purchase
description: The Rooney, Pace Group said it had bought Securities Counsel Inc., an investment management firm with about $400 million under management.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IN CHURCH The arts flourish in New York's houses of worship, from imposing cathedrals, such as St. John the Divine, where the very architecture may serve as backdrop for an exhibition or an avant-garde musical, to side-street churches that contribute a room for a theater group. One has a jazz ministry, another a poet's center, another a gallery. They are found in all boroughs and include St. Ann's, in Brooklyn Heights, at 157 Montague Street, corner of Clinton (834-8794), the arts are very much a way of life.

title: Block Urges Japan Access
description: The United States is ''unequivocally'' committed to supplying a reliable flow of farm products to Japan, but Japan must reciprocate by allowing American farmers ''fair access'' to its markets, United States Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: Vietnam Accuses China Of Killing Hundreds
description: Chinese forces have killed hundreds of civilians in cross-border artillery bombardments and raids on Vietnamese territory in the last two months, Vietnam charged today.

title: Tylenol Figure Sentenced
description: James W. Lewis, who was convicted of extortion involving cyanide-laced Tylenol, was sentenced Tuesday to two five- year prison terms for filing a false statement and a false claim with the Internal Revenue Service. Federal District Judge Ross T. Roberts ordered that the sentence run concurrently with a 10-year prison term Mr. Lewis is now serving for mail fraud. Mr. Lewis is scheduled to be sentenced next week in Chicago on a charge of attempting to extort $1 million from Johnson & Johnson in 1982 in connection with the cyanide-laced capsules that killed seven people. The three cases are unrelated.

title: BANKS AREN'T FOR GAMBLING
description: The near-failure of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company could not have come at a worse time for banks and others who advocate complete deregulation of the nation's financial institutions.

title: HERS
description: I WAS 18 when I first left the high white walls

title: Upset in Epsom
description: Secreto, a 14-1 shot ridden by Christy Roche, won the richest Epsom Derby in history today, beating the odds-on favorite, El Gran Senor, by a head. The victory was worth $318,652 to Secreto's owner, Luigi Migletti, a Venezuelan transport executive. The Derby, a mile-and-a-half race for 3-year-olds that was first run in 1780, drew a field of 17, in which Mighty Flutter was third.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Top Officer Quits Houston Natural Gas
description: In what some industry analysts interpret as a forced resignation, the board of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation announced yesterday that M. D. Matthews, chairman, president and chief executive officer of the company since 1981, had decided to take early retirement and would be resigning effective Friday.

title: SAUDIS TRY TO PLAY DOWN AIR BATTLE OVER GULF
description: Saudi Arabia tried today to play down the significance of its air clash on Tuesday with Iranian jet fighters, in which at least one Iranian plane was downed.

title: No Headline
description: Democratic Delegates: A State-by-State Count

title: USE OF U.S. ARMS IN MIDEAST RAISES CONCERNS IN CONGRESS
description: Tuesday's air battle over the Persian Gulf between Saudi Arabian and Iranian jet fighters featured American weapons on both sides, raising questions in Congress about United States arms policy in the region.

title: Ad Pages Up 13.7%
description: The Magazine Publishers Association has announced that member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau increased their advertising pages a healthy 13.7 percent in April over the same month last year and their advertising revenues 23.9 percent. The totals were 13,824 pages and $$425.1 million.

title: ARMS TRAINING BY KLAN CITED IN SUIT
description: A civil suit filed by a Moore County prison guard asserts that a Ku Klux Klan group operates a paramilitary army with more than 300 members in 11 North Carolina counties.

title: Letter to Jewel
description: The American Stores Company said it had sent a letter to the Jewel Companies, saying it was ''prepared to discuss and negotiate with you any aspect of our tender offer.'' Last week, American Stores offered $70 a share for 67 percent of Jewel's common and convertible preferred stock outstanding, and $70 a share in securities for the remaining 33 percent in a deal valued at more than $1 billion. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Jewel closed at $62.75, down 75 cents.

title: 9 Injured in Philippine Strike
description: The police charged 20 striking glass factory workers with assault today, a day after the workers were arrested in a clash with riot troops. At least nine people were injured in the melee, but none was reported in serious condition. The strikers, who have been picketing the factory in this city 360 miles southeast of Manila for nearly two weeks, were demanding the reinstatement of a worker who was fired after trying to form a union independent from the factory's main union.

title: RECITAL: HAENG-JA BAE, SAMUEL LIEFSHITZ
description: reaching program of song was given in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon by the soprano Haeng-Ja Bae and the pianist Samuel Liefshitz. Miss Bae may not have mastered fully the pronunciation of the Western texts she sang, but their essence belongs to her.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DIANE ARBUS. A Biography. By Patricia Bosworth. 366 pages. Knopf. $17.95.

title: WHAT TO DO IN JUNE
description: Flowering Shrubs

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a marketer of aviation parts and services, announced that Ira Eichner, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional title of chief operating officer.

title: ABC Firm on Olympics
description: James E. Duffy, the president of ABC, told an advertisers' group yesterday that the network had no intention of cutting back its television coverage of the Olympics in the face of the Soviet-bloc withdrawal. ''We are going full steam ahead with 186 hours of television coverage, almost all of it live and a great proportion of it live in prime time,'' he told a meeting of the American Advertising Federation in Denver. . . . The National Basketball Association and the Turner Broadcasting System have completed a $20 million deal that will give the network exclusive cable television rights for the next two seasons.

title: THE HANDLING AND CARE OF OLD CAMPAIGN CHESTS
description: The campaign or military chest, an early 19th-century English idea, evolved from the plain brass-bound box or trunk adapted to serve in the field and on the march. Most were handsome pieces, made from thick straight-grained mahogany planks.

title: RESORT PUTS BLACK FLIES TO THE TEST
description: Black flies have always bitten tourists in New Hampshire. Now Prof. John F. Burger, an entomologist at the University of New Hampshire, is trying to find out how much they hurt the tourist industry, the state's largest source of income after manufacturing.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $38,692 for the latest first quarter and $7,700 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SUMMARY OF VOTING IN JERSEY
description: Following is an unofficial summary of the voting in Tuesday's New Jersey primary election.

title: STATE PENALIZED ON DEFICIENCIES IN HEALTH CARE
description: New York State was penalized $58.6 million by the Federal Government yesterday on the ground that the state had failed to correct health, living and safety violations at five of its centers for the retarded and disabled.

title: ATLANTA OFFICIALS START EVALUATION OF VETERINARY SERVICES AT CITY ZOO
description: City officials said today that they were evaluating the adequacy of veterinary services at the city-run zoo amid allegations of mismanagement and mistreatment of animals at the 95-year-old facility.

title: Fein New York State
description: The number of felony drug arrests in New York State was 26.7 percent higher in the first three months of 1984 than in the same period last year, a state official reported today. Felony drug indictments rose 42.9 percent.

title: EGYPTIAN PREMIER SINCE 1982
description: Prime Minister Fuad Mohieddin died of a heart attack Tuesday, a few minutes after he arrived at his office in downtown Cairo, doctors said. He was 58 years old.

title: DANCE: RUSSILLO TROUPE'S U.S. DEBUT
description: FRANCE is now experiencing a dance boom of its own - especially in modern dance, an art form that was considered negligible in that country until the 1970's.

title: HURST BEATS YANKS; RED SOX 5, YANKEES 3
description: Lou Piniella sat in front of his locker, holding a can of beer and staring straight ahead, lamenting the fly ball he had hit to center field minutes earlier.

title: U.S.-BRITISH ALLIANCE
description: The powerful thrust across the Channel on June 6, 1944, marked today at ceremonies in Normandy and in southern England, was the zenith of the extraordinarily close wartime partnership between the United States and Britain. Forty years later, the British speak of the ''special relationship'' as a living entity. The bond established by Winston Churchill and Franklin D. Roosevelt has survived the decades in the intimate links still maintained between 10 Downing Street and the White House. American Presidents and British Prime Ministers, regardless of party, have since described the two nations as the closest and most reliable of allies.

title: New Credit Card Law Prohibits a Surcharge
description: Governor Cuomo today signed a bill banning merchants in the state from imposing a surcharge on customers who make purchases with credit cards.

title: Students Charged In Anti-Semitism
description: Five Hicksville High School students were arrested today and accused of spray-painting anti-Semitic slogans on the walls of their school and Syosset High School the night before a football game between the rivals last October.

title: Circumnavigator With an Extra Challenge
description: His trimaran Outward Leg bobbing

title: CUOMO SEEKING TO BAR RATE LINK TO SHOREHAM
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed barring the Long Island Lighting Company from charging its customers for the Shoreham nuclear power plant if it never goes into operation.

title: HONDURAN ARMY REVIEWS ITS LINK WITH U.S.
description: The commander of Honduras's armed forces, declaring that his ousted predecessor had compromised the country's ''pacifist and democratic'' principles, called tonight for new limits on military spending and a new dedication to a peaceful solution of tensions in Central America.

title: People
description: * Gordon L. Link has joined McCann- Erickson USA as executive vice president and director of media services.

title: JAIL ALL DRUNK DRIVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHOOSING A REPUTABLE CONTRACTOR
description: -improvement season, time for such things as repairing roofs, adding rooms and replacing windows. Summer, therefore, is also the season for homeowners' problems with less-than-scrupulous contractors, ranging from some who place bricks on a lawn, claiming that they have fallen from a chimney that must be rebuilt, to the capable worker who begins a job but leaves in the middle because the project cannot be finished alone.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
For the March of Dimes
description: Sun filtered through the trees in the

title: NITRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Including a gain of $900,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the settlement of claims owed Nitron under previous transactions with Astrocane Inc. c-Net loss.

title: Eagle's Creditors
description: Eagle Computer Inc. said it is meeting with a group of unsecured creditors to structure a payment plan for its unsecured debt. Eagle did not disclose the amount of debt in question, but said the creditor group is a subcommittee of an unofficial creditors' committee and represents a substantial portion of Eagle's unsecured debt. The company also said that, as part of a cost-cutting program, it had reduced its staff by about 50 employees in the last 90 days through attrition and layoffs.

title: AMISH FEELINGS MIXED OVER FILMING OF MOVIE
description: Ever since Paramount Pictures began filming the movie ''Witness'' here in Lancaster County a few weeks ago, displeasure has competed with curiosity among the local Amish.

title: LATIN CHIEFS ASK SUMMIT DEBT STEPS
description: Seven Latin American heads of government sent a plea today to participants at the economic summit meeting that begins here Thursday evening, urging them to initiate steps to ease Latin America's debt burden.

title: PANEL SETS $30 BILLION TAX RISES
description: House and Senate tax conferees agreed today on about $30 billion in tax increases over four years - more than half of their goal of $50 billion in additional revenues.

title: IRAN SAID TO USE F-14'S TO SPOT TARGETS
description: Iran has been flying American-built F-14 Tomcat fighters as radar surveillance and control planes to guide F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers attacking ships in the Persian Gulf, according to Middle Eastern diplomats and American officials.

title: VOTE BY COUNTIES
description: Following are unofficial returns from Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary in New Jersey: Pct CountyPctRptgMondaleHartJacksonLaRouche Atlantic 1601604,8032,9873,853159

title: KENNEDY, AT MARYMOUNT RITE, SPEAKS OF THE 'IDEALS' OF U.S.
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy told the graduating class of Marymount Manhattan College last night that if Americans ''demand new ideas, and we should, we do it in order to fulfill abiding ideals of liberty, of caring and compassion.''

title: OF RELIGION AND TAX LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: SIDNEY LUMET: FILM PRINCE OF THE CITY
description: New York City is Sidney Lumet's backdrop.

title: One-Hitter for Breland
description: Mylon Watkins glowered at Mark Breland when they met at the center of the ring last night at the Fort Worth Convention Center before their welterweight bout in the first night of the Olympic Boxing Trials. He came out of his corner winging left hands in earnest and he even landed a glancing blow to Breland's chin.

title: D-DAY FETES STIR 8TH-GRADERS' INTEREST
description: Two generations removed from World War II, 28 of the 36 students in an eighth grade history class at Junior High School 54 in Manhattan confessed that they had not heard of D-day before this week.

title: SENATOR REPORTEDLY JOINED A SPA IN IOWA THAT WAS LATER RAIDED
description: Two Iowa radio stations reported today that Senator Roger W. Jepsen joined a private spa in 1977 that was later shut down as a house of prostitution. In an interview with one of the stations, WHO-Radio in Des Moines, Senator Jepsen described the incident as a ''moment of weakness.'' He said that he had thought the spa was a health club, that he visited it only once and left ''immediately.''

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADERS PUT MONDALE ON TOP IN A DAY OF DECISION
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey was having breakfast yesterday morning at his home in Montclair when Walter F. Mondale called.

title: Officer Hurt in Park Protest
description: A police officer who tried today to arrest protesters sleeping in Lafayette Square across from the White House was knocked to the ground and injured, the authorities said today.

title: PLEA FOR SHOE IMPORT CURB REJECTED
description: The United States International Trade Commission today rejected a plea from the domestic shoe industry for protection from cheaper imports, saying that shoe imports had not seriously hurt American workers or businessmen.

title: 76 Years After the Race And Still Cranking Up
description: On Feb. 12, 1908, some 250,000 people jammed Times Square to watch six cars start a race that was to take them 22,000 miles across the United States, then to Asia, then to France.

title: Soviet Issues Warning On China Arms Deals
description: Yuri Dergachev, a commentator of the Novosti press agency, a feature syndicate, said today that the Soviet Union would have to respond to any military cooperation between the United States and China.

title: NEW EDITION FIXES 5,000 ERRORS IN 'ULYSSES'
description: An international team of scholars has produced a three-volume edition of James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' that corrects almost 5,000 omissions, transpositions and other errors included in previous editions of the seminal 20th-century novel.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Hustings in Grenada

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Brooklyn Dodgers Hall of Fame , inaugural induction ceremonies and opening of exhibit, at the Brooklyn Public Library, Grand Army Plaza branch, 10:30 A.M. The Dodger shrine concept was developed by Marty Adler, assistant principal of Jackie Robinson Intermediate School 203, which is situated across the street from the Ebbets Field housing development. It was Mr. Adler's idea to make sure that the first three inductees were all former Dodgers who had not been honored by induction into Cooperstown. They are Carl Erskine and Carl Furillo, who will be at the ceremonies, and Gil Hodges, who will be represented by his widow, Joan. The ceremonies are a part of the Brooklyn Day celebration, for which all schools in the borough will be closed.

title: HURST BEATS YANKS; METS 2, PIRATES 1
description: In one of the strangest evenings of baseball that either team could remember, the Mets defeated the Pirates, 2-1, tonight to complete a sweep of a three- game series.

title: JACKSON STRONG IN ESSEX
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale carried 18 of New Jersey's 21 counties Tuesday in winning New Jersey's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: SENATE OIL PANEL SHY OF A QUORUM
description: The chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, seeking to pass a bill to improve the nation's ability to handle a disruption of oil supplies, failed today to muster a quorum and chastised absent colleagues for ''complacency.''

title: Minnesota Bonds In Strong Demand
description: A $150 million issue of Minnesota general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 6.5 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.25 percent in 1989, 9.25 percent in 1994 and 10 percent in 1999, through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank. They said the Aa-rated bonds were well received, with $30 million of bonds still unsold late in the day.

title: Bridge: Greenberg Team Hangs On To Win Reisinger Knockout
description: An apparently easy victory became a tough struggle in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the Cavendish Club here Tuesday night, but Alan Greenberg and his team held on to win.

title: The Men Who Preserved D-Day on Film
description: What Lou Weintraub remembers

title: EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS OF MONDALE AND HART ON THE RACE
description: Following are excerpts from transcripts of remarks yesterday by Walter F. Mondale in St. Paul and by Senator Gary Hart in Los Angeles, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network: Mr. Mondale

title: Conviction Upheld for Youth Who Slew Father, an Abuser
description: The State Supreme Court today upheld the manslaughter conviction of Richard Jahnke, who said he had killed his father in self-defense to keep him from abusing the family.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''As of 11:59 this morning, central daylight time, over 2,008 delegates had pledged their support to me.

title: A GENERAL DREAMS OF BEING A COWBOY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: EQUITY-REGIONAL THEATERS TALKS ON
description: One of the most important contracts in the American theater - between Actors Equity and the League of Regional Theaters - expires on June 30 and is currently being renegotiated.

title: 6 Dead in China Floods
description: At least six people died and dozens were injured in weekend floods in Fujian province and Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southeast China, the official China Daily reported Wednesday.

title: LIMITS ON LAWMAKERS WIN APPROVAL ON COAST
description: Californians on Tuesday approved a voter-initiated referendum that would make major changes in the rules for the State Legislature and cut its financing by 30 percent. But Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. said today that he expected the law to be invalidated after a legal attack.

title: Casey Asked to Testify At Nicaragua Inquiries
description: The House and Senate Intelligence Committees today invited William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, to discuss charges that the agency exceeded the spending limit that Congress imposed on covert activities in Nicaragua.

title: REAPPRAISING PHOTOGRAPHY'S STATUS
description: NO matter what art scene you haunt these days - the alphabetical avenues of the Lower East Side, the chic streets of SoHo, even the galleries housing the Museum of Modern Art's show ''An International Survey of Recent Painting and Sculpture'' - there's no escaping the influence of the photograph. Art work after art work incorporates, imitates or otherwise makes use of images that we know courtesy of the camera, from the culturally freighted sculptural friezes of Robert Longo to the sketchily painted perceptual jokes of Mark Tansey.

title: A MAN AND HIS CIGAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Geneticists Reproduce Protein Fatal to Cancer
description: A substance that destroys cancer cells and that the body produces in tiny amounts has been produced in pure form by genetic engineering techniques for the first time, Genentech of South San Francisco announced yesterday.

title: OUTLOOK FOR BROAD BANK BILL DIMS
description: Last month's near-collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has set back lawmakers, mostly Republicans, who want to deregulate the nation's commercial banking system. And those legislators, mostly Democrats, who want to keep banks from expanding into other financial services have new strength.

title: Zimbabwe's Biggest Paper Criticizes the Foreign Press
description: An editorial in Zimbabwe's largest newspaper today applauded Government threats to prosecute foreign correspondents who write ''negative and unsubstantiated'' reports.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JACKSON SEEKING PARTY ROLE WITHOUT 'CLOUD OF THREAT'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and his aides have begun a new phase of the Democratic Presidential process convinced that he is in a powerful position to influence the party's direction.

title: LEBANESE SEEM WEARY OF THE ISRAELIS
description: The only road in and out of south Lebanon was closed today for a Jewish holiday.

title: 35 SUSPENDED BY MANHATTAN CENTER FOR RETARDED
description: An eight-month undercover investigation has led to the suspension of 35 employees of the Manhattan Developmental Center, state officials announced today.

title: Credit for Beatrice
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said it had arranged $3 billion in credit for its purchase of Esmark Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Beatrice said it had established a four-year revolving credit agreement with 17 banks. The agent for the loan is Citibank N.A. Beatrice is offering $60 a share for Esmark common stock and $42.60 for each preferred share, for a total of about $2.8 billion.

title: Recount Opens in Texas In Democratic Runoff
description: State party officials today began a recount of ballots cast in the Democratic primary runoff for a United States Senate seat. The contest was between a liberal state senator and a conservative Congressman.

title: THE TIFFANNY MODEL
description: It is nearly a generation since the fashionable concern was consumerism, decadence bred of affluence, the psychic damage of the ''work ethic.''

title: Murderer Given Death Sentence
description: A 25- year-old Trenton man convicted of sexually assaulting and murdering a 75-year-old widow has become the seventh person ordered to die by lethal injection in New Jersey.

title: CONTROL OF TRANSIT POLICE: OLD DEBATE IS REKINDLED
description: Rising crime in the subways has renewed the longstanding debate about who is ultimately responsible for the city's transit police force - the Transit Authority or the Police Department.

title: ; FIX BANKING'S ROOF BEFORE THE 'HEAVY RAINS'
description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND STRESSES CONCILITATION
description: -MARIE-DU-MONT, France, June 6 - Leaders of the victorious Western Allies in World War II stood together at the edge of Utah Beach today and listened to their host, President Francois Mitterrand, say that they had sealed their reconciliation with Germany.

title: Up From Minors
description: In the late spring of his ninth straight year in minor league baseball, Jim Pankovits, batting .323 with Tucson of the Pacific Coast League, was finally called up to the Houston Astros.

title: THE HUMAN SPECIES' ULTIMATE GAMBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: CrashKills2DriversUpstate
description: Two dump trucks collided head on this morning, killing both drivers, just south of the Canadian border on Route 276 in Clinton County, the state police said. The drivers were identified as Timothy Heath of Champlain and Robert Bedard, 31 years old, of St. Johns, Quebec.

title: HOW THE POLLS WERE DONE
description: The accompanying article is based on questionnaires given to voters in Democratic Presidential primaries in randomly selected precincts as they left polling places in four states: Ohio and Indiana on May 8 and California and New Jersey last Tuesday. The polls in Ohio, California and New Jersey were conducted jointly by The New York Times and CBS News; the poll in Indiana was conducted by CBS News alone.

title: Article 244758 -- No Title
description: The House today approved by voice vote a $34.2 billion 1985 agriculture bill for programs ranging from crop subsidies to food stamps.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A German Bid for U.S. News
description: Gruner & Jahr, the West German publishing group, said it had bid $150 million for U. S. News & World Report, the third-largest weekly news magazine in the United States.

title: Dean Witter to Offer a Leveraged-Buyout Fund
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to begin marketing the first leveraged-buyout fund available for individual investors. If it is successful, other investment banking firms are expected to offer similar products.

title: ON A TREK IN WEST AFRICA, CRADLE OF CHOCOLATE BAR
description: The crop expert parked his car under a dense jungle canopy. The air felt soothingly cool and moist after the drive down the strip of tarmac bisecting the tropical rain forest, when the wind coming through the open window had struck like the blast from a furnace.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 7, 1984
description: The Economy

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $3,258,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $782,000.

title: A MATTER OF CAPITOL DIGNITY AND TIDINESS
description: When a Parliamentary delegation from Britain marched into the Capitol in 1976 bearing an original copy of Magna Carta on loan to the American people, a Pepsi truck was parked at one end of the East Plaza, a bread truck at the other.

title: D-DAY CEREMONIES VEX WEST GERMANS
description: For those who bear the legacy of the defeated, the D-day celebrations on the Normandy coast today awakened feelings of rejection, embarrassment and self-pity. Among the young, for whom this was grandfather's war, there was a touch of anger.

title: A DAUNTING VICTORY
description: At the moment when Walter Mondale finally has the nomination in his grasp, it may seem churlish to speak of his problems. But they are there, and he has to confront them if he is to have a serious prospect of defeating Ronald Reagan.

title: Judges Chosen for Ballet Competition
description: Eight judges have been selected for the first New York International Ballet Competition, which will take place at City Center from June 26 through July 2.

title: I.L.O. Group Elects Woman
description: Anna- Greta Leijon, the Swedish Minister of Labor, was unanimously elected president of the International Labor Organization's annual conference today at opening ceremonies attended by 1,600 delegates from 133 countries. She is the first woman to hold the post.

title: Jets Drop Luscinski
description: Jim Luscinski , the 25-year-old Jet offensive lineman who suffered a broken neck in an exhibition game last season and has not played since, was released yesterday after he refused a suggestion that he retire rather than risk further injury.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a long-term net capital gain of $480,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of securities. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $106,000 for the quarter and $185,000 for the 6 months and a long-term net capital gain of $1,105,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of the GTE Corp. common stock. Results for the latest periods include operations of Plow & Walters Printing Canada Ltd. for which the purchase of 80 percent was completed on March 30.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A SHIELD NOT MEANT TO PROTECT PORNOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCIETY SCHEDULES AN ART DECO WEEK
description: ''IF I had to name three things that are quintessentially Art Deco,'' said Jack Kent Cooke, owner of the Chrysler Building, ''I'd name Louise Brooks, first; Louise Brooks, second, and Louise Brooks, third. She was a woman who had great style.'' Miss Brooks, the film star of the 1920's, was admired for her daredevil ways and geometrically cut jet-black hair.

title: New Vancouver Director
description: Rudolf Barshai, founder of the Moscow Chamber Orchestra, has been named music director of the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra effective September 1985. Mr. Barshai, who emigrated from the Soviet Union in 1977, is principal conductor of the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra in Britain.

title: Manila on Alert After Peso Move
description: The Government declared a military alert in Manila today, hours after President Ferdinand E. Marcos issued a series of economic orders that devalued the peso by 22 percent and established a two-tiered system of exchange rates.

title: PANEL SEES ALARMING DROP IN MATH RESEARCH
description: Mathematics research in the United States has suffered an ''extreme'' and ''staggering'' loss of financing and new talent since 1968 that has gone virtually unnoticed because of the rapid growth in computer science and related fields, a National Research Council committee warned today.

title: LONDON MEETING GAINS AN IDENTITY
description: Like each of the nine previous economic summit conferences, the one here is acquiring its own special features and style that, along with the substance of its decisions, become the grist of history books.

title: Another Pipe Bomb Found in Chicago Area
description: The police today discovered a fourth pipe bomb planted downtown in less than a week and said it was fashioned like 19 other bombs found in the Upper Middle West in the last month.

title: Action Delayed on Bill For Continental Illinois
description: A legislative battle between Illinois's two biggest banks moved behind the scenes today as a state Senate committee delayed action on a bill to help the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company find a merger partner.

title: TEEN-AGERS' THOUGHTS ON LIFE AND THE WORLD
description: Teen- agers are promiscuous and prudish, materialistic and altruistic, fearful and optimistic. They have adult ambitions and juvenile restraints. But most of all, teens-agers are individuals, each with his or her own views, dreams and frustrations.

title: WICAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's loss includes a charge against earnings of about $4.1 million covering writeoffs of inventory and bad debts.

title: SOVIET UNION'S ROLE IN WAR ACKNOWLEDGED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan paid tribute today to the 20 million Soviet dead in World War II, but at ceremonies on the 40th anniversary of D-Day, he also accused Moscow of remaining ''uninvited and unwanted'' in Eastern Europe after the war.

title: PERFECT FIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL TO OPEN OCT. 9
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's 1984 Next Wave Festival, which has become this country's leading showcase for large-scale avant-garde performance works, will open Oct. 9 with the first American performance of ''The Games,'' a music-theater piece by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong. The festival will continue until Dec. 23, concluding with two weeks of performances of ''Einstein on the Beach,'' the five-hour vanguard opera by Robert Wilson and Philip Glass, in a revival of the 1976 original.

title: Pretoria Premier Offers Proposal on Namibia
description: South Africa is willing to withdraw from South-West Africa, or Namibia, if a group of five Western nations takes over the territory's administration and defense, Prime Minister P. W. Botha said today.

title: PHILHARMONIC: 7TH IN CONTEMPORARY-MUSIC SERIES
description: THE seventh program in the New York Philharmonic's contemporary-music series, presented Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, went to great lengths to prove nothing much. Long concerts can seem to zip right along if they engage the attention, but this more-than-three-hour concert did no such thing. The works, on the whole Minimalist in effect, if not always in intent, were marked by scarcity of ideas, self-indulgent length and reliance on droning repetition as a primary technical device.

title: 7,000 Flee Zulu Strife In South Africa District
description: More than 7,000 people have fled their homes in the South African south coast district of Umbumbulu as the death toll in clan strife last week climbed to 44, local residents and a priest said today.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Cool and gray, a north wind wrapped in rain swept across Long Island Sound, soaking the rock and concrete moors of this nautical Elba and reminding those quartered in the lighthouse here that exile to the many is often refuge to the few.

title: HEARINGS BEGIN ON TAX REFORM
description: The Administration, seeking to link President Reagan's re-election to the possibility of tax reform in 1985, formally opened public debate today on overhauling the 70-year-old Federal income tax.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; A Zero-Coupon Issue Of Sears Eurobonds
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company became the second United States company to offer zero-coupon bonds in the Eurobond market this week. Through a subsidiary, Sears is selling $500 million face amount of zero-coupon bonds, which do not bear interest, through underwiters led by the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $54,000 for the quarter and a loss of $178,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including gains of $14,000 for the quarter and $48,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
PRODUCTS FOR THE DISABLED
description: -order companies that specialize in products for those who are recovering from an illness or who have a disability.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TIME was when only the homeowner with a couple of acres or more would think of buying a riding mower or lawn tractor. But this has changed recently, with the introduction of machines that are more compact, maneuverable and versatile, as well as easier to operate, store and maintain.

title: COLLEAGUE SAYS SAKHAROV IS WELL
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, is alive and well in Gorky, the city to which he was exiled in January 1980, a fellow member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Indonesian Trade Data
