description: Indonesia had a trade surplus of $1.7 billion in the first two months of this year, Information Minister Harmoko said today. He said exports totaled $3.6 billion in January and February while imports were $1.9 billion.

title: BUDGET MANEUVERS
description: On the surface, the negotiations that produced New York City's budget for the 1985 fiscal year were characterized by two factors - a general sense of civility and the completion of the adoption process before the legal deadline of midnight Tuesday. But other, less obvious factors were at work as well, and they may be more revealing about the shifting financial and political realities of municipal government.

title: SOVIET IS OUT OF L.I. MEET
description: The Soviet Union has withdrawn its team from participation in the International Games for the Disabled, a two-week-long event to be held in Uniondale, L.I., and the surrounding area starting June 16.

title: Ramapo Coach Learns Quickly
description: In his second year as head coach of the Ramapo College baseball team, 24-year-old Mickey Ennis did good work. His Roadrunners won the New Jersey State Athletic Conference championship and then went on to capture the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III title last week at Marietta, Ohio.

title: Henderson, Friedlich'sDrake Hotel Campaign
description: Having learned from a national research study that when it comes to hotels the Swiss have a very positive reputation in the areas of operations, efficiency and service, Henderson, Friedlich, Graf & Doyle has played up exactly those qualities in the print campaign it has prepared to celebrate the reopening of the Drake Hotel, now owned by Swissotel chain.

title: TO HELP CHANNEL 13
description: -TV, felt that the public today is more conscious of good design was one of the starting points for this year's Channel 13 auction, entitled ''By Design.'' The auction starts tomorrow evening at 8 P.M. and continues on Saturday evening as well as Sunday afternoon and evening.

title: Robbery Suspect Hunted in Canada
description: The manhunt for Victor Gerena, the suspect in the $7 million robbery of a Wells Fargo terminal last September, was extended to Canada today by the police and the F.B.I.

title: U.S. LETS RUSSIAN DEPART FOR HOME
description: The State Department said today that a Soviet mathematician, whose unusual behavior and indecision about leaving the United States produced a freeze in Soviet-American scholarly exchanges in April, was quietly permitted to return to the Soviet Union on Tuesday.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LONG-TERM BONDS FALL A POINT
description: Long-term bond prices, which have been fluctuating widely day to day, fell about a point yesterday in lackluster trading.

title: Teacher Freed in Italy
description: A teacher kidnapped seven months ago was released unharmed today after her parents paid a $480,000 ransom, the police said. The kidnappers originally demanded a ransom of $2.4 million, which the teacher's father, head of a wine-exporting business, said he could not pay. The teacher, Anna Maria Fusco, was kidnapped in November as she was driving from her home to the village school.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Recognition Equipment Inc. had the rating on its 11 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2006, raised to B- from CCC by Standard & Poor's.

title: NEWEST ROBOTS 'SEE' OBJECTS
description: ROBOTS are rapidly making their way from science fiction stories into automated production systems being installed in the manufacturing plants of industrialized nations. Unlike their fictional counterparts, though, most robots in use today are quite limited in what they can do.

title: HART NOT GIVING IN
description: Walter F. Mondale claimed victory yesterday in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and a number of party leaders united behind the former Vice President to urge his main competitor, Senator Gary Hart, to fold his campaign.

title: RAIL BAN ON DRUGS AND DRINKING SET
description: The Department of Transportation today proposed the first Federal ban on alcohol and drug use by railroad crews, expanding authority to test the workers but requiring leniency for those who seek treatment.

title: MOTHERLY REFLECTIONS AT A COLLEGE GRADUATION
description: LAST week my daughter was graduated from a college that no one ever leaves. I see 40- year-olds wearing sweatshirts that say

title: SAVING AN OVERSTUFFED BRITISH MANSION
description: Calke Abbey, a vast Palladian pile, is so well hidden in a hollow of the Derbyshire countryside that both the house and its owners have managed to stay out of the public eye for 280 years.

title: Doyle Dane Rapp Unit In Japan Partnership
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International announced yesterday that Rapp & Collins, its direct marketing subsidiary, would be a partner in the first such agency in Japan.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Playful Prediction Becomes Battle Cry
description: On May 22 in Wheeling, W. Va., Walter F. Mondale playfully vowed to reporters that he would cross the threshold of 1,967 delegates, the number needed to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, at 11:59 A.M. June 6, central daylight time.

title: Miss Budd in Olympics
description: Zola Budd sped from 16 rivals at the Crystal Palace in London last night to win a 3,000-meter race and qualify for the Bristish Olympic team.

title: A 'Choking' Price
description: When the Ladies Professional Golf Association announced early this year that there would be a $4 million bonus prize for any woman who could win the Nabisco Dinah Shore Invitational and the J & B Pro-Am on successive weekends this year, JoAnne Carner said she had finally found her personal choking price. No one can win the $4 million prize because Juli Inkster won the Dinah Shore tourney, April 8, and then Ayako Okamoto of Japan won the J & B, April 15.

title: VOTES FROM MOST AREAS GIVE CALIFORNIA TO HART
description: Senator Gary Hart won the Democratic Presidential primary in California on Tuesday by solidly outpolling former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in all sections of the state except portions of Los Angeles and a handful of other communities in southern California.

title: JAZZ: 'VINTAGE' SOUNDS
description: MORE than 75 jazz musicians, organized in eight bands, played a four- hour marathon billed as ''New York's First Vintage Jazz Band Bash'' at St. Peter's Church on Monday evening. It was a benefit to support a series of concerts of classic jazz, ''Vintage Jazz at the Vineyard,'' that began at the Vineyard Theater earlier this year.

title: Volcker Hails Debt Move
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that a decision by bankers to give Mexico better terms for repaying its debts was the beginning of a ''new phase'' in the Latin American debt crisis. ''I think this approach that was taken here - the initiative taken toward Mexico - is a constructive change to a longer-term perspective within the same basic approach that's been followed,'' Mr. Volcker said at a news conference. It followed the closing session of the International Monetary Conference here. Mr. Volcker was referring to the bankers' agreement to negotiate a stretch-out of payments from Mexico, beginning with those falling due in 1985.

title: New Antitrust Rules Would Allow for Imports
description: The Justice Department will announce new antitrust guidelines next week under which the market share of imports will be considered when mergers are being reviewed for possible challenge, the head of the antitrust division said today.

title: No Headline
description: Revenue estimates are total increase or decrease from fiscal year 1984 through 1987.

title: Letter: On Phone Service Keep Pay Calls at 10 Cents
description: To the Editor:

title: GERRY COONEY'S LAMENT
description: Gerry Cooney, gasping for breath, perspiration pouring down his face, unwrapped his strong but brittle hands and faced the crowd:

title: AVCO: CONGLOMERATE ON A DIET
description: In the 20 years since the Avco Corporation, a military contractor, began branching out to become one of the nation's most diversified conglomerates its strategy has come full circle.

title: REMARKS BY REAGAN IN NORMANDY
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan today at Omaha Beach at the joint American-French ceremony commemorating the 40th anniversary of the Allied landings in Normandy:

title: DOCUMENTARY ON THREE JAZZ PIANISTS
description: WHEN he went to make a documentary on New Orleans music - ''Piano Players Rarely Ever Play Together,'' which is being shown at 11 o'clock tonight on Channel 13 - Stevenson J. Palfi had a good idea. He would bring together the blues pianist Isidore (Tuts) Washington; his sometime student Henry Byrd, better known as Professor Longhair, a pioneering rhythm-and- blues pianist, and a Longhair disciple, the pianist-songwriter-producer Allen Toussaint. They would perform separately, and then play together in concert for the first time.

title: Haitian Boat Capsizes As Coast Guard Boards
description: Six Haitians drowned and 61 others were rescued when a sailboat capsized tonight after the Coast Guard boarded the vessel, suspecting her passengers were trying to enter the United States illegally, officials said.

title: The Kingdom Strikes Back
description: Saudi Arabia seems embarrassed by its fliers' success in shooting down one or more Iranian F-4 fighters. ''A strange event,'' said a Saudi broadcast, while the kingdom's envoy in Washington found it ''a pity we had to be dragged into this conflict.'' What's really strange is the outlook underlying these remarks - Saudi Arabia's complacent illusion that it could stay out of trouble in the Persian Gulf the easy way, with money.

title: ISRAELI RIGHTS CHAMPIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,500 IN SALVADOR FLEE REBEL AREA
description: More than 1,500 Salvadorans have fled what appears to be a major guerrilla recruitment drive in rebel-held territory of northern Morazan Province, according to refugees, deserters and military officials.

title: Block Islanders Agree on Referendum
description: The 620 year-round residents of Block Island, who have threatened to secede from Rhode Island unless they get permission to regulate tourist moped traffic, agreed today to seek a referendum aimed at forcing the state to take a stand.

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CELTICS WIN IN OVERTIME, TIE SERIES, 2-2
description: Larry Bird, who played a physical game tonight, used finesse in the end to help the Boston Celtics beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 129-125, in overtime and tie the championship series at two games each.

title: Coast Volcano Emits Steam
description: Airline pilots flying past Mount St. Helens early today saw a plume of steam and ash from the volcano rising to almost 30,000 feet, according to the National Weather Service.

title: JAPANESE FIGHT UNITARY TAX IN U.S.
description: A delegation of top business executives from Japan, led by Akio Morita, chairman and co-founder of the Sony Corporation, has begun an intensive lobbying campaign in state capitals across the country to abolish a tax that has angered foreign-based and domestic multinational companies.

title: Reliving The War Of Burgers
description: TO the executive wing of McDonald's last September, suing

title: SPEAKER O'NEILL: HARDBALL OR HAND GRENADES?
description: What is the proper role for the Speaker of the House?

title: Bank Rejection
description: The Old Stone Corporation of Providence, R.I., said the Federal Reserve Board had denied the company's application to acquire the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Catawba County, N.C. Old Stone said the agency had not outlined the reasons for the denial. The company signed a letter of intent in December 1983 and a definitive agreement last April to acquire First Federal, which has assets of $66 million. Old Stone had planned to merge First Federal with Perpetual Savings and Loan Assoction of High Point, N.C., which Old Stone acquired last year.

title: Buckle Down to Safety
description: Just a week after the New York State Assembly brushed aside a proposal to raise the drinking age, the Legislature seems poised to pass a far more effective measure for reducing highway injuries: a mandatory seat belt law.

title: Dupree Sums Up
description: Marcus Dupree's first season as a pro football player has been a good if not gaudy one and there are better days ahead, according to his coach, Dick Coury, of the New Orleans Breakers.

title: Yields Up Further At Banks
description: Annual effective yields on money market deposit accounts edged higher, to 9.36 percent in the week ended Wednesday, from 9.34 percent last week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: THE KEYBOARD STYMIES JAPAN
description: While increasing numbers of American office workers are adapting to the computer keyboard after years spent at the familiar typewriter, their Japanese counterparts face a more fundamental question: How do you use a keyboard?

title: MUSEUM FUND CUT DEFEATED
description: A measure to withdraw $7 million in city funds for the American Museum of Natural History was defeated late Tuesday night by the City Council. It fell seven votes shy of the needed majority.

title: Escapee Caught
description: State and local police officers recaptured a robbery suspect today, less than 24 hours after he escaped from the Community Correctional Center at Montville.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
3 Safe After Line To Scaffold Snaps
description: Three midtown window washers were left dangling 49 stories in the air yesterday when a line broke and dropped one end of their scaffold, the police said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Mattel, Solely in Toys,Combines Management
description: Reflecting a return to what has always been its lifeblood, the making of toys, Mattel Inc. yesterday combined its top management into a new office of the chief executive.

title: EXXON TO PAY $1.5 MILLION TO SETTLE DISPUTE ON WATER
description: The Exxon Corporation agreed today to pay New York State $1.5 million in a settlement stemming from the company's shipment of more than 100 tanker loads of Hudson River water to Aruba.

title: REAGAN HONORS D-DAY: CALLS FOR SPIRIT OF PEACE
description: The writer of this dispatch covered the Allied landings in Normandy in 1944 for the New York Times and has been military correspondent for The Times since 1970.

title: Scot Lad in Talks
description: Scot Lad Foods Inc., a food wholesaler based in Lansing, Ill., said it is negotiating the sale of most of its assets, including the company name, to Roundy's Inc. for about $40 million.

title: BY VENTURI: SOMETHING BORROWED, SOMETHING NEW
description: LAST month at the Wooster Street showroom of Knoll International, the long-awaited furniture collection by the Philadelphia architect Robert Venturi was presented to the New York design community.

title: PHILADELPHIA: NEW LIFE FOR OLD HOMES
description: PHILADELPHIA HAD it not been for the Great Fire of London in 1666, the streets of Philadelphia might not be, as they are today, at right angles to each other. But there

title: HOME CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: GOLFER REGAINS CONFIDENCE AFTER DESPAIR
description: Gary Koch was playing golf so poorly in 1981 that he thought of quitting the PGA Tour. Instead, he subjected himself to a complete overhaul of his swing, ''as if someone had told me to return to Go.''

title: DEFENSE DEPICTS THE BAWDY SIDE OF A WITNESS AGAINST DELOREAN
description: The defense in John Z. DeLorean's drug trial today played long segments of a videotape in which the jury saw a Government informer, James Timothy Hoffman, drinking, cursing and making bawdy comments about women. The Government showed other segments of the tape in building its case against Mr. DeLorean.

title: DISNEY REACHES ACCORD FOR GIBSON GREETINGS
description: Putting more of its shares in friendly hands, Walt Disney Productions said today that it had agreed to acquire Gibson Greetings Inc. for up to $337.5 million in newly issued stock.

title: Sales Tax of 7.5% Passed in Suffolk
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted, 10 to 8, today to ask the State Legislature to approve a one-quarter of a cent increase in the county's sales tax, bringing it to 7.5 percent.

title: EXHIBITION OF WORK IN STERLING SILVER
description: An exhibition of 51 works in sterling-silver holloware and flatware by undergraduate and graduate-school design students around the country is in progress in the lobby of Lever House, Park Avenue at 54th Street.

title: Argentine Debt Pact Seen Near
description: Argentina will sign a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund by Sunday on an austerity plan that would help it ease its foreign debt, according to Adolfo Canitrot, its Under Secretary of Planning. Mr. Canitrot, who has been involved in drawing up the agreement outlining Argentina's economic goals, told the Ambito Financiero newspaper that a letter of intent would be signed before President Raul Alfonsin leaves for Spain on Sunday for a four-day visit. ''The fundamental questions are already resolved,'' he was quoted as saying.

title: Mattel, Solely in Toys, Combines Management
description: Reflecting a return to what has always been its lifeblood, the making of toys, Mattel Inc. yesterday combined its top management into a new office of the chief executive.

title: MERLAND EXPLORATIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN TRIBUTE TO D-DAY DEAD AND PLEA FOR SPIRIT OF PEACE
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan to D-day veterans at Pointe du Hoc today:

title: JUDGE INSISTS AT TRIAL THAT HE NEVER TOOK BRIBES
description: A Cook County judge, the first to come to trial as a result of a Federal corruption investigation, denied today that he had ever accepted money to influence his rulings..

title: HEAD OF N.R.C. IS URGED TO QUIT SHOREHAM TALKS
description: Governor Cuomo called today for the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to disqualify himself from all licensing proceedings for the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island.

title: J.P. Morgan & Co. Investing in FGIC
description: J. P. Morgan & Company has invested $20 million in the FGIC Corporation, a municipal bond insurance company founded last year.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN, TRAIL BY 3 1/2
description: Willie Upshaw and George Bell homered as the Toronto Blue Jays beat Detroit, 6-3, tonight and inched closer to the struggling Tigers.

title: Nader Nominates Mondale As Best Consumerist in Race
description: Ralph Nader today called Walter F. Mondale the major Presidential candidate who most deserved the support of the consumer protection movement he has prodded to political action in the last 20 years.

title: THE GREAT REEF WRIT RACE
description: James G. Watt, the National Wildlife Federation, the Army Corps of Engineers, sport fishers and some of America's largest oil companies might not seem to have much common. But they all love reefs. Man-made fishing reefs, that is.

title: HART, SAYING RACE IS NOT OVER, VOWS TO FIGHT ON
description: Fresh from a major victory in the California primary, Senator Gary Hart today refused to concede defeat to Walter F. Mondale in their battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He vowed to continue fighting for delegates.

title: Coax Me Chad Is a Rare Colt
description: Most racing fans can easily reel off the last dozen or so Kentucky Derby winners, but one of the quickest ways to win a bar bet, even from a racetracker, is to ask him to name the last few Derby runners-up.

title: St. Louis Rejects School Plan
description: City voters have rejected a $63.5 million bond issue for the second time, raising the possibility that a Federal judge could order an increase in taxes to finance part of a voluntary school desegregation plan.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARETS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $12 million from the termination of a pension plan. c-Including a tax credit of $3,759,000.

title: Black Registration Alarms G.O.P. Leaders
description: Complacency among Republicans and other conservative voters, countered by thousands of potential voters newly registered by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a Democrat, is the major threat to the re- election of President Reagan this fall, Republican leaders in the South said today.

title: TAKEOVERS AND INSIDER TRADES
description: A PATTERN of what seems to be insider trading is emerging in the securities markets. Stocks of companies have been climbing, often on a sharp increase in volume, just before the announcement of some takeover or management buyout.

title: 308 PEOLPLE KILLED AS INDIAN TROOPS TAKE SIKH TEMPLE
description: At least 308 people were killed Wednesday and today as the Indian Army attacked and occupied the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion in an attempt to end a terrorist campaign that has tormented India's Punjab state for nearly two years.

title: GAS EMITTED BY SOIL AND BUILDINGS SEEN AS A CANCER SOURCE
description: Radon, a common radioactive gas emitted by soil, stones and most building materials, may be responsible for as many as 10,000 lung cancer deaths among nonsmokers in the United States each year, according to an editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: DIVERTING REFUND TO CHILD SUPPORT RAISES TAX CHEATING, STUDY FINDS
description: A wide study by the Internal Revenue Service has uncovered tentative evidence that use of the agency for nontax purposes such as collecting child-support payments may lead to an increase in tax cheating.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Andal Corp., a real estate developer, said it planned to make a tender offer to buy 1.5 million of its common shares outstanding for $4.75 each. The company has about 9 million shares outstanding.

title: Poland Detains 15 In Raid on Printing Plant
description: The Polish police have detained 15 people in a raid on an underground printing center and seven others who put up anti- Communist placards in public places, the official press said today.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 7, 1984 International
description: At least 300 Indians were killed as the army attacked and occupied the holiest Sikh shrine in an attempt to end a terrorist campaign that has tormented India's Punjab state for nearly two years. Officials said that about 450 rebellious Sikhs and their backers had been captured inside the temple complex. (Page A1, Col. 1.) More than 1,500 Salvadorans fled what appears to be a major guerrilla recruitment drive in territory of northern Morazan Province that has long been held by the rebels, according to refugees, deserters and military officials. (A1:2.)

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A SHIELD NOT MEANT TO PROTECT PORNOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Mutes Criticism
description: Soviet news organizations noted the celebrations of the 40th anniversary of D-day today without repeating their accusation that they were intended to sully the memories of Soviet war heroes. The official press agency, Tass, said the invasion ''was of much importance for the final routing of Hitler's Germany, which had been predetermined by the victories of Soviet forces on the main front of the war, the eastern front.''

title: FAVORING GERMAN DETENTE
description: Nearly four decades after the end of World War II in Europe, the superpower rivalry that divides the Continent is as tense as it has ever been, but East and West Germany seem to be moving toward a new thaw. The United States is increasingly concerned about this mini- detente, largely because of the questions that German reunification could pose for West Germany's commitment to the Western alliance. The concern is understandable, but Washington can itself do much to ease the problem by encouraging and participating in the rapprochment rather than opposing it.

title: Gacy, Convicted Killer Of 33, Is Denied Appeal
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today rejected the appeal of John W. Gacy, upholding his convictions in the sex killings of 33 young men and boys and setting a date for his execution.

title: AFTER 3 MONTHS, PRAISE FOR ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR
description: In his first three months in office, Mayor James L. Usry has won praise from many quarters for his highly visible, aggressive leadership in attacking city problems.

title: International Borrowing Off
description: The amount of new borrowing on the international capital market in May fell $5.9 billion from April and was down $2 billion from a year earlier, to $10.5 billion, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The volume of new bank lending and credit guarantees in May fell $3.4 billion from April, to $3.7 billion, while new bond offerings fell $2.4 billion, to $6.8 billion. Gross new borrowing through bond issues and bank loans from March through May totalled $41 billion.

title: 'WHAT KEEPS ME JUMPING'
description: Arnold Boldt never considered

title: Comings and Goings
description: Craig Swan , who has an aggravated tricep, a condition he had with the Mets earlier in the season, was put on the 15-day disabled list by the California Angels. Swan is 0-1 with a 10.80 earned run average. . . . Dennis Leonard will undergo knee surgery for a third time and miss the rest of the season, the Kansas City Royals announced. . . . Bert Blyleven, the Cleveland pitcher who has been sidelined with a broken foot since May 19, was expected to be reactivated today.

title: Soviet Jails Orthodox Priest
description: A Russian Orthodox priest, Father Nikolai Temirbayev, has been jailed for two years on charges of ''hooliganism'' after being accused of beating his wife and abusing parishoners, the trade union paper Trud reported today. Trud said the police had begun to receive complaints after the priest took over a congregation at Krasnovodsk in Central Asia.

title: HOUSE REJECTS RULE ON CAMERAS IN CHAMBER
description: The House of Representatives today defeated a proposal that essentially would have required television cameras that cover legislative proceedings to pan the chamber regularly to show viewers how many members are in attendance.

title: Bank in Alabama
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it had approved the assumption of the deposits of the failed Cherokee County Bank of Centre, Ala., by First Alabama N.A. of Anniston, Ala.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page yesterday misidentified William D. Ruckelshaus. He is Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: J. ROSS MacLENNAN
description: J. Ross MacLennan, a retired advertising and insurance executive, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: STRATEGIES FOCUS ON SINGLE MOTHERS
description: Several strategies to aid single mothers were recommended at a conference here today by members of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc., the largest organization of black women in the country.

title: Blacks Could Control New Council in Selma
description: A Federal court order redrawing City Council ward lines may help blacks win political control of this landmark of the voting rights movement when municipal elections are held July 10.

title: A CO-OP BREAKS GROUND FOR OWN ELECTRIC PLANT
description: In the first move of its kind by a housing development in the city, the 2,800- apartment Penn South cooperative in Manhattan broke ground yesterday for a private power plant that will replace energy from Consolidated Edison.

title: ADMINISTRATION DECIDES TO RELEASE RECORDS OF TRANSITION ACCOUNTS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials who directed two private transition funds have decided to release the records of the accounts to dispel questions about them, including the question of why they have been kept secret.

title: CITY BALLET: 'COUPERIN'
description: TUESDAY night's program by the New York City Ballet in the New York State Theater became an evening of friendly merrymaking. All four works offered were celebrations of conviviality.

title: 50 FIREFIGHTERS ARE DECORATED FOR BOLD RESCUES FROM BURNING BUILDINGS
description: When Hernando Figuero came to, he was dangling high above the street, draped over a firefighter's shoulder. With cinders showering his body, he grabbed the aerial ladder and would not let go.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Mobil President Gets a Successor
description: Allen E. Murray will succeed William P. Tavoulareas as president and chief operating officer of the Mobil Corporation when Mr. Tavoulareas retires on Nov. 1, the company announced yesterday.

title: Ex-Aide Backs Help on Westway
description: William C. Hennessy, the former State Transportation Commissioner, said in an interview yesterday that the state had relied heavily on outside consultants in making decisions involving the Westway because ''we just didn't have the expertise'' and it was thought their use might expedite the highway and development project.

title: Mr. Mondale's Strength
description: When the marathon began last winter and Democrats were asked to name the candidate they preferred, they were apt to say something like, ''Mondale, I guess.'' Ask the same question now, five grueling months later, and they are apt to say the same thing. Mr. Mondale probably has all the delegates necessary to be nominated. But that's not certain even now. Tuesday's mixed result, triumph in New Jersey and defeat in California, invites the same questions that have echoed through the campaign.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $586,000. c-Net income d-Includes a net after-tax charge of $904,000 related to the closing and sale of a plant.

title: Article 243722 -- No Title
description: The Colorado Supreme Court has upheld a $6.8 million negligence award in favor of a woman who says she suffered a septic abortion and nearly died after using the Dalkon Shield birth-control device.

title: Newark Airport Opens New Wing
description: A new $20.2 million international-arrivals area was dedicated today at Newark International Airport, the country's fasting growing airport.

title: RUMINATIONS INSPIRED BY A MEDICARE CARD
description: ''Grow old along with me!

title: THE CITY ; ;  Addabbo Can Run In G.O.P. Primary
description: The executive committee of the Republican Party in Queens last night gave Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, a Democrat, permission to run in the Sept. 11 Republican primary for his Seventh District seat.

title: FAIRFIELD PORTER, MASTER REALIST
description: THE felicitous ease of Fairfield Porter's canvases cause many viewers trouble. ''Are they modern enough? Too French? Too pleasant? Hasn't this been done before?'' are questions that - the critic John Ashbery amusingly suggests - people guiltily raise while succumbing to their charms. Art, as we all know, must be difficult, intellectually challenging, and not, well, immediately accessible. On these counts, the Porter works flunk, as is readily apparent in ''Fairfield Porter,'' the first major retrospective of this influential realist (1907-75), at the Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue, at 75th Street (through Aug. 19).

title: ONE MAN'S TWO VIEWS OF ETHIOPIA'S JUNTA
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSMATION INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FREE AGENTS. By Max Apple. 197 Pages. Harper & Row. $14.50. WITH ''The Oranging of America'' a few years ago, Max Apple established himself as a friendly critic of American culture. What distinguishes him from other critics is the affection in his voice, as if he were remonstrating with someone he loved - like parents, children or friends. There's something saintly about him; he's patient and amused, rather than angry. His wit is tender, soft-edged, insidious.

title: JACKSON HINTS GOALS MUST BE MET BEFORE UNITY IS ACHIEVED IN PARTY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson showed little inclination to compromise with Walter F. Mondale and the Democratic Party leadership tonight at the annual convention of Operation PUSH, the civil rights organization that he founded.

title: Election Tie in Greenland
description: The governing party finished in an 11-11 tie for seats in Parliament with a moderate opposition party in elections Wednesday, according to unofficial returns issued today in this capital, which is also known by its Eskimo name, Nuut. The unofficial returns gave both Prime Minister Jonathan Motzfeldt's nationalist, leftist Siumut Party and the Atassut Party 11 seats in Parliament.

title: graph of Shoney's net income since 1974; AT SHONEY'S, DETAILS COUNT
description: When Gary P. Spoleta, the president of Shoney's Inc., visited one of his company's restaurants in Kansas City, Mo., three years ago, he was upset by what he saw. A flood of conventiongoers at lunchtime overwhelmed the coffee shop's staff, and a line of customers waiting for tables extended out the door.

title: AGNICO EAGLE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures represent bullion revenue. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Conagra Option
description: Conagra Inc. said it had exercised its option to acquire the remaining 50 percent in Country Poultry Inc. from Imperial Foods Ltd. for $18 million. Country Poultry, which will be known as the Conagra Poultry Companies, was formed in September 1982 as a joint venture between Conagra and Imperial Foods.

title: Philadelphia of U.S.F.L. Sues N.F.L.
description: The Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League filed a civil antitrust suit against the rival National Football League today, seeking to prevent the N.F.L. from negotiationg with U.S.F.L. players when they are still under contract.

title: MIND-READING GORBACHEV
description: Here am I, Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, only 53 years old, next in line for Kremlin power. For four years, waiting for the General Secretary to die - first Brezhnev, then Andropov, now Chernenko - has been the main activity in the Politburo and we have all become good at it.

title: DIGITAL AND UNIVERSITY PLAN A COMPUTER DEAL
description: The 44,000-student University of Houston and the Digital Equipment Corporation announced today that they would set up a school computer network worth up to $70 million.

title: INTERCOLE INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,606,000, or $1.02 a share, on the termination of a contract.

title: Another Chief Is Named At Franklin Computer
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation, in the third major management shift in three months, announced yesterday that Morton E. David had been named chairman and chief executive.

title: DIAGNOSTIC DATA INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: BROOKLYN'S TEAM, AS EVER
description: Carl Erskine, Carl Furillo and the late Gil Hodges were inducted yesterday into the new Brooklyn Dodger Hall of Fame, a creation of the faculty and students at Intermediate School 320, now named for Jackie Robinson and situated on McKeever Place, where Ebbets Field fans once bought their hot dogs and parked their cars.

title: IN LEBANON, THE PESSIMISM DEEPENS
description: As the elegantly tailored deputies arrived at their bullet-splattered Parliament building every day this week to debate the new Cabinet proposed by Prime Minister Rashid Karami, they were greeted by a swarm of wailing women brandishing framed photographs and beating on the M.P.'s limousines.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $134,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: MOVIE: 'BEAT STREET'
description: ''BEAT STREET,'' which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is designed for everybody who still hasn't had his or her fill of break dancing, or who doesn't yet understand that break dancing, rap singing and graffiti are legitimate expressions of the urban artistic impulse.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: All Nippon Airways Co. Ltd.'s $100 million issue of 14 percent bonds due in 1994 was priced at par, through Morgan Guaranty Ltd. The issue is guaranteed by the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd.

title: Little League Assault Oklahoma authorities have filed an assault charge against a Tulsa man accused of hitting a Little League umpire over a disputed call in a game May 17. The suspect, the father of a player, was identified as
description: Butch McCreary. The umpire, Neal Banks, said McCreary hit him twice in the face as he was trying to explain to a group of angry parents why he had called a player out: Because his batting helmet had not been tightly strapped.

title: CASTRO TO GET OLYMPICS PLEA
description: -Peter V. Ueberroth, chairman of the Los Angeles Olympics Organizing Committee, left for cuba today to ask for Fidel Castro to drop his boycott. Cuba is among thirteen nations that followed the Soviet Union in pulling out of the games, which start July 28.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1984 International
description: The 10th summit conference of the seven major industrialized democracies opened in London in a mood of modest expectation generated by repeated official warnings that neither bold policy initiatives nor ''magical solutions'' were likely to be achieved. (Page A1, Column 6.) Violence erupted in Indian cities arising from the Indian Army's attack Wednesday on the Sikh shrine in Amritsar and the death of more nearly 400 people, including a radical Sikh leader. The army occupied the Golden Temple in an attempt to end Sikh terrorism. (A1:5.)

title: ART: RECENT DE KOONINGS
description: VISITORS to the Willem de Kooning retrospective held last winter at the Whitney Museum will recall how startling the show's finale was. Already in his works of the late 1970's there was a perceptible clearing of the formal undergrowth and a speeding up of the paint, but nothing on a scale to prepare spectators for the images of the early 80's, with their look of porcelain decorated with large, sweeping hieroglyphs.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE': A GRAMMARIAN CUTS UP
description: ALTHOUGH wheezing noticeably after nearly nine long years on the air, NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' can still come up with an interesting turn occasionally. In February, for instance, the host for the evening turned out to be Edwin Newman, the television reporter, best-selling grammarian and just about the last person one would expect to see dabbling in wacky comedy. That 90-minute session will be rebroadcast tomorrow at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 4.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise;  Mortgage Rates Rose in May
description: Mortgage rates continued to climb last month, with conventional fixed- rate loans for a new home rising to 14.34 percent from 14.12 percent in April, the Government said today.

title: CGA Accepts Bid
description: CGA Computer Inc. said it had agreed in principle to be acquired for $13 a share by Bernard M. Goldsmith 3d, who is its chairman; the General Atlantic Corporation, a private investment company based in New York, and other management investors. Based on CGA's approximately 3.4 million shares, the deal would be valued at $44.2 million. CGA jumped $2, to $11.50 bid, in over-the-counter trading yesterday.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan's trade surplus widened to $727 million in May from $387.1 million a year earlier, the Government said today. Exports in May reached a record high of $2.89 billion, up 34.5 percent from May 1983. Imports totaled $2.16 million, up 19 percent from a year earlier.

title: ISRAEL'S IRREVERSIBLE EXPANSION
description: During the 17 years since the 1967 war, Israel has ruled unchallenged over the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Golan Heights. While the international community has raged against this policy, successive governments and large numbers of Israelis have undertaken the single-minded pursuit of what the former President Chaim Weizmann once called ''building Palestine.'' This policy of creating facts has created a new reality.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Young Team of 6 Cuts Cards To Determine Partnerships

title: THE CABARET ARRAY: POP, BLUES, FOLK AND THEN SOME
description: HOMESPUN but eloquent pop, earthy blues, precise close harmony singing, post-Beat satire and surreal folk music are all in New York's clubs this weekend for people in search of quality cabaret.

title: No Headline
description: Coast Patient, 70, Sues To Detach Respirator

title: PARISH'S COMEBACK SPURS THE CELTICS
description: The jokes alone spoke volumes about how Robert Parish's contributions were being perceived during the championship series. There was one about the Boston bar that displayed a sign reading: ''Come to the Garden Thursday and see Robert Perish.'' Another asked: ''Is Parish burning?''

title: STATE TIES BACKING OF PARK PROJECT TO PRESERVATION OF BROOKLYN JOBS
description: State officials warned a private developer yesterday that he might lose their approval to build a park and marina on the Brooklyn waterfront unless he proved that he would also preserve 1,700 industrial jobs in nearby buildings he owns.

title: THE REGION ; ;  3 Crewmen Saved As Tug Capsizes
description: Three crew members were rescued when a tugboat capsized Wednesday night in the Connecticut River after colliding with a barge.

title: Turkish Journalists Complain of Jailings
description: Leftist Turkish journalists said today that 82 journalists, writers and artists had been jailed since the 1980 military coup and that 181 others had been questioned or temporarily detained.

title: Lewis Hine Photos
description: An exhibition of photographs titled ''Lewis W. Hine: Works from the National Research Project. 1936-37,'' is on view at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through July 8.

title: STANFORD'S CENSURE ON PLAGIARISM LEADS MEDICINE CHIEF TO QUIT POST
description: A Stanford professor resigned today as chairman of the department of medicine after a university ethics committee censured him for ''grossly negligent scholarship.''

title: A SHOE CONCERN TO CLOSE DOORS
description: Welpro Inc. of Seabrook, N.H., a 50-year-old maker of women's dress shoes, will cease operating July 1, Stanley Barr, president and son of the company's founder, told the 250 employees at noon today.

title: Sullivan, No Gilbert
description: ''The Zoo,'' a rare operetta by Sir Arthur Sullivan and Bolton Rowe, will be performed tonight at 8 at the Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street. Free tickets can be reserved by calling 355- 2200.

title: Sony U.S. Plant
description: The Sony Corporation of America, as expected, said it would build a laser videodisk facility in Terre Haute, Ind., provided it can get tax-exempt financing and Federal grant funds. Akio Morita, chairman and chief executive officer of Sony, said the company decided to locate in Indiana because of a pledge signed by state officials that the state would not impose a unitary tax against Sony. The unitary tax allows states to tax corporations based on their worldwide earnings, not just income earned within the state's boundaries.

title: Senate Sets Permanent Form For Indian Affairs Committee
description: The Senate on Wednesday made permanent its Select Committee on Indian Affairs, which has been operating on temporary authorization since 1977.

title: Sucking In Money - and Imports
description: The country's record foreign trade gap grows wider each month. In the first four months of this year, imports exceeded exports by $42 billion, and the full-year imbalance may be three times that. Something's wrong - and beware of quick, protectionist fixes.

description: The J. Paul Getty Museum has acquired nine private collections of 19th- and 20th-century American and European photographs - many of them unknown and not reproduced or publicly displayed before - and will house them in a newly formed Department of Photography, the museum announced yesterday.

title: A SMALL BANK'S FAILURE PAINS A SMALL TOWN
description: A month ago, the employees of the First National Bank of Rushford watched as a Federal official pulled down the bank's window shade and tacked up a notice telling customers that the 82- year-old bank was closed for good.

title: FOR EISENHOWER,2 GOALS IF BOMB WAS TO BE USED
description: The State Department issued a historical volume today on relations with Korea in 1952-54, which included discussions on the possible use of American atomic weapons against North Korea and China. Here are excerpts from discussions on their use that involved Gen. J. S. Bradley, staff officer, Joint Chiefs of Staff; John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State; Gen. John E. Hull, deputy chief of staff for operations administration, U.S. Army; Deane W. Malott, president of Cornell University, member of special advisory committee for the President, and Adm. Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Flooding Destroys 6 Homes And Blocks Roads in Vermont
description: Flash floods caused by heavy thunderstorms early today blocked highways, destroyed a half-dozen homes and caused power failures in three counties, the authorities said.

description: Former Senator George McGovern wants Massachusetts delegates to the Democratic National Convention who are pledged to him to stay ''on hold.''

SCREEN: 'GREMLINS,' KIDDIE GORE
description: THE star of ''Gremlins'' is none of the perfectly adequate actors in the cast but the mogwai, a small, furry, fictitious creature that looks something like a cuddly teddy bear with the ears of a rabbit, a Bambilike nose, eyes as round and deep and dark as glass buttons, a sweet disposition and a physical nature more unstable than hydrogen gas.

title: 2 Dead and 24 Injured In Midwest Tornadoes By The Associated Press
description: Tornadoes tore through the Middle West from Louisiana to Minnesota late yesterday, killing two people and injuring at least 24, while the threat of a mountain mudslide forced the evacuation of more than 200 people in the snow-shrouded ski resort town of Aspen, Colo.

title: Unocal Oil Find
description: The Unocal Corporation said its Union Oil subsidiary had made a ''significant'' oil and gas discovery in the Santa Barbara Channel off Ventura, Calif.

title: ; Doyle Dane Appoints Two as Vice Chairmen
description: Barry Loughrane, the new president and chief executive of DDB International, has promoted Arie L. Kopelman, 45, and Peter Falcone, 48, both executive vice presidents of Doyle Dane Bernbach, the domestic company, to the position of vice chairmen of that company.

title: METS WIN APPEAL TO PREVENT A LOSS
description: When the Mets beat the Pirates, 2-1, in 13 innings Wednesday night to complete a three- game sweep in Pittsburgh, the victory was overshadowed by two things. One was the strong no-hit bid made by the Mets' rookie pitcher Dwight Gooden, which ended on the first pitch in the eighth, The other was the bizarre appeal play in the Pirate ninth that spared the Mets from an apparent defeat, and ultimately allowed them to turn the game in their favor.

title: Topics Fiscal Embarrassments
description: Semipro In the opinion of New York's highest court, a journalist is not, legally speaking, a professional. According to the Court of Appeals, the law need not provide a prominent, respected reporter with the same business tax exemption it once gave lawyers, doctors, accountants, shorthand stenographers and others deemed suitably learned or disciplined.

title: Mattel Says Group May Take Control
description: Mattel Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that a group that agreed to invest $231 million in the company may have the votes to elect a majority of its directors in about two years. Mattel said the investment group initially would be given the equivalent of 17 million votes, or about 45 percent of the toy maker's voting power.

title: GRACE OFFERS OIL UNIT FOR SALE
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the chemical producer, said yesterday that it was putting its oil and gas subsidiary up for sale.

title: A TOAST TO PHILLIPS COLLECITON
description: The glowing palette of Pierre Bonnard provided a splendid backdrop Wednesday night for the reopening of the Phillips Collection, perhaps Washington's best-loved small museum. Diplomats and art aficionados gathered in the galleries of the red- brick museum housed in the 1897 Phillips family mansion near Dupont Circle to view 61 Post-Impressionist works by the French artist, many of them never before exhibited in the United States.

title: WHEN ARTISTS EXPLAIN THEIR INTERPRETATIONS
description: Russell B. Clown, a bee on his nose,

title: B.P.'s Profit Accelerates
description: The British Petroleum Company, citing gains in all sectors, reported a $478.8 million profit for the first quarter, up sharply from $103.6 million a year earlier.

title: 7 DEAD IN CAPSIZING OF VESSEL FILLED WITH FLEEING HAITIANS
description: A seventh body was pulled from the sea near Haiti today, and the Coast Guard and Navy searched for at least two more people missing after a sailboat capsized when United States immigration agents boarded the vessel to check for illegal aliens.

title: FILM: 'GHOSTBUSTERS,' WITH MURRAY AND AYKROYD
description: the systematic pursuit and apprehension of any spooks, vapors or phantasms to be found in a metropolitan area - seems a perfect profession for Bill Murray. It requires a cool head, which Mr. Murray most assuredly has, as well as the ability to remain unruffled by bizarre apparitions - the sight, say, of a fat green ghost in a hotel corridor, gobbling the scraps off somebody's room-service tray. This kind of work calls for the kind of sang-froid that, coming from Mr. Murray, amounts to facetiousness of the highest order.

title: YANKS GET DENT FOR FARM
description: Bucky Dent, an integral member of the Yankees in happier times, for them and for him, abandoned his role as a movie shortstop yesterday and prepared to resume playing shortstop in real life.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Phil Niekro, who dazzled the Blue Jays in Toronto, goes after his ninth victory.

title: BANKS BID FOR NEW POWERS
description: The commercial banking industry sought today to hitch its campaign for deregulation, newly set back by the near- collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, to the cause of consumerism. The industry argued before Congress that banks should be allowed to offer new financial services to meet the needs and demands of consumers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Hawley To Delay Meeting
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said in Los Angeles that it will delay its annual shareholders meeting, previously scheduled for June 28, until July to allow time for the processing of proxy materials. The meeting is being held for shareholders to consider the recent sale of one million shares of convertible preferred stock by Carter Hawley to the General Cinema Corporation.

title: 32 ACCUSED OF CORRUPTION IN CITY INSPECTIONS
description: Fourteen city electrical inspectors and supervisors and 18 electrical contractors were accused yesterday by the Federal Government of taking part in ''a widespread and systematic pattern of corruption'' in the inspection of buildings throughout the city.

title: 8 Injured as Striking Miners Clash With Police in London
description: Surging crowds of striking miners and their supporters battled the police outside the House of Commons today. The police said 8 people were injured and 120 were arrested.

title: FROM GLOOM TO EXULTATION: MONDALE'S LONG CAMPAIGN
description: On the evening of March 4, five nights after Walter F. Mondale lost the Presidential primary in New Hampshire, the former Vice President sat in a Boston hotel suite and heard that Gary Hart had unexpectedly won the Maine Democratic caucuses. A shaken Mr. Mondale confessed to aides that the race for the nomination might be over, and some of his associates drifted back to their rooms and wept.

title: U.S. Sikhs to Protest Today in Washington
description: American Sikhs are planning to march to the Indian Embassy in Washington today at 1:30 P.M. in protest at the Indian Government's crackdown on Sikhs in Punjab state.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO CURB AID AGENCY'S POWERS
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee today approved a measure that would prohibit the Agency for International Development from withholding funds to third world nations that failed to comply with economic strictures recommended by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Utility Eases Seabrook Pinch
description: The president of New Hampshire's largest electric utility told its stockholders today that the company probably would have had to file for protection under the bankruptcy laws if it had paid its regular quarterly dividend in May. The last dividend, paid in February, was $1.20 a share.

title: Cooke & Beiler Urges Jewel Talks By Reuters
description: A major investor in the Jewel Companies said he had urged that company's directors negotiate with the American Stores Company, which has made an offer for Jewel.

description: Denmark is issuing $100 million of 14 percent Eurobonds due in 1991 with warrants through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.

title: ARGENTINE PARTIES SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
description: President Raul Alfonsin and former President Isabel Martinez de Peron signed an accord today that officials called a triumph in Mr. Alfonsin's drive for national unity.

title: JUDGE CRITIZES U.S. AGENCY ON DENIAL OF BENEFITS
description: A Federal judge today denounced the Department of Health and Human Services as ''a heartless and indifferent bureaucratic monster destroying the lives of disabled citizens'' by denying them benefits to which they are entitled.

title: Nuggets Trade Vandeweghe
description: The Denver Nuggets traded the high-scoring forward Kiki Vandeweghe, an emerging superstar in the National Basketball Association, to the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday.

title: IRAN PROTESTS TO THE SAUDIS OVER PERSIAN GULF AIR CLASH
description: Iran has protested to Saudi Arabia the downing of one of its planes. It was Iran's first official acknowledgement of the loss in the aerial clash between Iranian and Saudi jets over the Gulf two days ago.

title: Bikel Sings at Y
description: Theodore Bikel will present Jewish songs and stories this weekend and next at the 92d Street Y (427-6000), 1395 Lexington Avenue. There are performances tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M., and tickets are $14.50.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Viguerie Denounces 48 As 'Soft on Communism'
description: The conservative publisher Richard Viguerie today named 48 people and organizations, including the three Democratic Presidential candididates, Gulf Oil and Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, to the ''liberal hall of shame'' as ''soft on Communism.''

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS SETS NEW, CUT-RATE COAST FLIGHTS
description: People Express Airlines said yesterday that it would offer flights between Newark and Los Angeles for $149 one way at peak hours and $119 at other times.

title: S.E.C. CHIEF CAUTIONS ON LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned last night that there was a prospect of more corporate bankruptcies because of the rising tide of leveraged takeovers and buyouts.

title: British Trade Revision
description: Britain's current account for the first quarter was revised to a surplus of l$:838 million, or $1.17 billion, from last week's estimate of $:691 million, the British Central Statistics Office said today. It compared with surpluses of $:339 million in the previous quarter and $:1.09 billion in the first three months of 1983.

title: HOUSE APPROVES PLAN FOR RAISING AGE ON DRINKING
description: Responding to the growing public outcry against drinking-related deaths on the roads, the House of Representatives today approved legislation that would reduce Federal highway funds to any state that did not raise its legal drinking age to 21.

The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Report Says Nicaragua Killed Some Indians
description: The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights said today in a report that some Miskito Indians were killed and hundreds were arbitrarily imprisoned by the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua.

title: Tobacco Chewing Is Up, As Is Snuff Dipping
description: Fewer people are smoking cigarettes but more are dipping snuff and chewing tobacco, Federal officials said today.

title: One of a Kind
description: Bobby Thomson is used to meeting people who almost compulsively describe exactly where they were and what they were doing on Oct. 3, 1951, when he hit the dramatic home run at the Polo Grounds that won the National League pennant for the New York Giants.

title: WHITE PLAYWRIGHT, BLACK OFFICER'S TALE
description: There is a truism in theater that an actor acts to escape himself and a writer writes to reveal himself. But for whatever autobiography exists in his new play, ''Split Second,'' Dennis McIntyre has also made the creative leaps to convey police life when he is not a policeman and black life when he is white.

title: 4,000 MORE STRIKERS RETURN AS CASINO PACTS CONTINUE
description: Four thousand hotel workers today began returning to five Strip hotels as settlements continued in the 67-day-old casino strike here.

title: SOUTH'S ACID RAIN FOUND INCREASING
description: The southern United States is facing the prospect of acid rain contamination similar to that in the Northeast and Canada, according to a report issued today by a coalition of environmental and public health groups.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC OF KURDISTAN AT THE ALTERNATIVE MUSEUM
description: THE urgent, volatile music of Kurdistan was heard in its first New York concert Sunday at the Alternative Museum. Cultural Survival Inc. co-sponsored a concert by Temo - a Kurdish troubadour from Iraq who now lives in Paris - to draw attention to the embattled culture of Kurdistan, a mountainous region that has been divided among Turkey, Iraq and Iran since World War I.

title: TIGERS' MORRIS WINS 11TH, 5-3
description: Newly acquired Ruppert Jones hit a tie- breaking three-run home run in the sixth inning today, and Jack Morris helped the Detroit Tigers split their four-game series with Toronto by pitching a seven-hitter to beat the Blue Jays, 5-3.

title: A LOOK AT THE PARTICIPANTS AND THEIR POLICIES Britain Margaret Thatcher . . . 58 . . . Prime Minister since 1979, This year's summit host . . . Though still popular personally, her Conservative Party has begun to slip in the polls . . . With growth projected at about 3 percent and inflation under control at 5 percent, Britain's economy is recovering faster than most in Europe, but unemployment still remains at near-record 10 percent level . . . Has set off a crisis in the European Economic Community with demands that Britain be allowed to reduce its financing of the bloc . . . Considered blunt and strong-willed.
description: France Francois Mitterrand . . . 67 . . . First Socialist to be elected President of France since the establishment of the Fifth Republic in 1958 . . . Despite unpopular austerity measures, foreign debt, unemployment and inflation are up sharply while industrial investment is falling . . . Though recent polls show that 60 percent of the French electorate disapprove of his policies, can afford to take politically unpopular actions now since next parliamentary elections take place in mid-1986 . . . Described as cool, formal, literary.

title: Summary of Meetings Held By Seven Nations Since 1975
description: The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the previous meetings.

title: Mondale Bids 2 Rivals Repudiate Farrakhan
description: Walter F. Mondale says Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson should join him in repudiating Louis Farrakhan, leader of Nation of Islam who is a Jackson supporter, for making racial and religious remarks that have ''no place in our political process.''

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
TAX PANEL DENIES CITY BID ON DATA
description: House and Senate conferees today rejected a provision in the Senate tax bill that would have allowed the Internal Revenue Service to give New York City confidential information from Federal income tax returns.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMF Inc., a diversified company based in White Plains, said it had acquired Pak-It Manufacturing Co., a Norcross, Ga., maker of equipment for the baking and food processing industries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Mock Assault in Honduras
description: United States troops conducting war games staged a mock airborne assault today on an airstrip 12 miles from the Nicaraguan border, the Honduran Army said. The airstrip was built earlier this year by United States crews. About 4,000 United States, Salvadoran and Honduran troops have been taking part in the maneuvers.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Today's report shows that the South is on the verge of an acid rain crisis.'' - Richard E. Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition. (A15:1.)

title: TELLS THEM INTEREST RATES WILL FALL
description: President Reagan met separately today with the leaders of Japan, Italy, West Germany and France and gave fresh assurances that American interest rates would fall soon, perhaps this summer.

title: Jeantot Capsizes In Ocean Race
description: Philippe Jeantot, the 32-year-old sailor known as the Flying Frenchman because of his record speed in the BOC single-handed yacht race round the world in 1982-83, capsized in a 60-foot catamaran early today during a solo race from Plymouth, England, to Newport.

title: HOUSE GIRDS TO TAKE UP TOUCHY IMMIGRATION BILL
description: House Democratic leaders today reaffirmed their intent to bring up comprehensive immigration legislation next week but expressed doubt that it would pass.

title: STOCKS END MIXED IN SLOWER TRADING
description: Stock prices ended with minor changes in slower trading yesterday as rising interest rates weakened investors' enthusiasm.

title: 27 DIE IN RIOTS
description: Sikh protests erupted in several Indian cities today after the army's attack Wednesday on the Golden Temple in Amritsar and the death of a radical Sikh leader. Twenty- seven people died in the demonstrations today, the Indian Government reported.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Continental Air Sees a Profit
description: Continental Air Lines, fighting to rebound from reorganization in Federal bankruptcy court, will post a profit for the second quarter, its chairman and chief executive, Frank Lorenzo, said at the annual meeting.

title: LEGAL AID FOR THE POOR: REAGAN'S LONGEST BRAWL
description: Few issues stir such ideological passions here as that of using tax dollars to pay lawyers to represent poor people in legal actions against, among others, the Government itself, especially when those lawyers have a tendency to lobby for liberal social programs.

title: DELOREAN LAWYERS SEEK A GRAND JURY TRANSCRIPT
description: Lawyers for John Z. DeLorean today asked Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi to ban prosecutors from discussing testimony with James Timothy Hoffman, the Government's star witness, before he returned to the witness stand Friday. Judge Takasugi rejected the request.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the D-day commemoration in Normandy and the caption for a photograph misindentified the American infantry division with which Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. served and the invasion area that he crossed. A corrective article appears on Page A13.

title: Summit Protesters Demand More Help for World's Poor
description: About 200 demonstrators staged a sit-down protest in central London today, demanding ''bread not bombs'' from the leaders at the Western economic summit meeting. The police arrested seven people on charges of obstruction.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend payable on July 2.

title: HART FINDS HOPE IN CAPITOL VISITS
description: Senator Gary Hart roamed the corridors of Congress today, reporting encouragement for continuing his long-shot bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination. But there were also signs that some party members thought he would be coaxed out of the race.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $9 million from a provision for phasing out certain operations and a gain on LIFO adjustment of $7.4 million. c-Net loss after a charge of $21.1 million for a plant closing, credit of $7.8 million on changes in pension cost assumptions, gain of $21.7 million on LIFO inventory adjustment and a gain of $5.2 million from foreign currency exchanges. d-After charges of $61.7 million associated with the planned closing of uneconomic production facilities, a $8.3 million loss from cumulative effect of accounting changes and a favorable LIFO inventory adjustment of $32.1 million after taxes. e-Net income after a charge of $21.1 million for a plant closing, an extraordinary gain of $4.6 million, a gain of $26.8 million from the cumulative effect of accounting changes and a favorable LIFO inventory adjustment of $56.7 million after taxes. Year-ago sales figures for both periods have been restated.

title: Let New York Lead on Acid Rain
description: Acid rain is gnawing away at the Statue of Liberty, poisoning the Adirondack lakes and killing the Appalachian forests. The Reagan Administration won't act and Congress can't agree on how to make Middle Western states, the major source of acid rain, clean up emissions.

title: Talking Businesswith DiBona of the Petroleum Institute ; Ways to Raise Energy Supply
description: Despite widespread public complacency over energy supplies, the conflict in the Persion Gulf is reviving concern about a major disruption in the flow of oil to the industrialized nations.

title: OPERA: GLUCK'S 'ORFEO' IN ST. LOUIS
description: The Opera Theater of St. Louis, now in its ninth season, runs for only a month each year and plays in a small theater with limited facilities. But Richard Gaddes's company has established a larger reputation than that - for innovative repertory and productions and fine, young American singers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Russians Planning a Film Of Standoff at Kennedy

title: U.S. PAPERS TELL OF '53 POLICY TO USE A-BOMB IN KOREA
description: Documents released today give details on a decision by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration in 1953 to use atomic bombs in North Korea and Communist China, if necessary, to end the Korean War.

title: MTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Belated Title Nearly three weeks after the Big Ten Conference track and field championships, Wisconsin was declared the champion yesterday. The decision, reached after a telephone vote by Big Ten athletic directors Wednesday, supports one made by a referee at the May 19-20 meet at Ohio State after Illinois and Indiana protested the outcome of the long jump. Meet officials at first measured the distances jumped using the metric system, with Wisconsin's
description: Al Toon finishing third, Iowa's Ronnie McCoy fourth and Michigan's Scott Crawford fifth.

title: 1907 Prize Car on View
description: The 1907 Thomas Flyer automobile, winner of what has been termed the world's longest auto race from New York to Paris, is on view at the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue, through next Tuesday.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Mrs. Winikow Leaving Senate
description: State Senator Linda Winikow, a Rockland County Democrat, said today that she would retire to take a $100,000-a-year job as a vice president of Orange and Rockland Utilities.

title: SWALE AND GATE-DANCER HEAD SO-SO BELMONT FIELD
description: The Triple Crown season will come to a finish at Belmont Park tomorrow with Swale, the Kentucky Derby winner, and Gate Dancer, who won the Preakness, likely to be sent off as virtual co-favorites in a field of 11 3-year- olds for the 116th running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Executive Shift At Lord, Geller

title: The Gamble in the Golden Temple
description: No one who cares about democracy can be indifferent to the bloody drama in India's Punjab. By sending soldiers into the holiest Sikh shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar, Indira Gandhi has put more than her own political life at risk. If things go badly, and communal violence widens, a nagging nightmare could turn into reality: the fragmenting of India's secular democracy.

title: Niagara Mohawk Shelf Offering
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for a shelf offering of up to 4 million shares of preferred stock.

title: NOW, BOTH CABLE CARS AND TROLLEYS
description: With Mayor Dianne Feinstein at the controls of the first car, a parade of old, old streetcars up Market Street signaled today's opening of another season of San Francisco's Historic Trolley Festival.

title: Free Jazz at Citicorp
description: The pianist Harold Mabern will perform a free jazz concert tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street at Lexington Avenue.

title: Leader of Italian Communists Suffers Cerebral Hemorrhage
description: Enrico Berlinguer, leader of the Italian Communist Party, suffered a cerebral hemorrhage while giving a political speech in this northern city Thursday night, hospital officials said.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Ferrari Net Up By 6.7% in 1983
description: Ferrari, the luxury car maker that also runs a Formula One racing team, reported today that profits rose to $4.8 million for 1983, up 6.7 percent from $4.5 million in 1982.

title: PHILHARMONIC: CRUMB AND KNUSSEN PREMIERES
description: QUALITY beats quantity every time. Too bad that truism is so hard for program builders to recognize, or at any rate to put into action. Last night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall contained only two works whose playing time totaled barely an hour, but every minute counted. The program, eighth in the orchestra's ''Horizons '84'' series, brought the world premiere of George Crumb's ''Haunted Landscape'' and the first performance in this country of the complete concert version of Oliver Knussen's opera ''Where the Wild Things Are.'' Both proved to be works worth paying attention to, and both would probably bear up under repeated hearings.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for
STATEN ISLAND, A 'WILD WEST' IN THE CITY
description: Swhich it is legally tied, Staten Island is New York's Wild West, bursting with muscle-stretching activity in its big spaces. For example, a probably slippy, slidy, muddy close-up examination of the wildlife in a pond will be provided Sunday at Clay Pit Ponds State Park, which is closer to Perth Amboy, N.J., than it is to anyplace in the four other boroughs. The Thunderbird Indian Dancers will perform at 1:30 P.M. on Sunday at the Children's Museum branch in the Staten Island Mall. At the Children's Museum itself, in the Stapleton section, visitors can hear Scott Joplin rags and music from a homemade banjo tomorrow or thump out music on hubcaps and gutter downspouts tomorrow or Sunday in a hands-on show called ''Soundtracks.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters dispatch in the Company News section of Business Day on Wednesday gave an incorrect figure for the percentage of assets employed by the Kay Corporation in international trading operations. It is 45 percent.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Initial Public Offerings

title: Cambodia Accuses Thais Of Using Gas Weapons
description: Cambodia's official press agency said today that Thai forces had fired gas shells into the western Cambodian province of Pursat, ''affecting many people.''

title: Crum & Forster Names Successor to Chairman
description: Crum & Forster Inc., the Xerox Corporation's insurance subsidiary, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive officer, B.P. Russell, would retire from those positions on July 1. John K. Lundberg, currently vice chairman, will succeed Mr. Russell in both posts.

title: Cousy the Fan
description: Bob Cousy, who helped the Boston Celtics win six National Basketball Association championships from 1957 to 1963, is keeping an interested eye on the current N.B.A. final series.

title: UNITED TIRE & RUBBER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax recoveries of $480,000 for the quarter and $1,390,000 for the year. c-Including a tax recovery of $1 million.

title: A Doug Rader Fan The Texas Rangers are deep in last place, a standing that produced speculation recently that
description: Manager Doug Rader's job might be in jeopardy. Now both Rader and the Rangers' president, Mike Stone , have moved to put an end to such talk, disclosing that they have reached a handshake agreement to extend the manager's contract beyond its scheduled expiration after the 1985 season.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split to be effective June 18.

title: Two Roosevelt Sons In Normandy Graves
description: The cemetery at Colville in Normandy that President and Mrs. Reagan visited Wednesday is the resting place for more than 9,300 Americans, including Quentin Roosevelt and Theodore Roosevelt Jr., sons of President Theodore Roosevelt who were killed in the two world wars.

title: 'PET' FILM RIGHTS SOLD
description: Movie rights to ''Pet Sematary,'' Stephen King's best-selling horror novel about dead animals and a dead child, have been sold to George Romero, director of the low-budget cult horror movie ''Night of the Living Dead.''

title: ; If it's scarce, it's important.
description: -quality 18th- century American furniture has become scarce, the focus of auction houses and collectors has shifted to lesser works.These are being categorized by the auction galleries as ''highly important,'' a case in point being the collection Hugh and Ethelyn Cox assembled over three decades to furnish their 18th-century Federal town house in Alexandria, Va. The Cox collection of 89 Newport, Philadelphia, Boston and New York chairs, settees, chests and tables will be on view tomorrow through next Friday and up for bidding next Saturday, June 16, at 3 P.M., at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: IN EXPLOSIVE HAITI, MUCH HUNGER AND LITTLE HOPE
description: Trim picture as needed.

title: U.S. A TARGET OF CRITICISM
description: THE Reagan Administration had hoped to

title: Orosco Status Is Day to Day
description: Jesse Orosco, a left-hander and the Mets' top relief pitcher, injured his right shoulder Wednesday in what his manager said was an attempt to jump over a fence near the hotel where the Mets were staying in Pittsburgh.

title: Comings and Goings X-rays of the right wrist
description: Mike Schmidt injured while checking his swing Tuesday showed he sprained it and his availibility will be considered on a day-to-day basis. . . . Mercury Morris , the former Miami Dolphin running back who is serving a 20-year prison term for cocaine trafficking, lost a bid for a new trial when a state appeals court in Florida refused to overturn his conviction. . . . Hector (Macho) Camacho, the World Boxing Council's superfeatherweight champion, is scheduled to defend his title July 22 at Las Cruces, N.M., against Louie Burke, the W.B.C.'s 17th- ranked contender. . . . The Barcelona soccer club has turned down an $8 million offer from Naples of the Italian first division for the Argentine- born star Diego Maradona .

title: ;  COMPANY NEWS ;
description: Iacocca Supports Idea of Union Seat

title: Israeli Gets 18 Monhts For Role in Terror Plot
description: Noam Yinon, the first of 27 defendants to come to trial in connection with an anti-Arab terrorist group, was jailed today for 18 months for illegally transporting explosives.

title: 7 LEADERS DISCUSS EAST-WEST ISSUES AT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: The 10th summit conference of the most powerful industrial democracies opened tonight in an atmosphere of modest expectations, created by repeated official warnings that neither bold new policy initiatives nor ''magical solutions'' were at all likely.

title: WHEN POLITICAL MATTERS WANDER INTO SPOTLIGHT
description: It happens at most summit conferences, and it is happening in London: Political issues are coming to the fore.

title: THIS TIME GEORGE WEIN IS PRODUCING ON THE PIANO
description: GEORGE WEIN, who produces the Kool Jazz Festival, which opens a 10-day run in New York June 22, will be in town tonight playing a different role.

title: ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-There are no year-ago sales figures because the company was an investment concern in the prior year. c-Net income.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday on the Democratic candidates' debate failed to mention that it was arranged and broadcast by NBC News and that the moderator was Tom Brokaw of NBC News.

title: THE REBIRTH OF PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE
description: Pennsylvania Avenue, the grand promenade that stretches from Capitol Hill to the White House, has been undergoing a transformation that is just beginning to be felt.

title: BRIEFING
description: Intent and Fact and Words

title: IN LONDON, PAGEANTRY AND ANGER
description: Fortunately for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the opening of the economic summit conference today coincided with the House of Commons' first debate on Britain's coal strike, now three months old.

title: OLYMPICS: 'AN IDEAL WHOSE TIME HAS PASSED'?
description: To the Editor:

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Gung-ho at Police Academy

title: 333D RITE AT HARVARD HONORS CARLOS OF SPAIN
description: King Juan Carlos I of Spain, delivering the commencement address at Harvard University today, said the chief concern of Spanish peoples could ''be summarized in just one word: peace.''

title: MOSCOW ASSURES U.S. ON SAKHAROVS
description: The United States has been officially informed that the Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov is alive and that his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, is not in any danger, a senior American official said today.

title: A MUSICAL ABOUT LAUREL AND HARDY DUE NEXT SEASON
description: ANYONE who doesn't know the names Laurel and Hardy is probably listening to Michael Jackson records right now and not reading this. Everyone else will probably be interested to know that ''Blockheads,'' a new musical about the legendary comedy team, is scheduled to come to Broadway next season, following a run in - where else? - London.
