The opening there is scheduled for Aug. 21.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1984

title: ECHOES OF A GRAIOUS ERA ON LONG ISLAND'S GOLD COAST
description: One result of New York's leadership as the nation's financial and mercantile capital during the Industrial Revolution was to endow the metropolitan area with great estates that expressed the material and social aspirations of the wealthy.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Smith College Deferring Honor for Nancy Reagan
description: Smith College, Nancy Reagan's alma mater, has deferred plans to honor the First Lady until after the Presidential election in November, according to officials at Smith. Mrs. Reagan graduated from Smith in 1943 with a bachelor's degree in theater.

title: CONCERT: HORIZONS '84
description: FRANCE loomed large in the Horizons '84 concert presented by the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night. Three of the four composers represented were French, and one of them, Gilbert Amy, was the conductor. The triumph of the evening was a 16-year-old French creation that has already achieved something of ''classic'' status - Pierre Boulez's ''Domaines,'' but the works that preceded it were of consequence, too. They were Betsy Jolas's ''Quatre Plages,'' Mr. Amy's ''Shin'anim Sha'ananim'' (''Angels of the Throne'') and George Walker's ''Serenata.'' Mr. Walker is, of course, American, and his piece, dating from last year, was the newest of the lot.

title: FESTIVAL OF ETHNIC TREATS IN ASTORIA
description: During the week, Sabit Shira earns his living working on a television-factory assembly line in Waterbury, Conn. On weekends, he earns his reputation as one of the world's foremost pizga players.

title: Miss Sons's Race Is No Contest
description: When the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships opened yesterday in San Jose, Calif., Bonnie Sons won the women's 10,000-meter run. No one else was close.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: Fate was with Isaac Stern and

title: CAROLYN G. ABRAMS IS THE BRIDE OF R.D. FRANKEL Carolyn Gail Abrams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Abrams of New York, was married yesterday to Reed Douglas Frankel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Frankel of Brooklyn. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.
description: Mrs. Frankel graduated from the Dalton School, attended Pitzer College in Claremont, Calif., and expects to graduate from the Fashion Institute of Technology this summer. Her father is president of Warren Elliot Associates, consultants in New York to the paper industry, and chairman of La Mer Diving Seafari Inc., an arranger in New York of scuba diving trips and was formerly executive vice president of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation in New York.

title: I.B.M. CUTS PRICES ON PC LINE
description: In a move to step up pressure on competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced deep price cuts on its entire Personal Computer line, including its troubled PCjr home computer. The reductions, which have long been expected in the industry, range from 18 percent to about 23 percent.

title: PUBLISHING: MAILER TALKS ABOUT HIS NEW THRILLER
description: ''THIS book is like an illegitimate baby - it was written in two months, therefore born out of wedlock, and I'm struck by the fact that the event took place.'' That is how Norman Mailer recently described ''Tough Guys Don't Dance,'' his psychological thriller, which will go on sale late next month.

title: Zambia and Angola Assail Pretoria on Pullout
description: Zambia and Angola say that some progress is being made in the withdrawal of South African troops from southern Angola but that the disengagement is proceeding too slowly.

title: UNION CHIEF DEFENDS GRUMMAN BUSES
description: The head of New York City's largest transit union said today that the Grumman Flxible buses, declared unsafe by the city's Transit Authority and removed from the streets, were safer than the buses that replaced them.

title: BECK LEADS WESTCHESTER BY 2
description: Despite all the fuss about extremely deep rough at Westchester Country Club's West Course this week, Chip Beck shot an 8-under-par 63 today in the opening round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic. His score was two shots ahead of the field and only one shot off the course record set by Dan Sikes in the 1967 Westchester Classic and equaled by Jimmy Wright in the 1976 tournament.

title: Deloitte Expands
description: Deloitte Haskins & Sells said it had acquired the practice of Goh, Tan & Company, the largest accounting and consulting firm in Singapore.

title: 'Romeo' in Boroughs
description: ''Romeo and Juliet,'' a touring production by the Riverside Shakespeare Company, will be performed today at 6 P.M. at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx, tomorrow at 2 P.M. in Brooklyn's Prospect Park and Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Richmondtown Restoration in Staten Island.

title: J.P. LYET, FORMER CHAIRMAN OF SPERRYCORPORATION, DIES
description: J. Paul Lyet, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Sperry Corporation and chairman of the President's Export Council, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: BALLET: A COSBY AND NUREYEV GALA
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet celebrated its 20th anniversary with a heartwarming and fascinating gala Wednesday night at the Philadelphia Academy of Music. The program involved everything from a new ballet by Peter Martins to an American premiere with Rudolf Nureyev as a Baroque nobleman, an introduction by Bill Cosby, and Mr. Nureyev's and Suzanne Farrell's first joint appearance in George Balanchine's ''Apollo.''

title: SIKH CHIEFS: FUNDAMENTALIST PRIEST, FIREBRAND STUDENT AND EX-GENERAL
description: They fought together and died together - a Sikh fundamentalist priest, a former Indian Army general and a firebrand youth leader. They were leaders of a Sikh radical movement that had diverted a peaceful drive for greater religious recognition and political autonomy into a campaign of terrorism.

title: Field for the Belmont Stakes
description: POSTPROB. NO.POS.HORSE JOCKEY TRAINE RODDS *1*1 Play On J.L. Samyn Billy Turner 4-1*2*2 Coax Me ChadHerb McCauley Ronnie Warren 20-1*3*3 Silent King Don Brumfield Buddy Delp12-1*4*4 Gate Dancer Angel Cordero Jr.

title: Stationat Astor Place Slated for Restoration
description: The Astor Place subway station - opened in 1904 - will be restored to its original condition under a $2.5 million Transit Authority program.

title: NOT USED TO JUST ONE HORSE
description: Wherever he goes, Jack Van Berg usually has three or four dozen race horses in his barn and more than 200 on his mind. He is currently training, mostly by telephone, 40 horses in California, 42 in Louisiana, 40 in Nebraska, 38 at Churchill Downs and 80 more at his Kentucky farm. During his 33 years as a trainer, he estimates, he has had about 10,000 horses. But at the moment he really has only one: Gate Dancer, the Preakness winner, who at 3-1 is the second choice to Swale for the 116th Belmont Stakes tomorrow.

title: ART: THE GRAPHIC SKILL OF DELACROIX AT THE MET
description: EUGENE DELACROIX is the great Romantic painter. Learned, intense, brooding, immensely gifted, he was preoccupied as much with large human passions as he was with himself. Like the handful of other artists in whose work tumultuous energy and exacting control are inseparable, Delacroix seems fully present in almost everything he did. If some of his large history paintings now impress us as overambitious, his commitment was so total and his compositional intelligence so convincing that he was almost incapable of creating something that is without interest.

title: Chile Is Said to Supply Cluster Bombs to Iraq
description: State Department officials said tonight that Chile was supplying cluster bombs to Iraq.

title: CENTER TO STUDY SHIFTS IN CLIMATE
description: A new climate research center that will draw on observations from space, the atmosphere and the oceans has been established by Columbia University, school officials announced yesterday.

title: Funds Fall by $724.5 Million
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Wednesday after rising the previous four weeks, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The drop, of $724.5 million, brought the total to $174.45 billion.

title: 7-Foot-1-Inch Boxer
description: Tom Payne, a 7-foot-1-inch former professional basketball player who spent 11 years in a Kentucky prison after a rape conviction, is scheduled to make his boxing debut at Los Angeles on June 14 in a four-round bout against Nick DeLong of Long Beach, Calif. After his parole late last year, he played with the Louisville Catbirds of the Continental Basketball Association.

title: PRICES UP FOR NOTES AND BONDS
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, as credit market participants became more optimistic that the Federal Reserve will avoid any actions that encourage higher interest rates in the near term.

title: Errors in Geometry
description: Shawn Abner spent a lot of time and effort on football and baseball during his senior year at Mechanicsburg Area High School in Pennsylvania, but not quite enough on geometry. That became apparent yesterday when school officials said that Abner, baseball's top draft choice and a promising quarterback, would not receive his diploma with his classmates last night because he had flunked a geometry course and did not have enough credits to graduate. Abner said he planned to make up the course.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''The conclusions of the report fall more in the role of speculation and advocacy than into the field of scientific analysis.'' - Fred Fields, spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency. (A15:1.)

title: Beach Boys to Return To Mall on 4th of July
description: After being kept away by James G. Watt when he was Interior Secretary, the Beach Boys are returning to headline this year's Fourth of July celebration here.

title: Allen Upsets Milton
description: Darin Allen, a light middleweight from Columbus, Ohio, upset Dennis Milton of the Bronx tonight in the 156-pound division at the United States Olympic Boxing Trials. Milton, who had been rated the second-best in his weight class, knocked down Allen with a straight right hand in the third and final round, but it was not enough to overcome Allen's lead.

title: Austin, Tex., Bonds Offered
description: A $52 million issue of Austin, Tex., general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7.25 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 9.45 percent in 1994 and 10.75 percent for bonds due in 2004 and 2005. The issue was well received by investors, with $15.9 million of bonds unsold by midday.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Semiconductor Materials International N.V., Bilthoven, the Netherlands, has appointed Franc R. J. De Weeger president of its ASM America subsidiary in Phoenix.

title: One-Vote Tally Raises Suspicion
description: Election officials were ordered today to conduct a recount in a local contest because a candidate said he got only one vote in a precinct where his wife and three children voted for him.

title: Patty Sheehan Leads After 65
description: Patty Sheehan, winner of the L.P.G.A. Championship by 10 strokes last week, shot a tournament-record 65 today, 7 under par, to take a two- stroke lead after the first round of the $350,000 McDonald's Kids' Classic.

title: THE CLOSING OF POWER MEMORIAL IS MOURNED AS A DEATH IN FAMILY
description: Today is the last day of classes at Power Memorial Academy, the last day of the last academic year forever.

title: KOHL WRONGLY REBUFFED
description: To the Editor:

title: BUFFALO'S EFFORTS FOR DOMED STADIUM ARE DEALT A NEW BLOW
description: The second effort in 15 years to build a domed sports stadium here suffered a blow this week when a state agency failed to support the city's request for $40 million in state money to help build a 40,000-seat domed baseball stadium downtown.

title: Latin Debtors Plan Meeting
description: Latin America's biggest debtor nations sent a signal for help to the London economic summit meeting today by calling their own conference to seek a way out of a staggering $350 billion of foreign debt.

title: Monsanto Trading Interrupted
description: Concerns about the Monsanto Company's popular herbicide Lasso led to an imbalance of orders on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning, and a subsequent trading halt lasting about an hour.

title: GATHERING TO SUPPORT THE PARK
description: The musicians greeted the early arrivals with ''I like New York in June, how about you?'' They couldn't have chosen a more apt theme. The sun was shining brightly, the trees were in lush foliage and 600 friends of the Central Park Conservancy had gathered for lunch at Tavern on the Green.

title: RAPE CONVICTION OVERTURNED
description: The Washington State Supreme Court today overturned the rape conviction of Frederick H. Coe, whose mother was later found guilty of trying to arrange the murder of her son's prosecutor and the judge who presided at the trial.

title: MRS. LLOYD IN FINAL IN PARIS BY 6-0, 6-0
description: Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Camille Benjamin in 39 minutes to reach the final of the $1 million French Open tennis championships for the seventh time in 11 years.

title: Donald Q. Coster, 76, Former A.I.D. Official
description: Donald Q. Coster, a former official of the Agency for International Development, died last Thursday at the American Hospital of Paris. He was 76 years old and lived in Paris and Washington.

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: An Indian kitchen over Times Square.

title: ON THE SECONDHAND HARM OF ALCOHOL
description: To the Editor:

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
IRAN'S REACTION TO AIR BATTLE CONSIDERED MILD
description: United States military analysts expressed surprise today at the tepid, delayed Iranian protest to Saudi Arabia over the destruction of two Iranian fighter planes by Saudi Arabian jet fighters in an aerial battle on Tuesday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Generation Gap At Cardozo Law School

title: STAGE: 'DANNY AND THE DEEP BLUE SEA'
description: AS a Bronx variation on ''Beauty and the Beast,'' John Patrick Shanley's ''Danny and the Deep Blue Sea'' could be called ''The Beast and the Beast.'' A man and a woman, both lonely outcasts, meet in a bar. He is violent and possibly homicidal, she is tormented and possibly suicidal; each is transformed by the love of the other.

title: WHAT D-DAY MEANS FOR TODAY'S YOUTH IN EUROPE: THE MOOD'S ARE MANY
description: -FRANCEVILLE, France, June 7 - They were in their early teens, born more than two decades after the historic events that were celebrated the day before just a few beaches up the Norman coast from here.

title: MONDALE TURNING ATTENTION TO HUNT FOR RUNNING MATE
description: Walter F. Mondale began the search for a Vice-Presidential running mate yesterday while pressure mounted among party leaders for Gary Hart to accept Mr. Mondale as the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: BIG DRUG MAKERS FAIL TO STALL BILL AIDING GENERICS
description: Officials of six large pharmaceutical companies today failed in an effort to delay Congressional consideration of a bill intended to double the number of generic drugs on the market and to cut the price of many popular brand-name drugs in half.

title: Birkenmeier Signs Pact
description: Hubert Birkenmeier, the star goalkeeper of the Cosmos who was waived last month after he had refused to accept a pay cut, signed a new contract with them yesterday and is expected to play against the Chicago Sting at the Meadowlands tomorrow. No details of the new pact were disclosed, but Birkenmeier's agent, Sandy Amdur, called it a ''good settlement'' and said it entailed a smaller cut than the Cosmos had originally demanded.

title: SUMMIT TALKS HAVE IMPLICATIONS FOR EARLY VOTING IN EUROPE, TOO
description: The economic summit meeting here has been described by some as a political campaign exercise for President Reagan, but its preparation and outcome involve important electoral considerations for the European participants as well - all of whom face voters over the next 10 days.

title: ISRAEL CAN UNDO EXPANSION
description: There is much talk these days among Israelis and foreigners alike about the ''irreversible'' conditions that the Israeli Government has created in the West Bank and Gaza. Proponents of this view claim that the expansion of Israeli settlements has made it virtually impossible to separate Israel from the territories it occupied 17 years ago this week in the 1967 war. In truth, the facts about what has happened in the territories do not necessarily suggest that the situation is irreversible. Future separation from Israel has by no means been foreclosed.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Pacillo Joins Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds yesterday signed Pat Pacillo, a 21-year-old pitcher from Seton Hall University who was their No. 1 choice in this week's draft, but he will make a detour before heading for their Class AA team at Burlington, Vt. Pacillo is a member of the Olympic team, and so he will not report to the farm until after the Summer Games.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Double Duty

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 wks to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1 million for the 12 weeks and $15 million for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $3,325,000. d-Net income including a tax credit $20,160,000.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Work Ethic

title: EVERDING RULES OUT MET OPERA MANAGER JOB
description: August Everding, the general director of the Bavarian State Theaters, withdrew his name as a candidate for the position of general manager of the Metropolitan Opera yesterday.

title: Transco Denies Houston Gas Link
description: The Transco Energy Company said there are no current discussions with the Houston Natural Gas Corporation or any other company concerning a business combination.

title: CULTURE MINISTERS' INTRUSIONS
description: Government meddling in the lives of individuals and the activities of institutions is not news, even, alas, in the ''free'' world. But a politician mucking up the administration of an opera house apparently still is.

title: Article 249318 -- No Title
description: House and Senate tax conferees today agreed on about $6 billion of tax increases, bringing the total of their compromise package to about $40 billion over four years.

title: No Headline
description: In Victorian days, a girl would start sewing her trousseau of household linens almost as soon as she could hold a needle. If her family was well off, she would have a battery of skilled embroiderers and lace makers to assist her, and they might spend as long as 10 years producing one coverlet. After World War I, when both expert needlewomen and laundresses of fine linens began to disappear into factories or offices, hope chests were likely to be filled with manufactured cotton, rather than hand-embroidered linen. And finally, with the introduction of no-iron sheets 20 years ago, most of the beautiful old linens began to languish in trunks or were donated to thrift shops or sold to antiques dealers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Special Valedictorian

title: INSURANCE BROKER DISMISSES TRADERS
description: In a sweeping move to close the books on a costly and embarrassing trading loss, the nation's largest insurance brokerage concern has dismissed the key managers in its investment department.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on July 11, 1983.

title: ROLE OF NETWORKS IN ELECTION RESULTS
description: Wednesday at 2:17 A.M., Warren Mitofsky, the head of the CBS News election unit, had a decision to make. Mr. Mitofsky, 20 pounds lighter than he was when the primary season began, looked over his half glasses at his computer terminal in the CBS News studio on West 57th Street. He had to tell Dan Rather, the CBS anchor, if Walter Mondale could be called the winner of the Democratic nomination. Mr. Mitofsky conferred with his associates. By his own estimates at that point, Mr. Mondale needed 95 delegates to assure victory at the Democratic National Convention, and California was providing him with 94.

title: GANE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SENATE VOTES TO DELETE $4 MILLION FOR TWO U.S. BASES IN HONDURAS
description: The Senate voted today to delete funds for construction of two military bases in Honduras that were originally sought by President Reagan.

title: PATENTS
description: Microbiology Inventions For Florida Company

title: NEW YORK ALLIES OF SOUTH AFRICA'S OPPRESSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast Takes Title
description: Joe Fink scored five times, three of the goals coming in a span of 41 seconds of the final quarter, and assisted on another goal to lead Baltimore to a 10- 3 rout of the St. Louis Steamers that gave the Blast the Major Indoor Soccer League championship, 4 games to 1.

title: NEW CITY OFFICE SET TO SUPERVISE GREENBELT PARKS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the creation of an office that will administer the city parks within the Staten Island Greenbelt and help acquire more park land for the Greenbelt.

title: Gross Sets Mark
description: Michael Gross of West Germany set a world record today by swimming the 200-meter freestyle in 1 minute 47.55 seconds.

title: G.O.P. Leader Predicts Close Race in November
description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee today predicted a close race in November between President Reagan and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: Residents Oppose Project in Queens
description: Queens residents briefly blocked construction equipment yesterday bound for a city sewer project the residents said had made them prisoners in their own homes.

title: Inquiry on Counterfeit Parts
description: Defense Department investigators here are trying to determine whether faulty electronic parts from a major West Coast counterfeiting operation have gotten into the military supply chain.

title: Feminist Candidate Asks For Matching Funds
description: Sonia Johnson, a feminist who is the Citizen's Party Presidential candidate, personally asked the Federal Elections Commission Thursday to certify her for Federal matching funds.

title: BANKERS CAUTIOUS ON BUYOUTS
description: In a banking industry already made anxious by third-world loans and the rescue of the Continental Illinois Bank, the fast pace of leveraged buyouts, which by some estimates total $10 billion so far this year, is adding to bankers' anxiety.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results are not available. Results for the latest first quarter represent the company's first two months of resumed operations.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER OFFERS MIXED PROGRAM
description: American Ballet Theater presented a typically eclectic program Wednesday night in the Metropolitan Opera House. There was the company premiere of ''Triad,'' by Kenneth MacMillan, a leading English choreographer of dramatic ballets. Natalia Makarova's staging of Marius Petipa's ''Paquita'' served tradition. And modern classical ballet was represented by Andre Eglevsky's ''Sylvia - Pas de Deux'' and Michel Fokine's ''Sylphides.''

title: RECORDS OF PRESIDENTIAL TRANSITION FUNDS RELEASED
description: Officials involved with two private funds set up in 1980 to help finance Ronald Reagan's transition to office made the funds' records public today after years of rejecting requests for them.

title: FLUID WORK HOURS URGED FOR DAY CARE
description: Allowing employees a more fluid work schedule without jeopardizing career advancement may do more for child-care needs than the establishment of on-site care centers, according to a federally funded study on employer-supported day-care programs.

title: PRIME MINISTER BOTHA'S 'MACABRE CHARADE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Turner Eyes U.S.F.L.
description: Ted Turner, whose Turner Broadcasting System signed an exclusive cable-television agreement with the National Basketball Association earlier this week, now has his sights set on the United States Football League. ESPN's 2-year, $11 million cable-TV contract with the U.S.F.L. expires after this season, and Turner is offering the league $62 million for the next 3 years.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS BILL ON IMMGIRATION FOR ACTION MONDAY
description: The House Rules Committee today cleared the way for the House to take up a comprehensive immigration bill Monday, but it set no time limits for debate on the measure, which has been politically vexatious for both parties for more than two years.

title: OPERA: BRITTEN WORK
description: Before the English National Opera arrives at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 20, it is giving performances in Houston, Austin, San Antonio and New Orleans. Altogether, the company is offering five productions on this, its first American tour. Four will be seen in New York. The fifth, Jonathan Miller's staging of Britten's ''Turn of the Screw,'' is being shown only at the San Antonio Festival. The first of its two performances was Thursday night; the second is Saturday.

title: SPLIT OVER U.S. BUDGET DEFICITS RUFFLES THE OVERALL HARMONY AT LONDON MEETING
description: The American budget deficit, which the Reagan Administration has been trying to keep off the agenda of the seven-nation economic conference here, came under open criticism today.

title: CAVENHAM, USA, INC reports earnings for 12 wks to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1 million for the 12 weeks and $15 million for the year. c-Including tax credits of $3.9 million for the 12 weeks and $22.9 million for the year.

title: CORRUPTION IGNORED
description: The State Investigation Commission said this week that William Hennessy, when he was the state's Transportation Commissioner, compelled an engineering consultant who was a critic of the Westway project to pledge future silence on the issue - in writing. That was the condition, the investigative body said, that Mr. Hennessy laid down as the price for his approval of an unrelated consulting contract the engineer had applied for - a $38,000 study of taxi traffic in midtown Manhattan.

title: John Fary, a Daley Ally, Dies; Served 7 Years in U.S. House
description: A former Illinois Congressman, John G. Fary, an ally of Mayor Richard J. Daley, died of a heart condition today at the age of 73.

title: PHILLIES SWEEP 2 FROM PIRATES
description: Kiko Garcia and Ivan De Jesus drove in fourth-inning runs tonight, helping the Philadelphia Phillies post a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and complete a sweep of their doubleheader.

title: Sale Adviser Set At Punta Gorda
description: Punta Gorda Isles Inc. said it had retained the First Boston Corporation as its financial adviser to discuss the possible sale of the company, its major subsidiaries or certain major assets.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DIRECTED A.I.D. FOR KENNEDY
description: Fowler Hamilton, a founding partner of the international law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton and the director of foreign aid under President Kennedy, died Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: BOMB DISCOVERED ON PERON PLANE
description: A bomb was found aboard a plane just hours before former President Isabel Martinez de Peron was scheduled to board it today to return to Spain, airport authorities said.

title: SIDE WALK CAFES FLOURISH AMID HONKS AND FUMES
description: This was not Christine Jerard's idea of a good time. ''I'm so hot,'' she whined, perspiring in an outdoor cafe yesterday as the temperature rose into the 90's. ''Let's go inside where it's air-conditioned.'' Her companion, John Melsner, did not speak, but fixed her with a terrible glare that seemed to say she was probably just perspiring to prove her point.

title: BECK POSTS 69 TO RETAIN LEAD
description: Chip Beck has led after the first, the second and the third rounds of a number of PGA Tour events, but never after a fourth and final round.

title: BGS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Nixon's Tapes to Stay Closed
description: Richard M. Nixon's White House tapes and transcripts given to the National Archives by the Watergate special prosecution force are not subject to release under the Freedom of Information Act, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Coast Vice Drive Nets 100
description: A crackdown on vice, partly designed to clean up the streets for the Summer Olympics, which will take place in nearby Los Angeles, has resulted in 100 arrests for solicitation for prostitution over the last two weeks, the Police Department's vice section has announced.

title: SOUTHLAND GUILTY IN BRIBE TRIAL
description: The Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, was found guilty last night of criminal conspiracy stemming from what the Government said was a plan to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases.

title: Absentee Votes Deprive Hart of Jersey Delegate
description: Senator Gary Hart has lost the only delegate it appeared he had won in New Jersey's Democratic Presidential primary. The outcome followed a count of absentee ballots in Mercer County, officials said today.

title: Kirkland Bars Advice On Any Running Mate
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that he would offer advice on the selection of the Democratic Party's 1984 Vice-Presidential candidate only if asked by the Presidential nominee.

title: MENCKEN MONUMENT SPURS 'FRENZIED PIFFLE'
description: They are finally ending another long argument here over H. L. Mencken, the iconoclastic journalist whose slashing critiques of American fables and foibles made him, for much of the first half of the 20th century, the most argued- over, admired and hated private citizen of the United States.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt in '39
description: Jean Stapleton will portray Eleanor Roosevelt today in ''The Royal Visit of '39 - Then and Now,'' a Dutchess County production that commemorates the 45th anniversary of the arrival of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of Britain to Hyde Park, N.Y., the family home of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: AMTRAK TRAIN DERAILS IN PHILADELPHIA, INJURING 36
description: Six cars of an Amtrak train bound from Boston to Washington derailed in southwest Philadelphia this afternoon, causing three dozen minor injuries, the authorities said.

title: Lapointe Retires
description: Guy Lapointe ended an impressive 14-year playing career by signing a two-year contract as an assistant coach with the Quebec Nordiques.

title: B.I.S. Chief To Leave
description: Fritz Leutwiler, president of the Swiss central bank and the Basel-based Bank for International Settlements, will step down from both positions at year's end, the Swiss Finance Ministry said today.

title: GROMYKO AND IRANIAN MEET ON U.S. MOVES IN GULF
description: A high Iranian official has met here with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, and diplomats say they believe the talks dealt with ways to avert any possibility of American intervention in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Collaboration on Science
description: A working committee urged the Western economic summit leaders to pursue greater international collaboration in science and technology to help stimulate economic growth. The working group, set up on the initiative of President Francois Mitterand of France in 1982, acknowledged the introduction of labor-saving technology at times of high unemployment could be seen as threatening. But it said it is convinced the necessary impetus to rejuvenate industry and promote trade must come primarily from new technologies.

title: HENRY SCHLANGER
description: Henry Schlanger, founder and president of Octagon Books, died of heart disease Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Dow Slips 1.19 Points; Volume Sharply Lower
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session in much slower trading. While most price changes were minor, Teledyne soared 10 points, to 212 1/4, in heavy trading.

title: TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY DISTRIBUTION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CITY BALLET: PREMIERE OF 'BRAHMS/HANDEL'
description: The New York City Ballet's latest premiere has the brashness of a scintillating guest with irrepressibly bad table manners. To put it another way, ''Brahms/Handel,'' which was co- choreographed by Jerome Robbins and Twyla Tharp, is really something new - radical in its break with rules of genteel ballet sensibility, as exciting as it is also flawed. Everyone should see it.

title: Nancy Rosenbower Weds
description: At Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in North Arlington, N.J., yesterday, Nancy Claire Rosenbower, a registered nurse with the medical services department at the Johnson & Johnson Baby Products Company in Skillman, N.J., was married to Anthony Joseph Musco, a psychologist with the Carteret (N.J.) public schools. The Rev. William Harms performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Col. Ernest L. Rosenbower, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Rosenbower of North Arlington and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Musco of Carteret.

title: CessnaToldtoPay $30 Million in Suit
description: A Federal jury ordered the Cessna Aircraft Company today to pay $30 million in damages to the families of three people killed in a 1980 plane crash and to the only survivor of the accident.

title: Transit Police on Trial
description: Has New York City responded appropriately to the death of Michael Stewart, a young artist and model who died after a subway arrest last September? And has it responded soundly to the Transit Police management problem the case may illustrate? The answer to the first question is probably yes; to the second, definitely no.

title: YANKS WIN IN 11TH ; METS 4 EXPOS 1
description: Near the end of spring training, Manager Dave Johnson sized up the Mets' young pitching staff and predicted that if his club was at .500 on June 1, it would be a contender in the fall.

title: Stars Clinch Title
description: David Trout kicked a 19-yard field goal with eight seconds remaining, lifting the Philadelphia Stars to a 21-19 victory over the Denver Gold tonight. Kelvin Bryant rushed for 194 yards, his best performance ever as a pro, and scored two touchdowns as the Stars raised their record to 15-1 and clinched the Atlantic Division title in the United State Football League. Denver (8-8) suffered its seventh loss in the last eight games.

title: A ROMANTIC LONG SHOT
description: At the far end of the Belmont stable

title: Sunstates-Treco
description: The Sunstates Corporation and Treco Inc. said they had terminated merger discussions, and Sunstates said it would proceed with steps toward a complete liquidation.

title: 2 Foreign Priests Reject A Pardon From Marcos
description: Two foreign priests and six Filipino lay workers who are charged with multiple murder returned to jail today after rejecting a presidential offer of freedom.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AUNTICIPATION
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Water To Get Taste Test
description: New York's drinking water will be matched against that of other major American cities in a taste test this weekend, city officials said yesterday.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $196,000. c-Net income.

title: NEW ISRAELI PARTY APPROVED
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens announced today that he had decided against outlawing the election slate of a new Arab-Jewish party.

title: ASSAULT ON SIKH'S SHRINE: A THORN REMOVED BY MRS. GHANDI?
description: The Indian Army's strike this week against the heart of the militant Sikh movement in Punjab and the killing of the movement's leaders has at least temporarily removed a source of chronic public anxiety. The raid on the holiest Sikh shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar, has led to expressions of relief throughout New Delhi, many residents of which have roots in Punjab. There is relief even - or especially - among many Sikhs. It also may well have deflated the two-year- old Punjab political problem and given Prime Minister Indira Gandhi the upper hand in negotiating a settlement.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Short-Term Rates Edge Up
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with only small increases for most securities due in less than a year, and small declines for longer term notes and bonds.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE LAKERS AND LEAD SERIES, 3 TO 2
description: On an oppressively hot evening at steamy Boston Garden, the Celtics turned in what Dennis Johnson called ''our first complete game'' in the championship series, got 34 points from Larry Bird and overwhelmed the Los Angeles Lakers, 121-103, tonight.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $263,000 for the quarter and $592,000 for the 9 months, extraordinary gains from the exchange of debentures of $1,000 for the quarter and $1,579,000 for the 9 months and an estimated loss of $750,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $415,000.

title: Henry Street 'Rigoletto'
description: Fully staged performances of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' will be presented this weekend at the Henry Street Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, by students and faculty members of the Henry Street Settlement Music School. The opera will be sung in English tomorrow at 3 P.M., and in Italian tonight and Monday at 7 P.M. Admission is $5; $3 for the elderly. The number for more information is 598-0400.

title: PATENTS
description: Resuscitator Can Help Chemical War Casualties

title: T.V.A. Battling Mosquitos
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority has started lowering and raising water levels in its reservoirs to help fight the summer infestation of mosquitos. The agency will change the water level one foot each week this summer to disrupt the insects' breeding and strand larvae onshore where the sun will kill them, officials said.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $22,000 and a gain of $832,589 from an accounting change.

title: IVY LEAGUER IN THE RING
description: Henry Milligan was an average, level-headed student at Princeton. He was graduated in 1981 with a B-minus average in civil engineering and earned a reputation for his athletic ability, winning 10 varsity letters in baseball, football and as an all-American wrestler.

title: A March for Jobs In East New York
description: About 200 high school students led by Representative Edolphus Towns marched in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday to appeal for summer jobs.

title: FOR MRS. REAGAN, A DAY FOR CHILDREN
description: Amid bobbing yellow balloons and waving British and American flags, Nancy Reagan toured the London Zoo today accompanied by 41 children, in her only official engagement during the seven-nation economic summit meeting that ends here Saturday.

title: Braniff Posts Loss in Period
description: Braniff Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $30.6 million for its first quarter, ended April 30, which included the company's intital two months of operations as an airline.

title: uf6116 Iraq Says Its Aircraft Hit Two Ships in Gulf
description: Iraq said today its aircraft successfully attacked two ''large naval targets'' north and west of Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island at the head of the Persian Gulf.

title: Swale Is Top Belmont Choice;  Early Speed Is a Factor
description: Bettors who claim to need a satchel to carry their money into the race track say they left their bankrolls at home for the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness this year but will unpack their bags at the parimutuel windows today before the 116th Belmont Stakes. The talk among the heavy-hitting horseplayers at Belmont Park yesterday was that Swale may have his 10 Belmont rivals over a barrel.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Night for the Opera

title: '84 SUMMER TRAVEL EXPECTED TO RIDE A CREST
description: A resurgent economy, a strong dollar and plentiful gasoline are pointing to a big travel summer for Americans at home and abroad, according to government and industry experts.

title: China Weighs Investor Law
description: A draft law on foreign cooperative business ventures in China has been approved by the Government State Council, the official New China News Agency reported today. The law will be submitted to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, China's legislative body, for deliberation and enactment, the report said. Other laws on foreign investment and trade are being formulated by Government ministries and commissions, university experts and local officials, according to the State Council Economic Legislation Research Center.

title: TEXT OF DECLARATION BY SUMMIT CONFERENCE
description: Following is the text of the Declaration on Democratic Values, read today by the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, at the economic summit meeting in London:

title: WALLACE ARMSTRONG URGED FLUORIDATION AS CAVITY PREVENTER
description: Dr. Wallace D. Armstrong of Minneapolis, an early advocate of fluoridation of water to prevent tooth decay, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: MONDALE WON, BUT MANY FAVORED BRADLEY
description: MAYOR MARY V. MOCHARY of Montclair, who last Tuesday won the Republican nomination for United States Senator, has said that Senator Bill Bradley, the incumbent Democrat from Denville, has an eye on the White House and is, therefore, not doing an efficient job of representing New Jersey's interests in the Senate.

title: Letter: On Free Speech ; Pornography and Legislated Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL AID TO CHICAGO BACKED
description: A Federal district judge said today that the Federal Government was obliged to provide $103.8 million to help desegregate Chicago's public schools in the 1984-85 school year.

title: Tax Fraud Conviction
description: A Federal jury yesterday found four top executives of two Wall Street securities firms guilty of conspiring to provide more than $130 million in fraudulent income tax write-offs for show business celebrities, bankers and business executives. It was unable to reach a verdict on charges against a fifth defendant.

title: Looking for Loopholes at OSHA
description: Regulating safety and health conditions in the American workplace is a matter of law, not ideology. Under the Reagan Administration, enforcement of the Occupational Safety and Health Act has been weakened by a series of strained interpretations of the law.

title: U.S. Scientists Call Off Talks With Russians
description: The National Academy of Sciences, citing concerns about Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, announced today that it was indefinitely postponing talks with its Soviet counterpart over a new agreement on scientific cooperation.

title: ORBIT OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Times Sq. Walking Tour
description: The Municipal Art Society will conduct a walking tour of Times Square and the theater district this morning at 9:30.

title: NAILS FOR A MANHATTAN NEIGHBORHOOD'S COFFIN
description: To the Editor:

title: HAMILTON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1984 International
description: Negotiations to resolve conflicts were urged by leaders of the seven major industrialized democracies, but they disagreed over a new appeal to Moscow on arms control talks. On the second day of the economic summit conference in London, the leaders issued a 500-word statement affirming belief in freedom, equality and progress. (Page 1, Column 6.) United States budget deficits were criticized by finance ministers at the summit meeting of the seven leading industrialized democracies. The Reagan Administration had been trying to keep the deficit issue off the conference agenda. (6:1-2.)

title: H.K. Porter Offer
description: The H.K. Porter Company said it is offering to acquire the Union Electric Steel Corporation for $32 a share.

title: U.S. WINDS UP WAR GAMES IN HONDURAS
description: The Granadero I exercises formally ended today on a parched dirt airstrip in a tiny valley not far from the border with Nicaragua. As a result, United States officials said, they will lower the American military presence here to fewer than 700 people from the current 1,700.

title: DEOMCRATIC OFFICIALS SEEK TO ASSURE HART AND JACKSON ONDELEGATES ISSUE
description: Officials of the Democratic National Committee today told Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson they would receive a fair hearing on any challenges they might make to the number of delegates held by Walter F. Mondale.

title: EAGLE'S BATTLE FOR SURVIVAL
description: Ronald N. Mickwee, president of Eagle Computer Inc., remembers well the day in February that three lawyers from the International Business Machines Corporation arrived at his office, charging Eagle had violated one of the giant company's copyrights.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nobody dies five minutes before the time God has set for them.'' - Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron of Argentina, after a bomb was discovered on the plane she was scheduled to board. (3:1.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NOVEL WALK There are many novels set in New York but few have fevered the imagination as warmly as Jack Finney's 1970 ''Time and Again,'' a story that combines science fiction and New Yorkiana. In it, a Government project has the hero, through psychological procedures, leaving modern New York for the New York of the early 1880's, a journey in which the Dakota, the marvelous early West Side apartment house, serves as medium and Central Park serves as initial point of entry into the past.

title: RAPID-AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $18,317,000. Results for the latest first quarter include Rapid-American's equity in the operating results of HRT Industries Inc. and Faberge Inc. Year-ago sales restated for operations held for sale.

title: COURT HALTS SALE OF THE BOOK 'EATING TO WIN'
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Stein & Day to notify its distributors and retailers to stop distributing and selling ''Eating to Win'' by Frances Sheridan Goulart with its present cover and to remove the book from public view.

title: A RARE SUMMER OF LUSCIOUS FRUIT
description: On a tip from a colleague I went to look at the apricots in the store the other day. I haven't bought a fresh apricot in 25 years. Like so many other things they don't taste the way they did when I was a child. And that is not just being crotchety.

title: NEW YORK ALLIES OF SOUTH AFRICA'S OPPRESSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholarship Suit Settled
description: Seven basketball players have settled a lawsuit against California State-Los Angeles in which they charged that they had been lured to the school by promises of scholarships but instead received only Federal loans and classes such as ''basketball theory'' and ''backpacking.'' The plaintiffs, all of whom were recruited by the school in the 1970's, were Rodney Murphy, Randall Echols, Adrian Chivers, Michael Redmon, Thomas Moore, Dwight Slaughter and Michael Ingram.

title: LA-Z BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
HEAD OF H.U.D. TELLS GRADUATES THAT PERSEVERANNCE PAYS OFF
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development told graduates at Queensborough Community College yesterday that ''perseverance knows no color, religion, no sex, no creed.''

title: Beating at Police Station Cited in Polish Death
description: A team of medical experts told a court today that a beating that killed a supporter of the outlawed Solidarity labor federation must have been inflicted while he was in custody at a police station.

title: WORLD TRADE TROUBLES BROUGHT ON BY THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones Replaces Johnson
description: Only two days after Jimmy Johnson had left to replace Howard Schnellenberger as football coach at Miami, Oklahoma State decided on its own replacement. He is Pat Jones, who had been Johnson's top assistant since both arrived at the school in 1979. The 36-year-old Jones is taking over immediately, even though contract terms have not yet been agreed upon.

title: T.W.A. to Rehire
description: Trans World Airlines said that it will recall later this month 10 pilots and 135 flight attendants now on furlough. The carrier cited strengthening traffic demands and attrition in its pilot and flight attendant ranks. T.W.A. said that if business continues to improve it might need additional pilots, but a spokesman said these recalls would be in small numbers. The airline said 566 pilots and 532 flight attendants remain on furlough status.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stalled in Manhattan

title: PATENTS
description: A computer program to help trace telephone numbers without complete information from callers was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. The system is in use by Bell Laboratories and A.T.& T. Information Systems. Richard H. Boivie obtained patent 4,453,217.

title: Charterhouse
description: Charterhouse Group International Inc. said it had acquired the Stanley Interiors Corporation for $56 million from an investor group led by Clayton & Dubilier, a private investment firm.

title: 2 Youths Drown Off Randalls I.
description: Two Bronx youths drowned Thursday off Randalls Island, a police spokesman said after the police recovered the bodies yesterday.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
7 LEADERS DECLARE POLITICAL VALUES AT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Text of statement is on page 6.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
5 Are Arrested In Phone Fraud
description: Five Manhattan residents were arrested yesterday on charges of defrauding the New York Telephone Company by making more than 1,500 illegal telephone calls, most of them to the Dominican Republic, in a three-day period.

title: PENINSULA RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOVIET CHARGES A.P. REPORTERS WITH CRIMINAL ACTS
description: The Soviet Government charged today that a correspondent for The Associated Press and a former reporter in Moscow for the news agency exceeded the ''framework of journalism'' by purportedly aiding a would-be defector.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Von Zedtwitz Match Brings A Misfortune for Leventritt

title:
Patents;
 Emergency Shutdown Of Reactors
description: WASHINGTON A SYSTEM to shut down nuclear reactors during an emergency was patented this week for the Department of Energy. The system, developed under a contract with the Argonne National Laboratory, has been successful in field tests.

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Oldfield Still Going, Battle After Battle
description: Brian Oldfield faced one battle today and lost. The bigger battle, he said, will come in the next few weeks when he attempts to compete in the United States Olympic trials and then the Los Angeles Olympic Games.

title: AMERICAN STORES MAY PARE JEWEL BID
description: The American Stores Company yesterday threatened to reduce the $70-a-share price it is offering for the Jewel Companies, or to change the cash-stock offer to all stock, if Jewel seeks a defensive acquisition to thwart American's bid.

title: U.S. NEWS SAID TO BACK OFFER FROM ZUCKERMAN
description: The directors of U. S. News & World Report Inc. have approved the sale of the company to Mortimer Zuckerman, a Boston real estate developer who owns The Atlantic, a source close to the transaction said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Poetry Begets Poetry

title: State of Emergency Declared by Peru
description: The Peruvian Government declared a nationwide state of emergency late today and suspended civil rights in an effort to crush a wave of strikes by teachers and civil servants.

title: JOHN R. BOTT
description: John R. Bott, city editor of The New York Post for 17 years before joining The New Mexican here in 1971, died today at his home. He was 70 years old. Mr. Bott, a native of Nyack, N.Y., had worked for The Post for 37 years when he became city editor of the newspaper here. He was named editor soon after that and retired in 1977.

title: 14 Seized on L.I. In Cocaine Ring
description: A ring that smuggled $25 million a week worth of cocaine into Suffolk and Nassau Counties and the Borough of Queens was broken by the arrests of 11 men and 3 women, the Suffolk Police Commissioner, DeWitt Treder, said today.

title: SPIES AND PLOTTERS
description: YEAR OF THE GUN. By Michael Mewshaw. 273 pages. Atheneum. $14.95.

title: Ruppert Jones Back in the Swing
description: Ruppert Jones tried free agency last winter after eight major league seasons with the Kansas City Royals, Seattle Mariners, the Yankees and the San Diego Padres. His .253 career average and 89 home runs did not attract offers, so he was a walk-on in spring training with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Flood Damage Putat$40.8Million
description: Connecticut sustained $40.8 million in damage from the May 27-June 2 rains and floods, Gov. William A. O'Neill said today.

title: FRENCH JOIN CEREMONY FOR GERMAN WAR DEAD LA CAMBE, France, June 8 (AP) - Officials from France and West Germany gathered today to honor German soldiers who died trying to hold back the Allied forces in Normandy 40 years ago.
description: About 200 spectators, many of them Germans, attended the ceremonies at a cemetery where more than 21,000 German soldiers are buried. Many are unidentified.

title: SIKHS IN TEMPLE HOLD OUT: MORE VIOLENCE IS REPORTED
description: Sikh terrorists holding out at the Golden Temple in the state of Punjab were said to have fired at troops today during a visit to the shrine by President Zail Singh.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $992,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $110,000.

title: TRAFFIC BUREAU LISTENING POST IN BROOKLYN HOME
description: Outside the window, the street in Brooklyn was nearly empty. But on the second floor of the gray shingled house with the huge antenna, behind the lace curtains, traffic was fierce.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Purchase Bid Cited By Malone & Hyde

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1984

title: ERNEST MCFARLAND, ARIZONA SENATOR IN '41-53
description: Ernest W. McFarland, a former Democratic United States Senator from Arizona who was the Senate majority leader from 1951 to 1953, died yesterday of congestive heart failure at the Good Samaritan Medical Center in Phoenix. He was 89 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Idaho Congressman Denied a New Trial
description: A Federal district judge today denied Representative George V. Hansen's request for a new trial on his four-count felony conviction and set sentencing for next Thursday.

title: IT'S MCENROE AGAINST LENDL
description: John McEnroe defeated his traditional rival, Jimmy Connors, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2, today in the semifinals of the French Open tennis championships and moved to one victory of becoming the first American to win the men's title since Tony Trabert did it in 1955.

title: STEINBERG MAKES 2 OFFERS FOR DISNEY
description: Saul P. Steinberg, a New York investor, today announced two alternative offers to take control of Walt Disney Productions. Either, if successful, would likely lead to Disney's breakup.

title: Cabanas SidelinedThe Cosmos will be without two of their stars when they play the division-leading Sting in Chicago tonight.
description: Roberto Cabanas is still nursing a hamstring injury, and Hubert Birkenmeier , the goalkeeper who re-signed Thursday after having been waived for refusing to take a pay cut, needs time to regain his sharpness.

title: Data General Court Appeal
description: The Data General Corporation said yesterday that it would seek a rehearing on a Federal appeals court ruling that the company had violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by licensing an operating system it developed only to customers that bought its Nova computers.

title: CUOMO AND LILCO
description: News Analysis

title: MRS. DOLE TO PROPOSE SELLING DULLES AND NATIONAL AIRPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would ask Congress next year to transfer Washington National and Dulles International Airports from the authority of the Federal Government to state or private ownership.

title: BRITAIN's LOGISTICAL RINGMASTER: NICHOLAS JOHN BARRINGTON
description: One night last month, Nicholas Barrington threw up his hands in exasperation. The British bureacracy, he concluded, was never going to produce a map of the area around Lancaster House, the site of this year's economic summit conference, that anyone could be expected to understand. Mr. Barrington, the man in charge of the arrangements for the conference, thrust the maps aside, grabbed a notebook and walked out of his office. He went into the streets around the 19th-century mansion, made a sketch and went home to draw the clean, uncluttered diagram that appears in the handbook issued to each of the delegates this week.

title: Beacher
description: Bert Cochran, a socialist author, educator and lecturer, died of cancer Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Bomb, Fifth Since May 31, Is Found in Chicago's Loop
description: Remnants of an exploded bomb were found downtown today, the fifth explosive device to be found in the city since May 31, the police said.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Results reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid April 24.

title: TEEN-AGE DRINKING VOTE: CRUSADER IS 'DELIGHTED'
description: For three days before the House voted on the issue of raising the legal drinking age to 21, Candy Lightner was telling lawmakers stories about the death rate among teen-age drunken drivers.

title: A Chance for Thomas
description: Paul Jacobs, the surgeon who operated on Gorman Thomas yesterday, said the Seattle Mariner had suffered a complete tear of the rotator cuff in his right shoulder and that part of the tendon in the shoulder had torn away from the bone. But the surgeon said he was ''cautiously optimistic'' that the 33-year-old outfielder would be able to play next year. Seattle acquired him last December in a trade with the Cleveland Indians.

title: YANKS WIN IN 11TH; YANKEES 4 BLUE JAYS 3
description: Steve Kemp's rejuvenated hitting and Dave Winfield's base running gave the Yankees a 4-3 extra-inning victory over the Toronto Blue Jays last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: A 'BOUNTY' FOR UNSAFE GAS VALVES
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission and a manufacturer of devices linked to fatal explosions have come up with an unusual plan to find them: The company is offering bounties to people who report them.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,618 and a loss of $222,444 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Soybean Prices Fall; Pork Bellies, Cattle Up
description: Soybean futures prices dropped sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade today on heavy selling by speculators. Grains futures also fell.

title: Steel Import Curb Fought
description: Two senior members of the Administration today criticized proposed legislation that would place quotas on steel imports.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: 9 Extra Votes Provide a Victory
description: A recount brought victory today to a local candidate who originally received one vote in a precinct where he said his wife and three children all voted for him.

title: Lemieux No. 1 Prize
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins intend to make Mario Lemieux the first choice in this afternoon's National Hockey League entry draft in Montreal, but there is one big hitch: Can they sign him? Lemieux is a 6-foot-4 inch, 200- pound center who scored 133 goals and had 149 assists for Laval in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League last season. He is ranked No. 1 by the N.H.L.'s Central Scouting bureau.

title: BRIEFING
description: Shelling Out for Rosie's

title: Your Money; Buyout Offers For Odd Lots
description: T HE Pacific Telesis Group, one of the regional

title: ALL BARBADOS IS ABUZZ OVER 10 STORY SKYSCRAPER
description: It is not uncommon to see residents of this spirited seaport shade their eyes and stare up at the 12 concrete towers that dwarf everything else in the city. The structures are part of the Government's new 10-story Central Bank building now going up, a project that has stirred a cacophonous debate that threatens to rival the clanking noises of construction.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Late for His Reward

title: JOURNAL SETTLES LIBEL SUIT FOR $800,000
description: Dow Jones & Company, publishers of The Wall Street Journal, will pay $800,000 to settle a $5 million libel suit brought by two former Federal prosecutors who said they were defamed by Journal articles in 1979.

title: Otasco Buyout Accord Signed
description: The Rapid-American Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with its Otasco Inc. subsidiary for a leveraged buyout plan under which a group led by the management of Otasco would acquire the company for more than $125 million. Otasco, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., markets home, auto and outdoor seasonal merchandise through a chain of stores, primarily in the Southern states.

title: Jayjia Hsia Wed to Robert M. Shaplen
description: Jayjia Hsia, a senior research scientist at the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J., and Robert M. Shaplen, a staff writer for The New Yorker, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's Princeton home. Mayor Barbara Sigmund of Princeton performed the ceremony.

title: Nevada Jury Convicts Man of Killing Two
description: A jury took less than four hours Thursday to find a man guilty of sexually assaulting two California teen-agers in the back of his van while his wife drove,then battering them to death and burying them in Nevada.

title: Eight Children Killed By Fires in 2 States By The Associated Press
description: House fires in two states killed eight children yesterday, four in Constantine, Mich., and four in Baltimore.

title: Two Virginia Murderers Captured in Vermont
description: Two of six convicted murderers who escaped from Virginia's death row and set off a manhunt in North Carolina were recaptured in Vermont today, one of them about five miles from the Canadian border.

title: Q. WHAT IS DIXIE? A. A KIND OF WALKER
description: It began in 1829 as a Protestant Sunday school festival. In 1860, the state made it legal. In 1959, the New York City Board of Education extended it to Queens and called it Anniversary Day. But we who grew up in the County of Kings always knew that school was closed on the first Thursday in June because that's Brooklyn Day.

title: Leader of Italy's Communists Is in 'Very Serious' Condition
description: Enrico Berlinguer, the Italian Communist leader and an originator of Eurocommunism, remained in ''very serious'' but stable condition today after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage during a campaign rally Thursday night.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column yesterday misstated the future role that the chairman of Nabisco Brands Inc. will play in the company. He will continue as chairman.

title: AIDES ASSERT HART SEEKS TO MINIMIZE DISCORD IN PARTY
description: After a roller-coaster primary campaign, Senator Gary Hart today determinedly pursued plans for winning the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: The Facts of Real Life
description: Last year a new Family Life/Sex Education curriculum was tested in several New York City high schools and reviewed favorably by Cornell University's Medical College. Students who'd taken the courses, the reviewers said, became significantly more knowledgeable and responsible about birth control, pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: JUDGE SEEKS REPORT ON DRUG INFORMER'S CALLS
description: The judge in John Z. DeLorean's drug trial today ordered the prosecutor to report to the court everything he could remember concerning his pretrial talks with a Government informer, James Timothy Hoffman, about unrecorded telephone talks between Mr. Hoffman and Mr. DeLorean. The calls were made when Mr. DeLorean was the target of an undercover investigation.

title: IS THIS HEARTBURN OFFICIAL?
description: I usually shun consumer goods that boast about being official. That's one reason I never bought a certain camera that called itself ''the official camera of the New York Yankees.'' The other reason is that I've never wanted a camera.

title: OIL COMPANIES NAMED IN SUIT ON TOXIC WASTE
description: A group of environmental lawyers filed a lawsuit today against 26 companies, including some of the nation's largest oil and petrochemical concerns, maintaining that reckless handling of toxic waste materials exposed many residents of Harris County to severe health hazards.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Year-ago first quarter results represent operations of the business when it was operated as a division of Atlan-Tol Industries Inc.

title: NEW YORK ALLIES OF SOUTH AFRICA'S OPPRESSED
description: To the Editor:

title: The Talk of Rochester
description: This city on the shore of Lake Ontario is celebrating its sesquicentennial while scrambling to complete an urban-renewal program that has changed its face without solving all its problems.

title: PEDAGOGICAL MECHANICS: OF PHYSICS, FUN AND THE ETERNAL BATTLE AGAINST ENTROPY
description: In 1982, as a lowly sophomore, Jane Bai was walking back to school from the big hangout that year, the Mirror Building coffee shop, when she spotted a bunch of seniors speeding down the hill toward her in little red wagons.

title: PRINCESS CAROLINE HAS CHILD;
description: Princess Caroline of Monaco gave birth to her first child today, a 6-pound 6-ounce boy, the royal palace announced. The 27-year-old Princess is married to Stefano Casiraghi, an Italian businessman.

title: OLYMPIA BUYS STAKE IN CADILLAC
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. of Toronto, one of the biggest real estate developers in North America, said yesterday that it had purchased or agreed to purchase a 19.9 percent interest in the Cadillac Fairview Corporation and that it might increase its stake.

title: INDEBTED NATIONS MAKE THEIR POINT IN LONDON
description: The indebted developing world, which is not invited to the economic summit conference, is getting its views across with more force and effectiveness at this year's meeting than at any meeting before, in the view of many officials.

title: China Goal Up For Car Output
description: China has raised its 1984 motor vehicle production target by 50,000, to 290,000, but demand, especially from newly rich rural residents, will still outstrip supply, the New China News Agency said today. It quoted an official of the China Automotive Industry Corporation as saying that domestic demand would reach 350,000 vehicles this year. Ownership of trucks and tractors in the countryside has increased sharply.

title: HISTORIC MANSION IS SETTING FOR TALKS
description: The governmental leaders here for the economic summit meeting began talks today as a brilliant sun bathed the city, turning the thoughts of most Londoners to anything but work. But true to her reputation as an indefatigable taskmaster, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher did not follow the example set by her predecessor, James Callaghan, who broke with the schedule to lead an impromptu walk through St. James's Park during the equally sun-blessed 1977 summit meeting.

title: U.S. OFFERS EXPLANATIONS FOR DEFICIT, BUT THE SKEPTICS SEEM UNCONVINCED
description: Like an unwelcome guest, the subject of the American budget deficit keeps appearing at the economic summit conference here despite the best efforts by President Reagan and his entourage.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HUNT FOR A WORD TO SET THE TONE
description: On a strawberry sundae of a day, all daisies and June sun and pastoral posing by world leaders on the Lancaster House lawn, a professional summit manager came up with a curious new word. It had the charm of corrugated cardboard: snimog.

title: BLACK LAWMAKERS WILL MEET WITH JACKSON IN A DRIVE FOR UNITY
description: Members of the Congressional Black Caucus will meet Monday with the Rev. Jesse Jackson to forge strategies designed to bring blacks together at next month's Democratic National Convention ''regardless of their preference of candidates,'' according to an official close to the group.

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income. The company is 80 percent owned by Technodyne Inc., a publicly held company.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. For the Yankees of 1984, things never seem to get any easier. Tonight's opponent is Dave Stieb, who for several seasons has been one of the American League's most consistent pitchers. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said its planned acquisition of the Bank of Hallandale & Trust Co. had been approved by the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $12,108,000 for the quarter and $43,809,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary charge of $22,033,000 for the 9 months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $14,532,000 for the quarter and $44,863,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE WORLD;
description: More About Sakharov

title: ALTERATIONS Paying the Bill When it comes to school desegregation, the Reagan Administration has taken contradictory positions. It abhors mandatory busing and supports only voluntary desegregation efforts. Yet it has also cut spending for voluntary desegregation.
description: In 1981 Mr. Reagan persuaded Congress to fold the Emergency School Aid Act, which helped communities ease the transition to desegregation, into a block grant with two dozen other educational programs. All were funded at 85 percent of their previous level.

title: NEW LIFE FOR OLD FURNITURE: REPLACING DAMAGED VENEER
description: VERY often one comes across a fine piece of old veneered furniture that has been damaged slightly and bears a small blemish that mars its otherwise beautiful appearance.

title: CONTADORA GROUP'S ENVOYS VISIT NICARAGUA
description: Foreign ministers of the four-nation Contadora Group began a tour of Central America today, seeking a peace treaty for the troubled region.

title: COGENERATION JARS THE POWER INDUSTRY
description: IN Freeport, Texas, the Dow Chemical

title: STATE GETS NEW D.R.G. RATE DEADLINE
description: TRENTON MEDICARE officials have said they will stop paying hospital bills set under the state's Diagnosis Related Groups (D.R.G.) system and will switch to a Federal rate- setting plan Jan. 1, unless the state can show that Medicare expenditures in New Jersey are not growing at a faster rate than in other states.

title: CUSTOMS OFFICE GETS REPRIEVE TO SEPT. 30
description: A LAST-MINUTE reprieve on May 31 may have temporarily saved the Bridgeport Customs office, but the Customs Service said that it was proceeding with plans to close the office by Sept. 30.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Questioning His Honor The bargaining in the Cook County courtroom of Judge John M. Murphy often involved cash instead of pleas, according to testimony last week in a judicial corruption trial in Chicago. One prosecution witness, a former police officer, said that Judge Murphy had fixed about 100 traffic cases.

title: A TALE OF FOUR CORNERS
description: A hundred years ago, most of the millions of acres in this part of the Southwest were known at best as scrublands and at worst as badlands. It is a place where nature, geology and time have twisted and eroded the land into lonely and barren shapes, shorn the soil of many of its nutrients, drained most useful water into deep and unreachable canyons, and baked it all under a relentless sun that is rarely interrupted by anything but the night.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
THE JOY OF BRINGING UP BUDS
description: Neal Johnston

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A GARDEN IS NURTURED IN NEWARK
description: THE ONLY two Newark students to be accepted by the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology this year - and, in fact, in the last three years - are in my senior homeroom at University High School.

title: LAWYERS ASK RULE ON ADS BE EASED
description: HACKENSACK OPENING arguments in an attempt to overturn the state's strict regulation of legal-services advertising began here last week, with both sides debating the issue of dignity.

title: A West German Breaks World Decathlon Mark
description: Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany collected 8,798 points to set a world record in the decathlon today during his country's Olympic trials.

description: Fiction1 13 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. Delacorte, $15.95.) title: MISS ALCOTT SURGES INTO ONE-SHOT LEAD
description: Amy Alcott overcame a four-stroke deficit and stifling 95-degree heat today to take a stroke lead after three rounds of the $350,000 McDonald's Kids Classic golf tournament.

title: Carroll B. Crane, G. W. Yandell 3d Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Carroll Bryson Crane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Carey Crane Jr. of Riverside, Conn. and George Wilson Yandell 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Yandell Jr. of Berkeley, Calif., took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: PIGIONS ARE FAIR GAME TO BUFFALO'S VERMIN PATROL L
description: The two uniformed men leaned their rifles against their blue and gold vans, looked carefully through the telescopic sights and began to shoot at the pigeons high overhead on the ledge of a downtown building.

title: IRAQ REPORTS ATTACK ON 2 SHIPS, BUT IRAN DENIES IT
description: Iraq announced today that its planes had hit two large ships north and west of the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island Friday night. Iran quickly denied the report and it was not confirmed elsewhere.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ADVERTISING;
RANKING THE MEMORABLE TV ADS
description: IS anyone surprised that Wendy's

title: Collette M. Reifers Weds Henry S. Huidekoper 2d
description: Collette Marie Reifers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Francis Reifers of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Henry Shippen Huidekoper 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Galloway Huidekoper, also of New Canaan. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Edward Howley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ecumenical ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Dena Siebert Married To David B. Thomas
description: At the First United Methodist Church in Chatham, Mass., yesterday Dena Walker Siebert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson A. Seibert Jr. of Boston and Chatham, was married to David Brian Thomas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Thomas of Arlington, Mass. The Rev. Daniel P. Freitas performed the ceremony.

title: CONGRESS SEEKING ACCORD ON MEDICAL AID FOR POOR AND ELDERLY
description: House and Senate negotiators start work next week on a bill that could make major changes in Federal health programs serving more than 50 million Americans.
