description: To the Editor:

title: OBERAMMERGAU PLAY: DEEPLY ROOTED OFFENSE...
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSFER BOOM
description: How the bidding habits of the experts and the near-experts have changed in the past 15 years has been an interesting matter for speculation. But now it is not necessary to speculate, for The Bridge World has conducted a most important survey. A long and detailed questionnaire was answered by 118 experts and 1400 readers. The aim was to update Bridge World Standard, a consensus expert system.

title: COLLEGE AND COMPUTERS
description: Although knowledge of computer programming is by no means a prerequisite to intelligent computer use, programming classes offer more than the mere ability to program; in the course of learning to program, one acquires ratiocinative skills well- suited to a wide range of problem-solving tasks. Teachers in other disciplines rarely discuss problem-solving skills explicitly; if they do, it is only in passing. In computer-programming courses, on the other hand, the methodology of problem solving is a central and recurrent theme. JONATHAN L. SHRIER Washington

title: SURE LOSERS IN THE WESTMORELAND CBS 'WAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Murphy Wed At a Bronxville Church
description: Deborah Dale Murphy, a daughter of Mayor and Mrs. William J. Murphy of Bronxville, N.Y., and Stratton, Vt., was married at the Reformed Church of Bronxville yesterday to Brian Francis Meade, a son of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Robert C. Meade of Great Neck, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield, assisted by the Rev. Brendan Riordan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TO MR. APARTHEID
description: Following is an open letter to Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa.

title: Ralph G. Nader Weds Wendy Beth Norman
description: Wendy Beth Norman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin Haines Norman of Great Neck Estates and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Ralph Georges Nader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Georges S. Nader of Port- au-Prince and Grand-Go^ave, Haiti. The Rev. John Mulryan performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck.

title: Sarah Anderson Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Jennings Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood L. Anderson 3d of Burlington, Conn., and William Erich Krengel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Franklin Krengel Jr. of Bellevue, Wash., were married yesterday. The Rev. Carol Anderson, rector of All Angels Episcopal Church in Manhattan and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Bristol, Conn.

title: THE CONTROVERSIAL FATHER GREELEY
description: Those of us who left clerical and religious orders in the 1960's (and we number about 10,000) did so for many reasons.

title: Fall Trial in Kennedy Death
description: A Sept. 14 trial date has been set for the two hotel bellmen accused of selling David A. Kennedy the cocaine that contributed to his death from a drug overdose, court officials said Thursday. The defendants are Peter Marchant, 24 years old, and David Linwood Dorr, 30. Mr. Kennedy, 28, son of Robert F. Kennedy, was found dead in his room at the Brazilian Court Hotel in Palm Beach April 25.

title: Hospice Progams And Volunteers
description: It was a pleasure to read your article, ''Growth of Hospice Programs Is Cited'' on May 20. The author captured the spirit as well as the particulars of what makes hospice a unique and compassionate program.

title: COMPANIES TRYING TO CUT COSTS OF HEALTH BENEFITS
description: INDIVIDUALLY and in new coalitions, corporations in New Jersey are increasingly focusing on reining in the costs of their health-care benefit programs. Although no figures are available on how much employers in the state pay for group health plans each year - the nationwide total is around $75 billion - executives from across New Jersey say that their companies' health expenditures have been rising by 10 to 20 percent a year.

title: ...MISTAKEN HORNS
description: To the Editor:

title: Virus Forces Killing of Birds
description: State and Federal officials have destroyed 518 exotic birds in two aviaries to prevent a deadly infectious virus from spreading throughout the state's $800 million poultry industry.

title: Dianne Metzger Weds Michael Peter Bracco
description: Dianne Eleanor Metzger, the daughter of Mrs. Samuel Parant Metzger 3d of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Metzger, was married yesterday to Michael Peter Bracco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Bracco of Garden City Park, L.I. The Rev. Arthur M. Tingue, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Mrs. Metzger's home.

title: THE LAST SOUNDS OF SPRING ON THE SCHEDULE THIS AFTERNOON
description: WHEN students of the Shumiatcher School of Music in Mamaroneck present their yearly ''Spring Sounds'' Festival this afternoon from 1:30 to 5 o'clock (the performances are free and open to the public), we can pretty well close the cultural books on spring. Next weekend, the yearly Hudson River Revival ushers in the summer solstice, and by the end of the month at least three more summer festivals in the county will be open for musical business.

title: 3d World's Food Needs Seen Growing by U.S.
description: The Agriculture Department said today that third-world countries would have to import 31 million tons of food next year, a rise of 3 percent, simply to keep hunger in check at a level far below accepted nutrition needs.

title: GAINS SERIES FINAL
description: John Fishel and Tom Thomas each drove in four runs to back the six-hit pitching of Todd Simmons as California State-Fullerton defeated Oklahoma State, 10-2, tonight in the semifinals of the College World Series.

title: ARTISTS PUT 'WEALTH' IN A BANK OF SLIDES
description: THOUGH the sign on the door says Artists Bank, it is not dollars that are on deposit in a small room in the offices of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts in Hartford.

title: COYOTE POPULATION IN STATE INCREASING
description: ONE OF New Jersey's wildest species, the Eastern coyote, has done more than survive farmers' bullets, hunters' traps and development pressures; its population has increased in the last decade, noticeably in the last two years.

title: TEXTS OF STATEMENTS ON EAST-WEST RELATIONS, TERRORISM AND THE GULF WAR
description: Following are the texts of the Declaration on East- West Relations and Arms Control and of the Declaration on International Terrorism that were adopted by the leaders at the economic summit conference and the text of a statement on the Iraq-Iran war by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the chairman, all made public today:

title: FOR BRAZILIAN FARMHANDS, A NOTABLE VICTORY
description: The first word of the strike came when huge logs blocked the path of trucks carrying farm laborers to nearby cane fields. Then, after a crowd destroyed the offices of a state water company, a battle ensued between protesters and the police, leaving one person dead and 50 wounded.

title: Lottery Jackpot Winner Faces Bad Check Charge
description: A man who won a $4.4 million state lottery jackpot in September now faces charges of writing bad checks, the police said today.

title: GLAD TO HAVE FOUGHT HAGLER BEFORE HE TURNED MARVELOUS
description: I HAVE the distinction of being the

title: Mame Kennedy Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Ellen Kennedy, the registrar of the Leo Castelli Gallery, was married yesterday to Victor Alexis Schrager, a professor of photography at the School of Visual Arts. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: THE CLASS OF '84 IS ANOTHER DISAPPOINTMENT FOR BLACKS
description: During the grim months that followed the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968, the country was swept by a determination to improve the outlook for black Americans. Among the favored strategies was expanding opportunities in higher education. Black enrollment in colleges and universities surged, raising hopes that the inequities of the past would be redressed. But now those hopes have foundered as the number of black students working toward undergraduate and graduate degrees has declined.

title: THE ARCHITECTURE OF SURREALISM
description: SURREALISM is creeping over the face of suburbia. The landscape that was once mocked as being made up out of ''ticky-tack, with houses all the same'' is taking on an appearance that would delight Salvador Dali.

title: SAFETY IN THE WATER AND ASHORE
description: ''Many people who dive into pools have scratched their nose or scraped their fingers on the bottom,'' said Bill Mullin, a quadriplegic who broke his neck while diving. ''It's so easy to injure the spinal cord that it's amazing that it doesn't happen more often.''

title: A NEW 'FIGARO' FOR AN OPERA FESTIVAL
description: LAWRENCEVILLE THE June Opera Festival of New Jersey will begin its inaugural season here Friday with a new English-language production of Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro.''

title: EGGPLANT TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: THERE ARE many points of inspirational departure when writing about food. It may be the sight of a vegetable or meat in our supermarket; it may be a neighbor's request for a recipe; it may be a dish we have sampled in the home of a friend or at a restaurant.

title: No Headline
description: ThousandsinMidtown P

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: One Bad Game for Lakers

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Cable TV
description: Movie buffs will find some haunting images from the past in this week's cable screen fare. Wednesday alone holds three surprises, starting with the 1935 ''Dante's Inferno,'' starring Spencer Tracy. (USA Network at noon.)

title: KATHERINE WATTS WEDS IN VIRGINA
description: Katherine Watts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Watts of Roanoke, Va., was married yesterday to Dale E. McIvor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar William McIvor of Blanchard, Mich. The Rev. Clay Turner performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Fincastle, Va.

title: A FEMINIST OFFENSIVE AGAINST EXPLOITATION
description: An unusual coalition of radical feminists and conservative women politicians in Minneapolis and Indianapolis is leading a novel campaign against pornography. Their goal is the enactment of local laws that would define pornography as ''the sexually explicit subordination of women'' and make purveyors subject to legal action for violating the civil rights of women.

title: STAGE: :ROBERT FROST'
description: Over the years there have been a number of attempts to re-create the world of Robert Frost on stage, with the emphasis more on the poetry than on the poet. The most memorable adaptation was ''An Evening's Frost,'' as performed by Will Geer. In the new play, ''Robert Frost: Fire and Ice,'' Arthur Peterson (in collaboration with June August) has reached for a full-length biographical portrait. As acted by Mr. Peterson, the monodrama is now running at the South Street Theater.

title: Borrowed Zoo Monkeys Removed From Atlanta
description: Concerned about the treatment of animals at the Atlanta Zoo, the Milwaukee Zoo has removed two monkeys it lent the facility more than three years ago, a Milwaukee Zoo official said.

title: A Bullish Bent for Market Technicians
description: TO the average investor, technical stock market indicators might as well be written in Sanskrit. Closely followed, but not always understood, these indicators - which are used to predict broad market movements on the basis of historic price and trading volume patterns - can prove frustratingly enigmatic. But a knowledge of what technical indicators are saying has proved a valuable resource to many investors, both large and small.

title: CRIMINAL ELEMENTS
LEARNING TO DELIGHT IN THE OBVIOUS
description: -wise traveler when

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: NORMANDY 40 YEARS ON
description: American pride in a military achievement, British satisfaction that the bill to Germany had been paid and French eagerness to erase the past by flexing martial muscle seemed to be the most significant attitudes evident as the Allies commemorated the 40th anniversary of the invasion of Normandy.

title: CAUCASIAN COLLECTIVE CIRCUS
description: Jeri Laber , the executive director of Helsinki Watch, writes about Russian literature, among other subjects. THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO CHEGEM

title: France Accuses Three Of Having Spy Contacts
description: Two men and a woman have been charged with having intelligence contacts with agents of a foreign power, believed to be the Soviet Union.

title: DEFENDING ARGENTINA'S NEW DEMOCRACY
description: Raul Alfonsin is a man in a hurry. At the Casa Rosada, the pink presidential palace, he holds meeting after meeting starting at 8 in the morning. At dinner at his official residence, he holds more talks with business, labor and political leaders. He darts around the country, pleading to be heard. Everywhere his message is the same: Argentina's new democracy is under threat. Gone is the euphoria of six months ago, when A lf o ns i n was inaugurated as President on the crest of an upset election victory, ending nearly eight years of bloody military rule. Though a number of former military leaders have been put on trial for the ''disappearance'' of more than 6,000 Argentines during an indiscriminate antisubversion campaign, human-rights groups complain that he is not moving forcibly enough to bring the guilty to justice. The Peronist Party, still stunned by its defeat at the polls, has been blocking A lf o ns i n's legislative program. The Peronist labor movement has been using the strike weapon to defeat A lf o ns i n's plans for union reforms.

title: IVES ARTS CENTER RISING ON A POND
description: DONALD E. WEEDEN of Danbury is a busy investment banker. But in his spare time these days he can be found picking his way around puddles and brush piles at a construction site on the West Side campus of Western Connecticut State University in Danbury.

title: HOW INDIVIDUAL NATIONS FARED THE CONFERENCE
description: Economic summit meetings have often produced winners and losers. The key factors have been the agendas set up by the leaders themselves, and how their performances turn out on the issues they earmarked as important to emphasize or to avoid.

title: Deborah Dickson Marries
description: Deborah Denise Dickson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Dickson of Wyndmoor, Pa., and Thomas J. Bracken Jr., the son of Mrs. L. Kerr Collingwood of Lafayette Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Bracken, were married yesterday. The Rev. John F. Cullen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Seven Dolors in Wyndmoor. The bride graduated from the Germantown Academy and Dickinson College. Mr. Bracken is a graduate of LaSalle College.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS June 10, 1984
description: Fiction1 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Warner, $4.95.) Murder in an Italian monastery. 2 GODPLAYER, by Robin Cook. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The marriage of two physicians crumbles as death stalks their hospital corridors. 3 INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM, by James Kahn. (Ballantine, $2.95.) More perilous adventures of the hero of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.'' 4

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINON;
SHOULD STATE COLLEGES BE UNIFIED?
description: AS CHAIRMAN of the Senate Education Committee and sponsor of the original legislation that created New Jersey's system of higher education, I welcome every effort to support and improve our colleges.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN its two centuries ''at the heart of East

title: THE CONTROVERSIAL FATHER GREELEY
description: Mark Harris's article on Andrew Greeley follows the myth which has grown up in the current atmosphere of hostility and criticism of the church and of authority in general.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Sounds Familiar In 1980, Dr. Kenneth Melmon was so engrossed in his new position as chairman of the Stanford University department of medicine that he didn't get around to making sure permission had been granted to use some material he borrowed for a textbook he was working on. As a result, he may be a little less busy. Dr. Melmon resigned his chairmanship last week after the publisher of the borrowed material accused him of plagiarism and a university ethics committee censured him for ''grossly negligent scholarship.'' However, officials said they found no fraud on his part and cited his ''devotion to the university's interests.'' Dr. Melmon, who will remain on the faculty, said his colleagues saw his censure and resignation as ''more than sufficient response to my mistake.''

title: U.S. Women Lose
description: The Japanese national women's volleyball team beat the United States, 2-15, 16-14, 15-6, 15-8, for the second straight time today.

title: EUROPEANS GIVE BOTHA A FROSTY VISIT
description: A large upholstered sofa was removed from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's office last week minutes before South Africa's Prime Minister, P.W. Botha, came to call. The Chancellor typically sits on the sofa with his foreign guests as photographers snap. This time, Mr. Kohl stood unsmiling and stiff next to a relaxed-looking Mr. Botha. The Chancellor declined to re-enact a handshake for the cameramen, who did, however, immortalize the departing piece of furniture.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We had a free flow of discussion and argument. This is not and has never been a yes-man's club.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. (12:2.)

title: STATES FINANCE AID PROGRAMS THAT U.S. CUT, STUDY FINDS
description: The vast majority of domestic programs begun by the Federal Government in the past three decades have survived despite budget cuts made under the Reagan Administration, according to a detailed study reported yesterday.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Brooklyn or L.I.?
description: When is part of Long Island not part of Long Island? When it's Brooklyn.

title: The Controversial Father Greeley
description: Often, we are all too quick to judge people from surface appearances and too little information (''Novelist, Journalist, Sociologist, Priest: Andrew Greeley,'' by Mark Harris, May 6).

title: HIGH-RISES CURBED BY SAN FRANCISCO
description: After 32 years of controversy over the construction of high-rise buildings, San Francisco's voters have finally accepted a proposal to limit upward growth.

title: Reagan Invites Allies To Join Space Project
description: President Reagan showed allied leaders a model of a permament manned space station today and invited them to join in the project.

title: OFFERING A SOLUTION FOR WESTHAMPTON BEACH EROSION
description: IN 1964, a beach stabilization

title: PREVENTING SPINAL INJURIES
description: ''It's started, the spinal-cord injury season,'' said Bill Mullin, edging forward in his Everest & Jennings wheelchair and surveying the audience of 60 high-school students before him. ''From June through September, it's happening in the ocean and the lakes and rivers and backyard pools. I'm here to try to keep it from happening to you.''

title: THE WORLD;
description: Remembering In Normandy

title: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS PLEDGE TO ASSIST DEBTOR COUNTRIES
description: The leaders of the seven major industrial democracies pledged today to make it easier for some of the hard-pressed third world countries to repay their debts, promised to continue their own vigorous policies against inflation and voiced their support for ''precise commitments'' to the ''nonuse of force'' by both East and West.

title: BOOKS
description: WHAT springs forth fresh from almost every page of ''Home Ground: A Gardener's Miscellany'' by Allen Lacy (Farrar, Straus, Giroux, New York, $14.95) is a splendid mixture of nostalgia and fact.

title: DAY OF INFAMY, DECADES OF DOUBT
description: Telford Taylor may have succeeded in belittling Seaman Ogg's testimony regarding advance knowledge of Japanese fleet movements prior to Pearl Harbor, but he has not conclusively disproved the theory that part of the infamy that fateful December 7 may have resulted from the behavior of President Roosevelt and his cohorts. Mr. Taylor's conclusion is that such duplicity is ''so scandalous and improbable . . . it cannot be seriously entertained.''

title:
GARDENING;
THIS IS THE MONTH FOR ROSES
description: JUNE is a glorious month in the garden. The weather is more often than not ideal, not too hot or too cold, and one is less apt to be caught by an unexpected shower.

title: MUSIC FROM MOVIES STIRS THE BLOOD
description: Film soundtracks continue to provide gratification for those who favor the modern orchestral idiom but find much late 20th-century music lacking in sufficient color, zest and ardor.

title: ; Erice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Earliest Vaccines
description: In ''The New Age of Vaccines'' (April 29), Harold M. Schmeck Jr. nicely summarizes the current and likely future status of vaccination.

title: CENTENARY OF A GOLDEN VOICE FROM IRELAND
description: Barrymore Scherer writes frequently about the arts.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ADVERTISING ;
THE LATEST SINGLE-AD 'MAGAZINE'
description: DEPENDING upon their specialties, doctors in the United States receive 50 to 85 professional journals every month. That's a lot of advertising - especially for pharmaceuticals, which account for the bulk of the ads. The problem for drug companies and the ad agencies representing them is to rise above the crowd - and the competition for the physician's reading time.

title: LEANER TIMES FOR DOCUMENTARIANS
description: Ellin Stein is a freelance writer and video producer.

title: U.S. Five on Top
description: The United States overwhelmed France today, 97-28, for its second victory and advanced to the winners' round of the William Jones Cup women's basketball tournament. The top scorer for the Americans was Pam McGee with 16 points.

title: FANS ARE HISTORY'S SOUVENIRS
description: Edith Standen, the former curator of the textile study room of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, thinks of fans as ''the T- shirts of their day'' - souvenirs that tourists from the beginning of the 18th century through the start of World War II brought back home from their travels abroad.

title: HARLEM, SCARSDALE STUDENTS IN EXCHANGE
description: JENNIFER SEIDEN is all of 14 years old and has yet to see anyone killed. That amazed Terrence Green, also 14, when he heard it. But then, Jennifer was somewhat startled to discover that Terrence wasn't sure what a house was.

title: COPING WITH A CRUEL DILEMMA
description: A. J. Sherman is the author of ''Island Refuge: Britain and Refugees from the Third Reich, 1933- 1939''. THE TRANSFER AGREEMENT

title: A CULINARY HIGHLAND FLING
description: The exact moment in 1978 can be pinpointed. It was when the Hilditch family found Ledcreich, a remote country house in a lovely Highland glen known as the Braes o'Balquhidder. That was when their minds wandered off without them.

title: DHOWS IN GULF SLIP BY IRAQIS IN IRAN TRADE
description: While Iranian and Iraqi jets have concentrated their fire on big oil tankers in the Persian Gulf, creaking wooden vessels have been plying the waters of the gulf daily, delivering Texas rice, American tires and Japanese appliances to Iran.

title: MORTGAGE RATES CREEP TOWARD 15%
description: People hunting for an apartment or a house during this peak home-hunting season have had two major concerns: getting soaked by record rains and being unable to afford increasing mortgage interest rates. Long-term mortgage and cooperative loan rates in the metropolitan area, which have risen a little every week since the middle of February, are now up by more than 1 percentage point for the period and are approaching 15 percent.

title: TALKS ARE TO RESUME IN MINNESOTA NURSES' STRIKE
description: Negotiations to end a strike of 6,300 nurses at 16 hospitals in the Minneapolis area will resume Tuesday, but neither side appears ready to yield ground in the largest nurses' strike yet in this country.

title: Designer Clutter
description: I was delighted to see the book-strewn rooms that designer Keith Irvine so carefully orchestrated (''Imperfection With a Purpose,'' by Carol Vogel, May 6). Actually, it took me a great deal less effort to accumulate the clutter in my own well-worn bedroom. As I carefully trace my path, now avoiding books, magazines and old photos, I exalt in the knowledge that my home, too, may seem to the untutored eye ''as though the decorator had not yet begun.'' NATALIE G. RESSNER, Woodmere, L.I.

title: STUDENTS CONDUCT MODEL LEGISLATURE
description: ON June 1, 26 students from 20 area high schools were sworn in by County Clerk Andrew J. Spano as members of the first model county legislature held in Westchester in more than 15 years.

title: New President for Intrepid
description: The Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum Foundation, which runs the museum on the converted aircraft carrier docked in the Hudson at 46th Street, has named Stanley Abrams, a former television and film industry executive, as its president and chief executive officer. Mr. Abrams has been a vice president of the Emerson Radio and Television Corporation, the president of a worldwide aircraft leasing concern and a vice president of finance for the Embassy Pictures Corporation.

title: INDIAN GOVERNMENT TAKES ON SIKHS IN A BLOODY ENCOUNTER
description: M OSLEMS against Hindus, Assamese against Bengalese, Sikh terrorists against all the rest - in India the sources of conflict that threaten the unity of the world's largest democracy seem endless. Last week, a long-running conflict between the Government and the Sikhs of Punjab, one of India's most advanced states, appeared to reach a point of desperation. Some 450 Sikh terrorists and more than 80 soldiers died as the army assaulted the Golden Temple of Amritsar, the holiest shrine of a holy city, and other religious centers.

title: OKINAWA: CHINESE INFLUENCE
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is the author of ''Kosode: 16th- Through 19th-Century Textiles From the Nomura Collection'' (Japan Society/Kodansha International). By AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM

title: A 'CHATEAU' WITH A VIEW TO MATCH
description: CHATEAU LA MER in Lindenhurst opened last New Year's Eve. Calling it a chateau is not overstating. The restaurant, which commands a spectacular view of Great South Bay from a soaring expanse of plate glass windows, is grand in every dimension.

title: The Menu    At Banquet
description: Following is the menu for the Queen's banquet tonight after the economic conference. The meal included poached salmon, lamb cutlets covered with chicken mousse and peaches served on coffee ice cream. Rosettes de Saumon Regence

title: Dr. Jeanne Kelly Wed To Dr. William Gomez
description: Dr. Jeanne Marie Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Kelly of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Dr. William Gomez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilberto Gomez of New York. The Rev. Christopher Dunne performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: No Headline
description: Of Dump Project Although the article (''Board Seeks Study in Dump Dispute,'' May 20) on the proposed dump in the town of Cortlandt was accurate and to the point, as a long-time resident of the area I think there are some important details that I can add.

title: Letters ; Bronx Renovation
description: To the Editor:

title: SATELLITE CASTING DOUBT ON KNOWLEDGE OF COMETS
description: A research satellite orbiting Venus, briefly tilted to watch a passing comet, has sent back surprising information that may force scientists to reconsider what they know about comets.

title: MARIJUANA RAIDS ANGERING RETIREES
description: Last fall, Judy and Mike Carlson say, the solitude of their retirement home in Hungry Gulch Valley was shattered by a helicopter with 20 heavily armed men circling low over their house.

title: HONDURAS HINTS AT A SOFTER LINE
description: Honduras's new military command finished tallying the pluses and minuses of its friendship with the United States last week and found the equation wanting. The effects will be felt not only within its borders, but throughout the region and in Washington.

title: PALE LILAC SPEAKS
description: Every morning, I start out the day with

title: Miss Ling Is Wed To Fenton Tom
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Genevieve Ling, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. S. Ling of New York and Geneva, was married to Fenton Charles Tom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fay S. Tom of San Francisco. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: HART SAYS HE WILL CONTINUE DRIVE BUT VOWS NOT TO DIVIDE THE PARTY
description: Gary Hart declared today that he would continue his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination and reminded delegates that under party rules, they are free to switch to him from Walter F. Mondale.

title:
ART;
SHARP IMAGES AT YALE
description: IN art, the 1980's is emerging as a

title: Food Prices Are Raised In the Philippines
description: The Government allowed increases of up to 40 percent in the prices of some foods and other controlled commodities today as Filipinos struggled with the effects of the third devaluation of the peso in a year.

title: THE NATION;
description: Whittling Is Hard Work

title: THE REGION;
description: City Inspectors Indicted on Bribe Charges

title: HOW TWO ARTISTS SHAPED AN INNOVATIVE MUSICAL
description: ''Art isn't easy,'' sings a character in ''Sunday in the Park with George.'' ''Having just the vision's no solution,/ Everything depends on execution./ The art of making art/ Is putting it together/ Bit by bit . . .''

title:
IN THE SUBURBS, BACKYARD POLITICS COMES NATURALLY;
EXPANSIVE NEIGHBORS

GARDENING;
THIS IS THE MONTH FOR ROSES
description: JUNE is a glorious month in the garden. The weather is more often than not ideal, not too hot or too cold, and one is less apt to be caught by an unexpected shower.

title: Satellite Out of Control After Florida Launch
description: A $30 million international communication satellite tumbled out of control after it was launched over the Atlantic Ocean today, and NASA officials said there was no way to save it.

title: Low Vote Predicted In Maine's Primary
description: Voters choose candidates Tuesday in Maine's Congressional primaries, although candidates in five of the primary races are running uncontested.

title: CROWDED SKIES
Dakar
description: To the Editor:

title: Top State Court to Hear Plea of Prisoner on Fast
description: Lawyers for Joel Caulk, a convicted rapist, are to argue before the New Hampshire Supreme Court on Monday that the 14th Amendment to the Constitution prevents the state from depriving Mr. Caulk of the ''liberty'' to die without due process of law.

title: International
description: Easier credit terms for some third world countries were pledged by the leaders of the major industrial democracies at the conclusion of their economic summit conference in London. The leaders also promised to continue their own hard-line policies against inflation and voiced their support of ''precise commitments'' to the ''nonuse of force'' by both the East and West. (Page 1, Column 6.) Bulgaria's secret services recruited the man who shot Pope John Paul II in 1981 in a plot to weaken the Solidarity movement in Poland, according to a report filed in court by an Italian State Prosecutor. The report was based on about 25,000 pages of documentation gathered by Judge Ilario Martella in his investigation of the attempt to assassinate the Pope. It asks for the indictment and trial of three Bulgarians and six Turks, including Mehmet Ali Agca, who has been convicted of shooting the Pope on May 13, 1981. (1:1.)

title: No Headline
description: For the Footpath And the Kitchen

title: Leslie N. Roberts Wed in Ridgefield
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn., yesterday Leslie Noel Roberts, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Roberts Jr. of St. Thomas, V.I., and Wilton, Conn., was married to R. Jeffrey Petersen, a son of Raymond J. Petersen of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Rosalie Iovin Petersen. The Rev. Mark Connolly performed the ceremony.

title: CHLDREN TRY HAND AT CARTOONING
description: B IFF! BAMM! ZAP! and WOW! For those of you comic-strip fans who enjoy seeing the ''Zzzzzzz's'' and the ''av*XV!*a*!'s,'' beware! There may be some future Al Capps, Milton Caniffs and Mort Walkers out there who are soon to put pen to art board and come out of their studios.

title: SAND MINES FACE CRACKDOWN
description: WHEN Frank Grausso, who owns 115 wooded acres in Speonk, applied two years ago for permission to operate a 90-acre sand mine on his property, his request gave Southampton officials a jolt. They turned him down, and he has since taken them to court.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An artcle June 3 on a court test of a 1981 state law intended to protect the privacy of victims in sexual-assault cases misidentified the Superior Court judge who ordered that pseudonyms be substituted for the real names of women scheduled to testify in a rape trial in Hartford. The judge is Jerry Wagner.

title: HORIZONS: NEW-MUSIC FESTIVAL ENDS
description: The New York Philharmonic's Horizons '84 new-music festival, which ended with its 10th musical program Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, was designed by Jacob Druckman, its artistic director, to compensate for many of the gaps perceived in the first festival last year. There were programs this time devoted to ''downtown'' experimentalism and a three-concert mini-series of computer music. And there were more women, black and non-American composers.

title: INVITATION TO MOSCOW TO BEFRIEND TEHERAN
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA MAKES IT A SLAM
description: Martina Navratilova overwhelmed Chris Evert Lloyd for the 11th straight time today, winning the French Open final in 63 minutes, 6-3, 6-1. In doing so, Miss Navratilova earned a bonus of $1 million and a somewhat grudging recognition as the third woman to capture the four Grand Slam events in tennis.

title: Texas-El Paso Faces Second Investigation
description: The University of Texas-El Paso track program, already under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, now will be looked at by the El Paso County district attorney's office for possible criminal violations, District Attorney Steve Simmons said Friday. He declined to specify which areas of Texas law may have been violated, but said police investigators would help.

title: ROMANTICISM MAY BE THE NEW NOTE IN CRITICISM
description: Music criticism, whether practiced journalistically, academically or novelistically, remains a humble craft, traipsing after music and struggling to discern its fast-fading footprints. Music criticism isn't just tied to music in this sense, reflecting and explaining as best it can. Its very manner of expression, the way music critics struggle with the nearly impossible task of rendering tonal intelligence into intelligible prose, varies according to musical fashion.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: NINE years of growth and prosperity in a rented storefront and converted gas station seemed long enough to prove the staying power of a cultural institution. And so, with its arts and crafts classes filled to capacity and many artistic endeavors vying for space, the Pelham Art Center has begun a fund- raising drive that would make a new, larger art center possible by October 1985, its 10th anniversary. Diana Reische and Stuart Epstein , executive co- chairmen of the Committee for the New Pelham Art Center, have announced a goal of $350,000. The plan calls for expanding and adding a new wing to the converted gas station building, which will triple gallery space, double classroom facilities, enlarge the museum's income-producing shop and create a dramatic landscaped courtyard for outdoor exhibitions and concerts.

title:
STAMPS;
ANNIVERSARY FOR A FAMOUS IRISH-AMERICAN TENOR
description: The United States and Ireland have put out joint commemoratives for the 100th anniversary of the birth of Irish-American tenor, John McCormack. One of opera's greatest tenors and of a performer of ballads without peer, John McCormack had an enormous following. He reached out to ordinary people with an immediacy of communication that few artists possess. What distinguished him from other singers of his time was parallel admiration from connoisseurs of opera as well as those of vocal repertory.

title: OPERATIC HYBRIDS COMING UP
description: Great composers, especially opera composers, sometimes have a hard time keeping their blue pencils off each other. The urge to correct, edit, adapt, or just tinker has given the world works by Mussorgsky/Rimsky-Korsakov, Weber/Berlioz and Handel/Mozart, among others. It has also given musicologists and critics a fertile field for controversy and investigation.

title: ALTERATIONS
description: Beggar's Opera

title: Davenport's Plea
description: Willie Davenport , the 1968 Olympic champion in the 110-meter high hurdles, petitioned Friday to compete in the United States Olympic trials, which begin next Saturday in Los Angeles. The 40-year-old Davenport said an injury prevented him from meeting the qualifying standard. However, he said he should be admitted because his indoor time of 7.33 seconds for the 60-yard high hurdles had qualified him for the national indoor championships.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A May 27 listing of events for the summer season incorrectly reported the telephone number of the Shore Line Trolley Museum in East Haven. The number is 467-6927.

title: No Headline
description: The virtually extinct paddle steamer is a strange beast, churning its way through the water with a boil of wide wake and the nostalgic thump-thump of wheels turning in paddle boxes. These boats are always broad of waist , but particularly so when they sport side-wheels substantial enough to allow navigation in the open ocean.

title: CALIFANO SAYS HE DID NOT EXPECT HAIG TO PAY FEE
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the lawyer who helped Alexander M. Haig Jr. prepare for his confirmation hearings to become Secretary of State, today denied that he ever asked Mr. Haig to pay for the services or that Mr. Haig had refused.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article and caption on page 34 of the Commercial Real Estate Report May 13 misspelled the name of the Christiania Building in Tarrytown, N.Y. In addition, the caption misidentified the developer. It is the Christiania Realty Company, of Tarrytown.

title: Utah's First Black Judge
description: Gov. Scott Matheson has appointed Tyrone E. Medley to Utah's Fifth Circuit Court bench, making him the state's first black judge. Mr. Medley, a 1977 graduate of the University of Utah Law School, replaces Judge Larry Keller.

title: Search Is Widespread For Last Two Convicts
description: A widespread search was under way today for two brothers who were the last of six convicts still at large after escaping from Virginia's death row 10 days ago.

title: ORIOLES' FLANAGAN STOPS TIGERS, 4-0
description: Mike Flanagan pitched a seven-hitter in 92- degree weather and John Lowenstein rapped a two-run, bases-loaded single as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4-0, today.

title: SOLVING THE MATHEMATICAL RIDDLE OF CHAOS
description: A premature summery Sunday takes Cornell University by surprise, and students head off to sun themselves at Treman State Park. The waterfall trail is closed, supposedly because of hazardous winter conditions. But not everyone is playing by the rules. High above the falls, a man stands at streamside, just where the smooth flow of water begins to speed and shudder. He is sweating slightly in sports coat and corduroys and puffing on a cigarette. Suddenly, in what might be a demented high- speed parody of a tennis spectator, he starts turning his head from side to side, over and over again.

title: The Long Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: A BULLISH BENT FOR MARKET TECHNICICANS
description: TO the average investor, technical stock market indicators might as well be written in

title: Nancy K. Kilpatrick Marries Rancher
description: Nancy Kate Kilpatrick, the daughter of Mrs. J. Howard Rambin Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Dr. Harold C. Kilpatrick, was married yesterday to Benjamin Eshleman 3d, the son of Mrs. Richard King 3d of Corpus Christi, Tex., and the late Mr. Eshleman Jr. The Rev. Charles Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: College and Computers
description: What seems at issue in Edward Fiske's article ''Computers in the Groves of Academe'' (May 13) is whether computers are, finally, means or ends in education. Mr. Fiske's view is certainly hardened by his unsettling claim that ''the communication and manipulation of symbols is what education is all about.'' While few would want to revive the simplistic notions of the 1960's that emotion and experience are crucial to learning, it is hard to believe that we have already shifted to the opposite pole. CRAIG HARBISON Associate Professor Art History University of Massachusetts Amherst, Mass.

title: WEEKLONG 'COLLEGE' DRAWS PRINCETON ALUMNI
description: The flag atop Princeton University's Nassau Hall hung limp in the hot, humid, afternoon air.

title: HANDLING OF SCHOOL FUNDS AT ISSUE
description: WITH the recent bankruptcy proceedings of Lion Capital and RTD Securities Inc., and the resulting freezing of millions of dollars of Long Island school districts' money, school and state officials are beginning to take a serious look at the way these districts are handling their finances.

title: ORGAN RECITAL: CLAIRE ALAIN PERFORMS
description: French organ-playing at its most characteristic was heard in St. Thomas Church Tuesday night. As recipient of the 1984 International Performer of the Year Award given by the New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists, Marie- Claire Alain performed a program comprising the Three Chorals of Cesar Franck, Three Dances by Jehan Alain and an improvisation on three disparate themes.

title: WHY WE NOW SEE MILLET DIFERENTLY
description: The 19th-century French painter Jean-Francois Millet is one of the artists who has benefited most from the shifting tides of recent art history. In the 1950's and 60's, when Formalism focused attention on the language of art, Millet's dramatizations of the noble peasant - weary, dirt poor, but pure and at one with his task and the earth - hardly seemed worthy of interest. But in the present climate, where what matters most to historians of 19th-century French art are its political implications and the social conditions in which it was made, exhibited and sold, Millet's paintings of the downtrodden of rural society, paintings that were profoundly disturbing to the French art establishment at the time they were made, have become art history worth fighting over.

ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
PHASES
description: WHITE PLAINS IN some other setting, they

title: PROGRAM AIDS STROKE VICTIMS
description: ON March 29, 1981, Betty Bartley of Coventry suffered a stroke that left her with a partially paralyzed left arm and leg. As she recovered, she wondered how she would again enjoy her favorite pastime, bowling.

title:
DINING OUT;
FROM THE KITCHENS OF KOREA
description: DESPITE Korea's proximity to China and Japan, the Koreans have held on to their own culture, traditions and cuisine. Although many dishes somewhat resembled Japanese, Chinese and Mongolian foods, the overall impression is of both sweeter and lustier flavors.

title: New Finance Minister Takes Office in Bolivia
description: Oscar Bonifaz Gutierrez, a Christian Democratic Congressman and former Commerce Minister, was sworn in Friday as the third Finance Minister this year.

description: It took less than 15 minutes for Hoboken's unused Sadie Leinkauf school to be sold for $1.2 million at a public auction last month.

description: The buildup toward the elections June 17 for the European Parliament seems to be marked by more tension in Greece than perhaps in any other member of the European Economic Community.

description: Senator Gary Hart's continued quest for the Presidential nomination has aroused fears among some leading Democrats that the party's chances against President Reagan could be hurt by a convention battle and continued internal divisions, as happened in some past elections.

description: The first thing you notice is the plateau, surging high above the valley, a rocky ship thrusting its prow against the sky. From miles away, it dominates the landscape, 2,000 feet above Colorado's rolling Montezuma Valley floor. But that is merely the beginning.

title: Space Programs Supported
description: Public support for space spending, which dropped in the Vietnam War era, has rebounded, a researcher says. Everett C. Ladd, executive director of the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, said Friday at a space symposium that in 1982 about 68 percent of Americans favored maintaining or increasing space expenditures.

CAMERA ;

description: In the 19th century, an Englishman named John Merrick was called ''the Elephant Man'' because he suffered from a rare genetic disease named neurofibromatosis that caused disfiguring facial tumors.

title: Miss Rowland Is Wed to Law Student
description: Emily Travers Rowland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Brabrook Rowland of Montclair, N.J., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Dale Allen Malone, a son of Merle L. Malone of Buffalo and Glenn A. Malone of Williamsville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Daniel M. Young performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Mondale Told His List Should Include Iacocca
description: A number of Democrats have suggested ''very strongly'' that Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, be considered as a running mate for Walter F. Mondale, Mr. Mondale's campaign chairman said today.

title: COOPED UP AT THE RACE TRACK
description: The musty wind that blew through the grandstand yesterday chased cigar smoke and hot-dog wrappers, and drifted through the barns where the stakes horses rested. No wind would have been better.

title: SUPERMARKET CHAINS CHARGED WITH FIXING PRICES
description: Three major supermarket chains have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to fix prices on Long Island by eliminating double-value and, in one case, triple- value redemptions of discount coupons.

title: Ryland Crary, 70, Historian; Taught at Teachers College
description: Ryland W. Crary, a historian who held professorships at Teachers College of Columbia University, the University of Pittsburgh and Bethany College, died of cancer at his home in Bethany, W.Va., on Friday. He was 70 years old.

title: K. K. Ward Wed To Leslie Villani
description: St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Plymouth, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Leslie Jean Villani, a daughter of Mrs. Peter Paul Villani of Plymouth and the late Mr. Villani, and Kevin Kingsley Ward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence William Ward of Cincinnati and Kennebunk Beach, Me. The Rev. Edward G. Carroll performed the ceremony.

title: LET EUROPE BE EUROPE
description: Irving Kristol is the John M. Olin Professor of Social Thought at N. Y. U.'s Graduate School of Business Administration and editor of The Public Interest. ANTIPOLITICS

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: There is no such thing as too much emotion in singing. When someone criticizes a performance as ''too emotional,'' it usually means that the external things commonly associated with passion - vehement gesture and pronunciation, taking leave of the musical pitch for emphasis, and so on - were present out of proportion to the emotional response felt by the listener. At Ilene Sameth's Carnegie Recital Hall debut last Saturday the externals seemed excessive.

title: NAUTICAL COLONY
description: On a 5.8-acre peninsula, itself on the Shippan Point peninsula in Stamford, the Collins Development Corporation is creating a ''dockominium,'' a colony of 78 apartments and 140 pleasure boat slips in which both kinds of accommodations will be sold as condominiums.

title: Landon Hall, D. F. Dickey Are Married
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Landon Hall of Cambridge, Mass., the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spotswood Braxton Hall Jr. of Richmond and Donald Faulkner Dickey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Whitney Dickey of Lebanon, N.H., took place yesterday. Bishop Robert Bruce Hall of the Diocese of Virginia, assisted by Canon Robert Hetherington, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: CHAMBER FESTIVALS AND EARLY WORKS FEATURED AMONG THIS WEEK'S CHOICES
description: THE festival floodgates are about to open, swirling us along on an exhilarating tide of great music all over the state. This Saturday, for instance, marks the start of two extraordinary feasts of chamber music in the Berkshire foothills - Music Mountain in Falls Village and Yale in Norfolk - and those events are surrounded by other festival openings in Hartford, Westport, New Haven and Stamford.

title: PUNJAB VIOLENCE EBBS, BUT 6 MORE DIE
description: Six people were killed in continued violence in Punjab, according to reports here today, but the day was one of the least violent in the state in the last four months.

title: SPONTANEOUS PLEASURES
description: James Carroll's most recent novel is ''Family Trade.'' His next novel, ''Prince of Peace,'' will be published in the fall. GOOD MORNING, MERRY SUNSHINE

description: Years ago, when a family found that

title: AN AVANT-GARDIST TAKES ON A STAID ITALIAN FESTIVAL
description: ''My idea was to turn all of Florence into a musical composition,'' Luciano Berio was saying. ''I wanted choral groups, instruments and ensembles to merge into a celebration of our beautiful city. Let all the church bells blend together; let the people take to the streets and make music. If you don't play an instrument, raise your voice and sing. But participate!''

title: THE CONTROVERSIAL FATHER GREELEY
description: The conflicting reactions to Andrew Greeley's novels - ''He doesn't know anything about sex'' ''How does he know so much about sex?'' - remind me of an incident when I was teaching a course called ''Novels Into Films.''

description: After all the hubub, hearsay and rumors, the National Hockey League entry draft went off today with little fanfare.

title: Miss Foster Has Nuptials
description: At St. James Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Sabele Foster was married to Richard E. Gray by the Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Esty Foster of Manhattan and St. Huberts, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Robert Gray of Philadelphia and the late Faith S. Gray.

title: Day of Infamy, Decades of Doubt
description: I support Telford Taylor's view of President Roosevelt's and General Marshall's behavior just before the attack on Pearl Harbor (''Day of Infamy, Decades of Doubt,'' April 29.) Although John Toland, in ''Day of Infamy,'' claimed that reports of the impending attack did reach our leaders in time, he glossed over the fact that reports of strikes against other targets were also being received.

title: KILLER BICYCLES
description: The other day, I came within an inch of being killed by a bicycle. This happens periodically in New York. It is the one menace of New York that nobody ever warns you against, yet it is by far the most common of the city's perils.

title: HOW'S THE BEEF?
description: HUMAN carnivores share a singular trait--their capacity to exempt from their enjoyment of meat everything they know about its source. Lend a copy of Upton Sinclair's novel ''The Jungle''--with its stomach-turning descriptions of the Chicago stockyards at the turn of the century--to a carnivore, and you may witness the fellow turning the pages in slack-jawed disgust. But soon you will encounter this same chap returning from the butcher, ravenous with anticipation, a trussed roll of pink flesh under his arm.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE state's junior United States Senator, Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of Montclair, is giving his Washington colleagues a good image - or, rather, images - of New Jersey. He's put the works of 14 New Jersey artists on display in his office.

title: AID TO RETARDED FACING A DISPUTE
description: A growing national debate over the philosophy underlying Federal aid for the mentally retarded and the developmentally disabled has led to a dispute among state executives, local administrators and experts in the field.

description: Federal officials are seeking to determine whether two Vermont concerns illegally exported advanced weapons technology to China.

description: Once upon a time, the Yankees had a good young pitcher, a left-hander - what was his name? You know, the one who pitched the no-hitter on July 4. Dave Righetti. That's him. Whatever happened to him?

title: BECK'S LEAD FALLS TO 1 ON A 70
description: The two-shot lead Chip Beck held after the first and second rounds of the 18th annual Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic was shaved to just one stroke in today's third round. But the 27-year-old North Carolinian said he felt fortunate to lead by any margin after shooting one-under-par 70 for a 54-hole total of 202.

title: Service on New Haven Line Disrupted by Electrical Fire
description: Hundreds of passengers on the New Haven Line of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad were delayed for up to three hours yesterday by a transformer fire in the system's main generating plant at Cos Cob, Conn.

title: ROYBAL DIGS IN HIS HEELS ON IMMIGRATION
description: Representative Edward R. Roybal remembers the incident clearly, and painfully. A fellow Congressman approached him several years ago and said to the California Democrat: ''I didn't know you were a Mexican. I thought all Mexicans were short and fat and wore mustaches.''

title: COMPUTER-TAMPERING BILL PASSES IN ALBANY

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: -licensed summer camps in Connecticut this year, according to Alan Buzzetti , supervisor of the recreational health and safety program in the State Department of Health Services.

title: AS A RATING, PG SAYS LESS THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: Steven Spielberg is up to his old tricks. Those distant popping sounds you hear this morning are not premature firecrackers but Mr. Spielberg as he shoots holes in the movie industry's PG (''parental guidance suggested'') rating. Mr. Spielberg may or may not make a couple of new fortunes this season - he probably will - but, as the director of ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' and as the executive producer of ''Gremlins,'' he is vividly demonstrating the inadequacy of the PG tag as it's now being used.

title: Striking Coal Miners March in Edinburgh
description: Tens of thousands of striking coal miners and their families marched through Edinburgh today, bringing the center of the Scottish capital to a standstill.

title: Amy Stover Becomes Bride
description: Amy Nelson Stover, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Stover of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Lucio Garofalo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Garofalo of Milan, Italy. The Rev. Carl Reimers, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Coventry Farm in Princeton.

title: Jail for Unpaid Power Bill
description: The City Council has approved a new ordinance providing a jail term and a $500 fine for willfully failing to pay a bill from Monmouth's city-owned electric utility. Community service work can be required instead of a jail term. City Manager Stan Kenyon said Wednesday that the ordinance was aimed mainly at helping landlords whose tenants move out without paying their Monmouth Power bills.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COINS AS REFLECTIONS OF HISTORY
description: NEWARK '' COINS can record the rise and fall of kingdoms and of states, and the reigns of kings and queens,'' wrote the numismatist A. H. Quiggen in ''The Story of Money.''

title: Mayor of Providence May Be Ruled Off Ballot
description: Former Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., who resigned in April after pleading no contest to assault charges, has won the right to run in the special election July 17, called to fill the office.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COUNTRY FURNITURE IN LITCHFIELD
description: TWO HUNDRED antiques dealers from nine Eastern states will be in line early next Saturday morning to register as exhibitors in the annual Litchfield Flea Market. The Litchfield show is held each summer on the White Memorial Grounds, just west of the town center on Route 202.

title: ABORTION OPPONENTS SEE REAGAN AS 'CLEAR-CUT' CHOICE IN CAMPAIGN
description: In a three-day convention, the National Right to Life Committee has affirmed its dedication to seeking President Reagan's re-election as a means of achieving its goal of banning abortion.

title: A RICH MIXTURE OF METAPHORS
description: IT'S HARD TO IMAGINE JACQUELINE Onassis and Lee Radziwill sharing what was then a tiny second bedroom when they were little girls,'' says the interior designer Kevin Walz, describing a two- bedroom apartment that once belonged to their father, John (Blackjack) Bouvier. Although the apartment has seen a succession of different owners over the years, the basic floor plan has never changed. ''It was a series of small, dark rooms entered through arched doorways,'' Walz recalls.

title: PERONE JOINS RACE FOR PISANI'S SEAT
description: ASSEMBLYMAN John M. Perone, Republican of Mamaroneck, made it official last week, just as the Democratic Mayor Suzi Oppenheimer of Mamaroneck, had two weeks earlier. He declared that he was seeking to replace State Senator Joseph R. Pisani in Albany.

title: Architecture
description: There is no period in the history of the skyscraper more beloved, it would seem, than the decades between World War I and World War II - the years that brought us the Chrysler Building, the Empire State, the jazzy tower of 70 Pine Street, and Rockefeller Center. The 1920's were the great years of the New York skyscraper, the years when the theatricality and flamboyance that are characteristic of the city held sway over the national architectural imagination and masterworks resulted.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICES Broadcast TV
description: On his 40th birthday, in December 1913, Ford Madox Ford decided to ''show what I can do'' and began to write ''The Good Soldier.'' The novel was beautifully adapted for Granada TV by Julian Mitchell, and the Masterpiece Theater presentation will be rebroadcast on Channel 13 on Wednesday at 9 P.M.

title:
GARDENING;
THIS IS THE MONTH FOR ROSES
description: JUNE is a glorious month in the garden. The weather is more often than not ideal, not too hot or too cold, and one is less apt to be caught by an unexpected shower.

description: ''THE accountant says, 'You'll take a loss for a couple of years,' and I say, 'No, I'm profitable now.' ''

description: Nancy Verga Conroy, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph B. Eastman and the late John L. Conroy of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Barclay Thorndike Leib, a son of Joan Coffin Whiteman and Gordon B. Leib, both of New York. The Rev. Frank McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton (N.J.) University Chapel, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Cogan, an Episcopal priest.

title: Sports of The Times ; Stephens and Pincay Make It 3 for 2 at the Belmont
description: WHEN he walked down the steps into the Belmont press box in his blue blazer, Woody Stephens had a half-empty glass of champagne in his left hand. But he should have had a waiter alongside him with a tray with two other glasses on it. Woody Stephens deserved three glasses of champagne yesterday and so did the jockey Laffit Pincay Jr.

description: Morris B. Abram is vice chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.
