title: BEIRUT IN U.N. PLEA ON ISRAEL PULLOUT
description: The Government today requested the help of the United Nations in effecting a withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and offered security guarantees for Israel's northern border.

title: Lisa Warren Wed To B. A. Johnson
description: Lisa Douglas Warren, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Y. Warren 3d of Suffield, Conn., was married in Greenville, Del., yesterday to Bruce Alan Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Johnson of Winter Garden, Fla. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: The Basis of Arab-Jewish Conflict
description: To the Editor:By his own hand, John C. Campbell disqualified himself as a reviewer of historical works when he concluded his critical evaluation of Joan Peters's ''From Time Immemorial: The Origins of the Arab-Jewish Conflict Over Palestine'' (May 13) with an expression of regret that ''a book with such scholarly pretensions, and with much real scholarship, will contribute nothing'' to the ''settlement of the Arab-Israeli problem by negotiation and conciliation.''

title: Rate of Killing of Polar Bears In Alaska Disturbs Officials
description: Alaska natives have killed about 270 polar bears this year, far ahead of the rate for the past two years, and officials are worried that the trend could threaten the bear population.

title: Barbaro to Return The Generals removed one of their more valuable performers,
description: Gary Barbaro , from the injured-reserve list yesterday and are expected to place him on the active roster before today's game against the New Orleans Breakers at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Barbaro technically was placed on the five-member developmental squad and thus ineligible to play in a game.

title: Rebels in Mozambique Said to Kill 10 on Bus
description: Rebels in Mozambique killed 10 people and wounded 19 when they fired on a civilian bus near the border with Swaziland Wednesday, the official Mozambique News Agency reported today.

title: CITY BALLET: DREAMS
description: The New York City Ballet danced its way through two choreographic dreams on Friday night in the New York State Theater.

title: COLLEGES TRY TO DEFINE OUT-OF-STATE ALLURE
description: FOR Jennifer McShane of New Haven, the combined lure of New York City and the Ivy League are drawing her to Barnard College. Matthew Newman of Trumbull is going to Boston University because its programs are diverse, and it is in Boston. Karen Sveda of Milford likes Rhode Island. Bryant College in Smithfield, R.I., has a high-quality business program, and so that is where she is going.

title: THE MAGIC BRICK OF BEREK SPIEGELGLASS
description: Richard Plant is writing a book on the Holocaust. THE FOREVER STREET

title: 13 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 13 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: WILL A SUBWAY DIG BUFFALO OUT?
description: As the gleaming trolley-like cars trundled through trial runs along the first segments of Buffalo's new mass transit line last week, leaders of New York's second largest city may have been holding their breath. The line was supposed to carry this troubled city toward an economic revival. So far, it's been a bumpy ride, but there are signs that better days may lie ahead.

title: PRIORITY WILL GO TO FIGHT ON INFLATION AND AID TO THIRD WORLD
description: The seven leaders at the economic summit talks pledged today to make the fight against inflation a central objective in the year ahead, saying that rising prices threatened the upswing that is under way in all their countries.

title: Helen Miller, Teacher Weds James M. Birch
description: Helen Holmes Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Miller of Round Hill, Va., was married yesterday to James Michael Birch, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander A. Birch Jr. of Corvallis, Ore. The ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, Va., was performed by the Rev. Richard Peard, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Egan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE CONTROVERSIAL FATHER GREELEY
description: I liked Father Greeley's reference to God's mind as His/Her mind.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Film
description: Beginning Thursday night, you might want to reserve all succeeding Thursday nights through Aug. 30 for the Thalia Theater's 90th anniversary retrospective devoted to the films of the great Jean Renoir. The humane artistry of Renoir, who was born in 1894 and died in 1979, will be defined by 26 films, including such silent classics as ''Nana'' and ''The Little Match Girl,'' his two great ''between wars'' films, ''Grand Illusion'' (1937) and ''Rules of the Game'' (1939), films from his Hollywood exile, ''Swamp Water'' (1941) and ''Woman on the Beach (1946), and at least two of his color masterpieces, ''The River'' (1951) and ''The Golden Coach'' (1952) with Anna Magnani.

title: FINALLY, TEXAS IS PAYING ATTENTION TO ITS GRADE SCHOOLS
description: The University of Texas is spending millions to make itself into one of the country's finer centers of higher learning, creating endowed chairs by the dozen and buying leading scholars. Yet when it comes to its children, Texas puts a smaller percentage of its wealth into primary and secondary schools than any other state except Nevada. Its schools are, by most standard indices, woefully inferior. Nearly one third of those who attend never graduate from high school; only seven other states do worse.

title: Davidson Geoghegan Weds Susan B. Shane
description: Susan Brooks Shane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lawrence Shane of Swarthmore, Pa., was married yesterday to Davidson Geoghegan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Geoghegan of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the Swarthmore Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Emily B. Geoghegan, the bridegroom's cousin.

title: AT RADIO FREE EUROPE, A FEW CHANGES OF PACE
description: After years of retrenchment and self-effacement, which followed the disclosure in the early 1970's of Central Intelligence Agency financing, Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty are being strengthened and expanded by the Reagan Administration.

title: A CHEESE LOVER'S TOUR OF FRANCE
description: PATRICIA WELLS, restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune, is the author of ''The Food Lover's Guide to Paris'' (Workman).

title: High School Chorale
description: The Nightingale-Bamford Chorale, which has won awards in the United States and Europe, will appear in concert tomorrow night at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. The appearance by the group, from the private girls school in Manhattan, will mark the first high school chorus to appear in concert at the hall. The chorale will present four new works created especially for the group, and will also feature choral numbers by, among others, J. S. Bach and Leonard Bernstein.

title: SOME OLD AND NEW WAYS TO USE FRESH LOCAL STRAWBERRIES
description: STRAWBERRY season is upon us. Baskets of ripe berries not only are arriving from California but also are available in markets and at stands from farms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Bolivia Seeks Diaries
description: The Bolivian Government has won a temporary injunction against the sale of the diaries of the late Cuban guerrilla Ernesto (Che) Guevara, arguing that the diaries are Bolivian property, The Times of London said Saturday. The newspaper said Bolivia won the injunction Friday, preventing Sotheby's auctioneers from selling the papers, which Bolivia said were found on Guevara and his men and taken by the Government.

title: WHEN A GAMBIT IS SPECULATIVE
description: Facing a speculative gambit is like coming under the influence of a good ghost story alone in the house late at night. A search through the rooms reveals nothing out of place, but after it is ascertained that the closets house only their natural disorder and that the space under the bed is indeed just that, there is still the feeling that right nearby there really is something to fear.

title: 30 REBEL LEADERS SEIZED IN NAMIBIA
description: Armed security police in South-West Africa detained 30 prominent leaders and supporters today of the internal wing of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization, which is battling South Africa's control of the territory.

title: Janet George Weds Edwin Fell, Submarine Officer
description: Janet Mildreth George, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Denison George of Mount Sinai, L.I., was married yesterday to Lieut. Edwin Mark Fell, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin R. Fell of Port Jefferson, L.I. The Rev. Ronald Patterson performed the ceremony at the Mount Sinai Congregational Church.

title: MONDALE GETS THE NUMBERS AND HART GETS A WARNING
description: A LL year, Democrats have been fretting about disunity. Last week, the party leaders came together behind Walter F. Mondale with a speed that seemed startling in contrast to the grinding ordeal of the Presidential primary campaign. With a degree of unanimity not evident for months, the leadership joined together to give Gary Hart a tour of the political graveyard reserved for defeated candidates who refuse to line up behind the victorious nominee.

title: LESSONS OF DEBT
description: The world's industrial giants agree that the most immediate threat to everybody's economy is the huge third-world debt.

title: Swazi Queen Replaces Four Top Officials
description: Queen Regent Ntombi dismissed four top officials of her Government on Friday as an investigation continued into a customs fraud case said to involve $10.4 million in this mountain kingdom on the eastern border of South Africa.

title: L.I. POTATO FARMERS MEETING CHALLENGES
description: THE rainy spring, dwindling acreage and tighter competition have been challenging the Long Island potato farmer this year. But one further obstacle may have been cleared when an 11th-hour solution appeared last week to a problem that has been plaguing him - some say bugging him - since the 1979 withdrawal of the pesticide Temik, his most effective weapon in the war against the Colorado potato beetle.

title: POCONO RAILROAD PLAN APPEARS DOOMED
description: -YEAR effort to resurrect railroad passenger service between the New York metropolitan area and the Poconos collapsed last week, when an Ohio investment concern failed to meet a deadline for depositing $2 million.

title: SHERIFF WITH STORMY RECORD RUNS FOR HOUSE
description: A sheriff who once chained his inmates to state property and was twice arrested in clashes with other officials is promising to shake things up if he wins a Democratic runoff Tuesday and goes on to win a seat in Congress.

title: MEPHAM WINS RELAY
description: Chris Curtin, who survived a fall in the 3,000-meter run Friday night to win her third straight New York State interscholastic title in the event, closed out her high school career today by anchoring the Mepham (L.I.) High School 3,200-meter relay to a meet-record victory.

title:
FASHION;
TWO DESIGNERS ON THE MOVE
description: CLAUDE MONTANA BECAME A noteworthy Paris fashion force less than a decade ago. One of his first major collections - with Amazonian models in wide-shouldered, black-leather, ankle-length coats, their heads swathed in black leather helmets, moving to the sound of howling dogs and snapping chains - is still talked about. That collection defined the Montana woman: Valkyrie, not Earth Mother. There were always superb clothes in these collections, but they often were submerged by the show's theatrics. With his ready-to-wear collection for this fall, however, Montana stripped away much of the flamboyant showmanship, letting the good designs speak for themselves. The black-leather opening was gone. Instead, 15 models appeared in malachite and amethyst leathers, cashmeres, coats, jumpsuits, even a reversible satin trenchcoat in this sophisticated color mix. There was a new mood at Montana. From that sophisticated opening, he moved quickly into a luxurious sportswear group in butter-pecan whipcord, flannel and cashmere for ankle- length coats, oversize sweaters and pleated pants that flopped on the shoes. Then, that nonchalant glamour dissolved to a prim and proper nanny look in navy gabardine; staged a comeback in a group of jewel bright jackets and toppers, and took over the stage in the satin collared, paisley printed, long velvet evening coats, worn over silk men's-wear pajamas that have already inspired several American designers, whose fall collections offer variations of this theme. As with many young designers, Montana had trouble finding the right backers at first. Now, however, he says that that problem has been resolved.

title: VAGUE FRUSTRATIONS OF A RETAILING CAREER
description: THOMAS M. Macioce, head of

title: YUPPIES AT HOME- A HI-FI HABITAT
description: Dreaming up new academic disciplines is an old trick practiced by professors who like to put together some special little niche for themselves. Along these lines we have lately had sociobiology, psychohistory, microclimatology, and several lively specialties concerned with death and dying. But it remained for William Livingstone, a nonacademic type, to come up with the latest branch of social science: the sociology of audio. In the current issue of Stereo Review, a respected journal edited by Mr. Livingstone, he explores various aspects of audio in relation to Yuppies.

title: PROTEST OF TURKISH PRISON CONDITIONS GOES ON
description: When she was 20 years old, Nigar Gulsat Aygen was a medical student and an active member of the Turkish Folklore Association.

title: TRENTON DEBATES FURTURE OF MILL HILL
description: IF anyone even whispered that seven historic 1870's row houses, each with $15,000

title: BALLETIC TRADITION IS ALWAYS IN DANGER
description: A production by American Ballet Theater has just caused a fuss. Many people have clucked over it and at least one retired dancer has complained, ''It's all wrong.'' What caused the hubbub was no wild new post-modernist experiment, but an old favorite, ''Les Sylphides,'' choreographed by Michel Fokine.

title: How to Give Airlines the Gate
description: Imagine that Apocryphal Airlines is eager to start 6 P.M. service to Duluth from Washington's congested National Airport, but discovers there are no takeoff ''slots'' available at rush hour. To get one, Apocryphal would have to persuade a committee of airline representatives, or a Government appeals committee, that it is more deserving than some carrier already flying at that hour. But under a plan now proposed by the Department of Transportation, it could

title: U.S. MOVES TO BAR AIR CLUB'S CHARTER FLIGHTS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board has taken court action to bar further charter flights by the air travel club that leased jets to Gary Hart's Presidential campaign.

title: 'SUGAR' BY-THE-SEA: HOW SWEET IT IS
description: -73 season, the musical ''Sugar'' was no big deal, but at the Claridge Hotel- Casino here, it most winningly is.

title: 14-YEAR-OLD IS A STAR OF THE NURSING HOMES
description: -year-old Bret Flood of Rye loves music. Eventually, he'd like to form his own band, but for now he performs alone at bookings throughout the county and in nearby Greenwich, Conn. And when he does, members of the opposite sex often gush with adulation, their hearts beating a little faster. Generally, they'll decide to sing along, because, of course, they know all the numbers: ''The Bowery,'' ''Moonlight Bay,'' ''Shuffle Off to Buffalo,'' ''East Side, West Side,'' and, his biggest hit, ''God Bless America.''

title: No Headline
description: For Bront"e Fans

title: SOMETHING ABOUT 'STAR TREK' TALKS TO EVERYMAN
description: ''Star Trek'' lives, refusing to fade away or to go wherever it is that old television series are interred. It was born on Sept. 8, 1966, and seemed to die, 78 one-hour episodes later, on Sept. 2, 1969. Its audience apparently was in decline, with teen-agers and small children making up a disproportionate number of viewers, and hope of an afterlife was slim. In fact, ''Star Trek'' has been reborn any number of times since then - in syndicated re-runs, as an animated cartoon, in three feature-length movies, and in the hearts and minds of ''trekkies'' everywhere. ''Star Trek'' was, and still is, a notable piece of television programming, and even now in midnight re-runs on WPIX/ Channel 11 it is as captivating as it was in prime time on NBC.

title: OUT OF CONTROL
description: Joe McGinniss's latest book is ''Fatal Vision.'' He is currently at work on ''The Forbidden City,'' a book about life at Los Alamos during the building of the first atomic bombs. WIRED

title: CABLE TELEVISION A POLITICAL BOON TO CONGRESSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: BOXING FOR THE BIG TIME
description: FORT WORTH WHILE Mark Breland rehearses for the Olympics and the end of his boxing apprenticeship, all around him preparations continue for his professional debut as if he were a new act planning his first concert tour. Shelly Finkel, who is a promoter of rock concerts and Breland's adviser, is plotting a course that he hopes will make Breland boxing's hottest attraction, and eventually, as financially secure as Sugar Ray Leonard.

title: THE NIGHTMARE OF SLEEP DISORDERS
description: ONE night eight years ago, Bruce Lawrence of Newtown awoke screaming and choking. It was not until minutes later that he realized he had run to the bathroom, clutching at his throat, gasping for air. The scene repeated itself every six months or so until two years ago, when he awoke screaming once every third night. Eighteen months ago, it escalated to three times nightly.

title: MERCER PUPILS GET FISTHAND ANSWERS
description: -grade pupils recently crowded into a small room at the Melvin H. Kreps School here and waited as their teacher made a conference call on the telephone.

title: CURRICULUM SHIFT ON SEX EDUCATION
description: An updated sex-education curriculum that deals with such issues as the rise in teen-age pregnancies and cohabitation outside marriage has been changed to meet the objections of some religious leaders, according to New York City school officials.

title: Highlights
description: At the Talks

title: Detroit Inquiry Is Dropped
description: Federal officials say they have dropped an investigation into possible thefts of surplus Government food earmarked for Detroit's needy after deciding the inquiry would lead nowhere. The inquiry began after Mayor Coleman Young said in March that an audit showed 194 tons of Federal surplus food had spoiled in city warehouses and officials could not account for an additional 79 tons of food. Richard Allen of the Department of Agriculture's Regional Office of Inspector General in Chicago said Tuesday, ''There were just too many holes to tie down.''

title: EARLY GRAVESTONES FOCUS OF CONFERENCE
description: THE Association for Gravestone Studies has chosen Connecticut as the site of its annual national conference this month, two months after the Connecticut General Assembly passed legislation recognizing the importance of grave markers as an early American art form.

title: The Physics Of Basketball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Patton's Town Remembers End of a War
description: While attention this 40th anniversary year has been focused on the D-day beaches of Normandy, there are other places in in Europe where the wartime sacrifices of Americans are remembered. One of them is the market town of Ettelbruck in Luxembourg, where each summer the strains of ''The Star- Spangled Banner'' and the drone and roar of jet fighters in a low flyover are heard during a ceremony of commemoration. Thousands of spectators and such officials as the United States Ambassador, Crown Prince Henri of Luxembourg, Luxembourg's Minister of Defense, the Mayor of Ettelbruck and high- ranking military officials of the two countries gather beneath weeping willows and among monuments for an occasion called Remembrance Day, originated by the citizens of Ettelbruck at the end of World War II.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVALS EXPAND
description: IF Theodora Bookman, director

title: DANCE: MIXED-MEDIA PERFORMANCE
description: The Guggenheim Museum is one of the most uncomfortable and difficult places for watching performances in the city, and it is also one of the most difficult in which to stage performances. Meredith Monk used its high, spiraling ramp effectively, but few have since. And ''Skydance/Skytime,'' a somewhat dated-looking mixed-media work presented at the museum on Friday, was no exception. A hodge-podge of music, balloon sculptures, dance and film, ''Skydance/Skytime'' originated in the concept of the sky as the origin and continuum of time in the human experience, according to advance information. It had the brave, irrelevant air of throwing peas up Everest.

title: ; PARTIES ARE UNFIT TO SPONSOR TV DEBATES
description: To the Editor:

title: A FOCUS ON U.S.
description: This was to be the harmonious summit conference saluting recovery of the world economy, with assurances of more to come. And by the time Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, the host, delivered the final communique from the cavernous chambers of the medieval Guildhall today, the harmony survived. But in economic matters, unlike the political issues that came to dominate the dialogue, the harmony was superficial. After three years of trying, six of the countries here succeeded in making the economic policies of the seventh, the United States, an important issue of their deliberations.

title: WINFIELD AND KEMP PACE YANKS AGAIN
description: Steve Kemp was in the on-deck circle in the ninth inning last night, with Dave Winfield at the plate, when a fan in the stands made a prediction. ''He shouted, 'Just like Friday night,' '' Kemp said, ''and I said to myself, 'Oh, sure.' ''

title: Piggott Wins the Oaks Aboard Circus Plume EPSOM, England, June 9 (AP) - Lester Piggott rode Circus Plume to victory over the mile-and-one-half Epsom course today in the 206th Oaks Stakes for 3-year-old fillies.
description: Media Luna, ridden by Paul Cook, finished second. Steve Cauthen was aboard Poquito Queen, who was placed third after a stewards' inquiry disqualified Out of Shot.

title: U.S. EXCLUDES REPORTER IN FAVOR OF RE-ELECTION CAMERAMAN
description: The White House today excluded an American reporter scheduled to cover the last session of the economic summit conference to make room for a cameraman hired to film commercials for President Reagan's re-election campaign.

title: Mitchell N. Schear Marries Amy Schultz in Scarsdale
description: Amy Isabel Schultz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Mitchell N. Schear, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Schear, also of Scarsdale. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

title: FRIENDLY TOWNS KEY TO FRESH AIR FUND
description: On a quiet August evening in 1884, 40 girls and boys in horse-drawn wagons rode slowly up a hill into Orwell, Pa. Townspeople swarmed around to welcome them as they sang and cheered, and a reporter described the scene:

title: 'COTTON CLUB' INVESTOR SUES PARTNERS IN FILM
description: Charging fraud and breach of contract, Victor L. Sayyah, one of the investors in the expensive and storm-tossed motion picture ''Cotton Club,'' has filed suit against his partners and Orion Pictures Corporation, the movie's American distributor.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE GARRETT COLLECTION SALE
description: The famous Garrett Collection continues to hold singular allure for numismatists. The latest public auction of coins from that collection had lively bidding. Lofty prices were the rule as a three-part sale of foreign and ancient Garrett coins opened last month in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Headliners
description: Resurrecting a Wright The works of great architects often have eternal qualities, but seldom are they literally reborn. David T. Henken hopes that will be the case with a dismantled Frank Lloyd Wright-designed house that he has stored in his Westchester County basement for 30 years.

title: Q & A ; FROM ROOMMATE TO LESSEE
description: I have been a tenant in a rent-stabilized building for five years. During this time I have had a roommate who has neither signed onto my lease nor paid any rent directly to the landlord. I am considering buying a co-op apartment elsewhere and would like to help make my roommate the lessee for our apartment. What are my rights? . . . J. G. V., Manhattan.

title: THE CRAZY DEMOCRATS
description: Just when most observers here thought things couldn't possibly get worse for the Democratic Party, Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson proved they could. The state primary elections brought out not the best but the worst side of Messrs. Mondale, Hart and Jackson, and now the question is whether the Democrats can control the damage.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GETTING THE BEST DEAL FOR YOUR DOLLAR
description: Travelers to Spain do it, to Bahrain do it; people barging on the Seine do it - they all foreign-exchange. The question is when to exchange American dollars for foreign currencies, where to exchange, how much and into what: United States traveler's checks, foreign currency, foreign traveler's checks?

title: THE HARVEST FOR REAGAN
description: For President Reagan, the London economic summit conference marked the culmination of a 10-day European trip that White House strategists count as one of their most successful efforts to project Mr. Reagan's strengths as a leader. It also brought support for his Administration's approach to the Soviet Union, though something less than the full vindication he had sought for his economic policies.

title: CROP LOSSES ARE HIGH AFTER DELUGE
description: AS floodwaters from heavy rains receded last week, farmers throughout the state looked at their fields and tried to assess their losses.

title: NICARAGUANS ARE REVIVING A DYING LAKE
description: This sweltering capital city sits on the shore of a giant lake, but nobody swims or fishes there, no one basks on its shores, and none of its water can be used for drinking, irrigation or any other productive purpose.

title: ACCIDENTS STIR DEBATE ON ULTRALIGHT AIRCRAFT
description: On a calm, clear day last June, a 14-year-old boy took to the sky in Sumner, Wash., in a tiny 30-horsepower airplane. It was his first solo flight.

title: HOW BASICS WON A WINGED FOOT OPEN
description: ONE thing that playing a United States Open at Winged Foot does for a professional golfer is get you back to basics. You know, keep your head down, swing smooth and follow through. Every golfer, from the leading money winner on the PGA Tour to a once-a-week player has to remember those things. But at no place is that more important than at Winged Foot when it's set up for the Open.

title: QUEEN GIVES A BANQUET FOR VISITING DIGNITARIES
description: With the economic summit talks behind them, the visiting dignitaries gathered tonight in the splendor of Queen Elizabeth II's State Dining Room for a farewell banquet.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HOBOKEN'S longshoremen have won a reprieve that will let them, at least for the time being, continue using the top floor of City Hall for their morning ''shape.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FOR those people dissatisfied with Federal and state programs to clean up hazardous- waste dump sites, the Washington-based Environmental Defense Fund has produced a detailed 183- page guide designed to getting the job done.

title: THE BOOM IN SHORT STORIES
description: LATELY I've been reading a lot of short stories. You probably have too. Time was, people read novels. Even in the 1920's and 30's, occasionally referred to as the golden age of the American short story, the big statement was always found in the novel. By the 50's, readers' appetites - and writers' ambitions - had grown to Maileresque proportions. And in recent decades, the Great American Novel began to go to extremes. William Gaddis's ''Recognitions,'' Thomas Pynchon's ''V'' and Mailer's ''Ancient Evenings'' all seemed to say that a novelist's ability to go the distance - over ever greater distances - counted as much as the various talents and abilities displayed along the way.

title: VACUUMING THE BEETLES
description: AS effective pesticides became increasingly unavailable to East End potato growers in recent years, some growers started toying with homemade concoctions of ground-up bugs and trying vacuum cleaners in an attempt to control the severe damage inflicted by the Colorado potato beetle. Their efforts proved futile until last month, when a Bridgehampton farmer, Edward Zebroski, reported that his home-designed commercial vacuum was gobbling up 70 percent of the potato beetles on his 150-acre farm.

title: OCEAN GROUP WINS FIGHT WITH NAVY
description: THE Oceanic Society in Stamford preaches caution. When it appeared to win a battle against the Navy last week, it stopped short of celebration.

title: A WRITING ODYSSEY THROUGH INDIA PAST AND PRESENT
description: THE FEELING OF quiet in Ved Mehta's apartment spurns the rush of Fifth Avenue below. The writer has created this stillness with care. The muted blues and burgundies of the sofas echo the colors in the Tabriz carpet. Books are everywhere, stacked in neat piles on tables and rising in tall bookcases. On one wall are 18th- and 19th- century miniature paintings from North Indian kingdoms, on another a Saul Steinberg drawing. A Mozart sonata lies open on the piano. Mehta's wife of six months, Linn, pours white wine. ''Temperamentally, I could just sit on the rug,'' he says in his soft voice. ''The rest is just compensation for things I missed out on as a child.''

title: Bell Sets U.S. Mark in Vault
description: In the last decade, whenever he was healthy, Earl Bell has been one of the world's leading pole-vaulters. Today, his left leg sound again, he became the first American to vault 19 feet outdoors.

title: DROP IN TEMIK LEVEL DEBATED

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISS WRUBLE AT TULLY HALL
description: Roxanne Wruble's piano recital - no, pianissimo recital - at Tully Hall Thursday reached its gentle crest in a pair of nocturnes by John Field, that dreamy precursor of Chopin. Gracefully phrased and tastefully graced, they brought out an aspect of Miss Wruble's playing that one would like to hear again.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Workshoes, Boots And Cream Puffs Knapp Shoes, begun 70 years ago with door-to-door sales of its own footwear, has come to be a nationally known label with 80 retail outlets. The manufacturer sells its own dress and casual shoes, Western boots, workshoes and workboots, high rubber boots for fishermen or firemen and red-soled rubbers for wear at construction sites. It also has authorized steel-toe safety shoes and boots for men and women. The company- owned Yonkers shop on Central Avenue just below the Cross County Center opened 21 years ago and a franchised shop is in Bedford Hills - the prices are the same.

title: 'Irreversible Coma' Reported For Italy's Communist Chief
description: The condition of the Communist Party leader, Enrico Berlinguer, who had a cerebral hemorrhage on Thursday, worsened today and doctors gave him no chance of recovery.

title: EARLY LANFORD WILSON, WITH A TOUCH OF TODAY

title: Frenchman Out of Race
description: Patrick Morvan, a 39-year-old French solo sailor who had been leading the 3,000-mile Observer/Europe I single-handed trans-Atlantic race, was rescued by a British cargo vessel early today after his 60-foot catamaran began sinking. Race officials here said that Morvan sent a distress signal at 7:10 A.M., saying that his twin-hulled Jet Services had hit what appeared to be a submerged piece of wood.

title: FASHION   TWO DESIGNERS ON THE MOVE
description: FOR THE FIRST TIME, THE FASHION establishment seems to have boarded the Jean Paul Gaultier bandwagon. This September, for example, Bergdorf Goodman will present the 32-year-old Paris designer's first major show in New York. Since l977, when he began designing on his own, Gaultier has demonstrated a talent for combining the classic and the eccentric in an amusing way. He also has been able to make new clothes look like old ones. ''I'm much more in tune with the London street scene than Paris,'' he says. ''Here the streets are no longer fashionable. In London, I always see a mix of the classic and the eccentric. I am much more inclined to eccentric. In Paris, French designers are concerned about 'chic.' They have the 1950's idea of 'chic is everything.' '' This is certainly the last thing Gaultier would ever be accused of. He is particularly fond of the current androgyny mood. For his fall show, he presented male and female models wearing variations of the same clothes. In fact, when he opens his own Paris boutique in January, he will mix men's and women's clothes together. ''I won't label them. I won't separate them,'' says Gaultier. ''Certainly, there are women who buy only men's shirts. There are men who may buy women's jackets because they like the fabric. There won't be any problem with sizes, because everything is already oversize.'' Not only is he an astute interpreter of the street scene, but, Gaultier says, ''I'm always studying people.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SEAN O'CASEY: Autobiographies, I and II. (Carroll & Graf, $10.95 each.) This monumental work, published in six parts between 1939 and 1954, is available for the first time in paperback and handily bound in two volumes. The Dublin-born playwright's re-creation of his long and combative life is one of the recognized masterpieces of our time. It was thus acknowledged even before Brooks Atkinson's rave review of the final volume, ''Sunset.'' Declaring that Sean O'Casey in his 70's was still ''thoroughly alive,'' The Times's veteran drama critic drew attention to the book's ''eloquence, passion, bitterness and force.'' O'Casey, who is best remembered for his antiheroic and antiwar plays of the 1920's (''Juno and the Paycock,'' ''The Silver Tassie''), was a militant patriot in private life, fiercely independent even as he was drawn to the utopian aspects of Communism in the 1930's. Unpopular with the Abbey Theater and eventually even with Yeats, he left Ireland in the early 30's for England, where he produced many more poignant and ironic plays while transcribing his life into this novel-like work. Also available in cloth, $21.95 each.

title: FUGARD TRACES A DARK PARALLEL ON FILM

For in ''The Guest'' - the first of two films by Mr. Fugard, best-known as a dramatist, to be shown this month at Film Forum - the lines virtually vanish between performance and autobiography, imagination and self-revelation.

The 39 women on the new Advisory Board range from the community affairs director of a major corporation to a woman who describes herself as ''a lady of leisure''; from the head of the Gray Panthers to the head of the White Plains Conservative Party.

title: HARD YEARS AND 'SCARY DAYS': REMEMBERING JEAN STAFFORD
description: JEAN STAFFORD'S first published novel was, of course, ''Boston Adventure.'' In Princeton, on April 30, 1942, she signed the contract at Allen Tate's house where she, her husband Robert Lowell and I had stopped on our way to hear a lecture by Randall Jarrell. I was at the time an editor with Harcourt, Brace, and when Caroline Gordon (Mrs. Tate) learned that I had brought Jean's contract with me she made a ceremony of the signing with lighted candles on either side of the desk. A few weeks later I went into the Navy; the novel appeared in 1944 to an excellent press. Yet never in all the years of our friendship - I saw Jean at the hospital the day before her death in 1979 - did she even hint at something I've just discovered: She had written two novels prior to ''Boston Adventure.'' The first remained unfinished, because a publisher was afraid of a libel suit, and Jean abandoned it; she completed the second, for which she had a contract, and it was rejected. All this happened before her marriage to Lowell. It's perfectly understandable that Jean would not have talked about these early unsuccessful efforts while ''Boston Adventure'' was in the process of being published, but I'm surprised she never mentioned them later, since she enjoyed telling stories about her younger years.

title: CHACO: ECHOES OF THE ANCIENT STRANGERS
description: Looked upon solely and narrowly as a Southwestern canyon, Chaco is unremarkable. The Grand is infinitely deeper and grander, of course; De Chelly is more colorful by far; Walnut and Oak Creek are certainly more picture-postcard scenic. None of these, though, holds quite the power to summon up the continent's dim human past as does Chaco and its brooding stones.

title:
DINING OUT;
MEXICAN FARE IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: ALTHOUGH its menu lists 15 variations on the tortilla, Camino Real is not just another Mexican restaurant. True, it dishes up tacos, enchiladas and tamales in messy conglomerates called combination plate, but its strength lies in the welcome list of some fine Mexican and Spanish dishes unavailable elsewhere in the county. By choosing those dishes that emphasize flavor but not heat, the kitchen challenges diners who believe that only the pick of dynamite serrano or jalapeno peppers signals the presence of authentic Spanish-Mexican food.

The end of the marathon, said Walter Mondale. Mr. Mondale's figure of speech was more apt. For one thing, given his delegate total, overtime is unlikely. For another, the campaign was much more an endless race than a game. There was no halftime, no timeouts, no time for reflection - just four months of chaos.

title: STAGE: 'BROWNSTONE,' NEIGHBORS SET TO MUSIC

The show, at the Hudson Guild Theater, does not aspire to satire and it is not really about brownstoning, that city preoccupation to own a piece of one's own life. It is about five diverse people (a married couple and three singles) who happen to live in the same brownstone on a quiet musical street. In other words, the title is a canopy for the characters, loosely affiliated, as neighbors can be.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The London economic summit meeting focused, as expected, on third-world debt, with the leaders of the seven major industrialized democracies agreeing that something must be done. But in keeping with the low-key atmosphere fostered by President Reagan and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, they offered few concrete proposals, preferring instead to express support for steps being taken elsewhere. By late Friday, the participants appeared ready to urge longer repayment terms and lower interest rates, but the Americans were opposing a call for caps on rates. Implicit in the discussions was the European criticism that high American budget deficits are largely responsible for lofty interest rates. As a result, Mr. Reagan spent much of his time explaining that the situation was under control.

description: Consumers, the driving force in the economy, are starting to hit the brake on installment purchases. One reason is that consumer credit costs, which always lag several months behind an upturn in interest rates, are beginning to rise. Another reason is that the same rise in interest rates is causing consumers to save more, since they will get a higher rate of return on their C.D.'s and money market funds.

He is among six former Yankees on the Blue Jays' roster. Shane Rawley, struggling with a 6.21 e.r.a., will make his second start since being recalled from the minors. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.)

I grabbed my afghan, mug of hot cocoa and settled down on the den couch for a good night of recreational reading, faithful dog curled at my feet. Halfway into the first juicy love scene, however, an unnerving tingling began on my right arm. I ignored it. It persisted. I read on; it headed for my shoulder.

Increasing tensions, particularly between Iran and Saudi Arabia, seemed to increase the chances that the United States could be drawn directly, albeit reluctantly, into the war. Washington was already deeply involved indirectly through its military assistance to Saudi Arabia and political support for Iraq.

title: Kelly Goes for Record The locale will be appropriate as
description: Jim Kelly , the quarterback of the Gamblers, goes after a professional football passing record today in a United States Football League game against the Chicago Blitz in the Astrodome at Houston. In his first 15 games, Kelly completed 36 touchdown passes to tie the record set in 1961 by George Blanda with the Houston Oilers of the American Football League. When the Gamblers and Blitz last met on March 11, Houston won, 45-36.

title: Jaguars Returning to Le Mans

Jaguar won the 24- hour race in its first attempt in 1951, and the British company's C-type and D-type racers lost only twice in the next six races. Then, after picking up its laurels in 1957, Jaguar abandoned international endurance racing.

In his new post, with a salary of $50,000 a year, he will coordinate state services to local government officials and will be responsible for the advance work for Mr. Cuomo's trips throughout the state.

Walter Thompson Company, is going to begin test marketing Slice, a new carbonated fruit juice soft drink, next week in Rochester and in Tulsa, Okla., and within two months in four other markets. For example, on approach shots to Winged Foot's undulating and banked greens Open contestants will find it difficult to get down in two if they have not hit the green. The typically long Open rough will also be a key factor.

title: Youth Held for Using Snake to Steal Beer
description: Investigators say they have solved a robbery with the arrest of one of three teen-agers accused of stealing beer from a store clerk while brandishing a snake.

title: BILLS OFFER PROTECTION FOR CHIPS
description: The House of Representatives is expected to approve a bill Monday aimed at protecting manufacturers of semiconductor chips from piracy of their easily copied products.

title: No Headline
description: Mistaken 'Juice' Costs Elderly Woman's Life

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Honoring Clyde The plumage is a bit more subdued these days, and the closest he gets to basketball is watching a game on television, but to a generation of Knick fans, Walt Frazier is still Clyde. When the former Knick star comes to town tomorrow it will be with the promise that he will not be forgotten.

title: KUWAITI TANKER ATTACKED IN SOUTHERN PART OF GULF
description: A Kuwaiti supertanker was hit today in the lower Persian Gulf by a rocket fired from an unidentified plane, the Kuwaiti news agency reported.

title: QUEBEC PARTY, DEFYING THE POLLS, TO FIGHT ON INDEPENDENCE ISSUE
description: The stage has been set for a showdown that may set Quebec's political direction for years to come.

title: TREASURY BILL SALES SET FOR TODAY
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, where new three- and six-month issues are scheduled for sale today.

title: Robin I. Wagner Is Wed to David Dodge Osborn
description: Robin I. Wagner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Wagner of New York and Lake Worth, Fla., and David Dodge Osborn, the novelist and screenwriter, were married yesterday by Rabbi Abraham Krantz at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan.

title: OX RIDGE A TEST FOR OLYMPIC HOPEFULS
description: When Melanie Smith was a youngster growing up outside Memphis, the Ox Ridge Horse Show was an event she only read about in equestrian magazines. ''It sounded like the epitome of horse-showing in the East - all the big-time horses and riders,'' she said.

title: INTERNATIONAL REPORT ; ; Oil Rig Passes Sea Test French Design Defies Winter
description: A state- owned maritime engineering company based in this French Atlantic port has developed the first self-elevating offshore oil platforms able to work all year in stormy waters.

title: No Headline
description: Church Members Back SanctuaryforRefugees

title: Debt Issues
description: Austria is issuing $100 million of eight-year, 13 5/8 percent coupon bonds through S.G. Warburg. The bonds are not callable and are priced at par.

title: RICE BECOMES TOUCHY POLITICAL PROBLEM FOR JAPAN
description: The rice planting is over, and Shizuo Sugawara now frets over whether this year's crop will be a good one.

title: Yarborough Wins In 500-Mile Race LONG POND, Pa., June 10 (AP) - Cale Yarborough, in a Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS, beat Harry Gant's Chevrolet by 3.57 seconds today to to win the Pocono 500 stock car race.
description: Yarborough skipped a late stop for gas, gambling that his final pit stop 46 laps, or 115 miles, from the end would be sufficient.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER PRESENTS ROBBINS'S 'NOCES'
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S estimable choreographic version of Stravinsky's dance-cantata ''Noces'' has returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory and it opened the company's program Saturday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Dr. Emily Sonnenblick Weds in Darien
description: Dr. Emily Bland Sonnenblick, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Sonnenblick of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Offit, a son of Dr. Avodah K. Offit and Sidney Offit, both of New York. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony in the garden at the Sonnenblick home.

title: Tortured in Uruguay
description: Torture is the dirty little secret of modern politics, and typically, victims are punished not only for real or imagined crimes, but also because they know the secret. They die, or ''disappear,'' or languish in jail for years to prevent their bearing witness against the degrading use of technology to smash bodies and bend minds.

title: AS PORT AUTHORITY BUS TERMINAL HAS EXPANDED, SO HAS PROBLEM OF CRIME
description: At a minute after midnight the other night at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan, a Ridgewood, N.J., man was on his way home with two friends. He was mugged on an escalator.

title: MUSIC: HARMONIE WIND ENSEMBLE
description: AN unpublished woodwind transcription of two Scarlatti sonatas was found among the effects of the late composer Dmitri Shostakovich. Steven Richman, the conductor of the Harmonie Wind Ensemble, learned of the work and ''by a circuitous route,'' the press release titillatingly intimated, obtained a copy of it from Russia; he gave its United States premiere Saturday at the Merkin Hall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1984

title: RELAXED REQUIREMENTS LURE TEACHER RECRUITS
description: The air-conditioning was broken and it was hot on the mezzanine of the New York Penta Hotel yesterday afternoon, but Edward P. Aquilone was smiling. All around him were men and women braving the heat because they were interested in becoming teachers in New York City's public schools.

title: Futures/Options
description: Spread of Rule Fight Is Feared

title: SHIFT IS REPORTED ON C.I.A. ACTIONS
description: Early in his term, President Reagan abolished interdepartmental consultations for covert operations by the Central Intelligence Agency, a move that continues to influence the number and character of covert operations, according to former and present senior officials of the Administration.

title: MOSCOW-DESIGNED BARRIERS TO ARMS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

description: Samuel Y. Coyne, 85; L

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 11, 1984: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc SecInterco Inc TUESDAY Amer StoresJewel CosChesapeake Corp VaOklahoma G & EDayco CorpPremier IndusFluor CorpTri-Contl Corp WEDNESDAY Handleman CoPacific Pwr & LtMorgan (J P) & CoParker Pen THURSDAY Adams ExpressMONY Mtge InvestDow ChemicalNatl Medical CareGenl Signal CorpVaro Inc FRIDAY Genl CinemaSoutheast BankingIllinois Tool WksSteego CorpMay Dept StoresTidewater IncPueblo Intl

description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.78

title: Police Hunting For Holdup Team
description: The police in New Jersey and Pennsylvania were hunting today for a holdup team who led them on a high-speed chase through several communities. The police said the team - a man and a woman - exchanged gunfire with them and stole at least three vehicles.

title: Inquiry on Satellite Loss Focuses on Jet System
description: Investigations into the failed orbiting of a $30 million communications satellite focused today on an attitude control system.

title: LAKERS WIN TO FORCE A 7TH GAME
description: It has come to this: For the first time since 1978, and only the 13th time in 38 National Basketball Association championship series, there will be a seventh and deciding game. Pat Riley, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, said that it would be ''the ultimate game.''

title: Dr. Friedan Wed To Dr. Eli Farhi
description: Dr. Emily Friedan, the daughter of Betty Friedan of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., the author and feminist leader, and Carl Friedan of Teaneck, N.J., an advertising executive, was married yesterday to Dr. Eli Farhites Farhi, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Farhi of Buffalo. Rabbi Simkha Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Sag Harbor home of the bride's mother.

title: TIGERS SWEEP ORIOLES BY 10-4 AND 8-0
description: Dan Petry hurled a three-hitter as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 8-0, to complete a sweep of today's doubleheader after crushing the Orioles, 10-4, in the first game.

title: Palms Killed by Frost Dismay South Texans
description: Thousands of palm trees that line the Texas coast are brown this season because of a killing frost last December.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Camp Controversy College basketball coaches, worried that assistants who worked those high school all-star summer camps gave their school unfair recruiting advantages, got the National Collegiate Athletic Association to pass what is known as the Garfinkel Rule in January 1983. That rule prevents staff members of N.C.A.A. schools from working at basketball camps associated with a scouting service, such as the Five-Star camp run by Howard Garfinkel.

title: LENDL WINNER OVER MCENROE
description: Ivan Lendl won his first Grand Slam tennis tournament today, making a spectacular comeback in the French Open to defeat John McEnroe in a four-hour match that left 16,500 spectators dazzled and chanting the winner's name. The scores were 3-6, 2-6, 6-4, 7-5, 7-5. McEnroe raced to a two-set lead with his usual aggressive style, including a scorching serve, that seemed destined to turn the match into a rout. But when Lendl broke him in the sixth game of the third set, he also broke the tempestuous American's momentum. From there on, it was a sparkling, emotional endurance contest that seesawed until Lendl made the final break. McEnroe's last shot was a potentially easy volley that he tiredly knocked out of court. It seemed to symbolize the steady decay of his game. ''I saw hope as soon as I broke him,'' Lendl said of the crucial third set. ''I felt that once I could break him, I could do it again.'' A disconsolate McEnroe, who missed the chance to become the first American male to win here since 1955, said his game seemed to deteriorate as the match went on. He also said he had injured himself slightly when he fell in reaching for a shot. But he did not blame the injury for his defeat. ''I couldn't ask for any more chances,'' the 25-year-old left-hander said. It was his first loss of the year, after 42 victories. Lendl's remarkable victory complemented Martina Navratilova's singles triumph Saturday that completed her Slam - successive victories in the Wimbledon, United States, Australian and French championships. Today Miss Navratilova added another accomplishment by teaming with Pam Shriver to become the first women's doubles pair to win the Slam.

title: All in the Cause of Art
description: Love of art blended with heroism yesterday as people lined up outside the Museum of Modern Art, braving the day's blazing sun. Just before the 11 A.M. opening, the line stretched down West 53d Street to Fifth Avenue, hugging the buildings for a sliver of shade.

title: Renault Joint Venture
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault said Friday it would form a joint company with United Technologies Automotives Inc., a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, to produce electrical connectors for the auto industry.

title: City Ballet Promotes Several Dancers
description: The New York City Ballet has announced that Joseph Duell, Lourdes Lopez and Stephanie Saland have been promoted to principal dancer.

title: COLLEGE TITLE WON BY FULLERTON STATE
description: John Bryant tripled home one run and scored two others tonight to support the combined three-hit pitching of Eddie Delzer and Scott Wright, carrying Fullerton State to a 3-1 victory over Texas in the championship game of the college world series.

title: U.S. PLAN TO AID PAN AM CASH FLOW
description: Pan American World Airways has signed up with the Air Force for a $104 million war-readiness program, but insists that it will make no profits on the contract.

title: Article 253372 -- No Title
description: Patty Sheehan resisted thoughts of fancy almost all afternoon and for that reason, among others, she set golf history. Miss Sheehan won the McDonald's Kids' Classic at the White Manor Country Club here and was awarded a $500,000 bonus, which combined with first-prize money made it the largest single payout ever given to a professional golfer.

title: SAVE CENTRAL AMERICA
description: This seems to be a good moment to find a solution to a Central American problem that is, at least for some of us, more than 50 years old. Why now? Because after long neglect, all parties concerned, including the United States, have ''discovered'' the problem. They are all worried now, and even fed up with the inevitable consequences of past mistakes.

title: Kick Off the Immunity Blanket
description: When it comes to lobbying for anti-crime legislation, New York's police and prosecutors usually stand together. Give the D.A. the tools, the police ask, to follow through effectively on arrests.

title: ZIMBABWEAN SOLDIERS TO RUN RANCHES WHITES ABANDONED
description: The Zimbabwe Government plans to open a major campaign Monday to reassert control over more than 600,000 acres in southern Zimbabwe that have been abandoned by white ranchers fearful of rebel attacks, according to officials and ranchers in the area.

title: CITY BALLET: NEW CAST FOR 'REJOUISSANCE'
description: MOST new ballets retain their original casts in their first season of existence. Lately, however, the New York City Ballet has varied some of its casting in even its most recent works.

title: FAMILY SUPPORT DURING EXAMS
description: ''I feel irritable, so don't bother me with dinner or ask me to clear the table or take out the garbage. Let me go to the library at school so that no one can tell me that 'General Hospital' is on television. My room is a mess. My vanity is gone, so I am wearing shorts and a ripped shirt. I want to feel comfortable. Nobody else in my family is doing anything else of importance right now.''

title: A SUMMER OF REST EARNED BY SWALE
description: Swale's victory in the Belmont Stakes Saturday was so easy that he looked ready to run another mile and half yesterday morning. But the colt now has won himself a vacation that may last until September.

title: Question Box
description: -3 hole, each golfer hits his drive onto the green. Player A is 3 inches to the left of the cup and 3 inches short. Player B is short and 20 feet away. When Player B putts, his ball goes too far left and knocks Player A's ball into the hole. If Player A thus wins the hole, does he also get credit for a hole-in-one, since he only took one shot?

title: DANCE: RUSSILLO'S 'COURT-METRAGE'
description: Metrage'' (''Film Shorts'') is the sort of mad endeavor one can only imagine coming from France. Performed by the Toulouse-based Ballet The atre Joseph Russillo on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, ''Court-Metrange'' takes music associated with 21 films, movie eras and film personalities and sets it to dance, throwing in a delectable Betty Boop cartoon for good measure.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS ALLIES WANT TALKS ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: President Reagan repeated today that the Western allies were eager to renew nuclear arms negotiations and other talks with the Soviet Union, but he said there did not appear to be a consensus in Moscow on how to respond.

title: A SIP OF THE MISSISSIPPI WINS BIG TASTE TEST
description: With bombast, poetry and some Olympic-class hoopla, eight bottles of crystalline and not-so- crystalline water - the pride of eight cities - were gurgled, sniffed and slurped by a trio of judges here today in a Great North American Taste-Off.

title: Lion Theater Becoming The Judith Anderson
description: Dame Judith Anderson's name is to

title: NASHVILLE'S SWAN BALL: 'GRAND, GLORIOUS, HOT'
description: It's getting very difficult, Sigourney Cheek was saying just before Saturday evening's 22d annual Swan Ball, to come up with different-looking swan designs. The white-tie ball, considered the social event of the year in Nashville, benefits the Tennessee Botanical Gardens and Fine Arts Center at Cheekwood.

title: DrugRaidersSeize 20 in Connecticut
description: Police officers raided 16 sites in Fairfield County, arresting 20 people and seizing about $1.2 million worth of cocaine, authorities said today.

title: YOU'RE ON YOUR OWN
description: As we enter the News Doldrums - that midsummer period in which events overtake nothing - this department closes down. For readers who may need quick opinion fixes over the coming weeks, here are a few mini- diatribes. C.I.A.'s Biggest Flop

title: MOCKING THE LAW
description: One of the worst abuses of official power in recent American history, and one of the nastiest, was the F.B.I. program called Cointelpro. Conceived by J. Edgar Hoover in his declining years, it was a secret plan to ''disrupt,'' ''misdirect'' and ''discredit'' radicals, black nationalists and others the F.B.I. Director didn't like. The quoted words are from a 1967 Hoover letter to F.B.I. field offices.

title: BOSTON CORRUPTION TRIAL SET TO BEGIN TODAY
description: Theodore V. Anzalone, long a close associate of former Mayor Kevin H. White, is to go on trial Monday in the first of two cases in which he is accused of extortion and illegal currency transactions designed to benefit Mr. White and his family.

title: Michael Birnbaum Is Married to Amiee Schachter,
description: Aimee Schachter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ken Schachter of Jericho, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Birnbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Birnbaum of London.

title: MUSIC: GOLDEN FLEECE
description: -opera group that has gone from space to space over the last decade, presenting new music-theater pieces conceived (or conceivably arrangeable) for small performing forces. At the tiny Mercer Street Theater, the group has been offering a triple bill that, in a matinee performance yesterday, proved thoroughly engaging.

title: I.M.F. Loan For Jamaica
description: The International Monetary Fund has approved in principle a $180 million loan to Jamaica, monetary sources said Friday.

title: STATUES OF ATHLETES FOR '84 OLMPICS STIR DEBATE
description: The 1984 Olympic Games have had their share of political turmoil, but last week, with the start of the Olympic Arts Festival preceding the Games, the focus, at least in Los Angeles, shifted from politics to art.

title: PUBLISHING OF HISTORICAL PAPERS DECLINES
description: ONE of the grandest ambitions of modern American scholarship - to publish comprehensive editions of the papers of prominent American historical figures - is being forced into retreat, according to historians, publishers and their patrons.

title: WINGED FOOT HAS SOME GOOD SPOTS FOR SPECTATORS
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HIGH AND LOW The atrium of the I.B.M. Building at 57th Street and Madison Avenue has become one of the more popular oases for footsore pedestrians and shoppers in Midtown Manhattan. This impressively high-topped space, sprinkled with tall bamboo trees and chairs and tables and a refreshment stand connects to a department store and to the Trump Tower next door.

title: DAME JUDITH ANDERSON TO APPEAR IN NEW NBC-TV SOAP OPERA
description: Tonight, on West 42d Street, Dame Judith Anderson will have a theater named for her, but in a month she will be hard at work in a venture unusual for the woman who towered as Medea, plotted as Lady Macbeth and fried as Mrs. Danvers in Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rebecca.'' She will be starting work on a new daytime drama, ''Santa Barbara.''

title: THE JUDICIAL SYSTEM, AILING, NEEDS HELP
description: Our courts display all the classic signs of ill health. Overcrowded calendars are wearing the familiar pillared institutions down to their marble bones. Poorly compensated judges stagger under the burden of case loads, lawyers complain of delays, and litigants, often puzzled by mysterious activities inside imposing buildings, resent exorbitant fees. The well-being of the body politic depends on the swift and just functioning of the courts. Yet this country has still not committed itself to a concerted attack on our judicial system's ailments. Why is that?

title: A.B.T. Will Tour Japan For 3 Weeks in Autumn
description: American Ballet Theater has announced that it will tour Japan for three weeks, starting Oct. 24.

title: George B. Girardet, 69, Dies; ExecutiveofReal-EstateFirm
description: George B. Girardet, a senior vice president of the Manhattan real-estate concern of Fredric M. Reed & Company and a figure in real-estate enterprises in London and Jamaica, died of a heart attack in New York on June 1. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JUDGE AND JUSTICE DEPT. EMBROILED OVER PRISON SUIT
description: The Justice Department's handling of a lawsuit charging Michigan's prison system with cruel and unusual punishment has been questioned by a Federal district judge and is being assailed by private lawyers as betraying prisoners' rights.

title: FOR OPEN, HE'S NICKLAUS AGAIN
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: Accounts
description: GEICO (Government Employees Insurance Company), Washington, to Doremus Direct for all auto insurance programs.

title: 33 Military Cadets Die In Venezuela Bus Fire
description: A bus carrying students from the Jauregui Military Academy in La Grita rolled over and caught fire after crashing into a bridge railing Saturday and 33 cadets died, according to the official Venezuelan press agency.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1984 International
description: Sikh troops deserted the unit of a top Indian Army commander who was slain by an unidentified gunman in the northeastern state of Bihar, the Government said. A separate report said the commander had been killed by Sikh mutineers who fought with other troops. The report said 600 Sikh troops had deserted the unit. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan repeated in London that the Western allies were eager to renew nuclear arms negotiations and other talks with th Soviet Union, but he said there did not appear to be a consensus in Moscow on how to respond. A senior Reagan Administration said that during the summit conference Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada pressed particularly hard for the other six countries to do more to promote detente with Eastern Europe. Speaking to reporters before leaving for Washington, Mr. Reagan went somewhat further than he has recently in discounting the possibility of improving relations with Moscow soon. (A1:4.)

title: Public Workers in Peru Vow to Stay on Strike
description: Striking civil servants and teachers said today that they would continue a week-old strike in defiance of a state of emergency declared by the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry.

title: FOR BEDFORD, VA., THE WATERS HAVE NEVER CLOSED OVER D-DAY
description: The citizens of Bedford passed the 40th anniversary of D-day without ceremony. Some townspeople remarked that it was an odd lapse, in this year of D-day fascination, considering how hard the people of Bedford grieved together in the summer of 1944.

title: METS' ROAD STREAK SNAPPED BY EXPOS
description: The Mets, who reached an emotional peak by sweeping a doubleheader from the Montreal Expos Saturday for their fifth and sixth straight road victories, had their streak snapped today in a 3-2 loss in front of 32,483 at Olympic Stadium.

title: Councilman in Philadelphia Is Killed by Gunshot Wound
description: City Councilman Al Pearlman, suffering from terminal lung cancer, died today of what police called a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

title: New Protests Flare In Philippine Vote Count
description: Thousands of Filipinos marched through Cebu today chanting ''Marcos resign!'' in protest at parliamentary election results that showed the defeat of opposition candidates on this central Philippine island.

title: Congressman to Seek Massachusetts Seat
description: Representative James Shannon has edged out Lieut. Gov. John Kerry in the battle for the Massachusetts Democratic Party's endorsement in the Sept. 18 Senate primary.

title: Olympic Trash Tippers Set
description: Spectators at the Olympics could generate 4,000 tons of trash in the two- week-long Games, and the company responsible for picking it all up is ready. ''I think we're as ready as the athletes,'' said John Lavender, Olympic project manager for Waste Management Inc. of Oakbrook, Ill.

title: MORE WOMEN OF BOTH PARTIES SEEK SENATE SEATS
description: A record number of Republican and Democratic women are expected to run for the United States Senate this year, but virtually all are challenging men considered unbeatable.

title: Getting Started
description: Florida's tarpon guides always have tackle available for their clients, but if one wishes to bring his own flyrod it should be able to handle a 10- or 11-weight line and have a reel capable of holding 200 yards of backing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perhaps, like fine wine, our water doesn't travel well.'' - Joseph T. McGough Jr., New York City Environmental Protection Commissioner. (A1:3.)

title: INVESTORS TAKING CAUTIOUS APPROACH
description: The outlook for the economy and interest rates are intertwined in ways that economists do not fully understand. Uncertainty about how interest rates affect the economy and vice versa is a primary reason why many potential investors in the stock and bond markets are keeping their funds parked in low-risk, short-term investments.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American General Corp., Houston, a diversified financial and insurance company, has elected Kurt G. Schreiber senior vice president and general counsel; Marcus C. Gibbs senior vice president, management services, and Douglas B. Pierce senior vice president, operations.

title: HEAT WAVE RAISES WORRIES ON WATER
description: Though the calendar said ''June'' yesterday, other vital signs said ''August'' as New York City endured the fourth day of an unbroken heat wave that has led to busier ambulances and lower water pressure than normal.

title: CONCERN OVER TEXTILE BUYOUTS
description: Corporate America's latest financial fad, the leveraged buyout, is sweeping the textile industry, much to the concern of many analysts and industry officials.

title: The Death of a Dinosaur
description: After two decades of mindlessness, reason has finally triumphed over the Garrison Diversion Unit, a wasteful, damaging and seemingly unstoppable irrigation project in North Dakota. Senator Mark Andrews has now agreed with the project's critics to look for an alternative. That's a happy ending to a venture that serves as a model of dysfunction in government.

title: ACCORD IS NEAR ON PROVIDING SUBWAY ACCESS TO DISABLED
description: An agreement is near to make some of New York City's subway stations accessible to the disabled and to permit a $150 million station modernization program to proceed, according to participants in discussions on the issue.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Boating Mistrials The United States Yacht Racing Union went to a lot of trouble last month in staging Olympic trials off Long Beach, Calif., to determine who will represent the United States in the Finn Class yachting competition. The organization has gone to even more trouble since.

title: MUSIC: 'H.M.S. PINAFORE' AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: AMERICANS operate at a disadvantage in the British world of Gilbert & Sullivan. The class struggle which runs gently through these comic operas is underlined by dialect and accent; indeed, the shading and length of a vowel sound are the clues with which any Englishman can quickly place a countryman - both geographically and by social rank.

title: PLAYROOM FOR ILL YOUNGSTERS
description: On a wall at the new Child Life Center on the roof of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, a poster invites comments from the children who come to play there. The poster is headed, ''The playroom is like . . . '' Below, the youngsters have written ''a dream house,'' ''a gym,'' ''a ship,'' ''a place for people,'' ''a greenhouse'' and ''a church.'' Someone, in elaborate printing, has spelled out ''marvelous.''

title: Eric R. Levine Is Wed To Melissa Sue Camhy
description: Melissa Sue Camhy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan S. Camhy of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue to Eric Roy Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Levine of Huntington, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Cantor Benjamin Siegel officiated.

title: DELTA AIR LINES' RETIRED CHIEF
description: William Thomas Beebe, who retired last year as board chairman of Delta Air Lines, died of a heart attack Saturday after surgery at Doctors Memorial Hospital in Atlanta. He was 69 years old and a longtime resident of Atlanta.

title: 'PERICLES,' PART OF SHAKESPEARE SERIES ON WNET
description: WHAT to do with ''Pericles''? That was the challenge facing the BBC's ''Shakespeare Plays,'' a project intent on producing all 37 of the plays attributed to William Shakespeare.

title: Margaret R. Bleifeld Is Wed to a Physician
description: Margaret R. Bleifeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Bleifeld of Roosevelt Island, Manhattan, and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. E. Michael Kramer, the son of Mrs. Bert Westman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Martin Kramer. Rabbi Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Westman home.

title: PIRATES' 7 IN 12TH DEFEAT PHILLIES
description: Lee Lacy's inside-the-park home run highlighted a seven-run 12th inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates ended their six-game losing streak by beating the Philadelphia Phillies, 12-6.

title: An Official Eye On the City
description: As a crowd of Democrats congregated on the sidewalk in front of Robert F. Wagner Junior High School on East 76th Street before a political meeting the other night, an official chauffeured city car stopped across the street.

title: LIBERIA'S LIMPING ECONOMY
description: In 1822, a group of freed American slaves arrived on the west coast of Africa in an expedition backed by the United States Government. For the price of six muskets, one cask of gun powder, a box of beads, three pairs of shoes, a barrel of rum and other considerations, the former slaves purchased a piece of land that would become Liberia, the continent's first independent republic.

title: 6 HOSPITALS, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE, WILL SHARE SERVICES IN BROOKLYN
description: A major share of medical services provided by private and public hospitals in Brooklyn will be consolidated under a plan to eliminate fragmented and duplicative services and reduce costs.

title: Letter: On 'Import Relief' American Copper's Unfair Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Feldstein Sees Faster Growth
description: The American economy will likely grow faster than the Administration's latest official estimate of 5 percent this year and inflation will remain under control, the chief White House economist, Martin Feldstein, said today. ''And, looking ahead to 1985, all of the current indicators suggest that the economy will continue to expand at a desirable rate with rising incomes and falling unemployment,'' he added.

title: BANKING LAWS: CONSUMERS, NOT REGULATORS, SHOULD PREVAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; F.D.I.C. Hopes To Limit Role
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BOLIVIA FACES NEW PRESSURES
description: The Government's recent decision to postpone payments on the $720 million it owes foreign commercial banks appears to have averted potentially violent confrontations with labor and the military. But it has also earned the Government the enmity of right-wing political parties, which are demanding that President Hernan Siles Zuazo resign.

title: SURVEY OUTLINES COMPUTER CRIMES
description: Almost half the business and government agencies responding to an American Bar Association survey reported suffering incidents of computer crime in the last year.

title: Tiana Givens Wimmer Is Wed to Curt Richter
description: Tiana Givens Wimmer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wimmer of New York, and Curt Richter, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Richter of New York, were married yesterday at the Richter summer home in Garrison, N.Y., by Town Justice Michael J. Tighe of Philipstown, N.Y.

title: LET'S SHARE TAXI RIDES, STARTING IN MID-BLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN SMALL TOWN MEETS BIG CITY: STUDENTS FIND A COMMON GROUND
description: That this Nathan's, opened in 1916 in Coney Island, was the world's first Nathan's did not impress Brett Close in the least. ''What's Nathan's?'' he asked.

title: Helicopter Pilot Dies in Crash On His Way to Tornado Scene
description: A helicopter on its way to aid in relief efforts after a tornado nearly erased this farm community crashed today, killing the pilot, a sheriff's deputy.

title: EUROPE VOTE: THE CONCERNS SEEM NARROW
description: When Europeans vote for their Parliament in elections beginning June 14, the essential issues will be less the future of the Continent than the narrower, national concerns that most Europeans say smother the goal of a united political Europe.

title: GENERALS DEFEAT BREAKERS, GAIN PLAYOFFS
description: Coach Walt Michaels removed the handcuffs from Brian Sipe today, and the Generals' quarterback completed passes all over Giants Stadium. The result was a 31-21 victory over the New Orleans Breakers that guaranteed New Jersey a place in the United States Football League playoffs.

title: Patrice Kaufman Marries
description: Patrice Gail Kaufman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt N. Kaufman of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Alan Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Schwartz, also of Oceanside. Rabbi Dov Schwartz performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: WOMAN IS FOUND SLAIN ON L.I.
description: A 19-year-old woman was found slain yesterday on the campus of the State University College at Old Westbury, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: French Rider Hurt
description: The French jockey Yves Saint-Martin suffered a broken vertebra today when he was thrown by his mount, Grise Mine, going out to the start of the Prix de Diane at this racing center outside Paris. Saint-Martin, 42 years old, will be hospitalized for five to six weeks.

title: EXPANSION IN U.S. CITED BY EUROPEAN FINANCIER
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the peripatetic financier who owns, among other things, Grand Union Stores and the Diamond International Corporation in the United States and L'Express, a weekly news magazine in France, wants more.

title: U.S. DATA SHOW A 7% DECLINE IN REPORTED CRIMES
description: Serious crime in America declined by 7 percent in 1983 as the rates of personal larceny and household burglary reached record lows, the Justice Department said today.

title: ARGENTINA BYPASSING I.M.F. STAFF
description: Argentina, unable to reach agreement here with a team from the International Monetary Fund over an austerity program to repay the country's foreign debt, is submitting its own program to the fund's leadership, Argentine officials said today.

title: U.N. CHIEF REBUFFS ISRAEL ON BUFFER FORCE IN LEBANON
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today rejected an Israeli proposal that United Nations peacekeeping troops serve as a buffer between Israel and Syrian forces in eastern Lebanon.

title: SOVIET CALLS CONFERENCE A DISPLAY OF DISUNITY
description: The Soviet press today depicted the London economic summit conference as a display of the ''differences that tear the capitalist world asunder.''

title: SOCIOLOGY PLAYS GREATER ROLE THAN BEFORE IN LEGAL RESEARCH
description: Richard D. Schwartz of Syracuse University recalls how, in his student days at Yale Law School in the 1950's, his efforts to use a long-neglected squash court for a research project on juries was rebuffed by school officials.

title: AGONY IN A THREE-PART SERIES
description: Not far from the French Open, where Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe dueled as the world watched, an international sporting event of heroic proportions was coming to a climax almost unnoticed today.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, whose six-game winning streak ended yesterday, will send their hard-throwing rookie, Dwight Gooden, to the mound.

title: BOOK CHARGES POPE WAS MURDERED IN '78
description: A book charging that Pope John Paul I, who died in September 1978 after a reign of only 33 days, was murdered, will be published simultaneously in six countries next Thursday.

title: Pope Laments India Deaths
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he regrets the loss of life during religious clashes in the Indian state of Punjab and asked prayers for his pastoral visit to Switzerland this week. ''In these days, the news has followed the ever more serious events in the state of Punjab in India,'' the Pope said in his weekly address.

title: GLOBAL MONETARY TALKS IN '86 SEEN
description: The United States and the world's other leading democracies are likely to call for a new international monetary conference similar to the one that led to the Bretton Woods agreement 40 years ago, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: KELLY BREAKS 3 PRO RECORDS
description: Jim Kelly, the Houston quarterback, set three American professional football records, and the split end Richard Johnson set another as the Gamblers clinched the United States Football League Central Division title today.

title: Crocker and Botha To Meet on Namibia
description: South Africa and the United States will discuss South-West Africa during the next two days, while Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa is here for a three-day visit, a spokesman for the United States Embassy said.

title: A WEAPON THAT ADDS LITTLE TO SAUDI DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: UNFINISHED TASKS
description: News Analysis

title: INDIA COMMANDER IS KILLED AS SIKHS DESERT THE ARMY
description: A top Indian Army commander was shot dead today by an unidentified assailant in the northeastern state of Bihar and Sikh troops deserted the unit, the Government said.

title: Theodora Higginson Weds
