description: The marriage of Theodora Winthrop Higginson to Bruce Duff Hooton, publisher and editor in chief of Art/World, a monthly newspaper published in New York, took place in Sea Cliff, L.I., yesterday.

title: MONDALE SECLUDED ON ESTATE
description: There were unconfirmed reports here today that Walter F. Mondale took an afternoon nap.

title: ARMS SUPPLIERS PUSHED ON COSTS AND QUALITY
description: The push by American industry to produce better goods at lower cost appears to be working its way slowly onto the factory floors of many of the Pentagon's major contractors.

title: BETTER MEMORIES
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: HART HINTS HE MAY NOT CHALLENGE MONDALE DELEGATES AT CONVENTION
description: Gary Hart, appearing increasingly conciliatory, indicated today that he might forgo his threatened challenge to several hundred Democratic delegates supporting Walter F. Mondale.

title: Dow Declines by 15.64; Interest Rate Fear Cited
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday on apprehension over rising interest rates. Trading remained light.

title: Malone & Hyde Accepts Bid
description: Malone & Hyde Inc. said it

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Mistrial In Sentinel Tax Case
description: A Federal jury, which last week convicted four executives of two Wall Street securities firms of engaging in a $130 million fraudulent income tax shelter scheme, said yesterday that it could not arrive at a verdict for a fifth defendant.

title: TRADERS WARY AS RATES RISE
description: Interest rates rose in quiet trading yesterday amid weak investor demand and continued fears that the Federal Reserve is arranging a subtle tightening of monetary policy and lifting of short-term interest rates.

title: DENT FEARED EARLY EXIT
description: Bucky Dent's friends assured him that he would not have to wait long before someone in need of a shortstop came calling. They were partially right. Not long after his release by the Texas Rangers near the end of spring training, there was a need for an experienced shortstop and a chance for Dent to return to uniform.

title: SALVADOR CHURCH ACTING AS MEDIATOR
description: The Roman Catholic Church in El Salvador has assumed a growing role as mediator between the Government and leftist insurgents as a result of a series of prisoner exchanges it has arranged in the last month.

title: DEBATE ABOUT IMMIGRATION CHANGES IN BRIEF
description: Following is a summary of major provisions of the immigration bill considered by the House of Representatives: Employer sanctions - The bill would authorize civil and criminal penalties for employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens. For the first offense, the Government would issue a warning. For subsequent offenses, the employer would be subject to fines of $1,000 and then $2,000 for each illegal alien. The maximum penalty would be one year in prison and a $3,000 fine for each illegal alien hired. The Justice Department could also ask a Federal District Court to issue an injunction to stop a ''pattern or practice'' of hiring illegal aliens.

title: 'SCHOOLBREAK SPECIAL' PORTRAYS FRESHMAN LIFE
description: -heavy title of ''The Alfred G. Graebner Memorial High School of Rules and Regulations,'' this afternoon's ''CBS Schoolbreak Special,'' being broadcast at 4:30, turns out to be a fairly charming trifle. It offers nothing less than an illustrated primer for teen-agers on how to get through the first year of high school without losing dignity and self-confidence forever.

title: MARY L. GOTTESFELD
description: Mary L. Gottesfeld, a psychotherapist and adjunct professor at the Hunter College School of Social Work, died of cancer Friday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 17 on school desegregation since 1954 erroneously described the status of desegregation orders in Cincinnati and St. Louis. In an agreement reached in February, Cincinnati's board of education and the state of Ohio agreed to share the costs of a court-ordered plan equally, and the school district is not appealing the order. The state of Missouri has appealed a consent decree on desegregation in the St. Louis metropolitan area; the St. Louis school board has not appealed, and the plan is operating.

title: LOTTERY TO OFFER LOSERS CHANCE TO WIN BOOKS
description: Lotteries have few winners - but soon, some of the many who fail to gain the larger prizes in the New York State Lottery will have an opportunity to win free books, under a program that was tested as an experiment last month and will be resumed next year.

title: Ernst Haeusserman, Director In Austria and in Hollywood
description: Ernst Haeusserman, an Austrian theater director and former associate of the producer-director Max Reinhardt, died Sunday in Vienna after a brief illness. He was 68 years old.

title: ARMY TEST MISSILE IS SAID TO DESTROY A DUMMY WARHEAD
description: An experimental antiballistic missile has accomplished the first direct interception and destruction of an incoming dummy missile warhead, Army officers reported today.

title: Topics Word / Games
description: Annals of Acronyms

title: THEATER: 'I DON'T WANT TO BE ZELDA'
description: IN ''I Don't Want to be Zelda Anymore,'' a one-character play by

title: SWARM OF COMET CHUNKS TIED TO STRANGE EVENTS
description: BALTIMORE THE great 1908 explosion in Siberia, a strange lunar flare- up seen by monks in 1178, and the severe jostling of seismographs left by astronauts on the moon in 1975 may all have been manifestations of the same phenomenon: a swarm of about 100 cometary fragments that constitute ''a new feature of the solar system,'' an astrophysicist suggested here today.

title: WEINBERGER AND CHINESE AIDE IN ACCORD
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and the Chinese Defense Minister, Zhang Aiping, ''reached agreement on a number of important matters they hope will improve both countries' military capabilities,'' the chief Defense Department spokesman said today.

title: Agency's Relocation To Queens
description: YOU follow the brick driveway a

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mitel-RCA Pact
description: The Mitel Corporation said its United States subsidiary, Mitel Inc., had signed a five-year contract valued at a minimum of $200 million with the RCA Service Company.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $121,000

title: OTTAWA PLAYING DOWN TRUDEAU'S DIFFERENCES WITH REAGAN
description: Canadian officials tried today to play down Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's apparently sharp differences with President Reagan in a discussion over East-West relations and arms control at the London economic conference.

title: THE CELTICS' RED-EYE FLIGHT
description: As the Boston Celtics' plane hurtled eastward through

title: MAYOR AFFIRMS WARD'S CONTROL OF TRANSIT FORCE
description: Mayor Koch issued a statement yesterday reaffirming a policy that places Transit Authority police strategies and deployment under the control of the city's Police Commissioner.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: The quest was brief. Just across the city line, in Lower Merion, there were the clues: the numeral 300 on North Latches Lane, a tall iron gate, a guardhouse and a curving drive.

title: Chrysler Backs Steel Quota Bill
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was joining the domestic steel industry's campaign for legislation imposing a five-year global quota on imported steel.

title: Marcos Foes to Challenge Parliament Rules
description: Opposition parties decided at a caucus today to challenge President Ferdinand E. Marcos's New Society Movement for the rules and the leadership of Parliament when it convenes on July 23.

title: ASSAULT ON THE 'GENIUS' OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: A THEATER FOR DAME JUDITH
description: The air was full of colored balloons sporting her name, now proudly emblazoned above the theater itself. Her arms laden with long-stemmed red roses, Dame Judith Anderson stepped up to the red satin ribbon and cut it, thus renaming the former Lion Theater on 42d Street's Theater Row the Judith Anderson Theater. ''We're open for business,'' she proclaimed.

title: COURT UPSETS NEW YORK'S MINIMUM LIQUOR PRICING
description: A New York State court yesterday declared invalid a state law that prohibits liquor stores from selling liquor at less than a minimum retail price.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $40,136,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: 1984 Wheat Harvest Data
description: The Agriculture Department said today that the 1984 winter wheat harvest is estimated at 1.97 billion bushels, down 1 percent from last year's 1.99 billion bushels and slightly less than forecast a month ago.

title: Feeling Unappreciated
description: Clive Toye helped build the Cosmos into a powerhouse in the 1970's, and he has been doing the same for the Blizzard during his three years as their president.

title: Ineligibility Looms Hundreds of college football players could be declared ineligible next fall because their schools failed to insure that they were enrolled in specific degree programs by the start of the third academic year, as required under a new rule of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. ''It's the topic we're most concerned with right now all over the country,''
description: Fred Akers, the Texas coach, said yesterday. ''Those that aren't concerned about it are not aware of it.'' The last apparent hope to forestall the regulation rests with the N.C.A.A. Council, which may delay its effective date from Aug. 1 to next year.

title: ORWELL RADIO SCRIPTS AND LETTERS FOUND
description: LONDONA cache of writings by George Orwell thought to have been lost in the London blitz of World War II has been discovered. The work, dating from the war period, and lost for 40 years because of a filing error, includes more than 250 letters, previously unknown radio adaptations of stories by Ignazio Silone, H. G. Wells, Anatole France and others, and 62 radio scripts that provide a weekly commentary on World War II.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
. . . And in Recordings
description: Meanwhile, the Mayor, star of television, literature and politics, is moving into the recording business, reading excerpts from his book.

title: The U.N. Today June 12, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MOON TO SEEK LIGHTER TERM, NOT A NEW TRIAL
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who faces an 18-month prison term for tax fraud and conspiracy, has dropped plans to seek a new trial and will instead move to have his sentence lightened, his lawyer said yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Energy Agency Picketed
description: Three dozen members of a religious group sang, prayed and handed out antinuclear leaflets today as they blocked the main entrance to the United States Energy Department, which has jurisdiction over the manufacture and transportation of nuclear weapons. The police directed department employees and visitors to other entrances.

title: Japan Trade Has Surplus
description: Japan posted a trade surplus of $2.23 billion in May, narrower than a $3.02 billion surplus in April but wider than a $2.12 billion surplus in may 1983, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Information Call Service by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would begin offering long- distance information service on July 15. William G. McGowan, MCI's founder and chairman, said his company would duplicate the directory assistance system operated by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Teaching Pro
description: Andre McCarter thinks he learned a lot at Haverford College. The former playmaking star of the U.C.L.A. basketball team in the mid-1970's spent last season as an assistant coach at Haverford, a suburban Philadelphia school with high academic standards that competes on the Division III level athletically.

title: Japan Robots for G.E.
description: The Nachi-Fujikoshi Corporation, a major Japanese robot maker, said today that it had concluded an agreement to supply its spot-welding robots to the General Electric Company. G.E. will market the robots worldwide under its own brand name, but the Japanese company will continue to market the robots under the Nachi name through its own marketing network.

title: RENEWED BEIRUT VIOLENCE KILLS 65 AND WOUNDS 200
description: Sixty-five people were killed and 200 wounded here today in the worst Moslem-Christian flare-up since a new Government was formed six weeks ago.

title: HIGH TECH: JAPAN'S APPROACH
description: What do you do with an exotic metal alloy that has the ability to ''remember'' its original shape and return to that shape when heated?

title: VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $36,000 for the latest year and $192,000 for the previous year.

title: APACHES END LEASES AND A RESORT IS FADING
description: One by one, the summer cabins and year-round homes of Non-Indians snuggled amid the aspens, firs, pines and spruces on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation are disappearing.

title: THE MOVE TO ALTER EQUIVALENCY TESTS
description: LAST November, a month after his 17th birthday, Clinton Langston quit high school because he thought he was not getting anywhere. He was in the 10th grade and his reading and mathematics scores were still at the elementary school level.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: PEOPLE would have left town

title: A Southland Case Mistrial
description: A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the case of a Southland Corporation executive who was charged with conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, which Southland runs. A jury was unable to agree on a verdict.

title: A Pay Cut at PSA
description: PSA Inc. said pilots with its Pacific Southwest Airlines unit had ratified a 15 percent wage reduction and a 15 percent productivity increase.

title: House Votes Chip-Mask Bill
description: Legislation to give copyright protection to developers of masks for semiconductor computer chips was approved today by the House and sent to the Senate.

title: ISRAELIS CHARGED AS TERRORISTS GET SOME SUPPORT
description: -occupied West Bank, June 7 - The 25 Jewish settlers under arrest for anti-Arab terrorism have begun to pick up expressions of support from some fellow settlers, politicians, teachers and others who assert that violence is a natural reaction to attacks by Arabs on Jews.

title: CORRUPTION IGNORED (2)
description: The story of the dishonest behavior surrounding the proposed Westway project keeps unfolding. The latest revelations about the $4 billion-plus megadevelopment came last week in a 119-page report by the State Investigation Commission.

title: FEDERATED GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MargiottatoBegin Work Release
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader, is to be released from a Federal prison in Allenwood, Pa., on Wednesday and placed in a work-release program, officials said today.

title: FUTILE EFFORT TO EXONERATE ISRAEL'S GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: JUDGE'S TRIAL HEARS OF HALLWAY MIRACLES
description: The Federal extortion and racketeering trial of a Cook County judge is winding down and is expected to go to the jury Tuesday or Wednesday, but interest has never waned.

title: TOP COURT ALLOWS ILLEGAL EVIDENCE IN TRIAL IF FINDING WAS INEVITABLE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 7 to 2, that illegally obtained evidence may be admitted at trial if the prosecution can prove that the evidence would ''inevitably'' have been discovered by lawful means in any event.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Fannie Mae Joins Trend With Zero-Coupon Sale

title: Rapist's Lawyer Defends Client's Starvation Plan
description: An attorney for a convicted rapist who says he wants to leave the world ''as a man'' went before the State Supreme Court today to argue that the inmate should be allowed to starve himself to death in prison.

title: Article 255632 -- No Title
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest handler of chemical waste, offered $21 a share yesterday for SCA Services Inc., the third-largest company specializing in chemical and solid waste services.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Monday Sports listing yesterday misidentified Doug Williams. He plays for the Oklahoma Outlaws and has been sidelined by injury.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beneficial Corp. has named Rolf F. Eriksen president and chief operating officer of the Beneficial Mortgage Corp., its mortgage banking subsidiary, in Wilmington, Del.

title: 574 SIKH DESERTERS REPORTEDLY HELD BY INDIAN FORCES
description: Most of the 500 to 600 Sikh troops who deserted in northeastern India on Sunday were arrested today at three places, including one where a gun battle left 26 Sikh extremists dead, Indian news agencies and officials reported tonight.

title: STATE EQUAL RIGHTS MEASURE IS BLOCKED
description: A proposed state equal rights amendment for women was blocked today when Senate Republicans said they would not allow it on the floor for a vote.

title: AlternateSentence ForFireIsRevised
description: A disagreement between a Roman Catholic charismatic movement and the Bergen County Probation Department has prompted a judge to revise a 1983 sentence that required a young woman to live and work at one of the religious group's homes for at least 30 months.

title: A REPORTER'S DEATH THAT SHIFTED U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban on Jockeys Upheld in Jersey
description: A New Jersey appeals court upheld today the denial of licenses to two jockeys who had been accused of accepting bribes to influence the result of a race in 1981 at the Meadowlands Race Track. The bribes were offered in connection with an undercover state police operation known as ''Operation Glue.''

title: AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a realized gain on investments of $479,000 and an extraordinary gain of $214,000. c-Net loss after a realized loss on investments of $208,000 and an extraordinary gain of $369,000.

title: DEFYING I.M.F., ARGENTINA SETS AUSTERITY PLAN
description: Argentina today submitted its own austerity program to the International Monetary Fund, in defiance of harsher proposals sought by the fund. The austerity program is intended to help the country repay its huge foreign debt.

title: EXPOS WIN ON HOMER IN 9TH
description: Tim Wallach led off the ninth inning by cracking his ninth home run of the season on the first pitch from Lee Smith and led the Montreal Expos to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Longer Hours at the Met
description: Beginning July 1, the Metropolitan

title: Why Sell Conrail So Cheap?
description: The ugly duckling has become a swan. Conrail, the Federal transportation system Congress created from the remnants of eight bankrupt Northeastern railroads, has soaked up $3 billion in Government subsidies since 1976. Now, thanks to good management, labor concessions, reduced regulation and the general economic upturn, Conrail has become very profitable.

title: EXCERTPS FROM HART AND JACKSON STATEMENTS TO PARTY'S PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from the statements of Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson today to the Democratic platform committee: Senator Hart

title: SOUTH AFRICAN LEADERS MEET POPE
description: Pope John Paul II met with Prime Minister P. W. Botha and Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa today, and shortly after the meeting the Vatican issued a statement condemning South Africa's policy of apartheid.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: FEDERAL DESEGREGATION SUIT REINSTATED AGAINST YONKERS
description: The Federal Government resumed its civil rights suit against the City of Yonkers and its Board of Education on charges of discrimination in housing and in education yesterday, after seven months of efforts to reach an out-of- court settlement failed.

title: Business and the Law; Manville's Big Legal Fees
description: S INCE filing for bankruptcy on Aug. 26, 1982, the Manville Corporation has not had to pay a single penny to any of the thousands of claimants who developed asbestos-related diseases after exposure to its products - but it is paying millions of dollars to hundreds of lawyers.

title: EX-CAMPUS EMPLOYEE HELD IN WOMAN'S SLAYING ON L.I.
description: A man who had briefly worked for the State University College at Old Westbury was arrested today and charged with murdering a 19-year-old woman whose body was found Sunday in a wooded area of the campus, the Nassau County police said.

title: EXPLOITING HALFBACK'S OPTION PASS
description: Playing backup to Herschel

title: CIVIL RIGHTS ADVOCATE IS SUED BY U.S. IN HOUSING BIAS CASE
description: Leon Weiner, a leading national proponent of fair housing, was sued by the Justice Department today over allegations of discrimination against blacks in the rental of apartments.

title: Utah Woman Goes on Trial On Baby Smuggling Charge
description: A Utah woman turned to smuggling Mexican babies into the United States because she was frustrated with bureaucratic delays in arranging adoptions through normal channels, a prosecutor charged today.

title: QUIETLY, EUROPE'S PARLIAMENT GAINS INFLUENCE
description: The European Parliament, to which Common Market citizens are electing members this week, is a largely powerless organization without a home of its own that many Europeans seem to laugh at but more frequently ignore.

title: LEADER OF ITALY'S COMMUNISTS
description: Enrico Berlinguer, the Italian Communist leader who started a movement among Western European Communists toward greater independence from Moscow, died yesterday at a hospital in Padua, Italy. He was 62 years old.

title: Pure Outrage
description: New York entered a sample of the city's drinking water in a municipal water-tasting contest in Dallas. The result was proof that the judges hired by the American Water Works Association don't know their water from wine.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $135,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $94,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 6 months.

title: HANS BETHE CONFRONTS THE LEGACY OF HIS BOMB
description: AN IMPATIENT young weapons designer wrote to Dr. Hans A. Bethe not long ago, urging the eminent physicist to stop his opposition to the development of a new generation of nuclear weapons.

title: Rare Foe Challenges Thurmond in Primary By The Associated Press
description: Senator Strom Thurmond faces a rare primary election challenge in South Carolina as several states hold primaries today. In Providence, R.I., voters begin choosing a new Mayor.

title: Continental Group Stock Declines
description: Continental Group's shares fell $3, to $41.375, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as Wall Street lawyers and investment advisers continued work on a $2.1 billion takeover bid for Continental that has not even been made officially. Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, has offered informally to pay $50 a share for the diversified container maker and energy concern.

title: CPC Selling Plant
description: CPC International Inc. said it had agreed to sell its corn wet milling plant in North Kansas City, Mo., to the National Starch and Chemical Corporation of Bridgewater, N.J. Terms were not disclosed. CPC said National Starch would make a ''very substantial'' investment in new facilities on the premises for production of basic and specialty corn starches, while CPC would continue to make dextrose, corn syrup and animal feed products there.

title: MONDALE'S RIVALS EMPHASIZE UNITY
description: Walter F. Mondale's rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination showed little interest today in challenging him on the platform to be adopted at the party's national convention.

title: RESPONSES TO WAR PERIL
description: ''STOPPING HISTORY'' is an intelligent, sensitive and ultimately frustrating documentary about how we respond, or should respond, to the threat of nuclear war. It asks if we are morally obligated to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, and, if so, what is the form of the obligation? The provocative program will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: Penney Property
description: The J. C. Penney Company and Western National Properties said they had formed a joint venture to develop an apartment community in Orange, Calif., containing more than 500 units. Penney said the project is the first residential real estate venture undertaken by its real estate subsidiary, JCP Realty Inc. The value of the completed project is estimated at $30 million.

title: ; SHORTCUT TO VERIFYING ARMS CURBS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLUEPRINT FOR THE DECAY OF A RENTAL BUILDING
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: An American Is the Winner Of the Correspondence Title
description: For the first time in 16 years, an American has won the world correspondence championship. The winner, 41-year-old Victor Palciauskas of Fullerton, Calif., took the 10th running of the event by scoring 11 points out of 14 games in the final.

title: BASEBALL OWNER BUYS WRIGHT HOUSE
description: The materials from a dismantled house by Frank Lloyd Wright, which had been thought lost and were found last week to have been stored for 30 years in a Westchester County basement, were sold Sunday night for $117,500 to Tom Monaghan, a Michigan businessman who owns Dominoes Pizza and the Detroit Tigers baseball team.

title: 5th Candidate Joins Race To Unseat Rep. Studds
description: Lewis Crampton, a Republican, today announced his candidacy in the crowded 10th Congressional District race. He accused the incumbent, Representative Gerry E. Studds, a Democrat, of ''diminished effectiveness,'' in part because of his censure by the House of Representatives.

title: ;  Cetus President to Head Grace Partnership
description: Robert A. Fildes, president and chief operating officer of the Cetus Corporation, the biotechnology company, has been named chief operating officer of a new partnership between Cetus and W. R. Grace and Company, the concerns announced yesterday.

title: MARGARET FARRAR, 87, EDITOR OF CROSSWORD PUZZLES, DIES
description: -puzzle editor who was instrumental in turning a word game into a daily American habit and then into an educational tool featured in newspapers, magazines and books all over the world, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Improvements Sought In 3 Michigan Prisons

title: INQUIRY ON MILK DRAWS A CHARGE OVER INTENTIONS
description: The State Department of Agriculture and Markets has accused a legislative commission of a ''substantial conflict of interest'' for conducting an investigation of the department at the same time its chairman was representing a milk company that had been denied a license by the department.

title: OFFER ON PLEA NOT BINDING IF RESCINDED
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a defendant has no constitutional right to enforcement of a proposed plea bargain that the prosecution withdrew before it became official.

title: Comparative Claims Don't Impress Judge
description: With the millions of dollars involved in package goods marketing moves, the people behind the products frequently lose sight of what petty decisions they are dealing with.

title: SCOTTS SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $32,000 from accelerated payment of debt. c-After income from discontinued operations of $99,000 and a tax credit of $75,000.

title: THE BATTLE GOES ON
description: THE bright young civil rights lawyers with whom Jack Greenberg frequently lunches say that the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund is an elite organization, and maybe it is.

title: Binney & Smith Agrees To Bid From Hallmark
description: Binney & Smith Inc., the company that makes Crayola brand crayons, and one that had been the subject of takeover speculation, announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Hallmark Cards Inc.

title: Whalers Satisfied Though the Hartford Whalers finished last in their division for the third straight season, club officials have extended the contracts of Coach
description: Jack Evans and his assistant, Claude Larose, by three years, through the 1987-88 season. . . . The New Haven Nighthawks, the American Hockey League team operated by the Los Angeles Kings, now has a second sponsor: the Rangers. Each team will supply the Nighthawks with 10 to 12 players.

title: Jackson Pulls Strings
description: ''America's Black Forum'' is a syndicated, independently distributed television program whose host is State Senator Julian Bond of Georgia. Barbara Reynolds, a reporter for USA Today, was to have joined Mr. Bond last Friday in Washington for the taping of an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a Democratic Presidential contender. When Mr. Jackson objected to both, however, Mr. Bond was replaced by Dolores Handy, a former program host, and Miss Reynolds was dropped.

title: ON 'FINAL' ASSAULT: DISSENSION IN IRAN?
description: Intelligence sources here and at North Atlantic Alliance headquarters in Brussels report signs of dissension and unrest in Iran.

title: 6-Term House Democrat Opposed by Stockbroker
description: Mary Downs, a Republican who is a former stockbroker, will oppose Representative woman Patricia Schroeder, the six-term Democratic incumbent, in Colorado's First District.

title: BUSINESSES PLAN OUTLAY JUMP
description: Business executives are planning to push their spending for expansion and modernization to a record $309 billion this year, a 14.8 percent yearly gain that would be the biggest in nearly two decades, the Government said today.

title: CONTINENTAL LOSES CHICAGO SUITOR
description: In a surprise move, the First Chicago Corporation announced yesterday that it no longer should be considered a candidate to take over the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company.

title: Penney Offering Extendable Notes
description: A $100 million issue of J. C. Penney & Company extendable notes is offered at a price of 99.8 with an initial coupon of 13 5/8 percent to yield 13.69 percent to 1988 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes, with a final maturity of 1999, are rated A-1 by Moody's and Ax by Standard & Poor's.

title: TELEVISION STARDOM NEAR FOR ACTOR, 64
description: Anyone who believes in happy endings will take consolation from the career of George Gaynes, about to become a television celebrity at the age of 64.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Pillsbury, Sedutto
description: The Pillsbury Company said it had acquired the Sedutto Ice Cream Corporation, a New York-based producer of specialty ice cream products.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 12, 1984 International
description: Most of the Sikh troops who deserted in northeastern India on Sunday were arrested at three places, including one where a gun battle left 26 Sikh extremists dead, according to Indian news agencies and officials. The Press Trust of India reported 574 arrests. At the same time, more Sikh defections and attempted defections were reported in the north and in the west near Bombay. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Sixty-five Lebanese were killed and 200 were wounded in the worst flare- up between Moslem and Christian forces since a new Government was formed six weeks ago. Both sides of Beirut's Green Line were pounded for 12 hours. (A12:3-6.)

title: QUESTIONABLE LIST OF TERROR GROUPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Top National Players Meet Their Match on Local Level
description: Some players, it seems, find it easier to win at the national level than the local level. In action recently were Marty Bergen of White Plains, Larry Cohen of New York City and Warren Rosner of Nanuet, N.Y., all of whom have won at least three national titles in the past three years, and Luella Slaner of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Steve Sanborn of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., both of whom have finished second in major national events.

title: Coast Guard Intercepts 2 Boats With Haitians
description: Two boats ''seriously overcrowded'' with 90 Haitians were intercepted in the same area where another vessel capsized last week, the Coast Guard said today.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Debt Issues
description: * Ryder System will sell $75 million of notes due June 15, 1994, as 14's at par through Salomon Brothers.

title: Those Living in Wilmette, Ill., Rated Most Highly Educated
description: Wilmette residents are the most highly educated in the country, according to data from the 1980 census.

title: AZTECH INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1983.

title: ART EXPLOSION reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MUSEUM BOARD AFFIRMS ANTI-APARTHEID POSITION
description: The American Museum of Natural History will post a statement opposing South Africa's racial policies at an exhibit containing fossils from that country, the museum's board of trustees decided yesterday. The decision by the trustees affirms the position taken late last month by Dr. Thomas Nicholson, the director of the museum.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Italy's Wholesale Prices
description: Wholesale prices in Italy rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in April from March and were up 11.4 percent from April 1983, the Statistical Institute said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MACHINE DREAMS. By Jayne Anne Phillips. 331 pages. E. P. Dutton/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: Market Place; The Challenge For Hewlett
description: W ITH a whirlwind of new products and price reductions buffeting the computer industry, competition has intensified, and even the industry leaders have had to adjust to the challenge.

title: EXILES SAY LIBYANS HAVE SEIZED 3,000
description: A Libyan exile group says the Libyan security police have arrested as many as 3,000 people and executed 7 people this month.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to March 31
TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates , at Shea Stadium, 8:35 P.M. Tim Leary, sent to the bullpen several weeks ago after some poor starting performances, has been pitching well in relief.

title: Turks in Prison Hospital
description: More than a dozen prisoners are in serious condition in an Istanbul military hospital after a 60-day fast to protest jail conditions, prisoners' relatives and informed sources said today.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Uganda Rebels Damage A Major Power Station
description: Rebels have stepped up their attacks against the Government of President Milton Obote, damaging a major power station on the outskirts of the capital with rocket-propelled grenades, the Roman Catholic newspaper Munno reported today.

title: RIGHTS AIDE ASSERTS THE RIGHT TO SPEAK HER MIND
description: Dissident employees of the United States Commission on Civil Rights recently circulated a spurious document poking fun at the agency's staff director, Linda Chavez.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE LONG MILE The cultural spine of New York may well be Fifth Avenue, between 82d and 105th Streets, a stretch lined by 10 institutions that open their wealth of arts and store of knowledge to the public. Today, from 6 to 9 P.M., this part of the avenue (86th Street, north) becomes a walkway, foot traffic only, for the sixth annual Museum Mile Street Festival.

title: 11% RISE IN RATES IS URGED FOR LILCO
description: A state hearing officer recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company receive an 11.8 percent increase in electric rates as soon as possible to keep the company from bankruptcy.

title: ; Official at Allegheny Now Vice Chairman
description: Clayton A. Sweeney, executive vice president and chief administrative officer at Allegheny International Inc., was named to the new post of vice chairman.

title: River Pioneers
description: Rob Lesser of Boise, Idaho, a 38- year-old kayak enthusiast who estimates he rides the Payette River about nine months of the year, returned from Pakistan last Friday and a down-river trip he expects to recall for a long time.

title: China-Australia Accord
description: China and Australia widened their relationship in iron and steelmaking today under an agreement signed by ministers of both countries. Lionel Bowen, Australia's Deputy Prime Minister, and Chen Muhua, China's Minister for Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, signed an agreement to bring Australian experts to China next month to survey older mills and report on refurbishing the plants.

title: HITACHI LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Share earnings are per American Depositary Shares, each of which equal 10 underlying shares.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Retailing Concern Names Chairman
description: William P. Arnold, who has been fighting cancer since 1969, stepped down yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer at the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

title: TURMOIL IN FRANCE
description: PARIS ON June 24, supporters of Roman Catholic private schools, opponents of the Socialist Government and a right-wing faction of French politics will join forces in a demonstration against a new law that gives the Government certain regulatory powers over private schools. The object of the demonstration is to put pressure on a review panel that will test the law's constitutionality.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS LTD PC reports earnings for Year to March 31
INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $871,888 and a tax credit of $495,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $52,082 and a tax credit of $461,000.

title: No Headline
description: James H. Righter, 67, E

title: Girl, 3, Wounded In Bronx Shootout
description: A 3-year-old girl was shot in the forehead and critically wounded in a shootout between two groups of youths on a Bronx street last night, the police reported.

title: Pickens Sees More Oil Ties
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said today that there are ''great potential values'' within the oil industry and predicted more mergers and acquisitions in the United States.

title: Henderson Is Given 4 Years 8 Months
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, the former all-pro linebacker, was sentenced today to four years and eight months for sexually assaulting two teen-age girls and then offering them a $10,000 bribe to keep them from testifying against him.

title: Italy Opens an Inquiry Into a Report on Pope
description: The Rome state prosecutor's office opened an inquiry today into how an American journalist obtained a confidential prosecutor's report on the purported Bulgarian connection to the 1981 attack on the Pope, the Italian news agency ANSA reported.

title: I.M.F. SEEN AS UNLIKELY TO ACCEPT PLAN
description: Despite widespread sympathy for Argentina's new democracy here and in other Western capitals, its latest proposal for economic retrenchment is unlikely to satisfy the International Monetary Fund's terms for fresh loans, monetary officials and commercial bankers said today.

title: A DAY IN THE SUN FOR THE CLUB PROS
description: John Gentile is a realist with no illusions of winning the United States Open, which starts Thursday at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

title: High and Dry at the Summit
description: The leaders of the non-Communist world spent two and a half days lecturing each other last week and then issued a communique that reads as if they were in perfect harmony. It only reads that way because of what it left out.

title: Financial Plan for Fair Proposed by Governor
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards flew here today with a proposal to resolve the World's Fair's latest financial crisis: $12 million in unpaid construction bills.

title: HALIFAX ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $46,000.

title: CITY AND UNION COALITION OPEN TALKS ON CONTRACTS
description: A group representing 200,000 municipal employees presented proposals yesterday for what it described as substantial wage increases and other benefits as it opened negotiations for new contracts with the city.

title: Sallie Mae Sets Up $1 Billion of Loans
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, said yesterday tha it had agreed with the Higher Education Management and Resources Foundation to lend up to a total of $1 billion over the next five years to student loan programs in three states and Washington, D.C. The foundation is a major national servicer, guarantor and provider of student loans.

title: WESTCHESTER USED AS OPEN TUNE-UP
description: David Graham shot one of the most methodically accurate final rounds in United States Open history when he missed no fairways and only one green for a 3-under-par 67 and the 1981 title at Merion. The only green he missed was No. 9, when his ball hit the green but rolled to the back and stopped on the fringe. The Australian two-putted from there.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Monday's Payday On Men's Tour

title: CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS ON THE STATUS OF ALIENS
description: Following is a list of events that preceded today's debate on a comprehensive immigration bill:

title: STEINBERG SELLS STAKE TO DISNEY
description: Paying what analysts consider a lofty price, and substantially weakening its balance sheet at the same time, Walt Disney Productions today bought back Saul P. Steinberg's stake in the entertainment company for $325.5 million in cash.

title: A Birthday Wish
description: Dave Concepcion will celebrate his 36th birthday two days after Friday's major league trading deadline, and he wouldn't mind celebrating it outside of Cincinnati. The 14-year veteran, miffed at being moved to third base by the Reds' manager, Vern Rapp, said he wanted to return to shortstop permanently even if doing so meant going to another team.

title: AGE OF INNOCENCE ENDS
description: IT took less than four months for

title: HICKAM, DOW B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ATTACK IN SOUTH PERSIAN GULF SAID TO THREATEN NEW PHASE IN WAR
description: The air attack Sunday on a Kuwaiti supertanker, widely presumed to have been launched by Iran, threatens to open a new phase in the Persian Gulf war, Arab and Western officials said today.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net loss

title: INTER-PROVINCIAL DIVERSIIED HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $87,000.

title: 'Mayor,' Page by Page
description: A few months ago, in an attempt to

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
CHINA VS. HONG KONG
description: Despite their stated desire to keep Hong Kong stable and prosperous, China's leaders may unwittingly bring about the decline and ultimate collapse of this British colony, now the world's third largest financial center.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
;  COMPANY NEWS
description: Pic 'n' Save Rejects $23-a-Share Offer

title: Testing the Waters
description: Bella Abzug has run for the House

title: Austrian Car Cutbacks
description: Two Austrian auto makers said today that a continuing shortage of auto supplies caused by the five-week-old metalworkers' strike in West Germany would force them to make further cuts in production. BMW-Steyr, a subsidiary of BMW, said it would halt production indefinitely on Tuesday, idling 1,000 of its 1,300 employees. The Vienna subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation said 300 more employees would be added Tuesday to the 1,200 on shorter shifts.

title: CELTICS AND LAKERS SEEK EDGE
description: Pat Riley, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, described the situation as one of ''quiet desperation.'' But it was only quiet because 17,505 loyal Laker fans were stunned. Their team trailed the Boston Celtics in games, 3 to 2, and by 11 points with less than 5 minutes remaining in the third period Sunday afternoon at the Forum. It was truly desperate.

title: NEW CHAPTER IN MERRILL'S SAGA
description: One of the most important chapters in the history of Merrill Lynch & Company is about to unfold, analysts and company insiders say. In style, content and message, the new chapter will undoubtedly change the way the world's largest securities firm conducts its business. And it will determine how effective Merrill will be in competing against financial service giants such as Sears, American Express, Prudential and Citicorp for the rest of the century.

title: Tower Burns; Arsonist Dies
description: A historic tower in the Highbridge section of Manhattan was damaged by fire last night after a man set its wooden upper sections aflame and jumped more than 130 feet to his death, a police spokesman said.

title: MISS HOLM IS HONORED AT FESTIVAL
description: ''I have nothing to say in my defense,'' Hanya Holm commented as she received the Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award Sunday night at the festival's opening ceremony here at Duke University's Page Auditorium. ''It just happened, and whatever has happened was with love, dedication, good will, gladly, and well. I keep on doing it as good as I can and as long as I can.''

title: HOUSE TO DEBATE IMMIGRATION BILL DESPITE PLEAS OF HISPANIC GROUPS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to begin a long-awaited debate on a comprehensive immigration bill, overriding the objections of Hispanic groups that wanted the debate put off indefinitely.

title: Teledyne Stakes
description: Teledyne Inc. and several of its subsidiaries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had eliminated their holdings in one company and reduced them in another. The group said it had sold all of its 1,203,900 shares, or 9.1 percent of the total outstanding, of the Crown Cork and Seal Company. The Teledyne group also said it had sold 300,674 shares of Colt Industries, lowering its stake to 1,990,136 shares, or 8.5 percent of the total outstanding.

title: VERNON JORDAN CALLS FOR THE REBUILDING OF BLACK-JEWISH TIES
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, called last night for a rebuilding of the ''historic alliance'' between blacks and Jews in the wake of the Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Includes a $226,000 anticipated loss on the disposition of three restaurants subsequent to April 1, 1984, for the quarter and year. c-Includes a $4.6 million charge based in an estimate of the disposal costs for certain restaurants. d-Includes a gain of $498,000 on the sale of a restaurant and a parcel of undeveloped land and an extraordinary gain of $339,000, or 10 cents a share, on the exchange of common stock for debt. The latest quarter and year had 12 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, while the year-earlier periods had 13 weeks and 53 weeks.

title: BRINK'S DEFENDANT DENIES AN ACTIVE ROLE IN ROBBERY
description: Samuel Brown took the witness stand in Westchester County Court today to deny that he was an active participant in the 1981 robbery of a Brink's armored truck in which a guard and two police officers were killed.

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $8,313 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $14,058 from discontinued operations.

title: TEMPLE RAID PUTS SIKHS 'IN A VERY FOUL MOOD'
description: A light rain today, harbinger of the coming monsoon, soaked the woven jute carpets leading to the golden-domed Bangla Sahib gurdwara, or Sikh temple, here.

title: Marriott Chain
description: The Marriott Corporation said it plans to start a national chain of moderately priced Courtyard by Marriott hotels, opening 20 to 30 properties over the next 18 months. Total investment over the next five years could be between $1 billion and $2 billion, the hotel and food service operator said. It said the new hotels would look ''like modern country inns'' and have 130 to 150 rooms priced at $35 to $55 a night.

title: THE TAX TITANS: A DYNAMIC DUO
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, bring more than their tax knowledge and their chairman's prerogatives to bear on the tax-writing process.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: WORLD OF CABARET CELEBRATES MABEL MERCER AND MEMORIES
description: Some 30 performing artists and 1,500 friends and admirers of Mabel Mercer gathered at Town Hall on Sunday evening for a memorial concert celebrating the music and spirit of the singer who died in April at the age of 84.

title: Sweden and Norway Planning A 'Peace Ship' for Nicaragua STOCKHOLM, June 11 (Reuters) - Sweden will join Norway in sending a ''peace ship'' with gifts to Nicaragua, escorted by minesweepers, as long as this is not part of a military operation, a Foreign Ministry statement said today.
description: Sweden would send paper worth $375,000 to be used for voting slips in the Nicaraguan presidential elections in November, the statement said.

title: Power Fails in Pittsburgh
description: Five high-voltage circuits feeding downtown Pittsburgh failed today, leaving many office buildings without light or air conditioning in 86-degree weather.

title: Elementary University of Iowa officials agreed yesterday to give an accounting to the Big Ten on the academic credit given to six former Hawkeye basketball players for a course whose reading list came entirely from recommendations made in a book called ''Sports Books for Children.'' The required reading for ''Hawkeye Insights,'' the name of the indepedent-study course, included such books as ''Dr. J.: The Story of Julius Erving'' and ''Incredible Basketball Feats.'' The players were told to produce a videotape or booklet on Hawkeye basketball but never completed the projects, concedes
description: Bradley Loomer , the professor of education who taught the class between 1981 and 1983. The players who got credit were Bobby Hansen , Mark Gannon , Kevin Boyle , Kenny Arnold, Mike Henry and Waymond King .

title: U.S. NEWS IS SOLD TO ZUCKERMAN
description: U.S. News & World Report Inc. and Mortimer Zuckerman announced today that the 47-year-old Boston real estate developer, who is also the publisher and owner of The Atlantic, had bought the weekly news magazine and the company's other properties for $168.5 million, or about $2,800 a share.

title: 46 Protesters Arrested At Base in West Germany
description: West German police arrested 46 people today in a confrontation with the 700 antinuclear protesters who had blockaded the barracks of a United States Army base where Pershing missiles are stationed.

title: TOP BLACK DEMOCRATS OPEN UNITY TALKS WITH JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today enlisted the aid of leading members of the Congressional Black Caucus, some of whom support Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, for a discussion of his platform positions and his contention that a number of the party rules are unfair.

title: SOVIET, URGING TALKS, INSISTS SPACE ARMS CAN BE VERIFIED
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, called on the United States today to start immediate negotiations on banning antisatellite and other space weapons.

title: U.S. WANTS NO VICTOR IN GULF
description: A high- ranking State Department official told Congress today that the Administration's basic position in the war between Iran and Iraq was that ''a victory by either side is neither militarily achievable nor strategically desirable.''

title: Sri Lanka Places Censorship On Dispatches About Rebels
description: Sri Lanka's Government, faced with growing agitation over its decision to seek Israeli help in fighting guerrillas, said it was imposing press censorship on reports dealing with the rebels, effective tonight.

title: Met Opera ToSellVideos
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday an agreement with Pioneer Artists, a division of Pioneer Video Inc., to market ''Live From the Met'' performances on laser video disks.

title: TAKE YOUR EYE OFF THE BALL, SCIENTIST COACHES SLUGGERS
description: FROM the sandlots to the big leagues, baseball batters are constantly told to ''Keep your eye on the ball.'' But this piece of sage advice, which has been passed from coach to batter since the days of Abner Doubleday, has now come under scientific challenge.

title: ADVERTISING
description: * Harold Katz promoted to executive vice president of Vitt Media International.

title: BOGOTA'S STREET URCHINS COME IN FROM THE COLD
description: Dressed in filthy baggy clothes, gangs of street kids wander through Bogota at all hours, begging and stealing and then falling asleep hundled together in doorways.

title: ENERGY OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Wooing Colt Fans After the Colts left for Indianapolis,
description: Leonard Tose , owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, spent $250 to buy a list of Baltimore season-ticket holders. He's now hoping to woo some of those disgruntled fans with direct-mail letters pointing out that Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia is only a 90-minute drive from Baltimore. ''It's a shot in the dark,'' said Paula Yudenfriend, an Eagles publicity aide.

title: HEMISPHERE DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $866,200 for the quarter and year.

title: SHIPS SAIL FOR LATIN WAR GAMES
description: Four United States Navy surface ships and two submarines left American ports today to join forces with eight South American countries for war games in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and the Caribbean, the Navy said.

title: INDIA AGAINST ITSELF
description: At a time when Indians seem ever more ready to kill one another over religious, class, language and ethnic differences, the Government's military assault on the Golden Temple complex in Amritsar looms as a terrifying failure of the democratic process. Reports that several detachments of Sikh troops have mutinied seem no less ominous.

title: Reuters Shares
description: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, a Government agency, has told Reuters Holdings that it has bought 36.5 million, or 12.5 percent, of the ''B'' limited voting shares in the news organization, Reuters said.

title: Moscow Denies Report Of U.S. Aide's Beating
description: The Soviet Union denied today that a United States diplomat had been beaten up recently outside a Leningrad restaurant, and it rebuked the American correspondent, Robert Gillette of The Los Angeles Times, who first reported the incident.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 12, 1984

title: A BIAS PUTS SELF AT CENTER OF EVERYTHING
description: NOTHING, wrote Walt Whitman 'is greater to one than one's self is.'' Whitman's words in ''Song of Myself'' are true for people not only in the obvious ways, researchers are now affirming, but also in a multitude of subtle forms that have not previously been known.

title: SWEATERS: A CHOICE CROP FOR FALL SEASON
description: Tweed, gabardine, cheviot, flannel - these are the fabrics of fall daytime clothes, many adapted from men's fashions. Satin, lace, lame and velvet - these are their counterparts for evening.

title: PITY THE FRAMED SHEEPSKIN ABOVE THE WASHER
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS Castle & Cooke To Cut Some Units
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the food company that markets Dole bananas and Bumble Bee tuna, said yesterday that it plans to get out of a number of low-return businesses and take a $78 million after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings. ''What we're doing here is cleaning house,'' said Ian Wilson, president and chief executive officer.

title: Fighting for a Future
description: Larry Pringle, a 26-year-old lightweight boxer, made his pro debut Saturday night, scoring a four-round victory over Stanley Bryant , and then returned under guard to Lorton Reformatory, a prison in the Virginia countryside.

title: POPE JOINS EUROPEAN LEADERS IN EXPRESSIONS OF CONDOLENCE
description: The announcement of Enrico Berlinguer's death prompted a steady flow of messages of condolence to his family and the Central Committee of the party he led for 12 years, expressing respect for the tenacity with which Mr. Berlinguer pursued his political objectives.

title: AGRARIAN NEW MEXICO SEEKS A SILICON HARVEST
description: New Mexico, a land whose stark beauty is as stunning as its economy is backward, is trying to take a giant leap forward from a 19th-century agrarian economy directly into the high-technology future.

title: PLANS TO RELEASE NEW ORGANISMS INTO NATURE SPUR CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON THE rapidly approaching day when American scientists and industry will begin releasing new genetically engineered organisms into the environment is sending shivers of apprehension through many prominent ecologists.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ACF Industries, a diversified railroad freight and tank car company, said shareholders had approved a merger with a group led by Carl C. Icahn for a previously announced $54.50 a share.

title: Egypt Oil Reserves Up
description: Egypt's petroleum reserves have risen 7 percent since 1982, to 4.5 billion barrels, the country's oil minister, Ahmed D. Hilal, said today. He predicted that Egyptian crude oil production would rise to 1 million barrels a day in 1985 from 900,000 barrels a day now.

title: SOLAR AIR-CONDITIONING UNITS
description: THE very sun that is responsible for all the heat may be used to drive new, more efficient air-conditioning systems, according to research being conducted at the University of California's Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory. Tests of a prototype machine were reported to have demonstrated the validity of the new air-conditioning concept.

title: 4 MORE DIE
description: Four heat-related deaths were reported in New York City yesterday as 90-plus temperatures continued for the fifth consecutive day in the metropolitan area.

title: NICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $50,000. c-Including tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 9 months. d-Including a tax credit of $80,000.

title: Jersey Approves Lottery Changes
description: The New Jersey Lottery Commission today approved changes in the Pick 6 weekly lottery to make it harder to win.

title: NEW INK-JET PRINTER
description: -clack of a typewriter, word processing on a computer is silence itself - until one turns on the printer. Then one might as well be sitting in a machine-gun nest.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: b-Includes a gain of $807,000, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: U.S. REPORT ON SUBWAYS CITES FLAWS
description: A Federal inspection of 100 miles of New York City's subway tracks has found 339 defects, some of which could lead to safety problems, according to a report released yesterday. It concluded that the system was badly inspected and maintained.

title: NOVAMETRIX MEDICAL SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Headline
description: ''If Christ's temple were destroyed, what would Christians say? What has happened is not tolerable to the Sikh community.'' - Jagjit Singh, in New Delhi. (A6:1.)

title: A.M.C. to Build Plant in Ontario
description: The American Motors Corporation said it plans to build a $764 million plant in Brampton, Ontario, to produce French-designed intermediate front- wheel-drive cars beginning in July 1987. A.M.C. said it had signed a letter of agreement with Canadian banks for a proposed $300 million secured loan to finance the construction. Additional financing will come from the Canadian Government and from the Ontario provincial government, which will share in up to $121 million of the plant cost, and from company equity, A.M.C. said.

title: Kennedy Asks Senate Panel To Assess Philippine Voting
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to hold hearings on allegations of fraud in the National Assembly elections held on May 14 in the Philippines.

title: MAINFRAME PLAN ENDED BY TRILOGY
description: Trilogy Ltd., the once-promising high-technology company started by Gene M. Amdahl four years ago to build a super-fast mainframe computer that would rival I.B.M.'s top-of- the-line machines, said yesterday that it was abandoning the project.

title: YANKEES DEFEATED BY 6-RUN 9TH INNING
description: Many Fenway Park fans refused to leave tonight until Reid Nichols made an encore appearance out of the Boston dugout after the game. Nichols was their hero because Dave Righetti had to make one too many appearances out of the Yankees' bullpen this past weekend.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $13,000.

title: THREE FINE DOUBLES TEAMS
description: Serene John McEnroe had blown a

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WIESEL CITED AT CEREMONY IN NEW YORK
description: Elie Wiesel and Naphtali Lavie, two men who were liberated from the Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald 39 years ago, were honored last night in Manhattan by Bar-Ilan University, an Israeli school chartered by the New York State Board of Regents.

title: Freddie Mac Plans A New Certificate
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell a new kind of mortgage participation certificate with a maximum maturity of 15 years.

title: LET BANKS ALSO CARRY THE LATING MILLSTONE
description: The usual list of reasons why the banks are having trouble with their Latin American debtors includes high oil prices, recession in the industrial nations and brutal United States interest rates. But another element, the issue of ''legitimacy,'' may be moving to center stage. Led by Argentina, the Latin governments are beginning to say they will not sweat their people to pay back loans made by bankers who knew the money was being spent not for economic development but to enrich crooks in previous governments and state-run enterprises.

title: INDIA EVENTS: A NEW ORDER OF DIFFICULTY
description: Two years ago, an obscure, black-bearded Sikh preacher named Bhindranwale was swaggering around Amritsar's Golden Temple, wearing his turban, bandoleer and Sikh warrior's sword. He railed against the Government, but was not taken very seriously.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF STRUGGLE FOR DISNEY
description: Here are the events that led up to yesterday's purchase by Walt Disney Productions of the stake held by Saul P. Steinberg:

title: A REFORMER'S BATTLE
description: EARLY in this century a Boston surgeon, Dr. Ernest A. Codman, proposed a revolutionary approach to make doctors more accountable for their work. He tried to persuade doctors to give a follow-up examination to their patients a year after treatment to create a kind of scorecard of the treatment's success. And he wanted that success- or-fail data accumulated so that patients would have an idea of how to shop for doctors. The competition, he felt, could only raise standards and lower prices.

title: Raffling Off an Empress
description: Dazzling white in the hot sun, the

title: Eagleton Will Not Seek 4th Term in Senate
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, announced today that he would not seek re-election when his third term expires in 1986.

title: Hitachi to Cut I.B.M. Funds
description: Payments being made by Hitachi Ltd. to the International Business Machines Corporation will decrease as Hitachi develops new software, Hitachi officials said yesterday.

title: Foreign Issue Of USA Today
description: USA Today, the Gannett Company's national daily newspaper, will begin distributing an international edition in Europe and parts of the Middle East on July 10, according to Allen H. Neuharth, chairman.

title: GOODEN, OROSCO DEFEAT PIRATES
description: More dazzling pitching from Dwight Gooden, home runs by Keith Hernandez and Hubie Brooks and a loss by the Cubs last night moved the Mets within a half-game of first place in the National League East.

title: Economic Scene; Post-Election Slowdown?
description: THE United States economy is expanding so

title: RATES FALL SLIGHTLY; TRADER ACTIVITY UP
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday on increased trading activity, though investor demand was modest.

title: No Headline
description: What's Special About Liquor? Let's say K-Mart sold tennis balls for a discount price just a few pennies over cost, less than local sporting goods shops could charge while making a decent profit. Should the state set, and enforce, minimum tennis ball prices high enough to keep the sporting goods stores in business?

title: Lotto Winner Faced Loss of Job
description: Two weeks ago, Frances Anne Blakely learned she might lose her job teaching learning-disabled students in Bethpage High School because of declining enrollment.

title: G.& W. TO SELL DOMINICAN HOLDINGS
description: In a move that would end nearly 20 years of involvement in the Dominican Republic, Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it would try to sell its sugar growing operations and holdings there.

title: Unrest in Cincinnati
description: The Cincinnati Reds haven't been doing well this year, and, with the major league trading deadline just two days away, there is speculation that they may be interested in some player exchanges. The speculation picked up yesterday after Dan Driessen, the Reds' 32-year-old first baseman, became the second Cincinnati infielder this week to indicate that he would be willing to be traded.

title: CRENSHAW LIKES WINGED FOOT CONTOURS
description: Ben Crenshaw was acting like a kid with a new toy as he hit golf balls and walked after them over the beautiful Winged Foot Golf Club's West Course.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Inflation in Sweden
description: Swedish industrial executives think the inflation rate in 1985 will reach 7 percent, far exceeding the Government's goal of 3 percent, Dagens Industri, a Swedish business daily, said today. In a survey commissioned by the newspaper, most of 101 executives polled also said they saw an increase in wage costs of 7.8 percent in 1985, well above the 5 percent voluntary cap that the Government is urging unions to accept.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day yesterday about Bella Abzug's possible candidacy for the House of Representatives in Westchester County incorrectly described the residency requirement. House members need only to be residents of the states that elect them.

title: Article 258276 -- No Title
description: A proposed friendly takeover of the Enstar Corporation was sweetened yesterday to $20 a share in cash for 51 percent of the common shares. The original tender offer, also for 51 percent, was for $18 in cash and $2 in securities.

title: No Headline
description: The Eurocommunist Enrico Berlinguer, who died Monday at the age of 62, headed the Italian Communist Party, the largest in the West, but he followed no standard party line.

title: WESTWAY: UNDESIRABLE FOR FISH AND MAN ALIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'PAMPERED PETS'
description: Oil portraits of Pomeranians, King

title: IN AFRICA, YOU NEED A LONG MEMORY
description: Though plagued by drought, famine, war and rebellion, Africans display a peculiar half- tamed energy and vitality that speaks of an exciting future. They are the oldest people on the planet, yet their average age is very young. Fully 45 percent of all Africans are under 15, compared with less than a third of the rest of us. Yet in Africa you need a long memory to explain the present.

title: Filipino Opposition Lauds Aquino as Hero
description: Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, was proclaimed a national hero of Filipinos at an Independence Day gathering of opposition parties tonight.

title: SENATORS VOTE FOR BILL CURBING SPACE WEAPONS
description: The Senate tonight approved a compromise measure that would forbid Pentagon spending to test American antisatellite weapons unless President Reagan certifies that he is ''endeavoring, in good faith to negotiate the strictest possible limitations on antisatellite weapons.''

title: DELOREAN PROSECUTOR REVERSES HIMSELF, SAYS HE HAS PRETRIAL NOTES
description: The prosecutor in John Z. DeLorean's drug trial reversed himself today and told the judge that he did have some notes on potentially important meetings he had last year to discuss a Government informer's unrecorded telephone calls to Mr. DeLorean.

title: SENIORITY IS HELD TO OUTWEIGH RACE AS A LAYOFF GUIDE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a court may not order an employer to protect the jobs of recently hired black employees at the expense of whites who have more seniority.

title: THE WHOLE-GRAIN MOVEMENT CARRIES ON
description: MANY members of the 1960's counterculture have shed their tie-dyed T-shirts and thong sandals and now don traditional three- piece suits. But there is evidence that the style of that generation has not faded completely. A cookbook called ''Uprisings, the Whole Grain Bakers Book,'' is a good example.

title: 7 EUROPEAN AIDES MEET TO BOLSTER NATO TIES
description: Seven foreign ministers from European NATO countries met here today in what they said was an attempt to strengthen the European pillar of the alliance.

title: TRIAL DATE IS SET FOR 4 SOLIDARITY ADVISERS
description: One day after Jacek Kuron, one of four detained Solidarity advisers, began a hunger strike to press the group's demand for either freedom or a hearing, defense lawyers were told today told that a sedition trial of the four would begin July 13.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allegheny International Inc., the Pittsburgh-based manufacturer of consumer and industrial products, has named F. George Scott senior vice president, human resources.

title: DANCE: BAUSCH TROUPE MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THE word was out, the place was mobbed. Pina Bausch, from West Germany, is the most talked-about choreographer in Europe and it was obvious that her reputation had preceded her at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, where the Pina Bausch Wuppertaler Tanztheater made its New York debut.

title: Leaders March to Call For Reagan's Defeat
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, led women's rights leaders and peace activists today in a symbolic ''race'' from the Capitol to the White House to draw attention to what she called President Reagan's ''Stone Age attitudes towards women.''

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect the 50 percent stock dividend, accounted for as a 3-for-2 split, paid July 15.

title: LIMIT ON INSANITY DEFENSE IS APPROVED IN ALBANY
description: Legislation to make it harder to use insanity as a defense in criminal trials was given final passage today by the State Assembly.

title: Justice Department Enters 3 Voting Suits
description: The Justice Department said Monday that it had moved to take part in three private lawsuits challenging at-large elections in Georgia, New Mexico and North Carolina.

title: INDIAN ARMY ASSERTS SIKH TROOP REVOLT HAS ENDED
description: At least 12 more Sikh deserters from the Indian Army were reported killed today and nearly 350 more were arrested.

title: Sundstrand Seeks All of Sullair Stock
description: The Sundstrand Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Sullair Corporation for $8.50 a share, or a total of about $74 million for the 89.3 percent of Sullair stock it does not already own.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dorothy Hamill , the figure-skating star, told the Los Angeles police that burglars had made off with $150,000 worth of jewelry from her home, which is situated in the exclusive Beverly Glen area. . . . Matt Robinson , the former Jet who is now a quarterback for the Jacksonville Bulls, has never fully recovered from a foot injury that caused him to miss six games earlier this year. So he will be benched for the rest of the season while he begins a rehabilitation program, Coach Lindy Infante announced. Robbie Mahfouz is his replacement.

title: NURSING OF INFANTS ADVOCATED
description: Mother's milk is ''not substitutable,'' and employers and hospitals should be more sensitive to women who want to breast-feed their babies, according to the Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop.

title: Soviet Aide Asserts Protests On Sakharov Don't Help Him
description: A Soviet Embassy aide said here today that protests over the plight of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, were intended to create an artificial crisis and would not help him.

title: WHAT'S IN WHILE IT'S HOT
description: Hot question of the week: how to keep cool and still look fashionable.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,078,000 for the quarter and $1,883,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $243,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the 9 months. The figures for both year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued oil and gas exploration and production operations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREASURE HOUSE It is impossible to skim through the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street (685-0008), because everything on show is either priceless and/ or beautiful and too fascinating to be skimmed or lumped.

title: BABY-SITTING CO-OPS THRIVING IN CITY
description: TO many parents, the best baby sitter is another parent. This philosophy is the one behind the baby-sitting cooperatives in the city that allow parents to provide child care and pay each other back in kind.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Let's just get together and talk about the general world situation, 'cause we've got to figure out some way not to blow each other up.''

title: KARAJAN BACKER OUSTED
description: The Mayor of West Berlin today announced the dismissal of Peter Girth, general manager of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, in an effort to end an acrimonious quarrel between the orchestra and its principal conductor, Herbert von Karajan.

title: CBI Is Purchasing Houston Gas Unit
description: CBI Industries said yesterday that it would buy the Liquid Carbonic Corporation from the Houston Natural Gas Corporation for $407 million.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Fans arriving at the park very early will get a chance to see some future Mets, as the Tidewater farm team takes on Pawtucket in a regularly scheduled International League game starting at 4:15 P.M. Scott Holman is scheduled to start for the Tides, whose outfield features Herm Winningham, one of the league's leading hitters.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $23.7 million for the quarter and $3.5 million for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5.4 million for the quarter and $12.5 million for the 9 months. The net income includes $32.7 million for the latest 9 months and $30.9 million and $85.8 million for the year- earlier quarter and 9 months, respectively, of earnings from the company's marketable portfolio, after assuming an allocation of interest expense and income taxes.

title: A NO. 1 IN BOXING SEEKS RECOGNITION
description: Like many boxers at last week's Olympic tials in Fort Worth, Pernell (Pete) Whitaker spent much of his free time in the lobby of the hotel, as if it were the neighborhood gym or a favorite hangout in his hometown. He wore a sweatsuit, high-top shoes and a baseball cap - a gold-medal favorite for the Summer Games perhaps, but just another fighter, compared to the attention given Mark Breland and even the heavyweight newcomer, Mike Tyson.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Comecon Talks Begin
description: Ten Communist nations today began their first economic summit conference since 1971, with energy supplies believed to be a crucial issue.

title: REDLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $28,125 for the quarter and $89,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: CHARITY DISPUTE SPLITS TWO FUNDS
description: Leaders of the National Black United Fund say that despite a three-year campaign most large corporations have not allowed their employees to earmark payroll deductions for the charity organization.

title: 7 Executed in Upper Volta
description: Upper Volta's left- wing Government has executed seven people convicted of involvement in an abortive coup against President Thomas Sankara, officials said today. The seven went before a firing squad Monday immediately after being found guilty by court-martial of the May 28 coup attempt, the officials said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; TRANSITIONS
description: When members of the audience

title: BRIEFING
description: Superpower Animosity

title: JAPANESE TO OPEN BOUTIQUES ON MADISON
description: Amid the banks and institutions of Madison Avenue below 60th Street, one of Japan's largest women's apparel and accessories manufacturers plans to open a mini-mall of designer- named clothing boutiques next August.

title: EX-DAILY NEWS CORRESPONDENT
description: Bernard Valery, a longtime Paris correspondent for The Daily News, died here Monday after a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: Finding the Right Buyer For Binney & Smith
description: A skilled marketer, Jack F. Kofoed has chalked up a big sale, totaling $203.5 million to be exact.

title: LEBANESE CABINET WINS A TEST VOTE
description: Lebanon's new Government won a vote of confidence from Parliament today after a week of heated debates and of heightened violence that claimed the lives of 150 people since the Cabinet was formed six weeks ago.

title: BRIBERY TRIAL OF CHICAGO JUDGE GOES TO JURY
