description: The bribery trial of Judge John M. Murphy, the first judge to be tried as a result of a Federal undercover investigation of the Chicago court system went to the jury today.

title: U.S. CHARGES THAT DRUG CONCERN FAILED TO WARN OF ADVERSE EFFECTS
description: A major pharmaceutical company was charged today with failing to warn consumers and the Federal Government about dangerous side effects of a drug to combat high blood pressure it marketed for eight months.

title: FILM: HUSTON'S 'UNDER THE VOLCANO'
description: BY the time Malcolm Lowry had finished filling ''Under the Volcano'' with ''signs, natural phenomena, snatches of poems and songs, pictures, remembered books and films, shadowy figures appearing, disappearing, and reappearing,'' according to Douglas Day, Mr. Lowry's biographer, the book ''finally became not a novel at all but a kind of monument to prodigality of vision.'' Certainly it evolved, as Mr. Lowry expanded his short story of the same name into the 1947 novel, into one of the most haunting and difficult works of modern fiction.

title: NEWS FROM PUNJAB: HOW NEW DELHI CURBS WHAT IS REPORTED
description: Anyone listening tonight to the Government-run All India Radio's main newscast would have learned that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was ''anguished'' by the developments in Punjab but that the situation there was improving. Listeners would have also learned that President Zail Singh felt that religion and politics should not be mixed.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: STAGE: 'BLUE WINDOW,' PRODUCTION COMPANY
description: LATE in Craig Lucas's ''Blue Window,'' a character wonders why everyone has been asked to Libby's dinner party. The question has been puzzling us since the first invitation extended by Libby at the beginning of the play. Most of the people have only a passing acquaintance with their hostess and they have very little in common with each other except for the fact that they are on Mr. Lucas's guest list. Once they gather, the conversation runs the gamut all the way from chit to chat.

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Medical Care Account
description: The Chicago office of Young & Rubicam has become agency for Medfirst, a medical treatment business operated by Humana Inc., of Louisville, Ky.

title: ; A TALL SHIP'S LASST CHALLENGE TO THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: DORSET RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the American Museum of Natural History yesterday misstated the trustees' position on a statement to accompany ''Ancestors,'' an exhibition that includes fossils from South Africa. The board will post a statement saying the exhibition ''demonstrates the common ancestry of all humans and the irrationality of racism.''

title: Vatican Disputes Book On Death of John Paul I
description: The Vatican yesterday dismissed as ''absurb fantasies'' the charges contained in ''In God's Name: An Investigation Into the Murder of Pope John Paul I'' by David A. Yallop.

title: Plan to Control Floods Described
description: A $930 million, 11-year flood-control plan for the Passaic River was displayed here tonight. It calls for a 14- mile, 40-foot-diameter tunnel to divert water from the an area that has suffered millions of dollars in flood damage.

title: PANEL ASKS PROTECTION FOR STEEL
description: A divided International Trade Commission found today that the American steel industry was being seriously injured by imports and that trade barriers should be raised to protect a number of its major product lines.

title: STAGE: PATRICK MEYERS'S 'JUST LIKE THE LIONS'
description: PATRICK MEYERS is an unpredictable dramatist, changing his coloration, environment and style from play to play. His first, ''Feedlot,'' was a claustrophobic drama about men and beasts confined in a Texas cattleyard. His most recent, ''K2,'' was a cliffhanging adventure about mountain climbers dangling at the top of the world. What surprises - and saddens - us about his new work, ''Just Like the Lions'' (at the Double Image Theater) is that Mr. Meyers is capable of writing what might as well be two different, bad plays at the same time.

title: 'Killebrew Day'
description: The Senators are long gone from Washington; the memories, however, are alive.

title: Drop in Finnish Jobless
description: Finland's unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent in May from 5.6 percent in April and 4.9 percent a year earlier, the Labor Ministry said today. There were 115,000 jobless workers in May, down from 144,000 in April and 121,500 a year earlier, the ministry said.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL COMPLETES ITS HEARINGS ON PLATFORM IDEAS
description: The Democratic National Convention's platform committee concluded its hearings today, having received suggestions for the 1984 party program from more than 1,000 witnesses around the country. A small working group, 15 of the 184 members, will begin formal drafting sessions here Sunday.

title: THE COACHING RIVALS' ROAD TO THE TOP
description: BOSTON One looks like an actor, the other sings in public for recreation. Yet there is very little show biz about the two recent assistant coaches who were paired against each other in last night's National Basketball Association showdown.

title: CUOMO OFFERS NEW PLAN FOR WASTE SITE CLEANUP
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed an $850 million program to clean up hundreds of hazardous-waste sites across New York by the end of the century.

title: NURSING HOME UNDER INQUIRY AFTER 4 DEATHS
description: The State Health Department said last night that it was investigating whether a breakdown of air-conditioning at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan contributed to the deaths of four elderly patients during last weekend's heat.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT DECISION ON RIGHTS OF SUSPECTS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today creating a ''public safety exception'' to the Miranda doctrine. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor dissented in part. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote a dissenting opinion.

title: No Headline
description: Just 48 hours after winning his first grand-slam title, Ivan Lendl suffered a surprising setback when he was defeated by an unheralded American, Leif Shiras, in the first round of the $200,000 Queen's Club grass-court tennis championships today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Belzberg Bank Unit Names a President
description: Stephen Shulman was named president and chief operating officer yesterday of the First City Capital Corporation, the New York-based merchant banking subsidiary of the Belzberg family's First City Financial Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: CAUTION: DENIZENS AHEAD
description: In New York we have an ambitious plan for upgrading the Times Square neighborhood. This used to be known as ''the Crossroads of the World,'' but now, unhappily, it has become a neighborhood that has denizens.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Figs Italian Style

title: UPSWING IN FISH EATING FOR PLEASURE AND HEALTH
description: THERE is a fresh excitement to the subject of fish and fish cooking these days. It comes partly from health considerations, as more people recognize the importance of fish in a healthful diet; partly from greatly increased availability all over the country in the last few years of a wider variety of fish, and partly from a new understanding of an old truth, that fresh fish, simply prepared, is a delightful item on any menu, whether the home cook's or the restaurateur's.

title: REACTION IS MIXED ON COURT DECISION
description: Some leaders of civil rights groups and women's organizations said yesterday that the Supreme Court's decision in the Memphis firefighters' case was a serious blow to the principle of affirmative action, but others said the ruling would have only limited application.

title: Careers; Finding Your Way To the Top
description: THE succession to top corporate

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 13, 1984 International
description: East-West summit talks were urged by two Senate Republican leaders because relations are so tense. The urgent appeal was made to President Reagan by the Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., and Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. However, the Administration reiterated its view that any meeting between Mr. Reagan and the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, should be carefully prepared and offer the prospect of tangible results. (Page A1, Column 1.) At least 12 more Sikh deserters from the Indian Army were reported killed and nearly 350 more were arrested. Military officials in New Delhi said the scattered three-day revolt by Sikh troops was ending. (A1:1-3.)

title: FISH IS GOOD FOR THE HEART
description: YOUR mother may have told you that fish was ''brain food'' (and there is now evidence she may have been right), but folk wisdom missed a valuable asset of fish that medical scientists have only recently discovered: its apparent protective effect on the heart and blood vessels.

title: 2 Seized at Bush Residence As President Attends Party
description: Two men, one armed with a pellet gun, were arrested several hundred yards from Vice President Bush's home where President Reagan was visiting tonight to help Mr. Bush celebrate his 60th birthday, the Secret Service said.

title: St. Regis Will Buy Colonial Penn Group
description: The St. Regis Corporation will buy all the stock of the Colonial Penn Group under a definitive agreement announced by the companies yesterday. The deal could have a total value of about $570 million.

title: British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace P. L. C. said it had ended the four-week-old merger talks with Thorn EMI P. L. C., a major electrical group. British Aerosapce said its board had decided that the financial and commercial disadvantages of merging would outweigh any advantages.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income

title: Fischbach Plan
description: An investment group led by Ivan Boesky, a New York City investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is seeking clearance from the Government to purchase more than 15 percent of the common stock outstanding of the Fischbach Corporation.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After tax credits of $642,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss after a loss of $854,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a gain of $455,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Top Management Shifts At New York Subways
description: Marvin Schwartz, 56 years old and 14 years president of New York Subways Advertising, has stepped up to chairman to make room for William M. Apfelbaum, 37, who will be president after 13 years with the company, most recently as executive vice president. Mr. Schwartz continues as chief executive.

title: Japan Cars For Canada
description: Japan will be allowed to export between 166,000 and 170,000 cars to Canada in the fiscal year ending next March 31, up from 153,000 a year earlier, officials of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Glenn Open to Second Spot
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio, who dropped out of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in March, said today he would consider a Vice-Presidential nomination but would not automatically accept it. ''We'd have to consider it,'' Mr. Glenn told reporters at his Senate office in answer to the question. But he added quickly that he thought the possibility that he would be named was unlikely.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Elders IXL Ltd., an Austrailian agricultural, brewing and finance company, made its debut in the Eurobond market with a $130 million convertible issue due in 10 years through Swiss Bank Corp. The 11 3/8 percent bonds were offered at 93 1/4 to yield 11.6 percent and may be converted into stock at a price to be announced later.

title: THE SCRAMBLE TO OWN CONRAIL
description: The approaching Monday deadline for submitting bids for Conrail has set off a flurry of activity, as the various bidders and constituents attempt to improve their positions.

title: Fining of Marc Rich Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling that required the Marc Rich commodities concern in Switzerland to pay $50,000 a day in fines for refusing to turn over records in a Government tax-fraud investigation.

title: Utility Offering
description: A $50 million issue of the Western Massachusetts Electric Company's 15 percent bonds due in 1994 is offered at 98 7/8 to yield 15.218 percent through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. The bonds, rated Baa-2/ BBB-, are not refundable for five years.

title: DR. MOSHE HELD
description: Dr. Moshe Held, professor of Semitic languages and cultures at Columbia University, died Saturday in Beersheba, Israel. He was 60 years old and lived in Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: U. OF CHICAGO FINDS INTELLECT AND PLEASURE DO MIX
description: When the University of Chicago decided to break up the long winter months by holding a winter carnival last year, administrators and students went well beyond the typical round of sporting events, pajama parties and dances.

title: THE BRITISH PUB RUNS AFOUL OF CHANGING TIMES
description: The British pub, whose praises are sung in legend, song and tourist guidebooks, has fallen on hard times.

title: Cavaliers Scan Draft
description: World B. Free may be for sale. The 30-year-old Cleveland sharpshooter and one of his teammates, Cliff Robinson , have both reportedly been put on the trading block in an effort to get the Cavaliers a higher choice in the National Basketball Association draft next week.

title: Reagan News Conference
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference Thursday at 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, at the White House, it was announced today. The news conference, to be nationally televised, is to be the 25th of Mr. Reagan's Presidency. One of main topics is expected to be Mr. Reagan's reaction to a proposal by Senators Howard H. Baker Jr. and Charles H. Percy that the President hold annual summit meetings with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader.

title: Citicorp Rate Up
description: Interest rates rose at this week's auctions of commercial paper issued by Citicorp. For $100 million of 91-day paper the average rate was 11.195 percent, up from 11.007 percent, and for $50 million of 182-day paper the average rate was 11.563 percent, up from 11.386 percent.

title: THE KNOWN LESSONS OF THE VIETNAM WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH TIDE FOR RAFTS AND DIGS
description: In Montana recently some of the old Western absolutes about water ownership got a new twist when the state's highest court ruled that the public was allowed to wade, float, fish or swim and otherwise enjoy the water in state-owned streams even when both shores of the stream are private property.
THE KENNEDYS. An American Drama.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT DECISION IN THE SENIORITY CASE
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in its decision that courts cannot order employees to modify valid seniority systems in order to protect recently hired black workers. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Harry A. Backmun wrote the dissent.

title: HIGH COURT CURBS RIGHT OF SUSPECT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that ''overriding considerations of public safety'' may justify the police in questioning a suspect in custody without first advising him of his right not to incriminate himself.

title: Garment Industry Studies Problems
description: The city, employers in the garment industry and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced yesterday that they were forming a nonprofit corporation to study the problems of the industry.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings was restated to reflect the effect of a 3-for-2 stock split on Oct. 27, 1983.

title: National Steel
description: The Justice Department said it would not challenge on antitrust grounds a proposal by Nippon Kokan Kabushiki Kaisha to purchase 50 percent of the shares of the National Steel Corporation. J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the transaction did not present competitive problems. Under the proposal, Nippon, Japan's second-largest steelmaker, would pay $292 million for 50 percent of the shares outstanding of National Steel, which is a unit of National Intergroup Inc. The purchase marks the largest move by a foreign steelmaker into the American market.

title: Long-Term Pill Supply Taken
description: Enough birth control pills to last a woman 17 years were stolen from the Dakota Family Planning Center, an official said. The theft occurred over the weekend and was discovered Monday morning, officials said today.

title: SERVAMATIC SOLAR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $191,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest year and $1,029,000, or 4 cents a share, for the earlier year.

title: Lockridge Keeps Lightweight Title
description: Rocky Lockridge knocked out Tae Jin Moon of South Korea in the 11th round last night to retain his World Boxing Association junior lightweight title.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Dome Files Prospectus With S.E.C. and Canada
description: The Dome Petroleum Company said today that it had filed a preliminary prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission and Canadian regulatory agencies for an offering of shares and warrants.

title: ATOM PLANT MAY BE CANCELED
description: The Consumers Power Company said yesterday that its directors would probably cancel its two-unit nuclear project in Midland, Mich., on Friday unless there is ''substantial progress'' on how customers and stockholders would share the project's costs.

title: Molloy, Tech Win Titles
description: Bill Morello hurled a three-hitter yesterday and led Archbishop

title: ARREST IN QUEENS THE CATALYST
description: -year-old woman hailed a police car in Queens and told the two officers inside that a gunman had just raped her. She said the assailant had gone into an A.&P. market nearby.

title: 6TH MAN SURRENDERS IN SLAYING OF A BLACK IN BROOKLYN IN 1982
description: The last of six whites sought in the 1982 beating death of a black transit worker on a Brooklyn street surrendered to the police yesterday.

title: CALIBRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income

title: CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA SAVNGS ASSN reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Not available because the company converted from a mutual savings and loan to permanent reserve fund stock association on March 30, 1984.

title: Mondale Is Assigned A 'Presidential' Suite
description: If his hotel room for the Democratic National Convention is any indication, Walter F. Mondale has the party's Presidential nomination in his hip pocket.

title: JUDGE FORCING JUSTICE DEPT. TO REVISE PACT IN PRISON SUIT
description: A Federal district judge here failed today to persuade the Justice Department to take a stronger stand in a key case involving prisoners' rights. However, Federal officials appeared ready to accept some changes in their position and are to prepare a compromise plan.

title: Soviet Said to Start Offensive in Afghanistan
description: Soviet forces have launched a major attack on Afghan guerrillas near the Iranian border, Western diplomats said today.

title: Transactions
description: Signed Joe Stephenson and Stephen Curry, pitchers, and Jody Reed, shortstop.

title: THE PROVACATIVE SAGA OF THE $400 HAMMER
description: Representative Berkley Bedell cuts a narrow swath through the House of Representatives. In 10 years in Washington, this soft-spoken Democrat from Spirit Lake, Iowa, has seldom raised his voice, or rated a headline.

title: Member Firms List Earnings
description: New York Stock Exchange member firms dealing with the public reported net income of $202 million for the first quarter, down 69.8 percent from $669 million a year earlier, the exchange said yesterday.

title: CLEANING UP THE E.P.A. VOCABULARY
description: A toxic waste dump by any other name may smell a little sweeter, according to the tenor of a memorandum recently sent to William D. Ruckelshaus, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: People
description: * Shirley M. Kaiden promoted to corporate executive vice president of Ruder Finn & Rotman.

title: RIGHTS UNIT'S NEW LEADER
description: Julius Levonne Chambers had been the first black editor in chief of The North Carolina Law Review and had gone on to earn a master of law degree at Columbia University when he was chosen as the first legal intern for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. That happened in 1963. Now, after years as a civil rights lawyer, a career that saw him win the landmark case in which the United States Supreme Court upheld busing as a remedy for school segregation, Mr. Chambers is to succeed Jack Greenberg as head of the fund, which initiates lawsuits to combat racial discrimination. He was elected Monday at a meeting of the fund's board of directors.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $65,435. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $5,727 and a gain of $1,807,879 from disposition of an asset.

title: ISRAELI TEACHERS JOIN EXPANDING WALKOUT FOR RISE IN SALARIES
description: Tens of thousands of Israeli schoolteachers joined Foreign Ministry workers and others today in strikes called to press demands for higher wages to offset increases in the cost of living.

title: PERSONALIZED CARDS AND PHOTO ALBUM
description: 1.*Children's Cards

title: Parents Object to Rule On Custody of Twins
description: A judge who was overruled when he decided to divide twins between their divorcing teen-age parents has now ordered that the 4 1/2-month-old, breast-fed babies spend alternate two-week periods with each parent.

title: More Transit Jobs Would Be Exempt
description: The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had increased by 449 the number of high-level supervisory jobs it wanted to fill without using Civil Service examinations.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ BAR ATTACKS ON CITIES
description: An agreement by Iran and Iraq to halt attacks on each other's cities took effect today, but both sides vowed to continue their 44-month- old war.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: a lot of time - to prepare a good tomato sauce. A friend recently described how her grandmother made it: ''She got up early, before the rest of the family, and started chopping her carrots and onions and garlic before adding her tomatoes and herbs. By the time the family got downstairs for breakfast the kitchen was alive with the good aroma of that tomato sauce, which she'd leave to simmer on the back burner all day long, once in a while adding a little broth or water to keep it from sticking.''

title: Dr. John M. Cotton, 76, Dies; St.Luke'sChiefofPsychiatry
description: Dr. John M. Cotton, former director of psychiatry at the St. Luke's Hospital division of the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The share earnings and the shares outstanding for both year-ago periods have been adjusted to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split effective July 15, 1983.

title: FOUR WIN AWARDS FOR CANCER WORK
description: Four scientists who made discoveries that have had a major impact on cancer research and treatment were named yesterday as winners of the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation prizes for 1984.

title: Letter: On OSHA
description: Safety in Industrial Experiments

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: US HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
OUTRAGE OVER DISNEY BUYOUT
description: The move by Walt Disney Productions to buy back Saul P. Steinberg's stake in the entertainment company at a premium touched off reverberations of outrage throughout the investment community yesterday, as Disney stock continued to plunge, falling 3 1/2, to 50 3/4.

title: SPANISH LEADERS SHIFTING ON NATO
description: In a gradual but significant shift, the Socialist Government appears to be turning away from the idea of dropping out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and is instead marshaling arguments for remaining a member.

title: COURT PROHIBITS ACCESS TO FILES OF STATE AGENCY
description: The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled yesterday that grand juries could not subpoena confidential records of a state agency investigating judicial misconduct.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Wheeled Tennis
description: A few months after Brad Parks broke his spine in a skiing accident in 1976, he joined a couple of other disabled athletes in Laguna Beach, Calif., to play tennis even though they were confined to a wheelchairs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 13, 1984

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $13,812. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $123,645 for the quarter and $270,175 for the 6 months. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of $886,863 and an extraordinary credit of $3,304,943. The year-ago figures were restated for discontinued operations.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HOUSE SPEAKER TO FORM PANEL ON DELEGATE RULES
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today agreed to a request by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that he appoint a commission to investigate the candidate's charges that the Democratic Party's delegate selection process had discriminated against his candidacy and was ''unfair.''

title: MOLD FOR TART CRUSTS
description: ONE of the best ways to take advantage of summer fruits and vegetables is by making quick tarts and quiches. Most home cooks find that the crust is the trickiest part to master. Sometimes it comes out soggy or too dense and often it cracks or falls apart during demolding. The clever new utensil pictured here, called the Demoul'vit (it translates as ''unmold quickly''), is a foolproof method of making symmetrical, unbroken crusts every time.

title: RCA RECORDS PLANS BERTELSMANN LINK
description: RCA Records and Bertelsmann, the big West German publisher, announced preliminary plans yesterday to merge their worldwide record, music publishing and music video businesses.

title: U.S. Lifts 7-Year Ban On Aid to Mozambique
description: The United States Government has lifted a seven-year-old ban on direct economic assistance to Mozambique, the American Embassy said today.

title: A NEW MEANING FOR LOW OVERHEAD
description: Pechin's Shopping Village has a bad location, a sagging roof, a pockmarked parking lot, no piped-in music and a $30-million-a-year business.

title: CONGRESS REACHES A SANG ON BUDGET DEFICIT PLAN
description: The Congressional effort to approve a package to reduce the Federal budget deficit ran into a snag today as the House and Senate began to dispute how to proceed.

title: Seabrook Plan Barred
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that the financially struggling builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant could not bill consumers for its investment in the canceled Pilgrim 2 plant in Massachusetts. The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, on the verge of bankruptcy from the rising cost of the Seabrook plant, had asked the Public Utilities Commission in March for permission to recover its $16.5 million investment in the Pilgrim 2 nuclear plant.

title: Janos Ferencsik, 77; Hungarian Conductor
description: The conductor Janos Ferencsik, who helped spread contemporary Hungarian music abroad, died today after a long illness, the Hungarian news agency MTI reported. He was 77 years old.

title: Union to Contest Ruling On Censored Textbooks
description: A teachers' union says it will sue to keep the school board from censoring five textbooks, including one that a board member said had ''funny pictures of Republicans and nicer pictures of Democrats.''

title: No Decision Yet On Jewel Proposal
description: The chairman of the Jewel Companies, Weston Christopherson, said at the annual meeting that the company's board had not yet met to consider a proposal by American Stores Inc. to acquire the company. He said no other statements on the offer would be made until then.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
Phone Access Charge Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Federal Communications Commission's plan to require payment of ''access charges'' by all telephone customers.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposition of property of $30,000. c-Net income includes a gain on disposition of property of $1,045,000.

title: FLOATING RATES CAN END A U.S. BOND BUYERS' STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Judge Says Tidelands Belong to Alabama
description: A 7,644-acre parcel of tidelands with a potential multimillion-dollar lode of natural gas belongs to the State of Alabama, a judge ruled today, turning down a university's claim.

title: I.B.M. DISCUSSES E.E.C. CASE
description: A top executive of the International Business Machines Corporation gave the computer giant's first detailed description yesterday of the antitrust investigation into its European operations carried out by the European Economic Community. He hinted that efforts to reach a negotiated settlement had not been successful.

title: Soviet Press Agency Assails U.S. on Missile Interceptor
description: The Soviet Union said today that the successful testing by the United States of a ballistic missile interceptor was a step toward ''the militarization of outer space.''

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:New System Saving TimeIn Scoring With Computer

title: A BREAK FOR COMEDY WRITERS
description: Almost anybody who has ever been enamored with the romance of television comedy would have recognized the picture: a table in an office building, cardboard cups of coffee, jokes shooting through the air on trajectories that sometimes hit a target and sometimes didn't. But the planning session for the new CBS comedy- sketch program ''Comedy Zone'' had two major departures.

title: CHEMICAL WON'T SEEK CONTINENTAL
description: The Chemical New York Corporation said today that it would not seek to acquire the ailing Continental Illinois Corporation.

title: YANKS ARE BEATEN; RED SOX 9, YANKS 8
description: In the other game in town tonight, the Boston Red Sox acted as if they were playing a championship game and once again concocted a stunning come-from-behind victory over the Yankees.

title: Advertising; The Statue Of Liberty Campaign
description: ON the back cover of Life magazine's special issue on the Olympics- 1.2 million copies of which have just been shipped to newsstands - is a beautiful picture of the Statue of Liberty surrounded by the rosy glow of sunset.

title: HOWARD E. RUTLEDGE
description: Howard E. Rutledge, a former prisoner of war in Vietnam who was an unsuccessful candidate for Congress, died of cancer Monday.

title: IMPROPER PAROLE INPUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Fanfare
description: John Williams, the conductor of the Boston Pops, has written memorable scores for some of the most popular motion pictures of recent years, including ''Jaws,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' ''E.T.'' and ''Superman.''

title: SHOPS SHAPE A RENAISSANCE OF AMSTERDAM AVENUE
description: Summer has arrived on Amsterdam Avenue. Salsa blares from sidewalk radios. Sarabeth's Kitchen is offering cold strawberry soup. The old people are fanning themselves on the benches on Verdi Square. And, truth be told, even the splendid looking individuals entering the Super Runners Shop are wilting in the heat.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,784,000 for the quarter and $5,178,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $293,000 for the quarter and $1,800,000 for the 9 months.

title: DOW DOWN 5.08, TO END AT 1,110.53
description: Stock prices retreated moderately yesterday in heavier trading following their sharp drop on Monday. Issues responding to specific or rumored takeover news were the biggest movers.

title: JAPAN URGES A NUCLEAR TEST BAN
description: Japan told the United States and the Soviet Union today that it was time they accepted their responsibilities toward the world by banning all nuclear tests.

title: MONDALE OUTLINES JOB QUALITIES IN RUNNING MATE
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that he would seek a running mate who would be able to ''advise a President from a national perspective,'' serve as a negotiator abroad and actively advance legislative programs on Capitol Hill.

title: Regan Silent on Loan to Argentina
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan refused today to say whether the Administration would extend beyond Friday its guarantee of $300 million lent to Argentina by four Latin American countries.

title: SOME AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS PETITION TO UNIONIZE
description: Air traffic controllers responsible for New York and Washington airways have petitioned to hold union organizing elections, saying a shortage of skilled staff has strained their ability to direct an increasing load safely.

title: The U.N. Today June 13, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LANDMARKS PANEL VETOES TOWER PLANS FOR ST. BART'S AND HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: Plans to build new towers above the landmark St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church and New-York Historical Society were rejected yesterday afternoon by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: HAITIAN ARTISTS ARE HURTING AS TOURISTS TRADE FALLS OFF
description: -HAITIEN, Haiti - An artist who owns a Haitian art gallery said the other day that no cruise ship had docked in this northern port city for 18 months.

title: GEORGE H. FLINN JR.
description: George H. Flinn Jr., a civil engineer and building-contracting executive, died of Alzheimer's disease last Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: MUSIC: AMOR ARTIS CHAMBER GROUP
description: HANDEL never composed a more nearly perfect work than ''Acis and Galatea,'' which is either an opera, a cantata, a masque or a pastoral oratorio, depending on which expert you choose to believe. Certainly he never composed a more charming or a more lovable one. Just to hear the opening lines of the first chorus, ''Oh, the pleasure of the plains!/ Happy nymphs and happy swains,'' is enough to bring a look of sappy bliss to any devoted admirer of the score.

title: REAGAN, MAN OF PEACE
description: In what is probably a foretaste of his re-election campaign, Ronald Reagan worked hard during his recent European trip to dispel the widely held view of him there as a ''trigger-happy cowboy.'' Over and over, he fervently proclaimed the sincerity of his devotion to peace; he repeatedly pleaded with the Russians to resume arms-control negotiations; and he advanced several conciliatory proposals, including even a pledge to renounce the use of force.

title: Brustein Is Honored For Boston Stage Work
description: Robert S. Brustein, the artistic director of Harvard University's American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., has been named the recipient of the second annual Elliot Norton Award for professional excellence in the Boston theater.

title: WATSON PUTS A FRIENDSHIP BEFORE GOLF
description: Golf obviously means a lot to Tom Watson, one of the game's best players for the last decade and the winner of the United States Open in 1982. But friendship means a lot, too, as Watson proved this week.

title: Executive at Showtime Unexpectedly Resigns
description: In an unexpected move, Michael Weinblatt has stepped down as president and chief operating officer at Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc., the nation's second-largest pay television service. Mr. Weinblatt's resignation is effective July 31.

title: ARMS CONTROL: ELECTION-YEAR PRESSURE ON REAGAN
description: For months, President Reagan has kept the issue of arms control largely on the political sidelines by arguing that it was the Soviet Union that walked out of the nuclear arms negotiations last November and is still blocking their resumption. But suddenly today, with the President just back from his European trip and Democrats no longer preoccupied with Presidential primaries, it is apparent that he will have more trouble now in fending off pressure from both Republicans and Democrats for some move to break out of the diplomatic stalemate with Moscow.

title: FOUR HOMERS HELP CUBS CRUSH EXPOS
description: Jody Davis walloped two homers and a double and drove in four runs today to lead Dennis Eckersley and the Chicago Cubs to an 11-4 rout of the Montreal Expos. Mel Hall and Gary Matthews added two-run homers for the Cubs.

title: Stolen Bats Seized The San Francisco police, who have recovered 63 bats and other equipment stolen from the Houston Astros at Candlestick Park last weekend, said they would try to cut some of the usual red tape in an effort to get the equipment back to the Astros as soon as possible. ''We wouldn't want to hold up a major league team,'' said
description: Ward Holmes , a burglary inspector, who noted that players often develop a special attachment to their bats and gloves. Mr. Holmes said the equipment was being photographed so it would not have to be held for the trial of two youths who have been arrested in the break-in. For all their attachment to their personal equipment, however, the Astros apparently don't need any special favors. Using equipment borrowed from the Giants, they beat San Francisco, 7-4, on Sunday, and using replacement equipment from their own supply stocks, they beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, in Houston Monday night.

title: PROBE INDICATES STAR CLOUDS THAT MAY FORM PLANETS
description: Newly analyzed infrared emissions indicate that as many as 40 relatively close stars are enveloped in clouds that it is thought will ultimately condense and form planets.

title: LORIMAR reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Buffalo Chooses Domeless Stadium
description: In what was termed ''a concrete first step in attracting major league baseball to Buffalo by 1990,'' the city's Downtown Stadium Committee today approved construction of a 20,000-seat expandable baseball stadium.

title: HOUSE PANEL TO SEEK STRINGENT CONTROLS ON C.I.A.
description: Leaders of the House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that they planned to press for stringent legislation that would require the Central Intelligence Agency to inform Congress of a broad range of covert activities.

title: Suspect Indicted in Flynt Case
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, a convicted murderer, was indicted by a county grand jury today on two counts of aggravated assault in the 1978 shooting that crippled Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, and injured Mr. Flynt's lawyer.

title: YANKS ARE BEATEN; PIRATES 6, METS 3
description: The Met hitters finally solved Larry McWilliams and his herky- jerky motion and his curveball in the ninth inning. But because Tim Leary, the Mets' starting pitcher, could not solve the Pirate hitters in the first, the Mets lost to Pittsburgh, 6-3, at Shea Stadium last night.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid on Aug. 1, 1983.

title: CELTICS BEAT LAKERS AND WIN 15TH N.B.A. TITLE
description: The Celtics, whose 1983-84 season began with a new coach, new ownership and Dennis Johnson, the big guard they lacked, brought a 15th National Basketball Association title to Boston tonight.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year and earlier period were after gains of $1,956,000 and $224,000, respectively, on restructuring of debt.

title: Bank St. College Loses U.S. Appeal
description: The Federal General Accounting Office has rejected an appeal by the Bank Street College of Education in Manhattan to overturn an award to Harvard University of a $7.6 million Federal contract for an education- technology center.

title: SO LONG, GOOD NEIGHBOR
description: ''Damn it, Pierre,'' President Reagan said to Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada at the summit meeting in London the other day, ''what do you want me to do? We'll go sit with empty chairs to get those guys (the Russians) back to the table.''

title: VIEW FROM ARGENTINA: RIGHTEOUS DEBT BATTLE
description: Argentina, in its remarkable confrontation with the International Monetary Fund over an austerity program, is once again imbued with a sense of righteousness and national determination. Not so long ago, a similar feeling led the country into an 11-week war with Britain over the Falkland Islands that ended in national humiliation.

title: TREE PATROL
description: Most people in Central Park were

title: Journal Case Injunction Set
description: Two stockbrokers, accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of participating in a fraud using advance information about Wall Street Journal articles, have agreed to a preliminary injunction prohibiting them from future securities law violations, tampering with evidence or spending alleged illicit profits.

title: TOMBSTONE FROM MONTICELLO
description: On the east side of the University of Missouri quadrangle, in the yard of the chancellor's residence, is a dull gray obelisk about six feet high.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: GAURI BHATIA went to a bank in midtown, cashed a $200 check and walked out into the wicked city. That was her first mistake. Her second mistake was to enter a crowded department store whose occupants were not all law-abiding. Five minutes later she discovered her wallet had been stolen. She wept, briefly, and then canceled her credit cards.

title: GEMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BIRD WAS HEART OF CELTICS
description: He made only 6 of 18 field goals in the final game. He was on the bench when the Celtics made their biggest spurt of the game, late in the third period. But Larry Bird was the most valuable player of the championship series, and everybody knew it.

title: Summer Activities For Youths Listed
description: City officials yesterday released the third annual Directory of Summer Programs for Youth, a bilingual list of educational, recreational and cultural activities, as well as places to go for health and counseling services and free breakfasts and lunches.

title: MEASURE TO LIMIT ANTITRUST SUITS BY F.T.C. VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a measure designed to prevent the Federal Trade Commission from filing antitrust suits against cities and other municipalities, but the action faces strong opposition on the Senate floor.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Frank Butterick, who says he is 50 years old and is only about five years shy of the truth, still slides. He slams a line drive off the side of the yellow brick school, scampers to beat the throw and - try not to look - is sliding into second in his gym shorts on the concrete playground. He is safe, relatively, with multiple abrasions.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TOP STATE COURT GIVES JOURNALISTS WIDER LIBEL PROTECTION IN RULING
description: The New York State Court of Appeals gave new protection yesterday to news organizations that misstate details of a person's private life, so long as the misstatement is inadvertent and is part of a larger article about public issues.

title: Carter Proposal
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said its board, at a meeting later this week, would consider asking shareholders to change the company's state of incorporation to Delaware from California. The company said the reincorporation would eliminate cumulative voting in the election of directors and help prevent The Limited Inc. from gaining board seats.

title: JERRY LEWIS TALK SHOW
description: WHEN Jerry Lewis appeared on Johnny Carson's ''Tonight Show'' several weeks ago, he managed, before I flicked off my set in mid-interview, to plug his latest movie, talk about how popular he is in France and assure everybody that he was fully recovered from his heart problems. He seemed rather serious and subdued, but perhaps he was only preoccupied with observing Mr. Carson in action. As it happens, Mr. Lewis is intent on becoming a talk- show host himself. ''The Jerry Lewis Show'' is currently being tested in syndication, and can be seen this week through Friday on WNEW-TV at 11:30 P.M. For the moment, Johnny Carson needn't worry too much about the new competition.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Advest Group Inc. , a broker-dealer in Hartford, said it had completed its acquisition of Burgess & Leith Companies.

title: R. J. Reynolds Urges Children Not to Smoke
description: Last month, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company ran a full-page ad with a rather startling copyblock under the headline ''Some surprising advice to young people from R. J. Reynolds Tobacco.'' It recommended that kids not smoke.

title: L.I. Rape Suspect Held Without Bail
description: A 23-year-old man charged with the rape and strangulation of a Long Island college student was ordered held without bail today.

title: FILING DEADLINE UPHELD IN DES SUITS
description: Women who discover they have cancer long after they or their mothers were exposed to the drug DES may not sue for damages, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: EMPLOYMENT UP IN 49 STATES
description: Unemployment declined from April 1983 to April 1984 in all states but Alaska, where the rate edged up slightly, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income The company said that the sales and earnings for the latest 6 months were adversely affected by a labor dispute which commenced on Jan. 15 and ended Feb. 13, which involved 16 of the company's 18 New Jersey stores.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $12,000 for the quarter and $36,000 for the 9 months.

title: No Headline
description: This Missile Is No Magic Bullet The Pentagon's timing is every bit as wondrous as its marksmanship. Just as the Senate was about to debate anti-satellite missiles and consider cutting the $1.7 billion budget for the Star Wars program, the Defense Department announced the successful test of a new space warfare device. A defensive missile intercepted and destroyed a dummy nuclear warhead by deploying a 15-foot metal spiderweb in its path. ''We really tried to hit a bullet with a bullet and it worked,'' an Army official exulted.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Banker Cites Peru Progress
description: Peru has met its first-quarter

title: Prosecution Partly Financed By Gifts Nets Death Penalty
description: A jury ordered today that Gerald Gallego be executed for murdering two teen-age Californians and that he serve life terms without possible parole for kidnapping them.

title: AUCTION OF FOUND JEWELS ENRICHES A FLORIDA YOUTH
description: Eric de Wilde, a Florida schoolboy, found a yellow bag of diamonds on a railroad track in March 1983. Yesterday, he sat silent and anonymous at Christie's auction house on Park Avenue as lively bidding on part of the jewelry made him richer by $281,490.

title: BAKER AND PERCY APPEAL TO REAGAN FOR MOSCOW TALKS
description: Two Senate Republican leaders told President Reagan today that East-West relations were so tense that he should meet with the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko. The Administration repeated its view that any meeting should be carefully prepared and offer the prospect of tangible results.

title: Turkish Cypriot Leader Arrives in Ankara
description: Rauf Denktash, head of the self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, arrived in Ankara today on a two-day state visit.

title: REAGAN SAID TO DROP OPPOSITION TO A BILL TO SET DRINKING AGE
description: The Reagan Administration has dropped its opposition to a bill sponsored by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg that would cut Federal highway funds to states that failed to raise the legal drinking age to 21, the Senator said today.

title: PARENTS SEEK $2.6 BILLION IN SUITS OVER DEATHS OF 4 IN BLAZE AT PARK
description: The parents of four teen-agers who died in a fire last month at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in New Jersey yesterday filed lawsuits seeking $2.6 billion, accusing the amusement-park owners of ''outrageous and reckless negligence.''

title: Market Place; Home Health Care Stocks
description: AS in many a Wall Street story, the concept is great but finding a way to invest in it is another matter.

title: IRAN THOUGHT TO SOFTEN POSITION
description: Intelligence analysts said today that they had seen the first tentative signs that Iran might be willing to negotiate a truce in the war with Iraq.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO PROHIBIT EMPLOYING ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Supporters of a comprehensive immigration bill made substantial progress today in the House of Representatives, which voted to prohibit the hiring of illegal aliens by employers of four or more persons. By a vote of 321 to 97, the House approved the ban on employment of illegal aliens, a central provision of the bill.

title: 25/ PAY PHONE CALLS PART OF RISES APPROVED FOR NEW YORK TELEPHONE
description: The 10-cent call from a pay telephone in New York State, started when postage stamps cost 3 cents and subway rides a dime, will end June 29. An increase to 25 cents for New York Telephone customers was part of a rate increase approved today by the Public Service Commission.

title: Penn Traffic
description: The Penn Traffic Company, a supermarket and dairy operator, said certain company officers were invited to meet with an investment company last February to discuss a possible leveraged buyout, but they decided there was no basis for pursuing the matter.

title: ANNIVERSARY NIGHT FOR BUJONES
description: Fernando Bujones will dance ''Swan Lake'' tonight with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. There is nothing unusual about that. Mr. Bujones, a leading dancer with the company, has danced Prince Siegfried - a signature role - in the ballet, and with companies around the world, countless times before.

title: A CONTRACT FOR A WATERMELON NOURISHES A 44-YEAR FRIENDSHIP
description: Roy Hoffman, the author of ''Almost Family'' (Dial), is at work on a second novel.

title: NEW INTERPRETERS OF MONK WORKS
description: ATTENDING memorial services and concert tributes for the composer-pianist Thelonious Monk, who died in 1982, one Monk admirer felt a nagging dissatisfaction. ''I remember being frustrated,'' said Hal Willner, a record producer and former music coordinator for ''Saturday Night Live,'' ''because I knew Monk influenced a lot of musicians who don't play jazz.'' So Mr. Willner went to work recording interpretations of Monk compositions for a double album, ''That's the Way I Feel Now,'' which is being issued this week by A&M Records.

title: JAEGER OF CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BORK ADDRESSES GRADUATES AT BROOKLYN LAW
description: Robert H. Bork, a United States Circuit Court of Appeals judge for the District of Columbia, told the 83d commencement of Brooklyn Law School yesterday that the increasing number of laws was putting a strain on society and the judicial system.

title: South Korea Accuses North
description: South Korea charged North Korea today with firing ''several'' rounds of automatic rifle fire across the demilitarized zone between the two countries. The gunfire came eight miles north of Chorwon, a border town 70 miles northeast of Seoul, at 6:15 P.M. Monday, the Defense Ministry said. It did not say whether there were injuries or damage.

title: LEVELS OF ART, SUBWAY STYLE
description: Pristine and graffiti-free, 16 murals

title: MIDWEST EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Rhode Island Rejection
description: Rhode Island voters today overwhelmingly rejected the Greenhouse Compact, a $250 million economic revitalization plan aimed at creating 60,000 high-paying jobs to replace a dying manufacturing industry.

title: Olympic Group Sued
description: A consultant who was dropped by the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee two years ago has filed suit against the group, contending that he was wrongly dismissed after he had charged that there had been irregularities in the selection of artifical tracks for Olympic events. The consultant, Vernon Wilkins , who is seeking $87,500 in lost salary, says he was dismissed after he had complained about the way a West German company, Rekortan Sports, had won the contract for the tracks, which he says are inferior to others that were available under more favorable terms.

title: Tyrell Biggs Does It His Way
description: Tyrell Biggs won his three matches during the Olympic Boxing Trials last week in workmanlike style, relying on a left jab a professional would envy. But he did not knock out anyone and was booed after each bout.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF you are going to the wine country of Europe this summer,

title: Girl, 3, Near Fight, Dies From Shot
description: A 3-year-old girl who was shot during a battle between two groups of youths on a Bronx street died yesterday at Abraham Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

title: EXPANSION OF MOBILE PHONE SERVICE QUICKENS
description: Mobile telephone service in the New York area, now limited to about 2,000 customers and 12 calls at any one time, is about to become available to many more thousands of customers, perhaps as early as today.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The year-earlier results reflect a net after-tax charge of about $592,000 representing estimated costs associated with divestiture of two product lines. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in January.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
POPE, IN SWITZERLAND, STRESSES UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II began a six-day tour of Switzerland today and renewed a pledge to strive for unity among all Christian churches.

title: UNLIKELY IMPROVEMENT OF IMMIGRATION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMBER CONCERNS NOT MINDFUL OF THEIR FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading Ice Cream
description: Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, in remarks to the House of Representatives, June 7:

title: The Court Strains to Make Work
description: Why Did It Have to Decide the Seniority Case at All?

title: JAZZ: STEVE KUHN LEADS TRIO AT VANGUARD
description: STEVE KUHN'S piano has usually been heard in recent years in the context of a quartet, into which the voice of Sheila Jordan was integrated, or in solo situations. This week at the Village Vanguard, through Sunday, he is back in the setting in which he spent most of his earlier years - a trio supported by bass and drums, but with differences.

title: Victor of Japan
description: The Victor Company of Japan Ltd. said it would soon begin exporting its small video camera-recorders to the United States and Europe.

title: Duke Power Rate
description: The Duke Power Company, which is based in Charlotte, said that the North Carolina Utilities Commission had granted it an electricity rate increase of $131 million, or 8.4 percent. Duke had asked for an increase of $213 million, or about 13.6 percent. Most of the increase was granted to cover part of Duke's investment in a nuclear station near Charlotte.

title: Hostetler Still Waits
description: Jeff Hostetler, the former West Virginia quarterback who has been negotiating with the Giants and the Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League, is not close to signing with either, according to his agent. The agent, Robert Bennett, noting that Hostetler, the Giants' third-round draft choice, appeared at their minicamp last month, said he would not report to their regular camp in July unless he had a contract by then. . . . Red Miller, the former coach of the Denver Gold who was dismissed in May 1983 after a series of disagreements with the owner Ron Blanding, lost an arbitration over his claim for continued salary payments.

title: HONDURAN SAYS ANTI-U.S. MOOD IS BEGINNING
description: A Honduran opposition politician said today that two recent mass rallies showed that the American military presence was beginning to generate anti-United States feelings and calls for the withdrawal of American forces.

title: TRIAL BEGINS FOR AIDE TO EX-MAYOR OF BOSTON
description: At the opening of the trial of Theodore V. Anzalone, long a close associate of former Mayor Kevin H. White, the prosecution today outlined two elaborate schemes by which it said Mr. Anzalone illegally funneled more than $100,000 to Mr. White's family.

title: WINFIELD SETS PACE
description: In the only game in town tonight, Dave Winfield took off on a one-man fast break and ran the Yankees into a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Reward for Laimbeer
description: Bill Laimbeer, the 6-foot-11-inch center who helped lead the Detroit Pistons to their first playoff berth in seven years, has signed a four-year contract extension reportedly worth $2.4 million. The deal makes him the second-highest-paid player in the club's history, after the 12-year, $11 million pact signed by Isiah Thomas in March. The 27-year-old Laimbeer, who averaged 17.7 points and 12.2 rebounds last season, has started every Piston game - 194 in all - since being acquired from Cleveland in 1982.

title: CANADIANS FEAR FOR GREAT LAKES
description: Canadians are increasingly concerned about the possibility of large United States diversions of water from the Great Lakes.

title: LYNCH AND SISK PITCH 3-HITTER
description: Rhythmically, methodically, the Mets beat the Pittsburgh Pirates last night, 2-0. It may have been the team's most unspectacular victory of the season, an evening of understated excellence.

title: The Celtics Prove Their Point
description: While champagne was pouring freely over the heads of the Celtic players long past midnight in Boston yesterday, the stunned and dejected Los Angeles players were poring over the reasons why the Lakers had not won the National Basketball Association championship.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTENTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After gains on sale of real estate of $723,411, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,237,381, or 21 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After a gain on sale of real estate of $449,010, or 11 cents a share.

title: MOVE TO REPLENISH PENSION AGENCY FUNDS GAINS
description: The Senate Labor Committee today approved a measure to replenish the deficit-ridden Federal insurance program that guarantees 37 million workers and retirees against the collapse of their pension funds.

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGN REPORTED SPENDING TO THE LIMIT
description: While the Democrats are spending every campaign dollar they can get in their battle for the Presidential nomination, President Reagan's campaign is also paying out as much as the law allows on his virtually unchallenged bid for the Republican nomination.

title: OF CRIME AND THE BERMUDA TRIANGLE
description: To some Republicans, the House Judiciary Committee is like the Bermuda Triangle. They say legislation sails in and then disappears, either lost in a maze of subcommittees or sunk in a vortex of fierce opposition.

title: CUBS SEND HALL TO INDIANS IN 7-MAN DEAL
description: The Chicago Cubs, first in their division, and the Cleveland Indians, last in theirs, made a seven-player trade today in which the Cubs acquired the pitcher Rick Sutcliffe and the catcher Ron Hassey, and sent the outfielders Mel Hall and Joe Carter to the Indians.

title: ; Contraceptive Sponge Account to Key/Donna
description: Key/Donna/Pearlstein of Los Angeles has been selected by the VLI Corporation of Irvine, Calif., to do advertising for its Today brand vaginal contraceptive sponge.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Red Sox , at Boston. It's bombs-away time as both teams go with left-handers for the final game of the series in the shadow of the Green Monster.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DOW UNCHANGED IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices ended with minor changes yesterday despite signs that the nation's economy is slowing down, a trend that would reduce upward pressure on interest rates. Trading remained light.

title: INQUIRY ON ZOO ANNOUNCED AS NEW ALLEGATIONS ARISE IN ATLANTA
description: City officials here plan to bring in a team of top veterinarians to assess health care at the city-run zoo, where the deaths of an elephant, two bears and other animals has touched off a furious public controversy.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The sales figures do not include sales of licensed departments.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net loss

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $26,070. c-After income from discontinued operations of $218,790 and a reserve loss from discontinued operations of $990,678.

title: BIG FUND MOVE FROM HANOVER
description: In what will be one of the largest pension fund transfers, the New York State Teachers Retirement System has informed the Manufacturers Hanover Investment Corporation that over the next few months it plans to withdraw $1.9 billion of common stock assets currently under an advisory contract.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SENATOR KENNEDY AT DINNER HONORING PATERSON
description: Following are excerpts from an address prepared for delivery last night by Senator Edward M. Kennedy at a dinner honoring Basil A. Paterson:

title: Brazil Draws More Money
description: Brazil has completed its third draw-down from a $6.5 billion new money facility agreed to by commercial banks earlier this year, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

title: CENSORSHIP ACCORDS SIGNED BY THOUSANDS, STUDY SHOWS
description: More than 120,000 employees now working for the Federal Government have agreed in writing that for the rest of their lives they will submit for censorship any speech, article or book they produce that concerns the sources and methods of intelligence gathering.

title: Consumers Power Is Downgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday announced lowered ratings on $2.2 billion of the Consumers Power Company's debt and $781 million of the company's preferred and preference stock.

title: British Coal Talks Stall
description: Talks between miners union leaders and the state-owned National Coal Board aimed at ending 14 weeks of pit strikes broke down this afternoon, a board spokesman said.

title: DESIGNERS TURN TO BOUTIQUES
description: Some of the best-known fashion designers, including Georgio Armani, Ralph Lauren, Norma Kamali and Hanae Mori, increasingly are emphasizing their own boutiques. They see this form of retailing as the best way to showcase their talents and bypass the vagaries of department store distribution and merchandising. Moreover, profits at boutiques can be more than twice as high as those from supplying goods to other retailers.

title: ON FATHER's DAY IN THE AGE OF DIVORCE
description: ''HER son is leaving to live with his father,'' Jane Adams wrote four years ago, beginning one of the most memorable essays I've ever read. Looking out over the oceanic pain of separations, of divorced fathers, of sons, she told the story of the father who dropped one commitment and then another, until after 10 years even the birthday cards had disappeared.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $89,523 for the quarter and $349,073 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $554,237 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: PARENTAL LEAVE: A 'HOT POTATO'
description: WITH 44 percent of the work force made up of women, and with 80 percent of those women expected to become pregnant at some time during their careers, a growing number of corporations are re-examining their policies on parental leaves of absence.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page incorrectly reported the position formerly held by Stanley Sporkin at the Securities and Exchange Commission. He was chief of its enforcement division.

title: THEATER: 'ELM CIRCLE,' FANTASIES OF A 15-YEAR-OLD
description: JANET-ANN, the waiflike 15- year-old heroine of Mick Casale's ''Elm Circle,'' thinks she is both Vanessa Redgrave and Diane Keaton, and has competed against herself for an Academy Award. ''Ah well, la-di-da,'' she says philosophically, and describes her cinematic relationships with Woody Allen and others.

title: JOCKEYING BEHIND THE SCENES OVER MONDALE RUNNING MATE
description: George McGovern urged the Democrats to nominate Walter F. Mondale. Page B16.

title: People
description: * W. L. Abbott , vice president of Nabisco Brands USA, was elected chairman of the American Advertising Federation.

title: Steel Import Petitions Filed
description: American steel

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
8 Hurt in Plane Evacuation
description: Eight people suffered minor injuries sliding down an evacuation chute after an American Airlines plane made an emergency landing today because of a possible engine fire.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO OVERSPEND IN NICARAGUA
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that it had found that the Central Intelligence Agency had exceeded, by less than $1 million, Congressional spending limitations on covert operations in Nicaragua.

title: STATE SENATE PASSES PENALTIES FOR FAILURE TO BUCKLE SEAT BELTS
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate, after about an hour of debate, today approved legislation that would penalize drivers and front-seat passengers who fail to buckle seat belts in vehicles required to have them.

title: ALLEN & CO. IN OFFER FOR CONRAIL
description: Allen & Company Inc., the Wall Street investment house, entered the bidding for Conrail yesterday, saying it would submit an offer of $1.1 billion plus an undisclosed amount in warrants.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 14, 1984

title: VOLLEYBALL PRIORITY FOR ASPIRING M.C.
description: The match had just ended when

title: Southwestern Bell and Sprint
description: The GTE Sprint Communications Corporation has been selected to provide interstate long-distance service for certain official communications of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, which is based St. Louis. The service is expected to result in a savings of about 17 percent, or nearly $50,000 a year, on certain business long-distance calls originating from Houston and made to locations outside the five states served by Southwestern Bell Telephone. Those five states are Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas.

title: ;  President of Wyle Labs Is Appointed Chairman
description: Stanley A. Wainer, president and chief executive officer of Wyle Laboratories, has been named chairman, the company announced yesterday.

title: EMERGING CULTURE LOST IN THE ANDES
description: Hundreds of years before Pompeii vanished in the shadow of Mount Vesuvius, a series of similar volcanic disasters in the northwestern Andes snuffed out the New World's most promising civilization, recent findings indicate.

title: MULLINIKS'S 3 HITS HELP BLUE JAYS WIN
description: Rance Mulliniks got three hits, and Alfredo Griffin and Willie Upshaw collected a pair apiece to lead the Toronto Blue Jays to 7-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

title: Indonesian Ferry Sinks
description: Twenty-four people are missing and feared drowned after a passenger ferry sprung a leak and sank in the north Java Sea last week, a spokesman for the owners said today.

title: BILL TO LIMIT FRANCHISE SHIFTS GAINS
description: Legislation to restrict the movement of professional sports teams from city to city barely cleared the Senate Commerce Committee today on a vote of 9 to 8, and its future in a Congress fast running out of time in this election year was uncertain.

title: Comings and Goings The Winnipeg Jets traded
description: Lucien DeBlois , the team captain who was in a salary dispute, to the Montreal Canadiens for Perry Turnbull . . . . Mike Warren , who pitched a no-hitter for the Oakland A's against the Chicago White Sox last Sept. 29, was sent to Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League to work out some problems. He has a 3-6 record and 5.09 earned- run average. . . . Brian Oldfield , holder of the American record in the shot-put, asked a federal judge to let him compete in next week's Olympic trials, from which he was barred as a professional by The Athletic Congress in April.

title: MCGOVERN, ENDORSING MONDALE, URGES 'STIRRING VISION' FOR NATION
description: George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1972, today threw his political support behind Walter F. Mondale, urging his former rival for this year's nomination ''not to seek every vote but to offer the nation a stirring vision of its potential greatness.''

title: No Headline
description: No Recovery for Teen-Agers The latest employment news seems good - the national jobless rate has declined to 7.4 percent. But for teen-agers, the news is mixed. The need for Federal help has never seemed clearer, yet Congress remains paralyzed. There is a chance for modest relief, however, in a summer youth employment bill now before the Senate.

title: BOSTON POPS CONDUCTOR RESIGNS POST ABRUPTLY
description: John Williams, the conductor and Oscar-winning film composer, abruptly resigned yesterday evening as music director of the Boston Pops Orchestra. He will, however, finish the current summer season, according to an announcement by Thomas W. Morris, general manager of the Boston Symphony.

title: Bills Gain On School Investment
description: Reacting to the bankruptcies of two securities firms that could cost schools and municipalities $40 million, the state Assembly passed six bills today intended to avert future investment crises.

title: Tenant Blows Up Apartment
description: A 45-year-old man who is said to have owed about $1,500 back rent blew up his apartment today after his landlord tried to evict him, the police said. The tenant, Horst Titze, was critically injured in the blast, the police said.

title: Technology; A Big Advance In Home Video
description: TO a generation of home movie makers, the

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A VERY PRIVATE EYE. An Autobiography in Diaries and Letters. By Barbara Pym. Edited and annotated by Hazel Holt and Hilary Pym. Illustrated. 358 Pages. E. P. Dutton. $19.95.BARBARA PYM'S novels are so quintessentially English that even English publishers hesitated to put them out. She wrote them at a time, beginning in the late 1930's, when it was no longer fashionable to be so enthusiastically English, for the country was beginning to lose faith in itself and its customs. It was not until the early 1950's that publishers felt readers were ready for Barbara Pym.

title: 2 Men Surrender In Killing of Girl, 3
description: Two men have surrendered in the fatal shooting of a 3-year-old girl who was struck by a stray bullet during a fight Sunday between two groups on a Bronx street, the authorities said yesterday.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS WIN
description: John McEnroe, adjusting to fast grass after his loss in the French final on slow clay, overcame a sluggish start today and defeated Van Winitsky, 7-5, 6-0, in the second round of the 203,000 Queen's Club tennis championships.

title: LOUISIANA CONSIDERS A BILL TO GUARANTEE MORE LOANS TO FAIR
description: The Louisiana Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to allow the introduction of a bill guaranteeing $15 million more in loans to bail out the New Orleans World's Fair.

title: COURSE IS CHANGED TO LOWER SCORES IN U.S. OPEN
description: Officials of the United States Golf Association conceded today that they may have set up Winged Foot Golf Club's West Course as too difficult a test for the United States Open championship in 1974. As a result, they say they have attempted to ease things for the 84th Open that begins Thursday morning.

title: 7 War Protesters Convicted by Jury
description: A United States District Court jury convicted seven antiwar activists today of one count each of damaging Federal property and conspiracy in a Thanksgiving Day raid on a hangar at Griffiss Air Force Base.

title: CONSUMER POWER GETS PLANT SUPPORT
description: The staff chief of the Michigan Public Service Commission said today that he believes the Consumers Power Company can complete its $4.1 billion nuclear power plant at Midland, Mich. Roger Fischer sounded the optimistic note after Consumers officials and opponents of the plant met for less than two hours. Mr. Fischer, who had initially opposed completion, said he is ''leaning toward'' allowing Consumers to finish the project.

title: CALENDAR: MANSION ON DISPLAY
description: West Egg '84, Great Neck United

title: German Metal Lockout Set
description: Employers in the West German metalworking industry voted today to extend retaliatory lockouts after the breakdown of talks aimed at settling a five-week strike that has crippled the motor industry.

title: SELF-PROFESSED WORRIER WHOSE WRITING SHOCKS
description: T. Gertler is afraid of many things. She is afraid of refined sugar, mold on cheese and telling people her first name.

title: Cynicism Cited in Plan's Loss
description: Proponents of Rhode Island's ''Greenhouse Compact'' - a $250 million, seven-year industrial development package that was overwhelmingly rejected by voters Tuesday - said yesterday that they had no immediate plans to resurrect their proposal.

title: A 'FALKLAND FACTOR' FOR MRS. GANDHI?
description: Wearing a white cotton dhoti, a loincloth that is the badge of the traditional Hindu politican, Atal Bihari Vajpayee today pondered one of the most volatile results of the Indian Army's crackdown on Sikh militants in Punjab. It is called ''the Hindu backlash.''

title: Opening With a Flourish Aboard the QE2
description: There were flurries of activity

title: USING SOD TO MAKE INSTANT CITY LAWN
description: CITY gardeners can become just as obsessed with lawn care as their country counterparts, even though city lawns hardly have comparable acreage. In fact, the New York architect William J. Conklin tends one that measures only 4 by 5 feet.

title: Carter Predicts That Reagan Will Avoid Debating Mondale
description: A Former President Jimmy Carter predicted today that President Reagan would not debate Walter F. Mondale, the expected Democratic presidential candidate, in the fall campaign.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,650,000.

title: Taiwan Export Gain
description: Taiwan's exports of computer- related products are expected to rise to $700 million this year from $395 million in 1983, the Industrial Development Bureau said today. The products include microcomputers, minicomputers and components, disk drives, printers, monitors and terminals.

title: THUNDERSTORMS CUT POWER TO THOUSANDS AND TANGLE TRAFFIC
description: Back-to-back thunderstorms struck the metropolitan area yesterday evening, knocking out power to thousands of homes, making the evening rush hour more tangled than usual and delaying travelers at airports for up to two and a half hours.

title: Rights Group Assails Killings in Libya
description: Amnesty International today appealed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to stop what it called liquidation of his opponents. The London-based human rights organization expressed alarm at the execution of seven Libyans between June 3 and 7, saying they ''had all been arbitrarily arrested and hanged publicly withouttrial.

title: Udall to Head Inquiry On Delegate Selection
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today appointed Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona to head a special panel of House Democrats who will look into the charges by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that Democratic Party delegate selection rules are unfair and should be changed before this year's convention.

title: ERNEST BRIGGS, ARTIST AND FOR 2 DECADES A TEACHER AT PRATT
description: Ernest Briggs, a second-generation Abstract Expressionist painter known for his expressive, sometimes calligraphic brushwork and his geometric compositions, died of cancer Tuesday in New York. He was 61 years old.

title: Bank Rates Post Rise
description: Annual effective yields on money market deposit accounts and six-month certificates of deposit rose nationwide, but most sharply in the New York market, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Fluor Executives Named to New Post
description: Two executives at the Fluor Corporation were named to the new position of vice chairman and will form an office of the president, David S. Tappan Jr., Fluor's president and chief operating officer, announced yesterday.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $2,900. d-After a gain of $72,200 on the sale of retail stores and a tax credit of $5,200.

title: IOWA HEALTH PROGRAM TRIMS INSURANCE FEES
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield announced guidelines to help control the costs of diagnoses. Page B28.

title: Citicorp Unit Buys Lonconex
description: The Citicorp International Trading Company reached preliminary agreement today to acquire Lonconex Holdings Ltd., the commodity futures broking subsidiary of the Golodetz Group, for an undisclosed sum.

title: THE G.O.P. IS FOR WOMEN
description: I'm astonished and angered by the notion that Republicans tend to be ''anti-women'' while all Democrats are ''pro- women.''

title: TREATMENT FOUND TO PREVENT FLAREUP OF HERPES SYMPTOMS
description: Scientists today announced the first successful treatment to suppress or prevent recurring attacks of genital herpes in people infected with the fast-spreading, sexually transmitted disease.

title: BIAS REMEDY VS. SENIORITY
