description: In case after case over the last decade, the Supreme Court has walked gingerly through the minefield of affirmative action, always emerging with some questions answered and many more left for another day. The Court's decision Tuesday, in which it struck the balance between seniority rights and affirmative action in favor of seniority, was no different. The 6-to-3 ruling answered one question: whether Federal law authorizes a judge to modify an employer's valid ''last hired, first fired'' seniority plan in order to protect recently hired black employees against layoffs. The answer, to the satisfaction of the Reagan Administration, was no.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Houston Lighting Ruling Reversed
description: A Public Utility Commission ruling penalizing the Houston Lighting and Power Company for reported mismanagement of the South Texas Nuclear Project has been reversed by a Travis County state district judge, the utility said. Judge Herman Jones said the commission was ''somewhat presumptuous, certainly premature,'' in finding that Houston Lighting had mismanaged the two-reactor nuclear power plant under construction near Bay City, in light of the utility's pending litigation against the project's original designer and constructor, the utility said.

title: 'WAR AND POWER- THE RISE OF SYRIA'
description: IN ''War and Power - the Rise of

title: PASTORA VOWS TO KEEP FIGHTING SANDINISTAS EVEN WITHOUT U.S. AID
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader who was wounded in an assassination attempt two weeks ago, says he will continue his fight against the Sandinista Government even if the United States withholds support for his efforts.

title: NAVAJOS IN NEW MEXICO ASSAIL COAL LEASES TO STOP RELOCATION
description: Impending Federal leases to mine more than two billion tons of coal here in the San Juan River basin have stirred sharp resistance from Navajo Indians who face displacement and from environmentalists worried about potential destruction of precious natural and archeological sites.

title: OUR BLIND ENTHUSIASM FOR PAKISTAN'S TYRANT
description: The United States is shoring up a special relationship with an increasingly unpopular military regime in Pakistan. This is a sadly short- sighted policy. Our alliance with Pakistan may in the short term seem to enhance our position in the Indian Ocean, but Gen. Mohammad Zia ul- Haq, who rules by martial law, is becoming more repressive and isolated as internal challenges mount, raising the specter of an eventual uprising to overthrow him.

title: LTV Credit Pact
description: The LTV Corporation announced that it had completed the banking arrangements providing credit of $675 million for its merger with the Republic Steel Corporation, which both companies had approved in May.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOWING THE FLAG

title: NEW WORK ETHIC: SITTING IN COMFORT
description: Computers have once and for all changed not only the technology but also the look and tone of the office environment.

title: LANDMARKS CASES: A DECISIVE VERDICT
description: When the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission voted Tuesday to reject plans for towers at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church and the New-York Historical Society, it was issuing a decisive verdict against the growing trend toward turning landmark buildings into profit-making real estate. Under its new chairman, Gene A. Norman, the commission stopped short of saying landmarks were sacrosanct, but it made clear that adding skyscrapers on top of or beside them was not the kind of alteration it wanted to see.

title: A Leftist Grenada Party Lays Plans for Election
description: A new party named for Maurice Bishop, the leftist Prime Minister who was slain last year, says its campaign platform in elections this year will oppose both the presence of United States troops and the provisional Government's emphasis on private enterprise.

title: Japan Trust Bank
description: The Security Pacific Corporation is studying the possibility of carrying out trust banking in Japan in cooperation with the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Corporation, Security Pacific's vice chairman, Robert Smith, said. Last month, Japan agreed with the United States to end domination of trust banking by the seven Japanese trust banks and allow qualified foreign banks to enter the field. Security Pacific is the first American financial institution to announce a plan to cooperate with a named Japanese trust bank.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MUSIC: AMOR ARTIS CHAMBER GROUP
description: HANDEL never composed a more nearly perfect work than ''Acis and Galatea,'' which is either an opera, a cantata, a masque or a pastoral oratorio, depending on which expert you choose to believe. Certainly he never composed a more charming or a more lovable one. Just to hear the opening lines of the first chorus, ''Oh, the pleasure of the plains!/ Happy nymphs and happy swains,'' is enough to bring a look of sappy bliss to any devoted admirer of the score.

title: ARGUS TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company was formerly Tawcoa Exploration Inc.

title: Spielberg Plans to Film 'Peter Pan' in London
description: The American film director Steven Spielberg said today that his next project would be ''Peter Pan,'' J. M Barrie's story about the boy who never grew up.

title: THE NORTHEAST CRAFTFAIR MOVES FROM RHINEBECK
description: Leaving behind the three huge striped tents that had been its trademark for 10 years, the 19th annual Northeast Craftfair will open to the public June 22 at its new location in West Springfield, Mass.

title: RIVERFRONT OFFICE TOWER PLAN LIMITED BY WEEHAWKEN PANEL
description: The Weehawken Planning Board has endorsed zoning changes that would allow a huge real-estate development along the Hudson River but would bar construction of office buildings that would impede the township's view of Manhattan.

title: STRIFE TEST'S INDIAN ARMY'S COHESION
description: The revolt in the Indian Army by Sikh soldiers who deserted by the hundreds but are now reported to have largely surrendered or been captured has focused attention on India's military, which is regarded as nationalistic, patriotic and professional.

title: INDIRA GANDHI CALLS REBELLION 'UNDER CONTROL'
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared today that the rebellion by Sikh soldiers of the past few days was ''fully under control.''

title: BALLET: INTERPLAY OF MUSIC AND DANCE
description: LIKE many of the ballets in the company's repertory, the three major works that the New York City Ballet presented Tuesday night in the New York State Theater concerned the interplay between music and dancing.

title: TAX-REPEAL PLAN IGNITES INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE
description: An international spat is taking place on Capitol Hill among investment bankers from both sides of the Atlantic, the Treasury Department and the Netherlands Antilles as Congressional tax writers consider repeal of a 30 percent withholding tax on foreign investors. The jostling is not just across oceans but among factions on Wall Street as well.

title: OUT TOWN
description: Let the record show that the defendant - clean-shaven, polite and fit - arrived on time for his appointment, that his eyes, amber in the light, were clear and wide open, that he did not yawn or stretch or sigh.

title: Palmer Belongs in the Open
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: ATHLETES WARNED ON HORMONE
description: Many physicians concerned with the abuse of amphetamines and steroids in sports are warning that a newer type of drug that can also have broad and dangerous effects is gaining popularity among American athletes.

title: Russians Must Register Foreign House Guests
description: Soviet citizens who have foreigners as house guests face fines of up to $60 if they fail to have them properly registered with the police, according to a new law.

title: MONOPOLY IS SEEN IN CONCRETE SALES
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams, in a Federal lawsuit, asserted yesterday that one company had created a monopoly to fix prices in New York City's concrete-supply industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're very disappointed to have our kids walk so far to go to school.

title: Police to Patrol The S.I. Ferry
description: City police officers will patrol Staten Island ferries and terminals to help contain ''quality of life'' crimes, such as marijuana smoking and graffiti writing, officials said yesterday.

title: STATE-LOVING CRAB VOTED OFFICIAL FOSSIL
description: A prehistoric crab that once thrived across upstate New York, long before it was upstate New York, was selected by the Legislature today as the state's official fossil.

title: Coleco Sees Profit
description: Coleco Industries said it expects to report a profit for the second quarter, compared with earnings of $9.1 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ago. At the annual meeting, Coleco also said it had an unshipped order backlog of more than $400 million, of which about $300 million relates to its Cabbage Patch Kids product line.

title: CHERNENKO SHUNS ALLIED OVERTURES ON NUCLEAR TALKS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, today rejected a call by the leaders of the industrial democracies for renewed talks on nuclear arms and other issues, saying their proposal was not ''backed up by anything tangible.''

title: Meaningful Message For Students and Parents
description: During the commencement season,

title: Gulf Foreign Ministers Meet on Oil Shipments
description: The Foreign Ministers of an alliance of Persian Gulf nations met today in Taif, Saudi Arabia, on plans for insuring oil shipments despite the hazards of the war between Iran and Iraq.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PILOT UNION SAYS F.A.A. FAILS TO ACT ON AIRLINES'S VIOLATIONS
description: The airline pilots' union today accused the Federal Aviation Administration of failing to clamp down on safety violations by the strikebound Continental Airlines. The head of the union asked that a review of the airline's safety record be turned over to a special panel at another agency.

title: Calling for Equine EKG's At Central Park
description: As temperatures climbed toward

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article Tuesday on the American Dance Festival in Durham, N. C., misidentified the company with which Hanya Holm danced in Germany and the school she founded in the United States. She danced with Mary Wigman, and opened a branch of the Wigman school in New York in 1931.

title: FALL FUR PROFILE: BIGGER, LONGER, WIDER
description: month strike that one furrier described as devastating, most of the industry managed to get at least part of the new lines together in time to show them this week. Few shows had to be canceled because of the strike by the Furriers Joint Council of New York, which ended on May 14, but most were somewhat abbreviated.

title: CITY APPROVES A 10-CENT RISE IN TAXI CHARGES
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission unanimously approved a 10- cent increase in the cost of a taxi ride yesterday, the first across-the-board fare increase in more than four years.

title: Israel Warns U.N. Chief About Policy in Lebanon
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar here today that United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon would have to stop snubbing Gen. Antoine Lahad's militia forces in southern Lebanon if they were to be useful in the region.

title: ILL-CONSIDERED LIMITS ON COMMUNITY REVIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PASSIVE SOLUTION TO MUSIC'S ORTHOPEDIC MISHAPS
description: MUSIC seems to have become one of our tenser occupations. Famous pianists complain of stricken hands and crippled musculature. Conductors find themselves in traction or walk around in casts. Indeed, neurologists, osteopaths and physical therapists are our newest breed of virtuoso - enjoying the same upscale glitter once common among violinists or composers.

title: ;  Arbitron Radio Survey
description: In the United States, blacks listen to radio 20 percent more than the general public, Arbitron Ratings reports. The research company said that on the basis of data collected from diaries kept by 3,716 black households in 11 major markets, it figures that blacks spend an average of 30 hours a week, compared with the general listeners' 25 hours.

title: First Executive Offers Preferred
description: The First Executive Corporation, an insurance holding company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., is offering 5.4 million shares of adjustable rate preferred stock at $25 a share through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. The preferred stock offering, which was rated A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, was increased from four million shares.

title: SENATE DEFEATS EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS FOR MILITARY
description: The Senate narrowly defeated a measure today that would have provided new educational benefits to American military personnel in an effort to attract recruits.

title: AN OIL MARKET FIT TO DEAL WITH DISRUPTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: 40 People Injured As 2 Buses Crash
description: Two buses taking Long Islanders on an outing to Manhattan crashed on the Long Island Expressway today, sending 40 people to hospitals with mostly minor injuries, officials said.

title: Interest Rates Drop Broadly
description: Fresh evidence of slower economic growth helped reduce interest rates yesterday for short- and long-term issues.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEXT YEAR, V-DAYS
description: The D-Day ceremonies in Normandy last week stirred more than pride and patriotism. It is not too early to take account of the emotions and misunderstandings that surfaced in order to plan suitable commemoration of next year's 40th anniversary of the end of World War II.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HILLSIDE IS FINALLY ADOPTING SCHOOL DESEGREGATION PLAN
description: After an 11- year battle, all 2,000 pupils in the five elementary schools in Hillside, N.J., will be assigned to classrooms in September on the basis of a state-ordered racial desegregation plan, state and local officials said today.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FINES FOR HIRING ALIENS ENDORSED IN HOUSE VOTE ON IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The House of Representatives today endorsed the principle that employers should be penalized for hiring illegal aliens, one of the most important elements of a comprehensive immigration bill.

title: Indian Airlines Buys Boeing 757's
description: Indian Airlines, the state-run domestic carrier, has decided to buy Boeing 757's in preference to the British- French Airbus, Kamini Chaddha, managing director, said.

title: DUTCH PARLIMENT BACKS A PROPOSAL TO DELAY MISSILES
description: The Dutch Parliament concluded a 17- hour debate early today by approving a Government plan that will delay the stationing of United States cruise missiles on Dutch soil for two years beyond the scheduled 1986 deadline.

title: A LOOK AT B.B. KING'S BRAND OF BLUES
description: ''THERE'S no end to what you can do with this instrument,'' says the bluesman B. B. King as he lightly caresses the guitar he calls Lucille in ''Let the Good Times Roll With B. B. King.'' The 60-minute program, produced by the Boston public television station WGBH, is primarily a concert performance, an entertainment. But it manages to explain more of the hows and whys of Mr. King's mastery of the guitar than many programs of a more academic nature. It can be seen on WNET, Channel 13, tonight at 11:30.

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After reflecting an extraordinary tax credit of prior years' operating losses of $261,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. c-After reflecting an extraordinary item--life insurance proceeds of $3 million, or $1.43 a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Miss Jaeger Sidelined
description: Andrea Jaeger, the 19-year-old tennis star, has withdrawn from Wimbledon because of a pinched nerve in her neck that is expected to keep her out of action for a month, her representatives said yesterday. The same condition forced her out of the French Open last month. According to Bonnie Hagerman of the International Management Group in Cleveland, Miss Jaeger hopes to compete in the demonstration tournament at the Olympics in August and in the United States Open in September.

title: Debating Posters
description: When Howard Schnellenberger was the football coach at Miami, he was also the corporate spokesman for Norton Tire Company. Schnellenberger appeared in television ads for the company, and life-sized posters of the coach were in 35 Norton stores in the Miami area.

title: Reagan Names 2 Diplomats To Ambassadorial Positions
description: President Reagan said today he would nominate Howard Bruner Schaffer, a career Foreign Service officer, to be ambassador to Bangladesh.

title: BLUE CROSS DEVISES PLAN TO CURB UNNEEDED TESTS
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield today announced guidelines intended to reduce the incidence of unnecessary X-ray and similar diagnostic procedures, thereby controlling costs for medical care of the insurers' 80 million subscribers.

title: THE BETTER WAY TO COMBAT PORNOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Low-Ranked Team Shows SkillinKnockout

title: Panel Refuses to Give Parole To Killer of 25 Farm Workers
description: Citing the ''horrible nature'' of his crimes, a state panel today denied parole for Juan Corona, convicted of the murders of 25 farm workers.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by Ann P. Harris, a senior writer with Grey Advertising who formerly taught English and worked as a journalist.

title: Balcor in Film Accord
description: Balcor/American Express Inc., a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc., said today that it had agreed to provide $160 million to finance all production and marketing costs for New World Pictures through 1987. New World is a privately held film maker and distributor based here. The financing will include a $12 million investment that gives Balcor a significant minority interest in New World.

title: N.C.A.A. Testifies
description: David Berst , director of enforcement for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said the Committee on Infractions, which decides whether schools have violated rules, has no staff, no files and no secretary to handle correspondence. Berst was testifying in the third day of a District Court trial in Las Vegas in the case of Jerry Tarkanian , the basketball coach who contends the N.C.A.A. violated due process when it ruled in 1977 that he should be suspended for two years after his Nevada-Las Vegas program was assessed a two-year probation for 38 recruiting violations.

title: Reagan News Session To Be on TV Today
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE quantity of mail to this department makes it impossible to answer each letter individually. In addition, questions are often similar, which means that some must go unanswered to avoid duplication. So to catch up, the column is sometimes devoted to questions and answers.

title: ISRAEL STOPPED NO IRAQI A-BOMB PRODUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: LTV Corp., Dallas, said it had completed a $675 million eight-year credit arrangement with a group of 21 banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company for use in the company's merger with Republic Steel Corp. Separately, Moody's Investors Service said it had raised to Ba-3 from B-1 the rating on the 6 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 1988 issued by Vought Corp., now known as LTV Aerospace and Defense Company, a subsidiary of LTV. The rating change affects about $17 million of debt.

title: Britain and China Set New Hong Kong Panel
description: Britain and China set up a committee today to examine the details of an agreement the two nations are preparing on the future of Hong Kong after 1997, when China resumes sovereignty.

title: No Headline
description: DrunkenDrivingLaws ASbC

title: Veterans Win Struggle Over a Civil War Law
description: Activists for veterans rights succeeded in challenging a Civil War law that prevented millions of disabled veterans from hiring lawyers to fight for their disability benefits.

title: CALIFORNIA PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MAY SALES AT RETAIL ROSE 0.2%
description: Sales at the retail level rose just two- tenths of 1 percent in May, as the spring shopping spree moderated, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MONDALE AIDES PUSH TALKS WITH JEWISH LEADERS
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign organization, concerned about a potential shift of Jewish votes to President Reagan in the November election because of strains over the candidacy of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has quietly begun conferring with a wide range of Jewish leaders on the former Vice President's present and future dealings with Mr. Jackson.

title: Advertising; Tropicana Tries New Campaign
description: PITY the poor confused consumers. After years of being told not to squeeze the packaged goods by Charmin, suddenly they are going to be all but ordered to squeeze the packaged goods by Tropicana Products. And, can you imagine, the same ad agency is behind both campaigns.

title: NU-TECH INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AN AIR-CONDITIONER STORE WITHOUT A CROWD IS ONE THAT HAS PROBABLY SOLD OUT
description: When the temperature in the city began to soar, Alan Rubin took a hard look at the dozens of people pushing into his stores in Manhattan to buy air-conditioners - and promptly locked the doors.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WOMAN IS SENTENCED TO DEATH
description: A 51-year-old woman who said drug addiction led her to poison her male friend and her mother with arsenic was sentenced today to die Aug. 31 in North Carolina's death chamber.

title: Sale Arrangement For State Savings
description: The State Savings and Loan Association, with branches in Utah and Hawaii, is being put up for sale with help from Federal regulators to rescue it from problems that have accumulated since its purchase last October by a California financier, J. William Oldenburg.

title: EARLY JUNE AUTO SALES UP BY 0.3%
description: The six major American auto manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars edged up only three-tenths of 1 percent in early June from the 1983 period. The sales are figured on a daily selling rate basis.

title: PLAY BY SOVIET DRAMATIST IS OPENING IN NEW YORK
description: In the 35 years since his first play, ''Her Friends,'' was staged in Moscow, Viktor S. Rozov says he has been regularly asked why he focuses so often on the conflict between children and parents.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Celanese Corp. said its engineering resins division had agreed to buy all assets related to Occidental Chemical Corp.'s Durel polyarylate business subject to an evaluation of market potential; Durel is an amorphous engineering thermoplastic.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co. named Claude O. Goldsmith to the new office of senior vice president of acquisitions and divestitures. He will restructure the Los Angeles-based company's chemicals, metals, refining and marketing, solar and transportation businesses.

title: BUYING AND USING AN AIR-CONDITIONER
description: LAST weekend, the most popular places in town, it seemed, were the beaches, streets with open fire hydrants and stores that sold air-conditioners.

title: A SALUTE TO PATERSON, A CHALLENGE TO KOCH
description: It was billed as a tribute to Basil A. Paterson, but it was also the opening move in the challenge to Mayor Koch's re-election next year.

title: Man Charged in Bomb Case
description: A man who was arrested Saturday after his rented car blew up in Iowa has been charged with placing six bombs here. The suspect, Earl Steven Karr, 24 years old, is in Federal custody in a St. Paul, Minn., hospital, where he was being treated when the Wisconsin warrant was issued Tuesday. Mr. Karr, a suspect in setting pipe bombs in Wisconsin, Minnesota and Illinois, has denied responsibility for the incidents.

title: LOWRY AND MALAMUD TESTED ON FILM
description: Hollywood - which can create poignant, leathery aliens and make Superman fly, which can turn stage extravaganzas into film extravagancies with no loss of glitter or power, which can often make good films out of bad books - has never had equivalent luck when it tries to turn great novels into artistically successful movies.

title: Required Reading The Cookie Factory
description: Colloquy on the Senate floor over whether to adjourn at 9 P.M. or continue to vote on proposed amendments to the military authorization bill, June 12:

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
JAPAN'S SEX INDUSTRY: BESIEGED BUT STILL BOOMING
description: The Japanese Government has set out, as it does now and then, to do battle against Japan's prosperous sex industry.

title: U.S. STEPS UP PLANNING FOR POSSIBLE OIL CUTOFF
description: The Government and the oil industry, prompted by intensified fighting in the Persian Gulf, have stepped up efforts to determine how to respond to a possible cutoff of oil shipments through the gulf.

title: SHULTZ PRESSES FOR BILL PROHIBITING AID TO TERRORISTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, describing terrorism as a substantial and growing problem, called today for new and broader laws to prosecute Americans engaged in ''training, supporting, or inducing'' terrorist activities.

title: SWISS CRITICISM FOR JOHN PAUL
description: After meeting with Pope John Paul II here today, a group of academic officials and theologians issued a statement containing unusual open criticism of Vatican policy, condemning what they called ''unfavorable results of Roman centralism.''

title: Coaching Parents
description: The National Youth Coaches Association, which has about 15,000 member coaches in about 500 recreational areas, has instituted a volunteer parent-coach program to help insure that baseball and softball players from 5 to 16 years of age receive better treatment from adults supervising their games.

title: EARLY SKYSCRAPER ADVOCATE
description: Nathaniel A. Owings, a founder of the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, died yesterday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 81 years old.

title: Karol Malcyzynski Is Dead; Member of Polish Parliament
description: Karol Malcuzynski, a member of the Polish Parliament who declined to vote for martial law in 1981, died of a stroke today in a hospital here, friends said.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $230,957 for the quarter and $195,282 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the 9 months.

title: Fotomat Corp.  Narrows Loss
description: The Fotomat Corporation, a major photofinishing company, said today that its operating loss in the first quarter was narrowed to $8.87 million from $10.41 million a year earlier, although sales tumbled 32 percent.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; How Analysts View Insurers
description: THE property and casualty insurance industry

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Not available because the company was not in operation a year ago. c-After a tax credit of $150,900. d-Net loss represents the loss from operation of a discontinued business. The share earnings are fully diluted. Cardis was formerly Mediscience Inc.

title: NELSON CONFIDENT OF GAME AND COURSE
description: When Larry Nelson tees off at 1:22 P.M. tomorrow on Winged Foot Golf Club's West Course in defense of his United States Open championship, he plans to continue from where he left off at the Open at Oakmont, Pa., last year.

title: G.M.-Argentina
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had signed a manufacturing agreement with Sevel, the Argentine conglomerate, to provide for the assembly of the Chevrolet C-10 pickup truck in a suburb of Buenos Aires. The pact provides for the manufacture of between 5,000 and 6,000 trucks by Sevel using components supplied by G.M. as well as locally manufactured parts, a spokesman said. Production is scheduled to begin in May 1985, with output set for the Argentine market.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
IN CASE OF FIRE, PORTABLE LADDERS
description: -escape ladder can provide a measure of added safety in the home when used in conjunction with smoke alarms. If stairs are blocked by flames or smoke, a ladder that hooks over a windowsill and hangs down the side of the house can provide an escape route from second- or third-floor windows.

title: FLUKE IN GREAT NUMBERS Fluke in Great Numbers
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Fluke continue to be

title: Sinatra Cancels a Concert
description: Frank Sinatra canceled his concert scheduled for tonight at Carnegie Hall, because of a sore throat, his representatives said. Refunds will be made where the tickets were purchased. The singer will return for the concerts tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday.

title: RAISING TAXES WON'T REDUCE INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Coe Hurt Again
description: Sebastian Coe, the Briton who won a gold medal in the 1,500 meters at the 1980 Olympics, said he pulled a leg muscle while training last Saturday and will probably have to withdraw from a race Sunday, six days before a key Olympic qualifying event. ''I will make a decision at the last moment,'' said Coe, who has been visiting a physiotherapist twice a day. Although conceding that it was doubtful he would be able to run Sunday, the 27- year-old Coe said he hoped to compete in the 1,500 at the AAA Track Championships at London's Crystal Palace on June 23.

title: Promulgating U.D.C. Credo Against Favortism
description: Even among government seals of

title: Vicorp to Buy Sambo's Units
description: Vicorp Restaurants Inc. of Denver, said that it had signed a letter of intent to buy 183 restaurants from Sambo's Restaurants Inc. for $62.5 million.

title: Sandinistas Withdraw Bill to Curb Journalists
description: The ruling Sandinista National Liberation Front withdrew a bill today that would have forced journalists - foreign and local - to reveal sources of information and would have tightened other controls on news organizations.

title: SILVAR-LISCO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SALVADOR TO RESTUCTURE SECURITY FORCES
description: El Salvador's three security forces, long linked with the worst human rights abuses, are being streamlined and restructured, according to military and Government officials.

title: Molloy Takes City Title
description: Archbishop Molloy jumped to a 9-0 lead in the first four innings at

title: ANTIQUE QUILT DESIGNS
description: ADDIE HAVEMEYER, far left, is an artist and antique- quilt collector who was fascinated with the logic of color and design she observed in antique pieced quilts.

title: Measure to End Runoffs After Primaries Offered
description: A House Judiciary subcommittee chairman has introduced a bill that would eliminate runoff primaries.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: b-Net income

title: CONFEREES ON DEFICIT MEET BUT FAIL TO FIND WAT OF PROCEEDING
description: House and Senate budget conferees failed to agree today on how to work toward resolution of their differences over deficit-reducing packages.

title: Last Brink's Case Goes to the Jury
description: A jury of nine men and three women began deliberations today in the trial of Samuel Brown, the last of the defendants in the 1981 robbery of a Brink's armored truck and the murder of a guard and two police officers.

title: ;  Dean Witter Analyst Named Research Chief
description: Lawrence Adelman, a senior vice president and securities analyst who has covered the food, beverage and tobacco industries at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. since 1978, yesterday was named the company's director of research.

title: U.S. AIDS STUDY OF VIETNAM FILM
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities, under what its chairman calls an emergency grant, has awarded $30,000 to a group that monitors the media to assess a PBS series on the Vietnam War.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; High Rates Disrupting Local Borrowing Plans
description: High interest rates, with yields of well over 10 percent for high-grade tax-exempt bonds, are disrupting borrowing plans of many local governments.

title: LONDON SIKH ASSUMES ROLE OF EXILE CHIEF
description: A Sikh opposition leader in exile here today named a Cabinet, set up a bank account and opened a new headquarters for the Republic of Khalistan, of which, he said, he is both the ideal and the president.

title: ARCHITECTURAL ARCHEOLOGY IN THE VILLAGE
description: -estate agent, didn't know he had a small 19th-century treasure on his hands. He scarcely guessed it would become an archeological dig. But he had and it did.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Year to March 31
A NOSE FOR NEWS AND PSEUDO-NEWS
description: About 10 o'clock this morning, press officers in the Defense Department put out telephone calls to newspaper, news service and television correspondents who regularly cover the Pentagon. The word: a session at 2 o'clock in the Pentagon press briefing room on updated estimates of Soviet military spending.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 14, 1984 International
description: Moscow rejected an appeal by Western leaders for new talks on nuclear arms and other issues, saying the proposal ''failed to be backed up by anything tangible.'' Replying to questions in Pravda, Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, called the overture a ''screen'' to cover the deployment of new American missiles in Western Europe. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A delay in stationing missiles on Dutch soil for two years after the scheduled 1986 deadline was approved by the Dutch Parliament. At the end of a 17-hour debate, 79 legislators voted in favor of the Government's plan to delay the basing of United States cruise missiles and 71 voted against. (A1:4.)

title: U.S.I.A. Chief Pays Bill For U.S. Phones at Home
description: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, has repaid the Government $4,436 for two telephones that were installed in his home at Government expense and later challenged by Government auditors, a spokesman said today.

title: A TERM IN JAIL ON L.I. STARTS FOR MARGIOTTA
description: The former Nassau County Republican leader, Joseph M. Margiotta, who spent the last year in a Federal prison, reported today to the county jail, where he will spend the next two months in a work-release program.

title: CREUSOT-LOIRE SPURNS FRENCH AID PLAN
description: Creusot-Loire, France's biggest heavy industrial goods manufacturer, said today that it would file for formal receivership rather than accept the Government's proposed rescue plan.

title: JUDGE REJECTS A BID FOR DISMISSAL OF DRUG CASE AGAINST DELOREAN
description: Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi today rejected a defense bid for dismissal of drug charges against John Z. DeLorean. The judge also said a prosecutor had committed no improprieties in the handling of investigative notes, laying to rest an issue that generated four days of courtroom conflict.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock split by way of a 50 percent stock dividend effected July 15, 1983.

title: Poll Shows Hunt Lead Over Helms Is Growing
description: A new poll commissioned by the Democratic Party and released today shows Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. with a lead of 6 percentage points over Senator Jesse Helms in North Carolina's hotly contested Senate race.

title: Cooler Uniform For U.S. Open
description: Officials of the United States Golf Association finally are giving in to the hot weather and will dress comfortably for the 84th United States Open championship starting at Winged Foot today.

title: Worm Diggers in Maine End 7-Week Walkout Over Prices
description: The state's striking worm diggers have ended a seven-week labor dispute that disrupted Maine's $4-million-a-year worm industry.

title: Jewel Stock Up on Merger Bid
description: Stock in the Jewel Companies soared $6 a share in heavy trading today, to $68, as traders waited to hear whether the supermarket and drugstore operator would accept or fight a $70-a-share tender offer from the American Stores Company.

title: 8-Year Lapse
description: Lee McGriff, a wide receiver who gave up his pro playing career almost eight years, signed Sunday with the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League. The Bandits, who have clinched a playoff spot, have injury problems at wide receiver and two games remaining in the regular season.

title: ATTACK ON PASTORA: MUCH INTRIGUE BUT FEW FACTS
description: Two weeks after a bombing attack on Eden Pastora Gomez, an anti-Sandinista rebel leader, the Costa Rican authorities have established a key suspect - a man who, using a stolen Danish passport, traveled the region in recent months posing as a photographer.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column on June 2 misidentified a Florida newspaper that had interviewed the football coach John McKay. It was The Ledger, in Lakeland.

title: House of Fraser
description: The House of Fraser P.L.C., is deferring its annual meeting until the British Office of Fair Trading obtains assurances from Lonrho P.L.C. that it will not seek changes on the House of Fraser board for the time being, a Fraser spokesman said. He was commenting on the company's earlier decision to defer its annual meeting scheduled for late this month. The deferral was prompted by Lonrho's plan to pack the board with its own nominees and the subsequent referral of the Lonrho tactics to the Monopolies Commission.

title: Dewar's Scotch Ties In With Apollo Theater
description: The Schenley Imports Company is tying in with Harlem's fabled Apollo Theater in a $1 million advertising campaign as a way of promoting Dewar's White Label Scotch in the black community.

title: ARGENTINE WORKERS RESISTING AUSTERITY
description: About one-fifth of Argentina's 10 million workers are either on strike or threatening to strike, intensifying pressure on the Government not to compromise in its negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on an austerity plan.

title: Article 259879 -- No Title
description: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group announced today that it had made a $255 million cash offer for Grindlays Holdings, a British bank holding company. The transaction has been approved by Citicorp, which holds 48.6 percent of Grindlays, and by Lloyds Bank, which has 21 percent.

title: DRAMATIC EFFECTS IN RESTAURANT DESIGN
description: ''I'M a product of the Depression,'' said Al Nahas, co-owner of Nightfalls, a new garden restaurant in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. ''It never occurred to me that a small piece of marble and glass could cost $160.''

title: Navy Aide Guilty Of Racketeering
description: A civilian official of the Navy pleaded guilty yesterday to racketeering charges of extorting $120,000 in cash and free construction labor and supplies for himself from private contractors.

title: PANEL CLEARS WAY FOR AID TO REBELS
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today cleared the way for full Senate consideration of President Reagan's request for $28 million in covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels attempting to overthrow the Sandinista Government, according to Senator Joseph R. Biden, a committee member.

title: CLUES TO HOSPITAL QUALITY THE PUBLIC SHOULD KNOW
description: To the Editor:

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a credit of $4,242,000 from gain on retirement of bank debt.

title: Sudanese Army Reports Repelling Rebel Attacks
description: The official press agency reported today that 255 rebels and 8 soldiers died when Sudanese Army troops repelled two attacks by rebels in Upper Nile Province in the southern part of the country last week.

title: POLITICS OF CIVILITY
description: The Mayor of Boston, Raymond L. Flynn, keeps in shape by running. He was in Washington the other day for a meeting of the Democratic Platform Committee, of which he is a member, and at the end of the day he ran a few miles.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The U.N. Today June 14, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BRIEFING
description: To Zip or to Scan

title: ANGLERS LURED TO BLACK BASS
description: Although it does not receive the

title: First Florida Bid
description: First Florida Banks Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Financial Growth Systems Inc. for about $24.5 million. Financial Growth is an Inverness, Fla., bank holding company with assets of about $170 million. First Florida said the deal requires shareholder and regulatory approval.

title: HICKSVILLE VOTES TO RESTORE MOMENT OF SILENCE
description: Voters in Hicksville have overwhelmingly approved a referendum to restore a moment of silence in the public schools.

title: Jaguar Spinoff Details Given
description: BL P.L.C., the state-owned automobile manufacturer, today released the first details of the long-expected spinoff of its Jaguar Cars subsidiary.

title: Highest Rating
description: The CBS telecast of the seventh game of the National Basketball Assocation's championship series Tuesday night between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers drew a national rating of 19.3, the highest ever for an N.B.A. game and the highest for any network program this month, according to CBS research based on figures provided by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Court Rejects Colts' Plea
description: Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court refused without comment today to block state court proceedings in Maryland in which the City of Baltimore is trying to recapture the Colts.

title: No Headline
description: How Far to Bend on Steel American steel makers say that competition from abroad is the primary cause of their woes. Right, says the International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, voting 3 to 2 to recommend import restrictions. President Reagan must accept or reject the commission's recommendation by fall.

title: HOUSE VOTES PLAN TO ADMIT ALIENS TO HARVEST CROPS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to admit possibly several hundred thousand aliens to the United States as temporary workers to harvest fruit and vegetables.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a passage in an article yesterday on a treatment for genital herpes incorrectly suggested the availability of the drug Zovirax for oral use. As noted elsewhere in the article, oral use awaits approval of the Food and Drug Administration, which is is still evaluating the treatment.

title: BOSTON IS GREEN WITH PRIDE OVER CELTICS' CHAMPIONSHIP
description: In front of 200,000 jubilant fans, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, who once briefly played for the Boston Celtics, proclaimed Boston the basketball capital of the world today to celebrate the Celtics' 15th National Basketball Association championship.

title: FESTIVAL OF EARLY MUSIC OPENING IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Connecticut Early Music Festival, spread over three June weekends, opens tomorrow at 8 P.M. with a ''Venetian Evening'' in the Noank Baptist Church with music by Vivaldi, Monteverdi and Strozzi, played on reproductions of period instruments. The harpsichordist Igor Kipnis, co-director of the festival, will present the premiere of his reconstruction of a Vivaldi concerto for violin and cello, that the composer designated for possible keyboard performance.

title: State Alters Law For Continental SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 14 (AP) - The Illinois Senate approved emergency legislation that would allow the ailing Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company to merge with an out-of-state institution. Senators endorsed the proposed change in Illinois banking law by a 51-to-4 vote, sending it to the House.
description: The vote came two weeks after Continental's chairman, David G. Taylor, made a personal appeal to lawmakers to give the bank ''the broadest range of options possible'' in finding a solution to its problems.

title: THE WARNING FROM VOLCKER
description: The United States economy is zipping along,

title: FORTUNE'S CREATIVE APPROACH
description: The ad sales staff of Fortune

title: STRAWBERRIES
description: Strawberries are ready for picking this weekend at farms near the metropolitan area. With sunny days ahead, mid-June is a good time for a trip to a pick-it-yourself strawberry farm, combining a nostalgic visit to an operating farm, especially if accompanied by children, and a tour of the countryside, where alfalfa and other green grasses are being cut and baled as hay.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Justice Accelerates
description: Court delays too often result from the ''local legal culture,'' the belief among prosecutors, defense attorneys and judges that time is on everyone's side. Nowhere is the phenomenon more evident or infuriating than in voir dire, the questioning of prospective jurors.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT SOARS IN MONTH
description: Americans took on $6.41 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in April, the second-biggest increase on record, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: TEMPLE RAID: ARMY'S ORDER WAS RESTRAINT
description: The Indian Army that captured the Sikhs' Golden Temple here last week was under orders to damage the shrine as little as possible, the officers who led the assault said today.

title: A Tale About Schooldays As Vacation Days Near
description: On a weekend when the calendar indicates that the passing seasons have nearly driven a stake through the heart of another school year, some children may blanch at the thought of a television show whose plot pivots on the advent of a new school year.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Agencies Issue Caution On Texas Utility's Debt

title: SWITCH FOR STEVE KUHN: STRESS ON STANDARD POP
description: AT the age of 46, Steve Kuhn has decided to turn his career around. Over a quarter-century as a jazz pianist, playing in groups led by John Coltrane, Art Farmer, Kenny Dorham and Art Blakey, or leading his own trio and quartet, 80 percent of his repertory has been original music - his own or his colleagues' - and 20 percent standard pop songs.

title: DEADLINE EXTENDED AS FEW APPLY FOR OPENINGS ON TOP STATE COURT
description: Four days before the filing deadline, the number of applicants for two coming vacancies on New York's highest court, including the position of chief judge, is ''much too low,'' the chairman of a special judicial screening panel said yesterday.

title: Angola Rebels Report Capture of Americans
description: Forces of the Angolan rebel movement Unita captured 11 Americans, Portuguese and Colombians during attacks on Angolan Government troops, a spokesman for the rebel group said today.

title: IT'S BLOOMSDAY III, A JOYCEAN JAMBOREE AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: O tell me all about

title: Hobo's Willie Owners Have Designs for Cane
description: When it comes to junior dresses, Shelly Silverman and Larry Korman are strictly competitors. Silverman operates Mr. Lucky Fashions, and Korman's company is Eljay Fashions.

title: YANKEES 12, RED SOX 11
description: In one of the most bizarre games ever played in the remarkable rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees rallied from an 11-7 deficit and staggered away tonight with a 12- 11 victory on a 10th-inning home run by Willie Randolph against Bob Stanley.

title: BUSH BREAKS SENATE TIE, TURNING BACK MX EFFORT
description: In a cliff- hanging vote that required a rare ballot by the Vice President, the Republican- controlled Senate turned aside tonight a strong campaign led by senior Democrats against the MX missile.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Protest at the Modern For More Women's Art

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
KREMLIN POSITION
description: The Kremlin's spokesman said today that Moscow favored the idea of a Soviet-American summit conference, but that the timing would depend on the preparation of issues to be discussed.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-Includes charges of $2.4 million relating to provisions for accounts receivable, obsolete inventory and a reduction in the value of leased assets.

title: A ROLLER COASTER BIRHTDAY: 100 YEARS OF UPS AND DOWNS
description: DOMINIQUE DIENG was confident as his first roller- coaster ride began with the slow clanking haul to the top of the first hill. But as the car began its plunge down the other side, picking up the speed that would hurtle it banking through curves and bucking over bumps and dips, Mr. Dieng's knuckles went white, his eyes closed, and he became quite silent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Abbott Laboratories of North Chicago, Ill., said it had reached an agreement with Eli Lilly & Co. in which Lilly will make its intravenous drugs available for sale in a new drug mixture system developed by Abbott.

title: ANIMAL RIGHTS: A GROWING MOVEMENT IN U.S.
description: Out of the darkness, five figures moved quietly down a University of Pennsylvania walk, entered a building, descended to a subbasement and broke into a laboratory.

title: COMECON LEADERS BACK CLOSER ECONOMIC TIES
description: The leaders of the Soviet Union and its nine closest trading partners concluded their first economic summit meeting in 15 years today, endorsing what they said was a long-term economic strategy. What litle information was provided suggested that, despite declarations of unanimity, the discussions did not always go smoothly.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If they're ready to talk, we are, too.'' - President Reagan. (A13:5.)

title: YANKS WIN IN 10; METS 6 CARDINALS 0
description: Ron Darling, pitching with confidence and control, turned in his first major league shutout tonight as the Mets defeated St. Louis, 6-0.

title: Atlas Seeks Bar To Contrans Bid
description: Atlas Van Lines Inc. said it had asked a Federal court to block a tender offer from an investor group seeking control of the moving company.

title: Bataan March Survivors Seek to Sue the Japanese
description: Survivors of the World War II Bataan death march, describing their ''living hell'' in captivity, asked Congress today for the right to sue Japanese companies that profited from their slave labor.

title: ; When Forbes goes bidding.
description: UNLIKE most of today's collectors, who prefer to acquire art, antiques and autographs secretly, Malcolm S. Forbes, the business-magazine publisher, does it publicly and with gusto. He was visibly active last month, bidding and buying at New York auctions of historical autographs.

title: A CITY PROPOSAL TO BURDEN SMALL BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: SEVEN SCULPTORS AT PENN PLAZA
description: ONCE an integral part of architecture, art has been its barely tolerated guest during the reign of the International style. The corporate clients of architects are getting ever more active as collectors of art, but the sculpture that often stands outside their buildings remains an accessory - a giveaway strapped to the side of the main product.

title: FIRST CITY PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $716,000 for the quarter and $1,179,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits of $1.6 million for the quarter and $1,793,000 for the 6 months.

title: CHILD-CARE SERVICES: THE DOABLE THAT IS NOT DONE
description: To the Editor:

title: BEATRICE JUICE UNIT HAS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Wesley M. Thompson was named president of Beatrice Fruit Juices, a division of the Beatrice Companies, the parent company announced in Chicago yesterday.

title: THOMAS HUNTER LOWE
description: Thomas Hunter Lowe, former Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: CONDOMINIUMS GOING UP ON OLD RHINEBECK ESTATE
description: In 1968, Victor Weingarten and Roy R. Neuberger began a program of land investment. Thinking for the long term, they bought 14 parcels, a total of 6,000 acres, in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties, all of it in what they believed would be the path of growth.

title: PROTECTION URGED FOR COOPER IN U.S.
description: The International Trade Commission unanimously found today that imports were causing serious injury to American copper producers and that the Government should impose new trade barriers to help the industry.

title: CHINESE AIDE LEAVES WASHINGTON WITHOUT FORMAL ARMS SALES PACT
description: The Chinese Defense Minister, Zhang Aiping, left here today without reaching formal agreement with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on United States military sales and assistance to China, according to Defense Department officials.

title: COURT UPSETS CITY POLICY ON MINORITY CONTRACTORS
description: A New York City policy giving small companies in poor neighborhoods a 10 percent share of municipal construction contracts was overturned yesterday by the state's highest court.

title: Japanese Protest Port Visit By a U.S. Nuclear Submarine
description: A United States Navy nuclear- powered submarine capable of carrying nuclear cruise missiles arrived in this port today amid protests from left- wing, labor and pacifist groups.

title: DISCOUNTING RULES FOR BROKERS
description: Trying to keep discounting from getting out of hand, some of Wall Street's major full-service brokerage firms are beginning to set formal policies that specify just how large a retail customer's order must be before it warrants a price break.

title: N.C.A.A. Refuses To Postpone Rule
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association chose today not to change a new academic requirement and took issue with coaches who say the rule could cause many players to become ineligible.

title: FEDERAL JURY FINDS A COOKS COUNTY JUDGE GUILTY OF CORRUPTION
description: A Federal jury today found John M. Murphy, a Cook County Associate Circuit Court Judge, guilty of 24 out of 27 counts of racketeering, mail fraud and extortion.

title: ANGELS ROUT WHITE SOX, 9-3
description: Rob Picciolo, used sparingly this season by the Angels, drove in a pair of runs tonight to help California defeated the Chicago White Sox, 9-3.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Japan Fines American Under Fingerprint Law
description: A Yokohama court convicted an American college lecturer today of defying Japanese alien registration laws by refusing to be fingerprinted, in the first such test of the practice.

title: Time to Go Fly a Kite
description: Abraham and Straus, the department store, is presenting an afternoon of kite flying Sunday in Brooklyn's Prospect Park. Souvenir kites will be given to the first 500 arrivals at Raintrees Cafe on the Park, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, where the festivities begin at 2 P.M. It's free. Information: 788-0055.

title: I.B.M. PC Tie To Xerox Net
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced equipment that makes it possible to connect the International Business Machines Corporation's popular Personal Computer to a Xerox local area network. Such networks, which Xerox has marketed for several years under the name Ethernet, allow office workers to transmit information at high speed from one computer to another, and to share printers and mass storage devices.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK: BELLAMY BROTHERS
description: THE Bellamy Brothers, from Tampa, Fla., have established themselves in the last eight years as skillful practitioners of an easygoing country-rock that's very distinct in spirit from typical country music fare. Howard and David Bellamy's clean two-part vocal harmonies descend from the rustic fraternal tradition of the Louvins and the Everly Brothers.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Music of a Different Ilk

title: FATHER'S DAY GIFTS: CLASSIC OR OFFBEAT
description: Buying presents for Father's Day can be one of the most difficult tasks imaginable. But it needn't be, especially since there is so much in the stores to choose from.

title: NEW AMERICAN BID GETS JEWEL
description: Abandoning its struggle to remain independent, the Jewel Companies announced today that it had agreed to merge with the American Stores Company in a $1.16 billion deal that analysts said would form the nation's third-largest supermarket chain.

title: BRAVES END SKID ON 1-HITTER
description: Len Barker and Donnie Moore combined on a one-hitter as the Atlanta Braves snapped a five-game losing streak tonight with a 3-0 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax benefit of $449,000 from the settlement of federal income tax assessments for fiscal years 1971- 75. d-Includes a tax benefit of $389,000 from the difference between book value and the tax basis of a non-consolidated subsidiary sold during the third quarter.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Orioles, trying to keep in range of the Eastern Division leaders, will start Mike Boddicker. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. The Mets face Joaquin Andujar, who, in a return to form after a dismal 1983 season, is looking for his 11th victory. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.)

title: A NEW OPEN, A NEW FACE
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Two Women Abducted A
description: Two women were abducted at Queens bus stops in separate incidents Wednesday night and raped and robbed at gunpoint by the same two men, the police said yesterday.

title: Amerifirst Shift
description: Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association said its board had approved a plan to convert the company to a Federal capital stock institution from a Federal mutual institution. Under the plan, Amerifirst would form a holding company, the Amerifirst Financial Corporation, which would issue common shares. Amerifirst has assets of about $3.8 billion.

title: DOW FALLS BELOW KEY 1,100 LEVEL
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in heavier trading as investors displayed their growing concern over interest rates.

title: Tylenol Scare Extortionist Is Given 10-Year Prison Term
description: A man convicted of trying to extort $1 million from the makers of Tylenol after seven people were killed by cyanide-tainted capsules of the painkiller was sentenced today to 10 years in prison.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. and Philippines Revise Defense Plan
description: United States and Philippine military officials announced today that they had concluded a new defense plan for the Philippines in an annual meeting of the mutual defense board.

title: ; MARRIAGE OVERTURES' FITTING CONDUCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: COPPER QUOTAS' PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHERN BAPTIST MEETING VOTES OPPOSITION TO ORDAINING WOMEN
description: The Southern Baptist Convention went on record today in opposition to the ordination of women to the ministry. The resolution argues that women are subservient because of their responsibility for bringing sin into the world.

title: INQUIRY ON DISNEY TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an investigation of stock market trading in Walt Disney Productions, the big West Coast entertainment company said yesterday.

title: Required Reading Cool Basketball
description: Colloquy on the House floor on June 13 concerning the Boston Celtics defeating the Los Angeles Lakers for the world basketball championship in Boston Garden:

title: Arizona Utility
description: The Arizona Public Service Company is offering $100 million of 15 percent bonds due in 1994 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 15.10 percent through the First Boston Corporation. The bonds, rated Baa-2/ BBBx, are not refundable for five years.

title: Hole-in-One
description: Mark McCumber got a hole-in-one at the 190-yard, par-3 10th hole of the Winged Foot Golf Club West Course during today's opening round of the United States Open.

title: Enstar Bid Suit
description: Roy M. Huffington, the largest stockholder of the Enstar Corporation, said he is filing suit to enjoin the offer for the company made on Tuesday by the Unimar Company. Unimar, a partnership of subsidiaries of the Allied Corporation and Ultramar P.L.C., sweetened its offer for 51 percent of Enstar to $20 a share in cash. Mr. Huffington said the restructured offer cannot be legally consummated under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

title: BOARD REZONES PART OF MARKET FOR APARTMENTS
description: New apartments will be allowed in a small, southern patch of the Gansevoort-14th Street Meat Market on the edge of Greenwich Village under a rezoning plan approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: A SERIES THAT MAKES THE RERUN WORTHWHILE
description: RERUNS can be useful. Sunday at 9 P.M., public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' is bringing back the 13- episode BBC-Australian Broadcasting production of ''To Serve Them All My Days'' on Channel 13. It's a delightful summer treat, both for those who missed the series the first time and for those who want to see it again.

title: NEW ANTITRUST MERGER GUIDELINES ISSUED
description: Attorney General William French Smith issued new antitrust merger guidelines today that indicate greater flexibility in the way the Justice Department will decide whether to challenge merger proposals.

title: NOT JUST FOR DOLLS
description: To the Editor:

title: WAYS TO STOP DRUGS
description: The drive to control drugs has been well described by Vice President Bush as a marathon, but in this race no one party or branch of government can hope to capture all the glory. It is tempting to herald new initiatives or to announce large-scale arrests - I know because I made my fair share of such announcements when I headed the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: U.S. WARNS ARABS ON POSTAL OUSTER OF ISRAEL
description: The United States will withdraw its delegation and withhold money from the Universal Postal Union if Israel is expelled from the organization's congress, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Design Competition For Times Square Plaza

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After foreign exchange gains of $113,000 for the latest quarter and $2,000 for the year-earlier period. c-After foreign exchange losses of $49,000 for the latest 6 months and $136,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: 2 Named to Justice Board
description: President Reagan named the mother of a Maryland murder victim to the advisory board of the National Institute of Justice today. The nominee is Roberta Roper, 47 years old, of Upper Marlboro, Md., who heads an advocacy group for the rights of crime victims. Her daughter, Stephanie, was murdered by two men while hitchhiking in southern Maryland in 1982. Mr. Reagan also appointed Joan Lipsky, 65, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, to the board.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $3.8 million writedown on certain assets. c-Net income

title: LABATT, JOHN LTD reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a $19.7 million writeoff on disposition of surplus obsolete bottles. c-After a $3.5 million loss on disposal of Laura Secord division. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: VOLCKER PLAYS DOWN ARGENTINA'S DEADLINE
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today played down the importance of a deadline Friday for Argentina to qualify for a special $300 million Government loan to ease it through its immediate interest payment difficulties.

title: NOARKO RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR AFRIKANERS, REDEMPTION ON THE RUGBY FIELD
description: With some slight bewilderment, a visiting American remarked the other day that everything here seemed to turn on the issue of race. Well, almost.

title: A NUANCE IN FIELDING QUESTIONS
description: President Reagan dominated his news conference tonight with a tone of moderation and a concern for nuance in discussing possible changes in relations with the Soviet Union. At times, he sounded nonpartisan, but not so much that he could resist some humorous political jabs at his critics.

title: Celebrity Status
description: Ken Hobart, a 23-year-old rookie quarterback from Kamiah, Idaho, has begun to discover admirers in the world of pro football, heretofore so cold and cruel.

title: Diner's Journal
description: -size TriBeCa restaurant, with its graphic black-and-white- tile exterior, looks like an eccentric rock- music club in a neighborhood of eccentric rock clubs. Inside, however, it is comfortable and inviting - gray and black walls, soft lighting, Billie Holiday songs piped in - and from a kitchen the size of a subway token booth emerges some very special food.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $208,000 for the quarter and $309,000 for the 9 months.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FILM: 'CAREFUL HE MIGHT HEAR YOU'
description: WHAT appears to be a bright light is seen in the dark as muffled voices are heard offscreen. When the camera pulls back, the light turns out to be the reflection in the unblinking eye of a small boy, lying in bed and listening to the muffled conversation of the adults in the next room. Occasionally, he can make out individual words, frequently punctuated by cautionary ''shhhh's.''

title: Duva's Due
description: The sins of the manager apparently will not be visited upon his fighters when The New York State Athletic Commission gets around to dealing with Lou Duva. The commission was upset with Duva's behavior June 1 in Buffalo after one of his fighters, Johnny Bumphus, lost the World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title to Gene Hatcher.

title: Funds Withheld From Facility Where 7 Drank Cleaning Fluid
description: The Texas Department of Health said today that it would withhold Medicaid funds from a nursing home that accidentally served cleaning solvent instead of juice to seven patients, including one who later died.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about a tribute to Basil A. Paterson misstated the date of a reception for him at Automation House. It was Tuesday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KAYE WAYFARING IN 'AVENGED': Four Stories. By James McCourt. 181 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: TRILOGY SEES DELAY FOR 'WAFER' CHIP
description: Trilogy Ltd., the troubled Silicon Valley company that earlier this week scrapped its plans to build an innovative mainframe computer, said today that it will be at least 1986 before it can bring its large, ''wafer scale'' computer chips to market.

title: Coffee Account To McCaffrey
description: McCaffrey & McCall, which last month got a special project assignment from the National Coffee Association of USA, yesterday won the whole ball of wax. And it will probably bill around $14 million.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains of $37,000 from discontinued operations and $30,000 from tax credits. c-After a gain of $33,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $94,000 from discontinued operations and tax credits of $97,000.

title: Raises in Japan Average 4.42%
description: The Japan Federation of Employers' Associations said today that workers at major Japanese companies received an average annual pay increase of 4.42 percent, or $39.81, in wage negotiations this spring.

title: IRT Fire Injures Five And Routs Hundreds
description: A fire under an IRT subway car in Brooklyn injured five passengers during the morning rush hour yesterday and forced hundreds of others to evacuate the train, the police said.

title: LEGALIZE DRUGS
description: As a trial lawyer with some 20 years' experience, I have followed the battle with drugs with a keen interest. Month after month, we read stories of how the Government has made a major seizure of drugs and cracked an important drug ring. It is reassuring to know that for more than 20 years our Federal, state and local governments have been making such headway against drugs. It reminds me of the body counts during the Vietnam War, when every week we heard of large numbers of North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers killed in battle. Somehow, they kept coming, and they finally forced us out and overwhelmed their enemies.

title: Bridge: BEasterners May Benefit
description: A major surprise on the West Coast last weekend has slightly improved the prospect of some East Coast players in the Grand National Team Championship.

title: U.S. CAMPAIGN TO FIGHT DRUGS IN STATE BACKED
description: The Reagan Administration has endorsed a new $25 million air, land and sea program to combat drug smuggling in New York State, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today.

title: ART: RIVERA, THE CUBIST FRUITFUL ERA IN EUROPE
description: DIEGO RIVERA is best remembered as a leading light of the Mexican mural movement in the 1920's and 30's (and in some circles as the painter Frida Kahlo's husband). He executed his busy, socially conscious wall paintings, stressing the fruits of revolution and the evils of capitalism, for such respectable edifices as the National Palace in Mexico City, Rockefeller Center in New York (the mural is now destroyed) and the San Francisco Stock Exchange. And their fame has eclipsed the Cubist paintings he did in Europe between 1913 and 1917, under the spell of the Paris avant-garde.

title: Israel's Forces Return Fire From Inside Syria
description: Israeli soldiers in southeast Lebanon fought a two-hour gunbattle today with attackers firing from behind Syrian lines, the Israeli military command in Tel Aviv said.

title: THEATER: 'KENNEDY AT COLONUS,' ON ROBERT'S LIFE
description: IF you forget the mixed notices

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Take the Country Out of the Colors
description: Gold is gold, silver is silver and bronze is bronze. But the Olympic medals that will be sought by athletes in Los Angeles this summer will not have any nationalistic colors attached.

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: A small, elegant place in SoHo.

title: Sonics Re-sign Sikma He helped lead the Seattle SuperSonics to the National Basketball Association championship in 1979 and has been named an all-star six times in seven years. But after two consecutive seasons in which the SuperSonics were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs, there was speculation that the center
description: Jack Sikma might be put on the trading block while the SuperSonics sought younger talent in the draft. Yesterday, Sikma and General Manager Les Habegger sought to put an end to such talk. They announced that the 28-year-old player had signed a five-year contract designed to keep him in Seattle for the rest of his career.

title: 2 ISRAELIS ADMIT BELONGING TO JEWISH TERROR GROUP
description: Two more defendants in the trial of 25 suspected Jewish terrorists pleaded guilty today to a variety of conspiracy charges, including membership in a ''terrorist organization.''

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 15, 1984 International
description: President Reagan is willing to meet ''any time'' with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, to discuss a broad range of issues to improve mutual understanding, Mr. Reagan said at a news conference. He said, however, that Moscow had rebuffed him by insisting on ''a very carefully prepared agenda.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.)

title: CABARET: VARIETY SHOW
description: IN recent years, the word ''cabaret'' has been used to describe a

title: ANNA T. GAGARIN
description: Anna Timofeyevna Gagarin, mother of the cosmonaut who became the first man in space, Yuri Gagarin, has died at the age of 80, the Soviet television announced today.

title: QUESTIONABLE ROOTS OF ANTI-SOCIAL CONDUCT
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD TIMES, GOOD PAY FOR SUMMER LAW INTERNS
description: For the next few months, the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore will, among other things, pay half of each summer associate's rent, while Debevoise & Plimpton will cater picnics for its associates at Shakespeare in the Park.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BROADWAY;
description: What's in a name? If it's Churchill, there's a musical.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: New Zealand Calls Election for July
description: The Government has lost its one-vote working majority in Parliament and has called general elections for July 14, Prime Minister Robert Muldoon, said today.

title: Tape on DeLorean Replayed
description: The prosecution today replayed for the jury portions of its surveillance tapes of John Z. DeLorean talking about a purported cocaine deal.

title: Dane Settles Rats Case
description: Prime Minister Poul Schlueter agreed today to pay $59,000 to the man who bought Mr. Schlueter's house and then complained that it was infested with rats and that the timberwork was rotting.

title: California Ratings Are Seen in Peril
description: Bond ratings for California and 458 local governments in the state are threatened by a tax-limiting proposal known as Jarvis 4, according to analysts at Standard & Poor's.

title: Changes in Divorce Law Gain in Britain
description: The House of Commons approved revisions of the country's divorce laws today, voting to allow couples to start proceedings after only one year of marriage instead of three.

title: Lion Capital Confusion
description: Despite the testimony yesterday of an official of the Lion Capital Group, a government securities firm that filed for bankruptcy last month, it is still not clear why several of the firms' creditors are claiming the same securities as collateral.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge from spun-off operations of $138,000. c-After a gain of $54,000 from spun- off operations.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring capital gain of $382,000. The year-ago revenue has been restated.

title: U.S. Quits U.N. Debate On a Space Arms Race
description: The United States delegation today walked out of a debate being held by a United Nations committee on the militarization of space when the issue of a possible arms race in space was reached on the agenda.

title: Romeo' Gets Around
description: ''Romeo and Juliet,'' a touring production by the Riverside Shakespearen Company, will be performed today at 6 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx; tomorrow at 2 P.M. in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, and Sunday at 4 P.M. in Cunningham Park in Queens.

title: Beatrice Tender
description: The Beatrice Companies said that about 20,259,000 shares of Esmark Inc. common stock, or 48 percent of the total outstanding, was tendered by Wednesday's withdrawal deadline.

title: WOODWARD STORES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $23,725,288 from the sale of a shopping center. c-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SAKHAROV KIN ASK NEW HELSINKI PACT
description: The stepdaughter of Andrei D. Sakharov said today that Western countries should consider ''suspending, denouncing or renegotiating'' the 1975 Helsinki accords with the Soviet Union to protest the treatment of the Soviet physicist and dissident.

title: AFTERMATH AT GOLDEN TEMPLE: HOLES AND A HOLLOW SCIENCE
description: At one end of the Golden Temple complex sits an ornate, brooding structure called the Akal Takht, where all Sikh priestly authority ordinarily resides.

title: LESSON FOR QUINONES
description: News Analysis

title: JERSEY SCHOOL BUZZES AS REAGAN PLANS TO DROP IN AND HAIL ANTIDRINKING PROGRAM
description: The seniors at River Dell High School here had just finished a final exam in the school auditorium when the principal summoned the student body for a surprise message: President Reagan was coming to the school next Wednesday.

title: Olivetti-Micropro
description: Ing C. Olivetti & C. S.p.A. said it had signed a deal with Micropro Interntional to develop and sell Micropro software programs for Olivetti personal computers. Micropro is based in San Rafael, Calif. Olivetti officials said that Micropro would develop foreign language programs to back up Olivetti's export marketing network for personal computers.

title: Heat Forces Peete to Quit
description: Calvin Peete was forced out of the United States Open today when he nearly collapsed while playing the third hole. The 40-year-old Peete was given emergency treatment at a first-aid station on the Winged Foot Golf Club course and a preliminary electrocardiogram that proved normal.

title: REPORTER'S NOTE BOOK: JACKSON AT THE RIVER JORDAN
description: On the final day of the Presidential primary season, a tired-looking Jesse Jackson stood at peace among his supporters, outside the Acorn housing projects in Oakland, Calif.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Calvert Distillers Co., New York, a wine and spirits company, has named Mark M. Taxel executive vice president, marketing.

title: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates eased fractionally yesterday as traders sorted through a confusing array of new economic and financial data. Economists said the data do not point convincingly to either higher or lower rates.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DANCE: GABRIELA DARVASH
description: GABRIELA DARVASH is known as one of the best ballet teachers in New York, attracting many professional dancers as well as young students to her classes.
