A number of these professionals, including Nancy Raffa of American Ballet Theater and Judith Fugate of the New York City Ballet, are appearing in the series of performances entitled ''Darvash Dancers on Display'' that run through tomorrow at The Open Eye, 316 East 88th Street. Miss Darvash has dedicated the programs to the late Nina Brito, a friend of many dancers.

title: Dining Out Guide: Restaurants With Views
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ANNA'S HARBOR RESTAURANT, 565 City

title: SUBWAY AIDE CITES AN ORDER TO BLOCK CARS
description: The New York City Transit Authority official who was responsible for accepting the authority's new Japanese subway cars has charged that he was ordered by superiors to find a reason to hold up approval of the cars ''or else.''

title: CENTRAL MAINE
description: The Central Maine Power Company said it had notified the Public Utilities Commission of its plan to file for a $60 million, or 13 percent, rate increase. The company said it would also propose that the commission examine a ''rate plan'' designed to hold rate increases, excluding adjustment for fuel costs, to an annual average of about 7.5 percent for the five years through 1989. Central Maine said the plan is designed to improve its financial health, while sharing the burden of canceled plants between investors and consumers.

title: Georgia's Loss
description: Vince Dooley, the football coach at Georgia, lost Herschel Walker for his senior year when the 1982 Heisman Trophy winner signed to play with the Generals of the United States Football League last year.

title: Opera in Brooklyn
description: ''Trio,'' a chamber opera by Noa Ain, can be seen in previews at St. Ann's Church (834-8794), 157 Montague Street in Brooklyn, tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 4 P.M. before its American Music Theater Festival production in Philadelphia. Tickets are $10; $5 for students, the unemployed and the elderly.

title: Jackson Assails Decision On Seniority Over Race
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today criticized the Supreme Court's decision Tuesday that gave priority to seniority systems over affirmative action considerations in determining employee layoffs. He said the ruling was one ''designed to protect the privileged position of the white male minority.''

title: U.S. WORLD AND NEWS MILLIONAIRES
description: Obadiah Person, the company chauffeur at U. S. News & World Report for 39 years, has never been a wealthy man. But he may be shortly.

title: CITY LOSES A BID TO RECOVER SOME COSTS OF '77 BLACKOUT
description: The state's highest court ruled yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company need not pay New York City for the additional police and fire protection or loss of revenues caused by the 1977 blackout.

title: Gurdon F. Flagg Dies at 83; Developed the Duquesne Club
description: Gurdon F. Flagg, who was instrumental in developing the Duquesne Club into one of the nation's foremost private clubs, died Wednesday night at St. Francis General Hospital. Mr. Flagg, who was 83 years old, had suffered several strokes.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN HOME FROM EUROPE TOUR
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha returned home here today after an 18-day tour of Western Europe that has been interpreted here as a move away from his racially divided nation's international isolation.

title: Lawyer and Firm Settle After High Court Ruling
description: A woman who won a United States Supreme Court ruling that law firms must follow Federal antidiscrimination laws when choosing partners settled her lawsuit today against her former law firm.

title: Fumes From Warehouse Fire Forces Evacuation in Florida
description: Dangerous chemical fumes from fertilizer and pesticides in a smoldering warehouse here forced hundreds of nearby residents to flee today and caused minor injuries.

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TAX UNIT VOTES $6 BILLION RISE
description: Senate and House conferees today approved about $6 billion in tax increases, primarily affecting corporations and tax shelter investors. The conferees also decided to raise the deduction allowed to individuals for transportation expenses incurred in connection with voluntary charity work.

title: Frazier Remembers It was a ceremony to honor 10 new members of the Madison Square Garden Hall of Fame, but it was two of the inductees who seemed to be doing much of the honoring - of each other. ''He's the one who developed me,'' said
description: Walt Frazier, the former Knick star. ''He was always a great defensive player, and he became a great passer,'' said Red Holzman, the former Knick coach.

title: Evelyn B. Kenvin Wed To Arthur Rosenbloom
description: Evelyn B. Kenvin, the daughter of Binnie Billig of New York and Lido Beach, L.I., and the late Max J. Billig, was married yesterday to Arthur H. Rosenbloom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rosenbloom of Great Neck, L.I., and Miami Beach. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan apartment.

title: INVENTORIES SWELLED IN APRIL
description: Businesses continued to restock their shelves and showrooms at a rapid rate during April, pushing inventories 1.5 percent higher than in March, while sales were rising seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PINIELLA WILL END CARRERR AS PLAYER
description: Lou Piniella, who has been announcing his retirement for the last four years, announced it for real today, saying the Yankee game Saturday against the Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium would be his last as a player.

title: ; The stop-go adventure of 9 1/2 Weeks.'
description: INSIDE his trailer, which bears a

title: ELAINE DIACUMAKOS, HELD A LEADING ROLE IN CELL MICROSURGERY
description: Dr. Elaine G. Diacumakos, who played a leading role in the development of cell microsurgery, died of a heart attack Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 53 years old.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $3,108,000 for the quarter and $6,133,000 for the 6 months.

title: RIGHTFUL INHERITORS OF PRE-COLUMBIAN TREASURES
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. CREDIT: A BUYOUT PIONEER
description: As one of the biggest purveyors of financing for leveraged buyouts and an aggressive proponent of ''creative financing'' for American companies, the General Electric Credit Corporation is growing rapidly in the turbulent financial services industry.

title: No Headline
description: The Patient Has a Right to Know ''An educated consumer is our best customer,'' says the ad for Syms, a New York clothing store. The Department of Health and Human Services now proposes to apply a similar, laudable national policy to medical care. Doctors and hospitals are resisting, thus impeding the effort to tame the runaway inflation for health services.

title: RICHARD LURIA KITT
description: Richard Luria Kitt, a manufacturer and importer of women's clothing, died of cancer in an ambulance on the way to Lenox Hill Hospital Wednesday night.

title: ;  Citibank Executive Joining London Broker
description: Anthony Regan, senior vice president of international investments at Citibank, will join the big London stock brokerage firm of Fielding Newson-Smith in July.

title: LATIN AID DISPUTE SEEMS DEADLOCKED
description: A stalemate between the House and Senate over authorization of $21 million in emergency aid for covert operations in Nicaragua has frozen a supplemental spending bill containing $62 million in military aid for El Salvador.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split distributed Jan. 24.

title: THEATER: 'PRETTY BOY' AND A BECKETT
description: IN their creative explorations,

title: Norfolk Southern to Bid for Conrail Monday
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it will submit its bid for the acquisition of Conrail on Monday, the last day the Department of Transportation will accept bids for the federally owned rail carrier.

title: Prof. William A. Clebsch, 60; Leader in Religious Studies
description: William A. Clebsch, a professor of religious studies and humanities at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., collapsed and died in his campus office Tuesday. He was 60 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

title: Ted Bates and Needham Testing for Anheuser
description: The fact that Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewer, is testing Michelob TV commercials by Ted Bates Advertising and Needham, Harper & Steers, was confirmed yesterday by D'Arcy MacManus Masius, the longtime Anheuser agency.

title: Strawberry Gets Votes
description: Darryl Strawberry of the Mets led all outfielders when the first weekly results of fan balloting for the National League's all-star team were announced yesterday.

title: ART: FOR JEAN COCTEAU, WORD WAS MULTIFARIOUS
description: JEAN COCTEAU is a subject to make a curator's mouth water. A member of the avant-garde hall of fame, Cocteau collaborated or fought with many of the major avant-garde figures of the first half of the century. A respected novelist, playwright, film maker and, above all, poet, Cocteau was also a gifted draftsman, who needed the jet-propeled wings of lines on paper as much as the solid but more methodical wings of words.

title: Books: Right Face
description: THE RISE OF THE RIGHT. By William A. Rusher. 336 pages. William Morrow & Co. $15.95. ''THE RISE OF THE RIGHT'' comes at us with endorsements from William F. Buckley Jr., Senators Jesse Helms, Orrin G. Hatch and Paul Laxalt and Representative Philip M. Crane. It's a model of truth in packaging.

title: Kirin and Amgen Hormone Venture
description: The Kirin Brewery Company of Japan and Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company, said they had received approval from the United States and Japanese Governments for a joint venture and have capitalized the new company at $24 million.

title: PRESIDENT EXPRESSES WILLINGNESS TO MEET MONDALE IN DEBATE
description: President Reagan tonight expressed his willingness to debate Walter F. Mondale this year if Mr. Mondale wins the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: 11 More Children at a School In Jersey Are Felled by Heat
description: Eleven children at graduation exercises in the Elwood Primary School in Mullica Township, N.J., were taken to a hospital last night when they were overcome by the heat. It was the second day on which pupils fell victim to the heat in the school's auditorium, which is not air-conditioned.

title: Teamster Plan Repays Funds
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan announced today that $6.75 million had been repaid to the teamsters' Central States Pension and Health and Welfare funds by the current trustees, fiduciaries and liability insurers.

title: Wilander Hurts Wrist
description: Mats Wilander, the world's fourth- ranked men's tennis player, said in his native Sweden that he might have to withdraw from the Wimbledon tournament, which begins late this month, because he had sprained his right wrist in practice. ''I don't know when I will be able to play tennis next,'' he said. ''If I am not all right, there is no reason for me to go to Wimbledon.''

title: TENNIS LADY reports earnings for Year to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss

title: EPITEK INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After special gains of $43,000 for the quarter and $61,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after special losses of $125,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the 6 months.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $136,200, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $259,100, or 8 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $128,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $59,600, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: STAGE: ROZOV'S 'NEST OF THE WOOD GROUSE'
description: WHILE it is unusual to find a contemporary Soviet play on a New York stage, it's even more unusual to find a contemporary Soviet play by an author who is not a dissident. Such a rare theatrical specimen is ''The Nest of the Wood Grouse,'' the Viktor Rozov comedy that Joseph Papp has staged at the Public's Newman Theater. Unlike the other Eastern European authors whom Mr. Papp has showcased this year - Vaclav Havel (''A Private View'') and Janusz Glowacki (''Cinders'') - Mr. Rozov co-exists with the authorities at home. As a program insert informs us, ''The Nest of the Wood Grouse'' is ''currently playing to capacity audiences at the Satire Theater in Moscow.''

title: Utility Ends Negotiations
description: The Consumers Power Company canceled negotiations today with opponents of the Midland nuclear plant, as utility directors prepared to decide whether the $4.1 billion project should be halted.

title: POPE URGES SWISS TO MONITOR BANKS
description: Pope John Paul II urged the Swiss people in a sermon today to keep their country's banks honest.

title: Citicorp Offering
description: A $250 million offering of Citicorp extendable notes with a final maturity in 1999 is offered at a price of 100 with an initial coupon of 13.60 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. After two years investors have the option of redeeming their notes at par. At that time, Citicorp will announce a new interest rate and a new maturity of from one to five years.

title: MONDALE TO NAME SOME TICKET OPTIONS
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that he expected to announce in the next few days the first group of men and women he would interview in the search for a Vice-Presidential running mate.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PAL GOES ON STAGE

title: A SERIOUS EVENT
description: It was a serious event. Big-league urban politics and fund-raising.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: THE Americas were around long before 1776, and they extend past the Mexican and Canadian borders. When the seventh Great Hudson River Revival presents all-American folk music this weekend at Croton Point Park - an hour up the Hudson from Manhattan - the program will reach beyond the historical and geographical limits of the United States.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 15, 1984

title: People
description: * Buffy Shutt named executive vice president-marketing of the Motion Picture Group of Paramount Pictures Corp.

title: FORMER BRIGADIER AMONG 86 SIKHS HELD AS TERROR SUSPECTS IN PUNJAB
description: At least 86 Sikhs suspected of being terrorists were arrested in Punjab today, Indian officials said, but no army desertions or violence were reported in the state and some transportation service was restored.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Mondale Platform

title: SAYS DOOR IS OPEN
description: President Reagan said tonight that he was willing to ''meet and talk any time'' with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, to discuss a broad range of subjects aimed at improving mutual understanding.

title: TRANSFERRING L.I. RETARDED UPSET IN U.S. APPEALS COURT
description: A three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which has jurisdiction over the three states, overturned parts of a ruling handed down in August 1983 by Jack B. Weinstein, chief judge of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 4 Nations Hold Votes For Europe Parliament
description: Voters in Britain, Ireland, Denmark and the Netherlands cast ballots today in the first of two elections for representatives to the European Parliament.

title: IRWIN SHOOTS 68, 2 UNDER PAR, TO SHARE 4-WAY OPEN LEAD
description: Hale Irwin, returning to the scene of his first United States Open triumph in 1974, and Hubert Green, the 1977 champion, each holed out of a bunker today at the 84th Open, Irwin with a 60-foot shot and Green with a 30-footer. Those shots helped earn them a share of the lead with Jim Thorpe and Mike Donald, two nonwinners on the pro tour, after the first round at Winged Foot Golf Club.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax settlement of $400,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: U.S.F.L. Said to Get TV Help
description: The United States Football League's future, one dimmed recently by shrinking television ratings and disappointing attendances, apparently is about to take a sharp turn for the better.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: Neither deadening heat nor threat of rain could dissuade Harriet Frankel from giving her rooftop garden party Wednesday night. And so with temperatures in the 90's and the sky darkening she set out her rented tables among the lettuces, ferns and firs that comprise the roof garden of the building in which she and her husband, Irving, live. The party was to be for Lynne Meadow, artistic director of the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: ARMS TALK SHIFT?
description: By opening up the possibility of a summit meeting in his remarks tonight, President Reagan may well have succeeded in transforming the domestic political debate about his arms control policies into a debate on summitry, where he has now seized the high ground.

title: TRADING HALTS: A NEW POLICY
description: Almost everyone loves a good mystery. For investors, it takes the form of a guessing game when the New York Stock Exchange halts trading in a listed company's stock with the simple but tantalizing announcement that the company has said there is ''significant news pending.''

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
After Gala, Trudeau Gives Farewell Speech
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, whose 16-year reign as Prime Minister is coming to an end, bade goodbye to the nation today and called on delegates to a Liberal Party convention to use ''good conscience'' in choosing his successor.

title: G.M. in Pact On Korea Car
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had signed a $426 million agreement for the Daewoo Motor Company of South Korea to build Adam Opel-designed cars for the Korean market, starting in the 1987 model year. Daewoo is half owned by G.M. and half by the Daewoo Corporation.

title: Seoul's Trade Deficit
description: South Korea's current account deficit widened in May, to $370 million, from $219 million in May 1983.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After benefits of net operating loss carry forward of $251,900 for the quarter and $525,700 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The latest 9 months' share earnings was restated to reflect 1-for-1 stock distribution paid in January 1984.

title: Assets Of Money Funds Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Wednesday, climbing $146.4 million, to $174.87 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Hearns and Duran Left to Themselves
description: Roberto Duran and Thomas Hearns, two of the chief mourners when Sugar Ray Leonard retired last month, completed their preparations today for the next best thing: fighting each other in an attempt to restore the luster to their careers.

title: Comings and Goings The Pittsburgh Penguins said they have signed 18-year-old
description: Mario Lemieux , the top choice in last Saturday's National Hockey League draft.

title: STATE SENATOR DECLARED WINNER IN TEXAS DEMOCRATIC RECOUNT
description: The Texas Democratic Executive Committee today certified a recount of the votes in the June 2 runoff for the United States Senate nomination and declared State Senator Lloyd Doggett the official winner over Representative Kent Hance.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Jersey Man Pleads Guilty to Gun-Running
description: A New Jersey man who conspired with a former Central Intelligence Agency agent to sell arms to terrorist groups has pleaded guilty to gun-running charges, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: 2 Damrosch Concerts
description: A concert of Rodgers and Hammerstein hits will be presented by the Metropolitan Life Foundation tonight at 8 in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park band shell (rain date, July 3). On Sunday night at 7 at the same site there will be a concert of Yidish folk, art and theater music (rain date, Monday). Both are free.

title: The U.N. Today June 15, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Brazil Cites Growth Signs
description: The rise in exports is the driving force behind the recovery now begining to be felt in the Brazilian economy, Finance Minister Ernane Galveas said today.

title: PROPAGANDA, PROPAGATION OR JUST PROP
description: White House officials scoffed when a reporter asked whether they might be running a ministry of propaganda. But a little-noticed White House ''outreach'' program has been working steadily for a year now at disseminating the Reagan Administration's view that Nicaragua is a Communist beachhead threatening the hemisphere and that the American public is not being fully informed of the danger.

title: Opera Costume Exhibit
description: An exhibition of costumes from the New York City Opera is on view in the Vera Maxwell Costume Gallery at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, through Sept. 3.

title: MCGREGOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $771,000. The company said that the loss from discontinued operations related to McGregor's equity interests in recently acquired Faberge Inc. McGregor acquired 61 percent of Faberge in March.

title: FEDERAL LEGISLATORS CLOAKED BY THE VOICE VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN GUIDE TO THE GLOW OF LOUIS TIFFANY'S GLASS
description: SEASONED collectors delight in telling tales about the truckloads of Tiffany glass that were carted off to junk shops in the 1920's, when the popularity of the Art Deco movement and of 18th-century-revival styles swept the country. And how in 1932, when Louis Comfort Tiffany's studios went bankrupt, the lead from the lamp bases was melted down and sold by the pound.

title: VOTING FOREIGN POLICY
description: The conventional wisdom that Presidential campaigns take a heavy toll on United States foreign policy is at the least an exaggeration and possibly dead wrong.

title: AUTHOR AND AIRLINE EXECUTIVE
description: George A. Spater, a former chairman of American Airlines who took up a second career as a biographer and was co-author of a portrait of Virginia and Leonard Woolf, died yesterday at his home in White River Junction, Vt. He was 75 years old.

title: French Inflation Eases
description: French retail prices in May rose five-tenths of 1 percent from April and 7.8 percent from a year earlier, the National Statistics Institute said today. The rate of increase was slightly slower than in April, when retail prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent from March and 7.9 percent from a year earlier.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: What's in a Perfume?

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Chicago and North Western Transportation Co. said it had filed for an $80 million public offering of consolidated series B mortgage bonds through Salomon Brothers.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: The year-ago quarter's earnings restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split distributed July 15, 1983.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW BLOOM ON THE 'ROSE'
description: ''THE NAME OF THE ROSE,'' a mystery novel set in an abbey in 1327 and written by Umberto Eco, an Italian professor of semiotics, was a surprise best seller after it was published in hard cover last year by Helen & Kurt Wolff-Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Still, many people in publishing were skeptical when Warner Books paid $550,000 for paperback rights, a sum said to be a record for a book translated from another language. They argued privately that despite the book's strong hard-cover sales, it was unlikely - because it is a literary novel - to do well in an edition aimed at the mass market.

title: CORRECITONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the expansion of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center misidentified Benno C. Schmidt. He is chairman of Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Philip Winston Pillsbury, 81, Of the Flour-Milling Company
description: Philip Winston Pillsbury, chairman emeritus of the Pillsbury Company, died today at the age of 81.

title: Trade Hits Snag The big trade Wednesday that sent the outfielders
description: Mel Hall and Joe Carter and the pitchers Don Schulze and Darryl Banks of the Chicago Cubs to the Cleveland Indians for the catcher Ron Hassey and the veteran pitchers Rick Sutcliffe and George Frazier ran into a snag yesterday. The interleague trading deadline passed many weeks ago, but General Manager Dallas Green of the Cubs neglected to place either Hall or Carter on waivers, the only way that a player can move from league to league once the deadline has passed.

title: GUILTY VERDICT FOR DEFENDANT IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Samuel Brown, the last of the Brink's defendants who have been caught, was found guilty today of murder and robbery, ending a two-and-a-half-year prosecution that included three trials.

title: Giants 5, Padres 2
description: Johnnie LeMaster and Jeff Leonard each hit home runs to lead San Francisco. Mark Davis (3-6) went the first eight innings and stymied the Padres on seven hits. Gary Lavelle got the final three outs for his seventh save.

title: 2 TELL OF GIVING FUNDS FOR EX-BOSTON MAYOR'S WIFE
description: Two witnesses with business ties to Theodore V. Anzalone, a longtime associate of former Mayor Kevin H. White, testified today that they had contributed money to a birthday party fund for the Mayor's wife.

title: A SERIOUS TOUCH OF THE SENIOR JITTERS PRECEDES A PROM NIGHT TO REMEMBER
description: For some reason, prom night always seems to have such a jittery start. ''There are just such high hopes for everything,'' said Gail Boorstein, the prom committee secretary.

title: Carter Defense
description: Directors of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. approved proposals - to be submitted to shareholders - that would prevent The Limited Inc. from winning seats on the board by using California's cumulative voting law, under which a shareholder gets one vote for each position but can allocate all those votes for one or two positions.

title: CASH GIFT'S FOR MAYOR'S DESCRIBED AT TRIAL IN BOSTON
description: The sister-in- law of former Mayor Kevin H. White, testifying in the trial of Theodore V. Anzalone, said today that she was surprised when Mr. Anzalone handed her an envelope with more than $50,000 in checks intended as a birthday gift for Mr. White's wife.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Colleges in Jersey To Report Crimes
description: The State Board of Higher Education approved rules today requiring colleges to report on-campus crimes to state education officials, as part of a program to better protect students from violence and hazing.

title: Conrail's Board Asserts Right to Approve Sale
description: The directors of Conrail have told Elizabeth H. Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, that they would reserve the right to make or support other offers for the railroad if they felt that none of those submitted by Monday were in the best interests of the corporation.

title: ALABAMA MAYOR HEADS PANEL TO PLAN DEMOCRATS' PLATFORM
description: Mayor Richard Arrington of Birmingham, who was credited with helping Walter F. Mondale win the Alabama Democratic primary in March, was named today as chairman of the 15-member committee that will begin drafting the Democratic platform here next week.

title: PREMATURE HIGH HOPES FOR YEN APPRECIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: IRWIN BIRDIES THE FINAL 3 FOR 68-136 AND SHOT LEAD
description: Winged Foot West's final three holes have stood for 55 years as perhaps the strongest ''last mile'' in United States Open competition. But today they bent slightly in the wind as Hale Irwin became the first player in four Opens at Winged Foot to finish off a round with a birdie on each of these par-4 holes.

title: CORRECITONS
description: An article on the stock market in Business Day yesterday misidentified the company holding discussions with Electronic Data Systems. It is the General Motors Corporation.

title: ART FOR THOSE ON THE GO IN CHICAGO
description: This city's latest ''art galleries'' are the three newest subway stations on the rapid-transit line that leads to O'Hare International Airport.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Big Brother?

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS Orange Juice Prices Hit Lows, Then Recover
description: Frozen concentrate orange juice futures ignored a bullish report of orange juice movements and slid to eight-week lows in New York today before recovering on late trade buying.

title: M.T.A. DISPUTES TRANSIT OFFICIAL ON JAPAN'S CARS
description: A Transit Authority official's charge that he had been ordered to find fault with new Japanese subway cars, ''or else,'' is unfounded, according to a report released yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Bridge: A Bid Turns Out to Be Right
description: A player in third seat with a minimum balanced hand often has three choices.

description: b-Including equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $47,000 for the quarter and $79,000 for the year and a tax credit of $602,000 for the year. c-Including equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $12,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the year and tax credits of $677,000 for the quarter and $1,707,000 for the year.

title: Egg Splatters Kohl At Campaign Rally
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl was hit by an egg and showered with fruit today at a campaign rally called by his conservative party for the European parliamentary election on Sunday.

title: French Output Off 3%
description: Industrial production in France, seasonally adjusted and excluding the construction industry, fell by 3 percent in April after rising 1.5 percent in March, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: Telephone Deal
description: United Telecommunications Inc., the nation's ninth-largest telephone holding company, was authorized to acquire U.S. Telephone Inc. through an exchange of stock currently valued at more than $70 million. The authorization was granted by the Federal Communications Commission, which concluded that the acquisition would ''serve the public interest'' by strengthening competition in the long-distance field. U.S. Telephone, based in Dallas, offers long-distance telephone service to customers in 88 cities using facilities leased from other companies. United Telecommunications, based in Kansas City, Mo., owns 20 local telephone operating companies.

title: 1,800 ATHLETES GATHER ON L.I. FOR INTERNATIONAL GAMES FOR DISABLED
description: More than 1,800 athletes from around the world will assemble this weekend at Mitchel Field for the opening of the 1984 International Games for the Disabled.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
15 AT CREEDMOOR TO FACE CHARGES
description: About 15 workers at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens were told yesterday that disciplinary charges would be sought against them as a result of an investigation into accusations of patient abuse and financial improprieties at the hospital, officials said.

title: POETIC CONJUNCTIONS
description: THREE LITERARY FRIENDSHIPS. By John Lehmann. 184 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $17.95.

description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings have been restated for 5-for-4 stock split on Aug. 15, 1983.

title: MX Petitioners Lose Bid for Nebraska Ballot
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that petitions cannot be used to put an initiative on the ballot to determine whether Nebraskans favor a two-way nuclear freeze and oppose deployment of the MX missile in the state.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Tickets Placed on Sale For Uniondale Games
description: Tickets for the opening ceremony of the International Games for the Disabled, which will begin at 2 P.M. tomorrow, are $8.50. Tickets for the closing ceremony, at 6 P.M. on June 29, are $5.

title: WARY BANKERS REJECT AN ARGENTINE PROPOSAL
description: A group of leading international bankers yesterday declined to agree to an arrangement under which Argentina would pay hundreds of millions of dollars in past-due interest to banks around the world.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
Mobile Phone System to Start
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday authorized the start of expanded mobile telephone service in the New York metropolitan area.

title: THE STORY OF A MUGGING
description: ''I've got a .38 in here, man,'' he announced, glancing down at his right hand thrust inside his purple jacket. ''Give me your money.'' We had passed him and his cohorts a few moments earlier: six teenagers - five males, one female. They were spread across the sidewalk, vaguely menacing. The one in the center was swinging a belt or chain.

title: THEATER: 'KUNI LEML,' ADAPTED FROM YIDDISH
description: There are few hoarier theater chestnuts than ''Kuni Leml,'' a musical written before 1880 by Abraham Goldfadn, the father, or the grandfather, of Yiddish theater, and it is simply remarkable how freshly roasted it is being served in its first English adaptation by the Jewish Repertory Theater on East 14th Street. The play not only sings its songs, but the production itself also sings, as a warm and high-spirited evening of comedy.

title: Letter: On Trade Policy Discharging a Debt, Charging Up a Deficit To the Editor:
description: Your editorial ''Sucking In Money - and Imports'' (June 8) rightly notes that when the United States' trade deficit exceeds $40 billion in four months, something is wrong. In ascribing its cause first to rapid economic growth in America and second to inordinately high interest rates provoked by Federal deficit spending, however, you neglect fundamental aspects of America's economic position in the world. By failing to mention the foreign debt owed to Americans and the enormous financial requirements imposed on debtor nations to meet current debt service obligations, you acquiesce in an incomplete and misleading analysis.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Partying in the Park

title: RIDERS WIN SUIT AGAINST CONRAIL IN WESTCHESTER
description: Eight commuters were awarded $250 each in punitive damages today because they suffered through poor train service for two months in 1982.

title: SURGERY FOR GYMNAST
description: Mary Lou Retton , who was the top woman gymnast at the recent United States Olympic trials, underwent arthroscopic surgery on her right knee yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Richmond, a hospital spokesman said. Miss Retton, 16, had two fragments of articular cartilage removed from the knee to relieve ''tremendous pain,'' the spokesman said. Dr. Richard Caspari , who performed the operation, said Miss Retton, who was discharged a few hours after the surgery, should be able to resume training in a few days.

title: MAKING THE WISHES OF BRIEF LIFETIMES COME TRUE
description: The waiting room in Mount Sinai Hospital's pediatric cancer clinic in Manhattan is filled with cookies and intravenous tubes, puppets, dolls and rubber gloves. It is a world apart. Vicky had stepped into and out of that world every week since she was 11 months old and was diagnosed as having leukemia.

title: TON OF COCAINE SEIZED IN FREEZERS ON CARGO JET
description: Customs agents today seized at least 2,000 pounds of cocaine found inside domestic freezers aboard a Panamanian jet in what officials said was one of the nation's largest cocaine seizures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: The Century Club

title: A WORLD DEBT CRISIS IS IGNORED AT OUT PERIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Farrar Service Set
description: A memorial service for Margret Farrar, a former crossword puzzle editor of The New York Times, who died on Monday, will be held at 2 P.M. on Tuesday at The Church of the Resurrection, 115 East 74th Street.

title: Conservative Is Firm On Race for Baker Seat
description: An outspoken conservative says he is sticking to his independent bid for the United States Senate seat being vacated by the majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, despite pressure from top Republicans who contend his campaign will hand the seat to a Democrat.

title: BROKERS MORTGAGE SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Large Labor Contingent At Convention Foreseen
description: More than 900 union activists will attend the Democratic National Convention as delegates and alternates, according to initial tabulations by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and the nonaffiliated National Education Association.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE CITY ; ;  CornerMayHonor SakharovandWife
description: A City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would name a street corner near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations after Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife.

title: U.S. CHALLENGING BIAS RULING
description: Quickly using a new Supreme Court decision limiting affirmative action, the Justice Department moved today to overturn a court order that bars the Cincinnati Police Department from laying off or demoting minority officers on the basis of seniority.

title: Opera in Brooklyn
description: ''Trio,'' a chamber opera by Noa Ain, can be seen in previews at St. Ann's Church (834-8794), 157 Montague Street in Brooklyn, through tomorrow before its American Music Theater Festival production in Philadelphia. Performances are tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 4 P.M.; tickets are $10; $5 for students, the unemployed and the elderly.

title: STATE IS URGED TO EASE RULES ON BASS CATCH
description: Restrictions imposed last year on the taking of striped bass in New York State waters have severely hurt commercial fishermen and should be eased, a task force has reported to Governor Cuomo.

title: 40 YEARS AFTER PACIFIC D-DAY, NO CROWDS AND NO PARADES
description: Just about no one visited Saipan's velvety beaches this morning to recall D-day in the Pacific part of World War II. The 40th anniversary came and went, bold only in its contrasts with the emotions and speeches that flowed in Normandy on Europe's D-day, June 6.

title: JAPAN'S STEREO TV SYSTEM
description: When Tokyo's Yomiuri Giants take the field, baseball fans watching the game on television are sometimes given a choice of two announcers - one of them impartial, the other clearly favoring the home team.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $185,000 for the latest quarter and $400,000 for the year- earlier period. The 1983 results were restated to reflect the discontinuance of retail and insurance premium finance operations.

title: ;  New Work Begins On
description: State and local officials broke ground today for the first phase of a $61 million state project to rehabilitate and rebuild the 60-year-old Hutchinson River Parkway.

title: Algeria Reports Clash With Moroccan Troops
description: Algeria said that its troops intercepted a 60-man Moroccan contingent inside Algerian territory early today and killed two Moroccan soldiers, wounded two and captured 31 in the fight that ensued.

title: ROOSEVELT HOME AT HYDE PARK ADDS LAND TO BAR DEVELOPMENT
description: A 26- acre parcel of land was added to the Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site here today, shielding the home of the 32d President and his wife from nearby commercial and residential development.

title: Traffic Jam Is Feared
description: United States Golf Association officials expressed concern over the possibility of extensive traffic problems Saturday and Sunday round the Winged Foot Golf Club if people without tickets try to attend the final two rounds of the United States Open. Officials feared additional congestion along the narrow roads, creating extra difficulty for golfers, fans and officials in getting to the course. The U.S.G.A. emphasized that all 20,000 tickets have been sold for each of the weekend rounds and that anyone hoping to buy a ticket at the gate will be turned away.

title: SHIRLEY PITCHES WELL IN YANKEE DEFEAT
description: A month ago, after Bob Shirley pitched five scoreless but admittedly sloppy innings against Seattle, Manager Yogi Berra was asked if Shirley would get another start.

description: b-Net income As a result of translation into U.S. currency, net income of Canadian subsidiaries for the latest quarter and year has been reduced by $15,000 and $415,000, respectively, and the net for the year-earlierquarter and year was reduced by $203,000 and $855,000, respectively.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Computer Delays Lottery Prizes
description: Lottery winners were unable to collect their prizes today as computer problems plagued the state game for a second day in a row.

title: NEW ELLINGTON TAPES DONATED BY HIS SON
description: --The son of the late American bandleader and composer Duke Ellington says he is donating to Radio Denmark nearly 50 boxes of unreleased studio tape recordings made by his father over the last 20 years of his life.

title: Isuzu's Sales Plan
description: Isuzu Motor Ltd., Japan's major truck maker, has prepared a three-year plan to increase sales by 50 percent, to more than 600,000 trucks and cars a year by 1987, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun said today. The daily said Isuzu would shortly sign a contract to export about 20,000 cars annually to G. M.-Holden's Ltd. of Australia, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation of the United States, which holds 34.2 percent of Isuzu stock. An Isuzu spokesman declined to comment on the report.

Fiber Optic Cable Plans Set
description: Plans to link North America to both Asia and Europe with fiber optic cables capable of carrying telephone messages at the speed of light were disclosed today.

title: Bank Gives Up Colorado Fight
description: United Banks of Colorado Inc. said it had agreed to end its hostile takeover bid for Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc. and to support the proposed merger between Affiliated and the Intrawest Financial Corportion. If the Affiliated-Intrawest merger is completed, United has the right to acquire, from Intrawest, the Bank of Boulder, which has assets of $128 million, and Intrawest of Colorado Springs, with assets of $45 million.

title: Carter Says Reporter Misquoted Prediction
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he was misquoted at President Reagan's news conference Thursday night by a reporter who said he had predicted that Mr. Reagan would duck a face-to-face debate with his Democratic opponent.

title: ELECTRONIC MAIL: NEW DISPUTE
description: The Postal Service's introduction of electronic mail in 1982 brought criticism from private industry, charges of unprofitability from Congress and legal objections from the Departments of Justice and Commerce. When the agency, which is now losing about $1 on each message it handles, decided last week to find a private contractor to take over or manage the troubled operation, it hoped to close the book on two years of contention.

title: FATHER'S DAY 1984, A TIME OF ACTIVISM
description: They can be seen in hospital delivery rooms as their wives give birth, and pushing strollers in the park. And their voices can increasingly be heard in child-custody cases and in hundreds of fathers'-rights and support groups that have emerged in the last few years throughout the country.

title: SANDINISTA SAYS SOME INSURGENTS REMAIN IN COUNTRY AFTER ATTACKS
description: The anti-Sandinista military offensive begun in March in northern and central Nicaragua appears to have ended with rebel forces having established some bases inside the country, according to a Nicaraguan military commander.

title: Software Arts Reduces Its Staff
description: Software Arts, the Wellesley, Mass., company that developed the Visicalc spreadsheet program, said it was laying off 60 of its 125 employees because of greatly reduced revenues.

title: PATENTS ; Process Separates PCB's From Liquids
description: The Electric Power Research Institute Inc., in Palo Alto, Calif., received a patent this week for the removal of polychlorinated biphenyls from oil or other liquids.

title: IRAN IS READY FOR PACT ON TANKER RAIDS
description: A senior Iranian official said today that Iran was prepared to extend an agreement with Iraq against bombing civilian targets to cover attacks on shipping in the Persian Gulf, according to the official Islamic Republic News Agency.

title: F.C.C. MOVES TO WIDEN COIN-PHONE OWNERSHIP
description: The Federal Communications Commission took action today that opened the way to allowing businesses and individuals to buy and profit from their own pay telephones.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: THON IS DOUBTFUL OF A RETURN IN '84
description: Finally feeling psychologically fit to discuss his eye injury that occurred when he was hit in the head by a pitch, Dickie Thon, the Houston Astros' shortstop, expressed strong doubt today that he could return to baseball this season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1984

title: ; UNFAIR FOREIGN ASSAULT ON THE U.S. COPPER INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph F. Fletcher Jr. Dies; Historian of Asia at Harvard
description: Joseph F. Fletcher Jr., a professor of Chinese and central Asian history at Harvard University, died of cancer Thursday night at the university's Stillman Infirmary. He was 49 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: YOUTH WHO KILLED ABUSIVE FATHER HAS TERM CUT
description: Richard Jahnke, a teen-ager serving a 5- to 15-year prison sentence for killing his abusive father, had his sentence commuted to three years Thursday by Gov. Ed Herschler.

title: 2 More Banks Close Doors
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today announced the closing of two banks - one in Tennessee and one in South Dakota.

title: Donna Ann Saniuk, a Nurse, Weds Quentin Besch
description: Donna Ann Saniuk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Prunkl of Toms River, N.J., was married yesterday to Quentin Wrightson Besch, a son of Mrs. Robert Woodruff Besch of Short Hills, N.J., and South Casco, Me., and the late Mr. Besch. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker of Christ Church in Summit, N.J., performed the Protestant ceremony at Mrs. Besch's Short Hills home.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Red Barber, Don Dunphy, Ted Husing and Bill Stern have been selected by the more than 600 members of the American Sportscasters Association as the first four members of the American Sportscasters Hall of Fame in Freehold, N.J. They will be inducted in September along with Graham McNamee, who was selected for induction by the group's executive committee. . . . Lou Duva , the boxing manager, will be fined $2,500 and given a ''severe reprimand'' by the New York State Athletic Commission for charging after Referee Johnny LoBianco June 1 in Buffalo after LoBianco ruled that Johnny Bumphus , Duva's fighter, could not go on in a World Boxing Association junior welterweight title bout won by Gene Hatcher . . . . Terry Cummings, the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year in 1983, said that, after two seasons with the San Diego Clippers, he would like to be traded to a contender. . . . John Castino , the Minnesota Twins third baseman who has been on the disabled list with a back problem for most of the season, is making a last-ditch effort to avoid surgery that could keep him out a year and a half and perhaps end his career. He has entered a hospital in Evansville, Ill., for a week of a new treatment based on anti-inflammatory drugs and intravenous steroids. Castino, who had surgery in 1982 to fuse two vertebrae, has been told he needs a further operation to fuse a third, but he hopes to avoid it.

title: German Prices Up
description: Retail prices in West Germany rose one-tenth of 1 percent in May from April and were up 2.5 percent from a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: Hilppa Alile Katriina Pirila Is Wed to Joe Lindell Roby
description: The First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn., was the scene yesterday of the marriage of Hilppa Alile Katriina Pirila, a daughter of Dr. Onni Olavi Pirila of Helsinki and the late Mrs. Pirila, to Joe Lindell Roby, a son of Mrs. Gerald C. Roby of Paducah, Ky., and the late Mr. Roby. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Producer Price Index Unchanged Last Month
description: Overall producer prices were unchanged in May for a second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today, and food prices fell at the steepest rate in nearly two years.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Delay for A.T.& T.
description: The Federal Communications Commission refused to allow the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to reduce its new ''Reach Out America'' long-distance rates immediately, saying it wanted more time to study the proposal. ''Reach Out America'' is a billing plan that allows a customer to receive an hour's worth of calling time for a set fee. A.T.& T. asked the agency earlier this week for permission to reduce the rates by 6 percent on one day's notice. Jerry Fritz of the F.C.C.'s common carrier bureau said the latest rate cut had been challenged by two of A.T.& T.'s long-distance competitors - MCI Communications and Lexitel Inc. - as unjustified and anti-competitive.

title: BACKERS STUDYING IMMIGRATION BILL
description: Several key supporters of a comprehensive immigration bill said today that they were reconsidering their positions because of a decision by the House of Representatives to include a program to bring aliens to the United States as temporary workers to harvest perishable fruit and vegetables.

description: Eight members of the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus rode free on a state plane to a New York City dinner honoring Basil A. Paterson last Wednesday, state officials said today.

title: GENERALS WILL PUT GILBERT INTO ACTION
description: Freddie Gilbert was one of Donald Trump's more expensive acquisitions and was regarded by the coaching staff as the most important rookie with the New Jersey Generals. But, because of injury, his contributions have been considerably less than the other rookies.

title: PATENTS ; Upright Brush Used In Cleaning Glassware
description: A rinsing brush for glassware, mounted upright on a suction base, was patented this week by Victor J. Van Rosberg of Deventer, the Netherlands.
