title: NUCLEAR SAFEGUARD IDEA VOTED
description: The Senate, by an 82-to-0 vote, today recommended the establishment of ''nuclear risk-reduction centers'' in Washington and Moscow to guard against the chance that a global holocaust could be triggered by accident or by the acts of a terrorist group or third nation.

title: DISCREPANCIES SEEN IN INDIA'S REPORT ON SIKH RAID
description: The body of Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, the militant Sikh leader killed last week during an army assault on the Golden Temple, contained 14 bullet wounds, including six in the head, according to autopsy reports from Punjab quoted today in the newspaper Indian Express.

title: MONDALE CAMP PRESSES TO RALLY BLACK SUPPORT
description: Walter F. Mondale will dispatch his campaign manager and several other top aides to Philadelphia this weekend in a move to retain the Democratic Presidential support of black delegates and other prominent black backers, most of whom will also be attending the annual convention of the United States Conference of Mayors.

title: Mother Cleared in Fire Fatal to Her 2 Children
description: Charges against a woman whose two children died in a house fire while she was at work have been dismissed for lack of evidence.

title: CIRCUIT RESEARCH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
STATE PARTY COMPLETES DELEGATION FOR G.O.P. NATIONAL CONVENTION
description: Without opposition or even argument, New York Republicans yesterday finished selecting their delegation to the Republican National Convention. Eighty-two men and 54 women were chosen to be delegates and 75 men and 61 women were selected as alternates.

title: AGENT TELLS OF REPORT ON DELOREAN
description: A Federal drug agent testified today that he was ''skeptical'' at first when an informer told him that John Z. DeLorean wanted to invest in narcotics. But the agent said he felt no rush to start tape- recording evidence because ''If a man wants to talk drugs today, he'll probably talk drugs tomorrow.''

title: MEXICO IS READY TO ACT IN TALKS WITH NICARAGUA
description: Mexico announced today that it had accepted an invitation from the United States and Nicaragua to play a role in talks between the two countries, but there was no confirmation from American officials.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $201,000 for the latest quarter and $95,000 for the year-ago quarter. Hallwood Group is the result of the April 30 merger of Atlantic Metropolitan Corp. and UMET Properties Corp. Results for the quarter to April 30 represent the last three months operations of UMET Properties which, for accounting purposes, was treated as the surviving company in the merger.

title: A URUGUAYAN POLITICIAN IS TAKING ON THE GENERALS
description: Like Washington crossing the Delaware, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, plans to make his way across the choppy, chocolate Rio de la Plata to Montevideo to challenge the Government of Uruguay.

title: SAIPAN: THE TIDE SHIFTS
description: Forty years ago yesterday, on Saipan the Japanese began to lose World War II.

title: HOW DINING BILLS ADD UP
description: Few people study menus with the same care the I.R.S. uses to scrutinize tax returns. Often it doesn't make any difference because there are no hidden messages. But more and more restaurants are using the bottoms of their menus to list special charges, sometimes in print so small the charges are easily overlooked. This is, however, an improvement over the custom 20 years ago of surprising patrons with ''le couvert,'' the cover charge that ''took care of the bread and butter'' and often appeared on the bill, without warning, as ''B & B.''

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: American Can Gets 9.8% of Retailer

title: FILLING GAP IN MEDICAL INSURANCE
description: One of the most vexing problems facing Americans as they approach retirement age is the need for the right kind of insurance to protect them against sudden or too- large medical bills.

title: EXECUTING JUVENILES FOR CRIME
description: Forty years ago today, on June 16, 1944, the state of South Carolina electrocuted a 14- year-old boy named George Stinney Jr. At the time of his execution, he was 5 foot 1 inch tall and weighed 95 pounds. The local newspapers reported that the guards ''had difficulty strapping the boy's slight form into the wooden chair built for adults,'' and that ''young Stinney was such a small boy that it was difficult to attach the electrode to his right leg.'' But the execution was carried out, and George Stinney became - and remains to this day - the youngest person to be legally executed in the United States in this century.

title: DANCE: A 'BLUEBEARD' BY PINA BAUSCH TROUPE
description: A room ringed by women pasted on the the walls like flies, a floor covered with dry leaves that inevitably become entangled in the loose hair of the woman who wallows in them, a chain of mournful figures moving with heads bowed, a scene of repeated physical abuse signaled by the not-so-silent stop-and-start of a tape recorder.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Kelly Is Having Enjoyable Year

title: METS WIN, 5-0, AND TAKE FIRST
description: On one of their busiest nights, the Mets regained first place in the National League East, recorded their third consecutive shutout and made a trade for a right-handed pitcher.

title: HALT TWO NUCLEAR PLANTS, SAVE $1.1 BILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Athlete's Widow Sues Police as Racists
description: The wife of a former Indiana University football player who was shot to death by the Bloomington police has filed a Federal civil rights suit charging that the policemen who killed her husband were ''negligent and careless'' and ''motivated by race.''

title: May to Add Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company announced a $1.5 billion program of new store construction and remodeling of its existing stores. David C. Farrell, May's president and chief executive officer, said the company planned over the next five years to add 21 department stores, 35 Venture discount stores and about 1,000 Payless Shoesource stores. He told shareholders at the annual meeting that after completion of the construction program the company would have about 165 department stores, 86 Venture stores and more than 2,400 shoe stores.

title: DOW FALLS ANOTHER 10.71 POINTS
description: Stock prices declined sharply again yesterday in heavier trading. All three of the major market indicators finished at their lowest levels in almost 16 months.

title: TESCO AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BRITISH ALLIANCE WINS UPSET
description: The Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, which has languished in the political doldrums since the Falkland War gave a lift to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Party, came back to life today with an upset victory in a key by- election.

title: HEARNS STOPS DURAN IN 2D
description: Roberto Duran took the biggest and maybe last tumble of his career tonight when he was knocked out in the second round by Thomas Hearns, who had predicted this week that he would do exactly that.

title: OARLOCK: NEW ENTRY FOR A DICTIONARY OF URBAN ILLS
description: ''Why don't you watch where you're going?'' asked the man in the straw hat, after his little red rowboat had been rammed broadside by a little green rowboat on the Lake in Central Park. The man in the green boat responded with a snappy ''Why don't you?'' and was instantly cracked in the rear by a little gray rowboat. ''Sorry,'' said a passenger in the gray rowboat, inspecting the beer that had slopped on his lap.

title: German Police Recover Seven Stolen Paintings
description: The police today recovered seven stolen paintings, including works by Gauguin, Rembrandt, Goya and Picasso, from a garage in the town of Hanau, east of Frankfurt, according to West German television.

title: MAN SURRENDERS IN 1982 KILLING OF A CALIFORNIAN ON THE EAST SIDE
description: A Bronx man surrendered to the police yesterday in connection with the 1982 killing of a California prosecutor on the Upper East Side, a police spokesman said.

title: COMECON OUTLINES CLOSER TIES
description: The 10-nation Communist economic community published an outline today for closer cooperation among its centrally controlled economies that appeared to give Moscow a measure of the integration it has been seeking.

title: Everett A. Babcock, Official With United Church of Christ
description: The Rev. Everett A. Babcock, the treasurer of the board for world ministries of the United Church of Christ from 1961 to 1971, died Thursday in the Venice (Fla.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Venice.

title: LEADING CASINOS SETTLE STRIKE
description: The strike at major Las Vegas hotel- casinos ended today when stagehands overwhelmingly ratified a five-year contract on the 75th day of the walkout.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $202,000 for the quarter and $751,000 for the 9 months and a nonrecurring loss of $1,891,000 for the 9 months on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Including tax credits of $479,000 for the quarter and $2,032,000 for the 9 months.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Consumer Saturday column last week incorrectly described a product of the Robertshaw Controls Company of Richmond. The company makes water-heater controls, all of which are sold to other manufacturers for installation on their water- heating systems.

title: Wang Product
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it would introduce a $595 circuit board for its personal computer that would make the machine compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer. A company spokesman said the move was part of a broader effort to make Wang equipment compatible with products made by other manufacturers. He also said that the company would sell for $1,850 a communications board that would make it possible for the I. B. M. computers to exchange information with Wang's office automation systems.

title: Chicago Chief Judge Resigns After Being Named at a Trial
description: A presiding chief judge named but not indicted in an investigation of corruption in the Cook County court system left his post today.

title: N.B.A. Files Suit Against Clippers
description: Yet one more legal battle over the movement of a sports team from one city to another began yesterday when the National Basketball Association filed a Federal suit in San Diego against the Clippers.

title: INSURERS OFFER HYBRID POLICY
description: A little-known type of life insurance called excess-interest whole life has been drawing increasing attention within the insurance industry since its creation about four years ago. And now, with more than 30 companies selling this policy, the public is becoming more aware of its existence as an insurance alternative.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1984 International
description: Limited economic talks with Moscow will be resumed by the United States, Reagan Administration officials said. They also said that the Administration had softened its opposition to talks with Moscow on curbing the development of antisatellite weapons. The announcements were interpreted by some officials as part of a general relaxation in tone and attitude toward the Soviet Union in response to concern at home and abroad over Soviet-American tensions. (Page 1, Column 6.) Argentina's financial troubles reached a new crisis. The Reagan Administration refused to grant further time for Argentina to qualify for a $300 million Treasury loan. But the United States left the door open for the loan's approval if Argentina meets its conditions and shows some willingness to compromise in the loan negotiations. (1:4.)

title: BLUE JAYS BEAT RED SOX ON 2 IN 11TH, 4-3
description: Rance Mulliniks ripped a bases-loaded single with two outs in the bottom of the 11th inning, driving in two runs that rallied the Toronto Blue Jays past the Boston Red Sox, 4-3, tonight.

title: Recovering Press Aide Plans Campaign Trips With Reagan
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, said today he would travel with President Reagan occasionally in the re-election campaign and offer political advice along the way.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a gain of $165,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of real estate investments and contingent interest of $445,000, or 11 cents a share. Year-ago 6 months results include a gain of $369,000, or 12 cents a share from the sale of real estate investments.

title: Creusot-Loire Pact Doubted
description: Talks between the French Government and the engineering group Creusot-Loire aimed at finding a solution to the company's financial crisis were expected to continue through the weekend, although chances of an agreement were slim, official sources said today.

title: PATENTS ; Computer Speech Codes Produced Automatically
description: An automatic way to produce speech element codes needed in creating computers that will talk or listen was patented this week for AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. The invention was made at the company's acoustical and behavioral research center by Frank C. Pirz, Lawrence R. Rabiner and Jay G. Wilpon, who were granted patent 4,454,586.

title: OFFICER IS KILLED WITH HIS OWN GUN
description: A police officer was shot to death with his own gun in a South Bronx store yesterday after he stopped a man accused of stealing a pair of eyeglass frames from a display case, the police said.

title: ;  Drugs Suspected In Fatal Shooting
description: A Bronx woman was shot and killed and the man she was living with was critically wounded early yesterday when gunmen forced their way into their home. The police said drugs appeared to be the motivation for the shootings.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results include net income of $136,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $272,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months from the amortization of negative goodwill which was fully amortized in 1983.

title: O'NEILL CALLS REAGAN 'CRUEL' OVER JOB FUNDS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, assailed President Reagan today as ''cruel'' and ''inhumane'' for linking money for summer jobs for youths to funds for covert operations in Nicaragua.

title: SPIRES AND INSPIRES
description: Black people have lived in Brooklyn since Dutch days, from the middle of the 1600's, and over the centuries that community developed its own churches and congregations. Today, blacks constitute about a third of Brooklyn's population and their churches, an important element in social organization, have also multiplied.

title: 'Covert' War on the Deficit
description: The Administration that invented the non-secret secret in order to wage ''covert'' war in Central America wants to see if the concept will work for taxes, too. The President's re-election campaign proclaims that America is feeling good again, and no one at headquarters cares to reveal a sobering truth: There has to be a tax increase next year.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CONTINENTAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings take into account the company's public offering of 1 million common shares on Sept. 27, 1983.

title: Musa Alami, Founder Of an Arab Aid Group
description: Musa Alami, a Palestinian lawyer, philanthropist and founder and president of the Arab Development Society, died in Amman, Jordan, on June 8 as a result of circulatory failure. He was 87 years old.

title: Assassin Gets Life Term
description: Hampig Sassounian, a 22-year-old Armenian immigrant, was sentenced today to life in prison without possibility of parole for the assassination of a Turkish diplomat. He had been convicted to first-degree murder for shooting to death Consul General Kemal Arikan, 54, in an ambush attack.

title: Connors to Play McEnroe Today
description: Jimmy Connors, the defending champion, and top-seeded John McEnroe advanced today to a semifinal meeting in the Queen's Club championships.

title: CITY BALLET: 'MOZARTIANA' AND A ROBBINS WORK
description: In its quiet, delicate way, George Balanchine's ''Mozartiana'' is one of the masterworks of the New York City Ballet's repertory. And a performance of it Thursday in the New York State Theater suggested that the ballet has lost none of its sense of mystery and reverence since the company's 1981 Tchaikovsky Festival, for which it was created.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Associate of Pisani Gets Probation
description: A key prosecution witness in the trial of State Senator Joseph R. Pisani was sentenced yesterday to one year of probation for destroying financial records in the investigation of Mr. Pisani.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including income from unconsolidated subsidiary and affiliates of $1,828,000 for the quarter and $23,507,000 for the 6 months and gains from property sales of $1 million for the quarter and $22.2 million for the 6 months. c-Including income from unconsolidated subsidiary and affiliates of $844,000 for the quarter and $1,675,000 for the 6 months.

title: SLOWDOWN IS HAILED
description: In what is seen as compelling evidence of an economic slowdown, the Government reported today that industrial production rose only four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the slimmest advance since November. It was the second smallest increase since the current expansion began at the end of 1982.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Universal Mayoral Woes

title: Japan G.N.P. Rises by 1.8%
description: Japan's gross national product rose an inflation-adjusted 1.8 percent in the January-March quarter from the previous quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: ABC TO BRING BACK THREE-HOUR DOCUMENTEARIES
description: It's rare to find documentaries in prime-time these days, and public-affairs time on the networks is not always particularly profitable, but, bucking both those factors, ABC News has committed itself to bringing back the three-hour news examination to television.

title: U.N. Council Votes to Extend Cyprus Peacekeeping Force
description: The Security Council unanimously passed a resolution today keeping the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus for another six months.

title: WROTE 'MUSIC MAN'
description: Meredith Willson, the author, composer and lyricist of the Broadway musicals ''The Music Man,'' ''The Unsinkable Molly Brown'' and ''Here's Love,'' died last night at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: G. E. Venture
description: The General Electric Company and Coherent Inc. said they had concluded a definitive agreement to operate a joint venture to make industrial lasers. The venture, to be named Coherent General Inc., will be 40 percent owned by G. E. and 60 percent by Coherent. G. E. said it would provide access to its marketing resources, research and development assistance and technology licenses. Coherent said it would contribute people, assets, technology and the facilities of its industrial group.

title: POPE GETS SWISS PRIEST'S GRIEVANCES
description: A young Swiss priest presented a giant safety pin to Pope John Paul II today at a meeting in the Benedictine abbey here with Swiss priests, two of whom suggested concern that the Pope is too conservative on church issues.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: HANSEN GETS PRISON TERM FOR ETHICS ACT VIOLATION
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, to 5 to 15 months in prison and fined him the maximum $40,000 for falsifying financial disclosure forms to Congress.

title: COMMITMENT'S THERE ON DEFICIT, BUT IS IT ENOUGH?
description: This year's plan for a ''down payment'' on the Federal deficit has become the hostage of procedural, political and personality clashes on Capitol Hill, and rescuing it will test the depth of commitment of Congress and the White House to act in an election year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Normandy's been on TV and in the papers. Each year the Pacific invasions fade a little more from our memories.'' - Robert T. Kline of Paoli, Pa., on Saipan. (4:1.)

title: Seaway Markets Offer
description: An investment group told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had proposed a buyout of Seaway Food Town Inc. for $20 to $22 a share. The group said it already owned 119,090 common shares, or 5.4 percent of the total outstanding.

title: ONE-MAN RADIO STATION IN GLOUCESTER WINS ROUND IN BATTLE TO KEEP F.C.C. LICENSE
description: Simon Geller, who runs a one-man radio station broadcasting symphonic music out of his basement home in Gloucester, Mass., won a round in a Federal appeals court here today in his battle to keep his license.

title: Disk Innovation
description: The Control Data Corporation said the partnership formed by it and Philips N. V. had developed a high- capacity computer disk memory that uses laser beams to record and read information. It said the new memory, developed by the Optical Storage International partnership, can store up to one billion bytes, or characters, of information for as long as 10 years on one side of a densely packed 12-inch glass disk.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $64,000 for the quarter and $364,000 for the 6 months.

title: SOUTH FORK OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CHRYSLER PLANS 5% STAKE IN MASERATI
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had agreed to buy 5 percent of the Italian sports car manufacturer Maserati, saying the deal will lead to joint ventures.

title: NEW BABY BOOM CROWDS CITY'S TOP HOSPITALS
description: Some of the city's best-known hospitals are facing periodic overcrowding in their obstetric units, ranging from a shortage of labor rooms to a lack of beds for women who have already delivered.

title: TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
19 Trucks Hijacked By Both Sides in Beirut
description: Rival militiamen hijacked 19 semitrailer trucks traveling between the Christian and Moslem sectors of the Lebanese capital in the morning rush hour today, prompting officials to close the only crossing briefly.

title: Prices Up 0.6% In O.E.C.D.
description: Consumer prices in the non-Communist industrialized nations rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in April after rising four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The 24-nation secretariat noted, however, that the rate of growth during the 12 months ended in April declined to 5.7 percent from 5.8 percent during the 12 months though March.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Cambodia Radio Says Vietnam Will Cut Troops
description: The official Cambodian radio said today that Vietnam would withdraw some troops from Cambodia this month.

title: THE REAL BABY RUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Layoff Threat By Kennecott
description: The Kennecott unit of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) will lay off 2,000 copper workers in Utah by July 1 unless unions agree to cost-cutting concessions, its president, G. Frank Joklik, said today. At a news conference, Mr. Joklik said that a continuing decline in the price of copper was forcing the company to cut production at its Utah operation by two-thirds. Kennecott currently employs about 4,400 workers in Utah.

title: TAKING THE YANKEES FROM STEINBRENNER WOULD SOLVE NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $653,000 for the latest first quarter and $703,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: REAGAN APPROVES TALKS WITH SOVIET ON ECONOMIC TIES
description: Administration officials said today that the United States would resume limited economic talks with the Soviet Union and had also softened its opposition to talks with Moscow on curbing development of antisatellite weapons.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS STRENGTH AMID INTEREST RATE RISE By The Associated Press
description: The dollar climbed toward 2.75 West German marks and rose sharply against other major currencies yesterday as the Federal funds rate for overnight loans between United States banks rose for the second consecutive day.

title: TAKING THE YANKEES FROM STEINBRENNER WOULD SOLVE NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
6 YEARS OF CANINE-WASTE LAW: ALL IN ALL, A CLEANER NEW YORK
description: Six years after a state law ordered city dog owners to clean up after their dogs, New York's canine population appears to be increasingly streetbroken.

title: GRACE TULLY, 83, A SECRETARY TO FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT, DIES
description: Grace Tully, a personal secretary to Franklin D. Roosevelt in his years as Governor of New York and as President of the United States, died today after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Starling Is Upset
description: Pedro Vilella upset Marlon Starling in a 12-round majority decision last night at Madison Square Garden, taking the North American Boxing Federation welterweight championship from Starling in the main live preliminary to the closed-circuit telecast of the Thomas Hearns-Roberto Duran bout.

title: WOMAN SAVES CHILD FALLING OFF BUILDING
description: The mailman screamed, ''Get the baby!'' Cynthia Nevers dropped her toasted cheese sandwich and raced from her front porch to see a 17- month toddler crawling along a second-floor railing.

title: ;  McNeil Pact Extended
description: Ever since the Jet defensive end Mark Gastineau signed a five-year contract worth about $4 million in March, Freeman McNeil, the team's best running back, had been trying to renegotiate his contract. McNeil, who had a year plus an option year left on his old agreement, let it be known that he was listening to offers from the United States Football League. Yesterday the Jets announced that McNeil had signed an extension through 1988, and Harold Daniels, McNeil's agent, said the package, signed Wednesday, would bring the player $5 million. ''That kid was so happy he was walking on air,'' Daniels said.

title: CONFEREES ACT ON FOUNDATIONS
description: Conferees from the House and Senate today approved a requirement that private tax-exempt foundations pay out a minimum of 4.35 percent of the value of their investment assets each year as charitable contributions.

title: NEW ECOLOGY AGENDA URGED FOR U.S.
description: The nation needs to develop new environmental policies and reshape laws to address threats to the land, air, water and human health posed by toxic contamination and other emerging pollution problems such as acid rain, a research group warned Thursday.

title: NO MORE BOTTLE BABIES
description: President Reagan and a lot of Congressmen want to raise the drinking age to 21 across the country. In some states it is now down to 18. In a society that lets people drive at 16, it is madness letting them drink at 18, but the puzzler is why so many politicians think 21 is just right.

title: Reactor Core Mishap Brings Alert in Vermont
description: An alert was declared yesterday at a nuclear plant in Vernon, Vt., when an instrument used to measure the nuclear reaction in the reactor core was accidentally withdrawn into an unprotected area after becoming radioactive.

title: MONDALE TO MET SENATOR BENTSEN AND MAYOR FEINSTEIN ON NO.2 JOB
description: Walter F. Mondale announced today that he would begin his search for a Vice-Presidential running mate by interviewing Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.

title: ARGENTINA DENIED MORE TIME BY U.S. ON LOAN APPROVAL
description: The Reagan Administration today refused to give Argentina any more time to qualify for a $300 million Treasury loan, thus pushing the difficulties over the third world's debts to a critical new threshold.

title: SPECULATORS LIFT BOND PRICES
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday as traders decided foreign demand for United States Treasury securities might increase significantly if Congress eliminates the 30 percent withholding tax on interest paid to some foreign investors.

title: Barry Harris at the Piano
description: The pianist Barry Harris is leading a trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater (244-0997), 368 Eighth Avenue, at 28th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., and tickets are $8.

title: Anne-Marie Soulliere Wed to Lindsey Kiang
description: Anne-Marie Soulliere, a development officer at Yale University, and Lindsey C. Y. Kiang, general counsel of the university, were married yesterday. The Rev. John W. Vannorsdall, the Yale chaplain, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Yale's Branford College Chapel in New Haven.

title: Unhappy Families
description: Ask most people to define ''family'' and they'll describe an ideal - the alliance of parents and children for the benefit of all society. But not all people can live up to the ideal. Some who find themselves responsible for a family cannot take care of themselves, let alone their abused offspring.

title: Bronfmans Get Control Of Cadillac
description: Real Estate Giant in Canada

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 4:05 P.M. The farewell game for Lou Piniella, who becomes the first-base coach after today. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. The Cardinals get a look at Dwight Gooden. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.)

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INDIA TALKS OF C.I.A. ROLE IN UNREST
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government has been insisting that ''certain foreign powers'' supported the Sikh terrorist movement in Punjab with the aim of destabilizing India.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S.-CHINA NUCLEAR PACT HITS SNAGS
description: Efforts to reach a nuclear cooperation agreement with China, the centerpiece of President Reagan's trip to Peking, have faltered and a pact is unlikely to be completed this year, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: North Korea Reports Killing a Seoul Soldier
description: North Korea said today that a South Korean soldier was killed on the northern side of the demilitarized zone on Thursday.

title: Group Withdraws Offer for Standex
description: The Standex International Corporation said an acquisition offer for the company had been withdrawn.

title: LED FOOD PRODUCTS CONCERN
description: Philip W. Pillsbury, former president and chairman of the Pillsbury Company, who helped transform the Minneapolis grain milling company co- founded by his grandfather into one of the largest diversified food products concerns, died of cancer at the Abbott-Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis Thursday. He was 81 years old and lived in Wayzata, a Minneapolis suburb.

title: FOR A POLITICIAN, POWER AND RICHES GO TOGETHER
description: There are two things to remember about Willie L. Brown Jr. He grew up poor, black and without power. Now he is rich and powerful, and he intends to stay that way.

title: Nawabzada Raza Dies; Ex-Envoy for Pakistan
description: Nawabzada Agha Mohammad Raza, former Pakistani Ambassador to China, France and the United States and a retired general, died here of a heart attack Thursday, the Pakistani Embassy announced. He was 79 years old.

title: STRANGE SHOTS AT THE OPEN
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: ;  Devils Trade MacMillan
description: Bob MacMillan, the Devils' forward, said he had been told by the club that he was being sent to the Chicago Black Hawks as part of a deal for Rich Preston, a forward, and Don Dietrich, a defenseman. Larry Brooks, a spokesman for the Devils, confirmed that MacMillan would be going to Chicago but said the deal had not been completed. The Devils and the Black Hawks have been working on the trade since the Devils, who had the second choice in the draft last Saturday, agreed not to pick Ed Olczyk, a Chicago-area player sought by the Black Hawks, who had the third choice, in exchange for an arrangement to be worked out.

title: SUIT FILED IN LEUKEMIA DEATHS
description: Relatives of 10 people who died of leukemia filed a Federal lawsuit here today, asserting that the deaths were caused by downwind radiation emanating from an underground nuclear explosion in 1962.

title: COMPANY NEWS ; A.T.& T. Feels The Rising Cost Of Phone Fraud 83 Loss $100 Million; Drug Link Suspected
description: It can begin with something as ordinary as a business traveler making a long-distance credit card call at an airport. Someone standing nearby jots down the card number as it is read to the operator. A few weeks later, the card holder receives a bill for thousands of dollars of overseas telephone tolls.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Version
description: The bloody fighting between the Indian Army and Sikh extremists in the Punjab left the rebellious state subdued, its Sikh majority stunned by the show of force that took at least 500 lives. Elsewhere, violence has been contained. To this extent, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi can claim vindication.

title: A NEW YORK GARBAGE SOLUTION ISN'T IN THE BAG
description: In Staten Island, my borough, lies the classic bad example of society's refusal to come to grips with the problem of disposing of solid waste. The site is called, misleadingly, Fresh Kills - a name originating in Dutch colonial times when the creeks were indeed pure and fresh.

title: MAYOR SURVIVED RECALL VOTE
description: Dianne Feinstein

title: NU-WEST GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DRAMA OR RESTRAINT: OPTIONS IN FALL FURS
description: As the fur shows continued this week, big coats were still very much in evidence. Yet some designers didn't go overboard on voluminous coats. Ralph Lauren, for one, used restraint and kept bulk under control. So did Ben Kahn and Viola Sylbert, with designs that were elegant rather than splashy. Still, there were new ideas: unusual patterned furs by Oscar de la Renta and jackets made of woven leather and wool, lined in fur, at Givenchy.

title: Maria Cummin Wed To J. Clayton Bright
description: Maria Starr Cummin, the daughter of Mrs. Graham French Cummin and the late Mr. Cummin of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to J. Clayton Bright, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Islesford, Me. The Rev. Frank M. Harron performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Peter's Church in the Great Valley in Paoli, Pa.

title: Gulf Shareholders Agree to Merger
description: The Gulf Corporation's shareholders approved the company's $13.4 billion acquisition by the Standard Oil Company of California, completing the largest merger in United States corporate history. Gulf said today that 138.8 million of its shares, or 84 percent of its total stock outstanding, had been voted in favor of the merger.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary by United Press International on June 9, on Dr. Wallace D. Armstrong, an early advocate of drinking-water fluoridation, misstated the fluoridation practice of some countries. Several Western European countries add no fluoride to their water but rely on naturally occurring fluoridation to combat tooth decay.

title: MET SETS DISPUTED ISRAELI SHOW OF ARTIFACTS FOR '86
description: An archeological exhibition from Israel, snarled for more than two years in a series of disputes over artifacts from the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, will open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the fall of 1986, museum officials said yesterday.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: A DANCE TROUPE TAKES FLIGHT
description: ''You're still not sure when you take the jump whether you fall or rise. But you're going to risk the jump. You're going to dive or fly. That's what it should look like. Take it to the edge. Take it to the edge.'' Four young dancers listen intently as Dianne McIntyre speaks. They start to move. ''Keep your nose on the horizon,'' she calls out across the studio. They churn, scoop and whirl as if riding out air turbulence, piano and drums building with them as sirens wail outside in the summer streets. ''Don't drive them, let them drive you,'' Miss McIntyre calls to her two musicians. Then ''Yahh, phoom,'' she cries and the dancers and music settle into a kind of serenity, the dancers' perspiring bodies poised, as if in flight.

title: FOR BRITAIN, NEW DEBATE ON FIREARMS
description: Tottenham, north of the center of London, is a struggling working-class area in which, as Postmaster Michael P. Coney said today, ''the police help keep it from turning into one of your American inner-city neighborhoods.''

description: Pope John Paul II warned the people of Switzerland today not to consider themselves ''an island of safety in the midst of the threatening surge of the world.'' He urged them to live up to their humanitarian obligations to less fortunate people and nations.

description: Charlotte Cheston Worsley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Randolph Worsley Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Timothy Shaw Pendergast, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Pendergast 3d of Providence, R.I. title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Every year, approximately 25,000 Americans are killed in alcohol-related accidents. With this in mind, I was appalled by Philip B. Linker's article, ''Drinking and Driving Can Mix'' (Long Island Weekly, June 3).

title: IRAQ SAYS IRAN VIOLATES PACT BY SHELLING CIVILIANS
description: Iraq accused Iran today of shelling an Iraqi border town in violation of the five-day-old moratorium on attacking civilians.

title: STOCKPILING WIHT PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: Last year's question, ''Do you have a personal computer?'' is now giving way to another, ''What are you doing on your computer?'' And if you still do not have an answer, it is not for lack of software. There is a program called the Bowling League Secretary. Another, Eliza, promises to act as a psychological counselor. There are horoscope programs, game programs, time- and money-management programs, and diet/exercise programs. And then there are the investment packages that supposedly help the home computer user make lots of money in the stock market.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: '' ON these general-public tours we try to explain what we do here in as simple terms as possible,'' Janet Tempel told her tour group of one - this one - as she wrestled the van along the western perimeter of the Brookhaven National Laboratory. ''But we also explain that there's no way to make high-energy physics very easy to understand.''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MORE than 1,000 Connecticut motorists found out last month that it does not pay to avoid an emissions test. They were caught driving with expired stickers on their car in a crackdown that is continuing this month.

title: Olivia Pierson and James Jacobs Marry

title: Westphal Files Plea
description: Paul Westphal, under pressure from the Phoenix Suns to retire, said he had asked for arbitration to determine whether his $300,000 annual salary was guaranteed for next season under the terms of his Suns' contract. The two-year pact provides that the second-year salary will be guaranteed only if Westphal played in or was available to play in at least 60 games in the first season.

description: Deliveries of The New York Times to areas of the East Side of Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx were disrupted early yesterday by a dispute between the Metropolitan News Company, a wholesale distributor, and members of its union.

title: 17 Held in British Rampage
description: The police made 17 arrests early today when 200 youths rampaged through the Yorkshire coal-mining town of Maltby, one of the areas supporting a three-month- old strike in the coal industry. The youths threw stones at the police station and smashed shop windows.

description: RANGING in age from 15 to 46, 8 excited Long Islanders will be among the 1,800 athletes from 53 countries participating in the International Games for the Disabled opening today at Mitchel Park in Uniondale.

description: Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, left Argentina Friday night and was arrested today aboard a ferry by the Uruguayan Navy as he was returning to his homeland for the first time in 11 years.

title: ADS TRY TO TIE REAGAN WITH THE BEST OF TIMES
description: In April, three men from the Reagan Bush office in Washington flew to New York with a page and a half of instructions. It was a memorandum, condensed from meetings at the White House and the campaign headquarters, directing the way President Reagan's re- election campaign would be sold to the public.

description: Mary Elise Moore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Raymond Moore Jr. of Vernon, Tex., was married there yesterday to Mark Francis Blaxill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Blaxill of Princeton, N.J., and Windermere Island, Eleuthera, the Bahamas. Retired Bishop George H. Quarterman of the Episcopal Diocese of Northwest Texas performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church.

title: WANT YOUR NAME ON A SYMPHONY?
description: Have you ever wanted to leave your name on musical history, but never been sure quite how? You might want to commission a masterpiece; it worked for Waldstein, Razumovsky, Kreutzer and Goldberg. Of course, it's a chancy ambition, like owning a Derby winner: just spending the money doesn't guarantee success. Heaven only knows how many Kreutzer Sonatas were run up by hacks until Beethoven came along and did it right.

description: ''I feel that the military action that has been taken has been done with competence and care,'' said the retired Sikh general, giving his white mustache a quick upward twist, ''but it hasn't solved any problems.''

title: VOLCKER COMMENTS RENEW STOCK SLIDE
description: Interest rate fears returned in force last week, spurred in part by remarks from the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, who warned that a credit squeeze, both in the public and private sectors, was putting heavy upward pressure on interest rates. And he said that the ''elements'' contributing to the robust recovery ''cannot be sustained indefinitely.'' Investors took his message to heart: The stock market accelerated its six-month decline, with the Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday closing under 1,110 for the first time in nearly 16 months. It fell nearly 11 points more on Friday, ending the week at 1,086.90, down 44.35.

title: Missouri River Flooding Forces 1,000 to Flee By The Associated Press
description: Surging with runoff water after a week of violent thunderstorms, the raging Missouri River yesterday forced more than 1,000 people out of their homes in Missouri and Kansas and covered thousands of acres of farmland.

title: UP IN THE AIR
description: SOMEWHERE AROUND THE house are a couple of old menus from the Hindenburg. I wish I could find them and see what wines one drinks on a zeppelin. Probably lots of good Rhine wines from the Staatsdom"ane at Eltville, the ones that used to have the big swastika on the bottle. No matter. The point I want to make is that drinking wine in the air is nothing new.

title: THE SOUND BECOMES A CLASSROOM
description: Aboard the J.N. Carter, flagship of one of Connecticut's most innovative marine science programs, junior-high students hauled up a net filled with flounder, skate and shrimp as unseasonable northern winds blew the 66-foot ketch on a brisk run out of New Haven Harbor.

title: OPERA: BRITTEN'S 'BUNYAN' PRODUCED IN ST. LOUIS
description: When Benjamin Britten decided to compose his first opera, back in 1941, he thought big: he tackled no less a figure than Paul Bunyan. Obviously, as a stage hero the mighty Paul presents certain problems, which were minimized but not entirely solved by the Opera Theater of St. Louis production of ''Paul Bunyan'' Thursday night.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: CHAMBER MUSIC SERIES

title: CRIME
description: It is hard to believe THE LAST LAUGH by John Riggs (Dembner/Norton, $13.95) is a first novel. It is confident and well constructed, moves fast, probes character and has natural-sounding dialogue. There are a few weaknesses in the plotting, but Mr. Riggs is such a sensitive and accomplished writer one happily goes along with him.

title: PHILLIES, WITH 5 RUNS IN FIRST, ROUT CUBS
description: Ozzie Virgil's two-run homer capped a five- run first inning today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to an 8-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: GARBAGE PLANT BUYER SOUGHT
description: THERE'S a market for everything, supposedly, and Hempstead Town is out to prove it. Town officials are looking for that perfect buyer, the one who will resuscitate the lifeless Hempstead garbage recycling plant. No one expects that the giant structure, which sits rusting alongside the Meadowbrook Parkway, can be restored to its glory as the great hope for Long Island's garbage industry, but the officials would like to render it capable of at least burning trash.

title: FACETS OF ANTWERP
description: Sleeping Beauty, as the uncut diamond has been called, awoke in Antwerp. The stone is by no means the only sparkling element to be found in the Belgian city, which calls itself the world center of diamonds, but it is an apt symbol of a place whose quiet exterior hides the sparkle of northern European art and history in streets that twist like rich veins in a mother lode. Those who live there like to quote the historian Carolus Scrilanus, who wrote in 1609: ''The Netherlands are the ring of the world, and the diamond in the ring is Antwerp.''

title: THE WORLD
description: A New Chapter In the Gulf War

title: MISS DAVISSON WEDS EDITOR
description: Lacy Davisson, a daughter of Zita Davisson Hendrickson of New York and Arthur A. Davisson of San Juan, P.R., was married yesterday to Kevin Lawrence Doyle, the son of Mary M. Doyle of New York and the late Lester T. Doyle. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the cermony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: No Headline

title: A.M.A. TOLD OF 85% FAILURE RATE IN BASIC TEST TAKEN BY FOREIGN MEDICAL GRADUATES
description: The American Medical Association was told today that more than 16,000 of the 19,000 graduates of foreign medical schools who took a basic test of medical knowledge three months ago failed it.

title: SHOW JUMPERS NEAR FINAL OLYMPIC TEST
description: With graph paper, yardstick and an experienced eye, Frank Chapot will take the measure of horses and riders in today's $25,000 Almaden Vineyards Grand Prix.

title: LEGISLATURE GETS PLAN TO REVISE CAMPAIGN FINANCING RULES
description: TRENTON THE recent Presidential primary season highlighted an argument over campaign financing and the use of so- called PAC money (funds supplied by the Political Action Committee of a special interest).

title: HALIFAX HONORS ITS ROOTS
description: JOYCE BARKHOUSE is a Nova Scotia writer. Her most recent book, ''The Witch of Port La Joye,'' is a children's book based on a French-Indian legend. Haligonians say that Toronto has the CN Tower, Montreal has Mount Royal, but their city has Citadel Hill. This great grassy mound, the site of a 19th-century fort, in the center of the Halifax metropolis, gives the city its character and is the focal point of its remarkable history.

title: U.S. Open Tee Times 1:23
description: Hubert Green (215), Lanny Wadkins (215).

title: A PHOENIX RISES IN LOUISBOURG
description: There was a period - about a hundred years, in fact - when the name of Louisbourg would have been recognized only by readers of Francis Parkman or by admirers of a handsome urban square on Beacon Hill in Boston. Today the Library of America, the publisher, is reissuing Parkman's historical epics, and the charm of Louisburg Square (Boston spells it without the o) endures. But recently Louisbourg itself, the 18th-century city and fortress on Nova Scotia's Cape Breton Island, has returned to lay its own claim upon our attention.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Rich Find Things picked up for Eric de Wilde last year when somebody dropped a bag of diamonds alongside a Florida railway track.

title: DANCE: RUSSILLO TROUPE
description: Joseph Russillo took on the creation of the world in ''Requiem, Maledictions et Lumieres'' (''Requiem, Curses and Lights'') on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. It was an unequal battle, despite the committed performing of his attractive company, the Toulouse-based Ballet-Theatre Joseph Russillo.

title: IN FOOD BUSINESS, NUTRITION ISN'T ALWAYS A NATURAL INGREDIENT
description: The food industry, always quick to respond to consumer whims, has become increasingly inventive in trying to appeal to the conflicting interests of American eaters. While ''good nutrition'' is now one of the industry's biggest selling points, some of the most popular new products are less nourishing than ever, and higher in fat and sugar than their more mundane counterparts.

description: Fiction1 14 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) title: EMIGRE TALKS ABOUT FEMINISM IN THE SOVIET UNION
description: Women in the Soviet Union are often thought of by Westerners as living and working on an equal footing with men. Many are doctors or hold other nontraditional jobs, and they have access to free education, health care and day care. And Soviet laws proclaim equality between the sexes.

title: NEW YORK RELIGIOUS COALITION WILL OPERATE SHELTERS ALL YEAR
description: An interdenominational group that operates a citywide network of shelters for the homeless in the winter has begun a program to provide shelters year-round.

title: Robert Morgan Davies Marries Lisa Caron Hazen
description: Lisa Caron Hazen, a daughter of Mrs. Anthony J. Paen Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Maynard Doran Hazen of Bal Harbour, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Morgan Davies, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morgan Ernest Davies of Menai Bridge on the island of Anglesey, Wales, formerly of London. The Rev. David L. Uhl and the Rev. Donald Poole performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: SCHOOL TASK FORCE IS GOING FULL TILT
description: AT A TIME when most educational enterprises are winding down for the summer, a 50-member commission appointed by Governor Kean last fall to promote community involvement in the public schools has never been busier.

title: FIVE $1,000 AWARDS WILL GO TO TEACHERS IN CITY HIGH SCHOOLS
description: Five outstanding teachers in New York City's public high schools will each receive $1,000 in a competition being sponsored by the New York Alliance for the Public Schools, a private group that promotes and supports the school system.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Part-Time Prisoner After a year in Federal prison in Pennsylvania, former Nassau County Republican leader Joseph M. Margiotta last week returned to Long Island as his home county's guest. Mr. Margiotta, who was sentenced to two years in prison after a 1981 conviction on mail fraud and extortion charges, is to spend the next two months in Nassau County jail in a work-release program. Until Aug. 31, when his parole begins, he is to spend his days working at a fulltime job, his nights in jail and his weekends at home in Brookville, L.I. Mr. Margiotta's colleagues were said to hope that he would not seek a job in his previous line of work and attempt to return to party leadership. Death Sentence

title: TRANSITION IN 'ALTERNATIVE' PRESS FOCUS OF MEETING
description: First there was the ''underground'' press of the 1960's. In the 70's, it became known as the ''alternative'' press. Most of the publications on display last week at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan, and the conversation about them, suggest that the phenomenon is now comfortable as a tributary of mainstream journalism.

title: HELPING THOUSANDS OF NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: ''TO assist those who come to this country with just a paper bag, who have to live in a three-story tenement, who do not speak a word of English and have no transferable work skills - this is what we aim for,'' said the executive director of the International Institute of Connecticut, based in Bridgeport.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: More Data on Computer Crime

title: THE ANGUISH OF FATHER'S DAY
description: TODAY is Father's Day, and it was only a month ago that we celebrated Mother's Day. These events should be celebrations of the shared love that begins at birth and develops into normal, healthy adulthood. For some, however, instead of celebration an overwhelming sense of helpless anguish darkens these events.

title: JAZZ SWINGS BACK TO TRADITION
description: Jon Pareles writes on music for The New York Times.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Ross Playground
description: After a seesawing turn of events in which Diana Ross and her production company first promised and then appeared to renege on a donation for a new children's playground in Central Park, the entertainer told Mayor Koch in January that she was making $250,000 available out of her own pocket.

title: Susan Mendelsohn to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Mendelsohn of Baldwin, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Leslie Mendelsohn, to Richard Mark Butin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Butin of Fayetteville, N.Y.

title: EASTERN EUROPE'S KLEZMER PLANTS NEW ROOTS IN AMERICA
description: These have been years of recall, of looking for roots, of burrowing about in one's ancestral attic and trying to learn what it was that went into the making of us and our ways. Musical roots are constantly being unearthed and pressed into concerts of old American, old Irish, old Caribbean. old African and old Asian song. In all of this, klezmer has caught on, too, with young musicians addressing themselves joyously to this bountiful expression of the Jews of Eastern Europe, a music that, like the people who played and danced to it, has been uprooted and was, until this revival, headed for extinction.

title: Claire Goodman and Paolo Pellegrini, Harvard Students, to Marry on Sept. 8
description: State Senator and Mrs. Roy M. Goodman of New York, Purchase, N.Y., and Jackson Hole, Wyo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Barbara Goodman to Paolo Marco Pellegrini, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Umberto Pellegrini of Milan and Cogne, Italy. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 9 of the Real Estate section last Sunday on East End Avenue incorrectly reported the residence of Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward. He lives in Whitestone, Queens.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The 52d Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., opens a remarkably varied 11-week season on Tuesday with performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company. This will be the company's first appearance at the Pillow, and it will perform five Graham classics in the intimate little Ted Shawn Theater.

title: Mozambique Dismisses 3 Cabinet Members
description: President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique dismissed three Marxist Cabinet members on Friday, including the Interior and Security Ministers, the state-run Mozambican press agency said today in a dispatch monitored here.

title: U.S. ASKS CITY TO BLOCK USE OF LIBYA 48TH STREET TOWER
description: The State Department has asked New York City to bar Libyan diplomats from occupying that nation's nearly completed 23-story East Side headquarters, pending clarification by the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on how the building will be used.

Duane Ferris performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church in Morristown.

description: -cent postcard. The state is about to spend a bundle advertising the fact that folks from out of state ought to come to Connecticut for a vacation. Now what is the sense of doing that if visitors cannot find a decent postcard in the drugstore or the card shop?

title: China Puts Computers Into Rice Paddies
description: China today unveiled its first rice paddies in which peasants use a microcomputer to control irrigation and reduce the work force for growing one of the world's most labor-intensive crops.

description: People who need a doctor in the Twin Cities area can now thumb through a catalogue to choose exactly the one they want.

title: THE WORLD OF PERE-LACHAISE
description: In a recent vacation in Paris my husband was planning the next day's activities. ''Tomorrow,'' he said, ''I have arranged a special trip. We are going to P ere-Lachaise to visit the grave of Marcel Proust. We'll take a picnic.''

title: Norad Commander to Retire
description: Gen. James V. Hartinger, Commander in Chief of the North American Aerospace Defense Command since January 1980, will retire Aug. 1. He will be replaced by Lieut. Gen. Robert T. Herres, 51 years old, according to an announcement by the command, whose mission is to protect the United States and Canada from nuclear attack.

description: Joe Delaney was a hero on the football field as a running back for the Kansas City Chiefs. He was proclaimed a hero again when he died trying to save two drowning boys in a Louisiana pond.

description: Karen Elyse Chachkes, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Trister Chachkes of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Douglas Jay Ende, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Scott Ende of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Steven Rosman performed the ceremony at Waveny House.

title: A COMMUNITY DEFENDS ITS CLAIM TO AN IDENTITY

Hansell of Narberth, Pa., took place yesterday. The Rev. Frederick J. Warnecke Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.
