title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A PHOTOGRAPHER AIMS FOR A POINT OF VIEW
description: THE photographer Nancy Crampton has never met a subject she hasn't liked. And since she specializes in artists and writers, a temperamental lot, this, she conceded, is unusual.

title:
CAMERA;
COMPOSING A PICTURE
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. has written many books on photography.

title: THE REGION
description: Final Word: Desegregate

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Athletics
description: International Games for the Disabled, at Mitchel Field, Uniondale, L.I. opening ceremonies, 2 P.M. to 5 P.M. More than 1,800 men and women athletes from 53 countries will attend, plus President Reagan and King Gustav of Sweden. (Television - Cablevision, 2 P.M., live; Sports Channel, 11:30 P.M., tape.). Auto Racing

title: PETER MARTINS IS FORGING A CHOREOGRAPHIC IDENTITY
description: Two new ballets by Peter Martins have recently had their premieres, but not in the same city. One was ''Rejouissance,'' created for the New York City Ballet where Mr. Martins is, jointly, balletmaster in chief with Jerome Robbins. The second ballet was ''Mozart Violin Concerto,'' first given at the Philadelphia Academy of Music in a gala celebrating the Pennsylvania Ballet's 20th anniversary.

title: LIFE'S MAGIC, $5.20, CAPTURES THE MOTHER GOOSES AT BELMONT
description: Life's Magic, who fell a neck short of catching Miss Oceana in the Acorn Stakes three weeks ago, came from last place in a field of five to reverse that decision yesterday in the $217,700 Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: ARBROATH SMOKIES, SCOTLAND'S PRIDE
description: For generations, the fisher folk of Auchmithie, a tiny village on Scotland's northeast coast, performed a daily ritual. The village, on a cliff overlooking the North Sea, has no natural harbor, and its fishermen were forced to anchor their boats in the shallows.

title: BELL IS CITING 202 SCHOOLS AS AMONG THE BEST
description: Education Secretary T. H. Bell says a ''can-do attitude'' pervades the 202 secondary schools that his department has named as some of the best in the nation.

title: Michelle Teichgraeber, Editor, Is Wed
description: Michelle Teichgraeber, a daughter of Bernard E. Teichgraeber of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Barbara Gehring Teichgraeber, was married yesterday to Keith McElroy Rockwell, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Hays Hamilton Rockwell of New York. The ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York was performed by the bridegroom's father, the rector of the church, and the Rev. Daniel Burke.

title: A FEARLESS MOMENT KEEPS ITS HOLD ON DICKIE THON
description: HOUSTON THE object came upon him too suddenly, too

title: THE FATHER AS GIRL SCOUT, AND OTHER WONDERS
description: William Kotzwinkle's most recent books are ''Queen of Swords'' and the forthcoming ''Seduction In Berlin.'' FREE AGENTS

title: TURKU, WHERE FINLAND'S HISTORY WAS WROUGHT
description: Second cities stand on their own, straightforward, unpretentious and generally more revealing of the core and character of a nation than their more sophisticated capitals.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Some Hope for Herpes Victims

title: A SMALL PLAYHOUSE IS RETURNED TO USE
description: AS the Old Capitol Theater in Port Chester proceeds slowly, and at times unsurely, with renovations and a campaign grows to restore the Music Hall in Tarrytown and bestow upon it some new-found glory, yet another gem of a playhouse in need of revamping, albeit on a smaller scale, has been rediscovered in the county.

title: Robin Wolfe Engaged To William L. Kaskel
description: Robin Jill Wolfe and William Lewis Kaskel will be married Aug. 26, the father of the future bride, Dr. Robert E. Wolfe of Nyack, N.Y., has announced.

title: POLITICAL CHIEF AND PRIEST SLAIN IN PUNJAB
description: Sikh terrorists in Punjab today killed a leader of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party near the town of Jullundur, according to officials in the state.

title: IN NEWARK, A CONDOMINIUM FOR LAW FIRMS
description: THE Port Authority of New York and

title: MEREDITH WILLSON, COMPOSER OF 'MUSIC MAN,' IS DEAD AT 82
description: Meredith Willson, the composer, librettist and lyricist of ''The Music Man,'' a landmark musical of the 1950's, died Friday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82 years old and lived in Brentwood, Calif.

title: LAW REWRITTEN ON STRIPED BASS
description: THE East Coast's populations

title: SUFFOLK HAILS MINORITY HIRING PROGRAM IN POLICE DEPARTMENT
description: Suffolk County is claiming success for a program that promotes women and members of minority groups hired as community aides in the County Police Department to the rank of officer.

title: CONGRESS MOVES TO GET HANDS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Technology and politics are the two driving forces of weapons invention, but they do not always push in the same direction. Last week they seemed to jerk around the compass at cross-purposes.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOLDING DOWN THE COST OF HOTEL PHONE BILLS
description: Carol Nashe knows a lot about telephones and a lot more about hotels. She is director of public relations for the 1,430-room Sheraton Boston Hotel, and it is part of her job to keep track of trends in the lodging industry. ''When I'm traveling,'' she said in an interview, ''I usually check where I plan to stay to see how much it will cost to phone from the room. Often, I give my office a time when I'll be available and let them call me.''

title: STRIPED BASS STUDY PURSUES AN ENIGMA
description: '' SAVE our Stripers'' is the cry along the Atlantic Coast. Fishing regulations for this highly prized game fish have been tightened. Conservationists demand that the striped bass be declared an endangered species because of the decline in commercial catch and reproduction rates.

title: HOW THE ORDEAL OF SAKHAROV WAS RECREATED FOR CABLE TV
description: LONDON From the beginning, the challenge in filming ''Sakharov'' was how to portray an enigmatic but courageous man caught inside a secretive and totalitarian state. What caused Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist credited with developing the hydrogen bomb for the Soviet Union, to be driven by conscience into a repudiation of nuclear arms? What motivated him to become an outspoken human-rights advocate in a state that does not suffer dissent or ingratitude kindly? And how could moral authority be packaged within a two-hour dramatization that attempts to avoid the pitfalls of Cold War cliches about saintly figures being persecuted by state inquisitors?

title: THE WORLD
description: Polish Dissidents Getting a Trial

title:
ART;
AN UPBEAT PHOTOGRAPHIC SHOW
description: -widening audience appreciative of its artistic concerns. Those who are sensitive to the medium's potential (as well as those who would like to learn more) will be intrigued with the group exhibition currently installed in the enlarged Firehouse Gallery at Nassau Community College. The broad stylistic range that was sought here has produced a show that reveals a great deal about photographic techniques in general and a great deal, too, about what photographers are doing today.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ATHENEUM READIES NEW GALLERIES
description: TODAY'S largest and most famous collection of early colonial furniture, iron work, kitchen utensils and other household furnishings of the Pilgrim century - 1,000 items from the definitive Wallace Nutting collection - was a gift in 1925 to the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. It had been purchased by J. Pierpont Morgan, whose father was born in Hartford, specifically for the museum, which is at 600 Main Street in Hartford.

title: MANHATTAN'S NEW SKYSCRAPERS PAY HOMAGE TO THE 20'S
description: If there is any stretch of recent architectural history

title: MARTINELLI, LONGO TESTIFY IN BIAS SUIT
description: MAYOR Angelo R. Martinelli and the Council minority leader Nicholas Longo testified in Federal District Court last week that they had opposed low-income housing in Yonkers, despite the fact that the city had agreed to construct housing units for low-income families in predominantly white areas in exchange for Federal funds.

title: THE WAYS OF FATHERS
description: SAVING ARRIVED AT AN age when much of my reading is rereading, I find myself engaged again with ''The Education of Henry Adams.'' I first read the book nearly 30 years ago. My father had died recently and was much on my mind, as Henry Adams's father was on his mind during the writing of his inimitable, if occasionally unfathomable, autobiography. I fastened on a fragment of his characterization of his father - ''singular for mental poise - absence of self-assertion or self-consciousness - the faculty of standing apart without seeming aware that he was alone . . . .''

title: CHURCHES JOIN DEVELOPERS FOR MUTUAL GAIN
description: Some unusual partnerships between churches and

title: HOW TO TEST POLITICAL WATERS
description: IF YOU want to run for public office, but lack the funds or political party support to consider

title: Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Married To Miss Emerson
description: At the Wellesley Hills (Mass.) Congregational Church yesterday Deborah Myers Emerson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart B. Emerson Jr. of Wellesley Hills, was married to David Struthers Pinkham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. R. Pinkham of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE VIRUS OF NATIONALISM DISTORTS THE OLYMPIC IDEAL
description: THE modern Olympics began with a boycott. Not

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CAPE COD
description: The vigilant and effective Association for the Preservation of Cape Cod has been defined as the organization that would ban traffic from mainland Massachusetts onto the Cape - once its last member crossed the bridge.

title: 'Y' BRIEFING IS SET ON LIFE IN ISRAEL
description: WEST ORANGE

title: 'GIRL GROUPS' TAKE A CUE FROM THE 50'S
description: Nostalgia is endemic in today's popular music. We have rockabilly revivals, folk-rock revivals, heavy- metal revivals, even Frank Sinatra standards revivals. And so, in a decade that seems to be reverting in spirit to the 1950's in so many ways, it is hardly surprising that we should be experiencing a ''girl-group'' revival - groups and individual women who have put aside the overt feminism of so many female singers of the late 60's and 70's and have gone back instead to a rock sound that features clangorously confessional, wailingly balladic or cheerleader-enthusiastic female vocals, all reminiscent of similar singers from the late 50's and early 60's.

title: ARTISTIC FURNITURE
description: BOSTON UNIVERSITY'S program in artisanry is considered one of the country's foremost training centers for makers of hand-crafted furniture. In recent years, graduates have garnered awards and acclaim in the demanding field of fine cabinetmaking, and students have found their work in demand for exhibitions and commissions.

title: JACKSON REPUDIATE FARRAKHAN
description: Since the death of Elijah Muhammad, in 1975, Louis Farrakhan has felt free to build a movement of extremist Black Muslims, who see their salvation in total separation from the ''white devils,'' and specifically reject our democratic system. As the national political conventions approach, it is important that he be publicly repudiated by those who have done so much to bring blacks into the democratic system.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: At first, it seemed to me that the most chilling aspect of Philip B. Linker's defense of drunk driving is its tone of supreme reasonableness. Mr. Linker wants us to know that he is an articulate man, an educated man, a moderate man - notwithstanding the fact that, by his own lights, he has probably driven home drunk (with a blood alcohol content of .10) every weekend for the past 25 years. He certainly does not ''encourage weekend intemperance.''

title: WATTEAU GETS SHOW AFTER 300 YEARS
description: A 300th-birthday celebration for one of the most mysterious figures of art history, the French painter Jean Antoine Watteau (1684-1721), opens today at Washington's National Gallery of Art. Organized by the gallery and two other important institutions, the Louvre in Paris and the Schloss Charlottenburg in Berlin, it's the first major international exhibition of Watteau's drawings and paintings, the latter in scarce supply in the United States.

title: Headliners
description: In Steinbergland For Saul P. Steinberg , it was another day, another $60 million. For many other investors in Walt Disney Productions, however, it was a day of outrage.

title: FILLING IN SOME BLANKS ON HOW TO SELECT THE BEST TAPE
description: With the growing popularity of home- video taping, the market for blank cassettes has burgeoned and become increasingly competitive. Advertising claims, often contradictory, confuse rather than guide the hapless viewer; yet, he cannot make his own controlled comparisons unless he records precisely the same image on different brands of tape. This can be done with a special signal generator (or a high- quality video disk) creating a test pattern on the screen. But few among the more casual users of VCR's (video-cassette recorders) are so equipped; they must therefore rely on independent test reports.

title: FOOD ; GRILLING OVER AN OPEN FIRE-WITHOUT LOSING THE JUICINESS
description: COOKING outdoors is one of the great pleasures of summer. There is nothing like the smell of meat or fish grilling over an open fire. But this method of cooking is one of the more difficult to get right. Because the grill is placed directly on the fire, the food can easily dry out and toughen or burn. Hamburgers, steaks and chops are the easiest to cook because they can stand up to the heat and still emerge juicy and tender. But after a few weeks, these can become monotonous.

title: HISTORY AT THE 18TH HOLE
description: AMONG the spectators around the 18th green at Winged Foot, he was the needle in the haystack. Now 71 years old, George Low had stood there for the finish of the three previous United States Open golf tournaments at Winged Foot, when Bobby Jones won in 1929, Billy Casper in 1959 and Hale Irwin in 1974. And he will be standing there again today when the history of this Open clunks into the cup on that green.

title: BLACK MONDALE SUPPORTERS STRESS GOAL OF DEFEATING REAGAN
description: Black delegates and supporters of Walter F. Mondale meeting here today indicated that their main concerns were the defeat of President Reagan in the fall and ''bread and butter issues'' that affect blacks.

title: Dr. J. M. Kaspareck Jr. Is Wed to Diane Miller
description: Diane Dorothy Miller, the daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Butkus of Andover, N.J., and Singer Island, Fla., and the late Albert J. Miller, was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Matthew Kaspareck Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kaspareck of Fanwood, N.J. Richard Arthur, uncle of the bridegroom and an elder in the Plymouth Brethren, performed the ceremony at the Kenilworth (N.J.) Gospel Chapel.

title: THE CADILLAC OF INVESTING PROGRAMS
description: The Savant Technical Investor

title: MARKETING EXPERT FOR A STOCK MARKET
description: '' A LOT of people are not aware of the fact that exchanges market themselves,'' said Dr. Marcia J. Kramer of Laurel Hollow.

title: Ousted Mayor Wins Ruling
description: The state Board of Elections has ruled that the former Providence Mayor, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., can run again for the post he had to leave after being convicted of a felony. But opponents of Mr. Cianci's candidacy say they will appeal to the Rhode Island Supreme Court or take the issue up again with city election officials. Mr. Cianci was forced to resign April 25, after nine years as mayor, after he was given a five-year suspended sentence for assaulting a man he believed was having an affair with the mayor's estranged wife in 1983.

title: ROCHESTER PINS ITS HOPES ON ANOTHER HIGH-TECH BOOM
description: While scouring this city in 1880 for equipment to establish his photography business, George Eastman found a small engine. It cost a little more than he wanted to spend and was a little more powerful than necessary. ''I really need only a one horsepower,'' he said, according to a biographer. ''This is two horsepower, but perhaps business will grow up to it. It's worth a chance; I guess I'll take it.''

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Control-Tower Discontent

title: UNDERGROUND URGES BOYCOTTS AND PROTESTS IN POLAND'S LOCAL ELECTIONS TODAY
description: ''Vote,'' say the Government posters at bus stops and street corners. ''Don't vote,'' say the small cards left surreptitiously on buses, staircases and in elevators.

title: WHISTLER'S DAD
description: Whistler's father is long forgotten though Whistler by him was begotten. As for me, I say it's rotten when filial kudos be so ill-gotten.

title: Animal Consciousnes; s
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Anthony Garcia Is Wed to Cliffeton Green
description: Cliffeton Green, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. Edwin Green Jr. of Harrisburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Garcia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis Garcia of New York.

title: BUILDINGS' SALE BACKS NEW BRUNSWICK REVIVAL
description: Officials of the New Brunswick Development Corporation have announced that an investment firm plans to buy two downtown office buildings. The officials say the move will continue the revitalization of this Middlesex County city.

title: Nancy E. Trettis Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Elizabeth Trettis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Trettis of Cohasset, Mass., was married yesterday to Andrew Louis Kirby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kirby of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Timothy John Joyce performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Cohasset.

title: Dr. Cheryl Courtlandt Weds Dr. W. F. Alleyne 2d
description: Dr. Cheryl D. Courtlandt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Courtlandt of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. William F. Alleyne 2d, a son of Mr. Alleyne of Brooklyn and the late Barbara Carson Alleyne. Bishop Emerson Moore and the Rev. Edward Alleyne, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Basque Rioters Dispersed
description: Riot policemen using tear gas dispersed several hundred youths who stoned security forces and blocked streets with cars and buses in San Sebastian and Bilbao in the Basque region of Spain Friday night.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A SON RECALLS HIS FATHER'S LIFE-AUTHENTIC, FREE OF NUANCE
description: WITH the passage of time, memories of my deceased father become brighter, sharper. I remember his warm, honest smile, his special charm and his deep melodic tones as he whistled one of his favorite songs, ''Some Day I'll Find You.'' I remember the many sad stories he told his children and how he reveled in our weeping pleasure. I remember, too, that when I was very young he informed me that there were two character flaws he would not tolerate, lying and stealing.

title: SALES TAX REAPS SURPRISE SURPLUS
description: HARTFORD AFTER four consecutive years of red ink, Connecticut's state government will close its fiscal year June 30 with a sizable surplus. And it is beginning to burn a hole in some legislators' pockets.

title: AN INNOCENT FROM IOWA
description: Barbara Creaturo is senior editor of Cosmopolitan magazine. IVY DAYS

title: Ban on Quaaludes Approved
description: The Senate approved legislation on Friday that would outlaw the sale of methaqualone by requiring the Justice Department to classify the sedative the same as heroin.

title: Disabled Games Today
description: The shouts and clapping of 12 young American men racing through passing and shooting drills rang out this morning on a basketball court in the vast new physical education center at Nassau Community College. In an adjacent court, eight young men from the Netherlands threw volleyballs at one another with an intense velocity.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: IT'S supposed to be April

title: TEACHER, 75, LOOKS TO NEW HORIZONS
description: FOR many young people, a career choice is an agonizing decision. But Lena Angelica of Enfield made up her mind early, at the age of 5,

title: IRWIN LEADS OPEN BY ONE AFTER 69 IN THIRD ROUND
description: Hale Irwin and Fuzzy Zoeller waged a memorable head-to-head battle for 18 holes in the third round of the 84th United States Open at Winged Foot's West course today, with one or the other holding a one-shot lead in the tournament on six occasions.

title: THE REGION
description: Enforcing a Low Profile

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: If Philip Linker has been driving while legally drunk for the past 25 years, as he declares in his article entitled ''Drinking and Driving Can Mix,'' he is not following his own dictum concerning true liberty, which, as he avers, involves the duty to ''police ourselves.'' So far he has been lucky, and so have the people he has not managed to kill while driving in a state of diminished alertness.

title: 20,000 More Workers Strike in West Germany
description: More than 20,000 workers staged warning strikes against the national airline, newspapers and retail shops on Friday as labor strife spread in West Germany.

title: NEW YORK WOMEN'S GROUPS TRYING TO REVIVE RIGHTS BILL
description: Women's rights groups have begun a last-minute campaign to resuscitate a proposed New York State equal-rights amendment that was blocked this week in a private meeting of State Senate Republicans.

title: RESURGENT HEARNS TAKES AIM AT HAGLER
description: Roberto Duran flew home to Panama today to mark his 33d birthday and to ponder the collapse of his boxing career. But Thomas Hearns flew home to Detroit, reveling in the revival of his career, and announced that he was drawing a bead on Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THROUGH THE GENERATIONS
description: IHAVE been reading my father's autobiography,

description: Duarte Shows His Style in El Salvador

description: To the Editor:

title: Ailey Dance Endowment
description: A $90,000 scholarship endowment fund has been established for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center by the Christian A. Johnson Endeavor Foundation. The grant, which will be paid in increments of $30,000 a year for three years, will help support the American Dance Center's merit scholarship program, which totally subsidizes the dance training of selected students. More than 1,500 students have been assisted by the program, which was founded 12 years ago.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: F. J. Gasparini Jr., Biochemist, Wed To Claudia Flynn
description: Claudia Grace Flynn, a daughter of Mrs. Edward F. Flynn of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Flynn, was married yesterday to Francis J. Gasparini Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gasparini Sr. of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Francis Boyle performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Last Hired, First Fired, Still Legal

title: THE QUEST FOR OLYMPIC GREATNESS
description: Jane Gross is a sports reporter for The Times.

title: CONFLICTING TESTIMONY HEARD IN INQUIRY INTO SINKING OF SHIP
description: A Coast Guard board of inquiry heard conflicting testimony this week on the effectiveness of safety measures aboard an oil-drilling ship that sank in the South China Sea last fall.

title: HOME AWAY FROM HOME FOR PRO GOLFERS
description: HARRISON TERRI BECK smiles about it now, but she remembers her first trip to the county as an unhappy experience. Two weeks after marrying the professional golfer Chip Beck in 1979, she found herself in a hotel room while he tried to qualify for the Westchester Classic.

title: SUMMER WORKSHOPS AND COURSES
description: A WIDE variety of craft courses taught by professionals is being offered at New Jersey art centers and colleges this summer.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS ASSAIL TRADE BARRIERS
description: Six environmental groups today entered the debate over a national industrial policy with a report that cites the promise of open world markets and high technology, and opposes trade protection.

title: TOBACCO INDUSTRY FACES INTENSIFYING HEAT
description: On the tobacco farms of the Southeast, the period of anticipation has arrived. With their crop maturing under a steady sun, growers await the harvest and the opening of the markets next month, when the auctioneer's chant will fill the sweet air. But, in addition to the seasonal jitters, the people who make their living from tobacco also feel the economic and political ground shifting.

title: PAUL R. STRAUSS IS WED TO ANN F. SANTOMASSO
description: Ann Fenlon Santomasso, a senior research biologist at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, and Paul R. Strauss, financial editor of Data Communications, a McGraw- Hill publication, were married yesterday. The Rev. Louis Giola, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's Manhattan apartment.

title: TITLE TO JODY ROSENTHAL
description: Jody Rosenthal of the University of Tulsa defeated Julie Brown of Scotland, 4 and 3, today to win the British Amateur women's golf championship.Miss Rosenthal, 21 years old, who intends to turn professional next year, clinched the title at the 15th hole and achieved only the fifth American victory in the final in 20 years.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUES FROM THE PACIFIC
description: The Federated States of Micronesia, with sets of four commemoratives and three airmail definities, are becoming the third of four Pacific Territories administered by the United States to initiate postal independence. This is a major step along the road to self-government.

title: Soviet Paper Says U.S. Envoy Was Ousted for Illegal Sales
description: A Soviet labor newspaper said today that an American Embassy official was compelled to leave the Soviet Union in February for illegally selling Western consumer goods out of his car trunk at a Moscow construction site at night.

title: HARD SWALLOW
description: To the Editor:

title: HONOR THY FATHER AND ODDBALLS, TOO
description: We are talking today about oddballs and about fathers and the double-headed nail. And how it is important to honor all of these.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: CONSIDERING the weather lately, perhaps stripping bunnies of their furry coverings isn't such a bad idea. But for those bunnies at the Playboy Hotel-Casino in Atlantic City, the skinning is permanent.

title: THE NATION
description: Antitrust Rules Are Modified

title: A REFLECTION OF THE PAST
description: NEW YORK'S FIRST DUPLEX APARTment houses were originally built for artists. Dating from around the turn of the century, they featured two-story ''studio'' rooms designed to function as both work spaces and living rooms, with oversize windows facing north and ample space for large canvases and easels.

title: GENERALS TOP GOLD BY 27-7
description: The Generals, who had become known as the Herschel Walker team, moved in another direction today. Their quarterback, Brian Sipe, threw three touchdown passes in an easy 27- 7 victory over the Denver Gold before a crowd of 28,915 in the last regular- season game at Giants Stadium.

title:
DINING OUT;
HOTEL DINING IN MORRISTOWN
description: IT'S difficult to explain why a restaurant that

title: AUCTIONER PLAYS MANY ROLES
description: AUCTIONEERS, according to Milton R. Crosby, cannot live on fast talk alone. ''Customers deserve a fair shake,'' he said. ''And I want my words to be heard.''

title: NEW CAFE IS BETTER AT LUNCH
description: STAMFORD'S once sparse restaurant scene has, over the past couple of years, been undergoing a slow but steady metamorphosis. The newest arrival is Mems Cafe, a small restaurant on Main Street, handily located for downtown walk-in traffic.

title: Letters ; Scarcity on L.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS WIN
description: A few hours after the Mets released Mike Torrez, their oldest pitcher, Dwight Gooden, their youngest one, threw seven efficient innings to win his sixth game of the season as the Mets defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-1, at Busch Stadium tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Pitkoff a Bride

description: To the Editor:

title: CLUB PLAN STIRS HAUPPAUGE
description: A PUBLIC hearing by the Smithtown Town Board to consider rezoning the Hauppaugue Country Club to permit the building of condominiums promises to heat up an already steamy summer season.

description: This Week:

title: TEMPLE RAID OPENING RIFTS IN INDIAN CITY
description: On the surface, life appears normal in this industrial city in the heart of Punjab state, 10 days after Indian troops raided and cleared the Golden Temple of hundreds of Sikh terrorists.

title: NUCLEAR POWER FROM CANADA MAY FILL NEW ENGLAND NEED
description: As the Seabrook 1 nuclear power plant sits dormant on the New Hampshire coast, three-quarters complete but on the brink of cancellation because of cost overruns, New England utilities are shopping here for alternative power.

title: N.B.A. Draft Is a Peek Into Future
description: Draft Day, 1984.

title: Thomas B. Trethaway Is Married to Julia Wu
description: -1-14, 2 lines Julia Wu, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. C. Wu of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Thomas Broad Trethaway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Broad Trethaway of Peru, Vt. The Rev. Robert L. Clayton performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Chapel in Manchester, Vt.

title: THACKERAY, UPDIKE AND THE GAS CRISIS OF 1973
description: James Atlas is an associate editor of The Atlantic and the author of a forthcoming novel, ''The Great Pretender.'' ROWSING among my Penguin Classics for something to read on a long flight, I was discouraged by the synopses on the back covers. ''For all its flaws,'' the jacket copy said of George Eliot's ''Felix Holt,'' ''the novel remains a major . . .'' Flaws I didn't need. ''Hard Times'' ''has never achieved the popularity and seldom the recognition of Dickens's other novels. . . .'' Why not, I wondered, putting it back on the shelf. Stendhal's ''Charterhouse of Parma,'' in which Fabrizio's ''final withdrawal into a monastery emphasizes his lack of contact with real life and his similarity to the ingrown hero of the twentieth century,'' seemed rather dispiriting put that way. Why should I be interested in a protagonist who has nothing to do with real life?

title: MOVING BRISKLY ON IMMIGRATION-LAW CHANGES
description: A S though making up for lost time, the House last week took up a broad immigration control bill and moved briskly through more than 50 amendments. By week's end, the debate still hadn't ended, but many opponents of the measure had begun to talk of the inevitabiliity of passage. ''Things don't look very good,'' said Robert Garcia, the Democrat from the Bronx who heads the Hispanic Caucus.

title: DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND PROPOSED
description: A Mayoral advisory commission has

title: GUITAR RECITAL: PETER COREY
description: In Peter Corey's recital at Goodman House on Wednesday night, a quantity of superior guitar playing was lavished upon music that--with one natable exception--was of little consequence. The exception was Bach's Lute Suite No. 4 in E. The other works were Giuliani's ''Sonata Eroica,'' Barrios's Waltz and ''Catedral,'' Enrique Ubieta's ''Sleepless Street'' and two groups of pieces by Mr. Corey himself--Five Preludes and Six Bagatelles.

title: A MILITARY STRATEGY FOR THE 90'S
description: The illusion that there is a ''Navy war,'' an ''Army war'' and an ''Air Force war,'' enshrined in as many separate war colleges, is at the heart of a runaway defense budget, structured to serve bureaucratic rather than national interests.

title: U.S. Park Service Honors 3
description: Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Frank Horton of Rochester were honored yesterday at a ceremony marking the establishment of the Women's Rights National Historic Park in 1980 - 475 acres in upstate New York that includes much of historic Seneca Falls. Mr. Moynihan, who was unable to attend, was commended by the National Park Service for pressing legislation for the park. Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Horton were cited for helping obtain an appropration of $500,000 for buying Wesleyan Chapel - the site for the first Women's Rights Convention, in 1848 - and other historic buildings.

title: NEW JERSEY BALLET MARKING 25TH YEAR
description: MILLBURN ''WHEN we began the New Jersey Ballet in December 1958,'' said Carolyn Clark, its artistic director, ''people thought we were a bunch of gypsies running around in white tights, and the general feeling about the art form was, 'Ballet? What is it?' ''

The Rev. Joseph B. Doty performed the ceremony at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington.

But the real substance of the conference is expected to take place in less formal get-togethers, where there may be a shootout of sorts between the countries that have been cooperating with the international banking community and those that have been defying it.

Production goals of 500,000 barrels a day of oil equivalent by 1987 and 2.2 million barrels a day by 1992 (more than 25 percent of our current production) were written into the law.

title: GO A BIT FARTHER AFIELD
description: DOES the warm weather induce a bit of the wanderlust in you? If so, this might be a good time to consider going outside the county for cultural enrichment. A two- or three-hour drive is not the problem it can be in winter - in fact, it is often a refreshing change of pace - and within that perimeter are extensive opportunities for the pursuit of musical happiness.

title: SAMPLING THE FLAVORS OF INDIA
description: JHOOLA in Syosset, the western branch of a restaurant of the same name in Smithtown, opened about two months ago. Business appears to be slow so far. The location, off Jericho Turnpike in a mini-mall opposite an indoor tennis facility, cannot help. But if you are fond of or even curious about Indian food and would enjoy the variety of preparations including superb flat breads, unusual vegetable dishes and grilled specialties, Jhoola is well worth visiting.

title: DONALD DUCK'S SECRET OF LONG LIFE: HE'S ONLY HUMAN
description: To be perfectly frank, Mickey Mouse has always seemed a bit of a prig, a thoroughly decent, unassuming sort of fellow who's a natural-born leader, but still a prig. He's the kid who's always elected president of his class without half trying, who does his homework on time and who, if he were on the football team, would never dream of breaking training, no matter how alluring the circumstances. It's in his character to do good deeds for the world's less fortunate and to say - and to believe - that it's always darkest before the dawn.

title: Julie C. Skakel Plans August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rushton W. Skakel of Greenwich, Conn., and Windham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Julie Corcran Skakel, to John Scott Kracke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut John Kracke of East Williston, L.I., and Windham. The wedding is planned for August.

description: State Senator Raymond Lesniak's proposed pesticide-regulation legislation (S. 1342) is a prime example of the way we have abandoned the three R's: Reason, Respect and Responsibility. (Mr. Lesniak, a Democrat, lives in Elizabeth.)

title: NEW YORK CHEESE PRODUCERS SET A RECORD FOR EIGHTH YEAR
description: Cheese production in New York State rose to a record 398 million pounds in 1983, up 11 percent from 1982, according to figures reported this week by the state's Crop Reporting Service.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
A NEW CYCLE IN 'YA' BOOKS
description: TODAY, ''The Catcher in the Rye'' would be ''almost impossible to issue as an adult book,'' according to George Nicholson, Dell's editor in chief of Books for Young Readers. Most novels of adolescence would now be perceived, and published, as Young Adult fiction. But librarians recognized teen- agers as a distinct audience long before publishers did - ''YA'' originated as a librarian's term. In the local public library 20 years ago, you couldn't satisfy your curiosity about sex, but you could do the other thing adolescents have always needed and wanted to do: You could read about yourself, both in the cheery, reassuring light of the ''older children's books'' and in the colder eye of a J. D. Salinger.

title: Reagan Asks for Return To Traditional Values
description: President Reagan, in a Father's Day weekend appeal for a return to traditional family values, said today that families are better off than they were under the Carter Administration.

description: Deborah Jean Roloff, a financial analyst for Harvard University, and N. Gregory Mankiw, a candidate for a doctorate and a law degree in a combined program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University, were married yesterday at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony.

description: Tournament bridge-players, like Caesar's Gaul, are divided into three parts. There are the traditionalists who lead the top card from three small and follow with the middle card. This has the advantage of making the high-card position obvious, but often leaves partner in doubt, even perhaps after the second trick, whether the leader began with a docubleton or a tripleton.

title: 'JOSEPH' LACKS THE ELEMENT OF SURPRISE
description: mostly demerits - of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' as performed at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport, it is easy to see that the show was conceived as a half-hour junior high school production in England and that it had its first American exposure as an amateur attraction.

title: CUOMO INTENSIFIES THE PRESSURE ON LILCO
description: DURING the past few weeks, Governor Cuomo has made it clearer and clearer that he is willing to let the Long Island Lighting Company stumble to the edge of bankrupcy - and maybe over it - to assure that the Shoreham nuclear power plant will not open.

title: HAIR-LOSS EXPERTS CITE INNOVATIONS
description: Recent innovations and experiments in coping with hair loss, ranging from a scalp-stretching technique to application of a drug, were discussed over the last three days at the International Congress for Hair Replacement Surgery, at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: THE COURT'S SECOND THOUGHTS ON MIRANDA
description: The surprise was not that the Supreme Court carved out an exception to the Miranda rule, but that it did so only last week, rather than years ago. As the most potent symbol of the liberal Warren Court era, the original 5-to-4 Miranda decision of 1966 was widely viewed as a prime target for reversal after Warren E. Burger became Chief Justice in 1969. But that did not happen, and the national uproar that attended the ruling has long since died down. Police departments across the country adjusted their procedures to conform to Miranda, which prohibits the police from questioning suspects before advising them of their legal rights. These ''Miranda warnings'' have become not the invitation to lawlessness that the decision's critics predicted, but an everyday routine familiar to anyone who ever watched a police drama on television.

title: ACTION AND REACTION; Country Life
description: Because the city's Health Department is predicting a severe mosquito season, it's applying a bacterial agent called Bactimos to wetlands in Staten Island, Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. The larvae, they say, won't have a chance.

title: AIR BAGS TO EARN INSURANCEDISCOUNT

description: MOSCOW

title: VOICES FROM THE LEFT
description: DURING THE CLAMOR OF the Presidential campaign, a familiar voice seems strangely muted. The more-or-less middle-of-the-road Democratic candidates can be heard loud and occasionally clear, as can the neoconservative thinkers and their President. But who and where are the thinkers of the left? Why have they been so relatively silent? What ideas and programs do they stand for? How do they see the nation's future?

title: U.S. PUPILS LAG FROM GRADE 1, STUDY FINDS
description: The academic achievement of American schoolchildren in reading and mathematics not only lags behind that of schoolchildren in Japan and Taiwan, but also does so from virtually the day they enter school, a new study has found.

title: ENRCIO BERLNGUER AND HIS CULT OF PERSONALITY
description: The death last week of Enrico Berlinguer, the Italian Communist leader, brought hundreds of thousands of mourners to Rome for a display that helped explain why his party is the second most powerful in Italy and the biggest Marxist force in the West. When he was stricken by a brain hemorrhage, Mr. Berlinguer was campaigning hard to insure a good showing for the party in elections today for the European Parliament. That wish seems likely to come true.

title: SIN AND SALVATION-- THE NOVELS OF ANDREW M. GREELEY
description: OU need not be bitter. You need not explain yourself. Nowadays, if you have been at the center of great events and been bloodied, or if you have not been at the center of great events and think you deserved to be, or if you have been a witness to great events and think they have been lied about or covered up, there is something you can do - write a novel. Novels are better than autobiographies, which people do not trust since they assume that you are lying or covering up. But people trust novels; you have only to mix a little public fact into your fiction and people will assume the worst - of your enemies. There is one problem; the public has to have heard of you first. The inside- great-events novel, as distinct from the older hidden- lives-of-celebrities novel, is a Media Age genre. To do it, you must learn not only the arts of writing but the art of packaging.

title: OLD LAWS REFLECT STATE'S RICH FAUNA
description: OLD WILDLIFE conservation laws and historical records paint a striking picture of the state's rich natural past.

title: The Day the Cloud Lifted
description: Freedom Day, it might be called. It could come on January 1, maybe sooner, and if it does occur, it will reverberate in the history of the melting pot. Through the night, people will line up by the thousands, perhaps by the hundreds of thousands, outside churches, community centers and government offices, waiting to come out of the shadows, waiting for freedom from fear. Freedom Day: the day on which two million or more illegal aliens become legal residents.

title: THE GETTY SHIFTS THE FOCUS WESTWARD
description: The news last week that the J. Paul Getty Museum has acquired some 18,000 photographs and added a full- scale photography department to its curatorial activities was more than unexpected; it was stunning. In one stroke the cash-rich California museum gobbled up the two most prestigious collections in private hands in this country, joined them with seven others to create a collection bigger than that of either the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Museum of Modern Art, wooed away the Metropolitan's curator of photographs to head its new department, and shifted the geographic center of photographic scholarship and connoisseurship in the direction of Malibu.

title: SCOTLAND ONA NEARER SHORE
description: DOUGLAS MARTIN is chief of The New York Times bureau in Toronto. Can you imagine a piece of the universe more fit for princes and kings?'' implores a folk song by the Cape Bretoner Allister MacGillivary. For anyone who has let his or her imagination drift into the fleecy mist below ponderous Cape Smoky on the Cabot Trail, hooked a salmon or trout on the winding Margaree River or chanced upon a rushing waterfall while hiking through the forest, the answer is clear enough.

title: MADRID'S GRAND AND AMIABLE PALACIO REAL
description: Christmas presents, as everyone knows, can often take on an odd or unwelcome form, but when, on the night of Dec. 24, 1734, the royal palace in Madrid burned down to the ground, its owner, King Philip V, was delighted. At last he was rid of the gloomy, inconvenient building he had hated from the very first moment he saw it. Philip, after all, had been raised in Versailles; when it came to palaces, he was used to the very best.

title: OVAL OFFICES
description: Ground will be broken next month for a 75,000-square-foot oval office structure to go up on a 3.3-acre site next to the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City, L.I.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; College Rights
description: A landmark ruling by the United States Supreme Court on Feb. 28 put small Grove City College in Pennsylvania in the limelight. The case gave rise to the Court's so-called narrow interpretation of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, which prohibits sex discrimination by schools that receive Federal funds.

title: REVISITING THE BATTLEGROUND OF AMERICAN MODERNISM
description: ROSLYN HARBOR, New York

title: No Headline
description: New & Noteworthy THE COMMON READER: First Series, by Virginia Woolf. Edited and introduced by Andrew McNeillie. (Harvest/HBJ, $4.95.) An uncommon reader herself, Virginia Woolf in this first collection of literary essays acknowledged ''the common reader'' (a term borrowed from Dr. Johnson), who ''reads for his own pleasure rather than to impart knowledge or correct the opinions of others.'' Some of these ''pleasures'' - like the Paston Letters, and the writings of the Duchess of Newcastle - may seem remote to the common reader of today. But Mrs. Woolf's most casual-seeming criticisms ''show an unwearying creativeness'' - as the unsigned review in our pages pointed out back in 1925, the year that also saw the publication of her first major novel, ''Mrs. Dalloway.'' Here we find her famous essay on ''Modern Fiction,'' exhorting novelists to convey ''the luminous halo'' and ''semi-transparent envelope'' surrounding reality. In writing about Jane Austen, the Bront"es or the Russian writers, Mrs. Woolf seems to apply her new prescription to criticism as well. And this gives her essays their special resonance.

description: It was over a year in the making, and it cost $1 million. But the new Charivari men's and women's clothing store that opened recently at 18 West 57th Street looks, from its plate-glass storefront to its gleaming high-tech interior, just the way a success is supposed to look.

description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 15 - This is Aston Magna's first year of life without its founding father, Albert Fuller. Mr. Fuller, who conceived the organization 12 years ago and helped develop it into perhaps this country's truly professional purveyor of 17th- and 18th-century musical style, withdrew after last season, apparently when his ambitious plans for expansion had met with resistance from within.

title: IN AFRICA, A NATURAL DISASTER MADE WORSE BY MAN
description: The drought that last year destroyed much of the food production in central and southern Africa has started again, leaving dozens of African countries parched. In Senegal, livestock herders have been forced south, touching off tribal violence. In Ethiopia, three million are suffering from malnutrition. And in Mozambique, the Red Cross has tallied 100,000 ''drought- related deaths.''

title: OF PROVIDENCE, FREE WILL AND THE FUTURE OF LEARNING
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer , winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1978, gave this address on May 24 at a celebration in connection with the opening of the New York Public Library's new exhibition area, Gottesman Hall. UDAISM is one religion based entirely on learning. Its very essence is the Torah, a scroll, a book. According to the Talmud, God has created the world with the letters of the Torah. The Talmud also tells us that a child studies the whole Torah while in its mother's womb; but at the moment of birth an angel flicks its mouth and it forgets everything. The motive for this unlearning is that erudition should be the result of free choice, not of prenatal study.

title: WHEN SELF-PROMOTION IS MUSIC TO A CONDUCTOR'S EARS
description: Since the first days of the Republic, Americans have been paying European artists and other celebrities to come over and lecture them about the inferiority of their culture. During the last century, in particular, a Yankee-baiting tour was considered de rigueur for writers such as Oscar Wilde and Charles Dickens, who crisscrossed the country collecting fat fees for demonstrating their superiority to the earnest members of women's clubs and assemblages of civic leaders. Nowadays, the spiritual descendants of those peregrinating celebrities turn up on television talk shows, where they take make it clear that while America is a great place to pick up dollars, they wouldn't want to live there. Strangely, Americans seldom take such slights personally. They actually seem to enjoy being condescended to. The cultural insult is just another form of entertainment, masochistic in form, for a nation that requires continual, unrelenting diversion.

title: FELLOWSHIP WORKS ON TAP IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON ''FELLOWSHIP SHOWCASE,'' a diverse mix of dance from folk to mime and featuring original works by five choreographers who received fellowships from the state's Council on the Arts, will be performed this weekend at the Mill Hill Playhouse here.

The era when entire railroad cars were rolled aboard the ferries is long past - although automobiles now make the trip routinely - but the ferries still provide a pleasant and convenient connection between England and the European continent.

Mr. Turner defeated Jean Chretien, the Energy Minister, on the second ballot of the party convention by a margain of 1,862 to 1,368. Donald Johnston, Minister of (Page 1, Column 6.) Reagan Administration officials remain divided over how to respond to a proposal by the Soviet Union to discuss a ban on antisatellite weapons, officials said. They said there was virtually no prospect for beginning discussions before the November elections. The weight of opinion remains skeptical that a prohibition of such weapons can be verified, the officials said. (1:3.)

title: ELECTRONIC MUSIC FESTIVAL: 3-WEEK SURVEY OF FIELD
description: For whom does one applaud at an electronic music concert? There are no performers, the sounds are on tape and the stage is decorated with nothing but a single set of loudspeakers. When the last notes die away and the houselights come up, a certain self- consciousness may overtake an audience. Applause, of dubious esthetic value to begin with, seems particularly silly in these circumstances; after a few scattered claps, response usually dissolves into nervous laughter and silence. After all, who is being cheered on? The man who operates the bank of tape recorders? The composer - who may be 20 years beyond, and an ocean away from, his creation?

These groups - along with the elderly - are, in the minds of most Democratic strategists, the key to unseating President Reagan.

title: RADIO'S HEYDAY OFFERS FUN AND THRILLS
description: Old radio shows never die - they just keep turning up in various reruns on records and cassettes. One of the latest outfits to enter the field is Metacom, a company based in Minneapolis that carries hundreds of spoken-word items in its ''Adventures in Cassettes'' series, some 40 of them dubbings of radio broadcasts from the 30's, 40's and 50's. I have been sampling a number of these, frequently with the feeling that I was sitting in front of an old dome-shaped Philco receiver in a fringe reception area. This illusion was abetted by the fact that many of these programs seem to have been recorded off the air in the midst of severe magnetic storms in the pre- FM era, with crackling static a frequent obbligato to the entertainment. Still, the voices are clear enough, and guaranteed to set off pangs of wistful nostalgia in all but the most case- hardened of older listeners.

title: Rozier Facing Surgery
description: Mike Rozier, the Pittsburgh Mauler running back who has missed several games because of an ankle injury he suffered in the Orange Bowl last January, will undergo major surgery after the United States Football League season, the club announced. ''It will be full-blown ankle surgery,'' said the Maulers' general manager, George Heddleston, who explained that the surgery would be to repair a bone chip in Rozier's left ankle and remove a calcium deposit.

title: A GROWING TASTE FOR SWEET RED PEPPERS
description: TRENDS AND PATTERNS in national taste have always fascinated me. Some of them are wholly understandable, as when a new fruit such as kiwi or an unaccustomed herb such as fresh coriander appears on the market. One trend has come about within recent months that is fortunate but, to my mind at least, puzzling. And that is the upsurge of interest in sweet red peppers, an ingredient that was common enough in my youth although not, as it suddenly is today, abundantly seen in the marketplace.

title: REAGAN MOVE ALTERS OF PLAY ON THE 'PEACE ISSUE'
description: WASHINGTON D URING the 1980 election campaign, Ronald Reagan's strategists constantly warned against ''an October surprise.'' They suggested that Jimmy Carter would use the power of incumbency for a diplomatic stroke that would put the Republican challenger at a political disadvantage. Last week, Mr. Reagan sprung his own surprise, exercising his Presidential prerogative to upstage rivals and critics in an election year by suddenly dangling the prospect of a summit meeting with Soviet leader Konstanin U. Chernenko.

description: William F. Mohan, a regional director of Moore-McCormack Lines in South America from 1949 to 1969, died Wednesday in Moore Memorial Hospital in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 79 years old and lived in Southern Pines, N.C.

title: IN SHORT, SUPERFICIALITY TAKES A LONG-TERM TOLL
description: Television's most damaging legacy could very well turn out to be the short take. It all began with the commercial, that highly profitable vehicle for selling just about anything. In the beginning, advertisers usually had one minute to deliver the sponsor's message. Then, as prices for air time soared, the 30-second ''spot'' became popular. Now, even as experts wonder if there might be a level of diminishing returns, 15-second commercials, known for the time being as ''split thirties,'' are being whizzed by viewers. Meanwhile, Madison Avenue has become almost spectacularly adept at cramming information into constantly shrinking spaces, and the television audience is being increasingly conditioned to the ''quick fix.'' The result is creeping shallowness and a general impatience with people or things that might demand more thought or consideration.

title: GETTING A JUMP ON FALL
description: OUTSIDE, ON ONE OF THE FIRST HOT days of June, the temperature was 86 degrees. But inside Saks Fifth Avenue, Mary Nielsen, a stockbroker from Wilton, Conn., was shopping for fall clothes in the Calvin Klein boutique. ''I forget all about summer sales because they never have my size,'' she said, pulling out several pairs of size-14 Donegal tweed pants. ''As soon as the new fall clothes come in I buy what I want since they always have a selection of sizes. I'm 5 feet 10, and I need a size l2 or l4, but they're next to impossible to find. If I don't buy my clothes in advance, I can never find anything when I need it. So I always shop out of season.'' She is not alone, as a growing number of women search for cold-weather clothes even as summertime begins.

title: SPRIGHTLY 'FIDDLER' A CELEBRATION OF LIFE
description: '' FIDDLER ON THE ROOF'' was one of the longest-running musicals in Broadway history. Since then, this story of a people vainly trying to preserve their traditions in a hostile and changing world has been done countless times by every theater organization imaginable. Whether it's seen for the first time or the 500th, whether it's being presented by an amateur group with a few babushkas and a wheelbarrow, or by the fully professional first-class touring company now at the Westbury Music Fair, this musical celebration of life is always a joy.

title: AN EYE FOR THE MAIN INGREDIENTS
description: EVERY year, just before the N.B.A. draft, I am invariably besieged by basketball-bitten family, friends and fellow journalists soliciting my opinions on this college player or that. For example, last season more than a few addicts asked me to evaluate the skills of a St. John's forward, David Russell. My response, in typical scout's staccato, was as follows: ''A raw talent in need of major repairs; can't shoot consistently from 18 feet; can't go to his right; not a good ballhandler; has too many defensive lapses; questionable court sense and savvy.'' A pause, ''All things considered, there's no way he makes the N.B.A.''

title: NEW RADIO DRAMA FOCUS ON MYSTERY
description: IF the ominous sounds of ghosts

title: Tracing the Skeins Of Matter
description: Is there no way that a mind such as that of Dr. Peter Carruthers can serve to engender human life rather than to imperil it (''Tracing the Skeins of Matter,'' by William J. Broad, May 6)?

title: JAZZ: FLAVOR OF THE TROPICS
description: The pianist Frank Ferrucci assembled a pan-American jazz band Thursday at the Bottom Line. He led musicians from Brazil, Cuba, the Dominican Republic and the United States through ''Music of the Americas'' - compositions that fused the advanced harmonies of 1960's jazz with an array of tropical rhythms.

title: CRUELEST PUNCHES FOLLOW FIGHTER'S FINAL RING LOSS
description: BILLY COLLINS stood at the edge of Old Franklin Road and looked down into the culvert where his son had died.

title: THE WORLD OF REACHING
description: Playground on Rails

title: Ccensorship in Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Fires in Boston Stores Are Arson, Officials Say
description: The fifth department store fire in less than a week broke out here early today and officials cited arson as the cause.

title: MONDALE PRAISES REP. FERRARO AFTER MEETING
description: Walter F. Mondale lauded Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today as a ''star'' in the Democratic Party and said she had all the qualifications to make a running mate.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: June 17, 1984Fiction1 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Warner, $4.95.) Murder in an Italian monastery. 2 INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM, by James Kahn. (Ballantine, $2.95.) More perilous adventures of the hero of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark''; novelization of the current film. 3

title: FAITH AMONG A RESTLESS PEOPLE
description: PILGRIMS IN THEIR OWN LAND

title: BEING BROOKE ASTOR
description: As Brooke Astor seems to be fond of limericks, I hope she will not be offended:

title: CANADA'S LIBERALS PICK A NEW LEADER ON SECOND BALLOT
description: John N. Turner, a lawyer and former Cabinet member, was elected leader of the Liberal Party of Canada today, replacing Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: NEW 'GOLDEN BOY' STRESSES URGENCY
description: AS a title, ''Golden Boy'' appears to be timeless. As the tale of a young man's determination to be a boxer, it has gone through various changes, guises and forms - all for the sake of timeliness. In its newest musical manifestation, ''Golden Boy'' involves a songwriting team, director and producer who live on the Island.

title: STUDY, IN REVERSE, CONCLUDES COMPANY DIDN'T LOSE PCB'S
description: A lengthy study by a New York State Assembly panel has concluded that a Newark waste disposal company did not lose 100 pounds of PCB's in 1982 while moving the toxic substance for New York City.

title: HOW THE SYSTEM FAILED IN A SEX OFFENSE
description: FREEHOLD WHEN John T. Cusick was released last September after serving 10 months of a three-year sentence for aggravated sexual assault of three girls in his neighborhood, residents of the area and officers familiar with the case protested.

title: LUSH BRYANT ESTATE BEGINS A NEW LIFE
description: ROMANTIC notions sometimes can flourish like an untended garden, where weeds and deliberate plantings sprawl over one another, leaving the observer only to guess at the original scheme.

title: MANY IN EUROPE SEE REAGAN OFFER AS VOTE BID
description: Some Western European commentators today viewed President Reagan's offer to meet with Soviet leaders more as a response to the pressures of an election year than as a major breakthrough or shift in American foreign policy.

title: Sports of The Times ;
description: One More 'Loooou'

title: No Headline
description: Strip Searches Upheld For Guards in Prisons

title: ; A Legend From 1907 Keeps on Going
description: THEY are rare, the legendary 12 cars, but this one has all the

title: A Military Strategy For the 90's
description: Stansfield Turner's article ''A Strategy for the 90's'' (May 6) is a laudable attempt to inject rationality into United States national security policy, but it falls short of the mark on several counts.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC FESTIVAL

title: Diane Arbus's Life
description: For the young aspiring artists and photographers who read The New York Times Magazine and believe in its authority, articles such as Patricia Bosworth's ''Diane Arbus: Her Vision, Life, and Death'' (May 13) lend credence to the antiquated belief that creative neurosis is not only divine, but a sine qua non of artistic achievement. This attitude is one that should have died out with Rimbaud, Van Gogh, etc.

title: WAITING FOR THE AX TO FALL
description: WASHINGTON IN early 1981, when Edward E.

title: WORKS OF AN ARTIST WHO PAINTS FOR HIMSELF
description: ''THEMES AND VARIATIONS, 1942 to 1983'' is the title of Bernard Chaet's show at the Washington Art Association in Washington Depot, and its off-handedness is deceptive. Though almost a retrospective, this display of 71 works, mostly oils, presents itself as a self-portrait rather than as a progress report.

title: The D.H. Steals Special Moment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A DETOUR ALONG THE PRIMROSE PATH
description: I AM a peaceable person. I abhor

title: Kathryn DeHaven Marries
description: Kathryn Mary DeHaven, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. DeHaven of Stockton, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony Carl Chambrovich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chambrovich of Orangeburg, N.Y. The Very Rev. John J. Bracken, Episcopal Vicar of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist in Lambertville, N.J.

title: A CORNER OF AFRICA WHERE TENSION IS CONTAGIOUS
description: Verbal and military skirmishing has intensified recently in the Horn of Africa, where President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of Sudan says neighboring Ethiopia and Libya and the Soviet Union are waging a ''secret war'' against his country. He has accused Ethiopia of helping the Sudanese People's Liberation Movement and other rebels in the south to sow dissension and unrest. The rebels have declared war on Sudan's Islamic path, General Nimeiry adds, referring to growing unrest since he proclaimed Islamic law for all 21 million Sudanese, including the many non-Moslems among the country's six million southerners.

title: Francona Out 8 Weeks
description: Terry Francona, the hot-hitting Montreal Expo outfielder, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday and will be out for as long as eight weeks, the club announced.

title: NEW HEALTH PLAN TACKS TRIED
description: AT LEAST three times a week, and for 30 grueling minutes each time, Arlene Segal, an accounting executive, does aerobic exercises in the red-carpeted fitness center at the corporate headquarters of Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick. An exercise physiologist leads the routines and, afterward, a locker-room attendant launders Mrs. Segal's gym clothes.

title: DIFFERENT DESIGN FOR PROPOSED CANDU REACTOR
description: The reactor that the Canadians are proposing to build to supply New England with power uses the same physical principles employed in reactors in the United States, but its design is entirely different. As a result, its proponents say, it would be less prone to accidents and shutdowns.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: OPTIONS FOR WOMEN OVER 45
description: Resources, a service center that is geared to helping women over the age of 45, has just been established in New York City and will begin offering programs for women this summer. Its directors believe it is the first such place for midlife and older women in the nation.

title: 'Terpsichore Revisited' On Display at Library
description: Photographs, rare books, letters and costume and stage designs are among the 100 items on exhibition in ''Terpsichore Revisited,'' which marks the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

title: MCENROE TAKES FINAL
description: John McEnroe, the top-seeded player, beat Leif Shiras in a stormy 6-1, 3-6, 6-2 final today to win the $203,000 Queen's Club tennis tournament, a key grass- court warmup for next week's Wimbledon championships.

title: NEESKENS SPARKS 2-1 COSMOS VICTORY
description: Now that Coach Eddie Firmani has got Johan Neeskens and Jeff Durgan where they belong, the Cosmos have two consecutive victories.

title: ART FOR ARMS' SAKE
description: Ours is a time marked by the esthetic mediocrity of its weapons - no matter how destructive - and by the alienation of artists from its central issue: national defense. I have a proposal for a way out of this shameful state of affairs. It would guarantee the beauty (and existence) of our armaments well into the future - a future preserved largely by this very solution.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ABOLITION. By Jonathan Schell. 173 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: A Reprieve for Midland Plant
description: The $4.1 billion Midland nuclear plant won a temporary reprieve after directors of the Consumers Power Company voted Friday to continue construction of the troubled project and agreed to talk to opponents of the plant on Tuesday.

title: MEDICAL ETHICS ARE FARE AT HASTINGS CENTER PARTY
description: Is it morally permissible to cut off nutrition to a dying person? How should society allocate such costly medical miracles as artificial hearts? Are the elderly entitled to the same quality of medical care as the young?

title: WHAT YALE MEANS TO FUGARD
description: NEW HAVEN THE last time Athol Fugard was in South Africa, he bought his burial plot, a $10 rectangle of earth in New Bethesda, not far from where he was born 52 years ago in the arid center of his nation. The playwright is not ill, nor is he obsessed with dying. His purchase was simply a testament to his ties to South Africa - his home, his inspiration, the setting for all his plays.

title: Image Problems; Indelicate Delegate
description: With no contest for their Presidential nomination this year, Republicans have been free to choose their national convention delegates with an eye to broadening President Reagan's electoral support.

title: Future Chinese Astronaut
description: A Chinese astronaut will definitely participate in a forthcoming United States space shuttle mission, officials say, although negotiations were not completed in time for a joint announcement on President Reagan's visit to China a month ago.

title: 'TELEVISION AND THE PRESIDENCY'
description: ''TELEVISION AND THE PRESIDENCY'' looks at two great institutions and finds they are joined. The finding is not arguable, although its implications are, and ''Television and the Presidency'' is ambiguous about them itself. It knows television has changed politics; it is uncertain if this is to be mourned or simply accepted. The two-hour documentary, fascinating on its own terms, however, will be shown on WOR-TV, Channel 9, at 9 tonight.

title: ON (AND OFF) A ROLL WITH THE TIGERS
description: DETROIT T HEY know about good times and hard times in Detroit. Take the automobile industry, which has had both in the last three years. Or, take the local baseball team, which has had both in the last three months.

title: THE ENCHANTMENT OF CARDBOARD FLUTES
description: To the Editor:

title: MAINE VOTERS APPROVE BOND ISSUE
description: Maine voters have approved a $15.7 million bond issue to finance the construction of as many as a dozen sewage treatment plants and the cleaning up of eight sites where hazardous wastes had been dumped.

title: A.M.A. FEARS RATIONING OF SERVICES
description: The American Medical Association opened its annual convention here today with members both apprehensive and defensive in the wake of new Federal laws aimed at braking the $1-billion-a-day national bill for health care.

title: Image Problems; Nuclear Toasters If you didn't know the nuclear industry was having image problems, the soothing tone of its press releases would be a tip-off. The heat radiated from the destroyed core at Three Mile Island Unit 2, we're now told, is no more than that of ''17 home toasters.'' That's a lot more inviting than calling it a pile of radioactive rubble that could still scorch your hand off.
description: If you're bored with beaches and have had it with hiking, the nuclear industry has a novel vacation idea: ''A side trip to a nuclear information center can be a fascinating part of a family vacation,'' says Carl Walske, president of the Atomic Industrial Forum. Lots of people apparently visit the wreck at Three Mile Island.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: LABOR SAYS VOTE VINDICATES ITS ROLE
description: With Walter F. Mondale the apparent victor in the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, American labor leaders say their decision to give him an early endorsement has been vindicated.

title: President's PoliciesAssailed by Rep. Ferraro By The Associated Press
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, Democrat of Queens, said yesterday that she not only could do the job of President of the United States - she could do a better job than President Reagan.

title: Pakistan Banks Delete Interest
description: Banks in Pakistan will stop paying interest to depositors next year to conform with Islamic law, according to Finance Minister Ghulam Ishaq Khan. Foreign-owned banks that operate in Pakistan have promised to cooperate, he said at a news conference Friday. Interest payments are forbidden by the Koran, the sacred book of the Moslems.

title: Linda Anderson Wed To Jeffrey Lowenthal
description: Linda J. Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Anderson of Los Alamitos, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey S. Lowenthal, a son of Dr. Joseph P. Lowenthal of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Shirley Lowenthal. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony in the Colonial Room at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: LEWIS IN OLYMPICS AFTER WINNING 100
description: Carl Lewis will be in the Olympics. By winning the 100-meter dash tonight in the United States Olympic track-and-field trials, the world's best sprinter and long jumper also won berths in two Olympic events - the 100-meter dash and the 400-meter relay.

title: Japanese Protest U.S. Plan To Deploy Missiles on Ships
description: About 4,000 people demonstrated today against United States plans to equip Navy vessels with cruise missiles as an American nuclear-powered submarine capable of carrying such missiles was berthed here.

title: U.S. TEAM ROUTS CHINA IN VOLLEYBALL
description: The journey from San Diego, where the United States men's volleyball team has its training center, to Long Beach, Calif., where it will compete in the Olympic Games, has become far more involved than a 90-minute drive on the freeway.

title: COPY/Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: JEWS OF RURAL NEW ENGLAND ENJOY RARE CHANCE TO GATHER
description: His silver hair glistening in the morning sun, Rabbi Everett Gendler held aloft sheaves of dry winter rye, planted and harvested by children at his temple in Andover, Mass. He told the group before him, ''The renewed emphasis on the natural aspect of Jewish observance is crucial to the revitalization of the Jewish tradition.''

title: French Atom Test Detected
description: France conducted its fourth nuclear test this year at its underground testing site at Mururoa atoll in French Polynesia today, a spokesman for the New Zealand Seismological Service said. The blast of a 35-kiloton device was recorded by a New Zealand monitoring station at Rarotonga in the Cook Islands. Scientists have detected 63 tests since France began its testing program at Mururoa in 1975.

title: AN ILL-REASONED CALL TO TAKE THE 1988 OLYMPICS FROM SEOUL
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Paying Lottery Tickets After Computer Breakdown
description: Winners in last week's New Jersey Pick-It and Pick-4 lottery games were able to cash in on their winnings today, but the cause of computer breakdowns that plagued the lottery for three days remained unknown.

title: Market Place; Greeting Cards And Earnings
description: T HE American Greetings Corporation appears

title: CAMPAIGN PAPERS REMAIN A MYSTERY
description: The year- old controversy about the transfer of documents from President Carter's White House and re-election campaign to the Reagan campaign in 1980 is heating up again.

title: LIBYA TOLD U.S. OF PLANS FOR ITS EAST SIDE TOWER
description: Libya said yesterday that it had told the United States it planned to use its nearly completed, 23-story East Side tower for United Nations offices, an ambassador's residence, rental offices and other ''perfectly legitimate'' uses.

title: Rath Worker Takeover Leads to Dismissal of 2
description: Union-led stockholders of the Rath Packing Company have voted the concern's two top officers off its board of directors at the annual meeting here.

title: Susan Spiro Marries Bradley Stone in Great Neck
description: Susan Jane Spiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Bradley Charles Stone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stone of Encino, Calif. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Yaz the Younger Twenty-five years after his father won league most-valuable-player honors as a second baseman, Carl Michael Yastrzemski Jr. is beginning to make his own mark in the Class A Carolina League.

title: CHILDREN OF DIVORCE: VACATIONS
description: SCHOOL is out. Vacation plans

title: Margaret Schuller, 84, Dead;Sculptured Works of Animals
description: Margaret Schuller, a sculptor who specialized in works of animals and was known professionally as Greta Schuller, died Friday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She had had a stroke.

title: FOR 45 YEARS, A LEGAL ARM FOR RIGHTS
description: Jack Greenberg, director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., surveyed the crowd on the roof of 99 Hudson Street, the new home of the organization he has led for the last 23 years.

title: SONG: RAGAS FOR THE NIGHT BY PRAN NATH
description: AGAINST the backdrop of a Saturday evening in New York - the gentle squeal of tires, the distant whistle of the firecracker - Pandit Pran Nath sang night ragas at the Dia Art Foundation on Harrison Street.

title: Woman for Ticket Held Acceptable to Voters By United Press International
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco, picked by Walter F. Mondale to be interviewed about becoming his running mate, said yesterday that an ''enormous shift'' in attitudes has made the idea of a woman Vice President acceptable to Americans.

title: SWALE, WHO WON KENTUCKY DERBY AND BELMONT, COLLAPSES AND DIES
description: Swale, the colt who won the Kentucky Derby last month and the Belmont Stakes nine days ago, died yesterday morning after collapsing suddenly outside his stable at Belmont Park.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET DISPLAYS ITS DIVERSITY
description: TWO performances Saturday by the New York City Ballet in the New York State Theater exemplified the diversity of the company's repertory.

title: MONDALE ENTRUSTS OLD ALLY WITH SEARCH
description: From his secluded home in this suburb of St. Paul, Walter F. Mondale lifts the phone three or four times a day now and dials the number in Washington of his close friend, John R. Reilly.

title: F.B.I. Drops RadicalFrom Most Wanted List
description: Katherine Ann Power, one of the last 1960's radicals still at large, has been dropped from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of most wanted fugitives.

title: NEW ORLEANS FAIR IS FUN BUT TOO FEW ARE GOING
description: At the 1984 World's Fair there are the usual thrills and chills, jazz and bluegrass, spicy Cajun cuisine and colorful parades, but the mixture has paled beside the furor outside.

title: POP: 'MIXED BAG' CONCERT
description: THE Beacon Theater was the setting on Saturday of an unusual four-hour concert featuring Kate and Anna McGarrigle, Janis Ian, Maria Muldaur and Suzanne Vega, four acts who represent different aspects of the folk-oriented pop music that has fallen out of commercial favor in recent years. The event was the second ''Mixed Bag'' concert for which the host was the local disk jockey, Pete Fornatale, who has a popular radio show devoted to rekindling interest in the best of 60's and 70's folk-pop music.

title: MUSIC: SOPRANO SINGS WORKS FROM HER NATIVE CHINA
description: -Chuang Chao is a tasteful and conscientious musician with a small, bright, somewhat unsteady voice. Miss Chao's Saturday evening concert, her debut, at Carnegie Recital Hall was most successful when she concentrated on material from her native China - particularly in four ambitious recent compositions by G. S. Lau, P. K. Shen, T. Huang, and D. T. Tang.

title: CREDIT UNIONS' INSURANCE PLAN
description: The chairman of a powerful House committee is blocking a move by the nation's credit unions to greatly bolster the size of their deposit-insurance fund, which all sides agree is in need of a cash infusion.

title: NORMAN AND ZOELLER IN TIE AT OPEN
description: Greg Norman, the Australian known best for his 300-yard drives, sank a 40- foot par putt at the 72d and last regulation hole of the 84th United States Open today to tie Fuzzy Zoeller and set up an 18-hole playoff for the championship Monday at Winged Foot's West course.

title: OFFICIAL UNDERMINING OF PRESS CREDIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A 40-FOOTER FOR HISTORY
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: IN THE PARK, JUNE'S THE TIME FOR WEDDINGS
description: Twenty couples in white walked through the ornate Vanderbilt Gates at various times on Saturday afternoon and descended a broad flight of stone steps to have their wedding pictures taken among the trees, fountains and blossoms of the Conservatory Garden.

title: WORKERS' SUITS AGAINST MONSANTO GOING TO TRIAL
description: The first of 170 lawsuits by workers seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in compensation for medical problems that they say resulted from exposure to dioxin go to trial Monday in Federal District Court here.

title: Fund Is Established To Aid Boston Ballet
description: The Boston Ballet and the Permanent Charity Fund of Boston have announced the establishment of the E. Virginia Williams Endowment Fund to honor the late Miss Williams, who founded the Boston Ballet and was a leader in the regional ballet movement.

title: ADVERTISING
