description: Y.& R. Retains Motorola Ads

title: 'THAT FUNNY SOUND'
description: I T was a quiet Sunday morning at the barns, handlers walking

title: Washington Watch; Continental Deal Expected
description: WASHINGTON

title: Issues by U.S. and States Scheduled
description: Treasury financing this week consists of the regular auction of bills today, followed by Wednesday's $8.5 billion sale of two-year notes. On Tuesday, securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce a major package of auctions for the following week.

title: GTE Sprint Resolves Case Involving Claim
description: Among the eight cases resolved in May by the ad industry's self-regulatory program was one that involved the current hot competition in long- distance telephone service. In this particular case, GTE Sprint Communications, which is served by J. Walter Thompson, San Francisco, was advertising savings of up to 50 percent with its Sprint service.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Automatix Inc., manufacturers of robots and artificial vision systems, named Michael J. Cronin president and chief executive officer. Mr. Cronin, a founder of the company, was also elected a director.

title: PARTIES IN POWER SUFFER REVERSES IN EUROPE VOTING
description: Government parties, both of the left and right, suffered defeats in balloting for the European Parliament in the 10 member countries of the Common Market, according to computer projections and partial results released today.

title: REV. WALTER TAYLOR, EX-MAYOR IN JERSEY LED DRIVE FOR RIGHTS
description: The Rev. Walter Scott Taylor, a civil- rights leader and the first black mayor of Englewood, N.J., died of cancer Saturday at Englewood Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: SWEEP BREWERS SERIES
description: Tom Brookens's two-run triple sparked a five-run fifth inning that carried the Detroit Tigers to a 7-4 victory today over the Milwaukee Brewers and a sweep of their three- game series.

title: MOBILE PHONE USERS JOIN THE CELLULAR GENERATION
description: David Paul was a college sophomore tinkering with electronics when he installed a car phone in his year- old Chevy convertible in 1958, and he has not been without one since.

title: Berenyi Bows in Debut As Met
description: If first impressions count, Bruce Berenyi looks like the fifth starter the Mets have needed this season.

title: Minnesota Democrats Back State Official in Senate Bid
description: In a 22 1/2-hour convention, Secretary of State Joan A. Growe defeated Representative James L. Oberstar on the 19th ballot today for the Democratic- Farmer-Labor Party's endorsement to challenge Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Republican.

title: Midwest Flood Hazards Continue to Build Up By The Associated Press
description: Bands of thunderstorms dumped more rain yesterday across the sodden upper Midwest, causing new flooding in South Dakota and Wisconsin, while thousands of acres of farmland and towns remained under water along the swollen Missouri.

title: POLISH VOTE QUIET IN FIRST ELECTION SINCE MARTIAL LAW
description: Balloting for local councils was held throughout Poland today in an atmosphere of calm, but with few signs of public enthusiasm for this first Polish election since martial law was imposed in December 1981.

title: FEAR AND BRUTALITY IN A CREEDMOOR WARD
description: No one remembers exactly when it began. But the fear, the beatings, the brutality in a special ward of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens did not end until after a mentally ill patient had died while bound in a cloth straitjacket, his throat crushed.

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT TAKES LAND TO GIVE LAND
description: LEGALITY VS. MORALITY TO the Editor: Contrary to the suggestion of your editorial, there is nothing at all startling about the Supreme Court's decision to support the expropriation of private property at the expense of individual rights.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Placards Replace Father's Day Cards
description: Striking a different note from the

title: A Dollar Saved . . .
description: Some folded money tumbled from

title: Lorimar Adds Official For Advertising Group
description: Sid Marshall, who until last November was chairman of the Los Angeles office of Young & Rubicam-Dentsu (now DYR), has joined Lorimar Productions as senior vice president responsible for supervising its new Advertising Group.

title: Jon Eric Epstein Wed To Laurie Ellen Carver
description: The marriage of Laurie Ellen Carver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Carver of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Jon Eric Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Epstein of Roslyn, L.I., took place yesterday at the Danbury (Conn.) Hilton Hotel.

title: CABARET: BY NANCY HARROW
description: NANCY HARROW, a singer who ties a repertory of lusty blues and old vaudeville songs to an unusual assortment of theater and pop songs, has been something of a will-o'-the-wisp in cabarets and jazz clubs in the last two decades. She pops up briefly somewhere and then disappears, only to turn up somewhere else after a lapse of time.

title: A PARTNER FOR BRITISH AEROSPACE
description: After a month of talks, British Aerospace said last week that it was not interested in a merger bid from Thorn EMI, the consumer electronics and home entertainment company.

title: No Headline
description: NIMBLE CHARACTERS The characters used in Chinese writing are particularly graceful and inventive symbols that, in the hands of a master calligrapher, become high art. In the hands and feet of a dancer, they can also be transformed into art of a different kind, as the performances at 7 and 8:30 o'clock tonight at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, will set about demonstrating.

title: Continental, Penn Inquiry
description: Federal grand juries in Chicago and Oklahoma City have stepped up investigations of dealings between the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and the defunct Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: Advertising; A Laugh Attracts Attention
description: P EOPLE are beginning to talk about that woman in commercials with the easy, spontaneous and sexy laugh. She was first on radio for Molson's beer and American Express. Since May the warm chuckle has also been coming from television sets, since Molson, a Canadian entry, began using television advertising.

title: MUSIC: NAUMBURG PLAYS IN DAMROSCH PARK
description: TO be outdoors on a cool summer evening is a delight; hearing pleasant music well played is another. Many listeners find that the two go down well mixed, and an appreciative crowd of them turned out for the Naumburg Chamber Orchestra's concert in Damrosch Park on Saturday evening.

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT TAKES LAND TO GIVE LAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavia Wins Basketball Title
description: Yugoslavia, the defending Olympic champion, won the four-nation Kirin World men's basketball tournament today with a 64-50 victory over the University of Arkansas.

title: ARCHDIOCESE SEEKS ACCORD WITH CITY
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is negotiating with New York City to resolve church concerns that a mayoral ban on discrimination against homosexuals by agencies doing business with the city may violate church teachings.

title: STAGE: 'FOUND A PEANUT' AT THE PUBLIC
description: THOUGH Donald Margulies's ''Found a Peanut'' is only an inviting, unfulfilled shell of a play, it's full of goodies for its cast. The eight actors at the Public's Anspacher Theater - all in their 20's and 30's - get to romp about on a concrete blacktop, masquerading as very young children (ages 5 to 14) of Brooklyn, 1962.

title: No Headline
description: BRIEFS

title: The Zoo Story
description: Last year, the Humane Society of the United States called the Atlanta Zoo one of the 10 worst in the country. This year, it was suspended from the American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums, which sets standards for zoos.

title: WILLIAM LEE, UNION CHIEFTAIN IN CHICAGO FOR DECADES, DIES
description: William A. Lee, president of the Chicago Federation of Labor since 1946, and a force in Chicago politics, died of apparent cardiac arrest Saturday night at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 89 years old.

title: Oregon Woman Is Convicted Of Killing Child and Hurting 2
description: A woman nine months pregnant with her fourth child was convicted early today of shooting her 7-year-old daughter to death and wounding her other two children.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1984

title: DANCE: JUNE ANDERSON AND COMPANY
description: WHEREAS many young choreographers just babble away in their dances, June Anderson may have employed an unnecessarily limited movement vocabulary in the works that June Anderson and Company offered Friday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater.

title: BALLET: TORONTO FESTIVAL OFFERS NATIONAL BALLET
description: The Toronto International Festival, a monthlong celebration marking the Canadian city's 150th anniversary, is currently under way with a large variety of dance and music events from 15 countries.

title: REAGAN HAILS ATHLETES IN GAMES FOR DISABLED
description: President Reagan opened the International Games for the Disabled today by hailing the assembled athletes as world champions of the human heart.

title: Morocco Units Advance Against Polisario Front
description: Moroccan troops pushing eastward in their eight-year war against Polisario Front guerrillas are now in full control of Hawza, a deserted village once held by the Polisario Front as its provisional capital.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Traders Facing Lively Period;  Treasury Sets Record Sale
description: After a two-week respite from Treasury note and bond financings, the credit markets are again facing a flurry of auctions that will test the mettle of investors and securities dealers.

title: GOODEN A MODEL OF POISE
description: ST. LOUIS D WIGHT GOODEN, the Mets' 19-year-old fastball pitcher, leaned back in the visitors' dugout the other night and thought about the toughest hitter he had faced so far.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.59

title: ANGRY SIKHS STAGE RALLIES ACROSS INDIA
description: Thousands of Sikhs staged demonstrations across India today to protest the storming of the Golden Temple by army troops. A military source said nine Sikh soldiers reportedly mutinied in the Bijnor area, 85 miles northeast of the Indian capital.

title: VENEZUELA CONFIDENT ON DEBT
description: Venezuela's new Government is confident that its financial crisis is less acute than those of other Latin American debtor nations and believes it can be resolved without the involvement of the International Monetary Fund.

title: BALLET: SUSAN JAFFE IN 'OTHER DANCES'
description: THE AMERICAN BALLET THEATER left them cheering Saturday afternoon, in the next to last performance of its 1984 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. And what drew the loudest cheers from the audience was an exciting, beautifully conceived performance by Susan Jaffe in Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances.''

title: Yanks Shift Ellis to Minors
description: In Yankee country, the favored euphemism for dismissal is ''reassignment'' and yesterday Sammy Ellis joined the long list of coaches and managers reassigned within George Steinbrenner's organization. Ellis, who has shared the duties of pitching coach with Jeff Torborg this season, will now travel through the minor league system assessing young talent.

title: OUTDOORS: ANGLING- HUNTING BLEN
description: E XPERIENCED freshwater fly fishermen planning to try for tarpon, bonefish or permit on Florida's vast and shimmering shallows, or flats, should be aware that they are entering a totally new discipline.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He'd never had so much as an aspirin in his life because he was never sick in all the time I had him.'' - Woody Stephens, trainer of Swale. (C13:1.)

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: INSTITUTE SEES MOVE TO INDIANA AS A WAY OUT OF FINANCIAL WOES
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - When the president of the Hudson Institute announced last month that the research organization would pack up its scenarios of nuclear war and move to Indianapolis, he explained that he welcomed getting away from ''the power centers of New York and Washington.''

title: Nicaragua, Pro and Contra
description: Though President Reagan wouldn't agree, Congress would do him a service by ending his anomalous overt covert war against Nicaragua. From its inception in 1981, this operation has affronted principle and sense. Yet for a variety of reasons, Congress has been unwilling to deny funds to anti-leftist rebels harassing a hostile Marxist regime. It's worth reviewing those reasons.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article published yesterday from London on a debate over the use of firearms by the British police incorrectly reported that Steven Waldorf, a television film editor shot by the police in a case of mistaken identity, had died. Mr. Waldorf survived the attack. The article also misspelled his first name.

title: U.S. ADVISERS DEBATE WARNING ON NEW PAIN PILLS
description: One month after the Food and Drug Administration approved the nonprescription sale of the pain reliever ibuprofen. medical specialists and researchers are voicing concern about its safety when it is used without a physician's supervision.

title: JAILED POLITICIAN'S PARTY HALTS TALKS WITH URUGUAY MILITARY
description: One of the country's two dominant parties today broke off all political transition talks with the ruling military until the Government releases the party's presidential candidate and his son.

title: A Kiss at 12,500 Ft., A Leap Into Wedlock
description: Michael Ince and Loraine Kraemer took their wedding vows in an airplane at 12,500 feet, then parachuted with their eight-member wedding party to their reception.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Transworld Fills 2 New Top Posts

title: Glemp Urges Release Of Political Prisoners
description: Cardinal Jozef Glemp has called on the Polish authorities to release prisoners held for political opposition.

title: EARL JONES: 'MYSTERY MAN' OF DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON FO UR years ago, Earl Jones received the special treatment reserved for outstanding high school basketball players, especially those who are almost 7 feet tall. The recruiters were out in force and invitations to visit colleges were plentiful, despite his questionable grades.

title: A Prison Instructor in Jersey Charged With Aiding Escape
description: A Trenton State Prison employee has been charged with aiding the attempted escape of three inmates Saturday, correction officials said today.

title: Question Box
description: Ray Corio QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game that has less than a minute remaining, Team A deliberately substitutes an extra player in an attempt to tie the score. What is the ruling?

title: WHAT DO WE WANT IN NICARAGUA?
description: Did Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit to Managua mean that the Administration has changed course in Central America? Or was it only a tactical blip in a continuing confrontation? In fact, the visit probably signified much less than many observers would like to think. Even now, the Administration is still not sure whether containment or elimination is the best - and most feasible - way to deal with the Sandinista regime.

title: BILL LIBBY
description: Bill Libby, who wrote dozens of books on sports figures, died of a heart attack at his home Saturday.

title: Tretyak Retires
description: Vladislav Tretyak, the outstanding goaltender who won three Olympic gold medals in a 17-year career of international hockey, has retired, the Soviet press agency, Tass, said today.

title: NEW LEADER FOR CANADA: JOHN NAPIER TURNER
description: On Sept. 10, 1975, John Napier Turner, then Canada's Finance Minister, stalked out of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's office in what is recalled now as grim anger. The reasons for his resignation are a mystery that neither man has fully explained.

title: CENTRAL BANKS ASK U.S. DEFICIT CUT
description: The United States must take immediate action to reduce its budget deficit, the Bank for International Settlements said today in its latest annual report. The deficit, the report stressed, has become a threat to economic recovery throughout the world.

title: ALIENS BILL NEARS REALITY
description: Why, after so much delay, did a comprehensive immigration bill suddenly start rolling through the House of Representatives?

title: ON THE STRAW-HAT CIRCUIT: OF MOOSE HEADS, SNAKES AND SUMMERTIME STARS
description: They have been painting the barn red and white. They have been chasing skunks from the stage, clearing bird nests from the spotlights, scraping mildew from costumes, and very gingerly, in the manner of city slickers, shooing snakes out of the yard.

title: MISS ZIMRING, MISS BERUBE EARN GYMNASTIC BERTHS
description: Valerie Zimring of Los Angeles and Michelle Berube of Birmingham, Mich., won positions on the two-member United States Olympic rhythmic gymnastic team today.

title: 'GREED' AND 'FEAR' SLANT G.O.P. CONVENTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer of Times Fiber Elevated to Presidency
description: Colin J. O'Brien, executive vice president and assistant to the president of Times Fiber Communications Inc., has been named president and chief executive. The appointment is effective July 1, the company said.

title: Futures/Options; Volume Is a Sign Of Concern
description: A NYONE who wants to know what areas of the economy are of prime concern to those in commerce and industry needs only to look at the futures trading volume, because uncertainty is what lures both hedgers and speculators into these markets.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Elder Statesman There probably aren't too many basketball fans around these days who even recognize the name, and many of those who do undoubtedly assume he died years ago.

title: Linda R. Wolfson Is Married to Michael E. Fields
description: Linda Racquel Wolfson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Wolfson of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Eric Fields, a son of Ellen Kislak of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Lawrence A. Fields of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Abner Bergman performed the ceremony at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Bridge: E
description: Judging the right moment to defend doubled part-score contracts requires a great deal of experience. Both West players misjudged slightly in this department on the diagramed deal, from the recent final of the Harter Cup, a double knockout event from which life masters are excluded.

title: RECESS PLAN FOR STATE SENATE OPPOSED
description: The Republicans who control the State Senate say they plan to recess for the summer this week, but Governor Cuomo and the Assembly Speaker, both Democrats, say that such a move would leave a great deal of unfinished work.

title: Swiss Unemployment
description: Switzerland's unemployment rate in May was 1.2 percent, unchanged from April but up from nine-tenths of 1 percent a year earlier, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said Friday. There were 35,565 people out of work, up from 33,520 in April and 26,355 a year earlier.

title: WEST GERMANY'S FEARFUL TOOLMAKERS
description: Efforts in the United States to limit imports of machine tools have created a mood of anxiety in West Germany's powerful machine-tool industry, and that mood has been exacerbated by recent American moves toward protectionism in steel and copper.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Peripatetic Backman After moving his household nine times in his eight years in organized baseball (not counting between-season trans-continental treks to his permanent home in Oregon and then back to Florida for spring training) Wally Backman, the Mets' second baseman, has apparently had it with packing and unpacking.

title: China Nuclear Pact Is Stalled
description: A nuclear exchange agreement that was the high point of President Reagan's visit to China has been put on hold because of intelligence reports that China is supplying Pakistan with nuclear weapons technology.

title: Beil Wins L.I. Golf
description: Randy Beil of Plandome scored a 7-and-6 victory over Dr. Steve Frantz in the 36-hole final of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship today at the Huntington Crescent Club. In defeating the 47-year-old cardiovascular surgeon, Beil regained the title he won in 1981.

title: Dr. Nerenstone Wed to Dr. Paul Cohen
description: Dr. Stacy Ruth Nerenstone, a daughter of Marc Nerenstone of Washington and Benita L. Strait of Iowa City, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Jay Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Cohen of New York. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Stamford, Conn.

title: AUDIT CALLS OHIO PLANT MISHANDLED
description: Mismanagement in construction of the stalled Zimmer nuclear power plant is responsible for costs ranging from $1.3 billion to the full $1.72 billion spent on the project so far, according to a management audit ordered by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.

title: A Nicaraguan Leader Visits Soviet Union
description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, head of the Nicaraguan junta, arrived in Moscow today on a working visit, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Nucor's Chief Executive Adds Chairman's Title

title: Japanese Price Data
description: Wholesale prices in Japan rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May from April but fell one-tenth of 1 percent from May 1983, the Bank of Japan said Friday. Analysts at the Japanese central bank said the rise was partly fueled by a weakened yen, which caused import prices to increase. But they said the yen was stronger in May than it was a year earlier, leading to the year-to- year drop in wholesale prices.

title: Jewish Terrorist Trial Opens in Jerusalem
description: Twenty-two Jews accused of committing terrorist acts against Arabs in the occupied West Bank went on trial in Jerusalem today after a courtroom protest against the presence of an Arab lawyer.

title: JOHN PAUL STRESSES PRIESTLY OBEDIENCE
description: Pope John Paul II, celebrating mass at an airport here 10 miles from the center of the most troublesome dissident movement of the Roman Catholic church, reminded all priests today of their duty of obedience to their bishops and through them to the Pope, Bishop of Rome.

title: ABROAD AT HOME ; Respect For Law?
description: Does the Reagan Administration show contempt for the rule of law? A sharp denial of that charge has come from a distinguished legal figure in the Administration. Paul M. Bator, a Harvard law professor now serving as Deputy Solicitor General, addressed the question in a speech to the American Law Institute. His analysis deserves reflection.

title: VENEZUELANS SEEK TO EASE STRAIN WITH CUBA
description: Venezuela's new Social Democratic Government has decided to seek better relations with Cuba, according to officials here.

title: TEMPLE RAID: PERIL AHEAD?
description: Eleven days after Indian soldiers fought their way into the Golden Temple in Amritsar to root out a band of Sikh holy men and gunmen, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi seems to be riding a wave of popularity outside Punjab. Six months before an expected national election, she has acted swiftly and decisively, snatching from her political foes the argument that she was weak and vacillating in the face of an incipient secessionist threat to India's geographic integrity.

title: SOVIET SAID TO LEAD U.S. BY 8,000 WARHEADS
description: The Soviet Union has moved ahead of the United States in numbers of nuclear warheads, according to a new Defense Department estimate.

title: Phils Take Series From Cubs
description: Ozzie Virgil got four hits, including a home run, and knocked in three runs today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 9-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs and a sweep of their four-game series.

title: BROADER MEDICAL VIEW URGED FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: With concern over AIDS dominating health care for homosexuals, authorities in the field gathered in Manhattan over the weekend and called for increased attention to a broader range of physical and mental ills afflicting homosexuals.

title: The U.N. Today June 18, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ART: BATTERED VENICE BIENNALE SHOWS WILL TO LIVE
description: VENICE THOUGH now approaching its 100th year and more than once given up for dead, the Venice Biennale shares with certain historic reprobates an irrepressible will to live. Much battered by the student upheavals of 1968, during which it opened in a virtual state of siege, it took a long time to recover its nerve and an even longer time to recover any kind of international status. But just a few days ago the 41st edition was inaugurated and it turned out to be larger, though not necessarily better, than ever before.

title: Rep. Hansen Says He Won't Resign
description: Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, said Saturday that he will not resign or abandon his re-election campaign regardless of the outcome of his appeal of convictions for failing to report $334,000 in financial dealings.

title: BUSY PAN AM NEWSSTAND
description: Someone bought Esquire. A Glamour went. Then a Byte. Time. Harvard Business Review. The Irish Echo. Penthouse. TV Guide. The African Sun.

title: PESCAROLO CAR WINS LE MANS
description: Henri Pescarolo of France and Klaus Ludwig of West Germany overcame ignition problems with their Porsche 956 turbo to win the 52d Le Mans 24- hour endurance race today. It was the fourth victory in the race for Pescarolo and the second for Ludwig.

title: WORLD SWIM MARK
description: Alex Baumann of Sudbury, Ontario, shattered the world record for the 400- meter individual medley today during preliminary heats at Canada's 1984 Esso Cup Olympic team swim trials.

title: Force of a Hit-Run Accident Injures 43 on Chartered Bus
description: A state patrol officer said tday there was little chance of finding the motorist who forced a chartered bus full of Texas teen-agers and their chaperones off a southeast Colorado highway, injuring 43 people.

title: An Afghan Accuses Soviet of Slaughter
description: An Afghan resistance leader here has accused the Soviet Union of wholesale slaughter in Afghanistan. His statements amounted to a rare acknowledgement of serious losses inflicted by Soviet troops.

title: LLAMA OWNERS' LOBBY IS SET TO FIGHT IMPORTS
description: Members of Congress have been cowed on occasion, buffaloed more than once, and steered a lot by lobbyists. Now they are about to be llamaed.

title: A MAN AND A WOMAN FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN EAST SIDE HOME
description: A man and a woman were found shot to death last night in an Upper East side apartment in what the police say were drug-related killings.

title: ENDOWING DEMOCRACY
description: In a classic example of the old saw ''penny wise and pound foolish,'' the House of Representatives voted last month to eliminate a proposed $31 million appropriation for the fledgling National Endowment for Democracy. If the House is imitated by the Senate when it votes this week, the endowment will die and with it will go a promising approach to solving one of the most vexing dilemmas confronting American foreign policy.

title: Prisoner Admits Plot To Kill Federal Judge
description: An imprisoned drug trafficker convicted of obstructing justice in the killing of a Federal judge has pleaded guilty to plotting to kill a Federal prosecutor who was heading a series of drug investigations.

title: HOUSE PUTS A HOLD ON ARMS PROJECTS
description: Playing the middle against both ends is a proven political maneuver. Using it, a small group of legislators is turning the House of Representatives into a major force on arms control policy.

title: MAYORS APPROVE BUDGET MEASURES
description: A committee of the Democrat-dominated United States Conference of Mayors signaled strong bipartisan concern over the Federal deficit Sunday by endorsing pet Republican budget-balancing measures, including special veto authority for the President.

title: A FIRST IN PEKING: DINNER AT A KEY LEADER'S HOME
description: Hu Yaobang, a diminutive man, sat on the edge of his dinner chair running over a list of some Americans he has met. Most of them, as it turned out, have been American Presidents.

title: Turf Race Won By Hero's Honor
description: Hero's Honor, ridden by Jerry Bailey, scored a front-running victory in the $217,700 Bowling Green Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: SCHOOL IN QUEENS TRIES TO PUT FUN IN THE CLASS
description: Almost every weekday morning, Stephen Kaliscuk gets up at 6:30, dresses hurriedly and rushes through breakfast so he won't be late for the school bus that takes him from his home in Ridgewood, Queens, to Intermediate School 227 in East Elmhurst.

title: REAGAN SAID TO SEEK CUTOFF IF AID ABROAD GOES FOR ABORTIONS
description: President Reagan is determined to change United States policy to eliminate aid to international population control programs that practice or advocate abortion, White House officials said today.

title: Bill Would Ban 'Greenmail'
description: Another bill has been introduced in Congress to ban the corporate practice of ''greenmail,'' in which a company attempts to foil a takeover by paying more than the market price for a block of its own stock.

title: 2 Columbia Students InjuredIn Fall From Fraternity House
description: Two Columbia University students were injured yesterday when they accidentally fell from the fourth floor of a fraternity building near the campus, according to the police.

title: Why Is E.R.A. 'All Chowdered Up'?
description: Six months ago, when Governor Cuomo revived the idea of an equal rights amendment to the New York Constitution (a previous try was rejected in a 1975 referendum), Senate Majority Leader Warren Anderson said he'd have ''no problem putting the E.R.A. to a vote.'' This week, however, Mr. Anderson found a problem.

title: 'BUDDENBROOKS' SERIES FROM WEST GERMANY
description: THOMAS MANN'S ''Buddenbrooks'' has been transformed into a 10 1/2-hour television series as stately, awesome and penetrating as the novel. The West German production, made with some financing from French and Polish television entities, begins a weekly run on WNET-TV tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: THE LITTLE RAILROAD THAT DOES
description: As short lines go, the Batten Kill Railroad is surely one of the shortest.

title: USA Today Promotes President to Publisher
description: Cathleen Black has been promoted to publisher from president at USA Today, the Gannett Company's national newspaper.

title: New Meaning Emerges From a Fading Sign
description: Hank Roden, an aide to Representative Bill Green, reports that just north of City Hall he saw a store with a sign that once said MUSIC SHOP. But the sign, failing in its old age, has worn down to SIC SHOP.

title: U.S. Imposing a Stiffer Rule On Exposure to Ethylene Gas
description: Saying studies suggest that ethylene oxide ''is a potential occupational carcinogen,'' the Reagan Administration has put stricter curbs on workers' exposure to the gas.

title: IN DEFENSE OF ANIMALS OF NORTH
description: Frequently an event occurs here to emphasize this city's emergence from its recent wilderness origins.

title: STUDY INDICATES JOB PROGRAM IMPROVED BLACK YOUTHS' PAY
description: Black teen-agers who worked part- time under a Government-subsidized job program later moved into the labor market and got improved employment and earnings, according to a study by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation of New York, which managed the program.

title: RENT LIMITS ON NEWER APARTMENTS
description: Next month, the first 1,800 of nearly 30,000 New York City apartments built since 1974 - housing about 100,000 people - are to lose their protection under the rent stabilization rules unless the current law is changed. This prospect has drawn tenants and landlords to Albany to lobby state lawmakers.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1984 International
description: Voting for the European Parliament dealt defeats for both the left and right, with the French left apparently the biggest loser, according to computer projections and partial results. (Page A1, Column 6.) Poles seemed unenthusiastic as they voted for local councils throughout the country in the first election since martial law was imposed in December 1981. The atmosphere was calm, and the clandestine calls in Warsaw for demonstrations were overhwelmingly ignored. (A1:4.)

title: Indian Point 3 Is Restarted
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant has returned to operation after an automatic shutdown caused early Saturday by a broken valve, the New York Power Authority said today. An authority spokesman, Janet Wollak, said the valve was repaired and the plant was returned to service late Saturday. The problem was caused by ''normal wear and tear,'' the authority said.

title: The Poet's Corner: 25 Cents a Reading
description: Before the first drops of rain fell

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT TAKES LAND TO GIVE LAND
description: To the Editor:

title: SIPE UNLIKELY HERO IN GENERALS' ASCENT
description: When Donald Trump went hunting through the National Football League for an available quarterback last fall, the director of operations for the United States Football League, Peter Hadhazy, strongly recommended Brian Sipe to the Generals' new owner.

title: Homer Drives In $1 Million Prize
description: Ann Sommers has not been to a Baltimore Orioles' game in 25 years.

title: New Jersey Democrats Finsh Delegate Selection
description: New Jersey's Democrats have concluded selection of the delegation to the national convention in July, electing Representative Frank J. Guarini as chairman.

title: RIGHTETTI CUTS FINGER AND WATCHES AS YANKEES LOSE
description: A freakish accident in the bullpen, when Dave Righetti sliced his left index finger on a water cooler, may have cost the Yankees yesterday's game against the Orioles and left them without their star reliever with six games against the Detroit Tigers in the next 10 days.

title: DEBATE ON PENTAGON COMPUTER PLAN FOCUSES ON MILITARY'S EFFECT ON SOCIETY
description: A Defense Department plan to spend $600 million over five years to develop a new generation of computer-based military systems has become the focus of a debate among a number of senior computer scientists.

title: Amy Penzell, a Designer, Marries Steven M. Cohen
description: Amy Penzell and Steven M. Cohen, graduates of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Penzell, in Sands Point, L.I. Cantor Benjamin Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: EMBRYOS' FUTURE IN QUESTION
description: The deaths last year of a couple who supplied two human embryos frozen for implantation procedures have raised the question of whether the embryos should be destroyed or raised to maturity and receive a share of the couple's estate.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Athletics
description: International Games for the Disabled , at four sites on Long Island: Hofstra University in Hempstead; Mitchel Field in Uniondale; Nassau Community College in Garden City and Eisenhower Park in East Meadow. The first day of competition for the 1,800 athletes from 53 countries includes powerlifting at Nassau Community College, 7 A.M.; bocci at Nassau Community College, 8:30 A.M.; swimming at Hofstra, 9 A.M.; lawn bowling at Eisenhower Park, 9 A.M.; soccer at Mitchel Field, 7 P.M.; basketball at Nassau Community College, 7 P.M., and cross-country at Eisenhower Park, 9 A.M. Baseball Yankees vs.

title: 'COTTON CLUB' SUITS DECIDED
description: The director Francis Ford Coppola and the producer Robert Evans were ordered by a Federal judge today to share control of ''The Cotton Club,'' ending a monthlong court battle over the film.

title: UNHELPFUL 'HYSTERIA' OVER NUCLEAR ARMS USE
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERCROWED BY CHOICE
description: That the poor among us live in crowded conditions is a truism, not a discovery. But some weeks ago, a very senior housing official in the Reagan Administration offered a novel theory about this phenomenon as it relates to the more than 20 million Hispanic people in the United States.

title: COMMUNISTS GAIN FIRST VICTORY IN ITALY
description: Italy's Communist Party has scored its first nationwide election victory, narrowly edging the dominant Christian Democratic Party in voting for the European Parliament, official returns showed today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; MTV Networks Files For Offering of Shares
description: MTV Networks Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for an initial public offering of 5,125,000 shares of common stock at a projected price of $16 to $18 a share. The company operates the MTV music channel for cable television, and Nicklodeon, a children's cable service.

title: ZOELLER'S ZANIES: 'TAKE THAT, SHARK'
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: Whirlpool, Litton
description: The Whirlpool Corporation and Litton Industries said they had stopped negotiations toward the purchase by Whirlpool of Litton's Microwave Cooking Products division.

title: Rangers 6, Angels 2
description: Frank Tanana, backed by a four-run first inning, combined with Dave Schmidt on a seven-hitter for Texas. Tanana (8-6) was in command in the eight innings he pitched, giving up five hits and the first California run on a single by Doug DiCinces in the eighth.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Hammaker Progresses
description: Atlee Hammaker , the San Francisco pitcher who led the National League in earned run average last season before coming down with arm problems, has passed his first test on the road back. Undergoing a rehabilitation program with the Giants' farm team in Phoenix, Hammaker pitched Saturday night for the first time this season.

title: MAJOR U.S. ROLE SET FOR EDINBURGH
description: American cultural organizations will play a larger role than ever before in the 1984 three- week Edinburgh International Festival, according to festival officials, with the Smithsonian Institution mounting a number of major events.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Per Class A common share. c-Per Class B common share.

title: TransCanada Gets Wessely
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire the Wessely Energy Corporation of Dallas from the Rockefeller Group for $100 million.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. This is the opener of a three-game series that could tell a great deal about whether the Mets are a genuine threat for the pennant.

title: Yankees Appoint Connor as Coach
description: Continuing what has become a way of life for their coaches, the Yankees made one coaching change official today and announced another. There was disagreement among club personnel whether or not the changes were a possible prelude to the return of Billy Martin as manager in the near future.

title: IS THE PEN MIGHTIER THAN THE MOUSE?
description: PERSONAL computing is filled with the unfamiliar, often couched in everyday terms in an attempt to allay the potential user's fears. Mice, windows, bugs and similar comfortingly commonplace words abound, although in the context of computing none of them resemble their real- world counterparts. Electronic rodents have wheels instead of feet; windows grow, shrink and vanish on the video screen, and bugs are but ethereal electronic periods or quotation marks.

title: AIR FORCE AGAIN REFUSES TO ALLOW A CRITIC OF ITS PRACTICES TO TESTIFY
description: For the second time this year the Air Force has refused to permit a high-ranking civil servant to give official testimony to Congress on Air Force purchasing and auditing practices.

title: STRICT U.S. RULING TO SLASH PROFITS OF BANKS THAT LENT TO ARGENTINA
description: A number of the nation's major banks with loans to Argentina will be required to report substantially lower earnings because of a hotly disputed interpretation of accounting rules by Federal bank regulators.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income including a gain of $1,207,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change and a pretax gain of $7.5 million from the disposition of certain marine equipment.

title: ROUNDFIELD TRADED TO PISTONS
description: The Detroit Pistons, seeking help at power forward, obtained Dan Roundfield, one of the league's best, in a trade yesterday with the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Jim Hegan, a Top Catcher Who Also Coached Yankees
description: Jim Hegan, one of the finest defensive catchers in baseball history, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 63.

title: The U.N. Today June 19, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Argentine Debt Talks
description: A senior international monetary official said tonight that Economics Minister Bernardo Grinspun of Argentina was sending a ''technical mission'' to Washington later this week to continue negotiations with the International Monetary Fund about his country's debt.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Continental Bancorp Inc. , Philadelphia, said the Federal Reserve had approved its proposed merger with United Penn Corp.

title: Five in El Salvador Get 3 Ye i M
description: Five former national guardsmen convicted in the murders of four American churchwomen in 1980 were sentenced today to the maximum penalty of 30 years in prison.

title: KOHL RULES OUT BONN SHAKE-UP AFTER VOTE SETBACK
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he was ''not satisfied'' with the poor showing of his Christian Democratic Party in the elections to the European Parliament.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $504,000. c-Net income.

title: British Union Leader Hurt in Yorkshire Melee
description: The leader of the Britain's National Union of Mineworkers, Arthur Scargill, suffered a head injury today in a melee in Yorkshire that was described by the police as the most violent confrontation of this country's 15-week-old coal strike.

title: SECURITY TAG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HART FORCES SUFFER 2 LOSSES IN PLATFORM-WRITING SESSION
description: Gary Hart's lieutenant on the Democratic platform committee warned its drafters today that Hart supporters might lose their enthusiasm for the national ticket if some of his views were not reflected in the platform.

title: THE STANDARDS OF EVIDENCE IN BOOK PUBLISHING
description: What are the responsibilities of book publishers in a democratic society for maintaining standards of evidence, proof and disclosure in the books they publish?

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months results are translated at the rate of 226 yen equals $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of April 27, 1984. The results for the year-earlier periods are translated at the rate of 243 yen equals $1.00.

title: TO SOURCE OR NOT TO SOURCE: THAT IS THE QUESTION
description: ''This is just between us, you understand, and I wouldn't want you to quote this, but if you looked into it you might find that the rules and etiquette governing relations between Government officials and journalists have been very strange for decades and are probably getting worse.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 19, 1984

title: SATELLITE DISCOVERS LOST MAYAN RUINS
description: sensing data has led to the discovery of the ruins of two ancient Mayan cities hidden in the jungle of southern Mexico, according to a report by the Earth Satellite Corporation.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $155,000 for the quarter and $569,000 for the 9 months.

title: ZOELLER WINS OPEN BY 8 SHOTS FROM NORMAN
description: Fuzzy Zoeller surprised everybody, including himself, when he sank a 68- foot birdie putt on the second hole today for a 3-shot lead over Australia's Greg Norman. After that, the happy- go-lucky Zoeller had an easy afternoon, beating Norman by a record 8 shots and winning the 18-hole playoff for the 84th United States Open title on the West course at Winged Foot.

title: 30 Reported Injured In Rioting in Zimbabwe
description: More than 30 people were injured today when hundreds of supporters of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe stormed and burned the offices of the party of the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo.

title: MOSCOW'S HOSTILE MOOD
description: In the four months since Konstantin U. Chernenko became the Soviet leader, the Kremlin has settled into a hostile mood of a kind that has rarely been seen since the height of the cold war 30 years ago. Recent weeks have seen a sharp turning inward, a curtailment of ties with the West and a resort to something approaching rudeness in dealing with official visitors who have sought a return to compromise.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: When Mickey Arison, president of the Carnival Cruise Lines, decided to announce his company's advertising plans - including the biggest network TV buy in his industry - he was on the deck of the good ship Carnival docked in Nassau. That was on Saturday and word of that newsmaking event reached here yesterday by wireless.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: American Stores In F.T.C. Pact
description: The American Stores Company said it had entered into an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission under which the F.T.C. would not seek a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction barring its offer for the Jewel Companies.

title: Tragic Pattern
description: The sudden death Sunday morning of Swale, the colt who won this year's Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes, seemed to continue a pattern of tragedy among the best 3-year-olds of recent years. The last five 2-year-old champions were prevented by injury or illness from even running in the Derby as 3-year-olds, and the last two Belmont Stakes winners never raced again.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Dallas Reaches Accord On Convention Protests By United Press International
description: There will be protests against President Reagan at the Republican convention in Dallas in August, and there has been agreement on how they will be conducted.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: b-Including tax credits of $786,000 for the quarter and $1,221,000 for the 9 months. c-After a pretax provision of $3.9 million for restructuring operations.

title: New England Governors To Study Acid Rain Suit
description: Six New England governors today voted unanimously to create a committee to study the possibility of suing utilities responsible for acid rain.

title: Xerox Canada Inc. Sets Sale of Units
description: Xerox Canada Inc., a unit of the Xerox Corporation, said it had filed a final prospectus for the sale of 5.3 million units for $19 (Canadian) each, to raise a total of $100.7 million.

title: Radice Contracts
description: The Radice Corporation said it had signed contracts to sell the initial three office buildings in office parks in Fort Lauderdale and Clearwater, Fla., and in Pittsburgh.

title: CONRAIL: THE KIND OF BUYER THE GOVERNMENT SEEKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Navratilova, Mrs. Lloyd Gain
description: A week after completing the tennis Grand Slam at the French Open, Martina Navratilova opened her defense of the $175,000 Eastbourne women's title today with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Ann Kiyomura.

title: Continental's London Unit
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, a unit of the Continental Illinois Corporation, said it is talking with several international banks interested in acquiring Continental's merchant banking subsidiary in London.

title: ARE THE WHALES SAFE FROM THEIR FRIENDS?
description: THE passengers, several of them wearing ''Save the Whales'' T-shirts, filed aboard the whale-watching boat Dolphin V at the municipal pier in Provincetown, Mass., hoping that they would be lucky enough to see the animals at close quarters and watch them spout, leap out of the water, slap their huge tail flukes on the surface or raise them high in the air before making deep dives.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GAIN FOR PAPANDREOU SEEN IN GREECE
description: Despite predictions that it would suffer a humiliating defeat, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou gained a vote of confidence in the elections for the European Parliament.

title: SMILES, POLITESSE AND 400 WOMEN
description: As the polite applause for the Secretary of Defense subsided, Capt. Marilyn L. Carney, a Navy reserve officer, shot up her hand and asked him: ''When are you going to take the word 'manpower' out of Larry Korb's long and cumbersome title?''

title: 2 Due for Execution In Florida Get Reprieves
description: Two prisoners scheduled for execution Tuesday, the convicted killer of a convenience store clerk and a man convicted of killing two women, won reprieves today from Federal courts.

title: A BLACK PIONEER ON COAST
description: Born Dec. 29, 1917 in Calvert, Tex. . . . taciturn, moderate administrator . . . parents worked as sharecroppers . . . earned athletic scholarship to University of California at Los Angeles . . . quit college in 1940 to enter Los Angeles Police Academy . . . . . . rose to rank of lieutenant before leaving police force in 1961 to earn law degree, taking night classes at Southwestern University . . . practiced law briefly before becoming first black on Los Angeles City Council in 1963 . . . re- elected in 1967 . . . ran unsuccessfully for mayor in 1969 against Sam Yorty in campaign tinged by racism . . . defeated Mr. Yorty in 1973 to become city's first black mayor . . . created major redevelopment projects for downtown Los Angeles . . . vetoed Interior Secretary James G. Watt's plan for drilling off coast . . . helped bring 1984 Olympics to city . . . re-elected in 1977 and 1981 . . . sometimes criticized as reluctant to commit himself to controversial racial or political issues, which he defends as low- key management . . . was unsuccessful in bid for governor of California in 1982, losing to George Deukmejian, a Republican, by 52,295 out of 7.5 million votes cast . . . said in recent interview he was not ruling out running again for governor or mayor . . . married Ethel Mae Arnold in 1941 . . . two daughters.

title: Prudential Stake
description: Prudential-Bache Securities will soon acquire a 7.9 percent stake in Cortis & Carr, a Melbourne stockbroker, in the first such venture between American and Australian companies, Cortis & Carr said.

title: Supreme Court BacksPay TV Antitrust Trial
description: The Supreme Court today backed a lower-court ruling ordering a trial in a $60 million antitrust suit against Home Box Office and the Showtime Entertainment Corporation, two of the leading providers of pay-television entertainment.

title: GAF General Counsel No Stranger to Industry
description: Three years after he resigned as chairman of Reichhold Chemicals Inc. over what he says were ''differences in management policy,'' Edward E. Shea is back as a chemical industry executive. Yesterday, he started as senior vice president, general counsel and secretary of the GAF Corporation in Wayne, N.J.

title: WORKER IDENTITY SYSTEM MIGHT COST $1.5 BILLION
description: Under the immigration legislation now before Congress, the Federal Government would establish a computerized identity system estimated to cost as little as $185 million or as much as $1.5 billion in its first five years.

title: MISSISSIPPI SUMMER
description: On Monday, June 22, 20 years ago, I received an early morning call from a Nathan Schwerner of Pelham, N. Y. He said: ''My son, Mickey, and two other young civil rights workers are missing in Mississippi. They left Meridian in Mickey's car yesterday morning for a trip to Neshoba County and they have not returned or called in. Can you find out for me where they are - my wife and I are worried sick.''

title: G.O.P. AIDES NOTE SIGNS OF DISPUTE ABOUT PLATFORM
description: White House plans for a smooth Republican convention in August are being ruffled by talk of potential platform disputes between conservatives and moderates, Reagan Administration and campaign officials said today.

title: Union Planters
description: The Union Planters Corporation said it had discontinued talks with Stephen Adams, a Minnesota businessman, on his unsolicited proposal to acquire the assets of Union Planters, including the stock of the Union Planters National Bank. On April 18, Union Planters, based in Memphis, said it had received a letter from Mr. Adams proposing to buy all of Union Planters' assets for $100 million. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Union Planters dropped $3, to $19.

title: Ex-Nuclear Plant Aide Indicted on Lies in Test
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a former supervisor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant on charges of making false statements about his requalification test, a prosecutor announced today.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 19, 1984 International
description: A plan to curtail the military role of the United States in Central America was rejected by the Republican-controlled Senate. By a vote of 63 to 31, the Senate defeated a proposed measure that would have prohibited use of military forces in or over Nicaragua and El Salvador for combat purposes without the prior approval of Congress. (Page A1, Column 6.) Japanese ineptness with chopsticks is reported to be increasing. In a new Government report, only 48.4 percent of elementary school pupils surveyed said they could correctly wield chopsticks. (A1:2-4.) National

title: Article 012376 -- No Title
description: Without fanfare or even much attention, New York City's five borough presidents have received approval to nearly triple the amount of city money they may spend as they want.

title: RALLY ELIMINATES EARLY LOSS
description: After sliding sharply in light early trading, prices in the credit markets rallied yesterday afternoon and ended the day relatively unchanged from the close on Friday.

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN 12 DAYS
description: -LIGHTWEIGHT airplane designed to fly around the world without stopping or refueling has been built by engineers in California and will begin flight tests soon. Two pilots will take turns at the controls.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Mystery No More
description: The Giants took their time, but they finally confirmed Jeff Hostetler's report that he had signed a three-year contract with the club.

title: Soto Faces Suspension
description: Mario Soto is facing the possibility of being suspended for the second time this season by Chub Feeney , the National League's president. Disciplinary action against Soto, the Cincinnati Reds' best pitcher, and Claudell Washington of the Atlanta Braves is awaiting Feeney's study of videotapes and his review of umpire reports.

title: MELDRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PUNJAB RAID: UNANSWERED QUESTIONS
description: Operation Bluestar, the Indian Army's tactically successful raid to eliminate Sikh militants from Amritsar's Golden Temple, has been history for nearly two weeks. But questions and contradictions surrounding the operation and the army's continuing occupation of Punjab are likely to persist for some time.

title: Topics Persistence In Games and Life ''There's something that each of you understands that no one else can ever fully appreciate, something that has to do with courage, with will power and with the utter refusal to give up.'' That's how President Reagan greeted participants in the International Games for the Disabled on Sunday, and his words held special meaning for the American athletes. For his Administration has mismanaged the Federal disability insurance program, severely testing the courage and perseverance of the disabled.
description: Seizing on a Congressional mandate to reduce malingering, the Administration terminated benefits for masses of the handicapped.

title: SHUTTLE EXPERIMENTS SHOW HOW ZERO GRAVITY AFFECTS GASES
description: IT was a simple experiment, as simple as a

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend last Friday, on ''Bloomsday III'' at the Symphony Space, gave an incorrect publisher for the Critical and Synoptic Edition of Joyce's ''Ulysses.'' The publisher is Garland.

title: Study Backs Scrapping Plant
description: Opponents of the Midland nuclear plant have prepared a study that says the Consumers Power Company can survive abandonment of the $4.1 billion project, Hugh Anderson, State Assistant Attorney General, said today.

title: Rath Ouster Countered
description: Directors of the Rath Packing Company voted to create a new position to keep Lyle Taylor as president after stockholders had removed him from the board.

title: MUSIC: RAND STEIGER 'QUINTESSENCE'
description: RAND STEIGER'S ''Quintessence'' was the standout piece on the Merkin Hall program by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers Sunday to showcase its young grant recipients. It is a 13- minute work for piano, electric piano, clarinet, cello and percussion; the organizing dynamic is passage of primacy from one instrument (or pair) to another, as lyrical or transitional passages alternate with bursts of virtuosity.

title: NORTHWEST DRUG reports earnings for Year to March 31
Manuel Mujica Lainez Dead; Social Satirist in Argentina
description: Manuel Mujica Lainez, an Argentine author who established his reputation with writings on the decadence of Argentina's upper classes, died April 21 in his home in Cordoba, Argentina of lung cancer.

title: ORDER FOUND IN DEVELOPMENT OF EMOTIONS
description: BABIES, as everyone knows, have intense feelings from the moment of birth. But their early feelings are few, limited to the most primitive such as distress and disgust. Only with the passage of time does the full emotional panoply blossom.

title: A DOUBLE 'NO' IN EUROPE
description: Ballot-counting in the European parliamentary elections, completed today, showed a double ''no'' vote - disapproval of nearly all the parties in power and, through record abstentions, disillusionment with the ideals of European unity. Fewer Europeans than ever in the 10 countries of the Common Market voted for representatives to the Parliament in Strasbourg, France. Those who did vote turned against the incumbents in France, Britain, West Germany and Italy, often giving significant support to parties the political mainstream regards as extremist or marginal.

title: White Sox 8, Mariners 4
description: Harold Baines drove in four runs with a home run and a triple to spark Chicago.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: THEATER LIFE, SECOND LOVE
description: produced ''Sugar Babies,'' and if she has looked at the books lately she has to be pleased. The five-year-old musical burlesque, which left Broadway in 1982 after 1,208 performances, is still making money.

title: New VW Car Named Golf
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said today that its new 1985- model hatchback would be named the Golf.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''MRS. VREELAND snuck out through the kitchen,'' said Gloria Schiff. ''She didn't want to be photographed any more.''

title: WHY ADOLFO FANS KEEP THE FAITH
description: In winter they arrive wrapped in furs, to see what they will be wearing the next season. Yesterday they were wearing suntans - unless they belong to the sunblock school. They had come to the Adolfo fall and winter showing at the St. Regis as they do ritually twice a year, most in a style selected six months ago.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Greetings Corp., Cleveland, a producer of greeting cards and related products, has elected to its board Herb Jacobs, an investor and management consultant.

title: 7 DEMOCRATIC MAYORS AT PARLEY ASSAIL REAGAN FOR NOT ATTENDING
description: Seven Democrats attending a convention of 171 big-city mayors accused President Reagan today of snubbing urban America by declining an invitation to attend. Mr. Reagan sent a letter and two Cabinet members to defend his policies.

title: COURT REFUSES TO HEAR APPEAL ON DEPORTATION
description: The Supreme Court today let stand an appellate court order to deport a member of the Irish Republican Army who was convicted in Ireland of illegally manufacturing and possessing explosives and firearms.

title: Angeles, Quinoco
description: The Angeles Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Quinoco Companies for $50 million.

title: Texaco, ESPN
description: Texaco Inc. said it had completed the sale of its controlling interest in the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, or ESPN, and related assets to ABC Video Enterprises Inc. for $202 million. The sale price consists of $188 million for the 85 percent interest in ESPN not already held by ABC Video and $14 million for the cable network's satellite broadcasting facilities. ABC Video, a unit of the American Broadcasting Companies, bought a 15 percent interest in ESPN earlier this year for about $30 million.

title: S.E.C. SAYS DATAPOINT INFLATED SALES
description: The Datapoint Corporation, one of the stock market's high-technology favorites in the early 1980's, was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission today with engaging in a plan to inflate its sales and earnings in 1981 by tens of millions of dollars.

title: Tosco Bid Planned By Energy Reserve
description: Energy Reserve Inc. said today that it plans to make a tender offer for the Tosco Corporation, a Los Angeles-based oil refiner that dwarfs Energy Reserve but that has been struggling recently.

title: Why So Anti-Antitrust?
description: Could Federal antitrust enforcers sue local governments to keep them from exercising traditional regulatory powers? Worse, could municipal taxpayers be held liable for millions in damages for violating the antitrust laws?

title: Continental Adding Runs
description: Continental Air Lines will increase its flight service on July 1 to 107 percent of the passenger seat capacity it offered before filing for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, the company said today.

title: AUTHOR'S DAY AT P.S. 11: A CELEBRATION OF BOOKS
description: THE second graders in Room 210 at Public School 11 in the Highbridge section of the Bronx knew something special was happening one morning last week when several authors showed up in person to read from their works.

title: NEBRASKA ATTORNEY GENERAL FACES 2 NEW CHARGES IN FISCAL FAILURE
description: Paul L. Douglas, the State Attorney General, who narrowly avoided removal from office last month after being impeached, was arraigned today on two charges.

title: American Express Fee Rise
description: The American Express Company, which has 18.3 million charge card holders nationwide, said yesterday that it would increase some annual fees as much as $15, effective immediately.

title: HOUSE PANEL FINDS FAILURE IN WORLD DRUG CONTROL
description: A House committee has concluded in a detailed report on international drug enforcement that efforts to reduce illegal drug production in most Asian and Latin American countries are failing.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: A Nairs Winning Streak Alive

title: EARL WEAVER: ECHOES OF MOE BERG
description: Moe Berg was an extraordinary man. He was a secret agent who infiltrated the Nazi lines, an attorney, an adviser to large businesses, a major league baseball catcher (he was a teammate of both Walter Johnson and Ted Williams) and a man who was supposed to have been fluent in 12 languages and, it was said, couldn't hit in any of them.

title: FORMER BOSTON MAYOR'S AIDE TIED TO SUSPECT USE OF FUNDS
description: A former city official, testifying at the trial of Theodore V. Anzalone, said today that Mr. Anzalone had reimbursed him with cash for what he called ''contributions'' to a birthday party fund for the wife of former Mayor Kevin H. White.

title: Marian Cummings, 92, Dies; Licensed Commercial Pilot
description: Marian Engle Cummings, the first woman in the United States to receive a commercial pilot's license, died Saturday after a brief illness. She was 92 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
Cable Renews U.S.F.L.
description: The United States Football League formally announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement giving the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network three more years of exclusive cable-television rights to the league's games. The financial details of the contract, whose signing had been reported as imminent, were not announced, but a source close to the league said that the U.S.F.L. would receive about $70 million.

title: MEDICAL ASSOCIATION TO EVALUATE NEW LICENSING TESTS FOR DOCTORS
description: Stung by scandals involving the sale of medical diplomas and mass cheating on examinations taken by doctors, leaders of the American Medical Association today ordered an inquiry into the testing of medical school graduates to see if more difficult tests are needed for licensure.

title: BRAZIL SHOE CENTER A SYMBOL OF HOPE
description: The main hotel in this thriving provincial city is crowded with visiting businessmen most week nights, while dozens of job offers are advertised daily in local newspapers. The streets are deserted during working hours - evidence that most local workers are indeed employed.

title: Texas Democrats Back A Binding Primary
description: Delegates to the state convention of the Texas Democratic Party have called for a binding Presidential preference primary because the existing caucus system discriminates against the elderly, the disabled and others who are unable to attend the caucuses.

title: ADJOINING SCHOOLS IN ITALY SHOW STARK CONTRASTS
description: BOLOGNA, Italy ''THE difference between teaching at the university and at the center?'' Prof. Stefano Zamagni said. ''At the university I teach 900 students; the entire center consists of 120. My class there is likely to have no more than 15.''

title: FAR-RIGHT PARTY GAINS IN FRENCH VOTE
description: The results of the European Parliament elections in France, political leaders said today, were a major boost for the extreme right-wing National Front Party and a stunning defeat for the French Communist Party.

title: Topics Persistence
description: Two Potholes Back

title: TAX BENEFITS LIMITED BY CONFEREES
description: House and Senate tax conferees set new restrictions today that will limit tax benefits for many items, such as personal computers that are utilized for business and personal use.

title: Syria Foreign Minister In Beirut for Meetings
description: Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria arrived here today for talks aimed at reconciling Christian-Moslem differences within the Cabinet of Lebanon's Prime Minister, Rashid Karami.

title: Air Force Settles Suit Of 2,600 Black Workers
description: The Air Force will pay $3.75 million to 2,600 present or former black employees at Robins Air Force Base, Ga., in settlement of a discrimination suit, the Air Force announced today.

title: Solo Atlantic Sailor Sets Race Record
description: Philippe Poupon of France set a record by nearly a day and a half when he arrived here early tonight, but it was not certain he would be the winner of the 3,400-mile Observer Singlehanded Transatlantic Yacht race.

title: AMERICAN PSEUDO-THINK
description: To the Editor:

title: Sugar Plan Draws Fire
description: Ten major sugar-exporting nations introduced a proposal today that is aimed at balancing supply and demand, but the plan was sharply criticized by the Common Market, a major producer.

title: A WRITER FOR THE NEW YORKER SAYS HE CREATED COMPOSITES IN REPORTS
description: A longtime staff writer at The New Yorker has described how in nonfiction articles over the years he invented characters, rearranged events and composed conversations in search of ''a larger reality.''

title: A 'CARTEL' OF DEBTORS IS DOUBTED
description: A high Western monetary official said today that Latin American countries do not plan to set up a ''debtors' cartel'' at the ministerial meeting they are holding in Cartagena, Colombia, later this week to discuss the $350 billion in foreign debts they owe.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-After a loss of $55,000 from discontinued operations.

YANKEES WIN BEHIND NIEKRO
description: So what's all the fuss about?

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Management Shifts Are Begun By Mitel
description: The Mitel Corporation yesterday announced several executive changes designed to restore its profitability, and said it ''will make further additions and changes'' in management over the next several weeks.

title: Ampco Makes Bid For Union Electric
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it had signed an agreement to acquire about 28.3 percent of the common stock of the Union Electric Steel Corporation from the Wallace- Harrer family voting trusts for $40 a share. Ampco-Pittsburgh also said it had agreed to make a tender offer for all remaining shares of Union Electric for $40 each.

title: CITY'S PLANS CALL FOR AN ISLAND THAT'S STRICTLY FOR THE BIRDS
description: Not a single resident of Block 1935, Lot 1, showed up yesterday for a hearing before the City Planning Commission on the fate of their home.

title: STATE FAULTS CONDUCTORS SENT TO SUBWAY STATIONS
description: The Transit Authority wastes as much as $5 million a year paying subway-platform conductors who do not do their job, according to a report released yesterday by the State Comptroller's Office.

title: DEVON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Law and Clippers
description: Most accounts of the National Basketball Association's suit against the Clippers, filed with a Federal court in San Diego last week, left a big question unanswered: Why does the N.B.A. think it can succeed where the National Football League failed?

description: Simon A. Lubow, the last of the

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Lenox Inc., acquired in July 1983.

title: Italian Said to Deny Agca Was Pressured
description: An Italian magazine said today that the report by an Italian prosecutor investigating the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II rejects the contention that the Turkish gunman, Mehmet Ali Agca, was pressured into implicating Bulgaria in the assassination attempt.

description: THE JESUITS. History and Legend of the

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including gains of $393,000 for the quarter and $579,000 for the year from the sale of idle facilities. c-Including a gain of $735,000 from the sale of idle facilities.

title: NETS SEEKING HELP INSIDE AND OUTSIDE
description: Buck Williams is the Nets' strongest and most physical player, but even he has limits. Those limits were never more evident than after the first round of the recent National Basketball Association playoffs. After the Nets had won a grueling and emotional series from the Philadelphia 76ers, three games to two, Williams slumped in front of his locker and said, ''These games have taken everything I have.''

title: DANCE: JAPANESE GROUP IN TORONTO
description: The sight of four near-naked men, their chalk-covered bodies as white as alabaster as they dangled upside-down along the glass surface of a Toronto office building might make even a blase New Yorker take notice.

title: BANKRUPTCY BILL SPARKS BUSINESS-LABOR DISPUTE
description: A sharply divided and skittish Senate faces a showdown this week on what has become the year's most intense business-labor lobbying dispute: whether companies should be free to abandon union contracts when they file for protection from creditors under the bankruptcy laws.

title: Put the Super Back in Superfund
description: By creating the Superfund in 1980, Congress thought it had the answer to abandoned dump sites that leak poison. Yet such dumps continue to mar health and environment in every state, particularly New Jersey and New York, and the Superfund only mops at the surface of a sea of waste.

title: OAKRIDGE ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
FISHING TRIP'S BIG CATCH: A LESSON ABOUT THE HUDSON
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 18 - Armed with bait nets, window screens and kitchen strainers, 36 students from a Bronx elementary school recently descended on the Croton Marsh here at low tide, and the fish didn't stand a chance.

title: Library Largess
description: At the Bedford branch of the Brooklyn Public Library these days, there is new furniture, an added supply of books, a new cultural and recreational program for adults on Thursdays and a literacy program for people who can't read.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mothers In the Act Promoting Play's Move
description: Working on the theory that the most believable advertising testimonial is from a disinterested party, three of the top people behind the play ''Isn't It Romantic'' have enlisted their mothers to do the radio ads announcing the show's move Wednesday night to the Lucille Lortel Theater, off- Broadway at 121 Christopher Street, from off-off-Broadway at the Playwrights Horizons at 416 West 42d Street.

title: ABBOUD'S CHARGES ON FIRST CHICAGO
description: A decade ago, the First National Bank of Chicago faced liquidity and bad-loan problems nearly as serious as those now threatening the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, according to A. Robert Abboud, who became First Chicago's chairman in 1975 and who was dismissed by the bank's board in 1980.

title: Rise in Use Of Capacity Cut to 0.2%
description: In an apparent new sign of slowing economic expansion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today that the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.7 percent of capacity in May, up two-tenths of a percentage point from April's revised figure.

title: IMMUNE SYSTEM: GREAT MYSTERY IS SOLVED AFTER LONG QUEST
description: A MYSTERY that has puzzled biologists for more than a decade has been solved, and a new chapter has opened in the understanding of the human immune system.

President's Daughter To Marry in August
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, announced today that their daughter, Patti, would marry Paul Grilley, a yoga instructor from Columbia Falls, Mont., on Aug. 14.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Sports section on Sunday about the boxer Billy Collins Jr. misidentified the referee in Collins's last fight. He was Tony Perez, who is named as a defendant in a suit brought by the Collins family. Joe Cortez did not referee the fight and has no connection with the lawsuit.

title: Canada's Neo-Liberal
description: By tradition, Canada's Liberal Party chooses its leaders in an alternating cycle, with an eye to its French- and English-speaking voters. In 1948, Mackenzie King was succeeded by Louis St. Laurent; then came Lester Pearson, followed by Pierre Trudeau. So when the Liberals last weekend elected John Turner to replace Mr. Trudeau, who is resigning, it seemed to confirm a wizened custom.

title: MINI-COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $270,397 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $178,904 for the quarter and $208,924 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Leconte Injured Because of an injured shoulder,
description: Henri Leconte of France will not compete in the Wimbledon championships that begin next Monday. The left-handed Leconte fell on his left shoulder last week while losing a match at the Queen's Club tournament in London, a major grass-court tune-up for Wimbledon.

title: 4 Mortarboards in a Family
description: At York College in Jamaica,

title: HEBREW BOOKS SALE PROTESTED
description: -THREE Hebrew books and manuscripts, dating from the 13th to the 19th centuries and thought to have been destroyed by the Nazis in World War II, are scheduled to be auctioned at Sotheby's June 26, although some Jewish groups have questioned the legality of the sale.

title: Showdown Time for Mets Is at Hand
description: After winning three of four games over the weekend, the Mets face a crucial test - a three-game series with Philadelphia beginning tonight at Shea.

title: BOOKS: LANGUAGE
description: I STAND CORRECTED: MORE ON LANGUAGE. By William Safire. 468 pages.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $797,000 writedown and writeoff of assets.

title: Iran Says Volunteers Are Converging on Port
description: Iran said today that thousands of its volunteers were converging near the Iraqi city of Basra, apparently preparing for an offensive on the port city.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The new Firestone Retail Credit Corporation yesterday issued $140 million in commercial paper.

title: Market Place; Likelihood of Summer Rally
description: TECHNICAL analysts at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, who were a factor in

title: Accounts
description: * Schrafft Ice Cream Co. to Romann & Tannenholz.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ; CONRAIL: THE KIND OF BUYER THE GOVERNMENT SEEKS
description: To the Editor:

title: 22.75 SURGE PUTS DOW AT 1,109.65
description: The stock market erupted in a sharp technical rally yesterday in stepped-up trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 22.75 points, to 1,109.65.

title: STATES' CONTROL OF CABLE EASED
description: A unanimous Supreme Court decision today sharply limited the ability of the individual states to regulate the content of cable television programming.

title: Stottlemyre Cut
description: Mel Stottlemyre 's son Mel Jr. , a pitcher at Nevada-Las Vegas, was among those cut when the United States Olympic baseball team, now in training at Louisville, Ky., trimmed seven players from its roster yesterday.

title: Financial Officer Picked By Texas Instruments
description: William A. Aylesworth, 41, has been named principal financial officer of Texas Instruments Inc., succeeding James L. Fischer, who is retiring, the Dallas computer company announced yesterday.

title: 'Car Wars,' Battle 99
description: The Pentagon brass has routed

title: CITY'S IMMIGRANTS SHOW CONCERN AS ILLEGAL ALIENS BILL NEARS VOTE
description: Immigration counseling offices in New York report a deluge of telephone calls in the last week from immigrants worried about a bill nearing a vote in Congress that would penalize employers of illegal aliens.

title: GAMES PEOPLE PLAY WITH SECURITIES MARKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
