description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $14,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $496,000.

title: Plan Rejected For Marble Hill
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana today turned down a proposal from a consortium of three companies to complete the Marble Hill nuclear power plant. Hugh Barker, chairman of P.S.I., said the plan had been rejected because it would have required the utility to continue to find financing for the $7.1 billion project, which was canceled in January at the urging of a study group appointed by Indiana's Governor, Robert D. Orr.

title: CUOMO AND KOCH ARE OUT OF THE RACE FOR THE VICE-PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION
description: Had the 1982 campaign for Governor of New York State ended differently, perhaps the 1984 campaign for President of the United States might be different.

title: Kermit C. Claster Dies at 75; Former Ohrbach's President
description: Kermit C. Claster, former president of Ohrbach's Inc., died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Permanent Site for Olympics Is Recommended by Senate
description: The Senate recommended today that future Olympic Games be held at a permanent site ''suitable for insulating the Games'' from what it called ''unwarranted and disruptive international politics.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Many scholars attribute the dexterity of the Japanese people to hashi, and I myself think that has some validity.

title: G.E. Credit Signs Deal With Baldwin
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a $155 million financing agreement with the management of the Baldwin Piano and Organ Company.

title: MOSES WINS EASILY AT TRIALS
description: Edwin Moses, as usual, made it look almost easy. The 28-year-old Moses, the most successful 400-meter hurdler ever, won his specialty tonight at the United States Olympic track-and- field trials.

title: Chess: San Sebastian Tournament Won by Mednis and Mateo
description: The San Sebastian International Tournament in Puerto Rico saw the international master Ramon Mateo of the Dominican Republic and the Queens grandmaster Edmar Mednis tie for first place. Each scored 7-2 in the 10-player round-robin event.

title: Rose Apologizes
description: Pete Rose has apologized to a Montreal broadcaster, Jeff Rimer , with whom he engaged in a clubhouse scuffle Saturday night.

title: BRIEFS;
description: Debt Issues

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD S.E.C. ON SUBPOENA NOTICES
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously overturned a lower court's ruling that required the Securities and Exchange Commission to give advance notice to targets of its investigations before issuing subpoenas to other individuals or companies.

title: MORE JOBS, LOWER WAGES
description: The American worker is in trouble, despite the sharp decline last month in the unemployment rate to 7.5 percent.

title: Dress Code Imposed On Tanglewood Ushers
description: Volunteers who usher in concertgoers and hand out programs at Tanglewood are upset over a new conservative dress code at the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

title: AFTER LOW HEELS, HIGH STYLES
description: Though it is not the usual route to becoming a fashion designer, Joan Halpern served her apprenticeship in the shoe field. The Joan & David shoes she designs and sells with her husband, David Halpern, are made in factories in Italy and sold in shops around the world - in Switzerland, Britain, Hong Kong and Venezuela, among other places, in addition to about 60 stores in the United States.

title: Nuclear Plant Study Faulted
description: The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company said today that it disagreed with a consultant's report that concluded that the company had substantially mismanaged the Zimmer Nuclear Project.

title: New Life Arising?
description: A leading experimenter in the ways in which life may have originated suggested today that the process may be occurring near hot springs on the Pacific Ocean floor.

title: Robert M. Brush Dies at 70; Executive in Hotel Industry
description: Robert M. Brush, a hotel executive who was a community leader in New England for many years, died of a heart attack Sunday in Saunderstown, R.I., where he was visiting. He was 70 years old and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: AT THEATER One of the most extraordinary exhibitions in town for theatergoers is one flight down in the lavish galleries of the Fashion Institute of Technology, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue (760- 7760). ''Fashion and Broadway'' is an exquisitely staged show starring more than 130 garments, nearly half of them historic costumes worn in hit shows from a century ago until today, and the rest of them dresses and suits worn by showgoers during the same period.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Electromagnetic Systems division of the Raytheon Company received a $55 million Air Force contract for tactical jamming system spares for the EF-111A aircraft, the Defense Department said. In addition, the department said the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had received a $46.7 million contract from the Navy for aircraft weapons systems.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3 million on the sale of two hospitals in the first quarter. Share earnings reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid Feb. 1.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SIKH TRANSMITTER FOUND AT TEMPLE
description: An Indian military expert said today that a radio transmitter had been seized at the Golden Temple, indicating that a Sikh communications and command structure might still be operating in Punjab despite the Indian Army's campaign against the Sikh extremists.

title: Borough Pride
description: When the Municipal Art Society

title: A STRIKE ON L.I.R.R. IS AVERTED AS UNION SEEKS FEDERAL BOARD
description: A union that had threatened a strike against the Long Island Rail Road next Friday changed its position yesterday and asked for the appointment of an emergency board by President Reagan to investigate the dispute.

title: CONGESTION FORCES LOS ANGELES TO EXPAND AIRPORT
description: In time for the Olympic Games, Los Angeles has completed a $700 million expansion of its international airport that is expected to accommodate the city's growth in air travel at least through the year 2000.

title: Foli Asks Trade From Yanks
description: Last year, when Billy Martin was the manager, the line seemed to form at the right for Yankee players who were unhappy and wanted out. This year, in spite of the team's awful start, there is no displeasure among the players with Manager Yogi Berra.

title: BIFLYX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a gain of $217,100 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of assets.

title: AFTER INQUIRY AT CREEDMOOR, 10 RESIGN OR FACE DISMISSAL
description: Ten workers at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, including its deputy director and five doctors, have resigned or face dismissal after an investigation that turned up evidence of patient abuse and financial wrongdoing at the Queens hospital, officials said yesterday.

title: POLISH AUTHORITIES CLAIM VICTORY IN VOTER TURNOUT
description: The Polish Government said today that the turnout in nationwide elections Sunday represented a vote of confidence in its policies. But preliminary figures it released indicated that in the most urban areas, the election boycott called for by Solidarity sympathizers received significant support.

title: THE REGION ; Disaster Statement Signed by Reagan
description: President Reagan today signed a $40.7 million disaster declaration for Connecticut.

title: Advertising; Promoter Of Radio Sets Goals
description: THE radio industry very much

title: IMPORTS WIDEN U.S. TRADE GAP
description: A flood of imports plunged the broadest measure of the nation's foreign trade to a record deficit of $19.4 billion for the first quarter of this year, the Government reported today.

title: FUMBLED CHOPSTICKS AND THE FUTURE OF JAPAN
description: Chopsticks have become too much to handle for many Japanese.

title: Brooklyn Girl Found Drowned
description: The body of Jennifer Habib, a 10- year-old autistic girl who had wandered from her sleeping father Saturday, was found yesterday in Gerritsen Creek in Marine Park in Brooklyn, the police said. The girl, who could utter sounds but could not speak, had drowned, the police said, adding that there was no indication of foul play. Jennifer had lived with her grandmother near the park.

title: Economist Says Parties Are Avoiding Tax Issue
description: Republicans and Democrats alike are avoiding the crucial issue of raising taxes in 1985, the economist Lester Thurow said today.

title: MONDALE TO INTERVIEW MAYOR BRADLEY ON NO. 2 SPOT
description: Walter F. Mondale announced today that he would interview Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles on Thursday as a prospective Vice-Presidential running mate. He is the third person, and the first black, on the Mondale list.

title: Police Dog Joins the Force
description: Lillian Padilla was unhappy when

title: COLUMBIAN NORTHLAND EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Net loss figures for both periods reflect tax credits.

title: Panthers Clinch
description: Bobby Hebert returned to the Michigan lineup tonight and threw four touchdown passes as the defending United States Football League champion Michigan Panthers beat the Oklahoma Outlaws, 34-24. The victory was only the Panthers' third in their last 11 games, but it raised their record to 9-8 and guaranteed them a Western Conference wild-card berth.

title: 'DAY AFTER' FADES, BUT DEBATE ON EFFECTS LINGERS
description: My opinion now is that the movie was just a flop in our school,'' said 12- year-old Matt Goldman, a seventh grader in Evanston, Ill. ''A few days afterwards, no one really talked about it again. We dropped it.''

title: DNA MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRANS GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Volcker Visit To Yugoslavia
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, arrived today for talks with Radovan Makic, governor of the National Bank of Yugoslavia, according to the Tanyug press agency.

title: Staying Afloat
description: Bob Carter , the majority owner of the Vancouver Whitecaps, announced yesterday that the club's partners had contributed more than $1 million to keep the financially troubled North American Soccer League team afloat until the end of the season.

title: THE LESSONS REPORTERS CAN TEACH THE POLICE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Asks Reversal Of Layoff Ruling
description: The Justice Department, citing a recent United States Supreme Court ruling, today asked a Federal judge here to overturn his order that white public employees with seniority must forfeit their jobs to protect minority hiring plans when layoffs are required.

title: Israel Bars a Second Party
description: The election committee barred a new party of Palestinian Arabs and Jews early today from taking part in the elections on July 23. The party, the Progressive List for Peace, was barred on the ground that it included subversive elements identified with Israel's enemies. On Sunday, the committee banned the Kach Party headed by Rabbi Meir Kahane on the ground that its racist platform threatened Israeli democracy and public order.

title: BILL VOTED TO ALLOW NEW YORK TO RESTRICT AMBULANCE SERVICE
description: A bill given final approval by the State Legislature yesterday would let New York City's ambulance crews refuse to take anyone to the hospital if emergency care was found unnecessary.

title: Swale Is Buried;Inquiry Continues
description: While his breeder, some of his owners and many of the farmhands who raised him watched, Swale was buried yesterday at his birthplace, Claiborne Farm, near Paris, Ky. At the same time, racing officials and veterinarians in New York continued their investigation into the unexpected death of this year's Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes winner.

title: TAX SHIFT MAY AID SALE OF LOW-COST COMPUTERS
description: Computer industry experts said yesterday that any move to cut back on tax deductions for personal computers would have the greatest impact on the makers of sophisticated machines, particularly Apple Computer Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: PAUL G. HOWES, 91, A NATURAL HISTORIAN AND FORMER CURATOR
description: Paul Griswold Howes, a naturalist and retired curator-director of the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., died Saturday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 91 years old and lived in South Norwalk, Conn.

title: New Police Head For Westchester
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke named Mount Vernon's Police Commissioner, Anthony M. Mosca, today to be Westchester County's top police official.

title: A's 10, Royals 2
description: Two- run homers by Dave Kingman and Davey Lopes, and a three-run blast by Rickey Henderson enabled Oakland to crush Kansas City. Lopes hit an inside-the-park home run after a double by Carney Lansford in the sixth. Kingman hit his major league leading 18th homer off Larry Gura (7-3) in the seventh.

title: SOIA MENTSCHIKOFF, PROFESSOR AND EX-LAW DEAN, DIES AT 69
description: Soia Mentschikoff, a leading legal educator and scholar, died of cancer at her home here today. She was 69 years old.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES U.S. ROLE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today accused the Reagan Administration of having a ''double standard'' on human rights by instituting an economic boycott of Poland in response to suppression while expanding economic, diplomatic and military ties to South Africa despite suppression there.

title: JAMES ROWE, NEW DEAL AIDE AND AN ASSISTANT TO ROOSEVELT
description: James H. Rowe Jr., a lawyer and former special adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died Sunday night at his home here after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on June 11 about the Olympic Arts Festival in Los Angeles misidentified the sculptor of Lincoln's statue in the Lincoln Memorial, who was cited in a quotation from the sculptor Robert Graham. Mr. Graham correctly referred to the earlier sculptor as Daniel Chester French.

title: COMEDY SERIES TESTED BY NATIONAL LAMPOON
description: THE National Lampoon production gang that takes credit for such films as ''Animal House'' and ''Vacation'' is having another go at trying to start a television comedy series. This one is called ''Hot Flashes'' and is being tested this week, Monday through Friday, on WPIX-TV at 11 P.M.

title: ARAB-AMERICANS IN ISRAEL: A CASE OF DUAL IDENTITIES
description: One by one, Arab-Americans are coming to Israel to engage in a complicated search for their roots.

title: John A. S. Cushman, 57, Dies; Led New York Literary Agency
description: John Allerton Sill Cushman, a New York literary agent, died of cardiac failure Sunday after emergency surgery at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Talking Business with George Munroe of Phelps Dodge ; The Bid to Cut Copper Imports
description: George B. Munroe, chairman and chief executive of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, heads a leading company in the depressed ranks of domestic copper producers. Phelps Dodge and others say the low price for copper that has forced them to shut mines and operate in the red is caused by world oversupply, and one way the industry is trying to fight back is to win quotas on imports of foreign copper. In an interview, Mr. Munroe commented on the industry's situation.

title: HOW A SICK BANK GOT WELL
description: When Federal regulators arranged a package of emergency loans last month to stabilize the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, one precedent in particular came to mind: the First Pennsylvania Bank.

title: Saga Pizza Unit
description: The Saga Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Straw Hat pizza division, a chain of 205 family-oriented restaurants, to Bullwinkle's Inc. It said Bullwinkle's would pay at closing $40 million in cash or a combination of cash and two-year notes secured by letters of credit. Saga said the sale, if completed, will take effect Sept. 30. The food service company said that Straw Hat, while profitable, does not fit into its long-term plans.

title: Teen-Agers Find Rare Whale Fossil
description: Two Maryland teen-agers playing on the beach stumbled on the remains of what may be a previously unknown species of sperm whale that lived 16 million years ago, scientists say.

title: Park Sued by Jersey Family Over Death of Youth in Fire
description: The family of a Paterson teen-ager killed in a fire at Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park filed a lawsuit against the park today, charging negligence had led to the death.

title: DEEP-ROOTED DEMOCRAT
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE BARS LIMIT ON MILITARY ROLE IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The Republican-controlled Senate tonight rejected two Democratic proposals to curtail United States military involvement in Central America.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are on a pro forma basis.

title: MILBOURNE CHRISTOPHER, 70, MAGICIAN ON STAGE AND TV
description: Milbourne Christopher, a magician, author and former president of the American Society of Magicians, died Sunday of complications following surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RETAIN THE JOINT CHIEFS
description: Congress is considering a basic and far-reaching change in the carefully balanced Joint Chiefs of Staff system. The proposals would significantly revise the duties, responsibilities and functions within the system and move them toward the concept of a single chief of staff. Such a step would be unwise.

title: Blind Swimmers Set World Marks
description: Trischa Zorn of Mission Viejo, Calif., and Barbara Eiler of Macomb, Ill., two blind swimmers, each broke a world record today while winning two gold medals each at the third International Games for the Disabled.

title: RYKOFF, SE, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Local Jail Practices Criticized
description: A Federal study, finding that the nation's 3,493 local jails often hold ''inappropriate populations,'' recommends that juveniles, the mentally ill and drunks be housed somewhere other than in jail or in sections away from other inmates.

title: JOB PROJECT GETS DROPOUTS TO RETURN TO CITY SCHOOLS
description: For more than two years, John Orengo might have been called the student who wasn't.

title: JUSTICES TO DECIDE F.D.A. ROLE IN LETHAL INJECTIONS
description: The Supreme Court, accepting a Government appeal, agreed today to decide whether the Food and Drug Administration must investigate the use of federally approved drugs for executions by lethal injection.

title: Sony's Profit Soars in Period
description: The Sony Corporation said today that rising sales of video cassette recorders, color television sets and other products helped more than triple its second-quarter profit.

title: STATE LEGISLATURE AGREES ON PLAN TO CUT ACID RAIN
description: Key legislators announced an agreement tonight on a plan to reduce acid rain by sharply limiting emissions of pollutants from smokestacks in New York State over the next decade.

title: Mathias Barely Wins G.O.P. Convention Seat
description: Maryland's most prominent Republican, Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., barely won enough votes at his party's state meeting to win a seat at the national convention in Dallas.

title: CITICORP GROUP SETS CONRAIL BID
description: Citicorp said yesterday that an investment group it is forming had made a bid for Conrail before the midnight deadline. Citicorp added that it hoped the bid would bring together Conrail unions, management and the group of investors that includes itself.

title: WRIGHT AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CULTURED CULTURE CHIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: GETTING THERE ISN'T ENOUGH
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.

title: BULGARIA ACCUSED OF PLOT ON POPE ROME, June 19 (AP) - An Italian prosecutor said today that Bulgaria, possibly with Soviet support, masterminded the 1981 plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II, apparently in an attempt to eliminate the Pope's support for the independent Polish labor union Solidarity.
description: ''That's the conclusion of my investigation,'' the prosecutor, Antonio Albano, said in an interview.

title: THE STAGE: 'OH! OBESITY,' PORTLY FARCE
description: CHILDREN'S cartoon characters with names like Fat Momma, Fat Daddy, Ms. Knosh and Blimpie cavort through ''Oh! Oh! Obesity,'' the musical farce that ends its short run this Sunday at the New Federal Theater. With lyrics, music and story by Gerald W. Deas, a Queens nutritionist, the show isn't a really a musical comedy as much as it is a self-help burlesque show for the overweight.

title: Shultz to Visit Asia in July
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is to leave July 5 on a two-week tour of East Asia and the Pacific that will take him to Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Australia and New Zealand, the State Department said today.

title: No Headline
description: Plea for Prison Reform Made by Chief Justice

title: TAX CONFEREES SEEK END TO IMPASSE
description: In an effort to break a deadlock on this year's tax legislation, Senate conferees tonight offered to drop their major special tax cuts - including President Reagan's proposal to expand individual retirement accounts - if the House conferees would accept all the Senate's $12 billion in spending cuts, including $8 billion in Medicare.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: OUTSPOKEN TALK SHOW HOST SLAIN OUTSIDE DENVER HOME
description: Alan Berg, a popular and controversial Denver radio talk-show host, was shot and killed here late last night in a hail of .45- caliber bullets outside his building.

title: Reagan Names Mali Envoy
description: President Reagan today named Robert J. Ryan as the new Ambassador to Mali, replacing Parker W. Borg, the White House said. Mr. Ryan, a career member of the Foreign Service, has previously served in Rio de Janeiro, Paris and Rabat, Morocco.

title: DEVICE TO EXTRACT JUICES
description: THERE is nothing like fresh fruit juice to quench a summer thirst. One of my favorite warm weather drinks is freshly made lemonade, something that many people, especially the younger generation, have never tasted. They have been led to believe lemonade comes powdered in a jar or frozen. These varieties, however, are usually overly sugared beverages that are closer to soft drinks than to fruit juice.

title: BRONX MAN HELD IN MURDER OF 10
description: A 34-year-old Bronx man was charged last night with the slaying of 10 people in a house in the East New York section of Brooklyn last April, the police said.

title: Visicorp Loses Its President
description: Daniel H. Fylstra, cofounder and chairman of Visicorp, also assumed the duties of president and chief operating officer yesterday, following the resignation of Terry L. Opdendyk. Mr. Opdendyk, who joined the computer software concern in December 1980, resigned to pursue another business opportunity, Mr. Fylstra said. Visicorp, which in 1978 developed Visicalc, a popular business program, has been having difficulties since it was sued last year by its marketer, Software Arts, over ownership of the program. Mr. Fylstra, 33, said Visicorp, based in San Jose, Calif., is trying to market new products such as a $99 spreadsheet aimed at the casual business user.

title: TALKS IN LEBANON OPEN ON MILITARY
description: A four-member military committee, established after talks with Syrian leaders, started work today on a plan to reunite the Lebanese Army in hopes of ending years of civil war.

title: SENATE VOTES BANKRUPTCY BILL
description: The Senate tonight broke a three-month impasse and approved a broad package of changes in the bankruptcy laws, including provisions making it more difficult for consumers to escape debts by declaring bankruptcy.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 16 wks to May 19
description: b-Including a tax credit of $361,000. c-Including a tax credit of $196,000. Year-ago results are for the 13 weeks ended April 30, 1983.

title: NONFICTION TECHNIQUES DEBATED ANEW
description: The disclosure that a longtime staff writer at The New Yorker has long invented characters, rearranged events and composed conversations in nonfiction articles, has refocused attention on the blurring of journalistic distinctions between fact and fiction.

title: CEILING COLLAPSE LINKED TO FAULTS FOUND IN DESIGN
description: The ceiling collapse at the Journal Square PATH station in Jersey City in which two people were killed last year was the result of faulty design, inadequate supervision during construction and poor maintenance, inspection and repair procedures by Port Authority workers, the authority said yesterday.

title: NETS PICK FORWARD; KNICKS TAP SMALL GUARD
description: The Nets got their wish. After going into the National Basketball Association draft yesterday hoping to find a talented backup for Buck Williams at power forward, they found themselves with a pleasant situation: Three of the players they wanted most - Ben Coleman, a strong rebounder from Maryland; Jay Murphy of Boston College and Jeff Turner of Vanderbilt - were still available when the Nets' turn was called for the 17th selection.

title: OCEAN TITLE ELUDES FIRST BOAT TO FINISH
description: The man who finished first in record time in a singlehanded sailing race across the Atlantic Ocean lost the race today to a countryman who had stopped to help a troubled sailor and arrived nearly 11 hours later.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings reflect 40 percent stock dividend paid April 16.

title: U.S. Group Starts Drive Opposing 'Star Wars'
description: A group of Americans, including former President Jimmy Carter, began a campaign today against the so-called Star Wars program, saying it might violate the 1972 treaty with the Soviet Union on antiballistic missile systems.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Net income for the latest 6 months was equal to less than one cent a share.

title: STAGE: 2 ONE-ACT PLAYS BY HARRY KONDOLEON
description: THE young playwright Harry Kondoleon is rapidly becoming one of the more frustrating paradoxes of the New York theater. ''Linda Her and the Fairy Garden,'' the pair of one-acts now at the Second Stage, is the third major Off Broadway production that this distinctive, ever-promising writer has received in the last year. And, like the previous two (''Christmas on Mars,'' ''The Vampires''), it's a disappointment in spite of itself. Though Mr. Kondoleon's glittery language and absurdist world-view are as arresting as always, these attributes are still failing to sustain his plays. Are we eternally doomed to admire this man's talent while fighting off boredom?

title: N.J.TransitBu dget KeepsFaresStable
description: N.J. Transit today approved a $459 million operating budget that for the first time in five years will require no fare increases next fall for the agency's 300,000 bus and rail commuters, Governor Kean said.

title: Flood-Aid Centers In Connecticut
description: Federal officials will open five disaster- assistance centers in Connecticut on Friday, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has announced.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
Lease With a Twist
description: When Edward Bennett Williams , the owner of the Baltimore Orioles, pulled out a thick sheaf of papers at a dinner in his honor in Baltimore Monday night, Mayor William Schaefer and other guests assumed it was part of his speech.

title: ACADEMIC TEAM, DISPUTING CARTER STUDY, SEES AFFLUENT FUTURE
description: A major new assault is coming in the war between the pessimists and the optimists over the future of humankind. In a 585-page book to be published July 2, two dozen experts look upon the future and find it good.

title: Ingersoll-Finnish Deal
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company and United Paper Mills of Finland have agreed to jointly develop and market worldwide pulp and papermaking technology and equipment. The companies signed agreements Monday that provide for construction and operation of a research facility in Finland to develop and produce pulping systems and turnkey installations.

title: 10 NEW DEPUTIES NAMED IN EGYPT
description: President Hosni Mubarak appointed 10 new deputies to the recently elected Parliament today, including four from an opposition party.

title: TURNOUT LOW, POLES WILL RERUN 85 LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: The Polish Government said today that about 75 percent of the 26 million enrolled voters participated in local elections Sunday and that a low turnout required new elections in some areas.

title: Sallie Mae Charter
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, said it had submitted an application to charter a bank in North Carolina.

title: Owners to Vote
description: Major league baseball's club owners will meet in Kansas City tomorrow to vote on the antidrug program that their representatives negotiated with the Major League Baseball Players Association earlier this year. The players, by a 97 percent majority, have already ratified the program, whose emphasis is on treatment.

title: Carson Pirie Plans $50 Million Offer
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $50 million of senior notes due in 1994.

title: Stephen J. Bollinger Is Dead; Assistant Housing Secretary
description: Stephen J. Bollinger, Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has died, apparently of a heart attack. He was 36 years old.

title: DEFENSE POLICY FOR DEMOCRATS
description: If the Democratic Party is to recapture the White House and Senate, it must recognize that sound arms control and a strong defense are not contradictory. This is not only a matter of national security but of smart electoral strategy as well.

title: Unicorp Discusses Its Stake in Amrep
description: A group including the Unicorp American Corporation and the Unicorp Canada Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is talking with the Amrep Corporation about the repurchase of Amrep stock.

title: INVESTMENT BANKING LAWYERS
description: Allen Finkelson was no slouch in the law world. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1971, and made partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore - perhaps the most prestigious firm in the nation - a mere six years later.

title: AN UNAUTHORIZED 'ULYSSES' EDITOR'S CONFESSION
description: To the Editor: Now that we have learned that ''Ulysses'' was riddled with errors all these years, one can only wonder at how much scholarship has been de

title: 3 Mile Island Help Speeded
description: Utilities will donate at least $13.5 million by Jan. 1, 1985, toward cleaning up the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, directors of an industry trade group have announced. The Edison Electric Institute's board of directors, meeting in Boston Monday, voted to eliminate a formula that had been holding up contributions to the General Public Utilities Corporation, owner of the contaminated plant.

title: ACTING TO AVERT DEBTOR CARTEL
description: THE meeting of Latin American finance

title: India Asserts the A.P. 'Floated False Stories'
description: The Indian Government charged yesterday that correspondents of The Associated Press in India had ''floated many false stories'' about the situation in Punjab and about the army assault two weeks ago on Sikh extremists in the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

title: NICARAGUAN LEADER WINDS UP MOSCOW TALKS
description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan leader, is scheduled to leave here Wednesday after two days of meetings that Western diplomats said were probably aimed at obtaining more military aid.

title: Helping Himself
description: For some time now, Tim Lollar of the San Diego Padres has been considered one of the best hitters among major league pitchers, and, true to form, he is hitting .300 this season.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The 'Parkie' of the Year

title: Common Market to Send Officials to Latin Parley
description: All 10 European Economic Community Foreign Ministers today accepted an invitation to a conference in Costa Rica with Central American countries and the members of the regional bloc known as the Contadora group, diplomats said.

title: LIQUOR STORE DON'TS
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE PANEL HEARS SHARP DEBATE ON RAISING STATES' DRINKING AGE
description: A Senate subcommittee heard heated and conflicting testimony today on a proposal that would press the states to raise their minimum drinking age to 21.

title: AVON TO SELL TIFFANY, 5 YEARS AFTER IT TOOK OVER
description: Five years after it was bought by Avon Products Inc., Tiffany & Company is up for sale again.

title: U.S. TO SELL MILITARY TRANSPORT PLANES TO TAIWAN
description: The Pentagon announced the sale of 12 C-130 military transports to Taiwan today. They are worth about $325 million.

title: DANCE: DIANNE MCINTYRE'S SOUNDS IN MOTION
description: IN 1939, a young business major

title: I.R.A. Fugitive To Be Deported
description: A convicted Irish Republican Army explosives expert has lost a five-year battle against deportation and will be handed over to the Irish authorities, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: GASOIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $26,000. c-Net loss.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Modest Gifts From Guests

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY AGREE TO REQUIRE USE OF SEAT BELTS
description: State legislative leaders announced final agreement today on a measure to require drivers and their front-seat passengers to wear seat belts in New York State.

title: RECORD DEMAND CAUGHT UTILITIES OFF THEIR GUARD
description: The June heat wave has caught electric utilities in the Northeast off guard, creating record demand for power for many of them while they were still performing off-season maintenance on their generating stations.

title: Sutcliffe Halts Cubs' Slide at 4
description: Keith Moreland drove in two runs, and Rick Sutcliffe won in his Cubs' debut, helping Chicago snap a four- game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh tonight. It was the Pirates' fourth consecutive loss.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Niedenfuer , the Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher who just returned to action after a two-week layoff because of a strained elbow muscle, was hospitalized in Cincinnati yesterday for what the team said was a kidney stone, but he will be released today. Niedenfuer had collapsed in the coffee shop of the team's hotel. . . . Joe Lefebvre , the Phillies outfielder who injured his right knee Sunday, will be hospitalized in Philadelphia to determine the nature of the joint injury, which may need surgery. . . . Boomer Esiason , a left-handed passer from Maryland, signed with the Cincinnati Bengals. Terms of the contract were not announced.

title: Censored Speech Printed but Not Spoken
description: A newspaper printed an entire high school valedictory speech today, one that was never delivered because the principal objected to its criticism of his administration.

title: Louisiana Panel Backs New Fair Guarantees
description: A State Senate committee has approved a bill allowing $15 million in state loan guarantees, the first step toward bailing out the New Orleans World's Fair.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAN UPSET BY BANK THROWS ACID ON POLICE OFFICERS
description: A 70-year-old man who was upset because he thought a bank had given him worthless checks when he withdrew more than $98,000 in savings smashed windows in the bank yesterday and then threw sulfuric acid on police officers who tried to subdue him, the police said.

title: ROMBAUER FAMILY: JOY OF REMEMBERING
description: CINCINNATI EDGAR ROMBAUER JR. picked up a photograph from a heap of papers and stared at it disapprovingly.

title: MONDALE FORCES PUT FOES' PLANS IN THE PLATFORM
description: The Democratic platform drafters favoring Walter F. Mondale became more conciliatory today and put into the statement of party principles a good deal of language that had been drafted by his rivals for the Presidential nomination, Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: The Fiction of Truth
description: The end of the world seems near now that our colleagues at The New Yorker, that fountainhead of unhurried fact, turn out to tolerate, even to justify fictions masquerading as facts. Quotes that weren't ever spoken, scenes that never existed, experiences that no one ever had - all are said to be permissible in journalism, provided they're composed by honest reporters to illustrate a deeper truth.

title: New Low-Fare London Flights
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board granted temporary authority for Virgin Atlantic Airways P.L.C. of Britain to offer low fares on trans-Atlantic flights. Virgin Atlantic was started by Richard Branson, an entertainment impresario whose activities include promoting the rock group Culture Club and its lead singer, Boy George.

title: REAGAN HAILS ENVIRONMENTAL RECORD
description: President Reagan defended his environmental record today, claiming ''great progress'' in the year since a management scandal forced widespread changes in the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: PUNJAB SOLUTION NOW SEEN AS FAR OFF
description: A solution to the issues at the heart of the crisis in Punjab appears far off, according to politicians and political scientists.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Opera and the Odeon

title: Jury in Rape Case Clears Bartenders
description: A Superior Court jury today found three bartenders not guilty of sexual assault charges brought by a 20-year- old Ringwood woman who said she was raped on a tavern pool table.

title: JACKSON SEES POLITICAL MOVE IN MONDALE SEARCH FOR NO. 2
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today called the procession of potential Vice-Presidential candidates to meet with Walter F. Mondale a ''P.R. parade of personalities'' designed to capture press attention at a lull in the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (WINTER HAVEN) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Spain's Trade Gap Cut
description: Spain's foreign trade deficit narrowed by about half, to the equivalent of $2.13 billion in the first five months of 1984, from the period a year ago, the Directorate General of Customs said today. Imports rose 10 percent but exports went up 46 percent, the agency said.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $115,351 for the quarter and $1,265,351 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. d-Including a tax credit of $220,291. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting methods.

title: WOMEN'S SCHOOLS, NOW COED, SHORT OF MEN
description: More than a decade after shifting to coeducation, many former women's colleges in the New York area say they are not attracting enough qualified male students.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING OFF 10.5%
description: New home construction dropped 10.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline, to a still-strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.78 million units, had been expected in light of rising interest rates. It followed a 19.7 percent gain in April.

title: Candidate for Congress Dies
description: Fred Craner, the Democratic candidate for Congress in the First District, died Monday in an automobile accident as he and his family were returning home from the Democratic State Convention here. His wife and four grandchildren suffered cuts and bruises. Party officials began searching for a successor today.

title: PEE WEE HERMAN PLAYS 'A COOL PLACE'
description: This is a pivotal time for Pee Wee Herman, that high-strung pencil- headed little guy who drops in on David Letterman every few weeks or so and shoves toy helicopters at him and cries ''Watch out for your face, David!''

title: Black Caucus PAC Agrees To Pay Fine
description: The political action committee of the Congressional Black Caucus has agreed to pay a $250 fine for several minor campaign law violations, according to Federal Election Commission documents released Monday.

title: OPERA: REAL FIREWORKS FOR THE PARK'S 'RINALDO'
description: SAMUEL RAMEY'S thunderous entrance aria, sung from a dragon-shaped chariot, stopped the show when the Metropolitan Opera mounted Handel's ''Rinaldo'' this past season in a lavish production by Frank Corsaro. But does it work without the chariot?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TORCHBEARER The Statue of Liberty is undergoing rehabilitation after almost a hundred years of serving as receptionist at the door to the nation's largest immigrant port, and it seems an appropriate time for looking back. The New- York Historical Society, one of the city's most perceptive back-lookers, at 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400), today opens an unusual photographic exhibition about our statue.

title: 8 Injured as Ferry From S.I. Crashes
description: Eight passengers were injured yesterday, none seriously, when a ferryboat from Staten Island struck the docking racks at South Ferry at 7:50 A.M.

title: A CITY THAT CAN DO THE STRADIVARIUS STRUT
description: When the violinist Isaac Stern appeared at a Washington party recently, he brought with him, naturally, his Stradivarius violin. That made it a Seven-Strad party since the Cleveland Quartet played on four of the great instruments at the same event, Mstislav Rostropovich played on a Stradivarius cello and the party's guest of honor, David Lloyd Kreeger, whose birthday it was, played on his own Stradivarius violin.

title: GRAND JURY CHARGES 2 IN MASSACHUSETTS WITH TAKING BRIBES
description: The No. 3 leader of the Massachusetts House and a former city alderman were indicted today by a Federal grand jury. They were charged with extorting money from a mall developer in exchange for helping the mall obtain liquor licenses.

title: MARKET RESEARCH, AT A SCAN
description: FIRST there was Nabscan. Then

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it was offering $100 million worth of seven-year 13 3/4 percent notes due on June 15, 1991.

title: A NIGHT IN BROOKLYN
description: There was a party on the shoreline

title: 'JFK,' DRAMATIZATION ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''JFK - A ONE-MAN SHOW'' is a curious enterprise. Mike Farrell, who was B. J. Hunnicutt in ''M*A*S*H,'' plays John F. Kennedy talking about himself. He also recites speeches. This is meant to be a history lesson of sorts, dramatized insights into a President and his times. In fact, there are precious few insights, and drama is notable only for its absence. The 90- minute program, with Walter Cronkite as host, will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Wyeth Vaccine
description: The American Home Products Corporation said its Wyeth Laboratories Division had ceased production of pertussis vaccine, used to immunize children against whooping cough, because of possible liability problems associated with the shots.

title: SCREEN: FUGARD STARS IN LAST OF HIS TRILOGY
description: ''MARIGOLDS IN AUGUST,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is the third in the trilogy of small, remarkably vivid and moving South African films written by - and starring - Athol Fugard and directed with informed devotion to the material by Ross Devenish. ''Marigolds'' also reunites Mr. Fugard with Winston Ntshona and John Kani, the two splendid actors with whom he collaborated in the creation of two of his best plays, ''Sizwe Banzi Is Dead'' and ''The Island.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AT this season thoughts of food often turn to salads, which these days may be served cold, at room temperature or even lukewarm. Making salads invariably brings to my mind the old Spanish proverb that says it takes four people to prepare a good dressing: ''a spendthrift for oil, a miser for vinegar, a counselor for salt and a madman to stir it all up.'' In English, I am told, this is credited to Abraham Hayward's essay ''The Art of Dining.''

title: 4 in Group Raise Offer for Enstar
description: Four companies said they had sweetened their bid for the Enstar Corporation to the equivalent of $19 a share, plus 12.5 percent interest on the cash amount.

title: RICHARD ERNST OF BLOOMINGDALE UNIT IS DEAD
description: Richard C. Ernst, former chairman of Bloomingdale Properties and a founder of Atheneum Publishers, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and also had homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Elk Lake in the Adirondacks.

title: ART IN THE MAKING AT O'NEILL CENTER
description: In the lunch line, the subject was counterpoint. Later in the afternoon, scripts in hand and shoes off feet, the actors rehearsed. And at night, the sound of keyboards, both piano and typewriter, drifted through the dogwoods and out toward Long Island Sound.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including gains of $750 for the quarter and $4,620 for the 6 months on the purchase of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures. c-Including gains of $3,350 for the quarter and $13,850 for the 6 months on the purchase of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Turkish Press Officials Quit To Protest Government Move
description: The board of directors of Turkey's semiofficial press agency, Anatolia, resigned today to protest the Government's decision to put the agency under control of a state office.

title: Drunken Boaters Sought on Hudson
description: Rockland County is getting a boat to patrol the Hudson River because of the increasing number of complaints about drunken boaters, officials said.

title: U.S. CITES SCIENTIST'S ERRORS IN DENYING A GRANT REQUEST
description: The National Institutes of Health have declined to renew a grant to a renowned Swiss biologist, Dr. Karl Illmensee, after an international commission found he had committed a number of significant errors in his research.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $389,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of a building and relocation costs of $76,000 for the quarter and $274,000 for the year.

title: SIKHS PREPARE TALKS IN U.S. ON STRATEGY
description: Sikhs around the world have been invited to take part in a meeting at Espanola, N.M., on June 23-24 to formulate a joint program of action in response to developments in the Indian state of Punjab.

title: No Headline
description: The first semi-submersible oil drilling rig built in China was completed today at the Shanghai Shipyard, the New China News Agency reported.

title: 4 IRANIANS SEEK ASYLUM IN FRANCE AFTER 8 ARRIVE ON HIJACKED PLANE
description: France said today that eight Iranians, one a senior naval officer, arrived in Nice today on a commandeered Iranian aircraft. Four of them asked for asylum.

title: Crocker Cuts Its Dividend
description: Directors of the Crocker National Corporation, parent of the financially ailing Crocker National Bank, reduced the common stock dividend yesterday for the second time this year. The board declared a dividend of 10 cents a share, down from the 30- cent payment made this spring.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
EISENHOWER VS. CASTRO
description: To the Editor:

title: Telex to Purchase Raytheon Data Unit
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell the assets of its Data Systems division to the Telex Corporation for more than $200 million.

title: Sather to Lead Team
description: Glen Sather , the coach of the Stanley Cup champion Edmonton Oilers, was named general manager and coach of the Canadian national team that will compete for the Canada Cup this fall against teams from the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Sweden, the United States and West Germany. . . . The Devils and the Black Hawks completed the three- player trade in which the forward Bobby McMillan went to Chicago for the defenseman Don Dietrich and the forward Rich Preston . Dietrich was one of two members of Team Canada who were disqualified from the Winter Olympics last February because of past professional experience.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT happened to Katharine Hepburn in ''Coco''

title: SENATE DEFEATS A PROPOSAL TO BAN SEA-BASED NUCLEAR CRUISE MISSILES
description: The Senate, moving toward approval of its $230 billion military authorization bill, rejected an attempt today to impose a moratorium on deployment of nuclear- armed cruise missiles at sea.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Doing Justice in Albany ; Cut Time, Cut Crime
description: If you're arrested for a misdemeanor in New York City, your chances of going to trial are virtually nil. Almost all such cases are dismissed or decided by plea bargain. Yet the threat of a trial plays a powerful role in the disposition of cases and encourages delays that have all but paralyzed the criminal court. The Legislature could ease the paralysis by reducing sentence limits.

title: SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of a subsidiary of $2,315,000.

title: '47 ANTITRUST RULEDISAVOWED
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a longstanding principle of antitrust law, ruling that the prohibition against conspiracies to restrain trade does not apply to joint actions of a parent company and a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: U.S. RECORD SET BY JONES AT TRIALS
description: Carl Lewis, on his first long jump tonight, made the United States Olympic team in that event. But even the world champion was overshadowed by a record 800-meter run that put John Marshall of Villanova on the Olympic team and kept Don Paige and James Robinson off it.

title: ROYAL INTERNATIONAL OPTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEDICAL BODY VOTES TO HELP IN CUTTING COSTS
description: The American Medical Association, concerned about the impact of medical care costs on the image of the profession and about increasing Federal involvement in health affairs, today took a series of moderate actions intended to cooperate in efforts to control costs.

title: PROFILES IN DENIM
description: 1.*Facing Up to the Past

title: LaRouche Challenges Outcome of Jersey Race
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., a Democratic Presidential candidate, has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court challenging the outcome of the June 5 primary in New Jersey.

title: Personal Income Up 0.6% in May
description: Americans' personal income rose six- tenths of 1 percent in May, matching April's gain, the Commerce Department reported today. But in the overall category, wages and salaries grew much more slowly than in April.

title: Berra Dispute Reported
description: For the second time in recent weeks, Yogi Berra had a heated confrontation with George Steinbrenner during a staff meeting last Sunday, sources familiar with the meeting said today. According to the sources, the manager and the owner engaged in an exchange about the team's attitude on the field that became increasingly stronger.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE FURTHER
description: Bond prices slipped further yesterday in light trading, as participants in the credit markets reacted negatively to a series of economic and funding reports.

title: JEWISH GROUPS PRESS U.N. CHIEF ON ANTI-SEMITISM
description: American Jewish leaders met with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today to ask his help in combating what they see as persistent anti- Semitism at the United Nations.

title: CALIFORNIA CUISINE: FRESH AND FADDISH
description: SAN FRANCISCO AMERICA is flexing its gastronomic muscles, and nowhere is this more obvious than in California. Here, where chefs are as glamorous as movie stars and today's new dish is tomorrow's discard, preoccupation with the latest food trends surpasses most other leisure- time activity. But innovation, which has led to much-admired and often-copied creations, is, unfortunately, often practiced for its own sake.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. GRANTS UTAH TEAM APPROVAL FOR IMPLANT OF 2D ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Approval for the world's second implant of a permanent artificial heart was granted to researchers at the University of Utah yesterday by officials of the Food and Drug Administration in Washington.

title: WATCHDOG PATROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trends in Trash

title: BEA GOODMAN ROBINS
description: Bea Goodman Robins, founder and former president of Fala Direct Marketing Inc. of Melville, L.I., died of a heart attack Monday at her home in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: STRIKERS REBUKED BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today condemned what she described as ''scenes of mob rule and intimidation'' in the 100-day- old coal strike, a day after the worst outbreak of industrial violence in Britain's postwar history in Yorkshire.

title: A TENOR IN OPERAS
description: Davis Cunningham, a tenor prominent in opera, musical comedy and television throughout the 1950's, died apparently of a heart attack yesterday in San Diego. He was 68 years old.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
NETS PICK FORWARD; 3 CUBS DEAL 5 PLAYERS
description: As expected, the Houston Rockets and the Portland Trail Blazers made Akeem Olajuwon and Sam Bowie the first and second selections yesterday in the National Basketball Association college draft. The unexpected did not occur until after the second round, when the trading ban imposed midnight Monday was removed. The Washington Bullets, the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Seattle SuperSonics completed a deal involving five players, including Gus Williams and Cliff Robinson, both outstanding scorers.

title: Ethnic Tension in Yugoslavia
description: Ten ethnic Albanians living in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province received jail terms of 3 to 12 years today for antistate activities and hostile propaganda. A court in the provincial capital of Pristina said the 10 advocated armed struggle and formed an illegal group aimed at joining Kosovo - populated mainly by ethnic Albanians - with neighboring Albania.

title: New Attacks Reported In Afghan Capital
description: Nine people, including a Soviet professor and a retired Afghan general, have been killed by guerrillas in Kabul, and 10,000 Soviet troops backed by tanks and bombers carried out a big offensive in Herat, Western diplomats in Pakistan reported today.

title: THE BIASES OF CORPORATE BOARD MEMBERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGHTING THE FIRES OF BLACK-JEWISH HOSTILITY
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, participated in a debate recently at Brooklyn College, and the atmosphere in the room left him shaken.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: CPC International Inc., a grocery products company in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said it had completed the sale of $75 million of senior extendable notes due June 1991. Salomon Brothers assisted in the private placing of the notes with institutional investors.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Steve Carlton of Philadelphia, a certain Hall of Fame selection, faces an emerging star, Ron Darling. The Phillies are without Joe Lefebvre, a line- drive hitter who injured his knee in Chicago on Sunday while chasing a fly ball. He has been put on the 15-day disabled list. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ex-Chicago Aide Sentenced
description: James Canoff, a former City Attorney who admitted taking $5,800 to fix traffic cases, was fined $5,000 and placed on probation today for wrongdoing uncovered by a Federal investigation of corruption in the court system here.

title: Managing Editor Is Named By The Washington Post
description: The Washington Post announced Monday that Leonard Downie Jr. had been appointed managing editor effective July 23. He will be responsible for the newspaper's daily operations.

title: Seabrook Utility's Notes
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire has sold $90 million in one-year notes, and its financial adviser said today that the cash infusion could be the first step toward resuming work on the Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NEW ENGLAND UTILITIES TO BUY CANADA POWER
description: Officials representing utilities in all six New England states and Hydro- Quebec signed a preliminary agreement yesterday for the Canadian utility to provide electricity imports worth about $2.5 billion in the 1990's.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT RECAPTURED ISLAND AREA
description: The Iraqi commander of the Third Army Corps was quoted today as having said that his forces had recaptured more areas of Majnoon Island from Iranian troops.

title: Uruguay Lists Charges Against Opposition Chief
description: The Government says a military judge has formally charged the presidential candidate Wilson Ferreira Aldunate with aiding subversion and three other counts.

title: WITNESS IN BOSTON RECALLS HANDLING OF CASH
description: A former city official testified today that Theodore V. Anzalone gave him $5,000 in cash to be converted into checks and sent to a fund for the wife of Kevin H. White, then Mayor of Boston.

title: Change of Heart
description: Less than a week after he had accepted a position as head basketball coach at Dartmouth, Mike Steele told Dartmouth officials that he had made a mistake and would remain the coach at DePauw. Steele gave no reason for the change, but Dartmouth wasted no time in naming a successor to Reggie Minton , who left for the Air Force Academy. The newest Dartmouth coach is Paul Cormier , who had been an assistant at Villanova.

title: STOP THE WITCH-HUNT FOR CHILD MOLESTERS
description: This year, millions of children will be abused, though not sexually. But most of the reports in the media will be about sexual abuse. As a result, other maltreatment of children - physical abuse, neglect, endangering and emotional abuse - will remain in the shadow of sexual misconduct, even though most child-abuse cases are not sexual.

title: Soviet Submarine Is Trapped By Norwegian Fishing Wire
description: A Soviet submarine was trapped for three and a half hours today in the fishing wire of a Norwegian trawler in international waters, the Norwegian Navy reported.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COUNCIL BACKS CHANGES IN DEVELOPERS' TAX BREAKS
description: The City Council yesterday endorsed a bill that the Koch administration described as a needed change in its tax benefit policies but that critics said would strip the city government of bargaining power with developers in some areas of Manhattan.

title: Son of Andropov Gets Post
description: The son of Yuri V. Andropov, the former Soviet leader, has been appointed Ambassador to Greece, Eastern European sources said today. The son, Igor Y. Andropov, has been deputy head of the Soviet delegation to the disarmament conference here.

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH SHUFFLES EXECUTIVES
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation announced what it said was probably the largest management shuffle in its 56-year history. The forest products concern based in San Francisco promoted or transferred 10 vice presidents in its continuing attempt to revive its sagging revenues.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20, 1984
description: Companies

title: REGIONAL ROLL CALL ON ALIEN AMNESTY
description: Following are the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today approved an amendment by the majority leader, Representative Jim Wright, to offer legal status to illegal aliens who have lived in this country since 1982. A ''yes'' vote is for the Wright amendment and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: INJURY FORCES NOAH OUT OF WIMBLEDON
description: Yannick Noah has withdrawn from next week's Wimbledon championships because of an abdominal strain, the All-England club announced today.

title: MONDALE, BEFORE UNIONISTS, PREDICTS AND UPSET LIKE TRUMAN'S IN '48
description: Walter F. Mondale, waving his arms, his face flushed, told an enthusiastic union audience today that he was an underdog in the Presidential campaign, like Harry S. Truman in 1948, and that like Truman he would upset the Republican Party in November.

title: ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN POLITICAL SOLUTION: TIME IS RUNNING OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: CELEBRATION FOR A CLASSIC RESTAURANT
description: IF there is any place in New York

title: Purvis Holds Slim Lead In Primary Recount
description: The Rev. Melvin Purvis clung to a 320- vote lead over Cecil Williams for the Democatic Senate nomination to oppose the Republican incumbent, Strom Thurmond, after primary ballots were recounted in 44 of South Carolina's 46 counties.

title: EX-CITY OFFICIAL PLEADS GUILTY
description: New York City's former director of lease negotiations pleaded guilty yesterday to racketeering charges that prosecutors said involved the extortion of nearly $1.2 million from landlords of privately owned buildings.

title: COMMERCIAL RESTORATION ON BROOKLYN WATERFRONT
description: Although state and city redevelopment of Fulton Landing, a 15-acre Brooklyn waterfront tract between the Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan Bridge, has been stalled, a private effort to create new office space in the area's partly vacant industrial buildings is continuing.

title: Town, in 4th Attempt, Elects an Alderman
description: Voters finally picked a winner in the race for city alderman today, re-electing John Roach in balloting that had ended in ties in three previous elections.

title: BRIEFING
description: Counterfeit Marines

title: Rangers 4, Angels 2
description: Gary Ward slugged a two-run homer, and Dave Stewart and Odell Jones combined on a five-hitter for Texas.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: 3 Quebec By-Elections Are Won by Liberals
description: Liberals swept three Quebec by-elections in suburban Montreal districts Monday, extending to 21 the number of by-elections lost by the Parti Quebecois since it took power in 1976.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Balloons for Soaring Scores

title: U.S. Fights Arco's Deal With Alcan
description: The Justice Department, challenging a deal that could be valued at more than $1 billion, said today that it would not let the Atlantic Richfield Company carry out a plan announced in January to sell the bulk of its aluminum industry assets to Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canada.

title: DISKS BY YOUNG JAZZ FESTIVAL ARTISTS
description: JAZZ is a music that strives to define the character of the moment at which it is being played, and each player brings to this act of definition the sum total of his or her experiences and wisdom. Given this state of affairs, it would seem that a jazz festival, like the Kool marathon that begins Friday, should provide a forum for younger players who live the rhythms and textures of these times with particular intensity, as well as for the music's elder statesmen. Fortunately, these younger musicians are better represented on disks, as well as on the Kool festival schedule, than in years past.

title: AN UNAUTHORIZED 'ULYSSES' EDITOR'S CONFESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TELLS KUWAIT IT CAN'T HAVE MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration has informed Kuwait that because of political opposition in Congress, it will be unable to supply it with Stinger antiaircraft missiles for defense against possible Iranian attack, State Department officials said today.

title: SPECIALISTS SOUGHT IN ACCOUNTING
description: THOUGH they are expert at handling figures, accountants apparently have a hard time accounting for accountants - adding up, that is, how many accountants there are at any given time.

title: ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN POLITICAL SOLUTION: TIME IS RUNNING OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: N.B.A. Draft Selections in the 1984 National Basketball Association draft: FIRST ROUND 1, Houston, Akeem Olajuwon, c, Houston; 2, Portland, Sam Bowie, c, Kentucky; 3, Chicago, Michael Jordan, g-f, North Carolina; 4, Dallas, Sam Perkins, f, North Carolina; 5, Philadelphia (from San Diego), Charles Barkley, f, Auburn; 6, Washington, Melvin Turpin, c, Kentucky; 7, San Antonio, Alvin Robertson, g, Arkansas; 8, San Diego (from Golden State), Lancaster Gordon, g, Louisville; 9, Kansas City, Otis Thorpe, f, Providence; 10, Philadelphia, Leon Wood, g, Fullerton St.; 11, Atlanta, Kevin Willis, f, Michigan St.; 12, Cleveland, Tim McCormick, c-f, Michigan; 13, Phoenix, Jay Humphries, g, Colorado; 14, San Diego, Michael Cage, f, San Diego St.; 15, Dallas, Terence Stansbury, g, Temple; 16, Utah, John Stockton, g, Gonzaga; 17, Nets, Jeff Turner, f, Vanderbilt; 18, Indiana (from Knicks), Vern Fleming, g, Georgia; 19, Portland, Bernard Thompson, f, Fresno St.; 20, Detroit, Tony Campbell, f, Ohio St.; 21, Milwaukee, Kenny Fields, f, U.C.L.A.; 22, Philadelphia, Tom Sewell, g, Lamar; 23, Los Angeles, Earl Jones, f, District of Columbia; 24, Boston, Michael Young, f, Houston. SECOND ROUND 25, Indiana, Devin Durrant, f, Brigham Young; 26, Portland (from Chicago via Indiana), Victor Fleming, g, Xavier, Ohio; 27, Cleveland, Ron Anderson, f, Fresno St.; 28, Seatlle (from Houston), Cory Blackwell, f, Wisconsin; 29, Indiana (from San Diego via Philadelphia), Stuart Gray, c, U.C.L.A.; 30, Golden State (from Washington), Steve Burtt, g, Iona; 31, Golden State, Jay Murphy, f, Boston College; 32, Detroit (from San Antonio), Eric Turner, g, Michigan; 33, Portland (from Denver), Steve Colter, g, New Mexico St.; 34, Washington (from Kansas City via Detroit and Atlanta), Tony Costner, c, St. Joseph's, Pa.; 35, Golden State (from Atlanta), Othell Wilson, g, Virginia; 36, Phoenix, Charles Jones, f-c, Louisville; 37, Chicago (from Seattle via Atlanta and Kansas City), Ben Coleman, f, Maryland; 38, Dallas, Charles Sitton, f, Oregon St.; 39, Seattle (from Nets), Danny Young, g, Wake Forest; 40, Dallas (from Utah), Anthony Teachey, f-c, Wake Forest; 41, Dallas (from Knicks via Nets), Tom Sluby, g, Notre Dame; 42, Denver (from Portland), Willie White, g, Tenn.

title: USENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ELMO GIORDANETTI
description: Elmo Giordanetti, a professor and past chairman of Romance languages at Amherst College, has died of cancer at the age of 58.

title: Massey Layoffs
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it planned to close its harvester plant in Marquette in northern France and lay off all of the plant's 1,430 employees for a least three months because of abnormally high stocks. Production at the plant is forecast to fall to 415 harvesters this year, from 620 in 1983. A spokesman said an annual level of 1,200 was needed to maintain the current work force.

title: U.N. Says Flow of Refugees From Vietnam Tripled in May
description: The number of boat people fleeing Vietnam by sea more than tripled in May from previous months this year, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Aircal Will Add New Boeing 737's
description: Aircal Inc. said it would buy nine and lease three new Boeing 737-300 airplanes in a deal valued at more than $300 million.

title: LIFE INSURER STOCK CHOICES
description: LIFE insurance companies have changed radically in recent years. A major reason is the

title: GOVERNORS BAR SALE OF TRADE CENTER
description: Governor Cuomo and Governor Kean declared today that the World Trade Center would not be sold.

title: McEnroe Scolded
description: John McEnroe 's 10-minute tirade against officials at the Queen's Club tournament in London on Sunday has drawn a chorus of denunciations in the British press and a proposal from a Member of Parliament to punish the tennis star for his repeated outbursts. Calling McEnroe a ''lout'' who uses ''gutter language,'' Harry Greenway , a Conservative member and a qualified tennis umpire, proposed an international ban on the American and said he would raise the matter in Parliament.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RILKE: A Life. By Wolfgang Leppmann. Translated from the German in collaboration with the author by Russell M. Stockman. Verse translations by Richard Exner. 421 pages. Illustrated. Fromm International Publishing Corporation. $22.50.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advest Group, Hartford, a financial services company, has elected A. Clinton Allen 3d chairman and chief executive officer of its recently acquired subsidiary, Burgess & Leith Inc.

title: FARED ROBOT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are for the quarter ended April 30, 1983. The company changed its fiscal year-end.

title: HOLLYWOOD PLANS NEW RATING TO PROTECT CHILDREN UNDER 13
description: The motion picture industry, whose rating system has been under attack recently by parents, movie critics and theater owners, is negotiating the first major change in its rating code since the system was introduced 16 years ago.

title: OUTLAYS FOR THE RAISING OF A CHILD ARE LINKED TO FAMILY SIZE
description: The ''typical'' middle-income family with two children and a wife working part time spends almost $100,000 in 1981 prices to raise each child from birth until it graduates from a four- year public college, a study has found.

title: 2 FUGITIVE BROTHERS CAPTURED BY F.B.I. AT CAR REPAIR SHOP
description: Two brothers who escaped with four other convicted murderers from a Virginia prison last month were recaptured here tonight by more than 20 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the authorites said.

title: A Throwaway Vote in Europe
description: To understand the meaning, or non-meaning, of this week's elections to a European Parliament, imagine Democrats and Republicans arguing about tax rates in this country in the course of a campaign for seats in a Pan-American Legislature. Then imagine Canadian Liberals and Conservatives simultaneously competing for seats in the same remote body by debating bilingualism; Argentine Radicals and Peronists debating their foreign debt; Jamaican National and Labor candidates debating the bauxite business, and so on.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Facing Off Over a Stadium

title: HEALTH-CARE DATA UNFIT FOR PUBLIC CONSUMPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: A common misperception among wine enthusiasts goes something like this: The California wine business was founded by Spanish friars who, with the aid of faithful peasants and a few Indians, kept it going until the first Italian immigrants turned up in the 19th century. The Italians immediately built million-gallon cellars and invented jug wine. It was mediocre stuff but it was the best anyone could do until around 1964. That was when Robert Mondavi and a couple of other fellows invented fine California wine.

title: SOVIET TO SIGN SCHOLARS' PACT
description: The Soviet Academy of Sciences said today that it was now willing to renew an accord for the exchange of senior scholars. The papers are to be signed in New York and Moscow on Wednesday.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Changes at I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said a variety of graphics capabilities previously available on its larger computers would be offered for its System/38. I.B.M. also said that terminals used with its intermediate and large systems could now be attached to System/38 by remote communications lines. The company said it had also improved its Office/38 application programs, and added communications lines and PL/1 programming language capabilities. All enhancements will be available this month.

title: CHILDHOODS RECALLED
description: THEY are adults now, but they

title: HEADING COUNSELING OF TIME'S WORKERS
description: Edward J. Small, manager of employee assistance programs for The New York Times, died of lung cancer Monday at New York University Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DiBernardo Gets Some Distance
description: When the Cosmos asked four of their highest-priced players to take a salary cut several weeks ago, all of them initially balked and as a result were placed on waivers. Three of them - Hubert Birkenmeier, Jeff Durgan and Steve Moyers - were ultimately re-signed by the team at reduced pay, but the fourth, Angelo DiBernardo, was so miffed at the entire episode that he said he wanted only to get as far away from the Cosmos as possible.

title: Fast-Food Changes In Detroit, Chicago
description: There is some fast-food account action to report on from Detroit and Chicago. And you'll find the beef at neither.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a loss of $38,676 from discontinued operations.

title: KNIFE IN THE GARDEN
description: Dr. Harold J. Liverworth, the world's foremost authority, usually leaves me breathless with awe, but this time he has my blood boiling. I refer to his excursion into gardening which has resulted in his new book, ''The Name of the Game Is Pruning.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Marathon Unit Reaches $650 Million Loan Deal
description: The Marathon Oil Company's British subsidiary said today that it had reached a $650 million financing arrangement with 20 international banks for development of the North Brae field, an offshore gas condensate project in the British sector of the North Sea.

title: Levi Strauss Net Off 85%; 9 Plants to Close
description: Levi Strauss & Company reported today that its second-quarter net income fell 85 percent and identified nine plants employing 2,500 people that it plans to close.

title: FIRST HISPANIC HEAD OF MAYORS' CONFERENCE: HERNAN PADILLA
description: Dr. Hernan Padilla, the 46-year-old Mayor of San Juan, P.R., whose string of electoral victories goes back to his high school days, won his easiest race today when he was elected without opposition as the president of the United States Conference of Mayors. The choice made Dr. Padilla, a Republican in an organization that has about twice as many Democrats as Republicans, the group's first Hispanic president. He succeeded Richard H. Fulton of Nashville.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
No Headline
description: Panel Votes Subpoena Of Air Force Official

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allied Stores Corp . said shareholders had approved amendments to the certificate of incorporation that would raise the number of authorized common shares to 75 million from 30 million and would allow for the issuance of 10 million shares of preferred stock.

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income figures represent income before minority interest.

title: Protesters Disrupt Hearing on Death
description: Demonstrators yesterday interrupted a court hearing for three transit police officers accused of manslaughter in the death of a 25- year-old Brooklyn man.

title: CITICORP IS SAID TO CHOOSE REED AS NEW CHIEF
description: Citicorp, the world's largest banking organization, has named John S. Reed, an engineer by training and a consumer marketing executive by experience, to succeed Walter B. Wriston as chairman and chief executive, according to sources within the bank.

title: HBO'S FILM DRAMA ON SAKHAROV
description: -TV takes a giant step forward this evening at 8 o'clock with the kind of production that used to be the monopolized prestige staple of commercial television.

title: STOCKS RISE ON A SLOWING ECONOMY
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in slower trading, buoyed by additional evidence that the nation's economy is moderating, a trend that tends to depress interest rates.

title: CHAIRMAN TITLE ADDED BY THE CHIEF OF TRIANGLE
description: Nelson Peltz, who led a takeover of Triangle Industries in 1983, has assumed the chairmanship of the company, in addition to his position of chief executive officer. His associate, Peter W. May, formerly vice chairman, has been named president of the company, a post vacated by Mr. Peltz. Mr. May continues as chief operating officer.

title: 13 Diverse Conrail Bids Are Received by U.S.
description: The Transportation Department said today that it had received 13 bids for Conrail, the Northeast's principal freight railroad, which is largely owned by the Government.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Night after middle of the night, his wife would tell him to give it up, David, and come to bed. But David Mintz of Brooklyn would not come to bed. The world was out there waiting, he said, just waiting for a soybean- curd-based frozen desert. He could not, would not, rest until Tofutti was invented.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation received a $133.4 million Army contract for trucks, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Puerto Rico Sun Oil Company was given a $61.4 million contract by the Defense Logistics Agency for fuel, and Sanders Associates Inc. received a $37.4 million Air Force contract for spare parts for countermeasures test equipment.

title: Banking Bill Curb Deleted
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee unexpectedly announced today that he would remove from the bank regulation bill he is sponsoring a provision that would have forced commercial banks to get out of discount stock brokerage activities.

title: Bridge: An Australian Comes Up With a Book of Problems
description: To find a connection between a tropical rain forest and a book of bridge problems might seem an impossible task.

title: IN THE CITY BY THE BAY, FINE RESTAURANTS ABOUND
description: SAN FRANCISCO Those attending the Democratic National Convention, and other visitors as well, will find San Francisco a wonderful restaurant city. This is the birthplace of California cuisine, the light, straightforward style of cooking that emphasizes freshness and the use of local ingredients. On a recent weeklong visit it was a pleasure to find that many of the restaurants that were innovators of the California style are still in the vanguard.

title: REAGAN INSISTS ON LINKING FUNDS FOR JOBS TO NICARAGUAN OPERATION
