description: President Reagan today rebuffed a plan by Senate Republicans for separate votes on financing for a summer job program and covert aid to Nicaraguan insurgents, despite an erosion of bipartisan Senate support for the Nicaraguan operation.

title: Bertelsmann Venture
description: Bertelsmann A.G. said today that it was negotiating with three major American film companies on a joint pay-television project in West Germany. The West German media group would not disclose details of talks with the three, MGM/UA, MCA and Paramount Pictures. But the Government's Cartel Office said that Bertelsmann had formally notified it of intentions to form a joint venture, indicating that an agreement may be near.

title: 3 Killed as Copter Crashes Off Jersey
description: A helicopter flying from Atlantic City to Long Island plunged into the ocean off New Jersey during a sudden and violent rainstorm about 3 A.M. today, killing the pilot, co-pilot and and the only passenger.

title: Supreme Court Refuses To Block Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to stop the execution of Carl Shriner, clearing the way for Florida to electrocute him Wednesday morning for killing a convenience store clerk.

title: QUESTIONS ON SWALE'S DEATH
description: Swale, the 3-year-old colt who won the Kentucky Derby last month and the Belmont Stakes 11 days ago, suddenly collapsed and died a few minutes after a light gallop at Belmont Park Sunday morning. The incident was a complete shock to the colt's handlers, and the cause of death has yet to be determined. The death has prompted numerous questions from racing fans and from the public:

title: ARIZONA ENTREPRENEUR HAS HIS EYES ON TOSCO
description: Alfred P. Sprenger likes risk. At 16 he crewed on cargo ships entering World War II battle zones. He made his first million at 27 by investing in real estate in Arizona. He has since increased his fortunes in high-risk ventures involving computers, lasers and other advanced technologies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are going to try to bring people out of the shadows.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE DAY THE SIRENS GREATLY ALARMED THE KUWAITIS
description: The air-raid sirens wailed at 11 A.M. sharp.

title: M.T.A. PLANS MONTHLY TICKET FOR USE IN DISCOUNT PROGRAM
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to proceed with the introduction of monthly subway, bus and commuter tickets that employers can sell at a discount to employees, the authority's general counsel said today.

title: A REPUTATION BASED ON A STYLISH MENU
description: ''WE'RE not a jet-set restaurant - and we never will be,'' declared Tom Margittai, co-owner of the Four Seasons. ''We don't get semiretired chairmen of the board. They go to '21.' We don't get fashion people or the fast-lane crowd. Fashion designers come, but not the people who wear their clothes. We get hard workers, achievers - the editors, the publishers, the architects.''

title: Creedmoor Is Getting An Interim Director
description: A Rockland County psychiatrist has been appointed interim director of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens, where a recent investigation has turned up evidence of patient abuse and financial improprieties, officials said yesterday.

title: Swimming Mark
description: Shaking off the nagging effects of sciatica, Victor Davis bettered his world record in the men's 200-meter breaststroke tonight at the Canadian Olympic team swim trials. The 20-year-old Canadian from Waterloo, Ontario, was clocked in 2 minutes 14.58 seconds, bettering his mark of 2:14.77.

title: COURT SHIELDS U.S. IN CRASH LIABILITY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government cannot be sued for damages from aviation accidents said to have been caused by the Federal Aviation Administration's failure to monitor an aircraft's design or manufacture properly.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20, 1984 International
description: A plan to impose a moratorium on deployment of nuclear-armed cruise missiles at sea was rejected by the Senate as it moved toward approval of a $230 billion military authorization bill. The moratorium was sought by Republicans. (Page A1, Cols. 2-3.) A shift by the White House on abortion is sought by the Agency for International Development. The agency has urged the Administration to reconsider a proposal to eliminate family-planning assistance to Governments and organizations that support abortion. (A10:1-2.)

title: RICH TO SELL FOX STAKE TO DAVIS
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil entrepreneur, has reached an agreement to buy the 50 percent stake of the 20th Century- Fox Film Corporation owned by Marc Rich, the fugitive commodity trader. Mr. Davis currently holds the other 50 percent.

title: Doing Justice in Albany ; Put Order in the Courts, Quickly
description: In its waning session, New York's Legislature is tantalizingly close to agreement on a state constitutional amendment that would fashion a single-tier statewide trial court out of tribunals that now label themselves Supreme, Civil, Criminal, Claims, Family and Surrogate.

title: SESSION ON WESTERN WATER RIGHTS FINDS NO QUICK CURE FOR CONFLICTS
description: A Capitol Hill meeting today to ease the mounting conflict between Indians and non-Indians over the West's scarce water resources produced more evidence of the issue's difficulties than hopes of an early solution to them.

title: National Lampoon Hires Pattis Group
description: In an unusual move, National Lampoon has dismissed its four-member advertising sales staff and has hired an advertising representative company to handle the chores. That company is the Pattis Group of Chicago, the country's largest magazine rep.

title: LATIN DEBTORS SEEK A STRATEGY
description: Latin America's leading debtor nations began meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, today to design a strategy to deal with their creditors without raising the specter of a regional moratorium on debt payments.

title: The U.N. Today June 20, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TIGERS RALLY IN 8TH TO OVERCOME YANKS
description: The move the Yankees began making Monday night toward the lofty perch inhabited by the Detroit Tigers ended abruptly tonight. The Tigers, rallying for four runs in the eighth inning against Ron Guidry, thwarted the would-be challengers, 7-6.

title: PRAISE FOR ZOELLER, NOT COURSE
description: Fuzzy Zoeller's victory over Greg Norman in the 18-hole playoff Monday for the United States Open championship left many involved in the 84th tournament happy that golf had such a charismatic champion. Many expressed optimism that Zoeller could do for golf what Arnold Palmer did 20 years ago - create a special enthusiasm for the sport among fans.

title: A PREDILECTION FOR GINGER LED TO CULINARY ADVENTURE
description: MOST cooks can recall a moment when they discovered - or rediscovered - a particular food, when a familiar ingredient suddenly seemed to reveal its distinctive taste for the first time.

title: SAN JOSE IS LOSING SOME OF ITS GLITTER
description: ''I want to be Mayor of a city that provides the simple things for its people - a cop on the beat, a library that opens, a park with programs, and a plan to control unneeded growth,'' San Jose's Mayor, Thomas McEnery, told his constituents after taking office 17 months ago.

title: CONCERT: AMERICAN NEW MUSIC GALA
description: THE American New Music Consortium's ''Gala Symphony Space Concert'' Monday night was anything but gala. Indeed, it was dispiriting in the extreme, so much so as to call into question the organization of this festival as a whole.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
D'Amato Is Planning to Ask Soviet About the Sakharovs
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato said today that he planned to fly to the Soviet Union on July 9 and would ask for evidence that Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, was alive.

title: NATIONAL PRIDE LIFTS ESPRIT FOR DISABLED
description: Most of the winners in the opening events at the International Games for the Disabled on Monday were from the big countries - the United States, Britain and Australia. Today, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark and Ireland posted victories as the two weeks of games got into full swing in field, track and swimming events.

title: INMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AGENT IN DELOREAN CASE ACKNOWLEDGES BACKDATING OF DOCUMENTS
description: Documents that formally authorized the recording of two videotapes of John Z. DeLorean, showing the automobile executive meeting with purported narcotics dealers, were prepared and backdated two months after the videotaping occurred, a Federal drug agent testified today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Foreman Officiates
description: The altar was on the 50-yard line, the bride was attended by cheerleaders, and, when the minister stepped forward to perform the ceremony, he threw a couple of mock punches at the guests. That's because he was George Foreman , the former heavyweight champion, who presided before 38,000 fans at the Astrodome Monday night during halftime of the Houston Gamblers' game against the San Antonio Gunslingers.

title: No Headline
description: Reagan Delays Action On Oil Lease Fee Plan

title: POLITICS AND TELEVISION
description: WOR- TV presented a two-hour report the other night on the influence of television on Presidential politics. It was a good and timely documentary, but seemed to conclude that the influence of television on politics was not good.

title: Africans Seeking To Ban British
description: The Supreme Council for Sport in Africa has called for a total African boycott of British sport in retaliation for an English rugby team's tour of South Africa, Henry Zongo, chairman of the council's executive committee, announced today.

title: Kodak Microfilm
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a high-speed microfilmer and a retrieval terminal capable of finding one microfilm image from among 10,000 or more in seconds.

title: LINSKYS' ART IS ON DISPLAY AT MUSEUM
description: The Jack and Belle Linsky Galleries, containing one of the greatest collections in this country of European art from the Renaissance and later periods, opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Former Beauty QueenAccused of Harassment
description: A former beauty queen was arrested for harassing a Mormon missionary she was accused of kidnapping and raping seven years ago in England, but her lawyer said Tuesday she did nothing wrong in shadowing the man.

title: PHILS LEAD BY 1 1/2
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, who have a long history of spoiling the party for the Mets, did it again last night when they defeated the Mets, 6-4, in a kind of preliminary battle for first place.

title: Official Flower
description: To the long list of things - from beers to cars to cupcakes - that are official products of the Summer Olympics, there is now one to add. It is the Games' official flower, a red rose produced by the Armstrong Nurseries of Los Angeles. And it has been named, appropriately enough, Olympiad.

title: HOUSE BACKS PLAN LEGALIZING ALIENS IN U.S. BEFORE 1982
description: The House of Representatives today tentatively approved a proposal that would offer legal status to illegal aliens who have lived continuously in the United States since Jan. 1, 1982.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: NICOTINE is the most widely used addicting drug among Americans except for caffeine. Although the percentage of nicotine addicts has declined dramatically since the Surgeon General's first ''Report on Smoking and Health'' 20 years ago, 55 million Americans - nearly a third of the adults and 20 percent of the teen- agers - continue to use tobacco. According to surveys, a majority of the adults who do so say they would like to quit, and most have tried to at least once.

title: WHITE HOUSE URGED NOT TO BAR AID TO COUNTRIES SUPPORTING ABORTION
description: The Agency for International Development has urged the White House to reconsider a proposal to eliminate family planning assistance to governments and organizations that support abortion.

title: CHILDREN OF INTERRACIAL MARRIAGE
description: WHAT about the children? This is the question that is universally asked of those in interracial marriages, said Dr. Alvin Poussaint, an associate professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School.

title: REFORM RABBIS PUT ASIDE LUBAVITCH CONFLICT
description: The nation's Reform Rabbis today turned aside moves to address growing tensions between themselves and Lubavitch Orthodox efforts to attract Jewish college students to Orthodox religious practices.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: No Headline
description: Dallas Clothier Moves To Avoid Deportation

title: Huffington Awaits Vote For Enstar Directors
description: It is a day of reckoning for Roy M. Huffington, the dissident stockholder attempting to purchase the Enstar Corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column on Tuesday incorrectly described B. J. Surhoff's status with the United States Olympic baseball team. Unlike the six other players listed with him, he has not been dropped. He has returned to the University of North Carolina to complete his summer- school requirements and is due to rejoin the team Saturday.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE MERITS OF RENOVATING RENTAL APARTMENTS
description: IT used to be simple economic common sense that making

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Women on State Ballots Look to National Ticket
description: Three of the five Democratic women running for the Senate in 1984 said today that their chances would be improved if the party nominated a woman for Vice President.

title: JUDGES HEAR CASE ON 1980 CAMPAIGN DOCUMENTS
description: A Justice Department lawyer told a Federal appeals court here today that the courts had no power to order appointment of an independent counsel to investigate how Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign obtained debate briefing papers from President Carter's campaign.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Work Ethic
description: Doug Spedding , the owner of the Denver Gold, thinks he knows why the club has lost eight of its last nine games: Coach Craig Morton hasn't been putting in enough hours. ''I've never met a guy who worked from 9 to 5 that could get it done,'' said Spedding, who made it clear that if Morton didn't start working 12 hours a day he would be out of a job at the end of the season. . . . The Pittsburgh Maulers have lost 14 of their 17 games so far this season, and, according to the club's president, Paul Martha , the financial losses have been even more dramatic. Including some $5 million in start-up costs for the expansion team, the Maulers will have lost more than $10 million this year, he said, or more than twice the average for the United States Football League.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Before the 4:57 P.M. local begins its run to New York, a quick refresher in Newtonian law: Distance and geography aside, once a body is set in motion, it tends to resist any attempt to change its speed or direction.

title: U.S. HEALTH AID URGES LOGGING OF JOB-INJURY DATA
description: The director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health told a House subcommittee today that physicians should be required to report cases of work-related injury or illness, as they now do communicable diseases.

title: Teahouse Blast Kills Woman
description: A gas cylinder exploded in a teahouse today, killing a 56-year-old woman and injuring 10 people, a Government spokesman said.

title: CUOMO VOWS TO FIGHT FOR EQUAL RIGHTS BILL
description: Governor Cuomo promised today to lead a final weekend effort to bring a proposed state equal rights amendment for women to a vote in the Senate. A vote has been blocked by Senate Republicans, who control the upper house.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pat Day, the nation's leading jockey the last two years, set a record at Churchill Downs yesterday with seven victories in eight mounts. He has won 64 races on 208 mounts at the track this meeting. . . . Bruce Hood, a National Hockey League referee since 1966, retired after working 1,033 games, a record for N.H.L. officials.

title: Abner Brothers Have Big Week
description: This is a big week for the Abner brothers of Mechanicsburg, Pa., at least as far as New York baseball is concerned.

title: CITICORP'S ATYPICAL LEADER: JOHN SHEPARD REED
description: When Scientific American magazine ran an advertisement profiling one of its readers six years ago, the headline was remarkably prescient: ''The Citi is banking on John Reed for the future.'' The ad copy itself said that Mr. Reed was convinced that banks ''must assimilate new marketing skills and technology, but he is keenly aware of resistance within the traditional banking community'' - a resistance he suggested reflected ''the genetic makeup of bankers.''

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings give retroactive effect to the 1-for-1 common stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend to shareholders of record on Sept. 15, 1983.

title: BOTH SIDES ARE WARY AS MITTERRAND ARRIVES IN SOVIET
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived here today for a visit that both he and the Russians are approaching warily.

title: Chrysler Property
description: Chrysler said it had purchased a 47- acre tract containing an idle steel mill for possible future expansion of its Warren truck assembly plant.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest 9 months net includes after-tax nonrecurring merger costs of $18.1 million, or 21 cents a share. American Medical International merged with the Lifemark Corp., effective Jan. 20.

title: AMERICAN JUSTICE OUGHT TO FACE A 'GRAND JURY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Shipyard Slump
description: With global shipping sluggish, South Korean shipyards saw foreign ship orders fall 49.3 percent in tonnage and 58 percent in monetary value during the first five months of 1984 from a year earlier, the Korea Shipbuilders Association said today. Foreign orders for 40 ships totaled 689,399 tons worth $438 million.

title: China Criticizes U.S. On Nuclear Pact Delay
description: Deputy Prime Minister Li Peng said today the United States would be the first to suffer financial loss if Congress blocked a nuclear cooperation agreement with Peking, the New China News Agency reported.

title: No Headline
description: Aviation Safety Risks Cited in Memorandum

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEW ISSUE IN EMBRYO CASE RAISED OVER USE OF DONOR
description: The case of two frozen embryos and a Los Angeles couple who died in a plane crash last year took on another complication today that may clear the way for the husband's son to inherit part of the couple's estate.

title: ;  Seagram & Sons In Shelf Offering
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., the United States unit of the Montreal- based Seagram Company, filed a shelf offering yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $250 million principal amount of guaranteed debt securities.

title: A BITTER AND PUZZLING GERMAN STRIKE
description: When Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany reached London for the recent economic summit meeting, the question he was asked most often had little to do with East-West ties, the world debt situation or the future of American interest rates.

title: TAX-RISE TARGETS FOR 1985 EMERGING
description: Even before a House-Senate conference committee has finished polishing the $50 billion tax-increase bill, its decisions and debate point to some likely targets next year. That is when both the Administration and Congress are expected to try to combine ''tax reform'' with a fresh effort to raise more revenues to shrink Federal budget deficits.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1984

title: Presidential Debate Debate
description: ''There you go again!'' That was Ronald Reagan's famous expression of exasperation at Jimmy Carter during the 1980 Presidential debate in Cleveland. He repeated it the other night, in response to something the former President said about Presidential debates in 1984.

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Circuit City Stores was formerly the Wards Company and it began trading today on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol: CC.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Stores Corp. has elected John T. Cullen senior executive vice president; Howard E. Hassler and James A. Walsh executive vice presidents; Frank R. D'Elia, Benjamin Frank, Joseph M. Lesser and Frank T. Reilly senior vice presidents.

title: Curry Cancels Bout
description: Donald Curry , the World Boxing Association's welterweight champion, has canceled a July 14 title bout against Nino LaRocca in Monte Carlo on the ground that the effects of a recent virus infection left him too weak to train properly. ''Why do I have to risk my title on two or three weeks of training?'' said Curry, who last trained on June 3, two days before the viral infection was diagnosed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just think, I can't move my fingers, but here I am getting ready to shake the hands of the President of the United States.'' - Hector Del Valle of Dover, N.J., paralyzed after an auto accident in which he was drunk at the wheel. (B2:3.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Argosystems Inc., a concern in Sunnyvale, Calif., that produces electronic reconnaissance and counter- measures systems, said it had received two international contracts valued at $12.7 million.

title: Government Witness Admits Hiding the Truth
description: The defense in the drug trial of John Z. DeLorean today got a Federal drug agent to admit that he ''lied'' in filling out the date on a Government authorization form ''so I wouldn't look bad'' and that he had given false information to a grand jury for much the same reason.

title: Technology; Using a Phone As a Terminal
description: A LEXANDER GRAHAM BELL didn't realize it, of course, but what he invented in 1876 was the first computer terminal.

title: DOW GAINS 15.80 AFTER LATE RALLY
description: The stock market, down sharply for most of the day in a wide-ranging selloff, turned on a dime yesterday on rumors that the International Business Machines Corporation is planning a new stock buyback program.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, some copies of page A10 yesterday omitted the first part of an article about an Administration proposal to halt aid to family planning groups. Readers wishing copies of the corrected page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: DOCTORS ASK LOCAL RULES ON TREATING THE INCURABLE
description: The American Medical Association today endorsed the notion that local communities and hospitals should set their own guidelines for treatment of incurably ill infants rather than have the Federal Government or any other group lay down national standards binding in all cases.

title: Judge Gives Lecture
description: David Berst , the chief of enforcement for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, was testifying in the case brought against the N.C.A.A. by Jerry Tarkanian , the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, when he acknowledged under cross-examination that he had once referred to Tarkanian as a ''rug merchant.'' The term is considered a slur by various eastern Mediterranean groups to whom it is sometimes applied, and Paul Goldman , the judge who is hearing the case in Las Vegas, was angered by Berst's terminology.

title: WHAT BETSY ROSS WROUGHT
description: Nearly every day, a work crew climbs to the base of the Capitol Dome and for an hour or two flies American flags. Big flags and smaller flags. Cotton flags and nylon flags.

title: THEATER: 'DESIGN FOR LIVING'
description: NOEL COWARD'S ''Design for Living,'' an uninhibited account of a pansexual love triangle, was considered somewhat shocking stuff when it first opened in New York in 1933. To see the comedy now in its first Broadway revival is to realize that Coward's capacity to provoke, like his talent to amuse, has not at all faded with time. ''Design for Living'' isn't one of this writer's best plays, but it's an astringent, shapely piece that unabashedly celebrates money, success and emotional greed. As directed at a breakneck pace by George C. Scott at the Circle in the Square, it's a pleasant, elegant diversion about uncommonly unpleasant people.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Therapeutic Art

title: CRANSTON SAYS PAKISTAN CAN MAKE A-BOMB
description: Senator Alan Cranston plans to tell the Senate on Thursday that he has obtained declassified information that China has helped give Pakistan a nuclear ability.

title: 4 FRUIT FLIES FOUND IN MIAMI SPUR QUARANTINE
description: An 81- square-mile section of Miami was placed under an agriculture quarantine today and ground and air pesticide spraying was ordered after four Mediterranean fruit flies were found in a sour orange tree.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Upjohn Grooming 2 For Chairman Job

title: No Headline
description: For the second time in four days, a woman has profited handsomely from a grand slam. Evelyn Rogala of Charleston, S.C., won $100,000 when Brad Komminsk of Atlanta hit a grand slam in the third inning Tuesday night to help the Braves post a 11-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Profits in U.S.  Revised Higher
description: American companies' profits, like the economy in general, were stronger than expected in the first three months of this year, the Government reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Up-Front Proposal

title: NICARAGUA SAYS IT HAS BROKEN UP REBEL RING
description: The Nicaraguan Government said today that it had broken up a subversive network that was planning to carry out acts of sabotage and ''create anxiety and fear among our people.''

title: Brazilian Takes Over As Leader of O.A.S.
description: Joao Baena Soares, a veteran Brazilian diplomat, assumed his duties today as Secretary General of the Organization of American States.

title: Breakdancing Fad Held To Risk Serious Injury
description: A number of doctors have warned that the breakdancing fad can push the body beyond its endurance, causing torn ligaments, broken bones and more serious injuries. One man broke his neck and was left a quadriplegic after trying to imitate the acrobatic movements of a breakdancing group.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MIRROR MAKERS. A History of American Advertising nad Its Creators. By Stephen Fox. Illustrated. 383 Pages. William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: THE SUMMER ROSES THAT BLOOM AGAIN
description: THESE days, the approaching end of June need not mean the end of roses. There are now scores of cultivars that will continue to produce new flowers all summer long. And also it is now possible to continue to plant roses during the summer: not the bare root species from mail order dealers, but the potted roses that are in stock at local garden shops.

title: WRISTON: A SUMMING UP
description: The United States banking system is radically different today from what it was a decade ago, and much of that change can be attributed to one man: Walter B. Wriston.

title: DEPOSIT INSURANCE LIMIT ON BROKERS HELD ILLEGAL
description: A Federal judge ruled today that new regulations recently adopted by two banking agencies to restrict Federal insurance of deposits placed by money brokers was illegal.

title: INFORMATION BILL HELD IN DOUBT
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee reviewing a Senate proposal to modify the Freedom of Information Act predicted today that it would not reach the House floor this year.

title: No Mas for Duran
description: The boxer who said ''no mas'' to end a bout almost four years ago said no more to his career yesterday at the airport in Panama City. Roberto Duran , knocked out in the second round last week by Thomas Hearns, returned home and announced his retirement from boxing before a crowd estimated at 1,000.

title: CALENDAR: TAPESTRIES AND ITALIAN DESIGN
description: Modern Master Tapestries, 11 East

title: IF YOUR COMPUTER IS NO LONGER MADE
description: LAST fall, the Osborne Computer Corporation went bankrupt and discontinued production of its portable computer. Shortly after that Texas Instruments dropped the 99/4A home computer from its line. And earlier this year Timex stopped manufacturing Sinclair home computers.

title: CITY STUDIES CHARGE THAT SURPLUS CHEESE WAS SERVED AT PARTY
description: The New York City Department of Investigation is looking into accusations that Federal surplus cheese, intended for distribution to the poor, was served at a Christmas party held by the City Human Rights Commission last December, the City Investigation Commissioner said yesterday.

title: NEW WOLF TRAP CENTER
description: More than a thousand friends of Wolf Trap Park for the Performing Arts gathered this evening in the Virginia countryside 15 miles west of the capital to dedicate the new Filene Center that replaced the one that was destroyed by fire a little more than two years ago.

title: Norway Trade Surplus
description: Norway's foreign trade surplus in May was $350 million, up 17.8 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today This year through May 31 the surplus rose 30.8 percent, to $2.26 billion, from the first five months of 1983.

title: SENATE BARS MOVE TO REDUCE TROOPS WITH NATO FORCES
description: The Senate tonight turned aside a strong bid by Democrats to withdraw nearly one- third of American troops in Western Europe by 1990 if members of the Atlantic alliance fail to bolster their military contributions.

title: JOSEPH WOLL, UNION COUNSEL
description: Joseph Albert Woll, the general counsel to the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations since the merger of the two labor organizations in 1955, died of cancer Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 80 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: DOWN TO BRASS TAX
description: 1982, In nearly 10 million individuals or couples filing joint income tax returns with annual adjusted gross income of less than $10,000 were forced to hire a professional tax preparer.

title: TIGERS DOWN ON YANKEES IN 13TH
description: The Yankees may not be playing winning baseball this season, but they have devised their own system of sudden- death baseball. They played another of those games tonight and lost to the Detroit Tigers, 9-6, when Howard Johnson hit a two-out, three-run home run against Jose Rijo in the 13th inning.

title: BILL SPLITS LAWMAKERS FROM NEW YORK AREA
description: Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn, one of three black members of the New York Congressional delegation and a vigorous opponent of the immigration bill that was narrowly approved by the House today, told his colleagues during the debate that he was often mistaken for a West Indian.

title: HOME BEAT ; A BOOK: UTOPIAN PRODUCTS
description: published ''Utopia . . . or Bust: Products for the Perfect World'' (Delilah Books, $6.95) is an imaginative, funny volume that is as entertaining as it is sensible. This new paperback compendium of the Los Angeles-based designer and inventor is full of the objects he feels can provide solutions for both the present and the future of our society. They include a log-cabin skyscraper, left, ''for people who come to big cities from rural areas and find modern architecture too impersonal''; the ''Murphy Grand,'' far left below, which, according to Mr. Garner, ''allows for the prestige of having a piano, without the wasted space''; the ''Two-In-One-Appliance,'' below left, both a lamp and an iron, and ''Le Outlet,'' below, which is to make ''the mundane extension cord one of the most potentially exciting elements in a room.''

title: No Headline
description: Sagan Article Sets Off Dispute at Vanity Fair

title: UNIVERSAL MONEY CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Wheelchair 'Gladiator': A Versatile Life
description: Scott Schneider was 14 years old when he found out he had muscular dystrophy. The news did not hit him too hard. He thought that he would be able to keep shooting in the 80's on the golf course and competing in tennis, swimming and basketball.

title: IN SIERRA LEONE, LAND OF DIAMONDS, DECAY SETS IN
description: A European diplomat who has served in this wet and mountainous West African country for nearly two years was asked recently what had changed in that time.

title: Presidential Candidates Obtained $53 Million
description: The drive for the White House brought $53.4 million to Presidential candidates through February, with a fifth of the amount from the Treasury.

title: HOUSE, BY 216-211, APPROVES ALIENS BILL AFTER RETAINING AMNESTY PLAN IN FINAL TEST
description: Capping a week of bitter debate, the House of Representatives today approved by a five-vote margin a comprehensive immigration bill designed to stem the flow of illegal aliens into this country. The final vote was 216 to 211.

title: ACID RAIN CONTROLS EXAMINED
description: Permitting utilities to devise their own methods to control sulfur dioxide, a key component of acid rain, could save about $1 billion a year over mandated controls, a Congressional report said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Columbia Gas Chairman
description: Columbia Gas System Inc. yesterday named its president, John H. Croom, to the additional job of chairman. W. Frederick Laird, the current chairman, will retire on Aug. 1. Mr. Croom, 51 years old, will be the youngest chairman in the company's history. He has spent 30 years with Columbia Gas, which is based in Wilmington, Del. Mr. Croom has a background in both engineering and marketing.

title: NO CLUES IN SWALE TEST
description: Swale definitely did not suffer from heart failure, and the cause of his death last Sunday morning remains a mystery, veterinarians announced yesterday after completing preliminary laboratory reports.

title: KINGMAN HITS 19TH, HIS 3D SLAM OF YEAR
description: Dave Kingman walloped his third grand slam and major league-leading 19th homer of the season today to lead the Oakland A's to an 8-1 romp over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Consolidated Packaging Corporation said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: b-Includes a loss of $853,000 from discontinued operations. The latest quarter includes results of Flower Time Inc. which was acquired March 2, and year-ago period includes Frank's Nursery & Crafts Inc. which was acquired March 7, 1983. All figures restated to reflect change in fiscal year to the last Sunday in January from the last Saturday in December.

title: Chin Is Dismissed By School Board
description: The Board of Education has dismissed John Chin, the official whose arrest last February led to the suspension and eventual resignation of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado, according to a board spokesman.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ECONOMIC GROWTH PUT AT 5.7% RATE FOR THIS QUARTER
description: The nation's economy is growing considerably faster than expected while inflation is continuing to abate, the Commerce Department said today.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SCREEN DOORS OF WOOD
description: -FRAMED screen doors are effective in keeping out insects, but an old- fashioned wood screen door is just as effective and more pleasing visually.

title: Republicans Establish Panel of Moderates
description: A group of moderate Republicans today announced the formation of the Republican Mainstream Committee to lobby for arms control, women's and civil rights and environmental concerns at the party's national convention in Dallas in August.

title: SENATOR ALAN SIMPSON'S INTERVENTION WITH O'NEILL LED TO HOUSE DEBATE
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican, sat in front of a bronze sculpture of a cowboy on a bucking bronco and watched the House debate on a television set that was on his office floor. The debate, on the immigration bill, would probably not have occurred at all had he not interceded last winter with the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: PAINTER OF NEW YORK SCHOOL
description: Lee Krasner Pollock, a leading Abstract Expressionist painter, the wife and artistic partner of Jackson Pollock and a force in the New York art world for 30 years, died Tuesday night in New York Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in New York and in The Springs, East Hampton, L.I., where she will be buried alongside her husband in Green River cemetery.

title: Earnings Cut Seen By BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it expected that the impact on its second-quarter earnings from Argentina loans resulting from the recent clarification of accounting rules will be about $6 million after taxes.

title: MAYPORT JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: ON the eve of New York's Kool Jazz Festival, WNET has gotten a little of the festival bug. Tonight at 11, Channel 13 will show ''Mayport and All That Jazz,'' performances from the 1981 Mayport festival held near Jacksonville, Fla.

title: JERSEY HIGH SCHOOL FINDS REAGAN'S VISIT 'AMAZING'
description: Moments after President Reagan had spoken to students in the River Dell High School gymnasium here, Jeff Deiss, Chris Dispoto and Gary Brill climbed some bleachers and jumped up to a window ledge about 25 feet above the floor to try to catch a last look at the President.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Japan's Car Output Up
description: Japanese auto makers produced 994,785 cars, trucks and buses in May, up 10.2 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. It was the largest increase since October 1980. The output of cars grew 8.1 percent, trucks 13.6 percent and buses 42.3 percent.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Underground Nuclear Test
description: The United States Department of Energy conducted an underground nuclear weapon test today at its Nevada test site, officials said.

title: Turkish Press Agency Aides Withdraw Their Resignations
description: The directors of the semiofficial Anatolia press agency withdrew their resignations today after being told the Government would reverse a decision to put the agency under control of a state directorate.

title: No Headline
description: Dead Father's Marrow To Be Implanted in Boy

title: No Headline
description: The Trail to Bulgaria

title: 6 POLICE OFFICERS FACING CHARGES IN 2 BURGLARIES
description: Two sergeants and four officers from two New York City police precincts were arrested yesterday and charged with committing thefts and burglaries while on duty and in uniform.

title: SAUDIS SAY THREATENING AIRCRAFT WILL BE INTERCEPTED BEYOND BORDER
description: Saudi Arabia has told the United States and friendly nations in the Persian Gulf area that it will move to intercept threatening aircraft in gulf waters beyond Saudi territorial limits, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: President Is Promoted At CPC International
description: With an orderly transition in mind, James W. McKee Jr., the 62-year-old chief executive officer of CPC International Inc., said yesterday that that position would go to James R. Eiszner, 56, the company's president and chief operating officer, effective Sept. 1. Mr. McKee will continue as chairman. Mr. Eiszner will also retain his current positions.

title: UDALL OPPOSES A PLAN FOR MORE JACKSON DELEGATES
description: Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, chairman of a Congressional Democratic commission, today opposed a proposal for adding several hundred delegates to the Democratic convention to meet complaints by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that party rules have left him unfairly underrepresented.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR IS BATTLING 2 PAPERS
description: A siege mentality appears to have taken over the 11th floor of San Diego's City Hall these days. Mayor Roger Hedgecock contends that the city's two major newspapers, The Union and The Tribune, are out to destroy him politically.

title: Officer Rescues Woman on Bridge
description: A woman believed to be about to jump into the Hudson River from the Tappan Zee Bridge was rescued early today by an off-duty New York City police officer.

title: SENATORS VOTE 5 OIL PROVISIONS
description: The Senate Energy Committee, voting largely along party lines, today approved a proposal to give low-income consumers and state governors money to offset higher oil prices that might occur in a major oil-supply disruption.

title: EAST EUROPE IS SAID TO PREOCCUPY SOVIET LEADERS
description: President Francois Mitterrand is likely to find his Soviet hosts preoccupied with problems affecting Eastern Europe, according to diplomats and intelligence sources interviewed recently in London and Paris.

title: Dr. Felix Taubman Dies at 68; Former Director at St. John's
description: Dr. Felix Taubman, former director of medicine at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn, died Monday at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: VIRGINIA FUGITIVES HELD ON $10 MILLION BONDS
description: Two brothers, convicted killers who staged an escape from death row in a Virginia prison and eluded the police for nearly three weeks, were ordered held today on $10 million bail each.

title: ADropinDamage By Gypsy Moths
description: Gypsy moths are expected to strip the leaves off a quarter of a million acres of trees and plants in New Jersey this summer, but that is only a moderate loss compared with those of recent years, agriculture officials said today.

title: FRENCH WEIGH ASYLUM FOR IRANIAN HIJACKERS
description: As Iranian exiles marched through the streets of Paris today, French officials weighed a request for political asylum by four Iranians who commandered a navy plane and forced it to land in Nice.

title: LIBEL SUIT AGAINST VIKING DISMISSED
description: In a decision that lawyers say will strengthen the media's hand in libel suits, a South Dakota circuit court has dismissed a $24 million suit that the Governor of that state, William J. Janklow, filed against an author, his publisher and three South Dakota bookstores.

title: Japanese Fighters Sent Aloft As 7 Soviet Planes Approach
description: Japanese fighters scrambled today when Soviet planes, including at least three Backfire bombers, appeared off the west coast of Hokkaido.

title: No Headline
description: Mending the Medicaid Quilt A patchwork of Federal and state programs pay medical insurance for America's poor - but the patches fail to cover some important health problems. For three especially needy groups, coverage may be an accident of geography: single women's first pregnancies, women in couples whose principal wage earner is unemployed and infants up to one year old are not covered by various states.

title: Bomber Returned to Dublin
description: Michael O'Rourke, a convicted Irish Republican Army bomber, was arrested here today after being deported from the United States and was taken to the courthouse where guerrillas dynamited his cell to free him in 1976.

title: PORTUGAL'S POLICE RAID URBAN GUERRILLAS
description: The police in Portugal have detained at least 40 people and uncovered caches of weapons, explosives and money in a series of raids reportedly aimed at an urban guerrilla group.

title: Coal Deposit Found in China
description: Coal reserves estimated at more than 400 million tons have been discovered in southern China's Guangxi Zhuang autonomous region, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Continental Bank Aid
description: The seven banks that teamed with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in last month's rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company have been joined by eight other banks in the aid package, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said today.

title: Brewers 5, Blue Jays 4
description: Jim Gantner, with his second consecutive three-hit game, singled home the winning run with one out in the top of the ninth inning to give Milwaukee the victory.

title: Firstgulf Agrees To Amsouth Link
description: Firstgulf Bancorp said its board had approved in principle a proposal to merge with Amsouth Bancorp in a transaction valued at nearly $113 million. Under the agreement, Firstgulf shareholders would receive 2.1 shares of Amsouth common stock for each share of Firstgulf stock, $47 in cash for each share or a combination of cash and stock.

title: Psychiatrist Quits Creedmoor Post
description: A psychiatrist who worked in a ward of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center where patients were reportedly beaten has resigned, officials said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today June 21, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ROMANO MAZZOLI DEVOTED FOUR YEARS OF QUIET, RELETNLESS WORK TO MEASURE
description: The ordeal was almost over and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli was all but spent. ''I was at my mother's this weekend and I almost fell asleep into the spaghetti,'' he said.

title: HEALTH RESOURCES CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago figures are unavailable since fiscal 1984 was the company's first year as a publicly held company.

title: No Headline
description: An article in The Living Section on June 6 about the 200th birthday of Antonin Car^eme misstated the affiliation of Peter Kromberg, a chef preparing food for a celebration in Brighton, England. He is with the Inter-Continental Hotel in London.

title: Koosman's Skills Unaffected by Time
description: Tug McGraw, standing in Shea Stadium, where it started, remembered when he and Jerry Koosman were kids together on the Mets 17 years ago. Now, they are old-timers together on the Philadelphia Phillies. And McGraw, who has a sore shoulder but a robust vocabulary, said:

title: ; ARMY TREATIES REVOCABLE AT WILL ARE NO HELP
description: To the Editor: Bernard Gwertzman's June 8 news article about declassified documenta

title: Weinberger Defends Reagan's Missile Plan
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today accused critics of the Reagan Administration's work on an advanced plan for defensive missiles of putting out ''a wealth of misinformation.''

title: AT 31, FRANCIE LARRIEU STILL PUSHES ON
description: For most of the leisurely run 3,000-meter heat, she stayed on the heels of Mary Decker, which is as close to the top as Francie Larrieu-Smith has been in recent years. Several years ago, before female track athletes were popular enough to be known as American sweethearts - featured in television commercials and seen smiling from larger- than-life billboards - it was Miss Larrieu who was the leader, chasing only her own ambition.

title: Avon Stock Plan
description: Avon Products Inc. said it might use proceeds from the planned sale of Tiffany & Company to purchase up to 10 million shares of its common stock, make acquisitions, reduce debt or support existing business.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Swiss Protester Run Down
description: A cyclist who sat down on a busy roadway to protest traffic was run down and and badly injured by a car today.

title: WHAT REAGAN WROUGHT
description: From the day he took office, President Reagan acted on the theory that insult and intimidation were the keys to dealing successfully with the Soviet Union. Talk tough and build new weapons systems, and the Russians would negotiate seriously.

title: IT'S COLD IN HERE
description: There is an almost frantic search for signals these days in the absence of serious Soviet- American communications. Thus, some American Kremlin-watchers took heart last week when a Soviet spokesman, Leonid Zamyatin, answered a press conference question by saying a well-prepared summit meeting might be possible.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $800,000 related to development of a computer service associated with the company's oil and gas investments. c-After a nonrecurring gain of $3,199,000 from the sale of property. The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Bankruptcy Extension
description: The House today passed and sent to the White House a bill extending the temporary Federal bankruptcy court system through June 27.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA AID IS IN DOUBT
description: The White House is considering dropping its insistence on $21 million in emergency aid for Nicaraguan rebels to end a House-Senate deadlock and speed action on $100 million for summer youth jobs, an aide to the Senate Republican leadership said today.

title: Court Upholds Raiders' Move
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to reconsider its ruling that the National Football League violated antitrust law when it tried to bar the Raiders' move from Oakland to Los Angeles.

title: THE LONG-RUNNING PROCESS OF CHOOSING A CITICORP CHIEF
description: The process of selecting John S. Reed as the next chairman and chief executive of Citicorp, the world's largest banking organization, began at least a year and a half ago, when Walter B. Wriston first recommended his successor, a director of the company said yesterday.

title: VICTORIAN-GOTHIC MANSION ON VIEW
description: Lauralton Hall , 200 High Street, Milford, Conn., 203-878-0636. The Pond-Taylor Mansion will be open to the public through June 30 as a decorator show house.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Russians Denounce Michael Jackson
description: The Kremlin has denounced Michael Jackson as a singer who sold his black soul for white profit and is serving the Reagan Administration by keeping the American public's mind off the country's problems.

title: At Least 50 Killed In Angola Train Crash
description: A passenger train driven at ''great speed'' by an engineer who ''appeared to be drunk'' crashed about 160 miles southeast of Luanda and killed at least 50 people, Angola's official press agency said today.

title: CUTBACKS AT ALCOA, KAISER
description: Two major aluminum companies announced production cutbacks and layoffs yesterday, citing low metal prices and high energy costs.

title: Advertising; Combining Yogurt and Chocolate
description: C LEARLY savoring a career triumph, John J. Kazanas, fifth- generation yogurt maker, talked enthusiastically yesterday about La Chocolat, to his knowledge the first successful combining of increasingly popular yogurt with ever- popular chocolate.

title: ;  Illinois Central
description: Illinois Central Gulf Railroad offered $150 million worth of 10-year first mortgage bonds due June 1, 1994. The bonds, which have a coupon of 15 1/2 percent, were priced at 99.343, to yield 15.58 percent. Merrill Lynch was lead manager.

title: A GENTLE REDESIGN FOR A 1949 BOSTON HOUSING PROJECT
description: BOSTON WHAT impresses the eye on a walk along the narrow streets of Beacon Hill here are the peaks and valleys of the houses' roof lines, the protruding bay windows and, even in attached town houses, the distinct individuality of each building.

title: FOR BETTER OR FOR WORSE, LAW WILL AFFECT LIVES OF MILLIONS
description: Twenty-nine- year-old Maria H. and her 27-year-old husband, a laborer in a plant nursery, have been in the United States for four years, and they have four children.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,694,000 on the sale of real estate. c-Net loss includes an oil and gas properties writedown of $1.4 million. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,961,000 for the quarter and $2,816,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months' figures include results of United Television Inc., in which the company owns a 51 percent stake. The year-earlier quarter, the latest 9 months and the year-ago 9 months results include equity in income of United Television of $416,000, $334,000 and $2,484,000, respectively.

title: CARLTON FOILED BY STRAWBERRY
description: The Mets continued their strange mastery over Steve Carlton last night when they overpowered the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-4, and beat the renowned left-hander for the 33d time in his career.

description: Bridge:Playback at Grand NationalBecame Stuck in the Groove

title: SLAYER IS ELECTROCUTED IN FLORIDA
description: Carl Elson Shriner, who spent most of his 30 years behind bars but said that he found ''the light'' on death row, died in the electric chair today for the murder of a young mother in a store holdup.

title: Bill Aids Districts Hurt in 'Repos' Cases
description: The Legislature tonight approved a measure to help school districts and counties with fiscal troubles caused by the bankruptcies of two Government-securities companies.

title: Kentucky Delegation Released by Gov. Collins
description: Gov. Martha Layne Collins today released the 33 uncommitted members of Kentucky's delegation to the Democratic National Convention to vote as they wish.

title: JACKSON'S PLANK ON PALESTINIANS IS BEATEN, 13-2
description: An attempt by representatives of the Rev. Jesse Jackson to put the Democratic Party on record as favoring ''an independent state for Palestinians'' was defeated overwhelmingly today by the 15- member committee drafting this year's party platform. The vote was 13 to 2, with only the two Jackson delegates in support.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title:
HERS;
THE EXHLIARATION OF OVERCOMING THE PROBLEMS POSED BY A BROKEN MARRIAGE
description: WHEN my husband and I separated after one of the longer-running marriages of modern times, I knew that I would face a lot of problems. I am happy to report, however, that it is possible not only to survive these problems but also to enjoy them.

title: WESTWAY PARK DESIGN GOES PUBLIC
description: The final design for the 93-acre Westway State Park, which would be built over the proposed underground highway along the Hudson River, was made public yesterday by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch.

title: HOW TO SAVE MONEY ON COOLING COSTS.
description: THOUGH hot weather means bigger electric bills for those who use air-conditioners, homeowners and apartment dwellers can take steps to keep cool while holding the bills down as much as possible.

title: Patrick Petroleum
description: The Patrick Petroleum Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell substantially all of its oil- and gas-related assets to the Ladd Petroleum Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, for about $197 million. Patrick, which defaulted on a bank debt payment early this year, said the sale would leave the company with a net worth of about $41 million and no debt. It said the definitive agreement completes negotiations initially announced on March 19.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1984 International
description: Democrats were rebuffed as the Senate rejected, by a vote of 55 to 41, a proposal to withdraw nearly one-third of American troops in Europe in 1990 if NATO members failed to increase military contributions. The proposal was offered by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia. The Senate later voted, 94 to 3, to accept a compromise measure urging NATO members to increase their contributions to the alliance, but omitting any threat to withdraw American troops. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Widened Saudi air defense activity was indicated by Reagan Administration officials. They said that Saudi Arabia had told the United States and friendly countries in the Persian Gulf region that it would move to intercept threatening aircraft in waters beyond Saudi territorial limits. (A1:1-2.)

title: DO TELEPHONE CALLS AND DRIVING MIX?
description: To the Editor:

description: Walter E. Fauntroy

title: A.T.& T. Dividend Is Intact;  Expected Cut Is Not Made
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday declared a dividend of 30 cents a share for the second quarter, the same as the previous quarter, despite warnings from company officials in March that the telephone giant would be likely to reduce its payouts.

title: MEXICO CONSODERS GUATEMALAN PLAN
description: Mexico has been discussing with international agencies the possible creation of protected zones in Guatemala to allow some of the refugees to return home, a Mexican official said today.

title: ABC SEEKS REBATE ON OLYMPIC FEES
description: Citing an obligation to ABC's stockholders and its own insurance policy, Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, says he wants a rebate from the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee because of the Soviet-led walkout from the Summer Games.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. A rare weekday afternoon game for the Mets, in which Walt Terrell will try to continue his recent streak of excellent pitching. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. As the Yankees travel around the league, they meet many former members of their organization who have gone on to successful careers. Tonight they face another one, Scott McGregor, the starter for Baltimore. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.)

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Yields Rise On C.D.'s
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose to 10.77 percent in the week ended Wednesday, from 10.67 percent the week before, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: British-Dutch $67 Fare Set
description: Britain and the Netherlands formally agreed today to allow a $67 round-trip air fare between the two countries, thus abandoning the exising cartel system that had kept fares 60 percent higher.

title: 3 KEY CLUES LED TO SUSPECT IN MASS MURDERS
description: A tip from the father of two young victims, a cartridge shell in a burned- out apartment and identifications by two witnesses were the chief clues that led to the arrest of Christopher Thomas for the murders of 10 people in Brooklyn two months ago.

title: 156 MORE SIKHS ARE REPORTED ARRESTED IN PUNJAB
description: The authorities said the Indian Army arrested 156 more Sikhs in Punjab today, raising the number of those held since the army's assault on the Golden Temple two weeks ago to 4,200. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, meanwhile, declared that Indian soldiers would stay in the Golden Temple until all weapons there had been removed.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Consumers Power In New Plant Offer

title: DEADLOCK ON TAX BILL CONTINUES FOR A 2D DAY
description: House and Senate conferees were unable to break a deadlock over spending cuts and tax reductions today, stalling progress on the tax bill for the second consecutive day.

title: ARMY TREATIES REVOCABLE AT WILL ARE NO HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: RODIN The 100 pieces sculptured by Auguste Rodin are going to leave their World Trade Center aerie that has been for more than two years the highest museum in New York. They will not be leaving New York, but they will be on view in the 105th floor B.G. Cantor Sculpture Center in Tower One only through next Thursday. Then they will move to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum and other institutions. Mr. Cantor, a financier and ardent collector of Rodins, established the center adjacent to his suite of New York offices.

title: GREEN PARTY BOUNCING BACK IN BONN
description: The days are over when the breezy conventional wisdom in Bonn had it that the Green Party was a flash in the pan, a minor disturbance on the tranquil surface of West Germany's orderly and predictable politics, soon to be swept into oblivion by the conservatism of the nation's voters.

title: 5 REPORTED SLAIN IN ZIMBABWE RIOTS
description: Five people have been reported killed in the last two days in the central city of Kwekwe as bands of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's supporters attacked the homes of followers of the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo.

title: FORD FOUNDATION WEIGHING VENTURE
description: The Ford Foundation is exploring whether to start a philanthropic organization in Puerto Rico to stimulate economic development and social improvement there.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
O.E.C.D. FORECASTS SLOWER U.S. UPTURN
description: The rate of economic recovery in the United States will slow sharply next year, largely because of high interest rates and the large Federal budget deficit, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today in its semiannual forecast.

title: U.S. VISITORS PRAISE THE STATUS OF RELIGION IN SOVIET
description: A delegation of 266 American church leaders, the largest such group ever to visit the Soviet Union, today ended a two-week tour of 14 cities with praise for the status of religion in the Soviet Union and condemnation of the United States role in the arms race.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SORROWFUL TIME AT CLAIBORNE FARM
description: PARIS, Ky.

title: NO DATE SET ON CONRAIL DECISION
description: Kenneth D. Brody, a partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company, told Congress today that he would complete his analysis of the 14 bids for Conrail within a few weeks. However, a Transportation Department official was vague about when Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole would give Congress a recommendation on which bid to accept.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains, 6-1, 6-3
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova needed just 50 minutes today to beat Carling Bassett of Canada, 6-1, 6-3, and gain the quarterfinals of the Eastbourne tennis tournament.

title: Accord on Twins' Sale
description: After months of negotiation, Calvin Griffith has reached an agreement to sell his family's 52 percent interest in the Minnesota Twins to Carl Pohlad , a local banker who has pledged to keep the team in Minneapolis. According to both Pohlad and the Twins, the final papers will be signed at the Metrodome before tomorrow night's game against the Chicago White Sox.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WARRANT SAID TO BE ISSUED FOR ART WORLD FIGURE
description: A French judge issued an ''international arrest warrant'' Tuesday for the arrest of the former director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, the French newspaper Le Monde reported yesterday.

title: PRESS ABROAD MAKES U.N. A KEY TOPIC
description: Every day here in a narrow office on the second floor of the Secretariat building, several staff members spend hours sorting through hundreds of press reports on United Nations activities sent in by the organization's 64 information centers around the world.

title: NO TIME FOR CHORES? PEOPLE WHO HELP
description: for a price - will take on almost any task, a boon for those New Yorkers too busy or otherwise unable to do mundane chores. You can hire someone to balance your checkbook, pick up your cleaning, shop for your clothing or renew your passport. But such services do not come cheap: fees are often in the $30-an-hour range, and some jobs can take days to complete.

title: A DOUBLE SUICIDE BY TEEN-AGERS BEWILDERS A TOWN IN CONNECTICUT
description: Two teen-age youths described by residents of this quiet old factory town as well- liked and well-behaved apparently committed suicide together either Monday night or Tuesday morning.

title: Image-Makers
description: That foggy night in March when the Baltimore Colts and all their possessions were moved out of town was apparently a great advertisement for how to accomplish something quickly and efficiently. At least that is the way The Image Factory, a Baltimore advertising agency, saw it.

title: BANKING BY ANY NAME SHOULD BE MADE TO PLAY BY THE RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: Soto Is Banned Again
description: Mario Soto of the Cincinnati Reds, one of the National League's best pitchers, was suspended for five days and fined by the league yesterday for the second time in the last three weeks because of an on-the-field melee. Similar but lesser punishment was imposed on Claudell Washington of the Braves, with whom Soto fought last Saturday night in Atlanta after throwing several brush-back pitches to him.

title: Hall Shut at Park Where 8 Perished
description: A 1,000-seat hall at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, where eight teen-agers died in a blaze at a haunted-house attraction in May, has been closed for violating the state fire safety code, a state official said today.

title: Trade Gain for Finland
description: Finland's balance of trade swung to a surplus of $60 million in May from a deficit of $30 million a year earlier, the Government said today. Exports rose to $1.12 billion from $1.03 billion; imports stayed at $1.06 billion.

title: Threatened U.S. Executives Are Said to Leave Costa Rica
description: Several United States businessmen in Costa Rica, threatened with kidnapping, have left the country, according to business and diplomatic sources in the United States and Costa Rica.

title: HOW TOKYO ENDED UP WITH AN ALTERED RENOIR
description: A Renoir portrait that had been on display in Tokyo for many years, and was then sold at auction in New York last month, has returned to Japan in what Japanese art experts maintain is a mysteriously altered condition.

title: Accord Is Reached on a Plan To Assist Fair in New Orleans
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards and Mayor Dutch Morial of New Orleans worked out a plan today to aid the financially struggling world's fair. The plan allowed the fair to pay $1 million in sales taxes to the city later in the day.

title: Opera: Gangster 'Rigoletto' at Met
description: If ''Carmen'' could survive Peter Brook and the ''Ring'' could survive Anna Russell, there is no reason to think that ''Rigoletto'' will not survive Jonathan Miller. Mr. Miller's much-discussed revision of Verdi's opera, which transfers the action to New York's Little Italy in the 1950's, proved last evening to be an ingenious concept but not one likely to shake the foundations of opera or disturb civic peace.

title: DRAFTEE DRESSED FOR BUSINESS
description: Melvin Turpin was still close to all the excitement, separated from the crowds and the basketball executives by only a blue curtain. The blue pinstriped suit that Turpin wore was a reminder that he had at last become a businessman. He also wore a relieved smile, proof that the uncertainty of his transition from the University of Kentucky to the National Basketball Association had at last ended.

title: Baby for Julie Eisenhower
description: Julie Nixon Eisenhower, daughter of former President Richard M. Nixon, has given birth to her third child, a 9-pound, 8-ounce girl, a spokesman for Phoenixville Hospital said Tuesday. The baby, Melanie Catherine, was born at 8:12 P.M. Monday. She is 21 inches long, and both mother and baby were ''doing fine,'' the spokesman said. Mrs. Eisenhower, 35 years old, and her husband, David, the grandson of President Eisenhower, live near Philadelphia.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SERVICE RECALLS RIGHTS ACTIVISTS SLAIN IN SOUTH
description: Blacks and Jews gathered in a chapel in Manhattan at noon yesterday to remember three young civil-rights workers who were murdered 20 years ago in Mississippi.

title: A CHRONICLER OF CALIFORNIA ARCHITECTURE
description: WITH her white, severely cut hair, direct gaze and the ever-present cigarette she holds like a pencil, the Los Angeles writer and architectural historian Esther McCoy looks - to people who see her for the first time - like a personality. They are not quite sure, however, who. At a recent lunch in Venice, Calif., a waiter serving Miss McCoy mistakenly asked her to autograph two books by Lillian Hellman. Several weeks ago, at a Fifth Avenue bookstore - where her new book on Southern California architects, ''The Second Generation'' (Peregrine Smith Books, $27.50), had just been placed on the shelves - Miss McCoy was asked if she was not Georgia O'Keeffe.

title: Mortgage Corp. II
description: The Guaranteed Mortgage Corporation II yesterday offered $175 million worth of collateralized mortgage bonds. The bonds were issued in four series, all using coupons of 12.5 percent, and were priced to yield between 13.87 percent and 14.55 percent.

title: Wages Climb in Britain
description: Average earnings in Britain rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in April from March and were up 5.8 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. The Confederation of British Industry, representing manufacturers, said wage settlements in manufacturing during the first five months of this year averaged 6 percent, compared with 5.75 percent a year earlier.

description: The director of President Reagan's re-election campaign predicted today that a voter registration drive to find two million new Reagan voters would offset the Democrats' expected registration gains among blacks and other groups,

title: AT WASHINGTON MUSEUM, TEXTILES ONLY
description: -bred neighboring brick houses in the embassy- lined section of Kalorama. But inside it is the nation's only museum devoted to textiles. There are fewer than a handful of textile museums in the world and this, founded by a man impassioned with Oriental rugs, rivals the finest, experts agree.

title: Lawyer Is Fined ForRacialRemark
description: A Federal judge held a lawyer in contempt today and fined him $1,000 for referring to a black man who brought a police brutality suit as a ''boy'' and for disregarding rulings by the judge.

title: KOCH EASES EDICT ON HOMOSEXUALS PENDING CHURCH COURT CHALLENGE
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city would exempt religious organizations from a mayoral order that bars job discrimination against homosexuals until these groups could test the legality of the order in the courts.

title: Pomp, Not Protest, Greets Updated Verdi
description: JONATHAN MILLER'S radical reinterpretation of ''Rigoletto'' was preceded to these shores by a small storm of controversy and protest. Iit arrived calmly last night at the metropolitan Opera House, under clear skies, and acompanied by a touch of royal pomp.

title: U.S. FIGHTS MAIL-ORDER FIREWORKS KITS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has issued an alert on a growing danger: mail-order chemical sets for making fireworks at home.

title: American Envoy's Car Speeds Past Beirut Clash
description: Shooting broke out at the crossing between Beirut's Christian and Moslem sectors today today as the United States Ambassador, Reginald Bartholomew, passed through in a bulletproof limousine. American officials said he was unhurt.

title: Market Place; Bearish Firm's Stock Picks
description: WHICH stocks does a major brokerage firm recommend these days if it remains bearish on overall prospects for the equity market? After all, any sales force is hungry for ideas, even if the market keeps flashing an amber light.

title: Center of Search
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers' search for a reliable center goes on.

title: Elephant Kills Its Handler
description: A circus elephant killed one of its handlers during a training exercise and was put to death, the Austria Press Agency reported today. The Austrian National Circus was rehearsing in the resort of Badgastein on Tuesday when a 20-year-old Indian elephant charged Mohammed Harmzi and fatally injured him, the report said.

title: Car Track Tested At Meadowlands
description: The new track that winds through the vast parking lots of the Meadowlands sports complex got its first full-scale test today in preparation for the United States Grand Prix, an Indy-car race that is scheduled for July 1.

title: TWO DYNASTIES OF HASIDIM WED IN WESTCHESTER
description: For an hour Tuesday night, a half-mile stretch of the Bronx River Parkway was closed to all traffic. Nearby, at the Westchester County Center, the scene was right out of 18th-century Eastern Europe.

title: MONDALE, IN CALLS TO JACKSON, FAILS TO RESOLVE DELEGATE CONFLICT
description: Walter F. Mondale telephoned the Rev. Jesse Jackson twice on Tuesday but apparently failed to resolve differences over Mr. Jackson's demand for rule changes that would give the civil rights leader additional delegates at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco next month.

title: HOUSE PANEL ASKS REPRIMAND OF IDAHO LAWMAKER
description: The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct recommended today that the House reprimand Representative George Hansen for failing to disclose complete details of his complicated financial affairs.

title: Retardation Chief In Hartford Quits
description: Gareth D. Thorne, the Commissioner of the Department of Mental Retardation for the last 13 years, said today that he would resign effective July 27.

title: PRICES SLUMP ON G.N.P. NEWS
description: Prices in the credit markets tumbled yesterday as dealers reacted to a Commerce Department report showing that the economy is growing at a faster-than-expected pace in the second quarter.

title: The Immigration Bills: A Comparison
description: Employer Sanctions HOUSE Requires employers of four or more persons to ask all job applicants for documents to verify that they are citizens or aliens authorized to work in the United States. Acceptable documents include United States passport or a combination of driver's license with Social Security card or birth certificate. No requirement for study of or improvements in identification system. Requires Attorney General to establish a toll-free telephone number that employers could call to validate Social Security numbers. Employer would have a ''complete defense'' against charges of hiring illegal aliens if he had validated their Social Security numbers. After six-month transition period, first offense is punishable by a citation or warning. For second offense, there is a civil penalty of $1,000 for each illegal alien hired. For third and subsequent offenses, there is a $2,000 civil penalty for each illegal alien hired. No criminal penalties. Forbids employers to discriminate against United States citizens and legal aliens because of their national origin or status as aliens. Forbids immigration officers to enter farms or fields without a search warrant or the owner's consent. Increases criminal penalties for anyone who brings aliens to the United States if the aliens do not have ''prior official authorization'' to enter this country or live here. SENATE Same. Requires the President, after three years, to make such changes as ''may be necessary to establish a secure system to determine employment eligibility in the United States.'' No such requirement.
