description: Georgia Power Bonds Priced to Yield 16.02%

title: Giants Sign a Top Pick
description: Bill Roberts , an offensive tackle from Ohio State who was a first-round draft pick, has been signed by the Giants, along with 9 other of the team's top 12 choices. . . . Alphonso Carreker , the top draft choice of Green Bay, signed a series of four one-year contracts with the Packers that reportedly included a signing bonus of $850,000 for the defensive end from Florida State. . . . After 11 years in the National Football League and five times a Pro Bowl selection, the offensive tackle Leon Gray was cut by the New Orleans Saints. Gray, whose best years were 1973-78 with New England, was bothered by injuries the last two seasons in New Orleans and was never able to win the left tackle job from Dave Lafary .

title: San Luis Obispo Quake Felt at Nuclear Plan
description: A moderate earthquake shook two counties today and was felt at the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant, which was undergoing a Federal inspection.

title: SCREEN: INGMAR BERGMAN'S 'AFTER THE REHEARSAL'
description: AUGUST STRINDBERG'S heavily symbolic ''Dream Play'' has never been wildly popular in this country. It has a cast of 50, requires sets that are virtually unrealizable, has no coherent story line and is obsessed with the spectacle of human suffering during the dream that is Life. There are no conventional characters or, as someone says in a different context in ''After the Rehearsal,'' Ingmar Bergman's fine new chamber film, ''Everything represents. Nothing

title: Block Is Hospitalized
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block, described as fatigued after a trip to Japan, has been hospitalized for a bleeding ulcer but he hopes to be back at work as early as next week, an aide said today. Mr. Block was admitted at Sibley Hospital here Tuesday evening and was given a blood transfusion.

title: TO WIN LIBERALS AND LATINS
description: United States policy toward Central America requires broad support at home if it is to succeed. Yet President Reagan has been unable to win liberal backing for his policy. One problem lies with the liberals themselves, whose criticism of the Reagan policy is often based on overly pessimistic assumptions about Central America. The other problem is the Administration's fault: Its mixed signals and exaggerated rhetoric have put off even those liberals who might be willing to give the Reagan policy the benefit of the doubt.

title: Tureaud Assets
description: American Resources Inc. said it had tendered an offer of $45 million to the Bankruptcy Court in the Northern District of Oklahoma to acquire the assets of the bankrupt estate of Kenneth E. Tureaud. It said the assets included undeveloped acreage in Tulsa, Okla., Jupiter Island, Fla., and Palm Beach County, Fla. Also included are about 5,500 acres of oil and gas production and 114 wells in Oklahoma and the Saket Pipeline System, it said.

title: Argentina Pays Banks $100 Million From Fund
description: Argentina has paid its foreign lenders the last $100 million in a special escrow fund set up to pay overdue interest on its public sector debt, the chairman of the bank advisory group for Argentina said yesterday.

title: NASA Picks 3 Astronomers To Train for Shuttle Flights
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named three astronomers to train for 1986 and 1987 space shuttle missions devoted to studying stars and galaxies with an array of delicate instruments, including cameras to look at Halley's Comet.

title: VOTE DUE ON WIDENING STATE BANKS' INVESTING
description: Sweeping new investment powers would be given to state-chartered banks under legislation headed for final approval by the State Assembly.

title: PIRATES' DELEON QUIETS CUBS, 5-1
description: Lee Lacy singled in two runs and Jose DeLeon hurled a three-hitter tonight to help the Pittsburgh Pirates snap a four-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: ADVERTISING
description: 'Pinstripe Prayers'

title: Debt Issues
description: * Carson Pirie Scott & Co., a Chicago- based food services and lodging company, filed for a proposed offering of $50 million of senior notes due 1994 through Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: Vienna Bomb Kills Man In Turkish Aide's Car
description: A bomb exploded in a Turkish diplomat's car as it pulled up to his embassy today, killing the driver and wounding five other people. Telephone calls to news offices in Stockholm and Paris said the Armenian Revolutionary Army was responsible for the bombing.

title: Children and Divorce
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE ON BILL TO REVISE IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: Following is the 216-to-211 roll-call vote today by which the House passed the immigration bill. A ''yes'' vote is for the bill; a ''no'' vote is against the bill; xxx denotes those not voting. Voting yes were 125 Democrats and 91 Republicans. Voting no were 138 Democrats and 73 Republicans. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Erdreich, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, no.

title: DIFFERENT STROKES, COMPUTERIZED
description: An art form first developed in the fifth century has been used to solve a 20th-century technological problem and a result, according to a spokesman at the Library of Congress, is that East Asian scholars are ''jumping for joy.''

title: BREVITY SERVES TO SOOTHE THE C.I.A. AND THE SENATE
description: This is a town of proud people and institutions, where political grudges are often held for years and where peace treaties are rare, especially after a public fracas. But in recent weeks the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence and the Central Intelligence Agency have quietly concluded a new working agreement inspired by their worst rupture in memory.

title: Westinghouse
description: The Marine division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation received a $147.5 million Air Force contract for the second phase of full-scale engineering of the MX missile launching canister, the Defense Department said.

title: France Posts Trade Surplus
description: France recorded its first trade surplus of the year last month, and a Government official said today that it showed the success of the Government's export drive.

L.I.R.R. Panels Named by Reagan
description: President Reagan created two Presidential emergency boards today to intervene in a labor dispute between the Long Island Railroad and two of its unions, the White House announced.

description: The Reagan Watchers

title: U.S. and Israeli Forces Test Medical Airlift
description: Mock casualties were airlifted from ships of the United States Sixth Fleet to hospitals in Israel today, an Israeli military communique said. Military officials said it was the first joint military exercise between the two nations.

title: DUARTE WON'T TALK WITH REBELS YET
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that he would not negotiate with leftist guerrillas until he had created a political climate inside the country permitting such talks to take place.

title: No Headline
description: Free Market as Contraceptive Fear of fallout on abortion: that's why the Reagan Administration is cranking up an ignorant new policy on population control. Ignorant, and dangerous - an example of how staring at short-term politics can blind otherwise sensible officials to the worldwide reality of life.

title: ;  Junior Debt Offer By BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for a shelf offering of up to $400 million in subordinated debt securities.

title: REAGAN CALLS FOR DRINKING AGE OF 21
description: President Reagan got a glimpse of a New Jersey high school's program to combat drunken driving today and called for a nationwide minimum drinking age of 21. He then flew to Connecticut and criticized Democrats for opposing parts of his proposed anticrime legislation.

title: Franklin Computer Layoffs Made
description: Franklin Computer Inc., a maker of the only personal computers designed to be compatible with Apple Computer Inc. systems, has laid off 160 of its 275 employees at its plant and headquarters here, company officers said.

title: ; The treasures ofMrs.Gould.
description: Florence J. Gould entertained lavishly for 25 years, surrounded by her Impressionist paintings, 18th-century French clocks and furniture, English silver, Gothic and Renaissance objects and artist-illustrated books at El Patio, her villa near Cannes in the south of France. Mrs. Gould was the widow of Frank Jay Gould, the youngest child of the 19th-century financier Jay Gould and in his own right a real- estate tycoon, who developed Juan- les-Pins on the French Riviera. She was 87 at her death in February 1983 at El Patio, where such artists, writers and entertainers as Jean Cocteau, Andre Gide, Francois Mauriac, Colette, Henri Matisse, Marie Laurencin and Maurice Chevalier were among her luncheon and dinner guests.

title: BANACH TWINS GRAPPLE WITH THEIR PROBLEMS
description: It happened during the first-round qualifying here last month for the United States Olympic freestyle wrestling team. Lou Banach banged heads with Greg Gibson in their 220-pound match. Banach came away with a bleeding 2-inch gash above his right eye.

title: KOOL FESTIVAL, A TRIBUTE TO BASIE, OPENS TODAY
description: The Kool Jazz Festival, which begins this afternoon at 5 and continues through Sunday, July 1, will be celebrating its 30th anniversary since it started in Newport, R.I. It will also be celebrating the memory of one of the last of a generation of jazz giants who was a constant contributor to the festival - the pianist and orchestra leader Count Basie, who died last April at the age of 79.

title: Bolivia Going to Games
description: The Bolivian Olympic Committee, by a vote of 9 to 6, decided Wednesday night to participate in the Games that begin July 28 in Los Angeles.

title: BILLS TO PROTECT CHILDREN GAIN IN NEW JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Assembly approved two measures today designed to increase public awareness and sharpen official response to the problems of missing or abused children.

title: 12 in Family Reported Slain
description: Cattle rustlers murdered a farmer and his wife and burned their 10 children to death during a raid near Lake Kyoga, northeast of the Ugandan capital of Kampala, travelers from the region said today. The rustlers shot the parents and herded the children into a grass hut, which they set ablaze before making off with 400 head of cattle last Friday, the travelers said.

title: SCOUTING
description: U.S. Influence

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S REMARKS ON TALKS WITH SOVIET
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan today to students attending the National Y.M.C.A. Youth Governors Conference, as recorded by the White House:

title: PATTERN PROCESSING TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-The company had no revenues in the year-ago periods.

title: CRIME AMONG ALIENS: VICTIMS OF OWN ILLEGAL STATUS
description: The incident occurred Memorial Day in the Silver Dollar Lounge, one of the scores of barrio bars where English, not Spanish, sounds out of place and a stranger can talk about his hometown without fear of questions.

title: GLADYS DENNY SCHULTZ
description: Gladys Denny Schultz, a writer and editor, died of cancer Tuesday in Allentown, Pa., where she was staying with the family of her son, Peter. She was 88 years old and had retired to San Diego, Calif., in 1972.

title: CONTINENTAL RESCUE IDEA IS REPORTED
description: The investment adviser to the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has been circulating a proposal under which the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would commit more than $4.6 billion in loans and guarantees to entice a buyer for the Chicago bank, according to banking sources.

title: JUDGE REVERSES LAYOFF RULING ON MINORITIES
description: Following the United States Supreme Court's recent decision on layoffs, a Federal judge today reluctantly reversed his affirmative-action order that white public employees be laid off before employees from minority groups during hard times.

title: DEFIANT POLES LAY CROSS OF FLOWERS
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

title: THE WORRIERS OF WALL STREET
description: THE ''flash'' report from the Commerce Department that the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, has expanded at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the second quarter, following the upward revision of the first-quarter rate to a sensational 9.7 percent, drew mixed reviews in Washington and New York.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL TO MATCH RECIPIENTS WITH ORGAN DONORS
description: The House today overwhelmingly passed legislation to help patients awaiting life-saving organ transplants to find donors. The vote was 396 to 6.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $46,000. The share earnings for the year- earlier periods have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed Aug. 15, 1983.

title: THEATER: 'HURLYBURLY'
description: It seems too good to be true to

title: Dining Out Guide: Salads
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. FOOD WORKSHOP, 424 West 43d Street

title: STEPS TO EASE FLIGHT BOTTLENECKS ARE ANNOUNCED BY AVIATION CHIEF
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration announced several steps yesterday to help ease air traffic congestion that has caused a 55 percent increase over the previous year in flight delays. The measures include a Government-industry study of better scheduling and traffic flow as well as a new evaluation of the ultimate size of the controller force.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INCCtr to May 31 reports earnings for 1984
British Output, Income
description: Britain's gross domestic product rose 0.85 percent in the first quarter from the previous quarter and was up 2.7 percent from the first three months of 1983, the Central Statistical Office said today. It also said that Britain's real income rose by 1.98 percent in the first quarter from the fourth quarter and was up 4 percent from the 1983 first quarter, the office said.

title: POLISH NEWCOMERS REVIVE DYING GREENPOINT CUSTOMS
description: The Greenpoint section of Brooklyn has become more Polish than ever since the imposition of martial law in Poland in 1981.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds tumbled $860.1 million, dropping to $174.01 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: WHY COCOA OUTPUT IN GHANA IS DOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 in Ulster Tied to Murder
description: Three men and a woman from West Belfast were charged in a magistrate's court today with shooting and killing a policeman in Belfast last Friday during a raid on what the police believed was a guerrilla hideout. They were identified as Desmond Cullerton, 23 years old; Christopher McWilliams, 20; Gino Gallagher, 20, and Dorothy McCarron, 20.

title: CRIMINAL MISUNDERSTANDINGS Deregulating Death Do Federal drug regulators have to investigate certain drugs already approved for ordinary use to decide whether they're fit for executing prisoners? The Supreme Court has agreed to answer that question. A bothersome lower court said last fall that if the drugs in question were held out as ''safe and effective'' for the lethal injections that are becoming popular with state executioners, that might constitute misbranding and a kind of fraud.
description: While the Supreme Court's decision won't come until next term, there's not much doubt about the outcome in the current get-tough climate.

title: ; MARK TWAIN'S ODE TO NEW ORLEANS WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: HUDSON IS TOPIC OF PROGRAM
description: The Hudson River, redolent with

title: METS RALLY TO BEAT PHILS AND REGAIN FIRST PLACE
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, a team accustomed to doing a lot of hitting, forced the Mets into an unaccustomed hitting match at Shea Stadium yesterday. To the delight of many of the 20,410 fans, the Mets won, 10-7, and climbed back into first place in the National League East.

title: CHERNENKO DEFIED BY FRENCH LEADER
description: Francois Mitterrand and Konstantin U. Chernenko clashed publicly over human rights tonight, with the French President abandoning diplomatic convention to raise the case of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights activist, at a Kremlin dinner.

title: TO AVERT A 'RUNAWAY' CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Chairman Agrees With Jackson Criticism
description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, agreed today with the Rev. Jesse Jackson that Walter F. Mondale's well-publicized search for a running mate was a ''public relations sideshow.''

title: McGovern Will Teach Two Courses at Duke
description: Former Senator George McGovern, a Democratic Presidential hopeful until a few months ago, will become a visiting professor at Duke University in the next academic year.

title: BRIEFING
description: Patronage Data Bank

title: MARGOLIES RECEIVES 50 YEARS FOR '82 MURDER OF 2 WOMEN
description: Irwin M. Margolies was sentenced yesterday to 50 years to life in prison for the murders of two women in a bungled plot that also led to the death of three CBS technicians.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company was spun off from the Univar Corp. on March 1.

title: Irish Music and Dance
description: A mini-festival of Irish music will take place tonight and tomorrow at Folk City (254-8449), 130 West Third Street at Avenue of the Americas.

title: 10 PEOPLE HONORED FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO PUBLIC SERVICES
description: An orphan from Nampa, Idaho, who made a promise to ''help the children who fall through the cracks,'' was among 10 people honored at the Supreme Court today by the American Institute for Public Service.

title: JOSEPH CAMPBELL, U.S. AIDE;LED ACCOUNTING OFFIVE IN 50'S
description: Joseph Campbell, head of the General Accounting Office from 1955 to 1965, died yesterday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Offer Made in Lloyd's Case
description: In an effort to avoid years of complex litigation, Minet Holdings P.L.C. and the New York-based Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. today proposed a $52 million settlement of claims growing out of a scandal that shook the Lloyd's of London insurance market two years ago.

title: Misuse Found In Surplus Cheese
description: Employees of the city's Human Rights Commission took home nearly 200 pounds of Federal surplus cheese - originally intended for the poor - on two occasions last year, a city investigator said yesterday.

title: DOCTORS WARN CONGRESS ON FIXED MEDICARE FEES
description: The leadership of the American Medical Association warned Congress and the public today that many doctors would refuse to treat Medicare patients rather than accept a mandatory fixed-fee system now being considered by Congress.

title: SCREEN: 'POPE OF GREENWICH VILLIAGE'
description: ''THe Pope of Greenwich Village,'' which opens today at the Paramount and other theaters, is a singularly gross and unattractive screen version of Vincent Patrick's novel, adapted by him and directed by Stuart Rosenberg in the seeming delusion that he was making another ''Mean Streets.''

title: Atlantic Airline Wins Approval
description: Britain's fledgling Virgin Atlantic Airways said today that it had received final approval from British authorities to start its low-cost daily service between London and Newark.

title: BLUE JAYS TOP RED SOX, 5-2
description: Willie Upshaw drove in two runs, including the tiebreaker in the ninth inning, and the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5-2, tonight.

title: BERRLINGUER'S ASSETS AND MANY LIABILITES
description: Enrico Berlinguer achieved in death what he was never able to achieve in life - in the elections to the European Parliament, the Italian Communist Party overtook the Christian Democrats and earned a plurality of the popular vote. This may well upset the existing non-Communist coalition headed by Socialist Party leader Bettino Craxi and lead to new national elections. But Communist entry into the Government remains neither inevitable nor desirable.

title: The Teachers Learn, Too
description: At Public School 8 in Brooklyn

title: Taking 68 Years to Feel Like an Erasmus Alumnus
description: Half-a-credit short when his class

title: No Headline
description: Still 50-50 on Immigration? For about 15 minutes, the movie ''Moscow on the Hudson'' turns profoundly funny. A Soviet musician has just defected in New York City, in Bloomingdale's, and who teaches him about life in this country? A young woman sales clerk, recently arrived from Italy. A cab driver from Korea. A bus passenger who's Iranian. A woman shopper who's Japanese. It's the modern melting pot, barely an exaggeration of what's happened since the last immigration law reform, in 1965.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a plan by the Edison Electric Institute to help clean up the Three Mile Island nuclear plant incorrectly described a previous plan. Under the previous plan, money from utilities would not be made available until the institute had collected pledges of $100 million from its members.

title: The Loudest Voices
description: The loudest voices are being heard. The quiet majority doesn't get much of a forum. That is why the racial and ethnic strains in this city and elsewhere have grown to serious proportions.

title: FILM: 'TOP SECRET!', PARODY OF SPY MOVIES
description: Consider Omar Sharif staring earnestly out of a coffin- shaped bundle of metal splinters and wires that was once a Mercedes-Benz, which has recently been compacted with the indestructible, uncompactable Omar inside it; or, a white cow, covered with large black polka dots, ambling across a soggy field, in the manner of a beast that knows there are a thousand tomorrows, wearing rubber boots; or, the recollection of an East German who says that he had an uncle who was born in the United States, ''but he escaped during the Carter Administration - in a balloon.''

title: THE SHORT LIST FOR VICE PRESIDENT
description: In choosing a running mate, there are basically two ways a Presidential nominee can go - the tall way and the short way. You select someone who is either taller - or shorter - than you are. For a nominee to underestimate the importance of this decision would be the height of folly. My own feeling is that Walter Mondale would be wise to pull together a short list.

title: STUDY LINKS LOW-SALT DIET TO HYPERTENSION
description: In a sharp challenge to conventional medical views, a new epidemiological study has concluded that high blood pressure is associated with eating too little sodium, or salt, rather than too much.

title: KOCH BLOCKS ACCORD ON SUBWAY ACCESS FOR DISABLED PEOPLE
description: Mayor Koch blocked an agreement yesterday that would have made some of the city's subway stations accessible to the disabled and permitted the modernization of the city's subways to proceed.

title: Portugal to Hold Rebel Incommunicado 20 Days
description: Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, a Portuguese revolutionary leader arrested in a Government drive on suspected urban guerrillas, will be kept incommunicado for 20 days, his wife said today.

title: Uncharitable in Washington
description: The Reagan Administration, which has worked relentlessly to curb Federal funding for groups that it regards as leftist, has now revived efforts to remove certain groups from the roster of charitable organizations to which Federal workers contribute. Even after being rebuffed by two courts, the Administration is determined to issue new rules to accomplish its goal.

title: CONFEREES BREAK 3-DAY DEADLOCK
description: House and Senate tax conferees reached agreement on health care and public assistance spending cuts tonight, opening the way for approval of a $50 billion tax increase and a package of spending cuts totaling about $11.2 billion through 1987.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THIS place is real,'' Peter Wright was saying at a party to celebrate the purchase and renovation of two carriage houses on West 89th Street as headquarters for the Ballet Hispanico. ''So much else on the Upper West Side is not. When you see seven ice cream parlors in six blocks, you know it can't be real.'' Mr. Wright, a neighborhood resident, also considered ''real West Side'' the fact that the tape used for the rendition of a flamenco by three teen-age Ballet Hispanico students wouldn't play at first.

title: Olympic Accord For the Coliseum
description: An agreement has been reached between negotiators for the Coliseum and the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee for the use of the stadium during the Summer Games, which begin July 28.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Building Maintenance Industries, San Francisco, has elevated Sydney J. Rosenberg to chairman, and elected David Anacker president and chief executive.

title: House Unit Backs Bank Curbs
description: A House subcommittee approved a comprehensive bill today that would keep banks out of other financial businesses, including stock brokerage and direct operation of mutual funds.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF '1980, A PIECE BY PINA BAUSCH'
description: When members of an audience tell you that they absolutely hate what they are seeing on stage and then stay rather than leave - well, then, you know the artist responsible for it all has stirred the public in anything but a routine way.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1984 International
description: A French-Soviet verbal clash occurred publicly at a Kremlin banquet. Francois Mitterrand and Konstantin U. Chernenko made conflicting statements about human rights, with the French President abandoning diplomatic convention to raise the case of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights activist. Earlier, a Soviet spokesman, Leonid M. Zamyatin, indicated that Mr. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, was not prepared to meet with President Reagan soon. (Page A1, Col. 5.) The President criticized the Kremlin. Mr. Reagan said that Soviet officials ''do not know what they are talking about'' in insisting that his policies were too intransigent to make a summit meeting feasible. (A3:1-2.)

title: Sale of Indians Planned
description: American League ownership changes appear to be continuing with little letup. Just after it had been announced that Calvin Griffith would complete the sale of his Minnesota Twins in a pregame ceremony tonight, Patrick O'Neill , the chairman of the Cleveland Indians, said he was on the verge of selling controlling interest to David LeFevre , a Cleveland- born New York lawyer.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for 16 wks to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $21,000 for the quarter and year and a net loss of $330,000 for the year from securities transactions. c-Including tax credits of $3,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the year.

title: 2 PLANS THAT WOULD ADD TO POLICE FORCE DEBATED
description: Two plans to add to the city's police presence without paying the full cost for full-time officers are being debated by law enforcement officials.

title: Southwest Forest
description: Jefferson Smurfit Group Ltd. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed not to acquire more than 20 percent of the common shares outstanding of Southwest Forest Industries during the six- month period beginning June 13.

title: 2,000 Filipinos March In an Economic Protest
description: About 2,000 protesters, led by members of the family of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the assassinated opposition leader, marched in the Makati business district today to denounce the economic policies of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: CHALLENGE TO A.T.& T. COMPUTER
description: When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduces its entry in the personal computer market Tuesday, its biggest task may be to satisfy a horde of skeptics that it has not waded into battle with I.B.M. with the wrong machine at the wrong time.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss including a foreign tax credit of $8,688,000.

title: Chrysler Financial SetsIssues Up to $1.5 Billion
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that it plans to issue $1.5 billion of debt securities.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LINCOLN LOGS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A CITY PANEL APPROVES PLAN TO HELP BROADWAY THEATERS
description: After two years of discussion, a mayoral commission yesterday approved a series of zoning proposals and other incentives aimed at preserving Broadway's 44 legitimate theaters and strengthening the Broadway theater district in general.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS GRENADA INVASION PRESS BAN
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Defense Department was within its rights in prohibiting news coverage of the initial stages of the United States-led invasion of Grenada in October.

title: Dead Whale Under Study
description: Scientists began studying the carcass of a gray whale Wednesday in hopes of determining what killed it and several others found dead in inland waters in Washington and British Columbia in the past two months. While one or two deaths a year are considered normal in the Pacific Northwest's inland waters, a toll of six in a short period is not.

title: BONN TO CUT TAXES BY $7.2 BILLION
description: The West German Government today announced a hefty package of tax cuts intended to stimulate the economy. But business leaders voiced disappointment that the measures came late and afforded little help for corporations.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
HOLDING DOWN COSTS AT A COMPLEX IN SULLIVAN COUNTY
description: Since the mid-1970's the shortage of attractive new housing costing less than $100,000 has become much talked about. But there are some builders who have been able to turn out such homes and make a profit.

title: PENNINGTON'S STORES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $150,000.

title: Grace, Delmed
description: Delmed Inc. said it is in discussions with W. R. Grace & Company on an arrangement that would include Grace's acquisition of a minority stake and option for additional equity investments in Delmed, a maker of specialized medical products. Delmed said the arrangement would also call for Grace to receive a seat on Delmed's board and for the two companies to cooperate in a number of manufacturing and development projects. On the American Stock Exchange today, Delmed rose 75 cents, to $7.125.

title: INNOVATIVE SOUNDS GET A NEW SHOWCASE
description: This year, Verna Gillis of Soundscape is again booking the festival's fringe, but the concerts have been moved from Soundscape's 10th Avenue loft to the larger, more accessible, air-conditioned Irving Plaza (477-3728), 17 Irving Place, near Union Square. As with most Gillis projects, the lineup is cross-cultural, with concerts that should also suggest some unexpected connections.

title: Airlines Combating Drugs
description: The airlines are joining the Government in a campaign to keep commercial aircraft from being used to smuggle illicit drugs into the United States, the Civil Aeronautics Board says. Elements of the plan, developed by the Air Transport Association, which represents the airlines, include special training for flight crews to help them recognize and counter illegal drug trafficking; more intense scrutiny of cargo both in foreign airports and on arrival in the United States, and tighter security and inspections of aircraft.

title: JEWISH TERRORIST IN ISRAEL IS SENTENCED TO 10 YEARS
description: An Israeli court sentenced a Jewish terrorist today to 10 years in prison for his role in attempted assaults on Palestinian Arabs and for taking part in a plot to blow up one of Islam's holiest shrines.

title: Midwest Rain Continues And Crop Losses Mount By The Associated Press
description: Rain pounded the water-logged Middle West for a ninth straight day yesterday, adding as much as four inches to flood waters that have claimed two lives.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are some pretty hefty ones in my backyard. Several of them tried to carry me away.

title: ; 'Top Secret' rock star aims to be lovable.
description: Val Kilmer was not exactly typecast for his role as a 1950's American rock-and- roll star in ''Top Secret,'' which opens today at the Embassy 1 and 2 and other theaters (reviewed on page C10). For one thing, he had to learn to sing. For another, he had to dance. He also had to play one scene underwater and another doing everything backward. His three directors, the brothers David and Jerry Zucker and Jim Abraham, stopped short of having Mr. Kilmer juggle turkey legs, but only because they had featured a juggling stunt in ''Airplane!'' and didn't want to repeat themselves.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today June 22, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ACCORD IS SEEN CLEARING WAY FOR CLEAN WATER ACT
description: Environmental and industry groups have reached agreement with key legislators on a compromise that could pave the way for renewal of the Clean Water Act next week by the House of Representatives.

title: RECORD BLOCK IS TRADED
description: The stock market's flirtation with prosperity halted yesterday as prices finished mixed in heavy trading after climbing sharply in the previous three sessions.

title: FoodTemperature Tied to Poisoning
description: Improper regulation of food temperatures at the Hoboken High School cafeteria was the probable cause of 169 cases of food poisoning earlier this month, the New Jersey Department of Health said today.

title: LATIN DEBTORS CONSIDER A PANEL TO SPEAK FOR ALL
description: A consensus began to emerge among 11 Latin American countries today they they might form a commission to represent them in proposed talks with industrial nations on setting a new framework to refinance third-world debt.

title: TAKEOVER OF PETROLANE SET BY TEXAS EASTERN
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation and Petrolane Inc. said yesterday that they had entered into a definitive agreement for Texas Eastern to acquire Petrolane for $20 a share, or some $1.1 billion.

title: SUFFOLK IS SUED BY LILCO FOR BLOCKING SHOREHAM
description: The Long Island Lighting Company asked today in a $4 billion suit that Suffolk County pay for the Shoreham nuclear power station because of the county's efforts to block emergency planning and make licensing of the reactor impossible.

title: 2D COMPANY PLANS TO MAKE SCA BID
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd. said yesterday that it wants to acquire SCA Services Inc., which specializes in handling solid and chemical wastes, and combine it with its Laidlaw Industries unit, which is involved in solid-waste disposal in the United States and Canada.

title: Reagan Gets Maximum In U.S. Matching Funds
description: President Reagan on Wednesday became the first Presidential candidate to qualify for the $10.1 million maximum amount of Federal matching funds for a nomination drive.

title: Olajuwon's Demands
description: The Houston Rockets and Akeem Olajuwon , the top choice in the draft this week, have opened contract negotiations and have run into an immediate impasse. Olajuwon asked for a four-year contract similar to the $5.4 million deal Ralph Sampson got from the team last year, and the front office turned down the idea as too expensive.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for 16wks to May 20
description: b-Net income after a loss of $853,000 from discontinued operations. The latest quarter includes results of Flower Time Inc. which was acquired March 2 and year-ago period includes results of Frank's Nursery & Crafts Inc. which was acquired March 7, 1983. All figures restated to reflect change in fiscal year to the last Sunday in January from the last Saturday in December. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: One-Officer Cars Backed by a Study
description: A $500,000 study conducted for New York City concludes that one-officer police cars are not a threat to the safety of the officers.

title: HART CAMP CONCILIATORY ON PLATFORM
description: Backers of Senator Gary Hart expressed widespread satisfaction today with the latest draft of the Democratic platform, one that they had substantially influenced. They indicated they would probably not attempt to overturn the few votes that went against them in the drafting committee earlier this week.

title: Gold Futures Linkup
description: The New York Commodity Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange are still ''some way off'' from agreeing on a 24-hour linkup for trading gold futures, Comex's president, Alan Brody, said today. Mr. Brody, in Australia for negotiations with the Sydney exchange, said that ''too many variables'' were involved to predict a start-up date for the link that would allow traders to offset gold futures positions interchangeably on either exhange.

title: 'VIDEOVILLE' OFFERS DOCUMENTARIES
description: While the bulk of public television drifts toward safe programming, preferably introduced by a celebrity, WNYC, Channel 31, has been developing one of the system's more adventurous schedules. One example is ''Videoville,'' a showcase for independent producers, which can be seen Sunday nights through the summer at 10.

title: SCREEN: IN 'RHINESTONE,' CABBIE GOES COUNTRY
description: His role is that of a New York cabbie who isn't supposed to be able to sing throughout most of the story, and who, by the end of it, is. There's a moment in ''Top Secret'' in which the villains decide to torture their prisoner with Leroy Neiman paintings, then realize that this would violate the Geneva Convention. The authors doubtless hadn't seen Mr. Stallone in a spangled cowboy suit, trying to belt out something tuneful.

title: GETTING STARTED IN JINGLES
description: IF the memories of your Golden

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Dallas Cowboys quarterback, Danny White , who admitted he struck 17-year-old Jon Michael Clark in the face last Feb. 25 in a traffic dispute but said it was in self-defense, was acquitted last night on a misdemeanor assault charge. A jury of four-men and two women in McKinney, Tex., deliberated about an hour before returning the not-guilty verdict and ending a four-day trial. . . . Craig Swan , the pitcher who was released by the Mets last month and picked up by the California Angels, underwent surgery on his right arm and will be sidelined for several weeks. Doctors moved a muscle in Swan's upper arm that was restricting an artery. . . . Pat Kennedy , who has led Iona to three consecutive postseason tournaments in his four years as head basketball coach, has signed a new four- year contract with the school.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. It's Dwight Gooden's turn to pitch again, and he faces another hard-thrower, Bill Gullickson.

title: SCREEN 'KARATE KID,' BANE OF BULLIES
description: A large part of ''The Karate Kid'' - the best part, really - seems to be taking place inside a fortune cookie. It is here, in the serene realm of Oriental wisdom, Hollywood-style, that a teen- ager named Daniel (Ralph Macchio) is taught lesson after lesson about life. His instructor is an elderly man named Mr. Miyagi, played by Noriyuki (Pat) Morita, who is first seen trying to catch flies with a pair of chopsticks. Throughout the film, Mr. Miyagi sustains a scene-stealing, if hokey, eccentricity.

title: SCOUTING
description: A New Twist

title: Air Express Chooses Veteran Freight Official
description: Lawrence L. Rodberg, who led Burlington Northern Air Freight Inc. from its founding and resigned as chairman and chief executive because of policy differences, was named chairman and chief executive of the Air Express International Corporation yesterday.

title: 400 Are Laid Off By Charter Co.
description: About 400 of the Charter Company's employees have been laid off since the company filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy law two months ago, and future layoffs are possible, a company spokesman said.

title: RABBINICAL GROUP MAY TRY TO STOP SALE AT SOTHEBY'S
description: The Central Conference of American Rabbis, the group that represents Reform rabbis in the United States and Canada, said yesterday that it would go to court in an attempt to prevent the sale Tuesday of 33 Hebrew books and manuscripts at Sotheby's, unless the possessors of the books are publicly shown to have legal title to them.

title: REAGAN, REBUTTING RUSSIAN, SAYS HE'S IN SUMMIT MOOD
description: President Reagan said today that Soviet officials ''do not know what they are talking about'' in insisting that his policies were too intransigent to make a summit meeting feasible.

title: SCOUTING
description: Miller Time

title: JACKSON EASES POSITION ON RULES; CANDIDATE ALSO ASSERTS HE'S PREPARED TO BACK DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE
description: In his most conciliatory move of late, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that recent efforts by the Democratic Party leadership to resolve his concerns over party rules represented an ''earnest'' attempt to reach a solution.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WILD BERRIES. By Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 296 pages. Morrow. $15.95. Wild Berries,'' Yevgeny Yevtushenko's first novel, is the Soviet equivalent of a potboiler. It consists of action, sex, landscape and elementary discussions of Russian life and literature. The descriptions of landscape are the best part; Mr. Yevtushenko is, after all, a well-known poet. Here and there, he manages a nice vignette or two, but generally the writing and the plotting are slapdash. In fact, it's remarkable that such an experienced poet should be so clumsy even in his first novel.

title: Bid on Basic Four
description: Management Assistance Inc. said it had received a proposal from a private investor group to acquire the company's worldwide Basic Four Information Systems operations, including international maintenance activities.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $3 BILLION
description: In a report that did little to ease investor fears about the future course of interest rates, the Federal Reserve said yesterday that the nation's basic money supply, M-1, rose by $3 billion in the week ended June 11.

title: WET SPRING YIELDS BIG MOSQUITO CROP
description: With the first hatch of mosquitoes already in the air, official mosquito watchers in the New York metropolitan area have taken to their boats, trucks and helicopters to combat what they fear will be the worst infestation of the insects in years.

title: President Adds a TitleAt Bank of New England
description: Peter J. McCormick, president of the Bank of New England Corporation in Boston, was named to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Roderick M. MacDougall, who remains chairman.

title: INCREASE IN CANCER PREDICTED S MORE PEOPLE LIVE LONGER
description: Cancer cases may double among Americans over the next 40 years and the costs of treatment may become an even greater factor in the economy than Government officials have realized, according to a statistical analysis published yesterday in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute. The projected rise, which does not reflect increased danger from cancer-causing agents, would result instead from a proportionate rise in the number of people surviving into the years when cancer most often arises, according to the study. Nor does the study reflect the possibility that current extensive medical efforts against the disease may succeed in some measure.

title: RECALL ORDERED FOR G.M. CARS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered the General Motors Corporation to recall about 550,000 1980- model automobiles that have exhaust emissions exceeding Federal standards on nitrogen oxides.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
LONDON STAGE CHEERS RETURN OF MISS COLBERT
description: To praise from the British press and intermittent bursts of applause, Claudette Colbert returned to the London stage this week for the first time since 1928.

title: 'DERNIER COMBAT,' FRENCH SCIENCE FICTION
description: Luc Besson's ''Dernier Combat'' sounds like a feat of gamesmanship, but it certainly doesn't play that way. Mr. Besson has filmed this futuristic fantasy in black and white, using no dialogue and, for his locations, only a series of crumbling, deserted buildings. Amazingly, the lack of conversation isn't a serious handicap, since the leading actor, Pierre Jolivet (who also wrote the script with Mr. Besson) is as wordlessly expressive as the direction.

title: TAINTED NEWS ABOUT THE WAR IN AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: LINSKY COLLECITON OF PAINTINGS AND OBJECTS OPENS AT MET
description: The opening this week of the new Jack and Belle Linsky Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum celebrates yet another remarkable acquisition in bulk for this capacious institution: 373 objects - including old-master paintings, French furniture, bronzes, porcelains, enamels, goldsmiths' work and jewelry. They were donated in 1982 by Belle Linsky, who, with her late husband, Jack, built a modest stationery business into a multimillion-dollar corporation that included Swingline Inc., a manufacturer of staplers.

title: PANEL IS BEING FORMED TO RESCUE WORLD'S FAIR FROM FISCAL MORASS
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today that he would turn over the financial management of the 1984 World's Fair to a committee in an effort to improve the fair's muddled finances and keep it from closing.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $677,000 for the latest quarter and $112,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Georgia Power Co. , has priced its offering of $150 million of first mortgage bonds, 16 percent series, due June 1, 2014, at 99.875 to yield 16.02 percent, through Paine Webber.

title: Article 019082 -- No Title
description: The Senate passed early today a bill establishing or continuing $230 billion in military programs, and the measure headed for a House-Senate conference.

title: Phone-Mate Deal
description: Phone-Mate Inc. said it had entered into a letter of intent with the Asahi Corporation under which Asahi intends to supply substantial additional financial assistance to Phone-Mate and to acquire a majority interest in the company. Asahi, a maker of telecommunications products, is Phone- Mate's principal supplier. The intended financial assistance includes a $4 million subordinated term note, up to $5 million of trade financing and up to $1.5 million of cost reductions associated with Phone-Mate's purchase of Asahi products.

title: Beatrice-Esmark
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said its tender offer for all of Esmark Inc.'s common and preferred stock outstanding had netted 39,083,136 common shares, or 91 percent, and 1,886,037 preferred shares, or 73 percent, of Esmark's stock outstanding.

title: ART OF BRITISH HOMES TO BE EXHIBITED
description: More than 800 objects of art from at least 120 British stately homes will be sent to the United States next year for an exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: 2 Officers Cleared In Bronx Shooting
description: A Bronx grand jury cleared two police officers yesterday of any crime in shooting the wrong man during a grocery store holdup in April.

title: Topics: Criminal Misunderstandings
description: Anti-Crime Credit

title: D.D.B. Creative LeaderJoins Tuesday Team
description: Marvin Honig, the talented agency creative leader, while out at Doyle Dane Bernbach, which once helped defeat Senator Barry Goldwater by electing Lyndon Johnson, is in at the Tuesday Team, the group that has been pulled together to re-elect the Reagan-Bush team. That is the news from James Travis, the Team head.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $3.1 million from the sale of property.

title: Genscher Plans to Quit Party Post Early in '85
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has led the Free Democratic Party for 10 years, told his party today that he would step down as chairman early next year, a year sooner than planned.

title: BRIDGE
description: Bridge:Montreal Expert Achieved The Ultimate in Last Bows

title: HIGH JUMPER OF UNUSUAL STYLE
description: The sight was a strange one: Janet Rowley of Saugas, Mass., was whispering encouragement to her only rival in the high jump at the International Games for the Disabled today.

title: Alexander's Stock
description: An investment group including individuals associated with Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. of Fort Worth told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in Alexander's Inc. common stock to 608,600 shares, or 13.5 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Senate Votes to Form U.S. Peace Academy
description: The Senate voted today to establish a United States Academy of Peace to train American and foreign leaders in the nonviolent resolution of conflicts.

title: No Headline
description: Agency Must Explain A Long Benefits Delay

title: Prices Up in Denmark
description: Wholesale prices in Denmark rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in May from April, and were up 9.7 percent from a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today. April also showed a rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: An Informed Officer Is a Helpful Officer
description: Insignia on one lapel of their uniform

title: A WOMEN FINDS BIAS AS A RABBI
description: Every Saturday morning, the rabbi of the Beth Shalom Congregation walks nearly two miles to the synagogue, dons a prayer shawl and conducts a Sabbath service, complete with a sermon and the reading of the Torah.

title: ANALYSTS DIFFER ON COAL ISSUES
description: REVIEWING the performance of 110 stock groups, the Merrill Lynch Market Letter noted this week that the coal sector, on a relative strength basis, climbed to 18th place from 51st only a month ago.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in April 1984.

title: DEBT OF THE EAST BLOC: LESS THAN 'IMMENSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Kills Girl,7 And Then Himself
description: A Bronx man shot andf killed his 7-year-old daughter yesterday, critically wounded his 4-year old son and then fatally shot himself in the head, police said.

title: F-14 Falls From a Carrier
description: An F-14 Tomcat jet fighter fell into the Arabian Sea and was declared lost after it broke lose while being towed across the deck of the aircraft carrier America, the Seventh Fleet announced today. The pilot escaped with minor injuries when he jumped to the flight deck.

title: A Mortgage Series For Salomon Unit
description: Salomon Brothers Mortgage Securities II Inc. filed a shelf registration with the S.E.C. for up to $1 billion of collateralized mortgage obligations issuable in series.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RAWLEY DEFEATS ORIOLES
description: In a classic western film years ago, as Alan Ladd rode off into the sunset, Brandon de Wilde called to him, ''Shane, come back.'' Tonight Shane came back, Shane Rawley, that is.

title: Saturday Review Sold
description: Saturday Review, once a weekly journal of literature and the arts but moribund since January, was sold today by Jeffrey Gluck to a group of investors headed by Paul Dietrich of Washington, president of the nonprofit National Center for Legislative Research.

title: Florida Sprays to Combat Danger of Fruit Fly
description: Agriculture agents, armed with the insecticide malathion, sprayed trees here today in an effort to prevent any spread of Mediterranean fruit flies that could endanger the state's important citrus and produce industries.

title: BRIEFING
description: Attentive Contractors

title: For Children
description: MOVIN' ANIMALS, a program with Scott Bedrick, who will demonstrate to children how to make animals by using origami, the Japanese art of folding paper, Saturday at 1 P.M., (reservations required: 772-0210), and FOLK MUSIC FROM PUERTO RICO, played by Pepe Castillo y Estampa Criolla, Sunday at 2 and 3 P.M., at Belvedere Castle, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Free. THE TINDER BOX, a story by Hans Christian Andersen, told by Diane Wolkstein, Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Andersen Statue, near Fifth Avenue and 72d Street in Central Park. Free.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a $2,500,000 provision in the first quarter as a reserve for restructuring debt related to the 1981 divestiture of Glas-Craft.

title: BASEBALL APPROVES PROGRAM ON DRUGS
description: Major league baseball owners emerged from a three-hour meeting in Kansas City yesterday with ratification of a management-union program to deal with drug abuse among players.

title: To Halt Takeover
description: Atlas Van Lines Inc. told a Federal judge that he should block an investor group's bid for control of Atlas until the group provided stockholders with more information. Atlas, meanwhile, asked that trading in its stock be halted on the American Stock Exchange and said it might have an announcement later.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
MUSIC: 'PATIENCE' AT MET
description: One of the misfortunes of contemporary American life is that we have no Gilbert and Sullivan to stick pins in our pretensions while keeping us doubled up with laughter. Certainly enough targets exist to keep such a team of satirists busy on the popular musical stage. Of course, you might remark that the British also suffer from a similar lack at the moment. Broad parody is in demand, as always, but genuine satire, even of a mild variety, is hard to come by.

title: Thousands Flee Floods In Bangladesh and India
description: Tens of thousands of people have lost their homes in monsoon floods in Bangladesh and northeast India, officials said today.

title: PARTIES FOR THE ARTS, UPTOWN AND DOWN
description: Two parties Wednesday night reconfirmed one of the inexorable laws of New York nature. Uptown everyone loves a tiara. Downtown they just don't care.

title: WHERE TO WATCH THE BIRDS OF SUMMER
description: An indigo bunting sings greetings to the sun as it rises over hazy Yonkers and the Hudson River. The brilliant blue of the bird's feathers puts to shame the sky's early- morning pallor and distracts a solitary observer so that he doesn't notice a red- tailed hawk until it silently glides by right under his nose. He can almost reach out and touch the birds.

title: JACKSON EASES POSITION ON RULES ; PARTY'S OFFICIALS STRESS GOVERNOR'S SKILL AND THE NEW YORK VOTE
description: Governor Cuomo of New York was chosen today to give the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco next month, an important symbolic role that traditionally sets the tone for the convention and the fall campaign.

title: Puget Sound's Utility Bond Sale
description: The Puget Sound Power and Light Company yesterday offered $75 million worth of extendable first mortgage bonds due July 1, 1996.

title: NEW YORK ASSEMBLY PASSES BILL REQUIRING SEAT BELT USE
description: After a long debate in which safety, civil liberties and George Orwell were all invoked, the State Assembly tonight approved a measure requiring drivers and their front-seat passengers to wear seat belts in New York State. The vote was 82 to 60 - 6 votes more than were needed for passage.

title: LEWIS WINS 200, HIS 4TH BERTH
description: Carl Lewis has achieved all his goals in the United States Olympic track and field trials. His ambitious schedule ended successfully tonight when he won the men's 200-meter final in 19.86 seconds.

title: WORLD BANK UNIT TO DOUBLE CAPITAL
description: A World Bank affiliate that backs private enterprise in developing countries today won board approval of a doubling of its capital. The move is expected to lead to $30 billion of third-world investments in mining, textiles, tourism and other areas over five years.

title: Enstar Vote Tally Awaited
description: Roy M. Huffington said he believed that his dissident group had won its proxy contest against management of the Enstar Corporation. He made his remarks after Enstar adjourned its annual meeting until July 6 to complete counting the votes.

title: ART: 'NEW WORK,' AN ANTHOLOGY, AT NEW MUSEUM
description: Wiht its connotations of the assembly line, ''new work,'' like ''young artists,'' is a term that can bring on a sinking feeling. Often the new models come so hot on the heels of the old that the sense is of a glut to be stockpiled pending distribution - perhaps to nations less richly endowed with contemporary art.

title: MONDALE MEETS LOS ANGELES MAYOR ON NO. 2 SPOT
description: Walter F. Mondale began meeting prospective running mates today by interviewing Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles. He said the nation was ready for a black Vice President.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; DeLorean Defense Picks On U.S. Change of Dates
description: A Federal drug agent conceded today that when he told a grand jury that July 6, 1982, was the date when an informer first told him John Z. DeLorean was interested in transacting a drug deal, he had nothing to base the date on other than the informer's word.

title: BROADWAY;
description: Empty nest refills to hatch a comedy scheduled this fall.

title: PNC Financial In Expansion Deal
description: TThe PNC Financial Corporation has agreed in principle to acquire Northeastern Bancorp in a transaction valued at about $100 million, the two bank holding companies said.

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STARS ARE NEXT FOR GENERALS
description: When is a game just another game, an event whose outcome has no significance of any kind?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Archive Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., said it had signed six contracts worth $13.7 million with five companies to supply streaming cartridge tape drives, used for backup and protective storage of computer information.

title: SCOUTING
description: 'Fall From Grace' Stuns Torrez

title: Diner's Journal
description: Ristorante Dieci is a small, polished Italian restaurant on the Upper East Side (First Avenue, between 81st and 82d Streets), which appears to attract a regular clientele from the neighborhood. Outlanders may want to become familiar with it for two of its noteworthy summer dishes.

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: American cooking in year of the pillar.

title: IN THE VILLAGES OF CHINA, BUSINESS RIVALRY BLOOMS
description: A hand-cranked telephone still stands between Ma Tianying and his hopes of becoming the richest peasant in his village in Sichuan Province.

title: O'Neill Won't Call A Special Session
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill declined today to call a special legislative session to appropriate part of the projected state budget surplus to local schools. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities had requested the session.

title: Queen Cancels Visit To a Struck Coal Mine
description: Queen Elizabeth II has canceled a visit next week to a mine hit by picket-line violence, and the Government coal chief warned that a strike in its 102d day could go on until next year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: Warning: Film Violence Ahead Connoisseurs of subtlety treasure Alfred Hitchcock, who, even in his bloodiest film, ''Psycho,'' never showed a knife piercing flesh. They treasure, too, the way Fritz Lang signaled the murder of a child in his classic ''M'' - the balloon she was holding rose to the sky. And the way Jacques Tourneur showed the cat in ''The Cat People'' - with shadows on a wall.

title: Bad News for Giants
description: Gordon King , the Giant offensive tackle who broke his left elbow late last season, has failed to recover properly and will undergo further surgery next week.

title: No Headline
description: Body Chemicals Tied To Onset of Hay Fever

title: HUGE BLAST SAID TO HIT A MAJOR SOVIET ARMS DEPOT
description: A huge explosion apparently ripped through a major navy ammunition storage depot in the Soviet Union last month, and many people are believed to have died in the blast, United States intelligence sources said today.

title: Jobless Rate Dips in E.E.C.
description: Unemployment in nine of the ten countries in the European Economic Community fell to 10.8 percent in May from 11 percent in April, the community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today.

title: RESTRICTIONS ARE EASED IN PUNJAB BUT HUNT FOR MILITANTS CONTINUES
description: Most curfew restrictions were lifted, travel bans were relaxed and all but two Sikh shrines were reopened today in the northern state of Punjab.

title: UNION ASSERTS CITY DISCRIMINATES AGAINST OPERATORS IN 911 SYSTEM
description: New York City's largest union has filed Federal and state complaints charging the city with discriminating against the Police Department's 911 emergency operators on the basis of sex, race and national origin.

title: Purvis Again Ahead After Carolina Recount
description: Melvin Purvis, who squeaked ahead of his opponent in the Democratic Senate primary so narrowly that a recount was required, again came out ahead Wednesday after the votes were retallied.

title: FINAL ACTION ON ALIEN BILL DOUBTED BEFORE RECESS
description: Supporters of a comprehensive immigration bill said today that they wanted swift action to resolve differences between the House and Senate but that they did not expect final action before next month's Democratic National Convention.

title: THE CANDIDATE FROM HANNIABL, MO.
description: The nation's electorate, Mark Twain once said, has ''usually not been willing to have a chief magistrate of gold when it could get one of tin.'' Therefore, ''in the present emergency,'' Twain, as portrayed by his most devoted current disciple, is offering himself for President again this year ''to purify the political atmosphere.''

title: LAWHON, JOHN F, FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIEFING
description: Conservative Band

title: Equitable Realty Is Offering Bonds
description: The Equitable Realty Assets Corporation yesterday priced $161.5 million of mortgaged-backed bonds.

title: WHEN GOALS OF BOSS AND HIS STAFF LAWYERS CLASH
description: Some people go to work for the Government because they need jobs, others because they are fired by a sense of mission. The second category includes both William Bradford Reynolds, head of the Justice Department's civil rights division, and many of the lawyers working there when he took over in 1981.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE Friday DIXIELAND AT SUMMERPIER
description: The fact that they're English and play Dixieland is not the only unusual aspect of the NatWest Jazz band. The 10 men in the group were bank managers (all but one still are) in branches of the National Westminster Bank when they started playing together 10 years ago. At first they just played for bank functions, but they have gone public, and make recordings, too. They'll be at the South Street Seaport's Pier 16, Fulton Street and the East River, tonight at 8, in the free jazz series known as Summerpier. Concerts on Thursday and Friday nights at 8 (rain dates, Mondays at 8) through Aug. 10. Free tickets at the box office two hours beforehand. Chairs, blankets and refreshments welcome. Information: 669-9400. WRITERS AT PURCHASE

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Sunny Johnson, 30, Actress; Was Skater in 'Flashdance'
description: Sunny Johnson, the actress who portrayed Jennifer Beals's figure-skating friend in the 1983 film ''Flashdance,'' has died from a burst blood vessel in her brain, it was disclosed today. She was 30 years old.

title: 9 COMPANIES ASKED TO SUBMIT PLAN FOR HOTEL NEAR TIMES SQUARE
description: Nine ''big league, mega-developers'' have been authorized to submit proposals to build and operate a hotel within the Times Square redevelopment site, the chairman of the Urban Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: NATO CUTS SOVIET-BLOC ESTIMATE
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today published a revised comparison of its troop strength and that of the Soviet-bloc Warsaw Pact, and tacitly acknowledged that it had been exaggerating the numerical superiority of Soviet-bloc armies available for combat in Europe.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED ON RULES BUT NOT JACKSON DELEGATES
description: A committee of the House Democratic Caucus moved today toward recommending development of new rules for the 1988 election but not toward granting the Rev. Jesse Jackson more delegates to the party convention this year, according to committee members.

title: ORWELLIAN AMBIVALENCE TOWARD ADOLF HITLER
description: To the Editor:

title: Swedish Trade Balance
description: Sweden's current account deficit narrowed in April to the equivalent of $12 million from $36 million a year earlier, the central bank said today. In the first four months of this year, the current account swung to a surplus of $348 million, from a deficit of about $240 million in the period last year. The current account measures international trade in manufactured goods and services such as banking and tourism.

title: Carter Meeting
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores said that it has set July 26 as the date for its shareholders meeting in Los Angeles to vote on the company's sale of 1 million shares of convertible preferred stock to the General Cinema Corporation for $300 million. Shareholders will also consider changing the company's state of incorporation to Delaware from California in an attempt to prevent The Limited Inc. from gaining board representation through the use of California's cumulative voting process. Other measures to be considered involve the election of 19 directors, including re-election of four from General Cinema, which has attained 37 percent voting rights on the board through its transactions, and a proposal to increase the board to 25 members.

title: THEY'LL MISS THE RUSSIANS
description: The American water-polo team

title: Merrick Dropped
description: He did his part for the Islanders after joining them in 1978, but, with such rising stars as Pat LaFontaine competing for ice time, the center Wayne Merrick was used in only 31 games last season. Now the Islanders are looking to the future without him.

title: CHINESE ART OF 1970'S ON VIEW AT ASIA SOCIETY
description: ''Contemporary Chinese Painting: An Exhibition from the People's Republic of China,'' at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, through Aug. 26, is, therefore, a show with a certain urgency. The 53 brush paintings and sketches, representing 36 artists, provide us with clues not only about contemporary Chinese art but also about present-day Chinese culture. The art, all done since 1976 and loosely defined as traditional, is diverse and uneven. That diversity and unevenness, however, are marks of a transitional and increasingly open Chinese society.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains Semifinals
description: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd moved a step closer to their expected showdown in the final by posting quarterfinal victories today in the Eastbourne tournament.

title: Dancer Fitzgerald GetsRepublic Air Account
description: The powers that be at Republic Airlines in Minneapolis have decided to award their estimated $30 million account to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample of New York. That means that for all practical purposes Dancer has its first airline account in its 61-year history.

title: U.S.-Canada Airline Pact
description: The United States and Canada have reached an airline traffic agreement that breaks a 10-year stalemate in negotiations for new cross-border services, Canadian officials said today.

title: Fairleigh Names New President
description: Dr. Robert H. Donaldson, a specialist in international politics, today was named the fourth president in Fairleigh Dickinson University's 42-year history.

title: BERNARD BERGMAN, NURSING-HOME FIGURE, IS DEAD
description: Bernard Bergman, the central figure in New York City's nursing-home investigation a decade ago, died of a heart attack last Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Israel and Manhattan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Mariner Conflict
description: George Argyros , the owner of the Seattle Mariners, hinted that he might move the club, perhaps to Denver, because of a dispute with the Kingdome over a schedule conflict with the Seahawks of the National Football League. In contracts signed in 1976, the two teams were given conflicting priority over fall dates.

title: ESTELLE WINWOOD, AN ACTRESS WHOSE CAREER BEGAN IN 1888
description: Estelle Winwood, an actress for nearly a century, died Wednesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 101 years old.

title: Harlem Hospital Filthy, Regan Says
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that a state audit inspection at the Harlem Hospital Center found that the hospital was ''filthy'' and that some members of its housekeeping staff were ''idle, sleeping or watching television.''

title: Insider Case Guilty Pleas
description: A Brooklyn cab driver and a manager of an animal hospital pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they traded stock based on insider tips from a proofreader at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: Danish Project in Japan
description: Novo Industri A.S., the world's largest producer of enzymes, said today that it would build a $21 million production plant at Ishikari Bay in Hokkaido, Japan. The Takenaka Komuten Company signed a contract to build the plant for Novo Biochemical Industry Japan Ltd., a subsidiary of the Danish company. Novo said the plant would go into operation in the middle of 1986.

title: 9th Ave. Cornucopia
description: ''My God, they're alive!'' exclamed one woman, bending over a crate of snails from Argentina at the Central Fish Market. The snails, along with other New York gastronomic curiousities, were being closely observed by a group of visiting amateur cooks from York, Pa.

title: OPERA: 'RIGOLETTO' ANEW
description: If ''Carmen'' could survive

title: TIME IS A MATTER OF HOW YOU TELL IT
description: It looks like a perfectly normal watch: white numerals set neatly on a black face and a second hand elegantly tipped in red.

title: MAKE PUBLIC SERVICE AFFORDABLE TO LAW GRADUATES
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: A House roll-call listing by The Associated Press in some editions yesterday, on the immigration bill, misstated the vote of Representative Marty Russo, Democrat of Illinois. He voted for the bill.

title: PAKISTAN TIE IMPERILS U.S.-CHINA NUCLEAR PACT
description: China, contrary to its public pledges, may be continuing to aid Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, according to Reagan Administration officials and Congressional sources.

title: Harvester Extends Chairman's Pact
description: He has been called the Lee Iacocca of the corn fields. But Donald D. Lennox, chairman of the International Harvester Company, says the comparison has more to do with results than with the style of the flamboyant chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 10
BRIEFING
description: White House Fish Fry

title: CREDIT FILE PASSWORD IS STOLEN
description: A password that could permit access to the credit histories of 90 million people was stolen and posted on an electronic bulletin board, TRW Information Systems said yesterday.

title: BEYOND VOTING, MORE ACTION IS NEEDED
description: It's all over but the shouting. The Democrats' primary and caucus season - that raucous contest among political elites that goes by the name of democracy - has been good sport: the heated race, the costly gaffes, the fallen sprinters, the dark horses, the see-saw battles. It has made superb copy - a whole new vocabulary of yuppie politics, superdelegates, Hymietowns, runoff elections, the new ''old politics'' of a candidate who can't lose but doesn't quite seem able to win and the old ''new ideas'' of a candidate who can't win but doesn't quite seem able to lose. With the Russians out of the Olympics, the finale in San Francisco should be a boon to the summer spectator sports schedule.

title: 'Romeo' Schedule
description: ''Romeo and Juliet,'' a touring production by the Riverside Shakespeare Company, will be performed today at 6 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx; tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Fort Greene Park ballfield near DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn, and Sunday at 4 P.M. in Baisley Park in Jamaica, Queens. All performances are free. Information: 877- 6810.

title: U.N. ANTI-SEMITISM IS DENIED BY ARABS
description: An Arab spokesman has rejected charges, made by Jewish groups here recently, that the United Nations has become a center for anti-Semitic polemics.

title: PUBLISHING: CHEAPER CORRECTED :ULYSSES' AWAITED
description: The publication last week of a corrected version of James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' has been a major topic of conversation among Joyceans, some of whom have already ordered the $200 three-volume edition produced by Garland Publishing. But other Joyce enthusiasts have asked how soon they will be able to buy a low-cost edition that also corrects the 5,000 or so omissions, transpositions and other errors in existing editions.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $13,000. c-Net loss

title: NEW CHIEF SHAKING UP PRISON SYSTEM
description: In the month since Ray Procunier was appointed director of the Texas Department of Corrections he has sent shock waves through a system mired in charges of brutality, corruption and mismanagement.

title: 16 Offspring of Slaves Owned By Cherokees Seek Damages
description: Sixteen people who say they are descendants of slaves owned by Cherokee Indians have filed a $750 million lawsuit saying they have been deprived of rights bestowed on them by an 1866 treaty.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Including tax credits of $232,760 for the quarter and $487,400 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $128,340 for the quarter and $49,680 for the 6 months.

title: BRAZIL TO EXTRADITE FORMER REBEL CHIEF SOUGHT BY ARGENTINA
description: Brazil has unexpectedly granted the request for extradition of one of Argentina's most sought after former leftist guerrilla leaders.

title: BOND PRICES MOVE UPWARD
description: Bond prices rose in the credit markets yesterday after House and Senate conferees voted to repeal the 30 percent withholding tax on the investment income of foreigners.

title: CONFEREES URGING A FEDERAL FREEZE ON MEDICARE FEES
description: Congressional taxwriters have taken a tentative step toward imposing price controls on the medical profession by proposing to freeze Medicare fees for 15 months and assess penalties against doctors in the program who increase their charges.

title: EDWARDS, A.G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SALVADOR RIGHT REPORTEDLY PLOTTED TO ASSASSINATE U.S. AMBASSADOR
description: United States intelligence sources uncovered a plot by right-wing Salvadoran extremists to kill the United States Ambassador here last month, according to an Administration official in Washington and two sources in El Salvador.

title: FINANCIAL CORP. DOPS DEBT-EQUITY SWAP PLAN

Jesse Jackson.

description: Shimon Peres, the leader of Israel's Labor Party, said today that if he became Prime Minister he hoped to remove all Israeli troops from Lebanon in three to six months.

title: SCOUTING

title: The $2,000 Subway Token
description: That sound echoing through New York's subways is Mayor Koch choking on a monumental folly. Some people, Governor Cuomo among them, think the public should try to make the subways accessible to disabled people, even though only a handful would ever use them and even though that could cost $2,000 a ride. The Mayor, who once reluctantly went along, now bridles: ''I cannot accept it.''

title: 'GOOD NIGHT, MY SOMEONE'
description: ''Harold Hill'' and ''Marian the Librarian'' were among the hundreds of mourners today as the composer Meredith Willson was laid to rest here in the original ''River City.''

description: In the days before Poland's local elections this week, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish Communist Party leader, was often shown on television kissing the hands of female shoppers and workers, just like a Polish noble of the 18th century.

title: U.S. CONFIRMS A RIGHTIST PLOT IN EL SALVADOR TO MURDER ENVOY
description: Senior officials confirmed today that the Administration had learned of a Salvadoran right-wing plot to assassinate the American Ambassador. They said a high official had been sent to El Salvador to warn the leaders against carrying out the plot.

description: House and Senate tax conferees worked into the early morning today and appeared near final agreement on a bill that would raise $50 billion in taxes over four years.

title: INFORMED AND SO WHAT?
description: Every four or five months, I immerse myself for a few days in the political news pouring from the newspapers and television screens of America. Don't ask why. Maybe it's out of respect for a past when politics and government seemed vitally important.

title: Israeli Jailed in Dutch Blaze
description: Joseph Lan, a 36-year-old Israeli, was sentenced today to 12 years in jail for starting a fire Dec. 16 that killed 13 people and injured 25 at a sex club where Mr. Lan had been dismissed from a job as a janitor. He was born in the Soviet Union and had lived in the Netherlands for about a year before the fire.

title: THE GENOCIDE TREATY:UNRATIFIED 35 YEARS
description: The historic Genocide Convention - the first United Nations human rights treaty - was transmitted to the Senate by Harry S. Truman just 35 years ago. To the dismay of the international community, it has not yet been ratified. Senator William Proxmire correctly, if sadly, observed recently, ''There is not a single proposal that has been before the Senate as long.''

title: JOSEPH LOSEY, FILM DIRECTOR BLACKLISTED IN 1950'S, DIES AT 75
description: Joseph Losey, the American film director who spent three decades in Europe after fleeing the United States in the McCarthy era, died today at his London home. He was 75 years old.

title: Jean Hugo,Artist,Dies at 89
