title: RARE FINAL HONOR FOR SWALE
description: Some racing fans are wondering why Swale was buried at Claiborne Farm in Paris, Ky., his birthplace, instead of at Belmont Park, the scene of his final victory, the Belmont Stakes June 9. The reasons reflect the wishes of his owners and race-track tradition. The two horses prominently buried in Belmont's infield are Ruffian and Timely Writer, crowd-pleasers who broke down on the track during races and had to be destroyed. Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif., is the final resting place of Lamb Chop and Quicken Tree. Lamb Chop was owned by William Haggin Perry, a co-owner of Swale, who wanted her to be buried at the site of her first stakes victory. Quicken Tree, who won the Jockey Club Gold Cup in 1968, had been the first California-bred to win that race, and his owners wanted him returned to his homeland. Pan Zareta, the great turn-of-the-century sprinting mare, and Black Gold, who became the only Louisiana Derby winner to win the Kentucky Derby, in 1924, are both buried at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans. Native Diver, who won the Hollywood Gold Cup three consecutive times, from 1965 to 1967, is buried at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., as is Landaluce, the great 2-year-old filly of 1982 whose 21-length victory in the Hollywood Lassie Stakes was the most lopsided stakes score in the track's history. Swale, Claiborne's first Kentucky Derby winner after 74 years of trying, was going to receive the traditional farm burial, which would have been the interment of only his head, heart, hooves and reproductive organs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article June 16 on the Hudson Institute incorrectly described the role of B. Bruce-Briggs. He is a former senior staff member of the institute who edited some of Herman Kahn's work. For the last four years of Mr. Kahn's life, his regular editor was Carol Kahn.

A spokesman for Philips, the Dutch-based electronics concern, said the companies were still discussing financing and possible commercial production of chips smaller than .001 millimeter.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK

School is out for the day, or Henrietta Bowdon, the principal, would have their hides. Several children are hanging around the old Broad Channel Milk Farm store drinking Yoo-hoo chocolate drinks. Nearby, some others wade in shallow water trying to snatch slimy little critters and put them in a can.

John Hannah , the all-pro offensive guard, has signed a series of four one-year contracts with the New England Patriots. . . . The Los Angeles Dodgers placed 38-year- old Rick Monday , who has only one home run and seven runs batted in this season, on waivers.

description: The possibility of a strike this summer by Hollywood's motion picture and television directors has been growing in recent days.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Question and Answer column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly described the major concern arising from regular feeding of antibiotics to meat animals. The concern is that micro-organisms infesting the animals could develop immunity to the drugs, and could transfer that immunity to other micro-organisms, which threaten human beings.

title: To the Editor
description: In a May 18 Op-Ed article, New York City Council President Carol Bellamy proposed using capital funds to contract with nonprofit organizations to provide permanent housing for the homeless. As it stands now, up to $25 million may be spent over the next three years to fund her experiment. She calls it the ''dawning of a new policy'' for the homeless.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: United States Olympic team vs. South Korean Olympic team, at Shea Stadium, noon. A ticket to the Met game, which has been pushed back to 3:05 P.M., entitles a fan to arrive early and get this Los Angeles preview. The American squad has a 5-0 record on its national tour so far.

title: Lifter's Ban Lifted
description: A Federal judge in Chicago yesterday lifted the suspension banning Jeff Michels from international weight- lifting competition, including this summer's Olympics. Michels, a heavyweight from Chicago who is among the country's best lifters, was barred by the International Weightlifting Federation when tests taken at the Pan American Games last August revealed an unacceptable level of testosterone in his system.

Mr. Thatcher, 30 years old, signed a lease for an apartment at the Terrace House, its manager, Kitty Dozier, was quoted as saying. Contacted by The Associated Press, Miss Dozier said she was ''not at liberty to talk about'' the article.

title: AN UNFAIR TAXI FARE
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission's decision to raise taxi fares by 10 cents per ride is not only unjustified on economic grounds but also goes against principles endorsed by two mayoral studies of taxicab regulation issued over the last three years. It's an example of precisely the sort of collusion between industry and government that spurred the Federal Trade Commission to file antitrust suits against municipal taxi systems in New Orleans and Minneapolis.

title: CHINA'S TIBET PROBLEM
description: Thirty-four years after its invasion of Tibet, China remains in a quandary on the roof of the world. After seven years of secret negotiations with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled ruler, the difficult issue of Tibetan independence remains unresolved. The talks are stalled, but underneath their stated positions both sides seem interested in working out a deal - for more or less freely administered automomy. The burden is now on China - to recognize the full extent of Tibetans' nationalism and need for sovereignty and to take steps to advance the negotiations.

title: Japan 'Expanding'
description: Japan's economy is ''expanding,'' the Economic Planning Agency said today in its most optimistic monthly report so far this year. Prior reports termed the economy ''recovered'' in May and ''improving'' in April. A week ago, the agency reported Japan's economy grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 7.4 percent in the January-March quarter, for the second- highest growth rate among developed nations after the United States.

title: The City Council has decided to spend $750,000 to put out two newsletters a year for each of its 35 members.
description: The newsletters for the coming fiscal year, which begins July 1, were provided for in the new city budget and approved by the Council, the Board of Estimate and the Mayor this month. Until now, their impending publication and the cost went unnoticed, as can happen in a budget of $18.2 billion. But word is beginning to get out.

title: Exacta Inquiry Finds No Crime
description: An investigation by the state police has found no criminal activity related to a Meadowlands harness race that provided an unusually low exacta payoff May 3.

title: TALK-SHOW HOST VIEW ROLE IN LIGHT OF SLAYING
description: Ever since Alan Berg, the controversial radio call-in-show host was shot to death Tuesday, some of the broadcast provocateurs who invite the public to debate on the air are taking a hard look at the roles they play with their audiences.

title: Defense Presses Agent In DeLorean Case
description: A Federal drug agent testified today that it was ''possible'' he had once referred to the informer who proposed John Z. DeLorean for a narcotics investigation as his ''meal ticket.''

title: Ameritrust to Get Baldwin Interest
description: The Ameritrust Corporation said it had agreed to assume the Baldwin- United Corporation's limited partnership interest in the Central Colorado Company, a partnership that owns about 95 percent of Central Bancorporation Inc. of Denver.

title: In Moscow, Plus ,ca Change . . .
description: France's President Mitterrand mentioned the unmentionable in Moscow by raising the matter of Andrei Sakharov during a state visit. His hosts rebuffed him, as he knew they would. To every inquiry about the dissenting physicist and his ailing wife, Yelena Bonner, the Soviet response has been like Konstantin Chernenko's this time: ''We shall not allow anyone to interfere in our internal affairs.''

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss of $1 million from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.1 million. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the classification of the poultry products segment as a discontinued business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Automatic Data Processing Inc. of Clifton, N.J., said it had signed final contracts to acquire the payroll services business of Security Pacific National Bank; terms were not announced.

title: 20 CZECHS FREED BY ANGOLA REBELS
description: A senior Czechoslovak official escorted 20 of his countrymen out of captivity at a remote bush camp in southern Angola today after they had been held for 15 months as prisoners of rebellious guerrillas.

title: MRS. LLOYD IS STUNNED, 6-2, 6-4
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the world's No. 2 player, suffered a shocking 6-2, 6-4 defeat today at the hands of Kathy Jordan in the semifinals of the Eastbourne tennis tournament, the women's last warm-up for the Wimbledon championships, which begin Monday.

title: SCHLICHTER SUSPENSION LIFTED BY ROZELLE
description: Art Schlichter's gambling-related suspension by the National Football League was lifted by Commissioner Pete Rozelle today, a decision that the onetime Ohio State star said marked ''a great moment'' in his life.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 23, 1984

title: A STAR DISABLED ATHLETE MUST STILL HIT THE BOOKS
description: As at most games, all the action is not taking place on the playing field at the International Games for the Disabled.

title: HOSPITALS TOO SURE OF SLOW WEEKENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pol Pot Forces Report Killing 79 Vietnamese in 2-Day Fight
description: The Pol Pot forces said Friday that they killed 79 Vietnamese soldiers in a two-day battle near the southern Cambodian port city of Kampong Som.

title: 4 IRANIANS LEAVE PARIS TO RETURN TO TEHERAN
description: An Iran Air flight has taken home four Iranians who were unwilling passengers on a commandeered Iranian Navy transport plane, sources at Orly Airport said today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Conner Favored To Regain Cup

title: Letter: On Italy Berlinguer's Communist Bulwark To the Editor:
description: While necessarily brief and superficial, your editorial (June 13) on Enrico Berlinguer also unfortunately had little to do with the facts. No postwar Italian Communist leader has pursued a strategy of revolution and thus it was certainly not Berlinguer who discarded that idea.

title: No Headline
description: A Diplomat Is Missing From East Side Home

title: Slap on the Wrist
description: Kelvin Bryant , the Philadelphia Stars' best running back, won't start in tomorrow's game against the Generals because he is being punished for being late to team meetings, Coach Jim Mora said.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WHEN A LOAN IS REFUSED
description: CAUTION: If you are a good credit risk, lenders may hold it against you.

title: Democrats Cite Polls In Fight to Lead Senate
description: Democratic challengers for United States Senate seats jheld by Republicans in North Carolina, Iowa and Tennessee are leading in the polls and two others, in Illinois and New Hampshire, are in dead heats, a Democratic pollster said today.

title: Victory in Court
description: Marvin Fishman , a Milwaukee businessman who waged a 10-year court battle to wrest control of the Chicago Bulls, was awarded more than $17 million by a Federal judge. But Judge Stanley Roszkowski denied Fishman's request that the franchise be turned over to him and his associates, finding that this would be ''improper'' given the amount of time that had passed since Fishman sought to buy the team in 1972.

title: Recall of G.M. Cars Is Ordered
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered the General Motors Corporation to recall about 550,000 1980- model automobiles that have exhaust emissions exceeding Federal standards on nitrogen oxides.

title: SRI LANKAN SEEKS U.N. AGENCY TO FIGHT TERRORISM The President of Sri Lanka, who is trying to contain racial tensions and a militant separatist movement in his nation, yesterday urged the United Nations to consider forming a special agency devoted to stopping the spread of international terrorism.
description: In a speech to the Foreign Policy Association in New York, President J. R Jayewardene linked the sporadic violence between Tamils and Sinhalese in Sri Lanka to the growing threat of international terrorism.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've already said we'd freeze our fees, so it's not surprising that Congress should act to help us along.'' - Dr. William Weil, president of the Los Angeles County Medical Association. (9:4.)

title: LEE EXTRIDITION BID DOUBTED
description: The French Government is unlikely to request the extradition of Sherman E. Lee, the former director of the Cleveland Museum of Art for whom a French judge issued an ''international arrest warrant'' on Tuesday, a source close to the French Ministry of Justice said yesterday.

title: ANTITRUST INQUIRY ON I.B.M.
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had been conducting an antitrust investigation of the International Business Machines Corporation, examining the possible anticompetitive effects of a legal settlement that I.B.M. reached last year with a Japanese competitor.

title: Davide Lajolo Dies in Milan; An Italian Communist Official
description: Davide Lajolo, a leading figure in the Italian Communist Party and in the resistance in World War II, died Wednesday in a local hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: ADVISER TRAVELS RURAL AFRICA TO AID OTHER WOMEN
description: A friend to thousands of women in Ghana, Upper Volta, Benin and Togo, Ayele Foly spends her life on the road, traveling to remote villages in southwestern Africa. Her mission is to disseminate information about family planning, nutrition and health care.

title: EXERTS ON TRADE RELIVE THE 1930's
description: They had worked together for years in remote areas of the bureaucracy, sorting out the esoterica of American trade policy.

title: Homosexual Is Rebuffed In Suit of Newspaper
description: The California Supreme Court has refused to reinstate an invasion-of-privacy suit by a man who thwarted a Presidential assassination in 1975, and a lawyer says his client, Oliver Sipple, would have been better off ''if he had let that woman shoot.''

title: AUSTRALIA DISPUTE ARISES ON EMBRYOS
description: Dr. Linda Mohr, who runs the embyro freezing unit at the Queen Victoria Medical Center in Melbourne, told a medical conference in Helsinki last month that she had grave fears about the status of frozen embryos.

title: Miss Taittinger Wed to Peter Gardner
description: Victoire Taittinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Taittinger of Paris and Reims, France, was married yesterday to Peter Jaglom Gardner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Gardner of New York and Kinderhook, N.Y. Pierre-Christian Taittinger, a French Senator and the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the City Hall in the First Arrondissement in Paris.

title: U.S. TELLS HOW IT RETALIATES AGAINST ENVOYS
description: The State Department disclosed in detail today how it deliberately complicates the lives of foreign diplomats posted in the United States if their governments harass American envoys overseas.

title: No Headline
description: Ronald B. Gray Dies; Reserve Bank Officer

title: JACKSON TRIP OFFERS HIM ROLE AS PEACEMAKER
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to embark early Saturday on a six-day tour of Central America and Cuba, designed to portray the Democratic Presidential candidate as a man of peace.

title: DEBATE OVER FILM RATINGS WIDENING
description: The girls were 9 and 12 years old, and they had seen the movie ''Private Lessons'' advertised on television. One afternoon, they went to see it with some friends from school. Although the movie was rated R - meaning that those under the age of 17 were not permitted unless accompanied by a parent or adult guardian - the girls were sold children's tickets and let in to see the movie.

title: MITTERRAND, DESPITE CRITICISM, SEES BETTER FRENCH-SOVIET TIES
description: President Francois Mitterrand, ending two days of talks with Soviet leaders, said today that relations between Paris and Moscow were growing warmer and that ''it is pleasant when one can talk of everything and still remain friends.''

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $528,000.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 23, 1984 International
description: A foreign debt consultation process has been agreed on by 11 Latin American nations in what would be their first concrete move toward unity in dealing with the overall debt crisis, foreign and economic ministers said at their meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, where the agreement was reached. The 11 nations agreed to establish a task force headed by Argentina to represent them in proposed negotiations with industrial nations in the World Bank's development committee. (Page 1, Column 1.) A right-wing assassination plot in El Salvador to kill the United States Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, was broken up by United States intelligence sources, according to sources in Washington and El Salvador. The sources said that Roberto d'Aubuisson, leader of the National Republican Alliance, known as Arena, was among a small group of Arena members who were said to have planned to kill Mr. Pickering. (1:3.)

title: OPERETTA:'PATIENCE,' BY BRITISH GROUP AT MET
description: One of the misfortunes of contemporary American life is that we have no Gilbert and Sullivan to stick pins in our pretensions while keeping us doubled up with laughter. Certainly enough targets exist to keep such a team of satirists busy on the popular musical stage. Of course, you might remark that the British also suffer from a similar lack at the moment. Broad parody is in demand, as always, but genuine satire, even of a mild variety, is hard to come by.

title: School Desegregation Plan Backed by Court in Cincinnati
description: A Federal district judge today formally approved the settlement of a decade- old school desegregation lawsuit against the Cincinnati and Ohio Boards of Education.

title: MAY COSTS IN REGION UNCHANGED
description: Consumer prices in the New York- northeastern New Jersey area were unchanged in May, the first time since December 1982 that they have not increased, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: All the net income figures represent net investment income.

title: IRAN IS APPARENTLY DEBATING FATE OF THE 'FINAL OFFENSIVE'
description: A debate has apparently arisen within Iran's leadership over what to do about its long-anticipated ''final offensive'' against Iraq, American and Western European officials said today.

title: South Korea May Renew Contact With Soviet
description: South Korea may resume nonpolitical exchanges with the Soviet Union, Government officials said today.

title: A CRACKLING FRESHNESS
description: REQUIRED WRITING: Miscellaneous

title: SHAKY FORD EUROPE GETS A NEW LEADER
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was sending its head of international operations to take direct charge of Ford of Europe, a vital source of profits that has been shaken in recent months by lagging sales and the resignations, in rapid succession, of two chairmen.

title: AGENCY ENDORSES ATOM WASTE PLAN
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, after months of delay, today approved Government guidelines for selecting a site to house the nation's first dump for high- level radioactive waste.

title: 'Hurlyburly' Ticket Sales
description: Even before it opened Thursday at the Promenade Theater, ''Hurlyburly'' was selling out every performance since it began previews June 5.

title: SHELLFISH WARNING IN EFFECT
description: PEOPLE who eat raw shellfish,

title: No Headline
description: Of Shelley's 'Adonais' And Finance

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including gains of $11,788,000 for the quarter and $13,577,000 for the 6 months on the sale of investments. c-Including a gain of $1,666,000 on the sale of investments.

title:
Patents;
Warning in Synthetic Speech
description: WASHINGTON

title: DR. ROSS HARRISON
description: Dr. Ross Harrison, professor emeritus of psychology at Hunter College, died last Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: PROPOSED PLANK WOULD BAR SPECIAL INTEREST GIFTS
description: Drafters of the Democratic Party platform today proposed for the first time that Presidential and Congressional candidates be barred from accepting campaign contributions from political action committees.

title: A 3.86 GAIN IN DOW CAPS A SOLID WEEK
description: The stock market ended one of its best weeks this year by posting a small advance yesterday in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average finished the session with a gain of 3.86 points, to 1,131.07.

title: U.S. SAYS BLAST HIT SOVIET ARMS BASE
description: United States officials said today that a huge explosion about a month ago destroyed large stocks of ammunition for the Soviet northern fleet at a supply depot at Severomorsk, on the Barents Sea north of Murmansk. Between 200 and 300 people were reported killed.

title: Diana Donnelley Becomes a Bride
description: Diana Kirk Donnelley and Herbert McKelden Smith 3d were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill., by the Rev. Clark Grew.

title: Rosario Retains Lightweight Title
description: Edwin Rosario of Puerto Rico gained a 12-round split decision over Howard Davis Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I., today to retain his World Boxing Council lightweight title and remain undefeated.

title: ANNIE EDGE WINS AT BELMONT BY A NECK
description: Annie Edge, an Irish import making her third start in this country and her first in New York, rushed up in the final yards of a blanket finish to win the New York Handicap by a neck yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: PONIES OF CHILDHOOD'S WONDER
description: Only Fellini is missing from this scene of sun-drenched improbability, in which circus-colored horses and bearded white egrets blur into the stately disorder we call ''wild.'' There is something trembling on the edge of hallucination about watching three wild beach ponies, each spotted loudly with mocha or orange-chestnut, grazing green grass against a backdrop of sun-dazzled, Ektachrome-blue water.

title: Karen W. Schneider Weds Biochemist
description: Karen White Schneider, the communications and public relations manager for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Brownlee, an assistant professor of medical biochemistry at the Rockefeller University and adjunct assistant professor of medicine at the Cornell University Medical College. Dr. Sheldon Ackley, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at BargeMusic Ltd. in Brooklyn.

title: PORTRAITS IN PORCELAIN
description: Jack and Belle Linsky delighted in looking at people - and the art they collected over a 40-year period is the proof. This becomes abundantly clear in viewing the permanent installation of their Old Master paintings, baroque bronzes, French 18th-century furniture, period jewelry and, most of all, 18th-century porcelain figures, which opened to the public last week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY
No Headline
description: Holland Tunnel Tube To Close Some Nights

title: CAMPAIGN AIDE TO MONDALE PREDICTS KENNEDY'S SUPPORT
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who appeared to distance himself from Walter F. Mondale after the former Vice President's campaign faltered in the early Democratic primaries, will visit Mr. Mondale at his home here Sunday.

title: MATTINGLY IN GOOD COMPANY
description: BALTIMORE IN an eminently forgettable Yankee

title: SORTING OUT THE BEWILDERING ARRAY OF ADJUSTABLES
description: A YEAR ago, housing-industry leaders were worried about the expanding ''mortgage menu.'' Restlessly searching for a competitive edge, the large mortgage lenders seemed endlessly to be devising subtle variations on the adjustable-rate mortgage, the home-lending industry's answer to the unsettled state of interest rates in the last few years.

title: MISS DECKER TRIUMPS AT 3,000 METERS
description: Mary Decker, the world's most successful female distance runner, made the United States Olympic team tonight. So did August Wolf, a 1983 Princeton graduate who until three months ago was a journeyman shot-putter.

title: CLOSING OF FIRST SEARS STORE DISTRESSES CHICAGO NEIGHBORHOOD
description: When Sears, Roebuck & Company built its merchandise distribution center in 1906, the 40-acre site was bucolic, but now it is the middle of the impoverished Lawndale neighborhood on Chicago's West Side.

title: POSTINGS;
description: Soon to rise on a 24-acre site embracing a large piece of blighted urban renewal land in Glen Cove, L.I., will be a 328-unit residential condominium complex called Captain's Cove, overlooking Hempstead Harbor.

title: WHALING BODY CUTS QUOTA AND BARS '85 SPERM WHALE HUNT
description: The International Whaling Commission has reduced the number of minke whales available to commercial fleets by one-third and has decided to prohibit all hunting of sperm whales next year.

title: Rosalind Chang Hawley Weds Edwin Whitehead
description: Rosalind Chang Hawley was married to Edwin C. Whitehead yesterday in a ceremony performed by Dr. Walter Lawton of the Ethical Culture Society of White Plains and held at Mr. Whitehead's home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: 'LIVING OVER THE STORE' at Caramoor
description: -room Mediterranean style villa filled with priceless antiques might sound dramatic, but Michael Sweeley has become used to the experience. ''In a sense, I'm living over the store,'' he said, smiling, standing in a room whose vaulted ceiling was once part of a 16th-century Italian castle. ''A very grand store, but still, living over the store.''

description: Starring John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Terry Jones, Graham Chapman, Michael Palin; directed by Mr. Gilliam and Mr. Jones, 1974 RCA/Columbia Home Video 90 minutes. $59.95

title: Helen Keller Week Declared
description: President Reagan has declared next week ''Helen Keller Deaf-Blind Awareness Week,'' calling on the nation to help foster independence and job opportunities for people who are both deaf and blind. Next Wednesday will be the 104th anniversary of the birth of Miss Keller, who overcame blindness and deafness and became a model for others.

title: EAST GERMAN GROUP SAID TO TAKE REFUGE AT MISSION IN BERLIN
description: A West German newspaper reported today that 50 East Germans seeking passage to the West have taken refuge in the West German diplomatic mission in East Berlin.

title: Miss Navratilova Takes Final
description: Forty-eight hours before the start of Wimbledon, Martina Navratilova gained her third straight Eastbourne grass court tennis title today with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Kathy Jordan of the United States.

title: REVUE: 'BITTERSUITE' BACK IN NEW FORM AND SETTING
description: ''Bittersuite,'' a cabaretlike revue that was well received at an Off Broadway theater in a full-length, two-act production last February, has been condensed to an hour's running time for an actual cabaret presentation at Michael's Pub. In the transformation nine songs have been cut and two new ones inserted, and the cast of five has been reduced to four.

title: HURTING THE DISADVANTAGED
description: William Julius Wilson, the Lucy Flower Professor of Urban Sociology at the University of Chicago, is the author of the forthcoming book ''The Hidden Agenda: Race, Social Dislocations and Public Policy.'' CIVIL RIGHTS

title: ATLANTIC CITY FEELING SHORTCHANGED
description: Since May 5, New Jersey Transit buses have been leaving daily from the corner of Broad and Pearl Streets in Bridgeton to deliver workers to casinos 53 miles away in Atlantic City. With stops along the way in Millville and Vineland, the buses arrive in time for the start of each shift and return at the end of each shift.

title: ; A TALE OF TWO PROMS-- WORLDS APART
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOUSE TOUR SET IN LITCHFIELD
description: FIVE private residences, spanning almost two centuries of the architectural history of Litchfield, will be open to visitors July 14 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The homes are part of the 37th annual house tour held for the benefit of the Connecticut Junior Republic, an organization that aids homeless and troubled boys. Historic public buildings may also be seen.

description: To the Editor:

title: BARTOK AND KODALY FLOURISH AT THE HANDS OF A COMPATRIOT
description: Joseph Sefel is a Hungarian-born geophysicist who, several years back, emigrated to Calgary, Canada, and established the Sefel Group, Ltd., a company whose business is oil: What they do, mainly, is advise petroleum companies where theyre likely to find oil, and how much of it a site can be expected to yield. What, you might ask, does this have to do with recordings? Well, it happens that Mr. Sefel's interest in petroleum extends not only to the commodity in its raw state, but also to one of its products - the round, 12- inch diameter polyvinyl chloride disks popularly known as LP's.

title: DEBT TALKS DRAW A MIXED REACTION
description: A Government spokesman said today that the United States was relieved by the terms of an accord struck Friday by 11 Latin American debtor nations. But other experts cautioned that the agreement would move the countries closer to formation of a cartel if their loan burden worsened.

title: FOREIGN-TRAINED DOCTORS IN FOR A THOROUGH CHECKUP
description: As the social status of doctors has risen - along with their incomes - so has the number of people who try to find a way to profit from that success. In recent years, the medical profession has been worried that its reputation is being undermined by the increasing number of physicians who went abroad for their training after being rejected by medical schools in the United States. Last week, the American Medical Association ordered the start of what it thinks may be the remedy to the problem - a crackdown on the testing of prospective doctors. In addition, the association said it would cooperate with investigations of fraudulent degrees.

description: FREE HORSE SHOW

title: Maeryn Stradley Bride Of William S. Roebling
description: The marriage of Maeryn Barnes Stradley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Stradley of Radnor, Pa., to William Schley Roebling, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand William Roebling 3d of Lambertville, N.J., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. William Arnold officiated.

description: WHAT began as a compulsory writing assignment for eighth-grade students at Newark's South 17th Street elementary school has earned them accolades from President Reagan and the gratitude of the Marine Corps.

description: Forty-four opponents of South Africa's race separation laws were arrested Friday night and today while demonstrating against the official apartheid policy, the police said.

title: LIGHT WORKOUTS FOR THE REAGAN CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON O N the road again and on a roll, President Reagan came out last week in favor of sportsmanship, sobriety and safe streets. With each passing week, his approval ratings seem to continue their climb. Senior advisers acknowledge their failure to rid Mr. Reagan's re-election organization of overconfidence. On Capitol Hill, however, the President was finding the road somewhat more bumpy. Most of his military spending program for fiscal 1985 was approved by the Senate, but only after Republican allies felt it necessary to challenge him on arms control. To win Democratic support for his proposed budget cuts, Mr. Reagan had to accept a loss of some election-year goodies, such as extending Individual Retirement Account tax breaks to nonworking spouses.

title: REFRESHINGLY BRAVE WORK FROM A SOVIET DRAMATIST
description: Victor Rozov's ''From Night Till Noon,'' much admired and performed in the Russia of the mid-70's, brought onstage a scientist grimly convinced that children, relationships, feelings themselves were all dangerous distractions, keeping a man from his primary duty, which was to himself alone. The same play included an impassioned denunciation, voiced by an athletics coach, of ''The high-riders, who get into the saddle and ride like mad for the sake of their careers, not caring who their horses trample underfoot.''

title: DEALING WITH THE WORLD OF REALITY
description: MONTCLAIR AS AMERICAN crafts continue to mature, a rising level of professional expectations is generating new issues and demanding that old ones be updated.

title: CRIME
description: The first four paperback reprints in the Quill Mysterious Classic series have just been issued - THE BIGGER THEY COME by A. A. Fair, published in 1939; BURY ME DEEP by Harold Q. Masur (1947); THE ASPHALT JUNGLE by W. R. Burnett (1949); and NIGHT OF THE JABBERWOCK by Fredric Brown (1950). Each volume is priced at $3.95.

title:
GARDENING;
FOWERING TREES FOR SUMMER
description: WE gardeners often get ourselves in a rut by planting the same old things. Take flowering trees, for example. When the flowering dogwoods and crab apples are finished blooming in late May, our gardens are suddenly devoid of flowering trees. This need not be the case. Some of the more attractive flowering trees that are adapted to our area bloom in late spring, summer and even later into the fall.

title: TOWER WITH FLARE
description: In the dense and bustling commercial neighborhood where 43d Street meets Lexington Avenue - dominated by such landmark structures as the Chrysler and Graybar Buildings - Olympia & York, the Toronto-based development company, will erect a 30-story office building.

description: An unusual aspect of the American past that, at first glance, appears remote from our concerns today is presented by the American Stage Company in ''A Country for Old Men.''

description: Charlotte Moseley Lord, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goodwin of Baltimore, and John Michael Cole, the son of Maija Jansson Cole of Hamden, Conn., and Dr. Carroll P. Cole of West Haven, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles L. Hoffman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Woods Hole, Mass.

description: AS its Honduran mahogany hull and polished brightwork reflected the afternoon sun, Miss Stephanie, a 1930 vintage Aeolian Seaboat, gently bobbed in her berth alongside a float in Huntington Harbor.

title: INDUSTRY STAKES A NEW CLAIM IN SPACE
description: TOMORROW, when the space shuttle Discovery makes its scheduled

title: Half-Century Club
description: To the Editor:

title: RIDDLE A LOGOGRIPH
description: MAN is a riddling animal. He creates distinctions, and then detects resemblances; he apprehends mysteries, and longs for solutions. Like many other rituals and art forms, the riddle itself has rather come down in the world, and though collections of riddles can still be found in the bookshops the place to look for them is among the party games and Truly Tasteless jokes. But Mark Bryant's ''Riddles: Ancient and Modern'' (New York: Peter Bedrick Books. Cloth, $15.95; paperback, $6.95) serves as a useful reminder that riddles come in all shapes and sizes - sacred and profane, momentous and trivial, exquisitely ingenious and exquisitely silly. And they go back a long way, to Babylon and no doubt far beyond.

title: Sharon A. White Marries a Lawyer
description: Sharon A. White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erman White of Englewood, N.J., and Keith Calhoun-Senghor, a son of Senegal Senghor and Clarence W. Calhoun Jr., both of Norfolk, Va., were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Miller in Hanover, Md., by the Rev. M. Michael Morse, a United Church of Christ minister in Washington.

title: Bavaria Premier's Wife Dies
description: Marianne Strauss, the wife of Premier Franz Josef Strauss of Bavaria, was found dead this morning when a car she had been driving Friday night was discovered jammed between two trees in a field after an accident, the police said today. Mr. Strauss, the leader of West Germany's Christian Social Union, returned today from Yugoslavia, where he had been on an official visit.

title:
STAMPS;
A SEAWAY'S CELEBRATION
description: The 25th anniversary of the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway is being observed this Tuesday by simultaneous - but not identical - commemoratives from the United States and Canada. The waterway opened the industrial and agricultural heartland of North America on both sides of the border. It enabled huge ocean-going vessels to go all the way from the Atlantic Ocean to Duluth, Minn.

title: PROTECTIONIST PRESSURES ARE BUILDING
description: President Reagan, who came into office committed to an open trading system, will be under heavy pressure in the next few weeks to protect two basic industries from foreign competition. Mr. Reagan will get recommendations from the International Trade Commission on measures to help steel and copper companies fend off imports. His decisions may be influenced as much by politics as by economics.

title: COMPARING LUXURY IN BOSTON HOTELS
description: MARIAN BURROS is restaurant critic of The Times.

title: PRESS UNIT PLEA ON PARAGUAY BAN
description: The Inter-American Press Association asked President Alfredo Stroessner on Friday to lift the three- month-old suspension of the nation's largest daily newspaper, ABC Color, and was told the request would be considered.

description: Truckload of Money Being head of the teamsters union isn't just a job.

title: Back in Dublin Jail
description: Breaking out of a Dublin jail was as easy as lighting a match for Michael O'Rourke , an explosives expert for the Irish Republican Army. He escaped in 1976 after arranging for his cell wall to be blown away.

title:
ART;
TRACING THE REVIVAL OF THE ETCHER'S ART IN AMERICA
description: THE founding in 1877 of the New York Etching Club gave notice that intaglio printing was enjoying a revival as a fine-art medium, following a slightly earlier renaissance in Europe. The admiration of Rembrandt that inspired the anti-academic realists and Barbizon painters in midcentury sparked renewed appreciation of the master's etchings as well as his paintings, and artists were encouraged to emulate Rembrandt's poetic, expressive approach to a medium that since his time had been relegated to the status of a reproductive craft.

title: DISCOVERING THE LOST LIVES OF WOMEN
description: Since 1970, I have added 73 new biographies of women to my library. That does not include autobiographies, volumes of letters, diaries and journals or biographical essays. I am a collector of biography and a student of the form, but these numbers are out of all proportion to what might have been predicted by a competent statistician surveying my library 15 years ago. Before 1970, biographies of women were scarce and rigidly restricted in subject matter - only royal women or those who were attached to powerful men easily qualified.

title:
DINING OUT;
ATTENTION TO DETAILS IN SOMERS
description: FROM Mark Kaplan and Nancy Gedney, who opened American Bistro in Mamaroneck, comes Persnickety in Somers. The word Persnickety, the restaurant's calling card reminds us, means ''finicky, demanding great care and precision'' and it suggests that both owner and diner demand excellence. It is a brave parent who calls his child Charity or Grace, and an equally courageous restaurateur who dubs his establishment Delice or Plaisir, as though by sympathetic magic the prophecy in the name will be fulfilled. In rare instances do the name and the named become one. And the risk is great that heightened expectations will result in dissatisfaction with what would have been acceptable at a place with a less-promising name - for example, at Sloppie Louie's, where one expects and gets no-frills ambience, service and food.

title: BLEAK HUMOR MARKS 'PRISONER OF 2D AVENUE'
description: NEIL SIMON'S ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue,'' currently at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, is one of the playwright's bleaker versions of life. Like biblical characters coping with assault waves of plagues, Mr. Simon's urban couple struggles with stinking garbage, barking dogs, partying stewardesses, burglars and the overall national economy, not to mention a toilet that won't stop running until its handle gets jiggled.

title: Putting Olympics First An official from Rumania, the only Eastern-bloc country planning to compete in the Los Angeles Games, said the Olympic ideal was more important than disputes between nations. ''Our country is fighting to save the ideal of the Olympics, which is an important educational factor of the human being,'' said
description: Haralambie Alexa, the president of the Rumanian National Olympic Committee. He called Rumania's decision to participate in the Olympics its ''contribution to the maintenance of peace.'' He refused, however, to criticize the Soviet Union for its decision not to attend and insisted his country had not been pressured or harassed by the Russians to abstain.

Scores of women, however, wonder why designers and manufacturers took so long to produce it.

Then, in April, the village ordered the town to get out - to vacate its offices in the municipal hall by May 31 and to find somewhere else to hold its board meetings. In May, the village hinted at divorce - it said it would study the possibility of secession.

title: Mine Toll in Taiwan at 28
description: Fourteen bodies were recovered from a coal mine near Taipei today, increasing the confirmed death toll to 28 in what is regarded as Taiwan's worst mine disaster. Rescuers continued digging through debris to reach 43 other miners who were trapped in a tunnel 1.7 miles from the entrance of the Haishan Mine by a gas explosion Wednesday. But officials said the chances of finding survivors was ''virtually nil'' because of coal gas in the area.

title:
GARDENING;
FOWERING TREES FOR SUMMER
description: WE gardeners often get ourselves in a rut by planting the same old things. Take flowering trees, for example. When the flowering dogwoods and crab apples are finished blooming in late May, our gardens are suddenly devoid of flowering trees. This need not be the case. Some of the more attractive flowering trees that are adapted to our area bloom in late spring, summer and even later into the fall.

title: GLYNDEBOURNE CELEBRATES ITS 50 YEARS OF OPERA
description: GLYNDEBOURNE, England John Christie was an eccentric, strong-willed millionaire landowner, a former science master at Eton, who married Audrey Mildmay, a soprano who had sung with the Carl Rosa opera company, the rather tattered troupe then struggling to keep the operatic flame burning in England. They lived at Glyndebourne, a manor house tucked into a particularly verdant fold of the Sussex downs, a few miles from the Channel. In the twilight of empire, the grand aristocratic flourish was still alive and well in the land, and John Christie decided to add a little opera house to his country seat so Audrey could sing there.

title: MILES DAVIS RETURNS WITH REVAMPED BAND
description: Halfway through a dazzling set at the first of his two Kool Jazz Festival shows, at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, Miles Davis began playing the unmistakable strains of ''Time After Time,'' a ballad that is currently a Top 10 hit for the pop singer Cyndi Lauper. It seemed a somewhat unlikely choice of material, but before the trumpeter had finished his first chorus, it was abundantly clear that he had made the song his own.

The Town Board decided to delay accepting the gift until a right of access could be attained.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY --

Miss Ehrenreich seems to me to have it right - pursuit of consumerist pleasures, flaunting of status symbols and an inability to make personal commitments are simply new forms of arrested development.

title: EXCHANGE GROUP LOOKING TO THE ADULT MARKET
description: The organization that runs the world's largest international exchange program for high school students is expanding to include more adults, and as part of this initiative has negotiated one of the few exchanges in recent years with the Soviet Union.

title: THE REGION

title: COOLING THE HOUSE: THE AIR-CONDITIONER IS NOT THE ONLY WAY
description: THE recent hot spell has convinced lots of people that air-conditioning is needed for comfortable living indoors. But in many homes the only room that is air-conditioned is the bedroom, which does not help much during the day, and in many others there is no air-conditioning at all.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Perceiving a good thing when its audiences and the critics cheer, public television is bringing back Granada TV's sumptuous 11-part production of ''Brideshead Revisited'' starting Monday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13. Evelyn Waugh described the theme of his novel, written in 1944, as ''the operation of divine grace on a group of diverse but closely connected characters.''

title: A SIMPLE CUISINE PROVIDES PRODIGAL PLEASURES
description: Of all the great cuisines of the world, Italy's has always been the simplest, built as it is on the prodigal production of its rich farms and its teeming seas. Dishes like spaghetti with tomato sauce and roast veal owe everything to ingredients - freshly handmade pasta, sun-ripened tomatoes, virgin olive oil and newly picked basil in one case, milk-fed baby veal and fragrant rosemary in the other - and almost nothing to complicated culinary procedures. It is perhaps the hardest food to reproduce outside of its native territory, because of the emphasis on ideal ingredients, but at its best there is no better everyday food, in my judgment, to be found anywhere.

title: MISGUIDED CAMPAIGN ; NUCLEAR POWER: TOO COSTLY TO SAVE
description: MARK HERTSGAARD MOST American business executives probably share two opinions about nuclear energy. One, that after all the cost overruns, plant cancellations, near-bankruptcies, safety mishaps and public opposition, nuclear power is finished as a commercial venture. Two, that it's too bad.

title: DJAVAN, BRAZILIAN SINGER, MAKES AMERICAN DEBUT
description: Tonight at 8 o'clock, when the Brazilian singer Djavan makes his first United States appearance on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall in a program that includes the singer and pianist Tania Maria and the tenor saxophonist Stan Getz, the audience is likely to experience a blast of high- voltage samba that is hip, hard- swinging and even visual in its appeal.

title: SEAFOOD WITH REGAL TOUCH
description: SEVERAL years ago the Royale Fish relocated, moving from Amagansett to East Hampton. In the spacious East Hampton premises a combination of dinner and theater-in-the-round was offered on weekends in the past. But this season the Feleppas, who own the restaurant, are playing it straight. It is now strictly in the business of producing dinners seven nights a week during the summer and on weekends for a good part of the remaining year.

title: INSANITY PLEA UPHELD ALTHOUGH ILLNESS WAS FAKED
description: A man who escaped prosecution for 16 Brooklyn robberies by faking a mental disorder can keep the rewards of his fiction because prosecutors failed to detect it until after they consented to his insanity plea, a state appeals court has ruled.

title: Kingdom/Republic?

title: BLACK FILM FESTIVAL OPENS IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK ''ECLECTIC'' is how organizers of the Black Film Festival describe its 10th season, which began last Wednesday and will continue, except for July 4, every Wednesday through Aug. 1 at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

title: IS IT TIME TO SWAP WITH RHODE ISLAND?
description: THE president of the Chamber of Commerce of Northwest Conn. Inc., Vance A. Taylor, offered last week to give Torrington and its surrounding towns to Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island in exchange for Block Island.

title: WHALER IN WATER AGAIN
description: TEN days ago governor O'Neill hung a five-foot gilded eagle from the transom of the venerable Charles W. Morgan at Chubb's Wharf in Mystic. The ceremony ended yet another period in the remarkable saga of America's only wooden whaling ship.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph accompanying the review of ''The Kennedys'' (June 17) was incorrectly dated. The photograph was taken in 1937.

title: A DISTURBING SUBJECT, THOUGHTFULLY EXPLORED
description: ''The Child Molesters'' walks a narrow line through a terribly emotional subject. No one can condone the sexual abuse of children; it is a foul crime, in most times and places equated with sin. At the same time, crime or sin unexamined is crime or sin allowed to fester, perpetuated because there can be no remedial action. Television's dilemma, meanwhile, is that in trying to explain crime and sin, it may seem to be explaining them away. Without meaning to, television may sanction and legitimize, when supposedly it is trying only to warn. One problem with ''Something About Amelia,'' the ABC film about incest earlier this season, was that in its self-conscious urge to enlighten us, it removed moral opprobrium from the father who had committed the crime and made him the victim as much as his daughter. ''The Child Molesters,'' which examines a similar topic, and faces a similar problem, overcomes this. It also tells us a good deal about sexual aberrants. The first-rate documentary will be shown on WNEW-TV/Channel 5 at 9 tonight.

title: Lisa Harbach and Andrew Setos Wed
description: The marriage of Lisa Prosser Harbach, a daughter of Fay Caulkins Harbach of New York and Quogue, L.I., and William Otto Harbach of New York and Fairfield, Conn., to Andrew George Setos, a son of Mrs. George Setos of Yonkers and the late Mr. Setos, took place yesterday. description: ORADELL WHEN a demolition crew razed a vacant hospital on Kinderkamack Road here earlier this month, none of the onlookers seemed to mourn its passing.

title: FOSTER PARENTS NOT JERSEY EMPLOYEES, COURT SAYS
description: Foster parents are not state employees, and the state has no obligation to cover losses they suffer if they are sued for injuries to children in their care, an appeals court ruled Friday.

description: LONG ISLAND SOUND is Connecticut's major source of water recreation and shellfishing.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY --
description: What kind of a person (man or woman) works 10 hours a day, runs half an hour a day and allocates five minutes a day to others? I think it is one who is so self-centered and self-occupied that he has nothing left for friends, much less a spouse. Absent was any discussion of work other than that the new man does a lot of it.

description: In the article titled ''Impact of Mitchel Field Debated'' (May 20), Nassau County Executive Francis Purcell says that ''opposition to Mitchel Field has been minimal, absolutely minimal. We have received nothing but accolades for what we have done there.''

description: The Democratic platform committee today completed a platform for the 1984 campaign that includes fewer commitments to sweeping social programs and is considerably more conservative than those adopted by the party in recent years.

title: CHEESE PASTRIES
description: IF I WERE ASKED TO NAME THE SINGLE FOOD THAT is the most versatile in the kitchen or on the table, I would be hard put to do so. But it might very well be cheese - on its own, in virtually limitless combinations from the stove, and, especially, in breads and doughs. Since my earliest childhood, I have had what amounts to a passion for cheese straws, particularly those with a tangy bite that comes not only from the cheese but a touch or more of cayenne. The source of the recipe given here for those straws is Charlie Swayze Sr., a family friend of many years standing in Greenwood, Miss.

title: John Chester Jr. Weds Miss Poole
description: Laurie Murdoch Poole, the daughter of Mrs. John M. Hughes of York Harbor, Me., and F. Daniel Morrisey, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Congregational Church in York Harbor.

description: Don Sebesky, who was a trombonist in Maynard Ferguson's Orchestra 25 years ago, has spent the years since then building a reputation as an arranger who makes distinctive blends of a variety of musical sources that have provided recording settings for such singers as Astrud Gilberto and the team of Jackie and Roy and for a variety of instrumentalists, including Milt Jackson, Jim Hall, Freddie Hubbard, George Benson and Paul Desmond.

title: 'FAMILY REUNION' FORMONTEFIORE ALUMNI
description: DURING the 1890's, armed with newly donated funds, the trustees of Montefiore Hospital in Manhattan set about trying to find a more healthful country setting for tuberculosis patients. They considered locations in New Jersey but, adhering to the theory that linked altitude with the cure for consumption, ruled them out as being too flat. Instead, in June 1897, they settled on 136 acres at ''the highest point in Westchester,'' a place that, they said, was ''entirely free from mosquitos and malaria,'' and a mere ''one and a half hours train ride from New York City,'' facilitating patient transfer.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

description: Kathleen Anne Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Connor of Jackson Hole, Wyo., was married there yesterday to Thomas Hoyt Neiley, a son of Edward A. Neiley Jr. of Southport, Conn., and Mrs. Robert P. Weaver of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. John Wright performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Mountains Roman Catholic Church.

title: CONCERT: MARY FINDLEY PLAYS VIOLIN
description: Mary Findley would be an impressive violinist had she only the technical reliability to back up her sound intentions. Miss Findley's program of American music in Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night benefited greatly from big tone and confident enthusiasm; but too often her caring attention to many small individual phrases seemed diminished, even canceled out, by drooping intonation and crude articulation elsewhere.

title: CITY BALLET: A FAREWELL FOR DANCER
description: Karin von Aroldingen gave her final performance with the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night in the New York State Theater. The German-born dancer, who joined the company in 1962 and was appointed a principal dancer in 1972, bade farewell in one of the greatest roles that had been created for her: the female soloist in the first duet of George Balanchine's ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto.'' It was a splendid choice, for it displayed many of her most striking qualities as a performer.

title:
THE LITTLE TRAIN THAT CAN;
The sign said ''
description: To the Hythe Light Railway,'' but for a moment I had doubts. Hythe Station, with its enlarged parking lot and smart new buildings, was not as I remembered. But after I joined the throng on the platform of the Romney, Hythe and Dymchurch Railway - it runs near the Kent coast in southeastern England - those doubts receded. The little railroad I'd loved since childhood, one on which everything is scaled down to one-third of normal size, hadn't really changed.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
LIVING WITH HOME APPLIANCES ONN A FIRST-NAME BASIS
description: ALL a dog has to do is run and fetch a man's slippers or newspaper and people get misty-eyed, awarding the dog the man's-best-friend title for another year. The sight of the little nipper darting into the bedroom or down the driveway, ears flopping and tongue lolling, makes them forget that a man can just as easily run and fetch these things himself. And he can do this without giving in to the temptation, even once, of chewing the slippers or newspaper to pieces.

title: DANCE: 'LOST,' WITH SYNERGIC THEATER
description: One of the most bizarre dance-theater evenings of the season occurred Thursday, when the Synergic Theater of Durham, N.C., presented ''Lost'' at Pace University's Schimmel Center. Projections, shadowplay, movement, music and speech combined in a remarkably smooth way to combine the story of Virginia Dare, the first English child born in America, with the doings of a 1930's flapper and a lost woman of the 1980's.

title: The 'New Man' Controversy
description: In ''A Feminist's View of the New Man'' (May 20), Barbara Ehrenreich apparently fails to grasp the larger meaning of the points she so perceptively documents: namely, that if women have striven to ''liberate'' themselves from traditional dependency on men, men are simply taking steps to compensate for the loss. If women no longer depend on men, then men can no longer depend on women, and men are adjusting their equilibrium accordingly.

title: A PRESIDENT AT 74(77) IS A CONSIDERABLE RISK
description: If President Reagan is re-elected, he will be almost 74 when he begins his second term and almost 78 when he completes it. But death may not permit him to complete it, for, under insurance actuarial tables, a 74-year-old man has only a two-thirds chance of surviving for four more years.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The Goldman Memorial Band, which opened its 1984 season of free summer concerts last Wednesday, is an American institution. The band memorializes two Goldmans - Edwin Franko (1878-1956), who was one of the most important of all American bandleaders at a time when such groups were more influential in the world of music than they are today, and his son Richard Franko (1910-80), who led the band after his father's death.

The sort of market research that goes into selling toothpaste often is non-existent - fashion is rarely approached scientifically, at least by those whose livelihood depends on it.

title: GREGORY MUSEUM
description: Legend has it that selenite, a variety of gypsum occurring in crystalline masses, waxed and waned with the moon. That's why the ancients called it ''The Stone of the Moon.'' By any name, there is a 48-inch-long selenite crystal now on display at the Hicksville Gregory Museum. The specimen, from the Cave of Swords in Mexico, is the star of the Zarin Collection recently acquired by this nonprofit, privately run Long Island Earth Science Center. Purchased from the estate of the late Leonard Zarin of Massapequa, the 600-piece collection, which also includes opals, amethysts and beryl (emerald) as well as other examples of selenite, rounds out the museum's already extensive holdings, which also stem from a private collection, that of Dr. Gardiner E. Gregory, the museum's founder.

title: THEATER: 'ICE BRIDGE,' BY VETERANS' ENSEMBLE
description: In its five-year history, the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater has given a voice onstage to actual Vietnam veterans and has presented a number of plays dealing with war and related issues. The company is currently in residence at the Public Theater with ''Ice Bridge,'' a postwar, pre-apocalyptic drama by John Forster. While the subject - the threat of nuclear catastrophe - is one of utmost urgency, the play attempts to score political points at the expense of credibility.

title: MRS. GANDHI VISITS CAPTURED TEMPLE
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today visited the Golden Temple in Amritsar, the Sikh shrine that was the scene of fighting 16 days ago. She was reported to have heard demands from the head priest that the army be withdrawn and pilgrims be allowed to return.

title: PIONEERING ALUMNAE HOLD A REUNION
description: THANKS to a New Jersey historian, a pioneering experiment that laid the foundation for the workers' education movement and changed the lives of hundreds of women a half-century ago was re-enacted last week.

title: Publisher Names President
description: Andrew Velez has been named president of Frederick Ungar Publishing Co., which specializes in reference books and books on literature and films. Frederick Ungar, who is 85 years old and who founded the company in 1940, has become chairman of the board. Mr. Velez joined Ungar as its business manager in 1970. He recently held the post of executive vice president.

title: A NEW COLLEGE GENERATION DISCOVERS VIETNAM
description: The Vietnam War, largely shunned on America's campuses for almost a decade, is the subject of more and more courses as a new generation of students seeks to learn about a divisive chapter in the nation's history.

title: International
description: Cuba has agreed to a U.S. proposal to begin negotiations for normalizing the flow of Cubans between the two countries, but only after the November election, the State Departement said. The United States wanted talks earlier. American officials said Cuba's insistence on waiting was consistent with an apparent policy decision not to do anything that might seem to contribute to President Reagan's re-election. (Page 1, Column 3.) Journalists must have licenses issued by the Government in a growing number of Latin American nations. Fearful that press freedom is in danger, some publishers and editors in the hemisphere are trying to stop the trend. (1:1.)

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kenneth Sims , the defensive lineman for the New England Patriots, has not forgotten his all-America days at the University of Texas. Sims has set up a $100,000 endowment for women's athletics at the college. . . . The Chicago White Sox placed Bert Roberge , a right-handed relief pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list with an inflamed right elbow and activated Ron Reed , the 41-year-old right-hander. . . . John Denny , winner of the National League Cy Young Award last year, will remain sidelined for at least three to four more weeks with an inflamed nerve in his pitching arm, the Philadelphia Phillies reported. . . . Brian Oldfield , the shot-putter, has lost his bid to get the Ninth United States Court of Appeals to issue an order allowing him to compete in the United States track and field trials in Los Angeles, which end today. . . . Craig Swoope , a defensive back at Illinois last season, was arrested following an indictment by a grand jury for an alleged conspiracy to sell cocaine.

title: DO-IT-YOURSELF ELECTRICITY ON THE RISE

title: 'Drinking and Driving': Another View
description: I read the recent comments by Philip B. Linker titled ''Drinking and Driving Can Mix'' (Opinion Page, June 3) with an overwhelming sense of dej a vu. Like its author, Mr. Linker, I was a teacher who socialized every weekend with family or friends. I also drove home ''legally drunk'' many, many times without an accident or an arrest.

title: MOTORISTS TO FACE DELAYS AS REPAIRS BEGIN ON ROADS

title: Wildlife Refuge Acquired
description: Ash Meadows National Wildlife Refuge, a spring-fed desert wetland 90 miles from Las Vegas, Nev., has become the nation's 422d refuge, Interior Secretary William P. Clark has announced. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has bought for $5 million an 11,173-acre tract owned by The Nature Conservancy, a private organzation. The refuge is a habitat for 26 species of plants and animals found nowhere else.

title: THINKING MACHINES AND THEIR PEOPLE
description: William Stockton is assistant to the Executive Editor of The New York Times.

title: Republicans Considered Inviting Michael Jackson
description: Republican officials say they once considered inviting the singer Michael Jackson to the National Convention in August to celebrate President Reagan's renomination.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY
description: It sounds as if the ''new man'' is really just a remake of the 1950's Playboy. Instead of a sports car, the new man's status symbol has become his art collection, and ''sensitivity'' has replaced

title: Egg Hits Mrs. Thatcher During Visit to Wales
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was hit with an egg that splattered over her face and dress as she left a Conservative Party rally today, witnesses said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Caption under a photograph of fish carved in wood accompanying the article ''Santa Fe Folk Art, Funny and Ferocious'' (June 3) incorrectly identified the artist. The fish were carved by Jimbo Davila.

title: COUPLE TO KEEP RAFFLE HOUSE
description: A couple will be allowed to keep a house they won in a church drawing, even though they were arrested as illegal aliens when their photograph was published in a newspaper.

title: REUNION AT BRYN MAWR: WORKERS OF 30'S RETURN
description: Over the years, they had forgotten the words to ''Bread and Roses.'' They remembered the chorus to ''Joe Hill,'' though, and when the strains of the anthem of the American labor movement sounded, the women rose from the folding chairs on a grassy courtyard of Bryn Mawr College, linked arms, and swayed under the stars:

title: AbandonedAssets
description: Two years ago, Connecticut raised its income from escheat actions by more than 1,000 percent - from $1.2 million in 1981 to $19.7 million in 1982.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Shake Down The Memories

title: Chinese Leader Is Firm On Hong Kong's Future
description: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, said today that the future of Hong Kong after 1997 had been decided and could not be changed.

title: Hilary H. Huntington Is Bride in Greenwich
description: Hilary Hull Huntington, a daughter of Mrs. John A. Snyder of Darien, Conn., and the late Robert Dinsmore Huntington Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Philip van Voorhees Ralph, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fenn T. Ralph of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CITY HOLDS RECEPTIONS FOR POTENTIAL TEACHERS
description: Dr. William A. Profriedt wondered just how many present and former students of Queens College would show up for a reception intended to interest young people in teaching mathematics and science in city schools.

title: THE GREATEST SEASON A PITCHER HAS EVER HAD
description: BASEBALL'S Cy Young Award is a misnomer. Denton T. (Cy) Young won more games than any other major league pitcher - 511 - but the award named for him is a single-season award, given not for a career of good pitching but for a single splendid season.

title: VIOLENT CRIMES BY WOMEN INCREASING
description: IN August 1982, three young women robbed a North

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ALFIE GIVES A HAND
