description: To the Editor:

title: ATTORNEYS FOR DELOREAN DECLARE THEY MIGHT NOT CALL WITNESSES
description: With the Government's case moving closer to an end in John Z. DeLorean's trial on charges of trafficking in cocaine, defense lawyers say they have not decided whether to call any of their own witnesses.

title: HUNGARY UPSETS U.S. IN GOALBALL
description: Molnar Ferenc's second-half goal enabled Hungary to post a 1-0 upset of the United States, the defending world champion, in the opening round of goalball competition today at the third International Games for the Disabled.

title: Rebecca Starr Draper Is Wed
description: Rebecca Starr Draper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Draper 3d of Washington and Atherton, Calif., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Hill Mulligan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kerry Mulligan of Sacramento, Calif. Dean Robert Hammerton-Kelly of the Stanford University Memorial Chapel performed the ceremony at the chapel, assisted by the Rev. Steven Hein, a Presbyterian minister and cousin of the bride.

title: Cabanas Status Is Uncertain
description: Durability was the Cosmos' biggest concern when they decided that Roberto Cabanas would be Giorgio Chinaglia's main replacement after Chinaglia, the league's most prolific scorer, retired last year.

title: LAMB SHOWS SOME OF ITS VERSATALITY ON THE BARBECUE GRILL
description: OF the various meats suitable for cooking on a barbeque grill (and these days, it seems, anything goes), lamb is probably the most versatile. Except for the shanks, almost any cut of lamb is excellent when grilled.

title: Vietnam Brings Home 3,000 From Cambodia
description: About 3,000 Vietnamese soldiers returned home today as Hanoi began a partial withdrawal of its estimated 180,000 troops in Cambodia.

title: LITERARY AND OTHER SUBMISSIONS
description: Jane O'Reilly is the author of ''The Girl I Left Behind,'' a collection of essays. ELBOWING THE SEDUCER

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Gifts and Services And Special Prices Two retailers with custom services share the downstairs location under Hartsdale Home Center and each has special offerings available through July and until their Aug. 6 to 20 vacation period. Their hours are 10 A.M. to 4 P. M. Monday to Friday; they are closed Saturday until Labor Day and open 9 A.M. to 12 P.M. Saturday between September and May. The same telephone, 723-8811, serves both retailers.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BEACH REGULARS
description: NEW ROCHELLE

title: Diana Emmons Humphrey Is Married
description: At St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, L.I., yesterday, Diana Emmons Humphrey, a daughter of Richard Sears Humphrey Jr. of Beverly, Mass., and Joan Downey Humphrey of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married to Hugh James Halsey, a son of Charles Day Halsey Jr. and Sandra MacRae Halsey, both of New York. The Rev. Malcolm Foster performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WESTPORT IMPRESSIONIST

title: High-Jump Record
description: Tamara Bykova of the Soviet Union set a women's world high-jump record of 6 feet 8 3/4 inches today at the Soviet National Athletics Championships at Kiev, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. She bettered the mark of 6-8 1/4 she set last August at Rome.

title: Stones Gains Final, Criticizes Officials
description: Dwight Stones, who has been America's best or near-best high jumper for 12 years, qualified today for the high-jump final of the United States Olympic trials. He then assailed meet officials, saying they had changed the qualifying procedure at the last minute and denied six other jumpers a chance to compete in the final.

title: DANCE: EIKO AND KOMA IN A DIRHAM PREMIERE
description: The American Dance Festival is celebrating its 50th birthday this summer, and it has dedicated its anniversary season to Martha Hill, Louis Horst, John Martin and Balasaraswati.

title: AN AMERICAN IN PARIS
description: Gene Kelly, Leslie Caron, Oscar Levant, Georges Guetary, Nina Foch; directed by Vincente Minnelli, 1951 MGM/CBS Home Video 113 minutes. $69.95

title: A CONTRA-DICTION
description: The Senate will face a crucial test this week as it votes on President Reagan's request for $21 million to continue the anti- Sandinista contra operation. How can the Senate think of approving this money in the wake of former Central Intelligence Agency analyst David C. MacMichael's revelation that ''there has not been a successful interdiction, or a verified report, of arms moving from Nicaragua to El Salvador since April 1981''?

title: 27 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 27 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: KEAN VETOES PAY-EQUITY BILL
description: TRENTON LEGISLATION designed to correct wage inequities among state employees was conditionally vetoed last week by Governor Kean, who called for changes before he would sign the measure into law.

title: COUNTDOWN BEGINS FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: As the countdown began today for the maiden flight of the nation's third space shuttle, the Discovery, it was clear that no matter how successful the next mission, the program would not achieve all its goals for 1984.

title: Janet Anne Jones Becomes a Bride
description: Janet Anne Jones, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene D. Jones of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Nathaniel Westley Shipp Jr., the son of Gigiann Van Dyke of Norwalk, Conn., and Mr. Shipp, also of Norwalk. The Rev. Dr. Zdenek F. Bednar performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PEOPLE WON OUT OVER LANDSCAPES
description: Until recently Marion Post Wolcott was considered one of the lesser photographers of the Farm Security Administration, the government agency that, in the 1930's, created one of the world's great photographic archives while helping American farmers recover from economic depression and drought. Like all F.S.A. photographers, Mrs. Wolcott was supposed to document both the need for aid to the rural poor and the success of the F.S.A. in providing that aid, and like all F.S.A. photographers she did this, so far as she could, in her own way. However, she came late to the program, when the emphasis had begun to shift from arguing the need for aid to celebrating the agency's achievements, and her reputation has rested primarily on a series of beautifully composed landscapes featuring fertile, well-tended farmlands.

title: BEAUTY ; SWEAT'S SIDE EFFECTS
description: VIGOROUS EXercise may make you trimmer, slimmer and healthier, but working up a good sweat can also take its toll, especially in hot weather. Hair, for example, tends to get stringy and limp as a result of the sweat, oil and dirt that accumulate during a workout and requires frequent washings and stylings which can be damaging if not done with care. Skin, under the combination of heat, trapped perspiration and snug exercise clothes, can erupt in rashes and acne.

title: Fred Wenger Jr. Wed To Susan Leslie Smith
description: Susan Leslie Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas A. Smith of Waccabuc, N.Y., and Fred Griggs Wenger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wenger of Cape May Court House, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Scudder Edwards performed the ceremony in the South Salem (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: NEW YORK'S PARK RANGERS BLAZE TRAIL FOR OTHER CITIES
description: Like many an immigrant group, the starling population started small. In the early 1890's, one Eugene Schieffelin, who thought Americans should see the birds mentioned in Shakespeare's plays, brought 120 starlings from Europe to Central Park.

title: Katherine Sherts Wed To William J. Civitillo
description: Katherine Nancy Sherts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Miles Sherts of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to William Joseph Civitillo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Arnold Civitillo of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Richard Rush performed the ceremony at the First Church Congregational in Fairfield, Conn.

title: 3 Are Accused of Failing To Get Aid for a Baby
description: Three Christian Scientists are accused of involuntary manslaughter after trying to heal a critically ill baby with prayer instead of medical care.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Dick Francis Baffled, Too

title: SUMMER THEATER AROUND THE STATE
description: SUMMERSTAGE, Summerfun, Summer Festival. By any catch words, they add up to the season's ever-popular, mostly lightweight and almost universally unthreatening theater offerings.

title: Cancer Panel Chief Named
description: President Reagan named Armand Hammer on Friday as chairman of the President's Cancer Panel. The term of Mr. Hammer, board chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, will end in 1987.

title: KITE LEADS BY SHOT IN ATLANTA CLASSIC
description: Tom Kite, seeking his second victory of the season, shot a 6-under-par 66 today and took a one-stroke lead in the third round of the $400,000 Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Classic.

title: PATH Service Is Disrupted
description: Construction will force PATH passengers in New Jersey to take shuttle buses between the Journal Square station in Jersey City and the Harrison station every Sunday through July, beginning today, a spokesman for the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line said. Free buses will leave every 15 minutes between midnight Saturday and 5 A.M. Monday, the spokesman said. The disruption is caused by repairs on the Hackensack River Lift Bridge.

title: ''Riddled With Errors''
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Richard Fischbein Weds Susan Wishart
description: Susan Mary Wishart, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wishart of Presque Isle, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Ellis Fischbein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Fischbein of Dix Hills, L.I. Justice of the Peace Leon Bisson of Waterville, Me., the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Waterville Country Club.

title: COURT BARS PRACTICE IN A RESIDENCE
SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Sad Night for Griffith
description: On a tearful note, Calvin Griffith ended two eras Friday night when he turned the ownership of the Minnesota Twins over to Carl Pohland, a businessman in Minneapolis. Pohland and Griffith signed an agreement during pre-game ceremonies amid cheers from the crowd of 21,919.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
HELPING HAND FOR COIN COLLECTORS
description: Many an old-time collector has compared today's coin market to a jungle. A new book ''The Coin Collector's Survival Manual'' by Scott A. Travers offers helpful hints on how to avoid the pitfalls and the perils. It is the work of a 22-year-old resident of Manhattan who, despite his youth, has been buying and selling coins as a dealer for nearly 10 years. The project began germinating in his mind the first time he bought a coin by mail.

title: CITY IS CENTER FOR U.S. FENCERS
description: WHAT Michael McCahey wanted and found in New York was a mentor who could discard all that he had learned and build him anew. He also found that in this desire he was not alone.

title: A Vote for Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NATION
description: Jobs Program Is Bogged Down

title: UNITED JEWISH APPEAL RAISED $640 MILLION IN '84 CAMPAIGN
description: The national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal said last week that the charity had raised $640 million during its 1984 campaign, which ended in May.

title: 5 FAILURES ON GOALS FOR SCHOOL BUDGETS
description: IN the seven years since the state

title: WHERE IS 20TH CENTURY MUSIC, NOW?
description: How does 20th-century music compare with that of the past? Is modern music becoming more accessible? What is the impact of today's technology on composition? Are there significant differences between the music of different parts of America?

title: HOLLYWOOD AND BROADWAY SHARE A WEALTH OF TALENT
description: Have you recently had the feeling that you're seeing double? I mean, have you perhaps gone to the movies of a Monday and seen William Hurt up there on the screen, and then gone to another movie on the Thursday following and seen Christopher Walken up to his ears in Cinemascope, and then gone to a Saturday-matinee performance of the new David Rabe play, ''Hurlyburly,'' only to find yourself staring at the same two gentlemen in the living-and-breathing flesh on a Broadway stage - with not the least bit of fuss being made about it? Did you feel similarly surrounded, earlier this season, as you came away from Circle in the Square's ''Heartbreak House'' remembering how fetchingly Amy Irving had just curled up in Rex Harrison's arms, and

title: A Tradition Too Dear The high school in Englewood, N.J., where Vince Lombardi began coaching has dropped its football program. St. Cecilia's, with an enrollment of approximately 100, has elected to end the sport after only 12 candidates showed up for tryouts last fall, said the principal, the
description: Rev. Joseph B. DiPeri. ''You cannot live beyond your means,'' he added.

title:
GARDENING;
FOWERING TREES FOR SUMMER
description: WE gardeners often get ourselves in a rut by planting the same old things. Take flowering trees, for example. When the flowering dogwoods and crab apples are finished blooming in late May, our gardens are suddenly devoid of flowering trees. This need not be the case. Some of the more attractive flowering trees that are adapted to our area bloom in late spring, summer and even later into the fall.

title: IRAN-IRAQ WAR: IS LULL TEMPORARY?
description: A two-week lull in the Persian Gulf war between Iraq and Iran has encouraged some Arab nations to hope that a settlement may be within sight to this four-year conflict. But many diplomats and observers up and down the gulf say they expect fighting to break out again soon.

title: JUSTICES IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: Lawrence M. Friedman, the Marion Rice Kirkwood Professor of Law at Stanford University, is the author of ''A History of American Law.'' BRANDEIS AND FRANKFURTER

title: No Headline
description: Darby Wasson Marries

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Toxostoma rufum

title: A.D.A. Backs Mrs. Mink For Vice President
description: Americans for Democratic Action today urged the selection of Patsy T. Mink, a former member of Congress who was once president of the liberal political organization, as the Democratic nominee for Vice President.

title: LICENSING OF LATIN JOURNALISTS GIVES RISE TO GROWING FEARS
description: A growing number of Latin American nations have enacted laws requiring journalists to get government licenses before they can go to work, a trend that publishers and editors in the hemisphere are trying to stop because they say the laws imperil press freedom.

title: NEW YORK CITY-TELEVISION STAR IN THE ASCENDANT
description: New York's career as a television ''star'' continues to rise. The number of made- for-television films and specials that will be using the city as a backdrop or as an integral ingredient in story lines could well set a record in 1984.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
NEW LIFE FOR OLD DOCUMENTARIES
description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on developments in cable television.

title: HEMLOCK'S DIRECTOR TO STRESS NATURE
description: DON'T expect children to come home as computer wizards from Westchester County's Camp Hemlock - unless they were experts when they went there. Under the new director, Paul Craven of Hawthorne, outdoor activities will be stressed more than ever at this sleepaway camp at Mount Lakes in North Salem.

title: HUSTON'S 'VOLCANO' PAYS HOMAGE TO THE NOVEL
description: W hen, in 1957, at the age of 48, Malcolm Lowry was found dead in the small rented house he was sharing with his wife, Margerie, in Ripe, England, the doctor described the writer's end as ''death by misadventure.'' As had been his custom for most of his adult life, Lowry had been drinking heavily that evening. After a ferocious argument with his wife, who fled under the possibly correct impression that she was fleeing for her life, he had continued to drink and, apparently, also taken a number of barbiturates.

title: Robert L. Miller Weds Kelly Harmon
description: Robert L. Miller, publisher of Sports Illustrated, was married yesterday to Kelly Harmon, a model and actress. Commissioner Joseph Shane of Los Angeles Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Brentwood, Calif.

title: CITY BARS JUDAICA SALE: PROOF OF OWNERS SOUGHT
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Department has told Sotheby's auction house that it may not proceed with a planned sale of 33 Hebrew books and manuscripts until it is shown that those who wish to sell the items are the legal owners, a spokesman for the department said yesterday.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY --
description: Barbara Ehrenreich dismisses married breadwinners with children as fatuously voluble on the subject of fathering.

title: ; Co-op Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Washington Set the Drinking Age
description: Drinking and driving don't mix - especially when teen-agers do the mixing. The number of drunk drivers involved in fatal crashes declines sharply after 21, and when states raise their drinking ages from 18 to 21, accident rates drop 30 percent. That's why a Presidential Commission on Drunk Driving last year recommended a national minimum drinking age of 21. President Reagan finally endorsed this sensible idea last week, and Congress can make it a reality.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY --
description: Barbara Ehrenreich might have learned something more profound and less stylish if she had dealt with men over 40 - men who shaped their adulthood during the first two decades of the feminist revolution, as compared with younger males who have accommodated themselves to its journalistic aftershocks. I believe she would have found, among those older new men, sensitivity with commitment, marriage with fatherhood, physical fitness and political activism, all in abundance. JOEL SAVISHINSKY Ithaca, N.Y.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' CONTROVERSY --
description: I take issue with the judgmental tone Miss Ehrenreich adopts throughout the article. Any man who, 10 years ago, proclaimed his opinions in The New York Times Magazine on the contemporary state of the then ''new woman'' would have been told that the direction of feminist change was none of his damn business - the currents had shifted and he would just have to live with it. CHARLES J. ROSS JR. Chicago

title: No Headline
description: Officials Investigating Forgery of Toll Tickets

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN SOMETIMES, you wouldn't even know I had it. Months - even years - would go by and people would have no inkling there was a latent problem.

title: Patricia Barbara Colombo Wed to Thomas M. Varley
description: Patricia Barbara Colombo, a daughter of Barbara Colombo of Bedford, N.Y., and Patrick F. Colombo of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas M. Varley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Varley of Bound Brook, N.J., The Rev. Francis O'Malley performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel at Good Counsel Academy in White Plains.

title: Giverny
description: To the Editor:

title: INSTRUMENTS RETURN, WITH TALES OF WOE
description: AS the last note of the last school orchestra concert of the year fades away, hundreds of violin, flute and clarinet cases are being closed for the summer, and swarms of parents will begin arriving at the tiny office of the Ardsley Musical Instrument Service to return their children's rented instruments.

title: REFLECTIONS IN AN ANGUISHED EYE
description: Grace Glueck is an art critic for The New York Times. DIANE ARBUS

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AS the repository for the most comprehensive collection of works and writings by 19th-century American genre painter William Sidney Mount, the Museums at Stony Brook naturally go to the collection whenever possible. Fortunately, for the museum curators, Mount did not live by canvas and brush alone; his interests were varied and consuming.

title: BELGIUM
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GREENMAIL,' NEW FORM OF AN OLD CYNICISM
description: In 1961, when I first ventured onto Wall Street, I was immediately confronted by what seemed a disturbing ethical anomaly. On the one hand, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, was scuttling about the country scouting up new investors with the exhortation, ''Own Your Share in America!'' On the other, it was an article of absolute faith among the Street's professionals that ''the public is always wrong.''

title: METS' BERENYI DEFEATS EXPOS, 2-0
description: The train that Ken Singleton was talking about before the game had some caboose trouble tonight.

title: BOLET TO BE SOLOIST AS WATRELOO OPENS
description: BYRAM TWP. THE pianist Jorge Bolet will be the soloist Saturday at the opening concert of the Waterloo Village Festival for the Arts.

title: WOOD'S ROLE IS STILL UNCLEAR
description: Months ago, when Leon Wood's professional future was less certain, all he heard was that his amateur future was virtually guaranteed. The assurances of his friends and the words in articles from coast to coast all carried an identical message: He would run the United States men's Olympic basketball team in Los Angeles as surely as there would be traffic jams there.

title: BONNARD'S REALISM WAS SUMPTUOUSLY ACHIEVED
description: WASHINGTON

title: WHY INSTITUTIONS LIKE MUTUAL FUNDS
description: MUTUAL funds have experienced phenomenal growth in the 1980's as institutional investors who formerly eschewed mutual funds in favor of separately managed accounts began pouring billions of dollars into stock, bond and money market funds.

title: CONSUMER RATES
NUDGING NATO IS A TOUCHY ISSUE
description: For President Reagan, just back from celebrating allied solidarity at the 40th anniversary of the Normandy invasion, it was embarrassing last week to have to beat back a move in the Senate that would have reduced American troops in Europe unless the West Europeans did more in their own defense. The measure's sponsors wanted to strengthen NATO, but the White House feared it would open dangerous new fissures with Europe.

title: A RIPPOWAM HERO RETURNS TO STAMFORD
description: BOBBY VALENTINE, who as a Rippowam High School football halfback in the mid- 1960's received more than 200 offers for athletic scholarships from colleges across the country and who became a major league baseball star, is planning to return to Connecticut - as a resident.

title: JACKSON TRYING FIRENDLIER PERSUASION
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson last week called a halt of sorts to his running dispute with Democratic officials over party rules. Then, having made a gesture toward peace with his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, he took off on a ''fact-finding mission'' to investigate an ''escalation of war activities'' in Central America.

title: SQUASH
description: Whenever I am on the verge of declaring summer the supreme achievement of the Almighty Creator, somebody spoils the mood by bringing me a load of squash.

title: A MUCH-IMPROVED CAFE
description: ALL too often, in restaurants as elsewhere, success goes to the head. A restaurant lavishly praised and acclaimed suddenly becomes complacent, careless, sloppy. When the reverse happens, there is cause for celebration. In the case of Versailles in Stamford, let us make it a small celebration for the time being.

title: Mary Kay Campo To Wed Lawyer
description: The engagement of Mary Katherine Campo to Chester Lee Cobb has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. J. William Campo of Greenwich, Conn., and Hyannis Port, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Cobb of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Giving L.I. Business A Chance
description: As former president of the Long Island Public Relations Association, first president of the Long Island chapter of the Public Relations Society of America and currently president of my own public relations firm, headquartered in Hicksville, I write to raise - or repeat - the oft-asked question: Why do local organizations persist in misbelieving that essential public relations services must be obtained from New York City-based agencies?

title: JIMI PLAYS BERKELEY
description: With Jimi Hendrix, Billy Cox and Mitch Mitchell Vestron Video 55 minutes. $29.95

title: INDY CARS' MEADOWLANDS TEST
description: Al Unser has won the Indianapolis 500 three times, and is the reigning PPG Indy-car world series driving champion. He is the only driver to have lapped the Meadowlands Grand Prix racing circuit at full speed, and he expects that next Dunday's 200-mile race for Indy cars at the sports complex in East Rutherford, N.J., will be more physically demanding on the drivers than the 500 miles around Indy.

title: UTILITY IS CITED IN SURVEY
description: MANY electric utilities around the country have recently found themselves with construction bills higher than they can handle because of cost overruns on nuclear reactors. But according to a new national survey by a stock brokerage, the utility facing the greatest burden relative to its size is the United Illuminating Company, a partner in the Seabrook project in New Hampshire and in Millstone 3 in Waterford.

title: GARDENA: ALPINE VALLEY FIT FOR A PRESIDENT
description: The triangular main square of Ortisei, a smiling Alpine town in northeastern Italy, is the stage on which a scene is enacted several afternoons a year: A jeep with three carabinieri pulls up, followed a few minutes later by a vehicle from which an old gentleman climbs out to have an espresso at the Cafe Haiti. Those milling in the little piazza applaud, and some shake the hand of the coffee drinker.

title: VISIONS OF THE FUTURE YIELD TO POLITICS OF THE MOMENT
description: Every four years for a few weeks, the leaders of both political parties claim for their respective platforms a significance and vitality that is very difficult to detect, even in trace quantities, during the other 47 months of the quadrennium. While the platform is being written and fiercely debated in committee and on the convention floor, it seems briefly to overshadow the candidates and the prize. Then it promptly fades from political consideration.

title: 'THE JACKSON FACTOR IS NOT A BARGAINING CHIP'
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
STYLES DESIGNED TO CAPTURE LIKENESSES AND PERSONALITIES
description: TWO official portraits of judges that hang over the stairs in the Hastings-on- Hudson Muncipal Building are not part of ''Portraits Now,'' the current offering of the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson. The Gallery shares a floor with a courtroom, and those judicial portraits are a permanent fixture. Yet if they seem at first to be part of the show, it's because ''Portraits Now'' can accommodate just about everything under the sun concerned with likenesses.

title: PIQUET GAINS POLE IN DETROIT RACE TODAY
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, the defending Formula One driving champion, won the pole position for Sunday's Detroit Grand Prix in a Brabham-BMW, sprinting through the streets of the city at a speed of 89.126 miles per hour on his best lap.

title: ANIMALS CREEP BACK INTO TODAY'S ART
description: After years of being banished from the art world, the beast is back. There were few images of animals in mainstream art in the aftermath of World War II and almost none during the 1960's and early 70's, when art was dominated by urbane Pop Art and then by Minimal Art and Formalism, which prided themselves on having purified art of everything that was extraneous to it, such as imagery and content.

title: Pravda Says Reagan Is Using Religion to Justify U.S. Acts
description: The Reagan Administration is using religion to seek to justify intervention actions abroad and to make Americans feel they are ''God's chosen people,'' the Communist Party paper Pravda said today.

title: CABINET TAKES A STAB AT ARMY REFORM IN LEBANON
description: After some prodding from Syria, Lebanon's Cabinet announced agreement yesterday on a plan to reorganize the army as a major step toward resolving the basic problem of power sharing. But continuing violence and divisions among the country's political leaders who make up what is called the Government of National Unity tempered the official optimism about restoring peace among the warring sects.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: It wasn't New York City's biggest theft, but it qualified easily as one of its more embarrassing: $600,000 in cash stolen in July 1979 from a double- locked Transit Authority safe that was guarded around the clock by two or three transit police officers.

title: HIRSCH HESS, RIPE FOR SALVATION

title: Efforts to Save Striped Bass

title: MUSIC: WESTERN WIND, AN A CAPELLA ENSEMBLE
description: Voice, as the critic and composer Joan LaBarbara likes to say, is the original instrument: Not only does it take historical precedence, but it is the sole instrument everybody possesses by birthright. As such, although American instrumental music has come of age only in the last 100 years, we have a proud tradition of vocal music stretching back several centuries, practically back to the proverbial landing on Plymouth Rock. Tuesday night, the Western Wind, an excellent and remarkably versatile ensemble, paid tribute to this heritage in the Abraham Goodman House with a program devoted to ''Music in the New World.''

title: IS THERE A SAFE WAY OUT FOR THE URUGUAYAN MILITARY?
description: Although he was sitting in a Uruguayan military jail this weekend, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, a leading presidential candidate, appeared to be just where he wanted to be - riding a surge of popularity. But aggressive maneuvering by him and other civilian presidential aspirants, and by the country's military rulers, may upset prospects for Uruguay's first presidential election since 1971.

title: WILCOX OF TIGERS BEATS BREWERS, 5-1
description: Howard Johnson hit a three-run homer and Kirk Gibson connected with the bases empty today to support the four-hit pitching of Milt Wilcox over eight innings as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-1.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: PASSES PAVE THE WAY TO SAVING
description: Travelers who want to move around - without a car - when they visit Europe are shortchanging themselves if they do not buy a pass offering unlimited travel on buses and trains. These national and city travel cards - not to be confused with the 16-country Eurailpass, with which travelers speed across the Continent - save money. But that's not all. In most cases they eliminate the need to stand in line at ticket windows - you just show your card to the ticket collector - and to wrestle with unfamilar currency. Some are a boon to the rover who wants to cover a lot of ground; others suit the day tripper aiming to zip in and out of a city and around it.

Full-scale drills involve state and local governments. Onsite drills held by the plants alone will still have to be conducted annually.

title: STARTING STRENGTH IN THE 2D QUARTER
description: The ''flash'' estimate showing the gross national product expanding at a 5.7 percent rate in the second quarter surprised many analysts, who had been predicting a rate closer to 3 or 4 percent. In contrast to the revised 9.7 percent rate of the first quarter, the second quarter has moderated. But in past recoveries, the economy had slowed significantly by this point. Despite an inflation rate that is declining, some analysts worry that a still- spurting economy could lead to harsh inflation. Others say the figures may indicate fundamental changes in the economy that avoid the boom-bust cycles that have prevailed since World War II.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ALICE JAMES: A Biography, by Jean Strouse. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) As interesting and complicated as any heroine in her brother's novels, the younger sister of Henry James is made the subject of a biography for the first time. Jean Strouse's prize-winning book was hailed by Diane Johnson in 1980 as ''more than a biography, a complicated work of social history.'' ''A sentient and articulate person,'' in Miss Strouse's words, Alice suffered the consequences of a Victorian-American ethos that idealized women while placing a negative value on their intelligence. Hounded by neurasthenia most of her life, Alice overcame several breakdowns before acquiring a true sense of herself. If this book reads like a Jamesian novel, it may well be because Alice was a prototype of the Jamesian heroine.

description: ON the State Capitol's south lawn, flower beds have been moved to make room for two buildings that will serve as temporary offices for about 55 State Senators and Representatives during the Capitol's three-year renovation project. The prefabricated buildings, scheduled for occupancy on July 1, will be leased by the state until 1987.

title: 421-A TENANTS ENTITLED TO STABILIZED LEASES
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., PUT PRESSURE ON SUDAN'S PRESIDENT
description: The United States is getting quietly embroiled in a dangerous situation in the Sudan. Washington's ties to the erratic regime of Gaafar al-Nimeiry are increasing at a time when his own populace and other allies are distancing themselves from it. Unless current trends are halted, there may be major trouble in the Sudan.

title: 850,000 JAM PARIS IN A SCHOOLS PROTEST
description: At least 850,000 protesters demonstrated in the streets of Paris Sunday to show their opposition to a Government proposal that would give the state some new powers to regulate France's private schools.

title: OPERA WRITTEN FOR QUEEN ELIZABETH II'S CORONATION
description: Although composed at the height of Britten's powers, between ''Billy Budd'' and ''The Turn of the Screw,'' ''Gloriana'' remains the least known of his mature operas. Commissioned for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953, it was tepidly greeted at its premiere at the Royal Opera, Covent Garden - in part because the invitational audience apparently expected something more cheerful and accessible, and in part because Britten's longtime associates, Joan Cross and Peter Pears, as Elizabeth and Essex, had their deficiencies.

title: Kigen Is Winner
description: Simeon Kigen, a 22-year-old Kenyan who attends Mississippi State University, pulled away over the final three miles today to win the Cascade Run Off 15-kilometer road race.

title: FUSES IN NEW YORK PRISONS
description: By 1985, the New York State prison system may experience a series of violent eruptions that would stun the sensibilities of many citizens. If they occur, they will result in no small measure from citizen apathy toward the administration of our criminal-justice system, especially its prisons.

title: Rath Has Offer For 65% Stake
description: A New Jersey businessman has offered $25 million in financing to the Rath Packing Company of Waterloo, Iowa, in exchange for 65 percent of the stock of the troubled pork processing concern. The offer is in a memorandum of agreement filed Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Cedar Rapids, where Rath is undergoing a reorganization to stay in business.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Barristers-to-BeThe Knicks, whose tradition for scholarly players dates to Bill Bradley, would seem to have a hole in their academic roster with the expected departure of Len Elmore, a reserve forward.

title: Miss Nason and David Burchenal Wed
description: Kathryn Theresa Nason, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Adelbert Nason of Gales Ferry, Conn., was married yesterday to David Holland Burchenal, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Holland Burchenal of Noroton, Conn. The Rev. Robert E. McNulty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the United States Coast Guard Academy Memorial Chapel in New London, Conn.

title: IMMIGRATION MOVE HARD TO ENFORCE, SPECIALISTS ASSERT
description: Enforcement of comprehensive immigration legislation in Congress would present a huge challenge to the already overburdened Immigration and Naturalization Service, according to many specialists in the field.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I get scared and stuff because what if they do something to me.

title: OUTLOOK FOR INDIVIDUALS' TAX BURDEN
description: The House-Senate compromise tax bill is a patchwork of measures intended to raise $50 billion in revenues over four years while leaving individuals relatively unscathed. This deficit-reduction effort is expected to go before both chambers of Congress this week for final approval.

title: Volcker Meets Hungary Chief
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, and the leader of Hungary, Janos Kadar, discussed international issues and bilateral questions Friday, the official M.T.I. press agency reported.

title: RISE IN STATUS GIVES A HISPANIC GROUP GROWING PAINS
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson attended the 55th annual convention of the League of United Latin American Citizens, the oldest and largest Hispanic rights group, he was showered with flowers and was hugged by members.

title: ; ALBATROSSES OF THE AMERICAN JUDICIAL SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC SERIES EXAMINES ROMANCE
description: ''THE LOVE REPORT,'' a new daytime series that can be seen, Monday through Friday, at 11 A.M. on ABC, does try to take itself seriously. One of the producers has explained: ''This is not just another talk show. We will visit with celebrities from all walks of life - entertainment, sports, politics - taking an objective, in-depth look at the problems people face in their romantic relationships.'' But beneath this veneer of lofty purpose, the show is just another example of television trying to squeeze more profits out of fantasies, most of them revolving around sex. ''The Love Report'' is a kind of newscast version of ''The Love Boat.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Longhorns and Dickens At Lexington Ave. Festival

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Triathlete HeavenOn the theory, perhaps, that one triathlon deserves another, New York City is going to have two of the grueling three-event combinations this summer - or at least one and a fraction.

title: MISS DECKER UPSET IN 1,500
description: Forget that Dwight Stones broke an American record by high jumping 7 feet 8 inches. Forget that Steve Scott and Sydney Maree made the United States Olympic team, even though Jim Spivey beat both in the men's 1,500-meter final.

title: MORRIS POSTS NO. 12 AS TIGERS WIN, 7-1
description: Jack Morris allowed one hit through the first six innings for his 100th career victory and Lance Parrish and Ruppert Jones hit home runs today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 7-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: JOE WILLIAMS AND SARAH VAUGHAN
description: For 30 years, Joe Williams and Sarah Vaughan have been two of the three best-known jazz singers in the world (with Ella Fitzgerald as the third). On Saturday evening, now at a peak in their careers, combining distilled experience and full vocal skill, Mr. Williams and Miss Vaughan shared a program in the Kool Jazz Festival at Carnegie Hall that brought out the best in both of them.

title: How Much Haven for Drug Pioneers?
description: A long and stormy battle between rival groups of pharmaceutical manufacturers is near resolution in an important bill designed by Representative Henry Waxman of California. Despite objections by a break-away faction of large drug houses, the Waxman bill is a just compromise that will foster invention of new drugs and lower the price of older drugs coming off patent.

title: U.N. REPORT ON POLAND ASSAILED
description: An underground Polish human rights organization has sharply criticized an official report on human rights in Poland compiled earlier this year by the office of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: Panthers 20, Blitz 17
description: John Williams rushed for 161 yards and scored a pair of touchdowns and Novo Bojovic added two field goals to lead Michigan past Chicago.

title: JACKSON SAYS LEFTIST GROUPS IN EL SALVADOR WANT PEACE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he had received assurances from representatives of two leftist groups fighting the Government of El Salvador that they wanted a peaceful resolution of the longstanding conflict.

title: BRIEFING
description: Good Guys and Bad

title: Dodgers 5, Braves 2
description: Franklin Stubbs hit a two-run homer, and Pedro Guerrero, Mike Marshall and Greg Brock added one-run shots to help Los Angeles complete a three- game sweep of Atlanta.

title: PHYSICISTS MAY HAVE TRACKED LAST QUARK TO LAIR
description: Data obtained at the European Center for Nuclear Research near Geneva have produced what physicists there say they regard tentatively as the first evidence of a sixth kind of quark, one of the great prizes sought in modern physics.

title: No Headline
description: Following is a schedule of Jazz Festival events today. 5 P.M. Carnegie Recital Hall. Denny

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Tigers won two of three from the Yanks in a series last week in Detroit. (Television - Sports Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.).

title: Nixon Predicts Ticket Of Mondale and Hart By The Associated Press
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, speaking to reporters in Austin, Tex., predicts that Walter F. Mondale, the likely Democratic Presidential candidate, will pick Senator Gary Hart as his running mate and that the two will give President Reagan a tough fight in the November election.

title: SONG:MARTHA TONEY OFFERS WORKS OF SEVEN
description: MARTHA TONEY, the soprano who made her New York recital debut at Goodman House last Tuesday night, has an attractive voice that gave the lovely cantilena of Villa-Lobos's ''Bachianas Brasileiras'' No. 5 the tremulous floating quality it demands. And Miss Toney's singing was also very effective in items such as Bellini's ''Malinconia,'' Poulenc's ''Les Chemins d'Amour'' (a waltz composed in 1940 for Yvonne Printemps), songs by Rodrigo performed with guitar accompaniment and some Strauss songs, ''Dein Lied Erklang,'' for example.

title: CATHOLIC LIBERALS DEFEND ACTIVISM
description: A group of prominent Roman Catholic theologians from Europe, Latin America and the United States issued a statement yesterday that defends recent theological movements that call for church involvement in politics, especially in the third world.

title: Networks and Cable Covering the Shuttle
description: The four principal television network news operations reported plans yesterday for live coverage of the launching of the space shuttle Discovery from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Chase Colombia Loan
description: Colombia, host to last week's meeting of Latin American debtor nations, has been offered a $700 million loan by the Chase Manhattan Bank, Finance Minister Edgardo Gutierrez said Friday. He said that the bank offered to provide the syndicated loan for energy projects and that Colombia would sign a $370 million World Bank co-financing loan in Paris next week.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK:STAMMERING ON TAXES
description: There was applause near dawn Saturday in the House Ways and Means Committee hearing room on Capitol Hill. A few claps and then, after catching on, the rise of applause. It was 4:28 A.M. and Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, had just walked back into the hearing room, not looking the worse for the wear - suit jacket on, tie cinched.

title: Amy Beth Leeds And Anders Brag Exchange Vows
description: Amy Beth Leeds and Anders Carl Henrik Brag were married yesterday at the summer home in Greenwich, Conn., of the bride's mother, Isabelle Leeds, also of New York. Judge Sidney Landau of the Connecticut Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Summer in the CityHe had a chance to take his team on one of those pre-Olympic international dream tours with stops in Israel, Greece and Bulgaria, but Jack Donohue, the coach of the Canadian Olympic basketball team, had a better idea.

title: Reva Gisele Gershen Weds William Lowy in Princeton
description: At the Jewish Center of Princeton, N.J., yesterday Reva Gisele Gershen, director of education at the Frances Shervier Home and Hospital in Riverdale, the Bronx, was married to William Joseph Lowy, an associate with the New York law firm of Botein, Hays & Sklar.

title: Yonkers Manager To Revise Budget
description: The Yonkers City Manager, Rodney Irwin, agreed today to submit a modified four-year fiscal plan for review by the Emergency Financial Control Board overseeing the city's money.

title: WOMEN AND LONG WORKDAYS
description: HE was a 30-year-old compulsive worker who put in more than 50 hours a week at an investment banking firm. He earned a third more than his male colleagues who worked 40 hours a week. He considered himself an overwhelming success.

title: PROFITABLE 'STRANGLE'
description: WHEN in doubt about an option market's direction, many professional traders simply ''strangle'' it, and traders in Treasury bond options who did so last week profited handsomely.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, has elected to its board David C. Treen, former Governor of Louisiana.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Raquel Leventhal and Aryeh Rubin Are Married
description: Raquel Leventhal and Aryeh Rubin were married yesterday. Rabbi Yitzchak Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: GUIDRY TRIES TO PICK UP PIECES
description: Ron Guidry has been the victim this season of: (a) his poor pitch selection and poor location of his pitches, (b) his inability to make the big pitch when he has to, (c) the Yankees' porous defense, (d) the Yankees' ineffective relief corps or (e) all of the above.

title: Cagney Recovering
description: James Cagney suffered a heart attack June 16, but the 84-year- old actor is ''recovering nicely'' and is expected to be released from St. Andrews Hospital this week, his agent, Marge Zimmerman, said today.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHTIST TIED TO MURDER PLOT WILL MEET SENATORS
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the right-wing Salvadoran politician who has been reported to have been involved in a plot to assassinate the United States Ambassador to El Salvador, will meet with senators here this week, a Congressional aide said Sunday.

title: Deborah E. Grauer Weds Richard Scott Finkelstein
description: Deborah Eve Grauer, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Murray Grauer of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Richard Scott Finkelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Finkelstein of Long Beach, L.I. The bride's father, spiritual leader of the Hebrew Institute of White Plains and secretary of the Rabbinical Council of America, performed the ceremony at the Westchester Hotel.

title: DOWNGRADING OIL SHARES
description: Energy stocks in general have outperformed the market since the start of this year, in part because money managers had previously shown little interest in them. But the group gradually came to be perceived as a safe haven in an uncertain climate for equities.

title: 2 POPULAR ACTS SHARE A JAZZ-FUSION PROGRAM
description: -FUSION music, cleanly crafted but tepid in spirit, commanded the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night as Spyro Gyra and Bob James, two popular fusion acts, shared the bill.

title: Stanley White, 53, Producer Of Films and 'Tap Dance Kid'
description: Stanley White, one of the producers of ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' died in his sleep Friday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 53 years old.

title: INDIANS AND INDUSTRIES MEET TO AIR VIEWS ON LAND
description: The friction between industries trying to develop energy resources on Indian lands and tribal laws and perceptions about development is a familiar feature of economic life in the West.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1984
description: The Economy

title: LAW GUARDIANS OF STATE'S YOUTH FAULTED IN STUDY
description: Legal representation for abused and delinquent children in New York State is often inadequate and falls short in many cases of meeting state and Federal laws, an inquiry conducted by the New York State Bar Association has found.

title: QUALITY EDUCATION IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: JSE
description: Jess Stein, a lexicographer, died of a heart attack on Saturday, his 70th birthday, at his home in White Plains.

title: FEARS GROW FOR LIVES AND A WAY OF LIFE AS FLOODS HIT MISSOURI
description: Eight hundred acres of corn and soybeans lie beneath the Missouri River flood waters that swept across Joe Pepper's rich bottom land in Platte County two weeks ago.

title: CHILDHOOD IN 'HELL': GROWING UP IN TIMES SQ.
description: The sour stench of garbage and alcohol rose from the sidewalk in hot waves. In front of the Carter Hotel on West 43d Street, there were children everywhere, hanging off the door of the Rose Saigon restaurant, swinging on fire hydrants, wrestling in piles of beer cans in paper bags.

title: NEW YORK HOUSING AGENCY TAKES A BOW AT 50
description: Fifty years ago Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia shepherded into existence in New York City the first public housing authority in the United States. Its mandate, as he described it a year later at the opening of the first project, was ''to give the people of my city, in place of their tenements, decent, modern cheerful housing, with a window in every room and a bit of sunshine in every window.''

title: Body of Club Med Man Is Found Off Corfu
description: The body of a French employee of Club Mediterranee who disappeared on a fishing trip last week was found today in the sea off this resort island, Greek and French authorities said.

title: TOOL ORDERS INCREASED 27% IN MAY
description: Orders for machine tools jumped 27 percent in May from April as the industry continued its month-by-month strengthening, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. The gain followed a 23 percent rise in April.

title: Indians Memorialize Wounded Knee History
description: Indians from across the country encircled a historic burial ground here this weekend in memory of Indian deaths in 1890 and 1973 in the prairie foothills of southwestern South Dakota.

title: I.M.F. AIDE'S HARD LATIN ROLE
description: For Eduardo Wiesner Duran, an economist and politician who is now an international civil servant, these are not easy times.

title: SCRABBLE, HIS BRAINCHILD
description: Just about this time a half-century ago, in the midst of the Depression, Alfred Mosher Butts, an unemployed architect, began working on a word game he at first called Lexiko, then Criss Cross Words and, eventually, Scrabble.

title: No Headline
description: Ruth Cohen Is a Bride

title: EUROPEAN RIVALRY IN CARBON FIBERS
description: For several years, carbon fibers have been hailed as science's answer to high technology's needs in the aerospace industry. Their light weight and remarkable strength make them a potential substitute for aluminum and steel, and sales have soared in a market dominated by Japan and the United States.

title: OUTDOORS:A COOL DESCENT INTO THE INTRIGUING CROTON
description: WEARING a wet suit, I made an overheated descent down the steep slope leading to my favorite pool in Westchester's Croton River. But having slipped into its cool, late-spring current, I soon felt refreshed. Little bottom-dwelling darters eyed this large, snorkel-puffing intruder with cautious curiosity, finally sending up tiny swirls of sand as they went scurrying toward some imagined safety.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Buoyant Wishes

title: CARLTON AND PHILS BEAT PIRATES
description: Ozzie Virgil hit a two-run home run and drove in three Philadelphia runs, and Von Hayes pinch-hit a homer as the Phillies defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 4-2.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: I have read about ''fast'' pools in swimming. How can one pool be faster than another?

title: Dr. Leslie H. Gise Weds a Physicist
description: Dr. Leslie Hartley Gise, an assistant professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas Kimber Worthington 3d, a physicist at the I.B.M. Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Rosman performed the ceremony at the home of Freda Hartley, the bride's mother, in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Schroders Will DivideDuties of Its Chairman
description: When the 13th Earl of Airlie retires in November as chairman of Schroders P.L.C., the London-based merchant bankers, to take up his appointment as Lord Chamberlain of the Queen's Household, his former job will be split in two.

title: Quaker Oats Assigns Celeste Pizza Account
description: Last month Backer & Spielvogel got an unidentified cereal product assignment from the Quaker Oats Company.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:AmericanAreWaWe

title: Morgan Halperin Wed To Susan Lee Marcus
description: Susan Lee Marcus and Morgan Halperin were married yesterday at Le Club in Manhattan by Rabbi Mark Goldman. The bride is a daughter of Jerry Lee Marcus of New York and Muriel Sonnenblick Marcus Perry of Los Angeles.

title: Amax's Metals Group Split Into Three Parts
description: Amax Inc. has announced a restructuring of its metals group into two commodity metals businesses and a new specialty products sector. ''We are recasting the company entirely,'' said Pierre Gousseland, the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: THOUSANDS HOLD MARCH TO BACK HOMOSEXUALS
description: Thousands of homosexuals and their supporters, focusing their protests on the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York's stand on homosexuals, paraded yesterday in Manhattan with bands, banners and chants of ''Welcome to gay day'' in the 15th annual Gay Pride March.

title: BATTERY POLLUTION WORRIES JAPANESE
description: Japan's love of electronic gadgets is producing an unwanted and potentially lethal side effect - battery pollution.

title: Treasury Trims Size of Bill Auction
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular auction of short-term bills followed by the sale on Tuesday of $6 billion in new four- year notes.

title: FOCUS ON MCENROE, AND NOT HIS GAME
description: All of England seemed poised this weekend for the moment on Monday afternoon when John McEnroe will saunter onto the dwarf rye grass of Centre Court to begin the defense of his Wimbledon title with a first-round match against Paul McNamee of Australia.

title: Rebels Said to Attack Five Villages in Peru
description: Guerrillas attacked five villages in Peru over the weekend and killed 39 people, defying an offer by President Fernando Belaunde Terry to end military control in the area, the police reported today.

title: Piquet Leads Start to Finish
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil bolted from the pole position to an early lead today and then simply ran away with the third Detroit Grand Prix Formula One auto race. Driving smoothly and flawlessly under brilliant sunshine, he set a course speed record at an average of 81.679 miles per hour, surpassing the 81.051-m.p.h. mark set last year.

title: IT'S SIDNEY, A NEW FOE OF SCOFFLAW
description: Scofflaws could learn to hate Sidney.

title: COSMOS WIN, 3-1, FROM ROUGHNECKS
description: Two goals by Andrew Parkinson and some spectacular saves by Hubert Birkenmeier helped the Cosmos to a 3-1 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks today at Giants Stadium.

title: MICHEL CAMILO COMBINES LATIN AND AVANT-GARDE
description: -garde jazz shared a bill and stretched some categories Saturday at Irving Plaza.

title: A CHANCE, FOR ONCE, TO BE NO. 1
description: Although it was once the industrial heart of the region, Birmingham, Ala., has placed a poor second in recent years to Atlanta, a city that has come to symbolize the progressive New South.

title: Egyptian President Opens New Parliament
description: President Hosni Mubarak officially opened Egypt's newly elected People's Assembly today. It includes the largest and most cohesive parliamentary opposition any Egyptian President has faced.

title: HELP STOP THE WAVE
description: LIKE acid rain defoliating the countryside or a new strain of virus or killer bees mercilessly working their way up the Americas, a new plague has spread from the Middle West, reaching New York over the weekend.

title: Seabrook Resumption Voted
description: Officials of 16 New England utilities with financial interests in the Seabrook nuclear power plant voted Saturday to resume construction of one reactor under new management.

title: Foundry Finds Profit Niches
description: When Leo Ladehoff arrived here in 1979 to head the Amcast Corporation, he quickly sensed that the big iron foundry company faced a drastic shrinkage of its major market - the auto industry.

title: STARS AGAIN UPSET BY GENERALS, 16-10
description: Herschel Walker made two big plays today, one for a gain of only 2 yards but for a first down; the other for 50 yards and a touchdown. The plays, both in the fourth quarter, were the key ones that enabled the Generals to upset Philadelphia, 16-10, and end the Stars' streak of 14 victories.

title: 60 HONOR MEMORY OF RIGHTS WORKERS
description: About 60 people gathered here today to pay tribute to three civil rights workers who were murdered in the summer of 1964 while participating in an effort to register black voters.

title: RECITAL BY WALTER DAVIS JR., A PROTEGE OF BUD POWELL
description: IT is somewhat surprising to find

title: Mark Set in 10,000
description: Olga Bondarenko, 24 years old, set a world record in the 10,000-meter run today at the Soviet track and field championship in Kiev with a time of 31 minutes 13.78 seconds, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. The previous record of 31:27.58 was established last year by Raisa Sairetdinova, Tass said.

title: CECILIA DeMILLE HARPER
description: Cecilia deMille Harper, who worked with her father, Cecil B. deMille, on such major films as ''The Ten Commandments,'' died Saturday after a brief illness. She was 75 years old.

title: IN LIKE A LAMB AND OUT LIKE A LION
description: When the second session of the 98th Congress convened last January, conventional wisdom on Capitol Hill held that the lawmakers would not accomplish very much this year. With elections approaching, the argument went, members of Congress were anxious to avoid taking on controversy and handing fresh ammunition to their opponents.

title: TAX MOVES ON BIG ESTATES
description: WASHINGTON SOME big names got tax benefits and some did not in the $50 billion, four-year package of tax increases approved early Sunday morning by House and Senate conferees.

title: Nancy Ludmerer Married
description: Nancy Beth Ludmerer, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, and Geoffrey Peppiatt, a physics teacher at the Trinity School in New York, were married yesterday.

title: Palmer Wins by 3 Shots
description: Arnold Palmer played virtually error- free golf for 15 holes today, then weathered some late problems to hold off Peter Thomson of Australia and win the $250,000 Senior PGA Tournament Players Championship by three strokes.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA SERVES NOTICE: SHE'LL IMPROVE
description: THERE are all the trappings of celebrity: the row of cameras big and small that waggle and record her practice shots for home albums, the sea of rapt sunburned faces that parts respectfully when the star, having enough of autographing, comes through with ''Sorry, sorry.''

title: Utah Candidates Face Gubernatorial Runoff
description: Utah Republicans have sent House Speaker Norman Bangerter and Representative Dan Marriott into a primary runoff for the party's gubernatorial nomination.

title: Airbus Picked By Air India
description: The European Airbus consortium bested the Boeing Company for an Air India order of six airliners valued at $530 million, including spare parts and training.

title: HEALTH, VITALITY AND SEX: BOOKS FOR WOMEN
description: Although a few dust collectors may have been published before it, ''Our Bodies, Ourselves'' by the Boston Women's Health Book Collective - ''a book by and for women'' - created an important new category in the publishing industry.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The People's ChoiceThe votes are pouring in, and as they do each year, the question arises: Is fan voting the best way to select the All-Star teams that will face each other in San Francisco on July 10?

title: CARDIAC SURGERY: TOP CARE FOR VETERANS
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQIS RESUME GULF AIR ATTACKS, SLIGHTLY DAMAGING GREEK TANKER
description: Iraqi warplanes today attacked a Greek- registered tanker carrying Iranian oil in the Persian Gulf in the first such attack in over two weeks. Iraq vowed to increase attacks against shipping in the area.

title: MURRAY RUNS WITH THE BEST
description: GEORGE MURRAY still smiles when he remembers his first Boston Marathon. It was 1978, and Murray, who had competed in only one marathon in his life, knew he was facing the finest distance runners in the world. He had trained for months - hitting a punching bag, lifting weights, running up to 100 miles a week.

title: South Korean G.N.P.
description: South Korea's gross national product is expected to grow 8.1 percent this year, compared with an official 7.5 percent target and a 9.3 percent rise last year, the Korea Development Institute, a government research center, said in a report.

title: A Medal In First Attempt
description: Julie Holley knew she was facing tough competition in one of the amputee classes of the high jump in the third International Games for the Disabled this morning at Mitchel Park.

title: The U.N. Today June 25, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CANADA RESTORING RIGHTS OF INDIANS
description: An Indian woman from this Mohawk reservation near Montreal married a white man 46 years ago and as a result was legally barred from living in the house she inherited from her great- grandfather.

title: SCHOOL LIBRARIES AT THE CENTER OF DEBATE ON SOCIETY'S VALUES
description: The subject was ''The Battle Over School Libraries,'' but the discussion at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street the other day ranged from parent-child relations to social norms and morality to human nature.

title: EAST GERMAN CLERIC RECEIVES 'FREEDOM MEDAL' FOR RELIGION
description: Encouraged by his own Government to be here, an East German Protestant bishop received a Franklin D. Roosevelt medal in this Dutch coastal town this weekend.

title: Ned Glass, an Actor, Dies
description: Ned Glass, a character actor whose career covered more than half a century of roles on the stage, screen and television, died June 15 at Encino Hospital after a long illness, a hospital spokesman said Friday. Mr. Glass, who was 75 years old, made regular appearances on the TV series ''Bridget Loves Bernie,'' in 1972-73, and was nominated for an Emmy award in 1969 for his role as Sol Cooper in the comedy series ''Julia.''

title: KIM GALLAGHER RUNS WITH GOAL
description: For 10 days, the best American runners shared the brick-red synthetic track at the Memorial Coliseum, auditioning for a place on the Olympic team. Like the eager young would-be actors and actresses who still come to Hollywood, hoping someday to see their names in lights, it is easy for the athletes to be lost in the crowd - just another pair of pretty spikes.

title: FALLING LUMBER KILLS A WOMAN ON THE EAST SIDE
description: A woman was killed yesterday afternoon when an eight-foot piece of lumber attached to sheet of plywood blew from a midtown tower under construction and struck her on the head, the police said.

title: HOME MEDICAL ALERT SYSTEM
description: The problem struck him while he was shaving one morning in 1973.

title: KITE CAPTURES ATLANTA GOLF BY 5 STROKES
description: Tom Kite shot a front-running five-under- par 67 to score a relatively easy five- stroke victory today in the Georgia- Pacific Atlanta Classic.

title: LONG DISTANCE PHONE BATTLE
description: When historians look back on the war of the long-distance telephone business years hence, they are likely to note the major battle that is being fought here.

title: CREW OF SIX AWAITS TODAY'S FIRST FLIGHT OF SPACE SHUTTLE DISCOVERY
description: The space shuttle Discovery is ready for its first real flight with a crew of six and a cargo of assorted wares, a Navy communications satellite and a large mapping camera, an experimental solar-energy panel, and drug-processing gear that could lead to the first manufacturing in space.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ISSUED BY CATHOLIC THEOLOGIANS
description: Following is the text of a statement issued for publication today by Concilium, an unofficial group of Roman Catholic theologians:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
description: Worst Lines in Memory At the Passport Agency

title: Reader's Digest GettingNew Ad Sales Director
description: Richard F. McLoughlin, who recently returned to the publisher's chair at Reader's Digest, has announced that he is bringing Richard Murray in from the Chicago office to be advertising sales director, replacing Lynn C. Mapes, who was a vice president and is moving up to associate publisher.

title: 3 Other Ad Agencies Win New Assignments
description: In other account news Korey, Kay & Partners in New York, Griswold Inc. in Columbus, Ohio, and Wunderman West in Los Angeles are all welcoming incoming traffic.

title: Patricia Martin Weds Neil Warren Schluger
description: Patricia Martin and Neil Warren Schluger, 1981 graduates of Harvard College and members of the class of '85 at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, were married yesterday in San Juan, P.R. Chief Justice Jose Trias Monge of the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico performed the ceremony at the Caribe Hilton Hotel.

title: CONGRESS REPORT FAULTS PENTAGON ON HONDURAS SITES
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that the Defense Department used Federal funds improperly for much of its large-scale military construction and training activities in Honduras over the last two years.

title: SHULTZ URGES 'ACTIVE' DRIVE ON TERRORISM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that governments opposed to terrorism must do a better job of infiltrating terrorist groups and be willing to take ''appropriate preventive or pre-emptive actions.''

title: The Winning Streak
description: Since losing to Hana Mandlikova last January, Martina Navratilova has been unbeaten. Here is her 1984 record. title: Olympic Soccer Problem
description: Peter Ueberroth, president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, said he has become accustomed to nagging little problems as the Olympic Games approach, but wasn't prepared for the costly one the Rose Bowl provided two weeks ago. A motocross race held at the stadium killed the grass, Ueberroth said, making the site for preliminary soccer games and the final, a barren field of brown dirt.

title: No Headline
description: Olympic Nudge Congressional conferees on the defense authorization bill ought not to overlook a modest amendment approved by the Senate last week on the initiative of New Jersey's Senator Bradley. That's Bill Bradley, Olympic gold medalist in basketball.

title: NO ROOM FOR OLD SOLDIERS ON OMAHA BEACH
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE STEPS TO CHOOSING THE RIGHT JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPOS DEFEAT METS
description: The last six days were a lot like a merry-go-round ride for the Mets. Their fortunes rose and fell, but when they face the Phillies tonight in Philadelphia they will be in virtually the same position they were a week ago.

title: CLARENCE CAMPBELL IS DEAD AT 78;PRESIDENT OF N.H.L. FOR 31 YEARS
description: Clarence Campbell, soldier, Rhodes Scholar, lawyer and president of the National Hockey League from 1946 to his retirement in 1977, died early yesterday at Montreal General Hospital.

title: MONDALE'S 'EASY' DAYS BRING A FRESH AGENDA OF PROBLEMS
description: After the grueling primary campaign, Walter F. Mondale had a right to hope for easeful times once he apparently had enough delegates to secure the Democratic Presidential nomination. But that is not quite the way things are shaping up.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A man was stabbed to death, apparently during a robbery, in a fourth- floor hallway of an apartment building at 1233 White Plains Road in the Soundview section of the Bronx. The man was identified as James Lowery, 53 years old.

title: AFTER MET SEASON, THE MOOD AT BALLET THEATER TURNS HOPEFUL
description: A new and more hopeful mood prevails at the American Ballet Theater after the finish of its eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 16.

title: Detroit Edison
description: The Michigan Public Service Commission said it had granted the Detroit Edison Company an interim rate increase of 8 percent, amounting to $182.9 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: McConkey. 196 pages. Dutton. $13.95. IN 1886, Anton Chekhov, for no

title: DAVID OVERSTREET KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: David Overstreet, the Miami Dolphins' running back who had not yet fulfilled the promise held for him when he became a No. 1 draft pick in 1981, was killed this morning when his car swerved off a highway into gasoline pumps at a service station and exploded.

title: Mosey Is Winner In Monaco Golf
description: Ian Mosey of Britain won his first major European circuit event today when he shot a final-round 63 for a seven- under-par total of 131 in the first Monte Carlo Open golf tournament, reduced because of fog and clouds to 36 holes.

title: GATHERING DEBT DATA FOR BANKS
description: A wily French financial diplomat and a strong-willed West German economic policy-maker are at the helm of a new Washington institution that is starting to make its weight felt in the world debt crisis.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page June 20 about computer cataloguing of Asian books misnamed the New York site of the exhibition ''Words in Motion: Modern Japanese Calligraphy,'' sponsored by the Library of Congress and the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun. It will appear Sept. 27 to Oct. 11 at the World Trade Center. A different exhibition, of Japanese calligraphy from Western collections, will appear Oct. 4 to Jan. 6, 1985, at the Asia Society.

title: OPERA:BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S 'GLORIANA'
description: THERE were times Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, during the New York premiere of Benjamin Britten's ''Gloriana,'' that one felt oneself in the midst of an event - the sudden discovery of a neglected operatic masterpiece. By the end, that ebullience had not quite been sustained; this remains a flawed achievement. But its best moments are still very fine, and the English National Opera did honorably by this most quintessentially English of scores.

title: CONTEMPORARY DANCE:LONDON TROUPE AT DUKE
description: The London Contemporary Dance Theater made its United States debut in 1977 at the American Dance Festival, which was then based at Connecticut College in New London.

title: DEBTS AND REALITY
description: A critical time is at hand for the United States and other industrial countries on a menacing problem: The debts owed to their banks by third world governments. It is the sort of financial problem that many of us resist understanding. But the potential consequences, human and political, are too serious to leave this one to the bankers.

title: CUBAN POET IS SET FREE AFTER 20-YEAR IMPRISONMENT
description: The Cuban Government has released a prominent political dissident who had been imprisoned for more than 20 years.

title: SOME OBSERVATIONS FROM A RINGSIDE SEAT
description: As confidential aide to the Speaker of the House (Sam Rayburn), administrative assistant to the House majority whip (Hale Boggs) and a member of President Johnson's ''Five O'Clock Club,'' which met regularly at the White House to plan campaign strategy, D. B. Hardeman was friend, mentor, tutor, confidant and unofficial adviser to countless Washingtonians.

title: Bank of Japan To Alter Notes
description: The Bank of Japan has announced that it will start circulating new bank notes Nov. 1 to make its money counterfeit-proof. A Bank of Japan official said Friday that the bank would use a special ink to thwart forgers who have adapted sophisticated printing and photocopying techniques in recent years.

title: No Headline
description: Crash of Small Plane In Georgia Kills Five

title: DANCE:A LOWER EAST SIDE FESTIVAL
description: DANCE on the Lower East Side is an organization devoted to just what its name implies. For the past five years, it has offered classes, workshops and performances on the Lower East Side, often in cooperation with other groups in the area. On Friday night at the Harry DeJur Playhouse of the Henry Street Settlement, it presented what it called a Dance on the Lower East Side Festival featuring works by four choreographers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SCIENCE FICTION There are all manner of strange pictures to peer at in the current exhibition at the Society of Illustrators, 128 East 63d Street (838-2560), near where science fiction is represented in reality by subway steps going down to a subway station on a line that doesn't exist.

title: GROWING SAINSBURY MOVES INTO U.S.
description: John James Sainsbury seems to have had the stuff that supermarket legends are made of. In 1869, he opened a tiny dairy store on Drury Lane, with the modest hope that there would be enough shops someday for each of his six sons. The stores soon outnumbered the sons, and Mr. Sainsbury left 170 branches at his death in 1928; a company history says his last words were, ''Keep the shops well lit.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS ARE TALK OF CBS NEWS
description: There was much talk of comings and goings at CBS News this last week, and some of it turned out to be true. For months, as the ratings of ''The CBS Morning News'' slid and the program resumed its once-historic place as the third of the network morning programs, many people prepared to hear of a complete revamping of the program to give CBS a chance to play by its own rules instead of emulating the other networks' formats. At a network that in the last 30 years has had Jack Paar in the morning, Walter Cronkite in the morning and Charles Kuralt in the morning, but has never really won in the morning, this latest permutation on a long pattern of redesign was no shock.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1984 International
description: Federal funds were used improperly in Honduras by the Pentagon for much of its large-scale military construction and training activities there in the last two years, the General Accounting Office said. The G.A.O. report was obtained by Representative Bill Alexander of Arkansas, the chief deputy Democratic whip, who asked the agency for ''a formal legal decision'' five months ago on whether the Pentagon was acting illegally, as he had charged, in its military activities in Honduras, or legally, as the Pentagon claimed. (Page A1, Column 6) Recent theological movements calling for church involvement in politics were defended by a group of Roman Catholics from Europe, Latin America and the United States in a major challenge to the Vatican. (A1:5.)

title: CONVENTION TRIP IS PRIZE FOR RECORD NUMBER OF G.O.P. WOMEN
description: When Republicans gather in Dallas in August to nominate President Reagan for re-election, nearly half the delegates will be women. That is almost double the rate at previous conventions.

title: Outside Nurses Hired To Fill Twin Cities Slots
description: More than 125 nurses from other states have been hired to work at Twin Cities hospitals where registered nurses are on strike, according to the Minnesota Board of Nursing.

title: Audrey Walker Wed To Peter W. Kaplan
description: Audrey Mary Walker, a daughter of Joseph A. Walker of New York and Audrey L. Walker of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter W. Kaplan. Family Court Judge Benjamin Cohen, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kaplan, parents of the bridegroom, in South Orange, N.J.

title: VIRGIL OF PHILLIES EARNING RESPECT
description: IF he had been playing for the

title: DESPITE CONTINENTAL, CONTINUE DEREGULATION
description: Shaken by the run on Continental Illinois, Congress is fashioning its long- term response. Yet, in its effort to buttress bank safety, Congress is moving toward a regulatory philosophy that could exacerbate the risks already built into the banking system.

title: No Headline
description: Archbishop Contends Abortion Is Key Issue

title: Leading Filipino Lawyer Quits Aquino Inquiry
description: The president of a Philippine lawyers' organization has withdrawn from the investigation of the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., a rival of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: MANAGER PROMOTED AT DREYFUS FUND
description: Thomas R. Jackson, who was elected president of the Dreyfus Fund on Friday, considers himself an against-the-trend manager. ''I become interested in a stock when other investors tend to exit the game,'' said the 39-year-old executive.

title: Unitarian Delegates Plan Protest on Farm Labor
description: Delegates to the Unitarian Universalist Association meeting this week at Ohio State University will not be eating any products produced by the Campbell Soup Company.

title: MCENROE ELECTED
description: John McEnroe has been appointed to the board of the players' union, the Association of Tennis Professionals. McEnroe, seeded No. 1 and the defending champion at the All-England championships beginning Monday, was elected to the 10- member board by the players. Among his responsibilites will be to represent other professional players on matters ranging from conduct and complaints to tournament rules and facilities.

title: LEADERSHIP OF D.D.B. REALIGNED
description: LAST year Doyle Dane Bernbach

title: 10 Hurt in Crash; Mail Driver Cited
description: The driver of a United States mail truck was charged with careless driving today after his tractor-trailer slammed into a disabled bus on the New Jersey Turnpike, the state police said.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL'S POWER TO BAR SPECIAL COUNSEL UPHELD IN COURT
description: The Federal appeals court here ruled unanimously today that no court had power to order appointment of an independent counsel over the objection of the Attorney General.

title: LONDON HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
; Shearson Tombstones Given to Albert Frank
description: In a shoot-out between Albert Frank-Guenther Law and Doremus & Company, Wall Street's best-known agencies, Albert Frank, the smaller, has walked off with the tombstone advertising account of the recently merged Shearson Lehman/American Express. Billings are expected to be in the $6 million-$8 million range.

title: Chase Denies Loan Offer
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had made no offer of a loan to the Government of Colombia. ''We said we have had a long and positive history of supporting both the public and private sectors in Colombia, but talks are still continuing regarding financing needs,'' said a spokesman, who asked not to be identified. Yesterday, Colombia's Finance Minister, Edgardo Gutierrez, who said on Friday that Colombia had been offered a $700 million loan by Chase, said in London that Chase has only ''indicated'' to Colombia that it may attempt to arrange such a loan.

title: 6% AND 9% RISES APPROVED IN STABILIZED RENTS
