description: The basic rent for about 350,000 rent- stabilized apartments in New York City will rise by up to 9 percent under regulations adopted yesterday by the Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Germans See End to Strike
description: Arbitrators in the seven-week-old strike for a 35-hour workweek said today that they had struck a compromise that would probably end the worst industrial conflict in West Germany's history.

title: Morgan Sets Home Run Mark
description: Joe Morgan, who achieved a longtime goal on Sunday with his 265th home run as a second baseman, thinks the major league record he took away from Rogers Hornsby will remain in his possession for a long time.

title: The Tax Increase of '84
description: If anyone still doubts that America's tax code needs a fundamental reform, let him look at the 1984 tax bill. Driven by the simple objective of raising a badly needed $50 billion of revenue, Senate and House conferees have hatched a package that closes loopholes and opens new ones, postpones some tax cuts, raises some taxes and lowers others. For the second time in three years, the code has been made maddeningly more complex.

title: Chess: Karpov Captures First Place In Oslo Centenary Tourney
description: The Oslo Centenary Tournament in Norway, celebrating the founding of the city's chess federation in February 1884, was won by Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union. The world champion scored 6-3 to surpass by a half- point his nearest rivals, the grandmasters Tony Miles of Britain and Sergei Makarichev of the Soviet Union. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Karpov3066Miles4235 1/2Makarichev3155 1/2Adorjan0094 1/2Agdestein3334 1/2de Firmian2254 1/2Huebner0184Wedberg1353 1/2Arnason1353 1/2Hort0273 1/2

title: HART WITHDRAWS THREAT TO FIGHT RIVAL'S DELEGATE
description: Senator Gary Hart today withdrew his threat to challenge several hundred national convention delegates pledged to Walter F. Mondale and agreed to meet with Mr. Mondale on Tuesday.

title: The U.N. Today June 26, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A PHILANTHROPIST FINDS 'GIVING IS HARD WORK'
description: ''It's easier to make $100 million than to give it away,'' says Edwin C. Whitehead, who has done both.

title: 5 HITS BY WINFIELD HELP DOWN TIGERS
description: The mighty Tigers met the mighty Dave Winfield last night at Yankee Stadium and Winfield won out. The final score went Yankees 7, Tigers 3, with an addendum for Winfield: four singles, one double, four runs batted in, and one head-first slide for home. Simply, the hitter with the best batting percentage in the American league dominated the team with the best winning percentage.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ONLY PROBLEM. By Muriel Spark. 179 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: State Reported to Seek New Judge in Sect Case
description: State lawyers who organized the raid on a northeastern Vermont religious sect Friday filed a motion in Vermont District Court in Newport today asking that Judge Frank Mahady be disqualified in the case, according to sources who asked not to be identified.

title: Presidential Library Bill Gains
description: The House today approved legislation to require private interests to share the cost of operating Presidential libraries, an expense that has soared more than 12 times beyond original estimates.

title: CIRCULATION AUDIT PUTS USA TODAY IN 3D PLACE
description: The long-awaited first audit of USA Today by the Audit Bureau of Circulations has confirmed that the colorful national newspaper, started by the Gannett Company in 1982, is the nation's third-largest daily newspaper behind The Wall Street Journal and The Daily News.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL MAY BRING END TO LONG WAIT OF BOAT PEOPLE
description: For more than four years, thousands of Cubans and Haitians here have been anxiously awaiting a decision by the United States Government on whether they can stay in this country.

title: 9 INDICTED IN SALE OF 'MINISTRIES' FOR TAX SCHEME
description: A Federal indictment charged nine defendants yesterday with a tax-evasion scheme that involved selling ''ministries'' in the Life Science Church to thousands of people, including many police officers in New York City.

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $59,000.

title: Creusot Ruling Put Off
description: The Paris commercial court announced today that it had postponed until Thursday a ruling on an application by Creusot-Loire, a heavy-engineering group, to go into receivership. The ruling had been scheduled for today. The court said the postponement had been requested by the company.

title: GOLDEN TEMPLE IN PUNJAB IS REOPENED
description: The inner sanctuary of the Golden Temple in Amritsar was opened to the public today for the first time since the Indian Army raided the complex three weeks ago in an attempt to crush a two-year-old Sikh terrorist movement in Punjab.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for 12 wks to June 3
Photo Accord
description: Reuters and United Press International have signed a photograph-exchange agreement that will enable Reuters to begin a full news picture service outside the United States in January 1985, the two companies said today.

title: COURT UPHOLDS REAGAN ON AIR STANDARD
description: The Supreme Court today reinstated a key aspect of the Environmental Protection Agency's ''bubble'' policy for determining if industries are meeting air-quality standards.

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the quarter and $1,039,000 for the year.

title: Home Sales Off in May
description: Resales of single-family houses declined 1.3 percent in May, to an annual rate of 3.05 million houses, after rising for five months, the National Association of Realtors said. Rising interest rates were blamed.

title: BASS:WHY IS HUDSON SO IMPORTANT?
description: WHY does the

title: CORPORATE BOARD ROOMS ARE NOT FOR MERE 'CONSENSUS-MAKING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Piedmont Planes
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc. of Winston-Salem, N.C., has exercised its option to buy eight more F-28 MK- 1000 Fanjet aircraft, according to Fokker, the private Dutch aircraft maker.

title: Thriftimart Shares
description: Casino USA said it had acquired the 8.3 percent stake in the Class A shares of Thriftimart Inc. owned by Michael Forman and James Cotter.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 10 wks to May 26
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,340,000 for the ten weeks and twenty-five weeks. c-Including tax credits of $656,000 for the ten weeks and $6,920,000 for the twenty-five weeks.

title: Weinberger Rebuts Charges He Misused Honduras Funds
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today rebutted charges in a report by the General Accounting Office that the Defense Department had improperly used funds for military activities in Honduras.

title: FOR SPAIN AND FOR 'FELIPE,' THE CLOUDS TAKE OVER
description: When the Socialists took office in late 1982 they were young, idealistic, charismatic. Felipe Gonzalez, the Prime Minister, a man with a mischievous grin who looked more at home in a wrinkled leather jacket than a business suit, seemed a mixture of James Dean and John F. Kennedy.

title: MICHEL FOUCAULT, FRENCH HISTORIAN
description: Michel Foucault, one of France's most prominent philosophers and historians, whose writings explored society's reaction to deviants, died yesterday in the Pitie-Salpetriere Hospital in Paris. He was 57 years old.

title: RESTRICTIONS ON HOUSE BARGES WEIGHED ON L.I. SOUTH SHORE
description: When Florence and Henry McGann's children were grown, the couple sold their suburban ranch house, bought a two-story saltbox on a concrete barge and moored the floating home at the South Seas Marina here.

title: Sundance Oil Chief Leaves
description: The Sundance Oil Company said today that Caswell Silver, who recently sold his family's holdings in the company, had stepped down as its chairman, president and chief executive officer.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
SENATORS, 88-1, DROP MONEY TO AID NICARUGUA REBELS
description: The Senate voted 88 to 1 today to delete aid to Nicaraguan rebels from an emergency spending bill to clear the way for $100 million for summer youth jobs.

title: Part of Building Collapses on 2d St.
description: United Press International

title: Koch Aide Studies Animal Control
description: A mayoral aide said yesterday that he was exploring alternatives to using the A.S.P.C.A. to collect stray animals.

title: DOUGHERTY BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BEATRICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PLAN URGES BROADER SCOPE IN JOURNALISM
description: STUDENTS of journalism and mass communications should get more and better undergraduate training in the liberal arts and less work in vocational skills, according to a model curriculum being proposed after a two-year survey.

title: Continental Bank Aid Voted
description: The Illinois General Assembly today completed emergency action on a bill that would allow the troubled Continental Illinois Bank to merge with an out-of-state institution. Gov. James Thompson said after the Legislature's lower house voted 95 to 14 for the change that he would sign the bill quickly. The State Senate passed a similar measure 11 days ago by a 51 to 4 vote.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 26, 1984 International
description: Dwindling support for aid to Nicaraguan rebels was evident in the Senate. The Republican-controlled body voted, 88 to 1, to strike out $21 million in aid to the rebels from an emergency spending bill to clear the way for providing $100 million for summer youth jobs. In the face of the Senate action, President Reagan is expected to sign the bill. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Nicaragua's draft is widely opposed. Groups of mothers have protested that their sons have been indiscriminately conscripted since the draft took effect in January and have been cut off from contact with their families and sent to battle without proper training. Interviews conducted in six Nicaraguan provinces over the last two weeks suggest that draft evasion is widespread. (A1:4-5.)

title: OLYMPIC SHOW STILL GOLD MEDAL DRAMA
description: Art Aragon, running stride for symphonic stride

title: 3 CENSURED BY S.E.C. FOR AUDITS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, sending a signal to the accounting profession, today censured three partners of a North Carolina firm that the agency said had knowingly issued questionable auditing reports.

title: Bridge: High Winds in Vermont Get PT
description: High winds are a nuisance to athletes, golfers and tennis players, but they rarely affect bridge games. They did so Sunday, however, at a regional tournament in Jeffersonville, Vt.

title: THE MAKING OF 'JESSE OWENS'
description: Television producers always complain about time pressures, but they rarely have as inexorable a deadline as the one that confronted the makers of ''The Jesse Owens Story,'' a four- hour miniseries about the black Olympic track star of the 1930's. The show has its premiere on 130 independent stations around the country the week of July 8. The first of two parts can be seen in New York on Channel 11, Monday night, July 9, at 8 P.M.

title: 172 Call Boxes Lose Power in Manhattan
description: Emergency call boxes in Harlem, Inwood and Washington Heights were disconnected by a power failure at 7:55 P.M. yesterday, the Fire Department reported.

title: CMC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TRACK JOY SHARED WITH BLIND
description: Carl Simon remembers being a hot-shot high school track star who figured he knew everything there was to know about a 400-meter race. Blessed with a Herschel Walker-like body and the confidence of youth, he figured that ability could overcome whatever experience denied.

title: MACKENZIE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 26, 1984

title: Boosting the Bronx
description: The Bronx suffers from a cultural

title: 4 Family Members Die in Jersey Fire
description: A mother and three children were killed today in a predawn fire that engulfed their home, authorities said. Four other people were injured, three of them seriously.

title: CONVENTION CENTER OFFICIAL IS ASSAILED
description: The chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation told the president of the New York City Convention Center yesterday that he was dissatisfied with his performance and warned him to make changes within 30 days or face possible dismissal.

title: DOCUMENTARY ON MIAMI
description: ''A DIFFERENT MIAMI'' finds that Miami is changing. The finding is not exceptional and certainly it is not brand-new. On the other hand, ''A Different Miami'' makes the finding with intelligence and sensitivity, and, most surprisingly in a documentary like this, a certain amount of charm. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Allegheny International Inc. , has changed terms of its offer to exchange $25 principal amount of new subordinated sinking fund debentures, due 2002, for each share of the $2.19 cumulative preference stock to an annual rate of 10.4 percent from 10 percent.

title: Bird Gets M.V.P. Award
description: Larry Bird, who led the Boston Celtics to their 15th National Basketball Association title, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday. In balloting by 76 reporters and broadcasters, the 27-year-old forward received 52 first-place votes and 652 points.

title: 27 German Protesters Held
description: The police arrested 27 antimissile protesters who blockaded gates to a United States missile base here on Sunday. In another demonstration Sunday, 400 people waving banners and shouting slogans protested against the annual military air show at the Ramstein Air Base.

title: HE'LL BE ANOTHER STENGEL
description: ''We've never lost a lead after the seventh inning,'' Sparky Anderson was saying, looking up from his waffle at breakfast. ''We're 40 and 0 in that situation - 40 and 0. A manager gets smart real quick when that happens. Last year we had 28 saves all year; this year we've already got 25 saves. We're leading the league in saves.''

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SCOTTIE WAS BORN TO BE THE TOP DOG
description: The designation has occurred enough times, in enough places, to become part of a routine. A judge makes a decision that so many others

title: Gloom Marks E.E.C. Talks
description: The leaders of the European Common Market countries met yesterday at a semiannual summit meeting, still discussing the deadlocked issue of British budget contributions that has brought development of the Common Market to a near standstill.

title: Market Drifts as Trading Declines
description: Crosscurrents of good and bad news held the stock market to a day of drifting yesterday. The good news included the likely reduction in long- term capital gains withholding while the bad news included a rise in the prime rate, to 13 percent.

title: NewDrivetoFight Times Sq. Crime
description: A successful drive against crime in Times Square last summer will be resumed this summer but on a smaller scale, authorities said yesterday.

title: SEEK IRAN-IRAQ PEACE
description: The Reagan Administration is edging ever closer to policies that are likely to widen the Iran-Iraq war. This is a serious mistake. True, no government seems ready or able to halt this war. But there is no need for the United States to become militarily engaged in it. Indeed, by reducing its military involvement, the United States could help end the war and better serve its interests.

title: KEEPING DOORS OPEN
description: Homosexuality continues to be a tense and nervous subject in our society.

title: SIPE GETS MORE THAN ENOUGH
description: All Brian Sipe wanted, and had

title: World Record Is Set in Breast-Stroke
description: John Moffet had beaten Steve Lundquist before in 100-meter breast-stroke races, but never in a major meet. Tonight, in his first important victory over Lundquist at this distance, Moffet broke Lundquist's world record. Lundquist also broke it as both made the United States Olympic swimming team.

title: BUT IS IT WRITING?
description: NEXT to games, the use for home computers most touted is probably word processing. Oh, there are numerous software firms pushing educational packages, which for the most part turn out to be games with an educational twist, and home management programs, those pie-in-the- sky promises of personal money management, or, say, computerized cooking supervision in the form of electronically stored recipes and automatic portion-controlled formulas that end up being far more trouble to use than they are worth. It is not that these programs do not sell. They do. But so did the citizens band radios and pet rocks that now inhabit the remoter corners of hall closets and the cartons of technological refuse piling up in basements.

title: FATAL ACCIDENT SPURS A CHECK OF RAILINGS AT CONSTRUCTION SITES
description: New York City's Buildings Commissioner said yesterday that his department would re-examine all temporary wood railings on tall buildings under construction. A Manhattan woman was killed Sunday when she was struck by a piece of plywood used for such a railing.

title: Semiconductor Sues Pentagon
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation is seeking an injunction against the Department of Defense, contending that a potential three- year Pentagon ban on business with the company was not part of the deal when it pleaded guilty to mail fraud and making false statements.

title: HEINZ, H.J. CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 23, 1983.

title: MILITARY DRAFT IN NICARAGUA IS MEETING WIDE RESISTANCE
description: At a high school here two weeks ago, pandemonium erupted as word spread through classrooms that Sandinista military recruiters were in the building.

title: TAYLOR, PETERSON DOUBLE BILL
description: SOME 25 years after he first made an impact, the pianist Cecil Taylor can still drive some jazz fans to boo and walk out. By the time he finished a fine solo set Sunday in Carnegie Hall, following the pianist Oscar Peterson and his trio, more than half of the audience had left.

title: F.A.A. Says Student Pilot Flew Plane That Crashed
description: The pilot of a small plane that crashed in northwest Georgia early Sunday, killing all five people aboard, had only a student's license that did not permit him to take up other people, a Federal official said yesterday.

title: PROMOTING JOBS FOR YOUTH
description: The persistently high level of youth unemployment has elicited two kinds of responses: those that sing the praises of a subminimum wage for youth, and those calling for a federally funded comprehensive youth employment program. Only a full program will cope with the complexity of the problem.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Pan Am Planes
description: Pan American World Airways said it had agreed to sell its nine remaining Boeing 727-100's to the Intercredit Corporation, a unit of Flight International Group Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Pan Am, which operated as many as 31 of the 727-100's at one time, has in recent years been phasing out the model and replacing it with more efficient aircraft. The nine 727-100's will be delivered by the end of the year to Intercredit, which earlier this year bought three 727- 100's from Pan Am.

title: SNOOPY IN DESIGNER CLOTHES
description: -MARIE SCHIRO

title: Ore Train in Wales Stops For Miners' Picket Line
description: A train loaded with iron ore stopped at a coal miners' picket line at a steel plant in southern Wales today as the British coal strike entered its 16th week.

title: MORE THAN THE DEEDS OF 'ERRING YOUTHS'
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan Opinion in Europe

title: Block Returns to Work
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, who suffered an ulcer attack June 19, returned to his office today but will work a reduced schedule for a few days, a spokesman said. Mr. Block had been hospitalized for what was described as a bleeding ulcer. He was released from the hospital Sunday, the spokesman said.

title: CONNECTICUT TO INVESTIGATE BRIDGE INSPECTION PROGRAM
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that allegations of falsified reports, wasted time and lax supervision in Connecticut's bridge inspection program would be ''investigated fully.''

title: WEST'S LEADERS BRIEFED BY MITTERRAND ON SOVIET
description: President Francois Mitterrand today discussed his Soviet trip with the nine other leaders of the European Economic Community, reportedly saying that his talks with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, were candid, open and marked by ''the obvious differences.''

title: RCA Satellite Deal
description: The RCA Corporation said its RCA Electronics unit had signed a contract to design and build two high-powered, direct-to-home broadcast satellites for the United States Satellite Broadcasting Company. It said the contract, with equipment options, had the potential of producing revenues of more than $160 millin. RCA said the satellites, operating at up to 240 watts a channel, are intended to provide a diverse selection of entertainment, sports, education and public affairs programs.

title: 'Lucky Break' Helped Florida Find Fruit Fly
description: A woman found a Mediterranean fruit fly larva in an orange tree where the pests were first seen last week, in a ''lucky break'' that helped pinpoint the infestation, officials said.

title: 3-D IMAGES OF LIVE CELLS
description: SCIENTISTS at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology report that they have developed the first electronic microscope system that enables them to observe three-dimensional images of changes within living cells.

title: City Union Chief Urges 10% Raises
description: The city can afford to give its 200,000 nonuniformed workers a 10 percent salary raise in the next fiscal year and a similar increase the following year, Barry Feinstein, president of the teamsters' local, said after a negotiating session yesterday.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $31,663 for the quarter and year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $66,940 for the quarter and $81,861 for the year.

title: Argentine Ex-President Held in 'Dirty War' Case
description: Former President Roberto Viola was arrested today in connection with the disappearance and presumed death of a scientist in 1978.

title: U.S.-NICARAGUA TALKS REPORTED TO OPEN IN MEXICO
description: Representatives of the United States and Nicaragua met under tight security today in the Mexican Pacific resort of Manzanillo, according to diplomats in the region.

title: BILL ON TOXIC INJURY SUITS REJECTED
description: Republicans in the State Senate today rejected legislation giving past victims of toxic poisoning broad rights to go to court and collect damages for injuries and death.

title: Imelda Marcos Set to Testify For Panel on Death of Aquino
description: Imelda R. Marcos, wife of the Philippine President, is scheduled to testify before an investigative commission Friday about why she warned the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. against returning to the country.

title: Dole Warning On Gains Tax
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, warned the securities industry today that, if the cut in the capital gains holding period from one year to six months resulted in a significant revenue loss, Congress would probably return to the one-year period.

title: JAZZ PICNIC TOASTS WHITEMAN
description: THE Jazz Picnic at Waterloo Village sponsored by the New Jersey Jazz Society, which has become an annual event of the Kool Jazz Festival, presented its customary assortment of small jazz groups and soloists during its eight-hour performance on Sunday afternoon and evening.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
BONN BARS ITS EAST BERLIN MISSION TO EAST GERMANS TRYING TO LEAVE
description: The West German Government effectively closed its diplomatic mission in East Berlin today to East Germans seeking refuge and emigration to the West.

title: REAGAN SPEAKS OF HIS 'VIGOR AND VISION' ON RIGHTS
description: President Reagan today asserted that he had pursued a Federal equal rights policy with ''vigor and vision,'' but that critics had clouded his record with demagoguery.

title: Continental Executive In Conticommodity Post
description: Walter Goldschmidt yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of Conticommodity Services Inc., the trading arm of the giant Continental Grain Company, which is privately owned.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Coe to Run 1,500
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, who holds three world records, was selected to defend his Olympic 1,500-meter title at Los Angeles despite losing at the distance in the final British Olympic trials. Both Coe and Steve Ovett , the 800-meter gold medalist at the 1980 Olympics, will run both the 800 and 1,500 meters for the British team.

title: Fuel Contracts
description: The Hess Oil Virgin Islands Corporation received a $208 million contract for naval and jet fuel, the Defense Department said. In addition, a unit of the Exxon Corporation got a jet-fuel order of $126.6 million and the Steuart Petroleum Company received an order of $101.8 million.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON WIDER POWER FOR PROSECUTORS
description: Prosecutors would be given broad new power to seize airplanes, boats, cars or other property used to commit crimes such as drug dealing, under an agreement reported today by Governor Cuomo's staff and key legislators.

title: UTILITIES' CHAPTER 11 PROSPECTS
description: In Michigan, a major utility is warning its opponents that, if they do not drop their opposition to its nuclear plants, it will declare bankruptcy. In New York, Governor Cuomo is threatening to let the Long Island Lighting Company go bankrupt if it refuses to cancel its reactor.

title: Internorth Files For Debt Offering
description: Internorth Inc. said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the possible offering of up to $300 million of debt securities.

title: The Great Subway Debate
description: For graffiti messages approaching

title: Chase Provides Lincoln First Data
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said it and Lincoln First Banks Inc. had made a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, providing details of Chase's Series F preferred stock to be issued in connection with its acquisition of Lincoln First.

title: Tandy Expects Earnings to Drop
description: The Tandy Corporation, citing ''disappointing sales,'' said it expects to report an earnings decline for its fiscal fourth quarter. Officials of Tandy, a retailer of consumer electronics, said earnings for the quarter, ending Saturday, are expected to range from 60 cents to 65 cents a share, down from 71 cents in the year-earlier quarter.

title: AIDE CALLS HART RIGHT FOR NO. 2 SPOT
description: The chairman of Gary Hart's Presidential campaign, conceding that the Senator had given up one of the main tools he hoped to use to pry delegates loose from Walter F. Mondale, today hailed the Colorado Democrat as prime Vice- Presidential material.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $800,000 realized from a life insurance policy carried on a company officer.

title: No Headline
description: Nations Aiding Israel Assailed as 'Criminal'

title: ; Chiat Wins at Cannes For '1984' Apple Spot
description: Despair no more, oh ye of little faith. The nation's advertising creativity is not as dead as a dodo. Chiat/ Day won the Grand Prix at the 31st annual International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France, over the weekend - the first such win for an American agency in five years.

title: PUBLICITY ABOUT AIRLINE INCIDENT LEADS TO CRUCIAL DIAGNOSIS
description: SAN FRANCISCO ONE day after Kim Wah Chan flew here on a visit from London last March, he developed severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. Doctors at San Francisco General Hospital rushed him to the operating room because tests indicated his life was being threatened by a condition called small bowel obstruction.

title: U.S. CAR SALES RISE BY 12.4%
description: Sales of new American-made cars in the mid-June period increased 12.4 percent over last year, auto makers reported here today. The increase was based on average daily sales, which were at the highest level for the period since 1978.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Dart Drug Corp. of Landover, Md., said its board had approved the previously announced agreement to sell the company's drug store division to a management group for about $160 million.

title: JOHNNY O'NEAL PIANO CONCERT
description: JOHNNY O'NEAL, a young Detroit pianist who used to work with Art Blakey, is a talented romantic traditionalist whose playing clearly reflects the influences of Errol Garner and Art Tatum. In his solo concert in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday, Mr. O'Neal concentrated on richly harmonized, rhythmically propulsive renditions of standards such as ''Little Girl Blue,'' ''Love for Sale'' and ''How Long Has This Been Going On?''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Pritzkers Agree to Buy Midland-Ross Shares

title: Calm McEnroe Wins at Wimbledon
description: In an atmosphere of relative calm, with his only nasty words directed at selected members of the British press, John McEnroe began the defense of his Wimbledon title today with a Centre Court victory over the Australian Paul McNamee.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CITY BALLET:OVATIONS AT THE END
description: THE New York City Ballet closed its season Sunday night at the State Theater with a loyal audience calling the principal dancers out before the curtain for repeatedly long ovations after each ballet.

title: PLAN TO AID MINORITY COMPANIES IS CALLED A FAILURE
description: After a yearlong inquiry, the State Commission of Investigation yesterday branded as a failure a program designed to help minority-controlled construction companies get a larger share of the $10 billion awarded annually for public projects in New York State.

title: CGA COMPUTER reports earnings for Year to April 30
Adviser Resigns
description: Alan Beals, for six years an academic counselor to student-athletes who played football for Coach Johnny Majors at Tennessee, has submitted his resignation effective Aug. 1.

title: Chock Full To End Bid, Add Official
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation yesterday abruptly withdrew an offer to acquire the financially troubled Chase & Sanborn Corporation, clearing the way for Hills Brothers Coffee to acquire Chase & Sanborn. But Chock Full o'Nuts then said that once Chase's assets are sold, Arthur R. Berman, Chase's president and chief executive, would join Chock Full o'Nuts as president and chief operating officer.

title: Market Place; Growth Issues: A Bullish View
description: CHARLES ALLMON publishes a pair of investment advisory reports, Growth Stock Outlook and Junior Growth Stocks, in Chevy Chase, Md., and also runs $116 million in managed accounts for clients. As a long-time student of growth stocks, he took a look at the market in May 1983 and did not like the speculative froth and high price-earnings multiples he saw there.

title: Beatrice Profits Decline 5.2%
description: The Beatrice Companies, a leading food and consumer products concern, said today that its first-quarter profits fell 5.2 percent from a year ago, primarily because it sold several businesses in a realignment begun last year.

title: LEBANESE ARMY GETS NEW CHIEF
description: The new commander of the Lebanese Army, Maj. Gen. Michel Aoun, was sworn in today, and he presided over a meeting of the new six-man military council during which a plan to end fighting in Beirut was discussed.

title: BILL PASSED TO DEREGULATE STATE BANKS
description: A major banking-deregulation bill was given final approval by the Assembly tonight.

title: Duva Fined $2,500
description: As had been expected, Lou Duva , co-manager of Johnny Bumphus , was fined $2,500 and placed on a one-year probation by the State Athletic Commission yesterday for jumping into the ring and pursuing the referee the ring and pursuing the referee to protest his boxer's loss to Gene Buffalo. The incident took place after the referee, John Lobianco , had stopped the title fight in the 10th round.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income income.

title: Essex County Sues on Tax
description: An Essex County, N.J., official yesterday filed a lawsuit in the Federal District Court in Newark to overturn a Federal law that could indirectly tax interest paid on municipal bonds held by Social Security recipients.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Thursday on a dispute between the Mayor of San Diego and San Diego newspapers misstated the reason for the imprisonment of J. David Dominelli, a San Diego financier. Mr. Dominelli, who is accused of fraud, is being held on contempt charges for refusal to give data about his company to bankruptcy court officials.

title: PRINTERS TO PICK UNION PRESIDENT
description: The International Typographical Union has mailed ballots to 74,000 members and retirees in a leadership election that may set a new course for the nation's oldest labor union.

title: The Tax Increase of '85
description: Though important, the tax increase of '84 only points the way back toward reality. After the radical Reagan tax cuts and defense spending increases, the stability of the American economy - and of the world's, for that matter - depends on ever greater reductions in the looming Federal deficits. And any plausible reduction must include another round of larger tax increases.

title: LIFESAVING YOUNG AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying Again
description: ''Don't get mad. Get football!'' is the message on the cover of a brochure that is being circulated by the Baltimore Football Associates, a nonprofit corporation whose goal, according to Robert G. Merrick, the president, ''is to facilitate Baltimore's re-entry into the National Football League.''

title: ADIEU 'GOLD' HAMMERS
description: For months, the American people have been told that their tax dollars have been spent to buy ''gold-plated'' parts for weapons systems. But there are two parts to the story. The first is that for decades the Defense Department's spare- parts procurement has indeed involved cost overruns and waste - in some instances, the prices paid were outrageous. The second is that the Reagan Administration has taken aggressive steps to correct the problem. The media have thoroughly reported part one but have given short shrift to part two. It is time the public got the whole story.

title: The Politics of Heat
description: Some politicians can make hay out

title: Newark Faulted On School Guards
description: Tighter policies on hiring and arming school security guards are needed in the Newark system, where 38 guards have criminal records, the State Investigation Commission said today.

title: HUNT FOR OIL TREASURE SETS OFF TUG OF WAR OVER A BARREN ISLAND OFF ALASKA
description: A barren, forbidding island in the Bering Sea has become a pawn in a national energy chess game being fought by environmentalists, oil companies and Alaska natives.

title: HOW A SOVIET SECRET WAS FINALLY PIERCED
description: ABOUT three years ago a kind of obsession began to take hold of Dr. Mark M. Kuchment, a 48-year-old science historian who emigrated to this country in 1975 from the Soviet Union.

title: SOVIET'S FLEET, HURT BY BLAST, MAY LIE LOW
description: A preliminary study of evidence on the devastating explosion in May at the Soviet Union's ice-free Severomorsk naval base near Murmansk suggests to intelligence analysts that operations of the Northern Fleet will be hampered for some time and that the scale of scheduled fleet exercises may have to be curtailed. There is evidence that the accident cost the Northern Fleet, the strongest of the four fleets in the Soviet Navy, a substantial portion of its stockpiles of surface-to-air missiles and antiship missiles. It was felt that at least six weeks would be required for transfer of replacement supplies.

title: Cubs Lose Durham
description: The Chicago Cubs got some bad news yesterday in their struggle to remain close to the top of the National League's Eastern Division: Leon Durham, who has blossomed this year into one of the league's top sluggers and is their leading run producer, is badly enough injured that he will be out until after the break for the All-Star Game on July 10. Durham hurt his right shoulder sliding second base in the 11th inning of Saturday's 12-11 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and will not even be able to swing a bat for perhaps 10 days. His loss takes from the Cubs a .308 batter who has 12 homers and 52 runs batted in, with the season still well short of the halfway mark.

title: JUSTICES DECLARE ILLEGAL ALIENS ARE PROTECTED BY LABOR LAW
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that illegal aliens are entitled to the protections of Federal labor law.

title: Group Is Seeking Control of Dorsey
description: An investment group led by Shamrock Associates told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to seek a majority on the board of the Dorsey Corporation, a maker of plastic containers and highway trailers based in Chattanooga, Tenn. The group said it intended to request a list of shareholders from Dorsey but ''has not finally determined'' if it would submit proxy solicitation materials to the S.E.C.

title: SUBPOEAED OFFICIAL AIDE ASSAILS PENTAGON ON HIGH MILITARY COSTS
description: A senior Air Force official, a noted Pentagon ''whistle-blower,'' told the Senate today that ''bad management has shot down more airplanes, sunk more ships and immobilized more soldiers than all our enemies in history put together.'' He also expressed a belief that there were few major military contracts in which less than 30 percent of the outlay was wasted.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Poll in Michigan Finds Majority Prefer Reagan
description: A majority of Michigan residents prefer President Reagan over Walter F. Mondale in the Presidential race, according to a newspaper's poll.

title: THEATER AND MOVIE DIRECTOR
description: William Keighley, who directed dozens of Hollywood films, including ''The Prince and the Pauper,'' 'Green Pastures'' and ''The Man Who Came to Dinner,'' and who was the host of the Lux Radio Theater, died of a stroke Sunday. He was 94 years old.

title: U.S. Threatens to Cut Off Aid To U.N.'s Population Agency
description: The United States said today that it would cut off millions of dollars in aid to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities unless the agency guarantees the money is not used for programs subsidizing or advocating abortion.

title: Team
description: Arizona 25,568

title: MORE THAN THE DEEDS OF 'ERRING YOUTHS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mine Toll at 47 in Taiwan
description: The death toll in a coal-mine explosion near Taipei climbed to 47 today.

title: Swiss Economic Gain
description: Switzerland's gross domestic product rose 2.9 percent in the first quarter from the period a year ago, after adjusting for inflation, the Federal Statistics Office said today. It said that investments and foreign trade gave the economy its biggest boost while consumer demand trailed.

title: Penn Central Offers To Buy Back Stock
description: The Penn Central Corporation said today that its board had approved an offer to buy up to five million shares of its common stock at $47 a share.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PIRATES SNAP CLUB STREAK, 3-0
description: Bill Madlock slugged a pair of home runs, and Jose DeLeon hurled a four-hitter today to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3-0 victory over Chicago, snapping a three-game Cub winning streak.

title: PRESIDENT IS CRITICAL
description: The nation's major banks increased their prime lending rate to 13 percent yesterday, from 12 1/2 percent.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Saturday misattributed the announcement of a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning Florida Gulf Realty Trust. The announcement was by an investment group.

title: ALBERT E. TRIESCHMAN
description: Dr. Albert E. Trieschman, a psychologist who specialized in the treatment of emotionally disturbed children, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 52 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Indonesia Landslides Kill 11
description: Landslides resulting from heavy rains have killed 11 people on the island of Amboina in eastern Indonesia in the last week, a Social Affairs Ministry spokesman said today. Eleven other people are missing on the island, the spokesman said.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events. 5 P.M. Carnegie Recital Hall. Terry Waldo, piano;. $8.50. 7 P.M. Carnegie Hall.

title: KENNEDY WARMLY ENDORSES MONDALE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy warmly endorsed Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy today after successfully arranging a meeting Tuesday morning between Mr. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart.

title: CONFEREES SEEKING AN ACCORD ON MILITARY SPENDING RANGE
description: As one of the last moves in assembling a deficit reduction package this year, the House and the Senate are attempting to work out an agreement on military spending that would set a range on what could be spent.

title: Accounts
description: * Lou Scharf Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., to Beber Silverstein & Partners for Old Tyme Ginger Beer.

title: L.I. Man Arrested In Foot-Ticklings
description: A 20-year-old man who the police say climbed into second-story windows at night to tickle young women's feet and steal their shoes has been arrested and charged with burglary.

title: DIOXIN TRIAL OPENS AGAINST MONSANTO
description: Opening arguments began today in Federal District Court in the cases of seven men who say they suffer long- term health problems as a result of exposure to dioxin and other toxic chemicals while working for the Monsanto Company.

title: Inquiry on Lennon Disclosed
description: The Central Intelligence Agency joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation in gathering intelligence on John Lennon because the agencies feared he would disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention, according to a historian who has written about Mr. Lennon.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: b-Including a tax credit of $6.5 million. c-Including nonrecurring income of $22.2 million from the exchange of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. shares for shares of Corning Glass Works.

title: BIG TELECOMMUNICATIONS TRADE GAP SEEN
description: Through the breakup of the American telephone monopoly and other moves toward deregulation, the United States is opening up its telecommunications market to foreign competitors at a much faster clip than foreign countries are opening their markets to the United States, a Government study showed today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WHALING WALLS Long before men ran out West in search of gold and glory, they ran off to sea in search of whales and wealth. That era, 1820 to 1850, when whalers sailed from the Eastern Seaboard, brought with it, most incidentally, its works of art.

title: Former Nigerian Official Sentenced to 22 Years
description: A former Governor of Nigeria's Plateau State has been sentenced to 22 years in prison for misappropriating $24 million, the Lagos radio said today.

title: POP:BOBBY WOMACK SINGS
description: BOBBY Womack's concerts last Saturday at the Beacon Theater brought an increasingly rare style to New York - classic soul singing, the secularized legacy of gospel singing and preaching. During a late set that barely touched on more modern funk and pop styles, although it included hits from both the early 1970's and his current album, ''The Poet II,'' Mr. Womack poured passion and spontaneity into every phrase he sang.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Algonquin Gas Transmission Co., Boston, has elected Richard D. Morel chairman.

title: Discovery Oil
description: Discovery Oil Ltd. said its principal lending banks had declared the $9.6 million debt outstanding under its revolving credit agreement, including interest accrued, to be immediately due and payable. Discovery said that although the banks will not waive default, they will defer any foreclosure action while they monitor the company's progress in liquidating the bank debt. Separately, Discovery said it is continuing to pursue merger discussions through its investment banker, Samuel Montagu Inc.

title: SHUTTLE LAUNCHING DELAYED 24 HOURS BY THE FAILURE OF A BACKUP COMPUTER
description: A computer malfunction, possibly a memory lapse, forced the postponement today of the space shuttle Discovery's flight debut. But engineers raced to overcome the problem in an attempt to launch the $1.2 billion spaceship Tuesday morning.

title: ALL THE WORLD HAS BEEN HER STAGE
description: She has appeared in any number of roles: Catherine in ''Arms and the Man,'' Irina Arkadina in ''The Seagull,'' Amanda in ''The Glass Menagerie'' and Helena in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' And this season she is juggling dual roles: that of Mistress Quickly in ''Henry V'' at the Folger Theatre here and that of ambassadorial wife and mistress of the sumptuous British Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue.

title: 'Wired' Dust Jacket Draws Suit by Hotel
description: Many New Yorkers, including the

title: THE WASHINGTON POST:A THREE-RING OBSESSION
description: If Washington were a circus, as some like to think it is, The Washington Post would be the ringmaster.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Shane Rawley, who had been relegated to the bullpen, earned this start tonight by filling in for Jay Howell and beating the Orioles at Baltimore on Thursday night.

title: REAGAN CONFOUNDS THE FORECASTERS
description: A YEAR ago, many political observers predicted that education would be a major issue in the Presidential election campaign. This pleased educators because they hoped that such attention would breathe new life into school reforms. Democrats were elated because they considered the Reagan Administration's record in education vulnerable.

title: NEW FASHION ENTRY: TAILORED DRESS
description: Ever since the strict Courr eges shift faded from center stage in the late 1960's, to be replaced by T-shirts and blue jeans and, later, pants suits and separates, fashion prophets have been heralding the return of the dress.

title: France, Spain in Soccer Final
description: Two national soccer teams looking for exoneration and glory after failing in the World Cup two years ago meet in Paris tomorrow night in the title game of the European championship.

title: On the Record ; Kennedy on Mondale
description: From Senator Edward M. Kennedy's speech in St. Paul yesterday endorsing Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as transmitted by United Press International:

title: Prices Ease in a Slow Day
description: Prices of fixed-income securities eased yesterday in extremely light dealings. Dealers said the credit market ignored the action taken by several major banks to raise their prime lending rates by a half a point, to 13 percent, because the move had been widely expected.

title: ARCTIC 'ANTIGONE' HAS ESKIMO CAST
description: For the Eskimo cast of ''Yup'ik Antigone,'' the trip from their Bering Sea village to the stage at La Mama in New York - where they open tonight - is an adventure across time as well as distance.

title: President Draws Fire From Conservationists
description: Six private conservation organizations today accused President Reagan of compiling a ''dismal'' environmental record and of trying to dismantle agencies responsible for protecting the environment.

title: THIS CAN'T BE YOGURT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
National Gypsum
description: The National Gypsum Company said it had arranged a $400 million revolving-credit and term-loan agreement with Citibank N.A. and 11 other domestic banks. The company said the agreement would allow it to proceed with expansion and diversification as opportunities developed. National Gypsum, based in Dallas, makes building products.

title: Topics Auto Mated
description: Freezing Life When England's Louise Brown, the first child conceived in a petri dish, was born in 1979, Maurice Maeterlinck's Kingdom of the Future came to earth. In ''The Blue Bird,'' the Kingdom was a palace in the clouds where unborn children wait.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MR. PICKENS FROM AMARILLO
description: FOR a while there, T. Boone Pickens Jr. seemed to be just about everywhere. You could hardly tune in a network news talk show, pick up a news magazine or glance at any business publication without seeing his solemn, sun-lined face or hearing that soft, West Texas drawl.

title: IRAQI EXOCET HIT TANKER BUT FAILED
description: A Greek tanker attacked by Iraqi warplanes in the Persian Gulf Sunday while loading Iranian oil was hit by a French-built Exocet missile that failed to explode, a shipping executive said today.

title: Business and the Law; A Plan to Spur Joint Research
description: WHEN executives from 15 companies, including some of the nation's computer and aerospace giants, gathered two years ago to discuss setting up a joint research venture, many of them were worrying about possible antitrust problems. Indeed, Adm. Bobby R. Inman, president of the Microelectric Computer and Technology Corporation, the research consortium that grew out of that meeting, said several companies refused to join the venture for fear of antitrust suits.

title: Grand Jury Decides Not to Indict Wick
description: Charles Z. Wick, Director of the United States Information Agency, will not face criminal charges that he secretly taped telephone calls with Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, and a newspaper reporter, a county grand jury decided today.

title: Generals' Season a Success
description: The Generals, after an impressive upset over the Philadelphia Stars on Sunday, enter the playoffs as sound as any of the other seven teams that will contend for the United States Football Legaue championship.

title: U.S Track Team May Be Best Ever
description: The track and field team that will represent the United States in this summer's Los Angeles Olympics is probably the best ever. In the absence of the Soviet Union and most of its allies, the Americans are likely to win at least half the 68 medals for men and a third of the 47 for women.

title: INVESTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC:HOUSING AGENCY
description: AMERICA has had public housing for 50 years, and for about a quarter of that time public housing hereabouts has had the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra to play in its lobbies and courtyards and to provide an outlet for its musically talented residents. The group was joined by the Billy Taylor Trio for an anniversary celebration yesterday at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Bentsen Receives a Nod And Backing for Ticket
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas today got a nod from a Democrat and a strong endorsement from a Republican as a running mate for the expected Democratic Presidential candidate, Walter F. Mondale.

title: BRAZIL'S DJAVAN MAKES U.S. DEBUT AT FISHER HALL
description: THE problem with the Kool Jazz Festival's ''Musical Salute to Brazil'' Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall was that the Brazilian parts weren't jazz and the jazz parts weren't Brazilian. In addition, the evening hardly built to a climax. Still, for those unconcerned with categories, there were plenty of lively moments.

title: SALVADORAN'S VISA TIED TO HIS HELP
description: Administration officials said today that an entry visa was granted to Roberto d'Aubuisson, a right-wing Salvadoran leader who has been linked to death squads, in an effort to draw him into the democratic process after his defeat in El Salvador's presidential election.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE work of 15 new designers

title: I.B.M. ADDS 2 COMPUTER VERSIONS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced two new versions of its most sophisticated Personal Computer, intended to perform the kind of specialty graphics used by engineers, city planners and scientists.

title: OBSTACLES TO AMERICAN ENERGY INDEPENDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: PERFECT DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $12,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the year.

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP IS SEEKING OFFERS
description: Continental Group Inc., formerly the Continental Can Company, said yesterday that it was putting itself on the auction block to seek competing offers for the company.

title: JACKSON, IN CUBA, CALLS FOR PEACE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in Cuba for a two-day visit tonight and in an airport meeting with President Fidel Castro said the United States and Cuba ''must give peace a chance.''

title: Ruling for Tarkanian
description: Saying that National Collegiate Athletic Association officials acted like ''arrogant lords of the manor,'' a Nevada judge ruled yesterday in favor of Jerry Tarkanian and ordered the N.C.A.A. to halt its efforts to suspend the basketball coach. In a strongly worded opinion that followed a two-week civil trial in Las Vegas, District Judge Paul Goldman ruled that the N.C.A.A. violated due process in attempting to suspend Tarkanian for two years after it had placed his basketball program at Nevada- Las Vegas on probation in 1977 for 38 recruiting violations.

title: JUDAICA BOOKS RECORDS SUBPOENAED
description: The New York State Attorney General and the Consumer Affairs Department of New York City both ordered Sotheby's auction house yesterday to release its records concerning the ownership of 31 Hebrew books and manuscripts that are scheduled for auction tonight.

title: ; THE 'SLOBS' DRESSED DOWN FOR SUMMER
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
METS ROUT PHILS;DARLING GETS 8TH
description: The Mets opened Phase Two of the battle for first place tonight by pounding the Philadelphia Phillies, 10-5, and taking a lead of one full game in the National League's East.

title: MRS. GOULD'S ANTIQUES AUCTIONED IN MONTE CARLO
description: French 18th-century antiques belonging to Florence J. Gould that had filled El Patio - her magnificent villa near Cannes - were auctioned tonight in a festive atmosphere that the international socialite and philanthropist might have orchestrated herself.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Pacific Resources
description: Pacific Resources Inc. said a group of banks filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition against its Paramount Petroleum affiliate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Renaldo Nehemiah , the former high-hurdles champion who now plays wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers, is back in a Federal court in Newark in an effort to be declared eligible to compete as an amateur in track. . . . Lou Vairo , who coached the United States Olympic hockey team last winter and was recently named an assistant coach by the Devils, has been named an aide to Coach Bob Johnson, who will guide Team U.S.A. in the Canada Cup tournament this fall. . . . The Devils have signed Greg Adams , a free-agent center from Northern Arizona University who had 44 goal and 29 assists last season.

title: Rep. Oberstar to Run Again
description: Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, announced today that he would seek re-election to the House rather than run for the Senate. Mr. Oberstar had sought the the Democratic Farm Labor Convention's endorsement in the Senate race, but the convention endorsed Secretary of State Joan Growe.

title: SEEK IRAN-IRAQ PEACE
description: The Reagan Administration is edging ever closer to policies that are likely to widen the Iran-Iraq war. This is a serious mistake. True, no government seems ready or able to halt this war. But there is no need for the United States to become militarily engaged in it. Indeed, by reducing its military involvement, the United States could help end the war and better serve its interests.

title: ;  People
description: * J. Dixon Byrne named executive vice president of Venet Advertising.

title: CONCERT:GOLDMAN BAND RETURNS FOR 67TH SEASON
description: THE Goldman Band is back for its 67th consecutive season of summer concerts in New York parks, and the first 1984 program was played under Ainslee Cox's direction in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center last Wednesday night. The weather was ideal, the street and air noises were held down to a mild roar and the grand old marches by Goldman and Sousa rang with their customary energy and assurance.

title: IMPERIAL OIL'S NEW STRATEGY
description: Imperial Oil Ltd., the biggest energy company in Canada, seems to be trying to take most of the chance out of one of the chanciest businesses in the world.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Wells Fargo Officer Joins Crocker July 1
description: In yet another management change at the Crocker National Corporation, Richard M. Rosenberg will join the banking company July 1 as vice chairman and a member of the management committee. The announcement was made yesterday by Frank V. Cahouet, president of the corporation and chairman of the Crocker National Bank, its principal subsidiary.

title: FOR THE DISABLED,A GIANT STEP TO ACCEPTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: ROYAL HITTERS CRUSH A'S, 16-0
description: Mark Gubicza pitched a three-hitter, and George Brett and Steve Balboni each hit three-run homers as the Kansas City Royals crushed the A's, 16-0, tonight.

title: Dill Jones, Pianist, Dies at 60; Expert in Harlem Stride Style
description: Dill Jones, the Welsh-born jazz pianist who lived and performed in the New York area since 1961, died of cancer Friday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Vietnam Says U.S. Quota Delays Emigration
description: Vietnam said today that it had stopped issuing exit permits for resettlement in the United States because of a backlog of nearly 30,000 cases caused by a United States immigration quota on Amerasian refugees.

title: ITT Telecom
description: The ITT Telecom Products Corporation, a unit of the ITT Corporation, said it had signed a $150 million agreement to sell switching products to United Telephone Systems Inc. The ITT unit said the agreement is for the recently introduced ITT 1240 digital switching system.

title: PRESIDENT PUTS BLAME ON 'FEAR'
description: President Reagan said today there was no excuse for the latest rise in the prime interest rate other than just a baseless ''fear of the future.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's easier to make $100 million than to give it away.'' - Edwin C. Whitehead, who has done both. (B2:1.)

title: Advertising; At Fallon, Awards Aid Gains
description: IF you have always found the mountain-to-Mohammed concept a little

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Washington Watch column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described the revenue loss from two proposed estate tax provisions. The loss from the installment payment provision should have been $50 million to $60 million and from the disclaimer provision $50 million.

title: Dedication Postponed For Wood Theater
description: The dedication of the Audrey Wood Theater - which had been scheduled for noon today - has been postponed until Sept. 24, according to Jack Lawrence, the owner of the theater. The date was changed because of scheduling conflicts for several people who were to speak at the ceremony, including Helen Hayes.

title: A VOCAL DUO, TRUMPETER
description: MENAGE DE COLLAGE, an experimental female vocal duo, and Barbara Donald, an excellent straight-ahead jazz trumpeter, offered an interestingly diverse double bill of women-led jazz at Irving Plaza Sunday.

title: DEMOCRATS MEET KEAN ON TRANSPORTATION BILL
description: Governor Kean and the Democratic leadership of the New Jersey Legislature met for more than two hours today to look for a compromise on a $3.3 billion highway- and bridge-repair program, but failed to make any progress.

title: VACCINE LIABILITY THREATENS SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON THE nation's major drug companies, some stung by large liability costs, have been dropping out of vaccine production for years and the trend is continuing, raising fears that future supplies may be jeopardized, important research will be neglected and the costs of vaccines may skyrocket.

title: SEAT BELT SYSTEMS THAT ARE NOT FOR EVERYONE
description: To the Editor:

title: CARL FOREMAN, PRODUCER AND 'RIVER KWAI' SCREENWRITER, DIES
description: Carl Foreman, who wrote scripts for ''High Noon,'' ''The Guns of Navarone'' and ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' and produced many other films, died of cancer yesterday at his Beverly Hills, Calif., home. He was 69 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Answers Back
description: An official of the National Collegiate Athletic Association said that a Las Vegas judge's ruling against the organization will have no bearing on the way the ruling body of college sports does business. ''I do not believe it will have any effect at all,'' said Bill Hunt , the N.C.A.A. assistant executive director for enforcement.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
KOCH DECLINES TO SIGN MEASURE AT A CEREMONY
description: In a rare move - one he called ''sui generis'' - Mayor Koch yesterday declined to sign into law a bill regulating bicycle messengers and deliverers.

title: RISE IN PRIME STIRS DEBTORS
description: THE action by United States banks in raising

title: Drinking Ages Set by the States
description: The following is a list of the states and the minimum age requirement they each have set for drinking alcoholic beverages: 21 for all alcoholic beverages: Alaska, Arizona (effective January 1985), Arkansas, California, Delaware, Indiana, Illinois, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, Missouri, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Tennessee (effective August 1984), Utah and Washington. 21 for out-of-state residents; 19 for state residents: West Virginia.

title: A BILL TO PROTECT WORKERS' RIGHT GAINS IN ALBANY
description: Key legislators announced agreement tonight on a measure to protect workers from retaliation for reporting illegal activities by their employers that threatened public health or safety.

title: Top Yield 10.20% On Alabama Issue
description: The Alabama Highway Authority is selling $411.95 million of bonds, which are tentatively offered with a maximum yield of 10.20 percent for bonds due in 1998 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. For shorter maturities, yields range from 6.57 percent for bonds due in 1985, to 8 percent in 1987, 8.75 percent in 1989 and 9.75 percent in 1994.

title: PHILIP GLASS SALUTES JAZZ
description: Philip Glass is no stranger to Carnegie Hall. He and his ensemble of saxophones, electric keyboards and soprano gave their first concert there in 1978. Tonight, however, the Philip Glass Ensemble returns to Carnegie Hall under the unexpected auspices of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1984 International
description: -year-old budget dispute. Under a compromise reached by leaders of the 10 member countries, Britain would receive a rebate of about $800 million on its 1984 contribution to the Common Market treasury and $600 million for 1983. (Page A1, Column 6.) A corruption scandal shook Bonn. Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, a central figure in West Germany's center-right coalition, announced he had resigned because of the imminent confirmation of an indictment against him. (A1:4-6.)

title: A.T.&T. INTRODUCES PERSONAL COMPUTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, making its long- expected entry into the personal computer market, said yesterday it was ready to take on the International Business Machines Corporation in what appears to be the first head-to- head contest between the two giants.

title: REPEAL OF BOND TAX:IMPACT ABROAD UNCLEAR
description: Bankers and bond traders here say it will be months before they have a clear picture of the impact of the expected repeal of America's 30 percent withholding tax on interest from bonds sold to foreign investors.

title: POLITICIAN WITH A MISSION
description: W. Wilson Goode, the next Democrat to be interviewed by Walter F. Mondale as a Vice- Presidential possibility became first black Mayor of Philadelphia in election last November . . . deeply religious man with a somber manner . . . wears dark suits and has often acknowledged, ''I don't smile a lot'' . . . has master's degree in public administration from Wharton School of University of Pennsylvania . . . before becming Mayor was Philadelphia's Managing Director in charge of the city's 10 operating divisions . . . rarely sat at his desk worrying about problems when he could investigate them in person . . . once, checking city workers' performance, spent part of a normal 16-hour day on a sanitation truck . . . born Aug. 19, 1938, in a sharecropper's cabin in Seaboard, N.C. . . . at the age of 15, moved with his family to Philadelphia, where he was an honors student in school before attending Morgan State University in Baltimore . . . after a tour in the Army and a variety of jobs, thought of becoming a minster . . . decided instead on ''a ministry of a different kind, a ministry of public service'' . . . headed Pennsylvania's Public Utility Commission before before becoming Managing Director in Philadelphia . . . married to the former Velma Williams . . . they have three children.

title: NEW HARMONY OF 2 RIVALS FOLLOWS SHARP CLASHES
description: Although Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart buried the hatchet yesterday, saying their differences had been ''over-reported,'' they repeatedly attacked each other's policies on the stump in their long campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: AIR FLORIDA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN IS DISPLAYING INTEREST IN CULTURAL EXCHANGES WITH MOSCOW
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to revive an environmental information exchange that has been dormant since the late 1970's, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. CYCLIST RIDING HARD FOR THE TOUR
description: Greg Lemond, the world professional bicycle racing champion, turned 23 in a low key way today, refusing to admit that a special present he could give himself would be a victory in the Tour de France, which begins Friday. Although this will be Lemond's debut in the tour, the world's major cycling race, the American rider is one of a handful of favorites.

title: Distinction for Bench
description: Before retiring from the Cincinnati Reds last year, Johnny Bench had hit 389 homers and driven in 1,376 runs, both of which are club records. He belted 325 of those homers as a catcher, more than any other man who ever played the position in the major leagues.

title: RECTISEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
No Headline
description: Moon Speaks to Panel On Intolerance in U.S.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: INTIMATE MEMOIRS. Including Marie-Jo's Book. By Georges Simenon. Translated by Harold J. Salemson. 815 pages. Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: COMMON MARKET ENDS 5-YEAR FIGHT ON BUDGET SHARES
description: Leaders of the European Common Market countries today settled a five- year-old budget dispute and said the agreement cleared the way for movement toward greater European political and economic unity.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $82,000 for the quarter and $182,000 for the 9 months, a gain of $534,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of discontinued operations and tax credits of $324,000 for the quarter and $504,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $126,000 for the quarter and $494,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $35,000 for the quarter and $56,000 for the 9 months.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA IS FAST 6-4, 6-0 WINNER
description: With brilliant sunshine warming the lawns on Wimbledon's traditional Ladies' Day, Martina Navratilova opened defense of her title and Chris Evert Lloyd began her increasingly futile challenge today, both with resounding victories.

title: What 'Kosher' Entails
description: T O THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Plant Official Admits Sales of Tainted Beef
description: The manager of a meat processing plant has pleaded guilty to selling contaminated beef to the nation's school lunch program and has agreed to testify against six other defendants.

title: HALF-INTEREST IN JAZZ IS BOUGHT BY SAUDI
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi businessman, today purchased a half-interest in the National Basketball Association's Utah Jazz franchise for $8 million, club officials said.

title: Gregg Out of Bout
description: Eddie Gregg , the unbeaten heavyweight, has suffered a punctured eardrum while sparring, forcing the postponement of his Felt Forum fight against James Broad Friday night. Madison Square Garden's boxing department is trying to find a replacement for Gregg, so that it can reschedule Broad for a match in August. . . . The former world bantamweight champion, Lupe Pintor, abruptly retired from boxing in Mexico City, announcing he could not lose the weight needed to remain a bantamweight.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Sure, your apartment is small, but why take it out on the cat?

title: U.S. Reportedly Placed Heavy Guard on Envoy
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador, during a visit to Washington last month, was put under heavy guard because American officials feared that an attempt on his life would take place in this country, according to Senator David F. Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota.

title: Debt Ratings
description: American Airlines Inc.'s senior secured debt rating was raised to Baa-1, from Baa-3, and its subordinated debt to Baa-3, from Ba-3, by Moody's.

title: 18-STORY OFFICE BUILDING IS RISING IN FORT LEE, N.J.
description: Atop the 300-foot-high Palisades, on the other side of the Hudson River from New York City, Fort Lee, N.J., is becoming one of the hottest corners in the area's office space market.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Hand-Painted on Wood

title: Cool America, Boil the World
description: The further increase in interest rates may be just what the booming American economy needs - something to slow it down before inflation strikes again. But America does not exist alone. What may be healthy restraint inside our frontiers is an oppressive burden for third-world nations already submerged in debt. If they don't get relief, their critical situation could become disastrous.

title: L.I. Town Adopts Boat Safety Law
description: The town of Hempstead's first ordinance governing reckless operation of pleasure boats was unanimously approved today by the Town Board.

title: THE KENNEDY TOUCH
description: There comes a point in any political entanglement when events and timing make it ripe for resolution. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who remained on the sidelines in the Democratic Presidential primary campaign, has sensed and seized such a moment in the dispute between Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart and demonstrated once again his ability to influence his party's course.

title: COVENTION CENTER'S HEAD GETS BACKING IN DISPUTE
description: The president of the New York City Convention Center received strong support yesterday from the chairman of the corporation that will operate the center.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AEL Industries of Montgomeryville, Pa., a supplier of electronic defense systems and equipment, said it had completed the sale of its cable operation, Ultracom Inc., to Harte- Hanks Cable Inc. The price is expected to exceed $77 million.

title: THE DANCE: MIXED BILL
description: ''Ted Shawn must be rolling over in his grave,'' people murmured as they wandered through the grounds of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Saturday, in a gala celebration of the season's opening. Shawn, the American modern dance pioneer and presiding eminence of the festival, would probably have been pleased to see the Pokingbrook Morris Dancers entertaining the guests, given his interest in ethnic dance. The sight of stiltwalkers in Edwardian costume might have amused him.

title: Korea Fund Files For Initial Offer
description: The Korea Fund Inc. said it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of five million common shares. The initial offering price is expected to be $12 a share.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
75 Percent of Delegates Favor Woman on Ticket
description: The National Women's Political Caucus said today that preliminary results of interviews with a sampling of Democratic convention delegates indicated about 74 percent favored the idea of a woman for Vice President and 10 percent opposed it.

title: IN PEKING, A DISCOUNT MAXIM'S
description: For the average Chinese worker a $44 dinner at Maxim's restaurant in Peking would be more than a month's wagesBut starting Sunday there will be an alternative, Minim's, on the ground floor of Maxim's, the year-old copy of the elegant Paris restaurant owned by the fashion designer and restaurateur Pierre Cardin. Although by no means cheap for the ordinary Chinese, the most expensive meal at Minim's is a heaping plate of meat for under $5.

title: HEBREW BOOKS AND MANUSCRIPTS SOLD
description: Thirty-one Hebrew books and manuscripts that were thought to have been destroyed by the Nazis in World War II were sold last night in an auction at Sotheby's, despite a last-minute attempt by the New York State Attorney General to order Sotheby's not to consummate the sales of those items.

title: A Vote for 'Covert' Diplomacy
description: In a gust of hyperbole, Senator East of North Carolina charges that by abandoning ''covert'' aid to Nicaragua's contras, Congress is inviting a Communist takeover of Central America. He implies that the sole barrier to Communism in the region is a proxy army waging a war it cannot win without direct American intervention - which even he does not advocate. That's a thin gray line against the hordes.

title: Bass Tells S.E.C. Of St. Regis Stake
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. of Forth Worth told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 126,250 shares, or 6 percent, of $4.30 convertible exchangeable preferred stock of the St. Regis Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of the St. Regis Corporation. Bass said that its purchases and sales of the preferred shares ''are in the nature of arbitrage transactions'' and that it bought the shares as an investment.

title: BRIEFING
description: To Have and to Hold

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,128,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter, and $2,265,000, or 34 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,814,000, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter, and $2,863,000, or 42 cents a share, for the 6 months. Both year-earlier periods were restated.

title: Grumman Awards
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, received four Navy contracts totaling $145.5 million, the Defense Department said. It said the company received contracts for production of E-2C aircraft, including $44.5 million for six of the aircraft, $39.5 million for two aircraft for sale to Singapore, and $26.8 million for one aircraft that will be sold to Egypt.

title: MAINTENANCE DEFICIENCIES BLAMED FOR BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that ''deficiencies'' in Connecticut's bridge maintenance and inspection programs were the probable cause of the collapse of the Connecticut Turnpike bridge over the Mianus River last year in which three people died.

title: THE RISKY BUSINESS OF TOYS
description: Last June major toy makers read the initial script of ''Gremlins,'' a Steven Spielberg movie. In February Gizmo, the good gremlin, made his debut at the annual toy fair in New York, and there were 50 licensees. Gizmo seemed sure to be a hit.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Reagan Names 2 as Envoys
description: President Reagan named two career diplomats to ambassadorial posts in the Middle East today, nominating Paul H. Boeker for Jordan and Richard Wood Boehm for Cyprus. Mr. Boeker, 46 years old, a member of the State Department's Policy Planning Council, would succeed Richard N. Viets. Mr. Boehm, 58, deputy examiner of the Board of Examiners for the Foreign Service, would replace Raymond C. Ewing.

title: Reagan to Appoint Glitman To Head Vienna Arms Talks
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Maynard W. Glitman to succeed Morton I. Abramowitz as the chief United States negotiator for the mutual and balanced force reductions talks in Vienna, the White House said today.

title: DETROIT-TEXAS GAS GATHERNG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $437,000 from the sale of mineral leases and a loss of $185,000 from costs associated with the offering of a drilling partnership.

title: BUTTERFLY RECORD SET AT TRIALS
description: Pablo Morales, a 19-year-old Stanford University sophomore from Santa Clara, Calif., broke the world record tonight for the men's 100-meter butterfly swim. His victims included Matt Gribble of Miami University, the record-holder, as both made the United States Olympic team.

title: Florida Citrus Crop Called Safe by State
description: Agriculture officials today identified the 20 fruit fly larvae found this week in Miami as Caribbean, not Mediterranean, flies and said the insect was no threat to Florida citrus growing.

title: Angola Will Not Send A Team to the Olympics
description: The Marxist Government of Angola will not send a team to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, the country's official press agency reported today.

title: DENNY ZEITLIN AND SOLO PIANO
