description: THOUGH the San Francisco jazz pianist Denny Zeitlin's fans in the New York area might fault him for infrequent appearances here, they were amply rewarded Monday in Carnegie Recital Hall, where, under the auspices of the Kool Jazz Festival, Mr. Zeitlin delivered a riveting solo performance.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Summer Take-Outs

title: ELAN CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago figures were not provided because the company was not publicly held until Jan. 26, 1984.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL EJECTED BY GROUP
description: The Costa Rica-based organization of groups battling the Nicaraguan Government voted Monday night to expel Eden Pastora Gomez, one of the rebel leaders, a spokesman for Mr. Pastora said today.

title: METS LOSE;STRAWBERRY SIDELINED
description: It was a strange and losing night for the Mets, and in a sense it began when Manager Dave Johnson was suspended for one game and fined $200 because he kicked dirt at an umpire last Friday.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
Belgian Forecasts
description: Belgium's economy will grow by 1.5 percent during 1984 while inflation falls from 6.8 percent to 6 percent, the Economic Affairs Minister, Mark Eyskens, said today. He added that the Government would maintain its tough austerity program.

title: SPLITTING HAIRS OVER SPLITTING GENES
description: Bureaucracy, like nature, abhors a vacuum. When one develops, the bureaucrats invariably rush in, jostling and wrestling to see who will fill the void.

title: Director Picked in BidTo Complete Seabrook
description: Edward A. Brown is moving to New Hampshire soon, but he probably won't have much time for his favorite hobby, skiing.

title: ADVERTISING ; A Telepictures Project With Outward Bound
description: Telepictures Publications, already publisher of two popular quarterlies for the younger set, Muppet and Barbie, is bringing out an annual for big people next October.

title: THE NIGHT THE DUCKS, ALL NEAT IN A ROW, DIED
description: It was President Reagan's most important initiative for the cities. It had the support of most members of Congress, including moderates, conservatives and liberals. Mr. Reagan was on the telephone lobbying for it until late Friday night.

title: ROBOTS JOIN BLOCKS IN THE CLASSROOM
description: Topo, stop! Don't

title: Spread of Atom Arms Called Peril in Report
description: A report to be released here Wednesday by former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance warns that an increase in the number of countries possessing nuclear weapons would pose a threat equal to the superpower arms race.

title: Tempering a Rental Shock
description: Builders have put up 30,000 apartments in New York City since 1974 under a special state law, 421(a), that offered 10 years of partial tax forgiveness in exchange for 10 years of rent stabilization. The first of these buildings start paying full taxes this year, and when tenants' leases expire, owners may ask whatever rent they choose. Tenants understandably fear the increases, but legislating indefinite new control could imperil what's left of the housing industry.

title: MONDALE DENOUNCES MUSLIM REMARK ON JUDAISM
description: Walter F. Mondale yesterday denounced the most recent statements about Jews by Louis Farrakhan, the black Muslim leader, as ''venomous, bigoted and obscene,'' and once again called on the Rev. Jesse Jackson to repudiate the Muslim.

title: AUTHOR OF 'MACHINE DREAMS' FINDS DRAMA IN LIFE
description: Jayne Anne Phillips had no clear plan when she set out four years ago to write her first novel, ''Machine Dreams,'' which has recently been published to critical acclaim.

title: DAY CARE LINKED TO ILLS OF CHILDREN
description: The growing use of day care has caused an increase in the spread among children of diarrheal illness and other diseases, including hepatitis, medical experts said at a symposium here. However, the participants were far from alarmist, and said the problem had simple solutions.

title: Boomerang First To Finish Race
description: The leading sailboats in the biennial Newport-to-Bermuda race arrived at St. George's lighthouse in Bermuda early yesterday. But, because of the unfavorable winds that they had encountered along the 635 miles, they were far behind the time needed to break the race record, 2 days 14 hours, set by Nirvana in 1982.

title: A PLACE FOR FOSTER CHILDREN
description: The Government says a national drive to find permanent homes for foster children is paying off dramatically. In a report to Congress last week, Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the number of children in foster care dropped from 500,000 in 1977 to 243,000 in 1982, and the average time spent in care went from 47 months in 1977 to 35 in 1982.

title: LEGAL RIGHTS OF EMBRYOS
description: A married couple, unable to bear a child by natural means, produce three test-tube embryos through the process of in vitro fertilization. When implanted in the wife's womb, the first embryo fails. The two others are frozen for future use, but before they can be implanted the husband and wife are killed in a plane crash. Legal questions abound. Can the orphan embryos be destroyed, or have they become frozen souls with the panoply of rights accorded human beings? Must they be implanted in another woman and, if possible, carried to term? If they are born, who are their legal parents, and what are their inheritance rights?

title: MONDALE AND HART, WITH SMILES, SAY ONLY TARGET NOW IS REAGAN
description: Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart met yesterday for two hours and then declared that their conflicts had largely been resolved and that they were united, as Mr. Hart put it, by a ''profound fear of a second Reagan term.''

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 17, 1983.

title: THOMPSON CLOUTS 4 IN PIRATE-CUB SPLIT
description: Jason Thompson's biggest day at the plate this season - two homers in each game of a doubleheader - could not overshadow the Pittsburgh Pirates' first baseman's failure to hit the ball out of the infield when the second game was on the line.

title: IMPROVING MANAGERS' TECHNIQUES
description: WITH earnings improving, many top corporate managers might be forgiven for believing they are appreciated by the people they are managing. If so, however, they may be in for a shock.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a gain of $6.5 million related to an agreement for a cash for equity exchange for long-term debt. c-Including a gain of $4.1 million from the sale of the Burger King office building. d-Including a gain of $5.4 million from the sale of investment in Stokely-Van Camp common stock.

title: CITY OPERA STARTS FUNDS
description: The New York City Opera has announced the establishment of several ''special-purpose funds,'' with financing drawn from the company's recently completed $12 million fund drive.

title: HALT SET FOR WORK AT MIDLAND
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that it would halt construction of the Midland nuclear power plant tomorrow. The utility has spent $3.6 billion on the two-unit plant over the last 17 years.

title: AT T-4 SECONDS, THE SHUTTLE IS HALTED
description: In a tense drama acted out in split seconds, engines of the space shuttle Discovery began ignition and then cut off abruptly today, forcing postponement of the mission for several days or possibly several weeks.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: HUNDREDS of thousands, and perhaps millions, of Americans can suffer bad reactions to sulfiting agents, a class of preservatives widely used in packaged and restaurant foods.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6.5 million for the latest year and $9,978,000 for the previous year.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BISHOPS CHALLENGE MX IN TESTIMONY
description: Two Roman Catholic Bishops, speaking for the United States Catholic Conference, urged Congress today to reconsider its tentative approval of the long disputed MX nuclear missile and questioned the need for President Reagan's space- based defense plan.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL YIELDS TO JACKSON BACKERS
description: The rules committe preparing for the Democratic National Convention made a series of concessions today to backers of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Addendum
description: * Fahlgren & Ferriss and Swink Advertising merged to form Fahlgren & Swink.

title: A.T.&T. Wins in Court
description: A Federal appeals court today threw out a $690 million antitrust suit filed against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by the Southern Pacific Communications Company, former owner of the Sprint long-distance system. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia upheld a lower court's ruling that Southern Pacific Communications did not prove A.T.&T. had violated antitrust laws. It said that A.T.&T. instead had properly allowed rivals to use local switching facilities to connect long-distance networks.

title: SUMMER LIGHTNING: A WARNING
description: The combination of more frequent thunderstorms and increased outdoor activity can be dangerous, with lightning-related deaths and injuries peaking in the summertime, Government weather experts say.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Official Dismissed By United Artists
description: Robert Rosencrans, president of the United Artists Cablesystems Corporation, was dismissed by its owners earlier this month, just two weeks after engineering the merger of the cable company with another major cable concern.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: U.S. Agrees to Accept More Vietnam Refugees

title: Wackenhuts Back $24-a-Share Offer
description: The Wackenhut Corporation said its chief stockholders, George R. Wackenhut and his wife, Ruth, had accepted a proposal from Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to take the company private for $24 a share, or nearly $94 million.

title: PAKISTANI SAID TO JOIN ARABS FOR TALKS ON GULF
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan held talks today with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia on the Persian Gulf war, according to Arab sources.

title: OLSEN IS PRIMING FOR REDEMPTION
description: Billy Olson, the pole-vaulter from Abilene, Tex., will be the recipient tomorrow of the 1984 Tanqueray Achievement Award for excellence in the field of amateur sports at a luncheon at Gallagher's Restaurant.

title: AIGUEBELLE RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Several Bids For Orange-Co
description: S. Robert Davis, chairman of Orange-Co Inc., said the company had been approached by several large corporations regarding its possible acquisition. Mr. Davis, stating that the discussions have been ''preliminary,'' declined to identify the potential suitors.

title: How to Prevent Chain Snatchings
description: For a moment, James McHugh held

title: Manila Premier Testifies In Hearing on Aquino
description: Prime Minister Cesar Virata said today that it was wrong to rule out involvement by anyone in the Government in the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Return to the City
description: Tom Emlyn Williams, a native New

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES NEW LIMITS ON BANKING
description: The House Banking Committee approved a comprehensive bill tonight to halt recent bank moves across state lines and to force banks out of certain nonbanking businesses. The vote puts the committee at odds with the Senate and the Administration.

title: SCREENING TEST FOR LIVER CANCER STIRS WIDE HOPES
description: The development of a rapid, highly sensitive screening test for liver cancer was announced here today by scientists who said it might have an important effect on dealing with the disease.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ameritech Corp., Chicago, parent company for five Midwestern Bell telecommunications companies, has promoted Dean A. Grinstead to vice president of billing systems.

title: HIGH COURT BARS STATE SPENDING LIMIT ON CHARITIES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that state-imposed limits on the amount of money charities may spend on fund-raising violate the charities' constitutional right of free speech.

title: Coffee, Tea and Hart
description: While Walter F. Mondale and

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day yesterday describing troubled utilities misstated the equity of common shareholders in the Consumers Power Company. At year end it was $2.3 billion.

title: THE 2D SPACE FLIGHT HALTED AFTER IGNITION
description: Yesterday's shutdown of Discovery's launching sequence was the third time in the United States space program that computer monitors aborted a liftoff at the last moment, and the second time it occurred after the rockets had begun to ignite.

title: Australian Wheat Crop
description: Australia's wheat crop for the 1984-85 season is expected to produce about 18 million tons, down 25 percent from last year, the Government's Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today.

title: BONN ECONOMICS MINISTER RESIGNS IN BRIBERY CASE
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, a central figure in West Germany's center-right coalition, announced late Tuesday night that he had resigned because of the imminent confirmation of a corruption indictment against him. He said Chancellor Helmut Kohl had accepted the resignation.

title: Bush Granddaughter Born
description: Sharon Bush, the daughter-in-law of Vice President Bush, gave birth Monday to a 7-pound, 1-ounce daughter. A spokesman at Rose Medical Center said that Mrs. Bush and her newborn, Lauren Pierce, were doing well after delivery at 1:43 P.M. Mrs. Bush is the wife of Neil Bush, the Vice President's son.

title: EASY CHARCOAL STARTER
description: AN annual and sometimes frustrating challenge for outdoor barbecue cooks is lighting the charcoal. Almost everyone, it seems, has a trick method that is quick and efficient; such folk usually stand around your grill wearing a smug smile as you fumble about. I must admit that I am one of them, and to make life easier I am passing along

title: Sargent Considers $66 Million Bid
description: Sargent Industries Inc. said its board will meet later this week to vote on a proposed acquisition of the company, valued at about $66 million, by a ''major public company'' that it did not identify.

title: Sikhs' Golden Temple Closed by Indian Army
description: Indian authorities closed the Golden Temple in Amritsar today, a day after the holiest Sikh shrine was reopened for the first time since army troops stormed the complex three weeks ago.

title: Thatcher Foes Assail Agreement
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is facing sharp criticism from political opponents and misgivings among her supporters after today's compromise settlement of the five-year dispute over Britain's contribution to the Common Market budget.

title: Former GCA Executive To Head Robotic Vision
description: Pat V. Costa, who is 40 years old, was named chairman, president and chief executive of Robotic Vision Systems Inc. yesterday.

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
SOVIET POINTS FINGER AT A CIVIL RIGHTS CASE IN U.S.
description: In an apparent response to Western concern about a reported hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet Union has undertaken a publicity campaign about Leonard Peltier, an imprisoned American Indian activist who recently staged his own fast.

title: The Lonely Burmese
description: Which nation will field the smallest team at the Olympics this summer? Apparently Burma, which plans to send only one athlete, Zaw Latt , the country's lightweight boxing champion.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RISING RATES BENEFITING INVESTORS
description: The rise in interest rates, including this week's increase in the prime rate, is painful for the Federal Government, because the cost of borrowing to cover its deficit has soared. The same complaint comes from corporations, which borrow to finance new plants and machinery, and developing countries, which are trying to repay their ballooning debts.

title: Orbital Financing Set
description: The Orbital Sciences Corporation yesterday announced the completion of a $63 million financing package that will cover the initial construction of one satellite launching vehicle, and the development of another.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SALTY CINEMA Ever since man has been going down to the sea in scripts, ships and the people who work with them have been the stuff of great drama on film, just as in fiction and art. The South Street Seaport Museum, dedicated to recalling iron men and wooden ships, tonight starts a Wednesday series of outdoor movies at 8:30 P.M. on its Pier 16, Fulton Street and the East River.

title: 6-7.1% YIELDS ON NOTES OF LOS ANGELES COUNTY
description: A $600 million note financing by Los Angeles County has been tentatively priced with yields ranging from 6 percent to 7.1 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Today, underwriters led by Bank of America plan to announce interest rates for a separate $265 million issue of the county's long-term certificates of participation.

title: ISRAEL'S KIBBUTZIM LOOK TO NEEDS OF THE INDIVIDUAL
description: The children of this rural, communal society live in cheerfully decorated dormitories from the age of 6 months. Their mothers, who see them at least three times a day, wear radio beepers on their belts so they can be paged if their children need them.

title: Bill Would Change Restroom Rules
description: The City Council struck a blow yesterday against the long lines that frequently form in front of women's restrooms in public places.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch on Friday about a committee examining complaints by the Rev. Jesse Jackson erroneously described the political stances of two Pennsylvanians. Leroy Irvis, Speaker of the Pennsylvania House, is supporting Walter F. Mondale. Julius Uehlein, head of the Pennsylvania labor federation, will attend the Democratic convention as a Mondale delegate.

title: TRUDEAU'S STATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: RED SOX DEFEAT ORIOLES
description: Al Nipper did not allow a hit for 5Y innings and Wade Boggs had three hits tonight to pace a 14-hit attack that helped the Boston Red Sox defeat the Baltimore Orioles by 5-2.

title: BOTTOM-LINE OPTIMISM
description: ROBERT H. BUCKLES is a money manager whose style, as he expresses it, is ''to seek out growth at a reasonable price.'' That was his approach at the Lehman Corporation, a leading closed-end investment company, where he spent his entire business career until he left last month.

title: FUJITSU TO EXPORT COMPUTER
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer company, is planning to export supercomputers to the United States, mounting the first direct challenge to American manufacturers who make high-speed computers considered vital for national defense.

title: THE WESTWAY'S MAN IN THE MIDDLE
description: Fletcher Griffis ordinarily plays racquetball three times a week. But lately he has been playing every day. ''I'm trying to get my blood pressure down,'' Colonel Griffis said, smiling, ''so that it will have room to go up again.'' Bud Griffis, as the colonel is known, presumes that presiding over two 13-hour Westway project hearings, which began yesterday and involve environmentalists, public officials, labor leaders and representatives of special-interest and community groups, will not be a particularly relaxing experience.

title: EX-BOSTON MAYOR'S AIDE GUILTY IN MONEY SCHEME
description: A jury tonight found Theodore V. Anzalone, long a close aide to former Mayor Kevin H. White, guilty of covering up some illegal currency transactions for the benefit of Mr. White's family, but not guilty of another.

title: Continental Aid Signed
description: The troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company won the right today to merge with an out-of-state buyer when Gov. James Thompson signed emergency legislation sought by the troubled bank.

title: A. O. Smith Net
description: The A. O. Smith Corporation said it expects earnings for the second quarter to be between $4.8 million and $5.6 million, or 65 to 75 cents a share, compared with earnings of $5.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. Smith said results will be affected by losses in at least two agricultural units. On the American Stock Exchange today, Smith was the second-biggest percentage loser, closing at $12.375, down $1.50.

title: AN EVENING OF HAROLD ARLEN'S MUSIC
description: JUST before the final medley of songs at ''An Evening of the Music of Harold Arlen,'' a Kool Jazz Festival concert in Carnegie Hall Monday evening, Bobby Short, who served as host, co- producer and performer, mentioned Mr. Arlen's close relationship to black music, despite the fact that he is white. He quoted Ethel Waters's comment that ''Harold Arlen is the blackest white man I ever knew.''

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Travelodge International is part of Trusthouse Forte PLC of London.

title: Saints Not Marching
description: The New Orleans Saints, putting an end to rumors that they might move to Jacksonville, Fla., or one of a number of other cities, have reached a tentative agreement with the Louisiana Superdome in which the team will save about $800,000 a season in rental and other game expenses. Included in the accord is the state's promise to try to provide land that the Saints can use as a training site, at a cost to the club of only $1 a year.

title: DEFENSE FOCUS: A MISSING 'SUPREME ACT'
description: To the Editor:

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HART, FOOT STILL IN THE DOOR, VISITS EARLY BACKERS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Declaring, ''I don't quit,'' Senator Gary Hart returned to the scene of his breakthrough primary victory today.

title: Barden Settles S.E.C. Charge
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a Connecticut maker of medical supplies of helping the U.S. Surgical Corporation falsify its books.

title: Conversion of Brig ToCost$44Million
description: The estimated cost of turning the Brooklyn Navy Yard brig into a city jail has grown from $25 million to $44.9 million in just six months, officials of the Koch administration said yesterday.

title: INVESTOR'S DAILY:FIGHT FOR LIFE
description: After 10 weeks of publication, Investor's Daily - a California-based financial daily newspaper weighted with statistics and charts - is fighting for respect and profitability, a fight its creator insists will be won despite heavy start-up losses.

title: Helene Curtis May Narrow Loss
description: Helene Curtis Industries' president, Ronald Gidwitz, said at the annual meeting that the company may report a narrower loss for the fiscal first quarter, ended May 31.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Top Judge, Anyone?
description: It sounds incredible, but New York's Commission on Judicial Nomination has had so few applicants for two seats on the state's highest court that it had to extend the deadline and call for more recommendations. Don't most lawyers want to be judges? Not even top judge on the state's top court - Benjamin Cardozo's seat? What's going on?

title: BOARD RULES UNIONS LACK POWER TO CURB MEMBERS' RESIGNATIONS
description: The National Labor Relations Board, in a ruling that will make it tougher for unions to exercise discipline on their rank and file during strikes, said today that a union could not restrict a member's right to resign.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
17 Suspended for Cheating
description: Seventeen Air Force Academy cadets, lacking only their qualification testing for commissions in the military, have been suspended for cheating on a physics examination, the school announced Monday. The 17 will be allowed to return in a year and complete their testing because there is a feeling among school officials that others cheated and got away with it. The cadets were not identified.

title: HIGHLY PROBABLE PERIL TO THE HUMAN SPECIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CLEAN WATER ACT RENEWED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives, after two years of discussion and delay, voted today to renew and amend the Clean Water Act.

title: Loss Narrows At Air Florida
description: Air Florida lost $8.4 million in the first three months of 1983, the airline said today, compared with an $11 million loss in the first three months of 1983.

title: ARIAS WINS IN GRASS-COURT DEBUT
description: WIMBLEDON, England

title: Northwest to Sell Its Universal Unit
description: Northwest Industries said it had agreed in principle to sell its Universal Manufacturing Corporation unit for $70 million.

title: Sabbath-LawCase Set for High Court
description: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, said today that he would defend before the United States Supreme Court a state law granting employees the right to refuse to work on their Sabbath.

title: The U.N. Today June 27, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ASSEMBLT PASSES WATERFRONT PROJECTS IN QUEENS AND HOBOKEN
description: Legislation authorizing major waterfront developments in Queens and Hoboken, N.J., was approved tonight in the State Assembly, the second time in two years.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1983.

title: CITY OFFERS APARTMENT-SHARING PLAN FOR HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration, unable to find what it considers decent shelter for homeless families in the city, has proposed having at least 500 families move into and share apartments already occupied by other families receiving welfare.

title: SUBTLETIES OF THE FORMULA
description: There were times today when the corridors here looked like vast demonstration areas for a store selling hand calculators. And the conversations, all about the meeting of the Common Market's leaders, sounded like the talk of desperate students trying to pass an exam in advanced budgeting.

title: 2-Alarm Blaze At Restaurant
description: A two-alarm fire broke out during the renovation of a restaurant site on the Upper East Side yesterday and forced 100 people to be removed temporarily from a residential hotel above it.

title: MILITARY SPENDING DISPUTE STALLS BUDGET MEASURE
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, today refused to discuss military spending levels with the House, stalemating an effort to reach a decision on the last major portion of this year's effort to hold down projected Federal deficits.

title: Chrysler FinancialVariable Rates
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation said it would offer $300 million of quarterly variable-rate notes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, Salomon Brothers and its own facilities.

title: Japanese Output Up
description: Production at Japan's factories and mines rose 11.8 percent in May, compared with the same month a year ago, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: AT SOVIET DACHAS, BOUNTY FOR SUMMER
description: CONTRARY to popular opinion and my own crude expectations, Russian food turned out to be not all kasha, cabbage and standing in line. Tolstoy and Turgenev write about making jam and picking mushrooms and about meals like the one Levin gave Oblonsky in the country: ''herb brandy, bread and butter and above all the smoked goose and mushrooms, the nettle soup and chicken in white sauce, the Crimean white wine.''

title: WHAT 'PROFESSIONAL' E.R.A. BOOSTERS MAY BE UP TO
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazine Is Planned For Modern Black Man
description: George C. Pryce, formerly of Hill & Knowlton; Lockhart & Pettus, and Uniworld, the last two specializing in minority marketing, is going to publish a new magazine, called MBM and subtitled For the Modern Black Man, in November.

title: AID PHASE-OUT IS SEEN FOR FOES OF SANDINISTAS
description: The Senate decision on Monday against providing additional aid to Nicaraguan rebels this year will force at least a temporary phase-out of American support for the insurgents, senior Administration officials said today.

title: EVENT FOR THE AVERAGE ANGLER
description: -FISHING contest in Long Island waters this

title: HOUSE APPROVES CIVIL RIGHTS BILL
description: The major civil rights bill before Congress this year was passed overwhelmingly tonight by the House of Representatives after lawmakers voted to extend basic antidiscrimination protections to employees of Congress and the Federal courts.

title: MISS VERDY QUITS BALLET POST
description: Violette Verdy has resigned as artistic director of the Boston Ballet. Miss Verdy, formerly a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet and head of the Paris Opera Ballet, submitted her resignation Sunday.

title: STUDY FAULTING F.B.I. WORK MAILED TO DELOREAN JURORS
description: The trial of John Z. DeLorean on drug charges was shaken today when jurors said they had received copies of a Congressional report that was highly critical of Government undercover investigations like the one in the DeLorean case.

title: REPERTORY COMPANY BLOSSOMS
description: THE theater's capacity reminded one critic of a student attempt to cram a record number of human bodies into a Volkswagen. If space was tight inside the 80-seat house, however, the accommodations backstage were surpassingly inconvenient. The stars had no dressing rooms, relying instead on individual shopping bags stuffed with their costumes and suspended from a ceiling rack in a common changing area. During a performance, they had to be careful not to rustle the paper bags, since the audience could hear the crackling noises.

title: JURY'S USE OF STATISTICS UPHELD
description: Juries deciding whether a convicted murderer should receive the death penalty or life in prison can consider statistics that show whether defendants of similar backgrounds are likely to kill again after long prison terms, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

title: REAGAN SAYS HIS OUTLOOK IS YOUTHFUL
description: President Reagan waxed geriatric today and gently addressed an elderly audience as ''my fellow septuagenarians.'' He told them he still enjoyed the great debates of the day well enough to ''stay pretty young'' at the White House.

title: Foe of Studds Says Issue Is 'Child Molestation'
description: A Democratic challenger to Representative Gerry E. Studds today called the Congressman's affair with a teen-age House page ''an act of child molestation'' and said it would be the focus of the primary campaign.

title: SUPREME COURT RULES ON A QUESTION OF JURORS' BIAS
description: The Supreme Court, ruling that Federal judges should not second-guess state trial judges on questions of juror impartiality, reinstated a 1970 murder conviction today. A Federal appellate court overturned the conviction last year on the ground that the jury was biased by pretrial publicity.

title: 7 on Fire Truck Injured in Crash
description: A fire truck answering a call and a van crashed today, injuring seven firefighters and a civilian, the Nassau County police said.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Despite a decline from the 35-5 pace with which they opened the season, the Tigers continue to widen their lead. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. Dwight Gooden, the Mets' strikeout ace, tries to extend their first-place margin. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Soccer

title: SENATE VOTES BILL AIMED AT FORCING DRINKING AGE OF 21
description: The Senate today approved a bill that would both penalize states that failed to enact a minimum drinking age of 21 and reward those that enacted mandatory sentencing for drunken drivers.

title: IN LINE OF DUTY
description: When the score reached 16-0 in favor of the Kansas City Royals over the Oakland A's in the seventh inning Monday night, Manager Jackie Moore called Garry Hancock from right field to do the pitching for the A's, who were opening a 16-game road trip. Hancock, a 30-year-old outfielder-first baseman who is batting .211, had never pitched in a major league game.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Yields Jump at Treasury Sale
description: Yields rose sharply at yesterday's Treasury auction of $6 billion of four- year notes. The average effective yield, 13.69 percent, was produced by an average price of 99.805 on notes bearing a 13 5/8 percent coupon.

title: SOMETHING ABOUT BANANAS
description: Until four or five weeks ago I had never heard of Michael Jackson. I confess it without shame. I had heard of the Baron de Charlus, Serge Koussevitzky, Killer Kane, Ardala, Madame Lupescu, Judge Hardy, Guy Fawkes, Diamond Jim Brady, Brenda Frazier, Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov, Dred Scott, Jomo Kenyatta, Chinese Gordon and Ziggy Elman, but not - until four or five weeks ago - of Michael Jackson.

title: Afghan, Rumored Held, Reported Leading Battle
description: An Afghan guerrilla chief, Ahmad Shah Masood, who was rumored to have been captured, has returned to the Panjshir Valley and is directing operations against Soviet forces who overran it, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: POLICE LAUD 15 MEMBERS OF CIVILIAN RADIO PATROL
description: He was hailed as a hero yesterday, but William Santiago said he had done nothing very unusual.

title: Koch on Tape
description: His voice rose in delight, dripped

title: AT&T Information Adds to Ogilvy Joy
description: Elsewhere at Ogilvy & Mather yesterday the excitement concerned the formal announcement by its client AT&T Information Systems of its five computer products and the advertising to go with them, advertising that some trade sources put at around $40 million.

title: Bill Would Clarify Marble Hill's Status
description: The Assembly voted tonight to move the Marble Hill section of the Borough of Manhattan into New York County, thereby correcting a 46-year old mistake.

title: MUSIC: BIRGIT NILSSON AND THE PHILADELPHIANS
description: ''Brava,'' called a few admirers as the diva disembarked from her limousine.

title: IMMIGRANT CONTROLS
description: Although the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration bill appears assured of passage, the House's close 216-211 vote may spell trouble for the Immigration and Naturalization Service when the agency turns to enforcing the provision for employer sanctions. Unless the Congress insures that the service receives the manpower and budgetary resources necessary to carry out the law, and the service gets the public support necessary to resist crippling lawsuits and other political sabotage, illegal immigration may well continue much as before.

title: Hallmark Victory For Ogilvy
description: charged message to Ogilvy & Mather.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS CHOOSE A SUCCESSOR TO BERLINGUER
description: Alessandro Natta, a close associate of the last three leaders of the Italian Communist Party, was elected Secretary General of the party today. He succeeds Enrico Berlinguer, who died of a brain hemorrhage June 11.

title: Connecticut Man Shot in the Bronx
description: A man who works for the Westport (Conn.) Highway Department was shot eight times while in the Bronx yesterday, then driven to a Queens hospital, where he was left wandering in the parking lot.

title: WINFIELD SWINGING AT STEINBRENNER
description: As soon as Dave Winfield arrived

title: ; WHAT 'PROFESSIONAL' E.R.A. BOOSTERS MAY BE UP TO
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY LEADERS REACH ACCORD ON $3.3 BILLION PLAN FOR ROADS
description: Governor Kean and Democratic legislative leaders agreed today on a $3.3 billion program to rebuild New Jersey's roads and bridges.

title: ISRAELI'S TEAM SEEKS 3D GOLD
description: Zvi Karsh smiled as he watched the United States ''stand-up'' basketball team that is entered in the International Games for the Disabled move through a half-court scrimmage at Nassau Community College today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS a Burgundian schoolboy I was taught the remark attributed to Henry IV, apparently made upon his being crowned King of France in 1589: ''I want there to be no peasant in my realm so poor that he will not have a chicken in his pot every Sunday.''

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
No Headline
description: Bridge: Te To void Elimination

title: CADILLAC TAIL FIN: SYMBOL OF DISPUTE
description: ''YEAH, the Cadillac image,'' said Doug Michels, a Los Angeles architect. ''It's still potent after all these years.'' Mr. Michels is a partner in Ant Farm, a radical architectural group founded in San Francisco that created Cadillac Ranch outside of Amarillo, Tex. Ten years ago this month Ant Farm planted 10 Cadillacs in the ground, nose down, fins up, in chronological order.

title: NETWORKS CRITICIZED ON POLLS
description: The House passed a nonbinding resolution today - 351 to 65 - asking television networks and other news media to refrain from characterizing or projecting the results of an election before the polls have closed nationwide. The resolution now goes to the Senate for a final vote.

title: D'AUBUISSON IS FINDING A FRIEND ON CAPITOL HIL
description: Aides to Senator Jesse Helms said today that he has been defending Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist, because the Senator prefers Mr. d'Aubuisson's politics to those of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador.

title: HEARINGS OPEN ON WHETHER WESTWAY IS 'IMPERATIVE' OR IS A 'WHITE ELEPHANT'
description: The Westway, described as the most expensive Interstate highway in the nation and the costliest to defend in court, staked its claim to another record yesterday: the most debated.

title: And Haddock Too
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: O for that fine vacation place And who cares how many have heard of it Where if we can't get away from it all We might get away from a third of it.MAY RICHSTONE

title: Dow Drops 7.73; Trading Is Active
description: Stock prices ended moderately lower yesterday in active trading. Analysts said investors weighed the effects on the market of the recent half-point increase in the prime lending rate, to 13 percent.

title: Peru Asserts Guerrillas Killed 45 in Town Raid
description: Guerrillas killed 45 peasants Monday in the Andean town of Paicca, Government spokesmen said today. They called it was the biggest massacre by the rebels this year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on June 7 about privately run electricity generation at the Penn South cooperative apartment complex incorrectly described the power plant. It is among several such plants in New York City.

title: U.S. POLICY ON PAKISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: CURBS ON SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES, EASED SLIGHTLY, VOTED AGAIN IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Legislature today approved a new version of a bill that would limit smoking in restaurants and public places in the county. The vote was 16 to 2.

title: U.S. Jet Crashes in Spain
description: An F-16 fighter crashed near Madrid during a routine training flight Monday, killing its pilot, the Air Force said today.

title: BRAZILIAN FOODS REFLECT A CULTURAL MOSAIC
description: IT is lunchtime in the animated upstairs dining

title: SCREEN: PAUL VERHOEVEN'S '4TH MAN'
description: THE visual symbolism in Paul Verhoeven's ''4th Man'' is so fevered and relentless that the film has the feeling of a feature-length hallucination. Certainly it's a departure from the more earthbound works (''Soldier of Orange,'' ''Spetters'') of this Dutch director. Mr. Verhoeven this time concentrates on Christian imagery, the prescience of his central character and an overpoweringly portentous color scheme. Such material might benefit from a more delicate touch than Mr. Verhoeven's. But what he lacks in subtlety, he does make up in sheer intensity.

title: No Headline
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MAN KILLED IN RAID;SHOOTING IS TERMED ACCIDENTAL BY POLICE
description: A plainclothes police officer accidentally shot and killed a man yesterday while he and other officers were investigating an abandoned store in East Harlem where narcotics were sold, the police said.

title: FOOD STORES: THE SQUEEZE IS ON SPACE
description: A CENTURY and a quarter ago George Huntington Hartford and George Gillam opened a discount tea store at 31 Vesey Street in lower Manhattan. It was the first of what would become the A. & P. chain, which over the years originated many of the marketing techniques now familiar in supermarkets, including a variety of product categories in a single store, self- service meat counters, house brands, freshness dating and a cash-and-carry policy.

title: WHAT TERRORISM IS AND ISN'T
description: Bombings and kidnappings in Lebanon and gunfire from the Libyan Embassy in London have put terrorism back at the top of the international political agenda. At the summit meeting in London, Western heads of government issued a guarded statement of condemnation. President Reagan has asked 26 Federal departments and agencies for new counterterrorist options and has sent Congress a legislative package aimed at strengthening antiterrorist provisions in the Federal criminal code.

title: HBO DOCUMENTARIES FILL 3 NETWORKS' BREACH
description: Home Box Office is in the process of redefining the television documentary - a process that has its champions as well as its detractors. But whether one applauds or deplores the entry of the pay-cable giant into the documentary arena, there is no denying that HBO has suddenly become a major supplier of documentary films in this country.

title: F.T.C. STAFF ASKS EASED RULE ON SALE OF USED CARS
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission today recommended adoption of a rule on the sale of used automobiles that would drop an earlier proposal that dealers put stickers on cars disclosing their known defects.

title: VOICES OF CREW RECORD 'ABORT'
description: The voices of the astronauts and engineers in the launching control center at the Kennedy Space Center were calm and businesslike today throughout the attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ROLLINS'S QUEST: 'THE ULTIMATE SOUND'
description: SONNY ROLLINS, whose Kool Jazz Festival performance will take place Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall, has been an important, trend-setting tenor saxophonist for more than 35 years. But he is still searching for something that keeps eluding him, something that seems to hover enticingly just beyond his grasp. He calls that something ''the ultimate sound.''

title: People
description: * Jack Gellatly has joined Korey, Kay & Partners as executive vice president, director of client services.

title: AN ECONOMIC CONCEPT BELIED BY ITS ACRONYM
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CHILDREN AND THE BOMB
description: -heavy title, ''What Do Children Think of When They Think of the Bomb?'' is never quite as charming or illuminating as it clearly wants to be. The 27-minute film is on Channel 13 tonight at 9:30. It was made by Elizabeth Swados, John Canemaker and Mary D. Silverman, in conjunction with 19 nonprofessional New York City youngsters with assorted artistic and athletic credentials.

title: LAST DEFENDANT IN BRINK'S TRIALS GIVEN 75 YEARS TO LIFE IN PRISON
description: Samuel Brown was sentenced today to three consecutive terms of 25 years to life in prison for murder and robbery in the 1981 holdup of a Brink's armored car. The sentencing ended what Judge David S. Ritter called ''this lengthy and expensive case.''

title: Vermont Chief Backs Order to Raid Commune
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling said today that his approval of a roundup of children living in a church commune was the toughest decision he ever had to make in public office, but he defended the action.

title: CASTRO, AFTER TALKS WITH JACKSON, FREES 22 JAILED AMERICANS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today concluded a long day of talks with President Fidel Castro with a commitment from the Cuban leader to release 22 United States citizens imprisoned in that country. The agreement excludes those being held for airline hijacking.

title: AFTER MIDNIGHT, POLAND IS FREE TO LAUGH AT ITSELF
description: For five chilly hours, more than a dozen Polish comics and satirists ridiculed the Polish Government, its new economic policies, censorship, shortages and high prices in routines and songs.

title: Herzog vs. Hernandez
description: The battle of the crossword puzzles broke out today when Whitey Herzog, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, said that he traded Keith Hernandez to the Mets last year because Hernandez ''wasn't hustling'' and spent his time during practice doing crossword puzzles in the locker room. But Hernandez said tonight: ''That's a lie.''

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition during January 1984, accounted for on a pooling of interests basis, and also to reflect a 60 percent stock dividend paid in November 1983.

title: TIGERS BEAT YANKS ON CLOUT IN 10TH, 9-7
description: A night that started wrong finished wrong for the Yankees at the Stadium. Lance Parrish hit a two-out, two-run homer in the 10th inning last night on a pitch that pitcher Clay Christiansen described as ''nothing, really nothing,'' and the Yankees lost to the Tigers, 9-7.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The shuttle system did exactly what it was designed to do and I am very pleased that it did.

title: SECRECY SHROUDS SALVADORAN'S TRIP
description: The movements of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist who is visiting the United States, are being kept secret as a matter of prudent politics and personal safety, his hosts say.

title: HAVE CALIFORNIA CABERNETS LOST THEIR CACHET?
description: BY dint of talent and a formidable capacity for thoroughness, Robert J. Parker Jr. has become one of the most respected American wine authorities. His bimonthly newsletter, The Wine Advocate, is highly considered within the trade and by wine amateurs interested in current buys and in building a cellar.

title: No Headline
description: Leslie Burr of Westport, Conn., leading rider on the Mercedes Grand Prix series, rode Nightwork to victory in the Open Power and Speed class today as the 1984 Lake Placid Horse Show got under way. In capturing the feature, Miss Burr became the favorite for Sunday's Almaden- Lake Placid Grand Prix, the final trial for the United States Olympic show-jumping team.

title: WHAT'S JESSE DOING?
description: Presidential candidates have for many years campaigned from foreign capitals - usually it's good television and therefore good politics - but Jesse Jackson's trip to Cuba and Central America is something different. It's bad politics, bad diplomacy and bad manners.

title: ROLE IN ISRAEL IS PLANNED FOR EBAN
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, has said that Abba Eban, a former Israeli Foreign Minister, will have a senior policymaking role if the Labor Party wins the elections on July 23.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1984

title: AUTO RACING DREAM IS NEAR
description: The vision is on the horizon. From here at the Meadowlands sports complex, the vision looks somewhat like Emerald City, except the New York skyline is gray.

title: KUHN HAS IMPACT
description: For the first time in his 15 years as commissioner, Bowie Kuhn visited the Major League Baseball Players Association's offices on Third Avenue in Manhattan last Wednesday.

title: Jury Debates the Guilt Of 2 in Detroit Slaying
description: A jury today began deliberating in the trial of two men accused of violating the civil rights of a young Chinese-American by beating him to death with a baseball bat.

title: OPPONENTS OF WESTWAY WIN FEES
description: A judge ruled yesterday that New York State and the Federal Government must pay $290,000 to lawyers representing opponents of the Westway project.

title: RUMANIAN LANDSAT USE SEEN
description: Administration officials said today that the United States may sell satellite monitoring equipment to Rumania if a Commerce Department proposal is approved by President Reagan.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Paris Recalls Envoy Over Albania Shooting
description: France has recalled its Ambassador from Albania after the fatal shooting of a French employee of Club Mediterranee off the Albanian coast last week, an External Relations Ministry spokesman said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT OPINIONS IN N.C.A.A. CASE
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in the case of the National Collegiate Athletic Association v. the Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma. Associate Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote a dissenting opinion.

title: House TV Is Enlisted In Search for Missing
description: A Congressman displayed a photograph of Charlotte June Kinsey, a smiling blonde teen-ager from Oklahoma, before television cameras on the House floor today in the first use of the television system to search for a missing child.

title: 'Last-Ditch' Midland Talks
description: The Consumers Power Company and state officials have begun what the Consumers chairman, John D. Selby, termed ''last-ditch'' negotiations to reach an agreement that would permit completion of one unit at the Midland nuclear power plant.

title: THE EXPANDING WORLD OF AMERICAN CRAFTS
description: OVER the last decade, crafts have changed enormously. No longer just the products of cottage industries or homemade wares sold at street markets, crafts works in clay, metal, glass, fibers and wood are being purchased by major museums, exhibited at specialized galleries, shown at major crafts fairs and, most importantly, sought by a growing group of collectors.

title: BONN, ACTING SWIFTLY, PICKS A NEW ECONOMICS MINISTER
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today designated Martin Bangemann, a Free Democrat, to succeed Otto Lambsdorff as Economics Minister. Mr. Lambsdorff, facing a trial on corruption charges, resigned the post on Tuesday.

title: 5,000 Sikhs Visit Reopened Temple
description: More than 5,000 Sikh pilgrims poured into the reopened Golden Temple complex today, one day after it was closed abruptly. Many wept as they viewed damage caused by the Indian Army's raid on the shrine.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EXILE. The Unquiet Oblivion of Richard M. Nixon. By Robert Sam Anson. 360 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Israel Court Orders Candidate To Begin a Bribery Jail Term
description: Shmuel Flatto-Sharon, a financier wanted in France, today lost a 12-year struggle to stay out of prison.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: Meadowlands Grand Prix , practice and pole-position qualifying, at the Meadowlands sports complex. Al Unser Sr. and Al Jr., Mario and Michael Andretti, Tom Sneva and Rick Mears are among the Indy-car stars who will be on the track as two days of qualifying for Sunday's race begin.

title: MAZZOLI BILL IS NOT HELPING AT HOME
description: One thing about a city 373 miles from the nearest foreign border is that immigration is not a hot topic on the local cocktail circuit. So while Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Democrat, has been in the news for writing the immigration bill the House passed last week, his constituents here have been talking about Cissy and the college degrees.

title: Advertising; Champion Employee Campaign
description: CHAMPION International, a major force in paper, plywood and packaging, is going to spend $7 million on advertising to convince its 32,000 domestic employees it's a swell place to work.

title: REPAIRS EXPECTED TO KEEP SHUTTLE ON GROUND FOR AT LEAST 3 WEEKS
description: Analysis of the failed engine valve and other repairs and maintenance will probably keep the space shuttle Discovery grounded for at least three more weeks, officials of the Kennedy Space Center said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CAROL BELLAMY FIGHTS SHARING OF APARTMENTS FOR HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration's proposal to have homeless families share apartments with welfare families ''is a nightmare out of Dickens,'' City Council President Carol Bellamy charged yesterday.

title: WORD OF RELEASE CHEERS PRISONERS' FAMILIES
description: The families of 22 Americans whom the Cuban Government agreed yesterday to release from prison began receiving official confirmation from the State Department last night that their relatives would be returning home today.

title: JERSEY WILL HOLD HOSTS LIABLE IF DRUNKEN GUESTS CRASH CARS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that someone who ''directly serves'' liquor to a guest and allows him to drive away drunk can be held liable for injuries to others if the guest has an auto accident.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: Craft Classes and Workshops,

title: Sweden's G.N.P. Rises
description: Sweden's gross national product rose 5 percent in the first quarter from the period a year ago, and was up a seasonally adjusted 2 percent from the preceding quarter, Statistics Sweden said today. The agency said an 11 percent rise in exports from a year earlier was the primary cause of the first quarter gain, but added that domestic demand also picked up by 1.5 percent.

title: Frontier Airlines Ends Some Routes
description: Frontier Airlines said it is ending service to 20 cities and scheduling flights to more productive markets, beginning Oct. 1.

title: From Maine to the Marines
description: One day not so far from now, some of the names pinned to the shirts of the young men and women will become famous. For now, though, they were just trying to learn each other's names. The outstanding high school athletes from each state and Puerto Rico were honored last night during a brief stop on the way to wherever they are headed. When they began to talk, that was often what they talked about - where they are headed. Texas. Kentucky. Penn State. Pittsburgh. Minnesota. Indiana. Nebraska. Oklahoma. Parris Island.

title: ASHES OF 9,000 ARE FOUND DUMPED ON THE GROUND
description: For many years, thousands of Californians have paid to carry out the last wishes of their dead relatives by having their ashes scattered from an airplane over the Pacific Ocean or among the trees high in the Sierra Nevada.

title: P.S.C. LIMITS COST OF ATOMIC PLANT TO CONSUMERS
description: The New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday that if the cost of building the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant on Lake Ontario exceeded $5.4 billion, the utilities could not require consumers to pay the excess charges.

title: WRONG TIME FOR A PACT ON EAST-WEST STUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE BANK DEREGULATION AND EFFECT ON CONSUMER
description: A banking deregulation bill approved this week that gives state banks broad new investment authority could radically alter the way many banks operate in the state, according to legislators and banking experts. What those changes will mean to consumers and banks remains unclear because the powers given banks are new and untested and because the State Banking Department remains undecided over how those powers will be regulated.

title: MONDALE IN DILEMMA ON JACKSON AS JEWS START TO ASK REPUDIATION
description: Walter F. Mondale appears to be facing a deepening problem in his efforts to strengthen his support among Jews without offending the black constituency of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, which is considered important to Mr. Mondale's chances in November.

title: 200-Mile Race Is Reduced to 168
description: The average speed is expected to be less than 100 miles an hour, the television time slot Sunday is two hours, and the 200-mile Meadowlands Grand Prix for Indianapolis-type cars has been cut to 168 miles.

title: MURDOCH GETS ST. REGIS STAKE
description: The stock of the St. Regis Corporation rose today after Rupert Murdoch confirmed that he had acquired an interest in the paper and forest-products company, which is the nation's largest producer of newsprint. Several analysts speculated that Mr. Murdoch expects to profit handsomely in one way or another, but would not want to integrate St. Regis into his operations.

title: AFGHAN WAR:RUSSIANS TELL OF THE HORROR
description: Two Soviet Army deserters speaking a news conference here today described the fighting in Afghanistan as a ''monstrous war where innocent people are killed on both sides.''

title: No Headline
description: l Margate, N.J.: Offshore bluefishing remains excellent. Many sharks - makos, browns and a few blues - are being caught. Margate Bay fluke angling is still top notch and a few striped bass of 8-l0 pounds are being caught at the bridges. Barnegat, N.J.: Party boats are catching plenty of medium-sized bluefish day and night. Seaside Park, N.J.: Small bluefish common in the surf near Barnegat Inlet and are also being caught from the jetties. A few stripers are being taken on bait - often clams and squid. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Half-day party boat fluke-fishing trips in the ocean continue to produce good catches.

title: CHURCHES AND U.S. CLASH ON ALIEN SANCTUARY
description: Stacey Lynn Merkt, who has become something of a symbol in the conflict between the Federal Government and the growing movement among American churches to aid undocumented aliens, was sentenced today to two years of probation for transporting three Salvadorans who had entered the country illegally.

title: In the Original Hand
description: Matter-of-factly entered between

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This court senses that there may be a substantial change occuring in social attitudes and customs concerning drinking, whether at home or in taverns.

title: GOVERNMENT MOVES TO DROP FOUR CHARGES AGAINST JUDGE
description: The Justice Department moved yesterday to drop four of the seven charges against Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, including the principal charge that he took bribes from the owner of a brothel.

title: ROCK:KING CRIMSON PLAYS CONCERT
description: -concert series, which got under away again Tuesday night with the first of two shows by King Crimson, dates back to 1966. On July 1 of that year Jesse Colin Young and the Youngbloods gave a concert at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. Over the last 19 summers, the sponsors have changed - it's now Miller Beer - and so has the venue, which since 1981 has been Pier 84, jutting out into the Hudson River between 44th and 45th Streets. But the concept of quality acts at reduced prices has remained constant.

title: Holly Sugar
description: The Hunt International Resources Corporation said its Great Western Sugar Company had ended talks with the Holly Sugar Company on Holly's proposed acquisition of some Great Western assets.

title: Computer Merger
description: Inacomp Computer Centers Inc. and Compushop of Georgia Inc. said they had agreed on a merger that will pool 33 computer outlets in four states and Canada.

title: ;  General Mills Debt
description: General Mills Inc. filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of up to $200 million in unsecured debt securities. The company, based in Minneapolis, said terms would be set at the time of sale. The company said it would use the proceeds to pay off debt and for other corporate purposes.

title: Passing Remarks
description: Art Schlichter admits that he occasionally misses the tote boards at race tracks. ''Sometimes I do,'' the former Ohio State and current Indianapolis Colt quarterback said in an interview while he worked out at the Ohio Institute for Sports Medicine and Rehabilitation in Columbus.

title: TOBACCO MAKER CHANGES
description: According to plan, the directors of Philip Morris Inc. yesterday named Hamish Maxwell to succeed George Weissman as chairman and chief executive.

title: THE PRESENT DANGER TO OUR SATELLITES
description: To the Editor:

title: First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp has reached an agreement to acquire the Commercial Alliance Corporation, an independent commercial financing and equipment leasing company based in New York.

title: ;  Citicorp Filings
description: Citicorp and Citicorp Person-to- Person Inc., a subsidiary, filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of up to $250 million in guaranteed subordinated capital notes.

title: Hecht to Open A New Store
description: The Hecht Company, a retailing chain with 23 stores in the Washington-Baltimore area, announced yesterday that it will open a store in downtown Washington in the fall of 1985.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column is currently being written by Ann P. Harris, an advertising writer who has worked as a teacher and journalist.

title: Market Place; The Shakeout In Computers
description: COMPUTERS first captured the public's imagination more than 30 years ago and growth over the years has proceeded at a furious pace. In 1983 alone, companies in all phases of the industry rang up revenues of $110 billion.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Home Depot Debenture
description: Home Depot Inc. said it had agreed to sell $75 million of 8.5 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2009. It said the debentures, which have an interest rate of 8.5 percent a year and mature on July 1, 2009, are convertible at any time before maturity into the company's common stock at $26.50 a share. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the stock closed at $22.25.

title: HOSTAS:JUST PLANT AND FORGET FOR NEARLY PERFECT PERENNIALS
description: IT'S hard to find perfect perennials, but hostas come close.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD IS SET IN GERMAN METAL STRIKE
description: Negotiators reached a tentative settlement today in the 45-day metalworkers' strike that has left 440,000 workers idle and threatened to crimp West Germany's modest economic recovery.

title: MUSIC:OBOIST PLAYS BACH
description: STEPHEN HAMMER is a splendid young musician, one who is equally at home on the recorder and the baroque oboe. Although he specializes in elegant, stylistically authentic performances of baroque material, there is none of the inbred wispiness that so often characterizes such attempts at musicological reconstruction.

title: ICN and Kodak In Joint Venture
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will invest $8.4 million in ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. stock and join the company in drug research involving nucleic acid, the companies said. Kodak will buy all the shares of new classes of convertible preferred stock to be issued by ICN and an ICN subsidiary, Viratek, the companies said.

title: BLOCK ISLAND GETS POWER ON MOPEDS
description: A bill permitting officials on Block Island to regulate mopeds won quick approval in the Rhode Island Legislature today, and a leader of the resort island's drive to secede from the state said that effort would probably die.

title: NEW CAUTIONARY FILM RATING READIED FOR PARENTS
description: The motion picture industry has designed a new movie rating, a category between the current ratings of PG and R, to warn parents to exercise special caution in allowing children under the age of 13 to attend certain movies. The new rating, known as PG-13, will go into effect on Sunday.

title: Center for Sports Is Established
description: Northeastern University has become the first school in the United States to establish a program for the study of sport and its impact on society, called the ''Center for the Study of Sport in Society.''

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Year to March 31
Rise in Japan Exports
description: With car shipments to the United States up 28.2 percent in May from a year earlier, Japan's total motor vehicle exports rose 13.7 percent, to 525,348 cars, trucks and buses last month.

title: HEARINGS ON WESTWAY END, LEAVING DOZENS OF QUESTIONS TO BE CONSIDERED
description: The Army Corps of Engineers official who will rule on a crucial permit for the Westway said yesterday that two days of marathon public hearings had raised dozens of questions about the project.

title: TREASURY ISSUES MOVE HIGHER
description: Prices of Treasury debt issues rebounded yesterday, along with the tax-exempt and corporate bond market. Dealers attributed the turnabout to bargain hunting by investors after it became apparent early in the day that the credit markets were far more liquid than had been thought.

title: No Headline
description: Hippies, Yippies, Yuppies The Mondale and Hart icebergs are melting so fast it's easy to forget all the name-calling just a few weeks ago. Still, one piece of verbal business remains unsettled. What's the right term for all those post-1945 baby-boom voters: yuppies or yumpies?

title: RABE AND THE WAR AT HOME
description: David Rabe built his reputation as a playwright in the 1970's with a trilogy of dramas about the Vietnam War. His acclaimed new work, ''Hurlyburly,'' is a dispatch from a different front - the sexual battlefields of Hollywood. And while Mr. Rabe's subjects may appear wildly different, they share one of his common concerns: the difficulty of manhood.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings for both year- earlier periods reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective March 1.

title: BILL WOULD LET RELIGION GROUPS MEET IN SCHOOL
description: The Senate today voted 88 to 11 to approve a measure that would enable students to hold religious meetings in public high schools before or after regular school hours.

title: CUOMO REVAMPING CONVENTION BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo announced tonight that he was putting four members of his own staff - including his closest friend - on the board of the New York City Convention Center Development Corporation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. GOALBALL TEAM SCORES 2 VICTORIES
description: Reni Jackson's score on a penalty shot late in the second half gave the United States a 4-3 goalball victory over Yugoslavia today in the windup of the 13-nation round-robin schedule of the International Games for the Disabled at Nassau Community College.

title: ...HOW TO PUT A STOP TO ARBITRARY REMOVAL FROM BENEFIT ROLLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreman Tells Trial Of Assurances on Dioxin
description: Employees at the Monsanto Company's Nitro plant were assured that the chemicals they worked with would not hurt them and ignored advice to take safety precautions, a retired foreman testified today,

title: AN OLD LESSON RE-EMPHASIZED AT CREEDMOOR
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT HITLER LIKED ABOUT OBERAMMERGAU'S PLAY
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 28, 1984

title: Appeal Planned
description: Jacinto Vasquez will appeal to the State Supreme Court if the State Racing and Wagering Board accepts a hearing officer's recommendation that Vasquez not be granted a new hearing on his 12-month suspension for attempted bribery, the jockey's attorney said yesterday. David Vaughn, general counsel for the board, said that Harry Snyder, who heard Vasquez's motion for a new hearing two weeks ago, had found ''that Vasquez did not produce sufficient evidence to warrant a new hearing.''

title: POLICE WILL ASSIGN MORE OFFICERS TO FOOT PATROL DUTY NEXT MONTH
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that more officers would be assigned to foot patrol during the next fiscal year, which starts Sunday.

title: OUT TOWN
description: There was a great flurry around Irene Walle last week. The Mayor and the Police Chief of her town stood beside her wheelchair as an affable judge of the Superior Court declared her a citizen of the United States. Flowers were offered and pictures were taken. The nurses and attendants of her nursing home here embraced her and beamed.

title: ISRAEL'S ELECTION RACE:BIG ISSUES IGNITE LITTLE FIRE
description: Israeli politicians say their current election campaign is turning into one of the most peculiar their country has ever seen.

title: FOUR DIE AS PLANE CRASHES IN JERSEY
description: A single-engine plane carrying four passengers crashed between two houses in Lincoln Park, N.J., last night, killing all four people aboard, scorching both houses and setting parked cars on fire, the police said.

title: BALLET CONTEST OPENS
description: The New York International Ballet Competition opened Tuesday at the City Center with not one but two proclamations from the city of New York, an exuberant audience and an interesting evening of dance.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 28, 1984 International
description: Efforts to bolster U.S.-Soviet contacts are being made, President Reagan said. In a White House speech, he said Washington was working to strengthen economic, scientific, cultural, consular and other contacts with Moscow while reserving the right to denounce Soviet actions that threaten peace. (Page A1, Column 6.) Twenty-six Cuban political prisoners will be released by Fidel Castro today if Washington gives them visas and if arrangements can be made to transport them, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said in Managua, Nicaragua. The prisoners, he said, would be in addition to the 22 United States citizens whom Mr. Castro agreed to free early yesterday. (A1:4-5.)

title: BISHOP AND LAWMAKER DEBATE NUCLEAR ARMS
description: In a spirited exchange over the morality of nuclear arms, the churchman and the Congressman narrowed the issues this week but never came to an agreement.

title: A TRIBUTE TO THE DEBONAIR MR. GRANT
description: THE whole thing was Bill Paley's idea. ''That's right, it was my idea,'' said William S. Paley. In 1981, when Cary Grant received one of the Kennedy Center Honors for lifetime achievement in Washington with, among others, Helen Hayes, Mr. Paley, the former chairman of CBS and a good friend of Mr. Grant, huddled with the former movie idol, comedian and actor and suggested that perhaps he wouldn't mind coming up to New York sometime for a similar sort of tribute, this one to be held at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: FILM:'BRADY'S ESCAPE'
description: PAL GABOR'S ''Brady's Escape,'' the World War II adventure film that opens today at the Eastside Cinema and other theaters, is a United States-Hungarian co-production and, like so many of the early European co-productions, it has no real identity of its own. It's a decent, rather characterless movie with more political good will than dramatic impact.

title: ;  A New Consultant
description: Add to the ever-growing roster of consultants the name of Samuel Ferber, who will be doing his thing for the magazine or agency business from 10A, 200 West 58th Street. Mr. Ferber, now 64, was publisher of Esquire from 1974 to 1976 - the job that capped almost 25 years with the magazine. From there he went to Altman, Stoller & Weiss, where he was executive vice president. When that agency was acquired by Nadler & Larimer, a Mickleberry Company, he was named vice president there.

title: No Headline
description: Panel Assails Reagan On Job Rights Policy

title: FESTIVAL EVENTS SCHEDULED TODAY
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events. 5 P.M. Carnegie Recital Hall. Kenny Burwell, guitar; $8.50. 8 P.M. Carnegie Hall.

title: THE THING TO FEAR IS TOO MUCH SECURITY
description: The lines have become routine now, snaking back from the metal detectors, outside the Capitol and across the open plaza.

title: French Lift Wage Floor
description: The French Government said today that it would raise the minimum legal hourly wage by 1.2 percent effective July 1. The Minister for European Affairs, Roland Dumas, said after the weekly Cabinet meeting that the increase would bring the minimum hourly wage to 23.84 francs, or about $2.80.

title: RACAL ELECTRONICS PLC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5,190,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,000.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-2 stock split effective Oct. 7, 1983.

title: Pride Close to a Fall
description: Unless a buyer is found by July 17 for the Phoenix Pride, which plays in the Major Indoor Soccer League, the team will not operate next season. Bruce Merrill , the team owner, said he would not submit the $250,000 letter of credit the league requires by Saturday in order to keep the team on the active list. Merrill said he lost $2.2 million last season.

title: 70 Years of Matrimony
description: Beatrice and William Votaw were

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATES LETTER SENT TO DELOREAN JURORS
description: A letter to a Congressman that has set off an investigation into possible jury tampering in the drug trial of John Z. DeLorean was signed with the apparently fictitious name of ''William Frinkhouser,'' according to sources close to the investigation.

title: SCOUTING
description: Elitists Welcome

title: Romance Blossoms In Central Park
description: When Theodore Courtney Rogers

title: DEMOCRAT FROM QUEENS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the latest Democrat to be interviewed as Vice-Presidential possibility . . . born Aug. 26, 1935, in Newburgh, N.Y. . . . Italian immigrant father who owned a restaurant-bar died when she was 8 . . . mother worked as crochet beader to put two children through school . . . keeps maiden name in public life in gratitude for her mother's hard work . . . attended Marymount School in Tarrytown . . . went on to Marymount Manhattan College . . . earned a Fordham University law degree at night by working as public school teacher . . . will celebrate 24th anniversary of marriage to John Zaccaro, real estate broker, on the opening day of Democratic convention . . . worked in private law firm while bringing up three children . . . joined Queens District Attorney's office . . . first ran for Congress in 1978 from conservative Queens district that was the fictional site for ''All in the Family'' television series . . . won three-sided Democratic primary . . . a Roman Catholic who takes a pro-choice stand on abortion . . . member of Budget Committee . . . in 1980 ran for secretary of the Democratic Caucus and also became a member of the Policy and Steering Committee . . . held position in Carter-Mondale campaign in 1980 . . . concentrated most of her legislative energies on economic issues of interest to women.

title: TIGHT TIME LIMIT IS BARRED IN A RIGHTS CASE
description: The Supreme Court today cautioned Federal judges against allowing state-imposed procedural barriers to keep civil rights lawsuits out of Federal court.

title: DISABILTY:NO 'LAWLESS' GOVERNMENT STANCE...
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAWAY MARKS A 25TH BIRTHDAY AMID TROUBLES
description: Saluting a century of dreamers who worked to build the St. Lawrence Seaway, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, at the dedication in 1959, said their work was a ''magnificent symbol to the entire world of the achievement possible to democratic nations.''

title: U.S. School Drug Plan
description: Attorney General William French Smith announced today a drug abuse prevention program designed to reach 5.5 million United States high school athletes. A key component of the progam is a package of drug abuse prevention materials that the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration will

title: ONE MAN'S SHOW OF FURNITURE
description: HIS name is Sinya Okayama, and he is seated above on ''Crocodile,'' a silver-colored vinyl bench that has small colored lights where one might expect to find upholstery buttons. The bench is only one of the interesting pieces in a one-man show by the designer, who is from Osaka, Japan.

title: Topics Shameless
description: Bad Ethics, Bad Law

title: COVERT LESSONS
description: When a popular President wraps a policy in anti- Communist rhetoric, he does not often lose in Congress. So it was an event when the Senate this week joined the House in voting against further support for the covert war on Nicaragua. President Reagan lost, and it is important to consider why.

title: MRS. FERRARO WOULD ALLOW NOMINATION AS 'STATEMENT'
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Forest Hills, N.Y., the chairman of the Democratic platform committee, said today that she would permit her name to be offered for the Democratic Vice- Presidential nomination, but not as a challenge to Walter F, Mondale's choice.

title: Cosmos Defeated, 4-0
description: The Toronto Blizzard, who were shut out in their last two North American Soccer League games, tonight shut out the Cosmos, 4-0, ending a three-game losing streak. The defeat ended the four-game winning streak of the Cosmos (6-3).

title: TICKET BATTLE IS HEATING UP
description: Since last fall Ticketron, New York's giant of computerized ticket reservations, has seen four large chunks of business snatched away by a feisty four-year-old company that only recently broke into the New York market. Their rivalry is becoming fierce, according to followers of this lucrative industry.

title: New Orleans Fair Fund Passes Legislature
description: The Legislature gave final approval today to a $17.5 million loan guarantee for the critically acclaimed but financially ailing World's Fair.

title: SOVIET LINKS:REAGAN SHIFT
description: Although President Reagan said today that the United States had not forgotten Afghanistan, his speech signaled his inclination to end most of the sanctions imposed by Washington after the Soviet Union sent 100,000 troops into Afghanistan in December 1979. ''This kicks off a new era, considering where this Administration was,'' a State Department official said. ''They've come around 180 degrees.'' Another official said it was ironic that President Carter, who came to office without any anti-Soviet bias, ran for re- election in 1980 after having virtually cut off all high-level contacts with Moscow. Mr. Reagan, known for his strong anti-Soviet views, will now be campaigning for re-election offering to put new life into most of the accords worked out by President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger during the period of detente.

title: F.C.C. EASES RULES FOR BROADCAST TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission today lifted its longstanding requirements that television stations broadcast minimum amounts of news and local programing and limit the time devoted to commercials.

title: ST AUGUSTINE SPLIT ON PRESERVATION
description: The past and future are at war in the nation's oldest city.

title: CAREY SETS WORLD RECORD IN BACKSTROKE
