description: Rick Carey, a 21-year-old Texas senior from Mount Kisco, N.Y., broke his world record tonight in the men's 200- meter backstroke. It was the third world record on the first three nights of the United States Olympic swimming trials.

title: Orioles 3, Red Sox 1BALTIMORE (AP) - Scott McGregor held off Boston for 8Z innings, and Gary Roenicke hit a home run in a rare start against a right- handed pitcher to lead Baltimore. McGregor (9-6), who was rapped for 10 earned runs and 19 hits over 8Y innings in his previous two starts, allowed 11 Red Sox hits. He escaped frequent jams but left with two outs in the ninth when Dwight Evans singled with the bases loaded to drive in Boston's run. Roenicke, a right-handed batter, connected off Roger Clemens in the fourth. The Orioles scored twice in the eighth, aided by an error by the center fielder Tony Armas and a catcher's interference. Boston's Bill Buckner singled in the second for his 2,000th major league hit.;  Brewers 5, Blue Jays 1
description: Robin Yount, Cecil Cooper, Ben Oglivie and Ted Simmons stroked successive run- scoring singles in a five-run first inning to help Milwaukee complete a four-game sweep of Toronto. The Brewers hold a 6-0 edge this season over the Blue Jays, who have lost six of their last eight games.

title: NETWORKS GIVE RULING LITTLE IMPACT
description: Executives at CBS and NBC said yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission ruling that will permit television stations to air as many commercials as they wish would have little effect.

title: Antinuclear Group Asks Defeat of 12 Republicans
description: The Council for a Livable World, founded by nuclear scientists concerned about nuclear war, listed a dozen Republican House members as a ''Doomsday Dozen'' worthy of defeat.

title: STATE DEPT. SAYS SOME OF 22 ARE WANTED BY POLICE IN U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration minimized today the significance of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's meeting with President Fidel Castro that produced the promised release of 22 Americans in Cuban jails.

title: THE RISING FORCE OF WOMEN'S PACS
description: When Ann Richards was considering a last-minute entry into the Texas race for State Treasurer two years ago, she wanted to be sure she could raise enough money for a serious campaign. The trouble was that Miss Richards, then a County Commissioner, had a political base composed mainly of women and, she said, ''women will give you votes but not money.''

title: 'Graffiti Rock' Tunes In On the Hip-Hop Culture
description: ''Graffiti Rock'' brings an ''American Bandstand'' format to the hip-hop culture - break dancing, rapping, graffiti art and ''scratching'' disk jockeys. The half-hour show, tonight at 8 on Channel 11, includes teen- agers dancing to records, a glimpse of sneaker-lacing fashion, exhibition dancing from the New York City Breakers and raps from the team of Run-D.M.C. and from two-thirds of the Treacherous Three, all against graffiti-style backdrops by Brim Fuentes.

title: Early Rally Falters; Dow Drops 6.07
description: Stock prices struggled to the plus side in early trading yesterday, but the rally faded.

title: SALVADORAN DENIES ROLE IN PLOT AGAINST ENVOY
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist, said today that he believed there had been a plot to assassinate the United States Ambassador to El Salvador but that he was not involved. He told reporters he had ''helped to avoid such a terrible thing'' by denouncing it in public.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Esmark Executive Ousted by Beatrice
description: Frederick B. Rentschler, president and chief executive officer of Swift/ Hunt-Wesson Foods, an Esmark Inc. unit, was odd man out yesterday as the Beatrice Companies, Esmark's new owner, announced organizational changes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day June 15 about the General Electric Credit Corporation misstated the position of John W. Stanger. He is the vice chairman and has announced plans to retire at the end of 1984.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS PUT 24-HOUR CAMERAS IN CELLS
description: A black student activist, released recently from detention, says the South African police have installed closed- circuit television cameras in cells to provide 24-hour surveillance of those held under the country's security laws.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on June 18 about the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. incorrectly described its connection with Constance Baker Motley, Chief Judge of the United States District Court in Manhattan. She was once a lawyer with the fund.

title: CHURCH AND CIVIL RIGHTS GROUPS ASSAIL NEW REMARK BY FARRAKHAN
description: Major non-Jewish organizations, including the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the White House, joined Jewish leaders yesterday in condemning the latest remarks by Louis Farrakhan, the leader of a Black Muslim group, who called Judaism a ''gutter religion'' and denounced Israel and its supporters as ''a criminal conspiracy.''

title: Teachers View Their Profession
description: Ninety-six of every 100 teachers

title: Continental Line of Credit
description: The Continental Group Inc. said it had signed a $2 billion revolving credit agreement with 22 banks. It said the funds would be used ''for a wide range of corporate purposes.''

title: The No-Oil Drill
description: There's a long list of necessary projects that everyone favors somewhere else - building things like prisons, mental hospitals, drug clinics, waste- disposal units, power plants. Now please add a national necessity: offshore oil drilling. Congress is all for it off other people's coasts.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES BANK RULES
description: The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill that would halt moves by commercial businesses into banking, while giving banks powers to expand into other financial services.

title: YANKEES RALLY TO BEAT TIGERS
description: The Yankees resuscitated themselves in time last night for a victory and perhaps they learned something about how to go forward in the rest of this long season.

title: East and West Agree On Pollution Fight
description: A major East-West environment conference agreed today on a joint strategy to fight air pollution, but without committing participants to any specific targets on cutting industrial emissions.

title: E.E.C. Steel Output Up
description: Crude steel production in the European Economic Community rose to 11.6 million tons in May, up a seasonally adjusted 2.9 percent from April and up 8.3 percent from a year earlier, the E.E.C.'s statistical agency, Eurostat, said today. Greek figures were not included.

title: No Accord On Copper
description: The International Trade Commission, which has recommended that American copper producers be given relief from imports, failed today to reach a consensus on how that relief should be accomplished. On June 14, the commission recommended to President Reagan that copper imports to the United States be restricted because the American industry was being harmed.

title: ; D'Arcy MacManus Set For Direct Marketing
description: These days the popular agency communications diversification is into direct marketing.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
STRETCHING FRAMES THAT ARE VERSATILE
description: A NEW system of aluminum stretchers called Starofix, invented by two European specialists in painting restoration, is designed to virtually eliminate warping in large paintings. While stretching canvas is its main purpose, Starofix, because of its relative ease of assembly, can be used to create folding panels or doors covered with decorative fabric for large spaces, a temporary backdrop for displays and theater backdrops.

title: Bridge: The Shadow, a Radio Hero
description: Survivors of the Age of Radio will recall a sinister voice that regularly announced, ''The Shadow knows.'' The Shadow, a Superman type of hero, had the ability to cloud the minds of villains while viewing everything himself with perfect clarity.

title: SCOUTING
description: Gate Dancing

title: Warehouse Burns on Coast
description: Four boys using matches to light aerosol cans touched off a fire Tuesday night that engulfed a warehouse full of motor oil and caused an estimated $1 million in damage, officials said today.

title: FRANCE BEATS SPAIN IN SOCCER FINAL, 2-0
description: France, never a soccer power during its 80 years in the sport, won its first major title tonight by defeating Spain, 2-0, in the final of the European championship.

title: The U.N. Today June 28, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MYOPIA ON TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: Rushing to judgment is an American trait that at times can be dangerous but more often is just plain short- sighted. A current example is the almost frantic nationwide campaign to raise the age for purchasing alcoholic beverages to 21.

title: STUDY ASSAILS TRANSIT PURCHASING
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn charged in a report yesterday that ''serious managerial deficiencies'' in the Transit Authority's purchasing unit had ''created the climate that allowed'' a bid-rigging scheme to operate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rick Vaive , the Toronto Maple Leafs' captain, has signed a new contract that includes performance bonuses that will not go into effect unless the team makes the Stanley Cup playoffs. . . . Tal Smith , who has served as president of the Yankees and general manager of the Houston Astros, will become an important part of the Cleveland Indian front office after the team is sold to David LeFevre , a New York lawyer. . . . The Dallas Cowboys are working on restructuring the final four years of Tony Dorsett 's contract to provide their star running back with more money when his playing days are over. . . . Commissioners Doug Mitchell of the Canadian Football League and Pete Rozelle of the National Football League have agreed to continue to honor an unwritten agreement that bars the leagues from tampering with each other's players, but Pete Hadhazy , operations director for the United States Football League, says his league will continue to try to sign C.F.L. talent. . . . The Los Angeles Express of the U.S.F.L. is for sale and General Manager Don Klosterman , The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported yesterday, has talked with Jerry Buss , owner of the city's basketball Lakers and the hockey Kings.

title: Reports of Insider Trading
description: The New York and American stock exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: 2 BIG BANDS ON ONE BILL
description: TWO big bands based on contrasting approaches shared the stage at Carnegie Hall in a Kool Jazz Festival program Tuesday evening. A justifiably named All-Star band led by the saxophonist and arranger Benny Carter was focused on his arranging talent and Illinois Jacquet's Jazz Legends Big Band was a riffing setting for soloists.

title: Pottery for a Computer
description: ''Good swap,'' said Mike Crawford,

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: General Strike Brings Montevideo to a Halt

title: Morton Loses Job
description: In what the team's owner, Doug Spedding , called ''a friendly parting of the ways,'' Craig Morton ended his stay as head coach of the Denver Gold. ''We made a deal that would mutually release each other from the contract,'' Spedding said.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $540,000 for the quarter and $1,890,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $94,000 and $237,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday on House passage of a bill to renew the Clean Water Act misstated the vote. It was a recorded vote of 405 to 11.

title: 3-D QUARTER GAINS SEEN BY REGAN
description: In a preview of the Administration's official mid-year forecast, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he expected the economy to grow at a robust rate of about 4 1/2 percent during the third quarter, a crucial period in the election campaign.

title: O'NEILL HOME ON COAST TO OPEN AS MUSEUM
description: Tao House, where Eugene O'Neill wrote some of his greatest plays, will become a museum open to the public in January.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.5 million for the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared Oct. 25, 1983.

title: GARMENT CENTER FUTURE AT STAKE IN THE DEBATE ON TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: Since the end of World War II, as its skyline has grown and its factories have emptied, the rich southern half of Manhattan has traded a blue-collar past for a white-collar future.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Greenwood & Co., a precision valve company in Houston, said it had agreed to acquire Sarasin et Cie. S.A., a safety valve manufacturer near Lille, France, subject to certain conditions including French Government approval.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
F.A.A. CHIEF HOLDS AIRWAYS ARE SAFE
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration testified today that the nation's air traffic controllers were overworked but that the conditions did not threaten passengers' safety.

title: BRIEFING
description: Swing Your Patriotism

title: Australian Output Up
description: Australia's manufacturing sector recorded continued growth in May, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said today. Eighteen of the 26 key items for which seasonally adjusted figures are available recorded increases from April and 23 of the 26 improved from a year earlier, the agency said. The steel, housing, automobile, yarn and textile industries all recorded significant increases from a month earlier and a year earlier, the bureau said.

title: JACKSON SAYS CUBA OFFERS TO FREE 26 DETAINED AS POLITICAL PRISONERS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that President Fidel Castro of Cuba would release 26 Cuban political prisoners on Thursday if the United States gives them visas and if arrangements can be made to fly them there.

title: COMMON MARKET CHIEF PRAISED FOR PRAGMATISM
description: The resolution of the Common Market budget crisis, many commentators said today, points Europe's leaders toward a more realistic approach of what the community can, and cannot, do to strengthen Europe, which is now economically battered and politically restive.

title: ;  People
description: * Louis M. Schultz has been named executive vice president and director of media services for Campbell- Ewald.

title: Unimar Purchases Control Of Enstar
description: The Unimar Company said yesterday that it had purchased 14.3 million common shares of the Enstar Corporation for $286 million, giving it control of the Houston oil and gas concern.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS VOW TO FIGHT ON
description: Leaders of Nicaraguan rebel groups said today that the Senate decision on Monday against providing them additional aid would not immediately cripple their movements. They said they had already begun to seek money elsewhere.

title: ALBANY LEADERS DRAFT A PROPOSAL ON MALPRACTICE
description: Key legislators announced an agreement today on a measure to make it easier to discipline doctors in New York State charged with improper practices. The bill would create new avenues to move quickly against physicians who have been convicted of felonies or whose licenses have been suspended or revoked in other states. It would also give the state's Board for Professional Medical Conduct the authority to require physicians to underdo medical or psychiatric examinations if these were deemed necessary. A companion measure would raise licensing fees for physicians to pay for a program to deal with drug abuse, alcoholism or psychiatric problems among doctors. The licensing fees would go up by $10, to provide $350,000. The rehabilitation program would be run by the state's medical society.

title: Cocaine Seized in Houston
description: Nine men dressed in black were arrested today as they prepared to unload 237 pounds of cocaine from a Colombian freighter in the Houston Ship Channel. A police officer, Roland Johnson, said the cocaine was packed in pound bags labeled for street delivery.

title: POISONING POPULATION ASSISTANCE
description: In the last few weeks, there has been a concerted attack on the overall usefulness of international population assistance.

title: Corco Marine In Chapter 11
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said its Corco Marine Inc. unit had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Commonwealth Oil also said it may have to file for bankruptcy if its proposed recapitalization plan is not completed.

title: RULING ADDS OPTIONS FOR COLLEGES AND TELEVISION
description: The nation's major football colleges were busy reviewing their television options yesterday, assessing which of several contingency plans would prove most satisfactory to them and also acceptable to the courts.

title: ;  Addendum
description: * Kallir, Philips, Ross, a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, has opened a Brussels office called KPR S.A.

title: DELOREAN TRIAL JUDGE
description: When jurors unexpectedly disclosed Tuesday that they had received unsolicited copies of a Congressional report on undercover investigations, an event with potentially serious implications in the drug trial of John Z. DeLorean, Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi reacted with his usual restraint, refraining from comment about the impact on the trial.

title: 'JUNK BOND' MARKET GROWING
description: Suddenly investment bankers are scrambling to get into a business they had traditionally shunned - the underwriting and trading of ''junk bonds.''

title: SWISS TANKER IS REPORTED HIT IN GULF
description: A Swiss-owned supertanker was hit in the Persian Gulf today, apparently by an Exocet missile fired from an Iraqi warplane, and the ship's engine room was set on fire after the vessel had loaded Iranian oil at the Kharg Island terminal, shipping sources said.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including an extraordinary net gain of $173,000 representing proceeds of officer's life insurance.

title: Final Cuts Made For U.S. Team
description: The United States Olympic men's basketball team will include Chris Mullin, the scoring star from St. John's, and Jeff Turner, the first-round draft choice of the Nets.

title: Carter Vows to Shun Convention Spotlight
description: Former President Jimmy Carter says he will attend the Democratic National Convention next month and might make ''a brief address'' but plans to keep out of Walter F. Mondale's spotlight.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
description: b-Net income.

title: RECESSION IS SEEN HARMING HEALTH
description: The overall health of Americans is likely to be poorer for years as a result of the deep economic recession in 1981 and 1982, according to a Johns Hopkins University professor who conducted a study for Congress that was released yesterday.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: for removing paint, varnish or other finishes; for cleaning off rust or corrosion; for smoothing or shaping wood, metal or rigid plastics. All abrasive papers have one thing in common: None contains sand.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alpha Industries, Woburn, Mass., a manufacturer of microwave components and devices, has elected Allan L. Coon and Constantine Kamnitsis senior vice presidents.

title: 3 VILLAGES ARE DISPUTED ON THAI-LAOTIAN BORDER
description: A dispute over three remote villages on the border of Thailand and Laos has given rise to the latest armed confrontation in Southeast Asia.

title: MET MUSEUM GETS $2.5 MILLION TO ADD CENTER
description: The Henry Luce Foundation Inc. has made a $2.5 million grant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to add a study center to the American Wing, museum officials said yesterday.

title: THE COOKIE CUTTER AS A COLLECTIBLE
description: Rosemary Clapham has a fondness for cookie cutters, and when she and others like her hold a convention, they're eager to make deals.

title: SCOUTING
description: Reading, Writing And Discounts

title: ;  Bates Branches Abroad
description: Ted Bates Worldwide has bought half of Entente Delacroix, a group of eight European agencies, which it describes as ''highly creative.'' The owner of the other half is Oliver Dassault International Communications, another European company. ''It is our intent to grow more rapidly throughout Europe,'' said Robert E. Jacoby, chairman and chief expansionist at Bates.

title: Gannett Moving
description: The Gannett Company, which owns 89 newspapers nationwide and publishes USA Today, said it had begun moving its corporate headquarters from Rochester to Virginia.

title: PUTTING A NEW SHINE ON A CHANDELIER
description: SINCE chandeliers are usually electrified and made of fragile crystal or glass, their cleaning and repair is delicate business. ''Chandelier maintenance requires a rare combination of talents,'' said the lighting specialist Michael Pell of Custom Lamp Mounters in Manhattan. ''The person must understand how it works electrically but also must be good at cleaning.''

title: ; Pontiac to Sponsor Hall and Oates Tour
description: In an effort to endear itself to the group centered around the median age of 34, Pontiac is going to sponsor a national tour of Daryl Hall and John Oates, the No. 1 rock duo. Pontiac's sleek little Fiero sports car will be the focal point of the promotion.

title: Half a Jackson Transcript
description: Q: Reverend Jackson, you keep giving the idea that you scorn Jews. If you really want to escape that impression, why don't you at last dissociate yourself from Louis Farrakhan? Don't you think it reflects on you when this political intimate calls Judaism a ''gutter religion'' and supporters of Israel ''part of a criminal conspiracy''?

title: Technology; Medical Role For the Nose
description: THE nose has often inspired mirth. Jimmy Durante, for example. The nose also has a certain social status, as in nose jobs or cocaine. And there is the common medical aspect: runny nose and breathing.

title: Record Field at Henley
description: The blue and white striped boat tents are filled with a record 305 entries for Thursday's opening races of the 135th Henley Royal Regatta. The town of Henley nestles in the bucolic tranquillity of the Oxfordshire Hills, through which the Thames River course flows, and the regatta itself beckons back to an era when rowing and other sports were

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $141,844. c-Including a tax credit of $88,694. d-Net income.

title: Oregon Court Reverses Holding on Guru's Town
description: The Oregon Court of Appeals has reversed itself, saying it was wrong when it upheld the incorporation of Rajneeshpuram, a town founded by followers of an Indian guru.

title: JERSEY BID FOR YANKS CALLED PRELIMINARY
description: The Yankees have been approached by New Jersey sports officials about a possible move across the Hudson River, but the talks were ''very, very, very preliminary,'' said a spokesman for Governor Kean's office.

title: Belgian Prices Rise
description: Wholesale prices in Belgium rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May from April and were up 10.6 percent from a year earlier, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: WON WIDE ACCLAIM AS EXPERT ON BRIDGE
description: Oswald Jacoby, who was considered one of the best contract bridge players of all time, died yesterday in Dallas. He was 81 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Hamsho Goes to Court
description: The No. 1 ranked middleweight, Mustafa Hamsho , frustrated by his failure to get a title fight, filed suit against the world middleweight champion, Marvin Hagler , in Brooklyn Federal Court. Hamsho is seeking to prevent Hagler from making any other title defenses and has petitioned the World Boxing Council to strip Hagler of his crown for not making a mandatory title defense.W.B.C. rules state that a champion must defend against the No. 1 challenger every six months.

title: NEW CARE LABELS TO PROTECT CLOTHING
description: IN 1978, hundreds of consumers

title: Phone Sales Rule Relaxed
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to give the American Telephone & Telegraph Company and its former Bell companies additional leeway in their efforts to market telephone equipment and certain services.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA IS TESTED BUT WINS
description: Success against Martina Navratilova is measured in small and sometimes insignificant ways: the number of points and games won, the length of the match, the amount of concern she shows.

title: CONGRESS FAILS TO ACT ON BANKRUPTCH SYSTEM
description: The nation's bankruptcy courts went out of business at midnight Wednesday, as Congress failed to meet a deadline for extending their authority.

title: Funeral Held For Overstreet
description: Funeral services for David Overstreet, a Miami Dolphins running back, were held today in a prayerful, tearful ceremony at the small-town high school where he starred in football in the mid-1970's.

title: Court Rejects Payne's Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court rejected today attempts by Tom Payne, the former University of Kentucky basketball player who was imprisoned for 10 years for rape, to have his convictions overturned.

title: Murder Suspect Shifts Plea in Middle of Trial
description: James R. Kearns, accused as a contract killer, pleaded guilty today to a botched attempt to murder a Federal prosecutor and accepted a plea bargain agreement that spares his wife from prosecution in the case.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ABSTRACTS There are no more concrete realities on the American art scene than abstract art, and this is substantially documented in a big new exhibition that opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street (570-3676).

title: U.S. TRACES USE OF ENERGY IN HOME
description: At the end of a hot day, a majority of American homeowners can relax in air-conditioned comfort, but a new Government study says half of all rental households do not enjoy that luxury.

title: 'FIRST EDITION' SERIES, ON WRITERS AND BOOKS
description: THE series ''First Edition,'' which got started on cable, is now being made available to public television audiences.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES TAX RISE
description: The House and the Senate today approved a four-year, $50 billion tax increase and a $13 billion package of spending cuts - a major portion of this year's deficit-reduction effort.

title: ; El Al Switches Account to Korey, Kay
description: El Al Israel Airlines, which almost 30 years ago became an early beneficiary of the outstanding creative work of Doyle Dane Bernbach, has decided, as other clients have previously decided, that the agency has gotten too big for them.

title: C.D. Rates Still Climb
description: As New York's largest banks continued their rate war, annual effective yields on six-month certificates of deposit and money market deposit accounts climbed further in the week ended yesterday, the Bank Rate Monitor said. The increases come on the heels of the year's fourth increase in the prime rate.

title: ;  Fared Robot Systems Names New President
description: Harold D. Spidle, 49, who has just been named president and chief executive of Fared Robot Systems Inc., of Arlington, Tex., was not in his office yesterday. He was on the road with a marketing vice president to talk to potential customers such as the International Business Machines Corporation, the General Motors Corporation and the Whirlpool Corporation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN REMARKS ON SOVIET TIES
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan today to the Conference on U.S.-Soviet Exchange, as recorded by the White House press office:

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TIME FOR ACTIVE WAITING
description: Now that the U.S. Administration says it's eager for all kinds of talks with the Russians, Moscow has buttoned up tightly.

title: Taxi or Transit?
description: Four panelists gathered yesterday

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Cuomo Says the Keynote Will Reflect His Ideas
description: Governor Cuomo said today that Walter F. Mondale would have no veto power over his keynote address to the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco next month.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N.V. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-earlier results are stated on a pro forma basis due to the merger of WTC Inc. into WTC International N.V. on March 1.

title: POLAND IS CRITIZED BY AN I.L.O. INQUIRY FOR SOLIDARITY CURB
description: A special commission of the International Labor Organization said in a report made public today that the Polish Government had violated treaty obligations to guarantee trade union freedom.

title: 1,500 JOBS TO BE CUT BY MERRILL
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, seeking to cut costs in the face of slower trading on Wall Street, announced yesterday that it would reduce its work force by an additional 1,500 employees this year through layoffs and attrition. The world's largest securities firm, which said it is seeking to save $200 million in expenses in 1984, has already shrunk its work force by 1,000, to 43,000, since March.

title: ALFONSIN, IN TURNAROUND, CALLS FOR MORE AUSTERITY
description: President Raul Alfonsin, in a turnaround from his insistence that Argentines had suffered enough, called tonight on his country's citizens for greater economic sacrifice.

title: SYRIA-ISRAEL DEAL ON PRISONERS REPORTED
description: Syria and Israel have agreed to exchange war prisoners, Syria's official press agency reported today.

title: AMID CONGRESS DEBATE, NAVY GETS CRUISE MISSILES
description: The Defense Department announced today that the first long-range nuclear cruise missiles had been deployed on Navy ships in recent days.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $230,957 for the quarter and $195,282 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the 9 months.

title: GREAT RED HOPES IN THE OLYMPICS
description: Peter V. Ueberroth flew into town

title: Schorr Urges Restraint In TV Coverage
description: Daniel Schorr, a longtime broadcaster, challenged the television industry Tuesday to reconsider its ''circus'' of round-the-clock coverage of terrorist incidents.

title: AIR FORCE SEEKING A SHUTTLE BACKUP
description: The space shuttle Discovery will probably be grounded for at least three more weeks. Page A18.

title: GIANT COAST THRIFT UNIT IS CHARGED IN LAWSUIT
description: A retired construction worker, his son and his daughter-in-law have charged the Financial Corporation of America with several counts of racketeering, conspiracy and security law violations that they contend caused them to lose a $472,500 investment in a construction company.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings reflect for a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid July 10 subject to shareholders' approval yesterday.

title: Missouri River Reaches Its Highest Flood Level
description: The flooding Missouri River crested in Omaha today at the highest level ever recorded here in summertime after covering thousands of acres of nearby farmland.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Tanzania Bus Crash Kills 33
description: A bus hit a tree on Monday at Bukoba on Lake Victoria in northwest Tanzania, killing 33 people and injuring 74, the Tanzanian radio said today.

title: ;  Jones Intercable Debenture Filing
description: Jones Intercable Inc. said it had filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. relating to a proposed public offering of $30 million of subordinated debentures. The company said the offering will be co-managed by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. and A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc.

title: FULLER, H.B. CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $86,000 for the quarter and $32,000 for the 6 months, a net provision of $435,000 for the 6 months from disposal of worldwide Multi- Clean operations and an extraordinary net loss for the 6 months of $729,000 on assets in Lebanon. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $98,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 6 months.

title: Debt Issues
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., has completed an exchange of 324,165 shares of its common shares for l.9 million principal amount of its 7 5/8 percent debentures and $6.3 million of its Deutschmark denominated debt, all owned by Lazard Fr eres & Co.

title: U.S. Assets Overseas Up
description: The United States posted a decline of $43.6 billion in its net international investment position in 1983, the Government said today.

title: REAGAN OUTLINES STEPS TO IMPROVE TIES WITH MOSCOW
description: Excerpts from remarks, page A12.

title: U.S. PARLEY WITH NICARAGUA ENDS IN MEXICO
description: Representatives of the United States and Nicaragua ended two days of meetings at a Mexican resort town Tuesday night but offered no details of their discussions.

title: Curb on Entrapment Defense Held Constitutional in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of the revision in the state criminal code that narrows the use of an entrapment defense.

title: Knicks Bid for Pat Cummings
description: The Knicks, in need of big men, have signed Pat Cummings, the 6-foot-9-inch Dallas Maverick center- forward, to an offer sheet worth more than $2 million. The four-year offer, which includes a fifth-year option clause and a one-year no-trade clause, was agreed to by Cummings last Sunday in Cape Cod, at the home of Bob Woolf, his lawyer.

title: SUPERVALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $137,000 and a gain of $24,163,000 from disposal of County Seat Stores Inc. c-After net from discontinued operations of $627,000.

title: WIDE RANGE OF OPTIONS AT STRATFORD FESTIVAL
description: STRATFORD, Ontario

title: ADVERTISING McCann Loses B-F, Adds Heublein
description: -F Spirits, marketing division of Brown-Forman Distillers, announced yesterday morning that it is splitting with McCann-Erickson, which has been its agency for 13 years. Then before the day was over Heublein reported that it was switching its business to McCann from Marschalk.

title: THE PRESS:HOW TO USE IT OR LOSE IT
description: Journalism, which is accustomed to dishing it out, was a serious preoccupation here this week at two conferences that seemed to underline a love-hate relationship between the news business and conservative groups. In each case, it seemed, the group felt wronged by journalists but admitted it would dearly like to use them as an educational tool.

title: BRINGING IT ALL TOGETHER IN ONE ROOM
description: -story town house filled with antique furniture, artworks, books and all manner of memorabilia. Now he lives in one large room filled with many of the same antiques, artworks, books and memorabilia.

title: HIGH COURT ENDS N.C.A.A. CONTROL OF TV FOOTBALL
description: The Supreme Court today ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 33- year reign over the televising of college football.

title: Knight Is Offering $1 Million For Campus Press Program
description: The Journalists in Residence program at the University of Michigan will get a $1 million donation from Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. and the Knight Foundation if the school can match the gift, the company said Tuesday.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICA COS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
METS DROP TO 2D
description: Dwight Gooden, the 19-year-old prize pupil of the Mets, got his first look at the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, and regretted it.

title: ARGENTINA ACTS TO END IMPASSE
description: Argentina made an 11th-hour effort today to come to terms with the International Monetary Fund over an austerity program that the lending agency is demanding for Argentina to qualify for emergency credits.

title: BIT PLAYERS STAND IN FOR ELECTED STARS ON THE BOARD OF ESTIMATE'S STAGE
description: Every other Thursday at City Hall, a Cornell-trained economist from upstate who looks younger than his 28 years sits in a tall leather chair that is capped by a carved eagle. At that moment, in that place, the economist, John J. Gilbert 3d, is the Mayor of the City of New York.

title: South Africa's Ruling Party Loses to Right in Rural Vote
description: The governing National Party lost a key provincial by-election today to a right-wing coalition but strengthened its majority in another.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day June 4 about utility name changes misidentified the main subsidiary of the Florida Progress Corporation. It is the Florida Power Corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary last Saturday, of a former writer for Better Homes and Gardens and The Ladies' Home Journal, misidentified her. She was Gladys Denny Shultz.

title: MEASURE WOULD LET GROCERY STORES SELL A WINE BEVERAGE
description: Grocery stores and supermarkets in New York State would be allowed to sell a diluted wine drink with the same alcohol content as beer under a bill legislative leaders have agreed to pass.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY JACKSON
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Rev. Jesse Jackson concerning remarks by Louis Farrakhan, issued here today by Walter E. Fauntroy, a Jackson adviser:

title: Bundesbank Raises Rate
description: The West German central bank unexpectedly raised the country's discount rate today for the first time since 1980 to counter United States interest rates and protect its currency against further rises by the strong United States dollar. Central banks in Austria and Sweden quickly followed suit.

title: U.S. Takes 2 Goalball Titles
description: Reni Jackson and Jim Neppl each scored a goal in the shootout today as the United States retained its world championship in men's goalball with a 2-0 victory over Egypt at the International Games for the Disabled at Mitchel Park.

title: A FAIRER REALTY TAX FOR SMALL BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Garland Tribute
description: A tribute to the pianist Red Garland, who died this year, will be presented this weekend at the Jazz Center of New York (924-5026), 380 Lafayette Street, near Great Jones (East Third) Street. Tonight from 5 to 8:30, the pianist Phineas Newborn Jr. and the guitarist Chuck Wayne will perform; from 9:30 P.M. to midnight the alto saxophonist Lou Donaldson will lead his quintet, and the tenor saxophonist George Coleman will lead a quartet.

title: SATELLITE-TO-HOME PLAN IS ABANDONED BY CBS
description: CBS Inc., which two years ago raced to be one of the first communications companies authorized to build a satellite-to-home television system, yesterday abandoned the project, citing ''some open questions and the risks involved.''

title: 2 FIRMS SAY EUROBOND FRAUD COST $8.3 MILLION
description: Fraudulent Eurobond transactions by traders for two international securities firms have resulted in a total loss of about $8.3 million, officials of the firms said yesterday.

title: Panel Backs Fed Nominee
description: On a 10-8 party-line vote, the Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of Martha Seger, an economics professor at Central Michigan University, to be a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: EXCERPTS FRO ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an address by Louis Farrakhan Sunday night on radio station WBEE in Chicago, as recorded by a reporter for The Chicago Sun-Times:

title: Regan Warns On Bank Bill
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he would ''probably'' recommend that President Reagan veto a banking bill if it limited the ability of banks to expand into new financial services.

title: EL SALVADOR REBELS CAPTURE DAM BEFORE BEING DRIVEN OFF
description: Leftist guerrillas overran El Salvador's largest hydroelectric dam today in their most important military operation in the last six months. Government forces were reported to have retaken the dam later in the day.

title: METS ARE BEATEN 3D TIME IN ROW
description: The Mets' slump began to resemble a swoon last night when they lost to the Atlanta Braves, 5-3, and suffered their third straight defeat and fifth in the last seven games.

title: Suspension Stands
description: -hander, and Claudell Washington, the Atlanta Braves' top hitter, both drew fines and suspensions for an incident in a game June 16. Both appealed the penalties, and yesterday the National League announced that it would uphold the three-game suspension of Washington, who also was fined $1,000.

title: D Wiesleyan Professor
description: Dr. Edward Williamson, professor emeritus of romance languages and literature at Wesleyan University, died Sunday at his home in Middletown, Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach Buys Back Some Stock
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International, reportedly fearful of acquisition attempts, has bought back all the stock from the estate and trusts of the late William Bernbach, its co-founder, for more than $20 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Books on Wheels

title: BROTHEL KEEPER AS A WITNESS: U.S. SKIRTS THE RISK
description: Federal prosecutors and investigators worked for months to bring Joseph Conforte, a Reno brothel owner, back from Brazil to testify against Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas. But the petition filed Wednesday to dismiss the charges that rely on Mr. Conforte's testimony indicates that the Government doubts it can use Mr. Conforte to convince a jury that the judge took bribes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Shakespeare at a Party

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Asarco Inc. has elected to its board Michael Thomas Nelligan, president and chief executive officer of Ideal Basic Industries.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA IN FIRST PRISONER EXCHANGE IN 10 YEARS
description: Israel and Syria exchanged prisoners of war today for the first time in 10 years.

title: New Wisdom Vs. the Old
description: IN economics, the conventional wisdom - the set

title: 3-Man Chairman Office At White Consolidated
description: In its first top-level management changes since 1976, White Consolidated Industries said yesterday it was creating a three-man office of the chairman.

title: DELOREAN'S SECRETARY CHARGED IN JERSEY WITH COCAINE TRAFFICKING
description: A woman who is John Z. DeLorean's personal secretary and housekeeper at his New Jersey estate was arrested Wednesday evening in a motel in Clinton Township, N.J., along with three other people, on charges of trafficking in cocaine. The arrests sent another jolt through the DeLorean trial here.

title: ARMS AND THE ELECTION YEAR
description: The Reagan Administration is quietly curbing United States military activity in Central America and the Persian Gulf and is moving into a low profile on disputed military issues pending before Congress.

title: New Chief Set By Diasonics
description: Stewart Carrell, president and chief operating officer at Diasonics Inc., has assumed the additional post of chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday by Albert S. Waxman, chairman.

title: No Headline
description: Smoke Rings After citing the many hazards of cigarette smoking, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop has called for ''a smoke-free society by the year 2000.'' At the moment, however, that society seems a lot more than 16 years away.

title: CARL F. HOLMES
description: Carl F. Holmes, vice president and director of the Holmes Foundation in Manhattan, died Monday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 90 years old and also lived in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
RATES ADVANCE MODESTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday amid weak investor demand for notes and bonds. Securities dealers worried that higher rates might be needed to attract investors to next week's offerings of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: VIRGINIA WADE POSTS A 3-6, 6-4, 7-5 UPSET
description: For those who thought that an upset victory in the second round of Wimbledon had turned Virginia Wade's thoughts to 1977, the former champion offered a dismissive toss of the head and an ''Oh, good God!''

title: I.M.F. View
description: The International Monetary Fund has told Argentina that the nation must make deeper cuts in public expenditures to meet conditions for emergency credit, a senior monetary official said today.

title: Water and Power Lost on Rikers I.
description: Water and most electric service to Rikers Island was cut off yesterday when a contractor fixing a sewer in Queens severed the sole water main serving the island in the East River, which has the city's largest jails.

title: 3 HENLEY COURSE RECORDS SET
description: -ON-THAMES, England, June 28 - The course record was broken twice in heats of the Thames Challenge Cup today as the 135th Henley Royal Regatta began with qualifying in ideal conditions.

title: Price's 67 Earns Lead in Canada
description: Nick Price holed out from the fairway for an eagle 2 and a 5-under-par 67 today that gave him a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $525,000 Canadian Open golf tournament.

title: Analysts View Tandy's Future
description: TOMORROW marks the close of the fiscal year for the Tandy Corporation, and when the nation's largest retailer of home electronic products later announces earnings for the 12-month period, they should come as no surprise.

title: Meaner Streets, Cleaner Streets
description: Bombs Away

title: CITY ASSAILS STATE OVER HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration, in a continuation of its dispute with the Cuomo administration over the homeless, charged yesterday that the state had no ''legal or moral justification'' for refusing to share in the costs of sheltering families in a Bronx gymnasium.

title: Bulgaria Accuses Italy In Pope's Shooting
description: Bulgaria accused Italian judicial officials today of deliberately leaking false information about the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II to imply that it was a Bulgarian conspiracy.

title: Convincing Victory
description: The Seattle Mariners must have liked what they saw in Salome Barojas , the Chicago White Sox relief pitcher, even though he was partly responsible for their defeat.

title: South African Aide Resigns
description: South Africa's Finance Minister, Owen Horwood, resigned Wednesday after almost 10 years in the post, and Education and Training Minister Barend du Plessis was designated his successor today.

title: Debt Issues
description: IC Industries said its Illinois Central Gulf Railroad has completed an offering of $150 million of 15 1/2 percent bonds due 1994.

title: FILM:SCHWARZENEGGER IN NEW 'CONAN'
description: IT'S neither a man nor a bird but

title: Chinaglia's Plans
description: The moment Giorgio Chinaglia started negotiations to purchase 50 percent of the Cosmos and take control of the team from Warner Communications, he said he would make changes in the front office. Chinaglia is now on the verge of completing the negotiations with Steve Ross , chairman of Warner Communications.

title: AT AIRPORT, KIN AWAIT PRISONERS
description: Pat Privette said she had promised herself she wasn't going to cry, but the tears were already welling up in her eyes as she waited for the plane from Havana. She spoke about her son, Calvin, and what it would be like to see him for the first time in many months.

title: SHULTZ QUESTIONS HAVANA'S MOTIVES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Fidel Castro's decision to release 48 American and Cuban prisoners to the Rev. Jesse Jackson was intended as a ''propaganda victory.''

title: OSWALD JACOBY, TOP EXPERT ON BRIDGE AND A COLUMNIST
description: Oswald Jacoby, one of the greatest contract bridge players, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Dallas. He was 81 years old.

title: 4 at C.I.A. Due to Change Jobs
description: Four senior officials at the Central Intelligence Agency are scheduled to change jobs Sunday in a major shuffling of the agency's top command, intelligence officials said today.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 10
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for both latest periods reflect the issuance of 550,000 common shares on May 19, 1983.

title: SOVIET DERIDES REAGAN SPEECH AS ELECTION ORATORY
description: The Soviet press today derided President Reagan's call for improved economic, cultural, scientific and consular ties as a campaign gimmick. It said he was trying to shirk responsibility for a serious deterioration in relations between Moscow and Washington.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SITTING on squat wooden stools and picking from a communal plate with your hands may not be everyone's idea of an elegant evening on the town, but it certainly makes for interesting dinner conversation. Abyssinia, a spare but pleasant Ethiopian restaurant at 35 Grand Street, at Thompson Street, might be just the place to take jaded New Yorkers who think they've tried everything.

title: ART:GUGGENHEIM DISPLAYS NEW ACQUISITIONS
description: SURELY funds awarded a museum were never more aptly spent than when the Guggenheim, courtesy of General Felt Industries, bought Jan Dibbet's ''Octagon 1.'' One of the Dutch Conceptualist's panoramas, it consists of multiple photographs, variously angled, of a brown Renaissance-style building. These, arranged in an octagon, are more or less centered on a black panel. The effect is of a porthole looking skyward, and it makes a spectator feel imprisoned in this awe- inspiring structure, surmounted by a single tower.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The Hartmarx Corporation was formerly Hart Schaffner & Marx.

title: STEPS OF MAN ERODE LIFE ALONG APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: As he has been doing every year since 1978, Daniel Genson brought his sons to the mountains this week to hike a short but steep stretch of the Appalachian Trail, the 2,100-mile footpath that wends from Georgia to the highlands of central Maine.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES REMARKS MADE BY FARRAKHAN AS 'REPREHENSIBLE'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today disavowed as ''reprehensible'' the words of Louis Farrakhan, a Black Muslim supporter who had described the creation of Israel as an ''outlaw act'' and called the nations that helped found and now support Israel ''criminals in the sight of Almighty God.''

title: U.S. CHALLENGES ACCORD IN STARRETT CITY BIAS SUIT
description: The Reagan Administration yesterday challenged the proposed settlement of a discrimination suit at the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn, saying the accord did not resolve the issue of maintaining racial or national-origin quotas.

title: Armed Men Take $5 Million in Gems
description: An estimated $5 million worth of jewelry was stolen yesterday from a midtown Manhattan jewelry concern by four armed men who cleaned out the company's safe after tying up about a dozen employees, the police said.

title: THREE-STATE WARM-UP FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY
description: YACHTS, fishing boats, lifeboats and all other manner of seagoing vessels will be the focus of attention this weekend - with a few runners thrown in for good measure - at Harbor Festival '84. The eighth annual festival, as well as other historical, patriotic and artistic events, will start the metropolitan area's celebration of Independence Day, which does not arrive until next Wednesday.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 10
HBM/Creamer Lands Marshall's Campaign
description: HBM/Creamer, Boston, will be creating broadcast and magazine advertising for Marshall's chain of clothing stores with over 200 outlets in 60 cities.

title: 69 Amerasian Children Leave Vietnam for U.S.
description: Dozens of children fathered by American soldiers in the Vietnam War left with their relatives today after a compromise between Hanoi and Washington over refugee quotas.

title: HELPING FATHER ON ISSUES DAUGHTER KNOWS BEST
description: At first it sounds like a sitcom premise more appropriate to the Reagan family's Hollywood roots: Let's have the President's daughter become his paid strategist on the subject of women to help him overcome the charges of political misogyny that dog the genial patriarch's re-election chances.

title: Sargent Acquired
description: Sargent Industries said it had reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Dover Corporation for $8.90 a share, or about $68 million.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Boy in Elevator 14 Hours
description: A 7-year- old boy who was trapped for 14 hours in the broken elevator of a housing project says he spent ''some of the time'' crying while the police looked for him.

title: Smoking Curbs Are Set For Convention on Coast
description: Delegates to next month's Democratic National Convention will be free to smoke on the convention floor, but workers in any enclosed spaces must abide by the city's tough antismoking ordinance, officials say.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record.AlbumsThisLastWeekWeek13Born in the U.S.A.*

title: Connecticut Man Guilty in Slayings
description: A man accused in the April 1982 murder of his former wife and three other people, could face the death penalty after being convicted of three counts of murder and one count of capital felony today.

title: TAPE CONTRADICTS DISAVOWALOF 'GUTTER RELIGION' ATTACK
description: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Black Muslim group called the Nation of Islam, continued tonight to deny referring to Judaism as a ''gutter religion,'' but a tape recording made available today by The Chicago Sun-Times contained that phrase in a sermon broadcast by Mr. Farrakhan last Sunday.

title: THEATER:ALVIN EPSTEIN IN BECKETT'S 'ENDGAME'
description: ''NOTHING is funnier than unhappiness,'' says one of the world's last survivors in Samuel Beckett's ''Endgame.'' This is not loose talk. ''Endgame'' is as grim as any classic of the modern theater - far bleaker than its predecessor and companion, ''Waiting for Godot'' - and yet it is monstrously funny.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I find such statements or comments to be reprehensible and morally indefensible.

title: Utility Is Limited On Accident Costs
description: The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation may not recover $2.5 million in repair expenses from customers over an accident at a nuclear power plant two years ago, the Public Service Commission decided today.

title: DRINKING-AGE BILL GOES TO PRESIDENT
description: In the first significant Federal move against drinking since Prohibition ended in 1933, the House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval this morning to a measure designed to force states to adhere to a minimum drinking age of 21.

title: Norwegian Sets 5,000 Record
description: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway set a world record in the women's 5,000-meter run at the annual Bislett Games today.

title: 2 BANDS OFFER ROCK INTERLUDE
description: IF some of the talent in this

title: How to Tempt Jeremy Irons.
description: AS his eight-month Broadway run in ''The Real Thing'' draws to a close, Jeremy Irons is tired enough, he says, ''to look at a film script for 'Gone With the Wind' and probably say, 'No, it'd never work.' '' Mr. Irons, whose ''Swann in Love'' (which he describes as ''a good two hours in the movie house'') will open in New York next month, has no other movie plans at the moment. But he's looking for what he calls ''a street picture,'' even a Hollywood hit. ''I'd love to do a film that pulls in a wide audience,'' he said. ''A 'Terms of Endearment' is the sort of thing one dreams of in terms of being palatable for just about everybody.''

title: SCA Will Begin Acquisition Talks
description: SCA Services Inc., a waste disposal concern that has received a $300 million offer from one company and expressions of interest from others, said it had authorized management to begin talks with companies interested in purchasing it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Insights Through Poetry

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chairman, President Leaves Bangor Punta
description: Stating that the Bangor Punta Corporation's recent merger into Lear Siegler Inc. had left it ''in good hands,'' David W. Wallace yesterday resigned his position as Bangor Punta's president and chairman. The resignation will take effect Saturday.

title: Limited Files Suit
description: The Limited Inc. said it had filed a lawsuit in California to prevent the proposed change in Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.'s state of incorporation to Delaware, from California, and is soliciting proxies to elect its two nominees to the Carter Hawley board at a special shareholders meeting scheduled for July 26. If Carter Hawley reincorporates in Delaware, it could eliminate cumulative voting for directors, under which a shareholder gets one vote for each position but can allocate all those votes for one or two positions. Carter Hawley, based in Los Angeles, said it plans to take ''appropriate steps'' to protect the rights of its shareholders.

title: Yacht's Survivors Tell Of a Gale Off Canada
description: QUEEN CHARLOTTE CITY, British Columbia, June 28 (AP) - The passengers and crew of a luxury yacht that sank off the Canadian coast Wednesday formed a human chain and tried to bail out the craft in a ''screaming'' gale as 20-foot waves smashed over the deck.

title: PHILIP GLASS ENSEMBLE
description: PHILIP GLASS at the Kool Jazz Festival? Mr. Glass's music of layered, pulsing, continually shifting rhythmic and harmonic patterns, performed by his ensemble of amplified keyboard and wind instruments, has no place for improvisation and does n't ''swing'' in a jazz sense. But it has attracted considerable attention in the jazz world recently. During the last year, virtually every major jazz publication ran a lengthy article on the composer and his music.

title: SCOUTING
description: For Chris Lewis, Return to Reality

title: Indians on Film
description: The Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is presenting films on North American Indians tomorrow at 2 P.M. in conjunction with the exhibition ''Common Heritage: Contemporary Iroquois Artists,'' on view through Aug. 19.

title: U.S. Surgical Reports Deficit
description: The United States Surgical Corporation said yesterday that it lost $4.6 million on sales of $158.1 million in 1983.

title: HIGH COURT RESTORES CURBS ON TOURIST TRAVEL TO CUBA
description: The Supreme Court today reinstated the Reagan Administration's curbs on tourist and business travel to Cuba. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: LORD ASTOR, HEAD OF DYNASTY AND AIDE AT TIMES OF LONDON
description: Lord Astor of Hever, former chairman of The Times of London and head of the Astor dynasty, which was founded in the United States and was later transplanted to Britain, died of cancer today at his home in Scotland. He was 66 years old.

title: Restaurants to D.D.B
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, San Francisco, has won the Straw Hat Restaurant Division of the Saga Corporation with billings of $3.1 million. The account was formerly handled by McCann-Erickson, Los Angeles. In the midst of the competition for the account, Saga announced it was selling the chain to Bullwinkle's Inc., but that didn't slow down the race.

title: Soundscape Finale
description: Soundscape will wrap up its festival programs at Irving Plaza (477-3728), 17 Irving Plaza, at 15th Street, with a bang - along with clangs, paradiddles, cymbal crashes and rimshots. ''A Night of Percussion,'' a triple bill of drummers and percussionists, begins tonight at 8.

title: SHUT UP OR GET OUT
description: As I prepare to depart on vacation, I am struck by a feeling in me not merely of escape, but escape from violence. I am not speaking necessarily of physical violence, though that is always present in the urban abrasion pot, but rather of the violence of discourse.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Treasury ConsideringZero-Coupon Offerings
description: Treasury officials are considering changes in the marketing of United States Treasury notes and bonds in the hope of reducing the interest rates paid on future issues.

title: GREECE UPSETS U.S. IN TERRORIST CASE
description: A senior State Department official said today that the Greek Government had freed an accused terrorist from jail without trial or notice to Washington, despite the fact that physical evidence of his guilt had been turned over to Athens by the Reagan Administration.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aeronca Inc., an aircraft structural assemblies company in Charlotte, N.C., said it had decided not to pursue its plans to acquire the Continental Scale Corp., a closely held weighing scales company in Bridgeview, Ill.

title: MOTOROLA'S POWERFUL NEW CHIP
description: The Motorola Corporation yesterday introduced a powerful new microprocessor that analysts said would make it possible for the next generation of desktop computers to rival the power of giant mainframe machines.

title: ONYX & IMI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 10
description: b-Net income

title: Cancer and Contraceptives: Study Confirms Lack of Link
description: Additional studies confirm a preliminary 1983 report that oral contraceptives do not cause breast cancer, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Turkey to Ease Martial Law
description: The Government decided today to lift martial law in 13 additional provinces, the semiofficial Anatolia press agency reported. Martial law will continue in 41 of Turkey's 67 provinces, including the major urban centers of Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir, for at least four months, the agency said.

title: REAGAN GRANTS HASIDIM 'DISADVANTAGED' STATUS
description: They were talking about it in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday. Bearded men in dark coats under a hot sun, men known for their deep spiritual values, their belief in education and hard work, their pride in self-reliance.

title: Law College Settles Suit On Sexual Harassment
description: The private William Mitchell College of Law said Wednesday that it had settled a $3 million sexual harassment lawsuit filed by eight women.

title: Israel Court Drops Ban On 2 Political Parties
description: The Supreme Court in Jerusalem overruled the Central Elections Committee today and cleared an Arab-Jewish peace party and a rightist party to run in parliamentary elections July 23.

title: ADVERTISING ; Magazine Is Offering A Discount
description: IN an effort to attract regular magazine advertising and not just the

title: Irish Millionaire Charged
description: Barney Curley, a millionaire who raffled off his mansion in February, has been charged with illegally organizing a lottery. Mr. Curley sold 9,000 tickets at 175 Irish pounds (then $196) when he raffled off the mansion 50 miles west of Dublin and 377 acres of land. He earned $1.76 million, at least $600,000 more than he was likely to have obtained if the property had been sold conventionally. Mr. Curley was charged Wednesday with breaking a 1956 law that makes lotteries illegal unless they are for charity.

title: HISPANIC MAYOR IN TEXAS
description: Mayor of San Antonio will be interviewed as Vice Presidential possibility July 4 by Walter F. Mondale . . . born in San Antonio June 11, 1947, son of a career army officer, Col. J. George Cisneros . . . father's parents from New Mexico, mother's from Mexico . . . received bachelor's and master's degrees at Texas A&M . . . another master's degree from Harvard . . . White House Fellow assisting Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in 1971-72 . . . professor of public administration at University of Texas at San Antonio since 1974 . . . received doctorate in public administration from George Washington University in 1975 . . . first elected to San Antonio City Council in 1975 . . . elected mayor six years later, first Mexican-American to hold the office in this century . . . re-elected last April with 94 percent of the vote . . said three weeks ago ''only ambition'' at present was to win a third two-year term . . . member of National Bipartisan Commission on Central America, wrote minority addendum to final report urging suspension of covert United States aid to anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua . . . endorsed Mr. Mondale more than a year ago . . . married 15 years, two young daughters.

title: DOW INDUSTRIALS CLIMB 9.83
description: The stock market, buoyed by hopes for an improved economy and a contraction of the nation's money supply, ended its three-day downturn yesterday with a gain of nearly 10 points for the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: CONFEREES ADOPT PLAN TO OVERHAUL BANKRUPTCY LAW
description: A House- Senate conference committee today approved a major overhaul of the Federal bankruptcy system that has required two years of struggle.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IS NARROWED
description: Rising exports and a sharp drop in imports of oil and manufactured goods narrowed the nation's trade deficit in May to $8.84 billion from a record $12.2 billion in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: EXOCETS: SMALL BUT DEADLY
description: The Exocet is a class of small missile developed for the French Government by Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale in the 1970's.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Technology Chief Retiring at I.B.M.
description: B. O. Evans, vice president for engineering, programming and technology at the International Business Machines Corporation, the company's research and development arm, will retire on July 1, the company said yesterday.

title: TV WEEKEND ; IT'S THE TIME OF YEAR WHEN THE PLOT THINS
description: SUMMER is the time when the networks begin slipping duds into the schedule. Hence, the sudden appearance of those scattered half-hour situation comedies and 90-minute films that clearly don't have much of a future. Tonight at 9:30 on Channel 7, for instance, there is ''Spraggue,'' a movie described as ''based on characters from the novels of Linda Barnes.''

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SIX months and two chefs after it opened just down the street from the Joyce Theater, Roxanne's is humming softly. Through floor-to-ceiling windows, this tiny oasis on a dusty block of Eighth Avenue sends out its welcoming beacon of light. And at the door, Roxanne Betesh, who has learned her trade at some of the city's better small restaurants, seems to treat friend and stranger equally well. It's an attitude she has imparted to her staff.

title: PUBLISHING:MCGRAW-HILL AT 75, A ROBUST GIANT
description: -Hill Book Company, in 1909, listed 200 titles. Many of the books were imports, but one, ''Principles of Mining,'' was written by a mining engineer from Iowa named Herbert Hoover. The following year, only seven years after the Wright Brothers made their epic flight near Kitty Hawk, N.C., McGraw-Hill published ''The Art of Aviation.''

title: 16 Die in Brazil Plane Crash
description: A twin-engine prop plane struck a mountainside in a rainstorm 100 miles north of here today, killing all 16 people aboard, an airline executive said. He said all the victims were Brazilian.

title: 13 Are Charged As Loan Sharks
description: Thirteen people, including a rabbi, a dentist and three men described as high-ranking members of crime organizations, were charged in Manhattan yesterday with taking part in a loan shark business financed by organized crime.

title: Steinbrenner Says Yanks Not Moving
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that talk of the Yankees' moving to New Jersey ''was a lot of speculation about nothing.''

title: For Children
description: Central Park Fun CASTLE TOYS AND GAMES, a program directed by the Wiz of Belvedere, who will show how to make toys from unusual objects, Saturday at 1 P.M. (reservations required: 772-0210), and FOLK SONGS INTERNATIONAL, a musical program, Sunday at 2 and 3 P.M., at Belvedere Castle, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Free. THE MUPPETS TAKE MANHATTAN, an exhibition that gives a backstage view of the costume designs, puppets and props from the film ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' as well as scenes, from the film to be shown continuously, starting Saturday (and continuing Tuesdays through Sundays until Sept. 3), 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., at the Central Park Dairy, 64th Street, east of the Carousel. Free. Information: 772-0210.

title: HOUSE REJECTS DEBT CEILING RISE
description: The House of Representatives, in an apparent move to force the Senate to negotiate on military spending, today overwhelmingly killed both a two-month and a one-year increase in the nation's debt ceiling.

title: ASTROS' RALLY SINKS PHILLIES
description: Kevin Bass cracked a two-run double in the ninth inning tonight to complete a comeback that gave the Houston Astros a 7-6 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Phillies. The Astros had trailed by 6-1 going into the eighth inning.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE PRISONERS TO BE RELEASED
description: Following are lists, provided today by the State Department, of the 22 American inmates and the 26 Cuban political prisoners being freed from Cuban jails, with ages and places of birth. An official said it was not possible to say with certainty if the list of Cubans was accurate.

title: OPERA:A BRITISH 'WAR AND PEACE'
description: PROKOFIEV's ''War and Peace'' is really two operas, tenuously linked by the thread of a love story. In fact, the composer at one point wanted his retelling of the Tolstoy epic broken up and presented on two nights. He finally settled on a much- shrunken one-night version of 13 scenes and that condensation has found a place on the fringes of the international operatic repertory.

title: People
description: * PARIS, Peter Tate elected a group senior vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach. * Arthur Karlan appointed advertising director of Newsweek. * Donald M. Roux, president of the Carlson Marketing Group in Minneapolis, elected chairman of the Promotion Marketing Association of America. - ADVERTISING

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 29, 1984
description: The Economy

title: LAW FOR RELIGIOUS MEETINGS IN SCHOOLS STALLED BY O'NEILL
description: After a rare clash with a senior Democrat, the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., today sidetracked a measure that would enable students to hold religious meetings in public high schools before or after regular school hours.

title: FABI'S LIFE AS 2-CAR FAMILY
description: Teo Fabi does not count the miles, nor does he enumerate the frustrations. But he is the only racing driver competing oceans apart in two major series, and he has traveled far enough to know he can't choose both forks in the road.

title: THE LINES FORM FOR A NEW TREAT FROM ITALY: GELATO
description: Charles Azevedo journeyed to Central Park from Brooklyn the other night to attend a performance of Verdi's ''Ernani,'' but about halfway through the opera he became ''a little bored,'' so he wandered over to Columbus Avenue and 82d Street to sample a newer Italian cultural contribution to America: gelato. He wasn't alone.

title: STAGE:YUP'IK ESKIMO 'ANTIGONE'
description: ''YUP'IK ANTIGONE,'' at La Mama E.T.C. through July 8, may be one of the most powerful and challenging of the many adaptations in which Sophocles' ''Antigone'' has been presented. Though it is not without a problem or two, ''Yup'ik Antigone'' combines Greek legend with Eskimo myth and ritual for theater of simple grandeur.

title: Accounts
description: * Cadillac Dealers Association of Southern California to Sawden & Bess.

title: Trio at Jazz Theater
description: The pianist Barry Harris will lead a trio, which will be joined by the saxophonist C. Sharpe, tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater (244-0997), 368 Eighth Avenue, at 28th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., and tickets are $8.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD VOTES TRADE-OFF:STREET FOR SCHOOL
description: Shearson Lehman/American Express will be allowed to close off a street and build a computer center and office tower in lower Manhattan in return for building a new elementary school nearby, under a plan approved yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: NEW ROCHELLE MID-RISE BUILT OVER A RAILROAD CUT
description: Oldtimers in Westchester County remember with affection the Westchester & Boston Railroad. It started in 1912 with trains running northward from 180th Street and Morris Park Avenue in the Bronx.

title: FEDERAL FUNDING'S COST IN AMERICAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Salesman Seized In Rape-Slaying
description: A 24-year-old eastern Connecticut insurance salesman was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape- slaying of a teen-ager in Lisbon, Conn., two weeks ago. The victim was the last of six young women whose slayings have brought terror to the area since 1982.

title: Indian Troops Rescue Victims of Flood
description: Indian troops used speedboats today to rescue victims of floods that have killed up to 20 people and left almost one million homeless in West Bengal, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: G.M. ENTERING COMPUTER FIELD ON MAJOR SCALE
description: The General Motors Corporation moved today to take a major role in the electronics industry by agreeing to pay $2.5 billion for the data-processing company founded by H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire.

title: S. Carolina's Mazda Bid
description: Gov. Dick Riley said he would visit Hiroshima, Japan, in mid-July to try to persuade the Mazda Motor Corporation to build an auto assembly plant in South Carolina. Mazda is considering Greenville as a possible site for a United States assembly plant, along with a mothballed Ford Motor Company plant in Flat Rock, Mich., and an undetermined site in Nebraska. Governor Riley said this week that he would present Mazda officials with a gift from local businessmen and artwork by local students promoting life in South Carolina.

title: ARGENTINA HINTS IT MIGHT PAY
description: The Government of President Raul Alfonsin, faced by yet another critical interest-payment deadline Friday, said today that it would act to protect its creditor status.

title: ORWELL ON HITLER: AN EFFORT TO UNDERSTAND EVIL
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch last Friday on the choice of Governor Cuomo as keynote speaker for the Democratic National Convention misidentified the previous New Yorker who had that role. In 1916, when Martin H. Glynn was the keynoter, he was a former Governor.

title: Drug Research at Games
description: The International Olympic Committee announced today that a four-year research project in sports medicine and drug abuse would begin at the Summer Games in Los Angeles. Prince Alexandre de Merode, president of the I.O.C.'s Medical Commission, said at a news conference here that the program would continue the testing of athletes for use of illegal drugs and seek to expand the number of laboratories from the current 15.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STAYING WITH IT. On Becoming an Athlete. By John Jerome. 225 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: CUBANS ARE SAID TO HAVE REFUSED 'REHABILITATION'
description: Most of the 26 political prisoners freed tonight by President Fidel Castro had been in jail for two decades. They represent a small fraction of the political prisoners in Cuba, which some estimates have put at more than 5,000.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE week preceding the Fourth

title: OLYMPIANS TROUNCE N.B.A.
description: In its first appearance since the final roster cuts were made, the United States men's Olympic basketball team tonight alternately dazzled a capacity crowd at the Providence Civic Center with spectacular plays and frustrated the most significant spectator with its inconsistency.

title: ACTORS AND THEATERS EXTEND PACT
description: Actors Equity and the League of Resident Theaters have signed a 14- month contract, averting a strike against the 77 theaters. The agreement, reached late Wednesday, extends the current contract from July 1, 1984, to Sept. 1, 1985, and includes 4.5 percent increases in salary and per diems, and a rise in medical benefits.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 29, 1984 International
description: Twenty six political prisoners being freed by Fidel Castro were picked up in Havana by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, along with 22 United States citizens who had been held there, mostly on charges related to drug trafficking. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) Fidel Castro's decision to release 48 American and Cuban prisoners to the Rev. Jesse Jackson was an attempt to gain a ''propaganda victory,'' according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. In an interview, Mr. Shultz said the Cuban leader had not given any sign he was ready to moderate Cuba's ''subversive'' policies in Latin America. (A1:4.)

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY BACK BILL TO CURB SOME TRIAL RIGHTS
description: Key legislators reached agreement Thursday on a measure intended to unclog the criminal courts by eliminating a defendant's right to a jury trial in 70 relatively minor crimes.

title: NEW ACCORD REACHED TO PROVIDE SUBWAY ACCESS FOR THE DISABLED
description: Governor Cuomo and the legislative leadership said today that they had reached agreement on a new plan to provide access to New York City's subway system for disabled commuters.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago results were restated.

title: HEBREW BOOKS' STORAGE DISCLOSED BY SOTHEBY'S
description: An unidentified individual smuggled 59 rare Hebrew books and manuscripts from Germany into the United States in 1939 and they remained in a safe-deposit box until most of them were sold at an auction at Sotheby's last Tuesday night, according to statements made by a Sotheby's lawyer.

title: Tiffany Rejects $16 Million Bid
description: A family-owned New Jersey mail-order company that built its business on selling inexepnsive clothes offered to buy Tiffany & Company for $16 million in cash, but the jewelry company's parent promptly rejected the offer. Max Habernickel, owner of the Haband Company, said he thought his ''family personal touch'' and ''excellent service'' could help turn around Tiffany, a subsidiary of Avon Products Inc. But he said he was not interested in buying the company's building on New York City's Fifth Avenue. Avon previously said its expects the sale of the eight-store Tiffany chain to bring more than $160 million.

title: ORCATECH reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
