description: b-After special losses of $3,673,000 for the quarter and $3,397,000 for the 9 months. c-After a special gain of $111,000. d-Net income after a special loss of $43,000.

title: MEXICO SEES PERILS IN PROPOSED CHANGES IN U.S. IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: Mexico expressed concern today that proposed changes in United States immigration laws could ''seriously undercut and injure the human and labor rights of Mexican workers.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUSIC LIGHTS UP THE HUDSON

title: Senate, 51-42, Votes to Back Plan to Promote Democracy
description: The Senate voted 51 to 42 tonight to try to salvage the Reagan Administration's plans for a multimillion-dollar project to promote American ideals abroad, a program the House of Representatives voted down last month.

title: YIGAEL YADIN, FAMED ISRAELI, DIES;WAS ARCHEOLOGIST AND WAR HERO
description: Yigael Yadin, military hero of Israel's war of independence and archeologist of Masada and the Dead Sea Scrolls, died yesterday of a heart attack in Hadera, Israel. He was 67.

title: Meaner Streets, Cleaner Streets; Successful Scooping
description: Six years ago a New York State law ordered dog owners to clean up after their pets - and launched a thousand bad jokes and more than a few gadgets. As time went on, however, dog owners found that nothing beats a paper towel, a shirt cardboard or a plastic bag delicately folded over the wrist.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Sugar Falls Sharply;Cocoa Also Plunges
description: World sugar futures fell sharply near the close of trading today on a burst of selling in the July contract, which expires Friday.

title: Unitarians Endorse Homosexual Marriages
description: The Unitarian Universalist Association voted today to approve religious blessings on homosexual unions, becoming the first major church to do so.

title: N.A.A.C.P. ON FARRAKHAN AND ANTI-SEMITISM
description: From a statement Wednesday by Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advcancement of Colored People:

title: Tour de France To Start Today
description: The 71st annual Tour de France bicycling race, covering 2,498 miles in 23 days, begins in an eastern suburb of Paris on Friday.

title: Dining Out Guide: Ice Cream and Sherbet Desserts
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. DARBAR, 44 West 56th Street (432-7227)

title: JULLIARD PICKS A PRESIDENT
description: Joseph W. Polisi has been named president of the Juilliard School, which counts as America's foremost conservatory of music and also boasts active dance and theater divisions.

title: STOCK COMMISSIONS ARE HEADING UP
description: The stock market has been lackluster of late, but the price of admission is going up anyway.

title: A BIG BAND AND A SMALL
description: WILLIAM PARKER's rambunctious big band and Tim Berne's meticulous sextet performed last Monday at Irving Plaza.

title: E.E.C. Prices Up 0.5%
description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose five-tenths of 1 percent in May from April and were up 7.5 percent from a year earlier, the trade bloc's statistical service said today.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: Meadowlands Grand Prix, second and final day of qualifying, at the Meadowlands sports complex. Preparations continue for Sunday, when the metropolitan area's first major auto race in more than 50 years takes place. The gates open at 8 A.M., practice begins at 10 A.M., and the trials are set for 1:30 P.M. Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. After two shaky outings recently, Ed Lynch tries again for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9 and WTBS, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.)

title: SHAW-HAMPTON DOUBLE BILL
description: ARTIE SHAW retired as a musician in 1954, the year that the Newport Jazz Festival was started. On the 30th anniversary of both events, Mr. Shaw, leading the orchestra he formed last December, and the Newport Jazz Festival, now called the Kool Jazz Festival, finally got together in a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening that Mr. Shaw shared with Lionel Hampton's orchestra.

title: Liberty Regatta Starts Tomorrow
description: International yacht match racing will return to New York City waters tomorrow for the first time in 64 years when eight crews from six countries will compete in the first Liberty Cup Regatta.

title: HIGH COURT PUTS LIMITS ON BANKS
description: In a significant victory for the securities industry, the Supreme Court today struck down a 1980 Federal Reserve Board decision that had permitted banks to underwrite commercial paper, the short-term debt of major corporations.

title: CUOMO SAYS CONVENTION CENTER PROBLEM IS 'FALSE'
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that the structural safety of New York City's Convention Center was ''a false problem'' and that some of his closest aides should play a greater role in seeing the often-troubled center to completion.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: The results do not reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 29.

title: The U.N. Today June 29, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GOLD RUSH TIME
description: You can get anything you want at

title: FROM CHLOE FOR EVENING
description: Despite its ephemeral nature, fashion can have a certain continuity. The house of Chloe, which pioneered the development of couture ready-to-wear in Paris, has gathered quite a coterie of fans all over the world. Started by Gabrielle Aghion just 30 years ago - she took care of the designing herself for the first few seasons - the company rose to prominence with the work of Gerard Pipart. When he left 20 years ago to design couture clothes for Nina Ricci, Karl Lagerfeld took over the design rooms.

title: Goalby Shoots 70
description: Bob Goalby, shot a par 70 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the United States Senior Open Championship at the Oak Hill Country Club.

title: Daily Test for Adweek
description: The advertising press competition continues to escalate. The newer, brighter Adweek changed its publishing date to go head-to-head on Mondays with Advertising Age.

title: Pass the Civil Rights Act of 1984
description: Most of Congress clearly wants to do something, fast, to make sure the Federal Government doesn't subsidize discrimination against minorities, women, older Americans and the handicapped. The House has voted 375 to 32 to overturn a Supreme Court decision that allows schools and other institutions to accept Federal money through one office while discriminating in another.

title: Murdoch Explains St. Regis Intentions
description: Companies led by Rupert Murdoch have spent more than $65 million to purchase 5.6 percent of the St. Regis Corporation's shares outstanding and - in an unusual declaration - ruled out ''greenmail,'' according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss of $214,000. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2.3 million.

title: Assets of Money Funds Up $759.1 Million
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $759.1 million, to $174.77 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, largely due to a big turnaround in the institutional fund category, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: ADMINISTRATION WEIGHS INSIDER BILL
description: Momentum appears to be gathering in the Administration to oppose legislation intended to toughen penalties for the illegal use of insider information in the trading of securities, according to Government and industry sources.

title: WAVE OF REPAIRS BRINGS FLOOD OF TRAFFIC ILLS
description: There was a time when shrewd drivers trapped in northbound traffic on the construction-snarled Henry Hudson Parkway could break loose at the 95th Street exit and take Riverside Drive.

title: FILM:'IT'S NEVER TOO LATE'
description: THE premise of Jaime de Arminan's ''It's Never Too Late'' is rendered all the more strange by the clean, crisp fashion with which the film unfolds. It concerns 73-year-old Ursula (Madeleine Christie), a virginal, sweet-faced, white-haired Basque woman, who is quietly obsessed with the young newlyweds whose window faces her own. She is particularly interested in the husband, Antonio (Jose Luis Gomez), fabricating reasons to visit him when his wife is away and on one occasion stealing a wedding picture. She takes this home, cuts out the photo of the wife's face, and replaces it with a likeness of herself.

title: NOW Parley to Focus On Defeat of Reagan
description: The National Organization for Women, which meets here Friday in a state it boycotted in the fight for the proposed equal rights amendment, will devote much of its convention to planning how to defeat President Reagan.

title: PILOT IN PLANE CRASH KILLING FOUR AVERTED HITTING TWO HOUSES
description: Investigators looking into the crash of a small plane here Wednesday night said today that eyewitnesses had told them that the pilot had apparently maneuvered the falling plane to avoid hitting homes in a residential section of this Morris County community.

title: Judge Rejects Appeal To Stop Seal Slaughter
description: A Federal court today turned down a request to stop the killing of 22,000 North Pacific fur seals in Alaska, scheduled to start next week.

title: HOW TO PUT NEW YORK UNDER DRUG SIEGE
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to commit speedboats, radar equipment and helicopters to mount a sea and air battle against drug runners operating through New York's ports. While the equipment will undoubtedly be useful, the agreement highlights the continuation of a Federal policy that has become totally unbalanced and operates under the pretense that enforcement efforts alone fulfill Washington's responsibility in addressing a nationwide drug disaster.

title: THE SCREEN:'ANOTHER COUNTRY'
description: ''ANOTHER COUNTRY,'' the English film that opens today at the Cinema 2, is a well-acted, literate but insufferably smug little movie that fictionalizes the life of Guy Burgess, who with Donald Maclean defected to Moscow in the early 1950's. Burgess and Maclean were among the first to be revealed of that small group of Englishmen who, though born to upper-middle-class privilege in the 1920's, turned to Communism in the depressed 1930's and lived double lives as Soviet agents.

title: Ratings Lowered For Beatrice Debt
description: Ratings for the Beatrice Companies' bonds were reduced to A, from AA, and its commercial paper rating was reduced to A-2, from A-1x, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday. The reductions ''reflect the significant increase in financial risk'' resulting from Beatrice's $2.5 billion takeover of Esmark.

title: UNITED TELECONTROL ELECRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
AUCTIONS
description: In an auction of the antiques collection of Florence J. Gould, which ended here tonight, rarities, exotic decorations and rococo furnishings with a lot of glitter commanded the most attention.

title: ART:AT THE MET, 72 PIECES TO EXPLAIN THE FASCINATION OF IVORY
description: IVORY is an emotionally and historically loaded material. It is

title: State Panel Warns City on '85 Budget
description: The State Financial Control Board yesterday unanimously approved the city's next budget as balanced, but warned of uncertainty because the city is negotating new contracts with its labor unions.

title: MONDALE ASSESSES 'REALITIES' OF SURVEY OF VICE-PRESIDENTIAL CHOICES
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that when he seriously assesses Vice-Presidential candidates from groups long left out of the political process, ''there are certain realities'' to be considered.

title: JERSEY LAWMAKERS GIVE APPROVAL TO A STATE BUDGET OF $8.1 BILLION
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final approval today to the state's $8.1 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins Sunday. The vote was 53 to 25.

title: TOWERMARC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $254,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $13,000 for the quarter and $177,000 for the 6 months.

title: SPLENDOR AND SHANTIES IN SOUTH AFRICA 'HOMELAND'
description: The white-painted mansions that straddle the hill, like moored ocean liners, would not look out of place in Hollywood. The slums that nestle below them might also find a place there, in the script of a movie about poverty.

title: AN OFTEN-REVISED WORK
description: Prokofiev began to draft a setting of Tolstoy's ''War and Peace'' in April 1941 and stepped up his efforts when Germany invaded the Soviet Union in June of that year. For the next 12 years, until his death in March 1953, he labored over the score, revising it several times to emphasize the epic aspect in line with Soviet policy.

title: BRIEFING
description: Remember Machias Seal

title: Arkla's Stock Jumps on Rumors
description: Arkla Inc.'s stock jumped $3, to $21.50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, apparently in response to rumors that the gas utilities company would soon be the subject of a takeover bid.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes special gain of $4 million, or 19 cents a share, on the exchange of land, and after-tax benefits of $4.4 million for LIFO inventory adjustments.

title: ARGENTINE COURT FREES EX-PRESIDENT
description: The Argentine military's highest court today ordered former President Reynaldo B. Bignone freed from barracks arrest.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FESTIVAL EVENTS SET FOR TODAY
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: 5 P.M. Carnegie Recital Hall. Jorge

title: FREED SLAVES' DETOUR EN ROUTE TO A HAVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: ; POOR U.S. INVESTMENT IN 'PROMOTING DEMOCRACY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurence, Charles Gets Laxative Account
description: Laurence, Charles & Free, one of the Mickelberry companies, has been named to do advertising for Fiberall, a sugar-free natural fiber laxative that only recently reached national distribution.

title: Mancini Gets Go-Ahead
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini , the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, has completed a series of physical tests and has been given permission to return to the ring. Mancini lost his title June 1 in Buffalo, when he was stopped by Livingstone Bramble in the 14th round.

title: Dorsey Holdings
description: An investment group led by Shamrock Associates told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Dorsey Corporation common stock to 1,038,700 shares, or 27.7 percent of the total outstanding.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Promise to a Friend Is Redeemed

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $832,000 for the quarter and $2,614,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,060,000 and a gain of $9,500,000 from termination of retirement plan.

title: JACKSON BACK IN U.S. FROM CUBA WITH PRISONERS SET FREE BY CASTRO
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson returned to the United States last night with freed American and Cuban prisoners, capping a dramatic excercise in personal diplomacy with President Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: Manila Panel Is Urged To Check Aquino Body
description: Two experts in forensic medicine urged the Philippine Investigative Commission today to recommend exhumation of the body of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., saying it might hold the key to a dispute about his slaying last Aug. 21.

title: Thrift Unit Attacks Suit
description: The thrift unit of the Financial Corporation of America today strongly denied charges filed by three former borrowers that it had engaged in racketeering, conspiracy and security law violations.

title: No Headline
description: Cell Discovery Is Seen Aiding in Cancer Fight

title: NUTRI FOODS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NEW RULE PLANNED ON TAMPON LABELS
description: The Food and Drug Administration plans to require makers of tampons to provide labels stating the absorbency of their products to help women reduce the risk of contracting toxic shock syndrome.

title: Bad Show - in Turkey
description: Repressive regimes are rarely capricious in their choice of victims. They often single out prominent dissenters so as to intimidate the less prominent. When justice is thus debased, the result is a show trial. A particularly ugly contemporary example was Turkey's trial of 23 leaders of a peace association, who languish in jail even under a new civilian regime that is embarrassed by their plight.

title: SCOUTING
description: Cummings's Year

title: New Bonds Guard Against Price Fall
description: A new kind of tax-exempt security, offering protection against the risk of declining bond prices if interest rates rise, is gaining wider acceptance among securities dealers and investors. Underwriters led by Matthews & Wright Capital are preparing this week a new $35 million offering of Top's, a trademarked term for the tender option bonds that the firm began offering in March.

title: Epson Introduces 2d Lap Computer
description: Epson America Inc. introduced a $995 notebook-sized computer, called the Geneva PX-8, that weighs four pounds and includes several programs etched on chips that can be plugged into the machine.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
'88 ELECTION OFFER DROPPED IN BRAZIL
description: Brazil's military regime today withdrew an offer to permit presidential elections by popular vote in 1988.

title:
LEGISLATURE, PUSHING FOR A RECESS, WEIGHS HELP FOR AN INDUSTRY AND A CITY;
THE COUNTY REJECTS BID TO AID YONKERS WITH A $4.85 MILLION
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said today that there was no support among county leaders for a $4.85 million grant or loan to help Yonkers close its budget gap.

title: ART:HOW STUDIOS LOOK TO THE PAINTERS WHO WORK IN THEM
description: TELLING a friend how as a young man he hatched ideas for paintings and drawings, Joan Miro said: ''I'd come home to my Paris studio in Rue Blomet at night. I'd go to bed, and sometimes I hadn't any supper. I saw things, and I jotted them down in a notebook. I saw shapes in the chinks in the walls, and shapes on the ceiling, mainly on the ceiling.''

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: EX-AUTO WORKER GUILTY IN SLAYING
description: A former Chrysler assembly worker who beat a young Chinese-American to death with a baseball bat two years ago was convicted today of a Federal civil rights charge.

title: Turkish Deficit Shrinks
description: Turkey's foreign trade deficit narrowed to $974 million in the year through May from $1.46 billion in the first five months of 1983, the Government said today. Exports in 1984's first five months rose 32.7 percent from a year earlier, to $3 billion. Imports rose 6.9 percent, to $3.98 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCOUTING
description: Helping Hands

title: GENERALS WILL SEE MORE OF BRYANT
description: In discussing his team's playoff game against the Stars in Philadelphia Saturday, the Generals' coach, Walt Michaels, said the other day, ''We expect to see Kelvin Bryant from the start. He means as much to them as Herschel Walker does to us.''

title: 8 DIED IN GULF RAID, SHIPOWNER SAYS
description: Eight crewmen were killed and three seriously hurt in the Iraqi missile attack on a Swiss-owned supertanker Wednesday, the ship's owners said today.

title: Homfeld Wins With Coastline
description: Conrad Homfeld of Petersburg, Va., rode Coastline to a narrow victory Wednesday night in the Time First Jumpoff at the Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: Comings and Goings
description: -racing driver and trainer, has been suspended by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, which charged him with driving under the influence of alcohol and drugs. He can reapply for his license in a year. . . . The Executive Commission on Ethical Standards is looking into the propriety of contributions received by the acting New Jersey State Athletic Commissioner, Robert Lee , to finance his unsuccessful bid to become president of the World Boxing Association in 1982, according to a report in The Newark Star-Ledger.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANELS END PREPARATIONS
description: Democratic committees completed final preliminaries today for the Presidential nominating convention in San Francisco next month, and the solid majority supporting Walter F. Mondale held dissension to a minimum.

title: ONE COURT SYSTEM'S MEAT, ANOTHER'S POISON
description: To the Editor:

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON RELIGIOUS ISSUE
description: Following is the roll-call vote Wednesday by which the Senate passed an amendment to an education bill to permit students' religious groups to meet in public high school facilities. On this vote, a vote ''for'' was a vote to permit such use, while a vote ''against'' was a vote against such use. There were 88 votes ''for'' and 11 votes ''against.'' One member, Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, was absent.

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $292,967, or 24 cents a share.

title: Plane Subsidy Rejected
description: The Australian Government will not help subsidize a small version of the European Airbus airplane designed to compete against Boeing Company's new 737-300, Industry and Commerce Minister John Button said today. He said Australian participation in the Airbus A-320 would be too expensive even though it would have helped employment in the local aircraft industry.

title: World's Fair Loan Guarantee
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards today signed a bill guaranteeing a $17.5 million loan, the second from the state, to try to keep the debt-ridden 1984 World's Fair open though its six-month run. In exchange, fair managers were forced to turn over the daily financial dealings of the exposition to a seven-member committee.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Journey's Long Day Proves Fruitful for New Englanders

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT'S OPINIONS ON TRAVEL BY TOURISTS TO CUBA
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in the case of Regan v. Wald. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote a dissenting opinion.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: -day Kool Jazz Festival, which is dedicated to Count Basie this year, will reach an appropriate climax tomorrow evening at 8 with a memorial salute to the pianist and band leader as the last major concert of the festival.

title: TV RULING CREATES CONFUSION
description: One day after its exclusive control of college football telecasts had been voided by the Supreme Court, the National Collegiate Athletic Association began the process today of returning to a lower Federal court to determine the extent of direction it will be allowed to impose.

title: James R. Thornwell, 46, Dies; Sued Army Over Test of LSD
description: James R. Thornwell, 46 years old, the unknowing subject of an Army LSD experiment who received $625,000 from Congress after filing a lawsuit, died of an apparent seizure while swimming, according to his wife, Rose.

title: VIRUS CASTS A PALL OVER LEXINGTON SALES
description: This is the time of year when Kentucky's biggest commercial throughbred breeders should be rubbing their hands in gleeful anticipation of the blue-chip yearling sales next month, when free-spending buyers will come to town to spend millions of their dollars, pounds and riyals.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE was never any doubt that August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' would make it to New York, not after its reception at the Yale Repertory Theater last spring. The real questions were who would get it and when it would get here. The answer to the first question is Robert Cole, a young man who had never been involved in commercial production, and a former writer, actor and co-founder, with Beatrice Straight, of the Michael Chekhov Acting Studio. As to when, Mr. Cole is talking with the Shubert Organization about a theater, but the opening is set for Oct. 11, after a short run at the Annenberg Center in Philadelphia, starting Sept. 20.

title: JENNA JOHNSON WINS FAST 100 BUTTERFLY
description: Sixteen-year-old Jenna Johnson of Santa Rosa, Calif., made this a night to remember.

title: TALKS FAIL IN RESCUE OF CREUSOT
description: Creusot-Loire, France's largest heavy engineering company, was placed into receivership by a Paris court tonight after the failure of last-minute negotiations between the company and the French Government.

title: REBEL SEEKS ROLE IN NICARAGUA VOTE
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, a Nicaraguan rebel leader, held a series of meetings here today with members of Congress, Congressional sources said.

title: FOREIGN POLICY IN A REAGAN SECOND TERM: RADICAL OR CENTRIST?
description: Foreign policy has not been Ronald Reagan's first-term priority. In a second term, he may want to give America's role in the world the priority it has not yet received. He would have a choice between two policies: one moderate, one radical. On his choice would depend the future of international relations.

title: Dismissal Is Sought in Case Against Priests in Philippines
description: Prosecutors have joined defense lawyers in calling for murder charges to be dropped against two foreign missionaries and six Roman Catholic church workers on trial in this Negros Island town.

title: Cleveland Plane Emergency
description: A United Airlines 727 made an emergency landing Wednesday at Cleveland Hopkins International Airport after its hydraulic system failed.

title: SCREEN:BURT REYNOLDS IN 'CANNONBALL RUN II'
description: FANS of Don Knotts, Jim Nabors, Sammy Davis Jr., car crashes and trained orangutans may want to celebrate the opening of ''Cannonball Run II'' today at the Movieland and other theaters. For anyone else, it's a mixed blessing at best. Directed in slam-bang style by Hal Needham, the film is an endless string of cameo performances from a cast whose funny participants are badly outnumbered and whose television roots are unmistakable. When Doug McClure turns up as the blond-haired slave of an Arab sheik, explaining that he's an actor and he hasn't had a series job in seven years, the movie is as clever as it's going to get.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-After a gain of $328,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Levitz Agrees To Dalfort Bid
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation said its board had received and approved a definitive acquisition proposal from the Dalfort Corporation, which controls Braniff Inc. Levitz said the offer contemplates a series of transactions under which Levitz would be purchased by a company that would be 95 percent owned by Dalfort and 5 percent owned by Levitz management. Levitz said shareholders would receive $20 a share in cash and an equity-participation certificate entitling the holder, for a period of five years, to a pro rata share of one-third of the company's cumulative pretax earnings in excess of $40 million a year before interest on acquisition debt.

title: Police Group Bars Homosexual Unit
description: A coalition of 18 police fraternal, religious and ethnic organizations, known as the Brotherhood-in-Action Police Group, said yesterday that it would not grant membership to the Gay Officers Action League.

title: SHUTTLE CHIEF TELLS OF A CALM CREW AFTER MISFIRE
description: As engineers continued their investigation today of the failure of the space shuttle's engine valve, the Discovery's commander, Henry W. Hartsfield, recalled the crew's moments of surprise, disappointment and humor after the engines shut down abruptly seconds before the appointed liftoff time Tuesday.

title: SCOUTING
description: Big Engagement

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about long-distance telephone service in Charleston, W. Va., incorrectly described certain market statistics. Nationally, 1.7 percent of all businesses account for 58 percent of all long-distance revenues; 10 percent of the households account for 51 percent of all residential long-distance revenues.

title: MONDALE WARNED BY WOMEN'S GROUP
description: Judy Goldsmith, president of the National Organization for Women, said today that unless Walter F. Mondale chose a woman as his running mate the Democratic challenger would not get the full support of the women's movement.

title: F.D.I.C. SUIT ON PENN SQUARE
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today filed a $138.5 million lawsuit against six officials of the failed Penn Square National Bank, two years after the Government shut down the Penn Square here in the sixth-largest bank failure in United States history.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: The share earnings have been restated to reflect stock splits of 2-for-1 on March 17, 1983, and June 22, 1983.

title: Alliance Concerts
description: Artists' Alliance, a musicians' cooperative, is presenting concerts at the Village Gate (475-5120), Bleecker and Thompson Streets. Tonight at 10:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., the All-Star Alliance - featuring the saxophonists Sam Rivers, John Stubblefield, John Purcells and Sonny Fortune - will share double bills with the poet Amiri Baraka. Tickets are $10.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 1:20 P.M. Ron Darling, the first Met pitcher to win five straight starts since Jerry Koosman in 1976, goes for No. 6. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:15 P.M., live, and 7:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:15 P.M.) Football

title: AN EBULLIENT GOVERNOR
description: Next Vice-Presidential possibility to be interviewed by Walter F. Mondale will preside over the Democratic National Convention . . . first woman to be Governor of Kentucky and only current Governor who is a woman . . . ebullient public speaker who seems somewhat shy and low key in private . . . born Dec. 7, 1936, in Baghdad, Ky. (population 250) where her father was a funeral director . . . active early in 4-H Club competitions and beauty contests . . . graduated in 1959 from the University of Kentucky, where she was the first Kentucky Derby Queen . . . worked 12 years as a home economics and mathematics teacher before getting involved in politics in 1971 in gubernatorial campaign of Wendell H. Ford, now a United States Senator . . . won first statewide office in 1975 when she was elected Clerk of the Court of Appeals, a post that has since been abolished . . . four years later elected Lieutenant Governor by more than 200,000 votes over Republican rival . . . elected Governor last November, defeating the Republican candidate, Jim Bunning, the former big-league pitcher . . . supports the proposed Federal equal rights amendment but, citing her beliefs as a Baptist, opposes abortion . . . is annoyed when the two issues are linked . . . husband, Bill, is a dentist . . . they have a son and a daughter.

title: KEY ECONOMIC INDEX DECLINED A BIT IN MAY
description: The Government index intended to predict the course of the economy fell in May for the first time since August 1982, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 5 U.S. Crews Win at Henley
description: United States eights won heats today in the Ladies' Challenge Plate at the 135th Henley Royal Regatta, giving the Americans five of the eight crews remaining in the event. Temple University defeated Selwyn College of Cambridge University by more than five boat lengths and Yale's varsity lightweights defeated Trinity College of Dublin by 1 3/4 lengths, setting up a Temple-Yale race in Saturday's quarterfinals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On the Avenue, Sixth Avenue

title: SPACE TEAM TO REPLACE FAULTY SHUTTLE ENGINE
description: Technicians troubleshooting the space shuttle Discovery failed today in their attempts to pinpoint the cause of the abrupt engine shutdown and the space agency decided to replace the entire engine.

title: Broadcast by First Lady Set
description: Nancy Reagan will borrow the President's weekly politically paid air time Saturday to deliver a five-minute radio broadcast on her crusade against the use of drugs by young people. The First Lady will make her broadcast from Camp David, Md., at 12:06 P.M., the time regularly allotted to the President over the Mutual Broadcasting System and carried on several other stations.

title: No Headline
description: Ruling Is Said to Cloud Firefighter Hiring List

title: AVERAGE PRICE OF NEW HOME TOPS $100,000 FOR FIRST TIME
description: The goal that has come to be known as the American dream has crossed a historic threshold: The average price of a new, single-family home broke into six figures in May, the Commerce Department said today.

title: U.S. FOREST PLAN SET IN CALIFORNIA
description: California's Senators, reaching a compromise that promises to end a 20-year stalemate, announced Thursday that they had agreed on legislation to protect 1.8 million acres Federal forestland in their state as wilderness.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ACF Industries Inc. , a New York railroad freight and tank car company, said its merger with a company owned by Carl C. Icahn had become effective.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Justice Vanishes

title: ODD ALLIES IN JERSEY
description: Governor Kean had an army of supporters from organized labor when he faced down the Democrats in the New Jersey Legislature this week and got his $3.3 billion transportation program passed. The sight of labor officials pressing their historic allies to help a Republican Governor underscores the political dividends Mr. Kean may reap from the program - a four-year road and mass-transit construction plan that will be the largest ever in the state - as he approaches his expected re- election campaign next year.

title: CONGRESS AND REAGAN AIDES DIFFER ON LATIN MOVES
description: A sudden flurry of developments in Cuba and Central America, highlighted by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's mission to Havana, has stirred some hopes in Congress of a new opening for peace diplomacy. But there has been a skeptical reaction from the Reagan Administration.

title: GENERALS SEEKING A SWEEP OF STARS
description: Two sets of numbers, 2-0 and 7-1, are not in the Generals' favor for the first-round United States Football League playoff game today against the Stars at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

title: PACT EXTENDING LIMIT ON RENTS IS SET IN ALBANY
description: Legislators reached agreement late Friday night to allow a temporary extension of rent protection for 30,000 apartments built in New York City over the last 10 years.

title: VOLUME UP
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in heavier trading as investors continued to be encouraged by the tone of the nation's economy.

title: ARGENTINA TO PAY OVERDUE INTEREST IN BANKING PACT
description: Argentina announced today that it had reached an agreement with international banks that gives the country a respite in its debt crisis. The accord came a day before a deadline for repaying overdue interest.

title: AID TO SALVADOR REBELS IS SPORADIC, U.S. SAYS
description: A new Reagan Administration report on Nicaragua accuses the Sandinistas of continuing to promote subversion in Central America, but concludes that military support to guerrillas in El Salvador has been sporadic since 1981.

title: GOVERNMENT'S PROBLEM WITH THE HEALTH PLAN TAX SHELTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Coal Output
description: Canadian coal production rose 24.3 percent in April to 4.6 million tons from 3.7 million tons a year earlier, Statistics Canada said today. For January through April, production totaled 19.9 million tons, up 27.2 percent from 14.5 million tons a year earlier.

title: BAN ON PROTEST SLEEPING IS UPHELD BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government's ban on overnight sleeping in the national parks near the White House does not violate the free speech rights of those who want to sleep there as a symbolic protest.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. STATEMENTS ON SPACE-WEAPONS NEGOTIATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a Soviet Government statement issued in Moscow yesterday proposing talks on the banning of weapons in space, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass and reported by The Associated Press, and the text of a statement issued in response in Washington by Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser: Soviet Statement

title: Home Care Filing
description: Medical Home Care Inc. said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company, which operated pharmacies, leased medical equipment and supplied home nursing services, suspended operations earlier this week, a company spokesman said.

title: JACKSON AND FARRAKHAN SOUGHT UNITY
description: Starting last November, a number of dapper black men from the Nation of Islam wearing bow ties began appearing as security guards in the entourage of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's newly formed Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: O'ER TO THE BOUNDING MAINE
description: It is very dark in the middle of Portland harbor at midnight.

title: Jurors Reject Death Penalty For Convicted Killer in Jersey
description: An Essex County jury today rejected the death penalty for a 54-year-old man convicted of killing three people.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYOFFS REJECTED
description: The 105 schools in the nation's chief college football division overwhelmingly rejected today a proposal for a postseason championship game. The margin of the decision probably means that the schools will not even consider a championship playoff again for the next couple of years.

title: Vermeil Declines
description: The Denver Gold may want Dick Vermeil as their next coach, but the former U.C.L.A. and Philadelphia Eagles' coach said that he was not eager to get back into the business. ''I have no intention of returning to coaching,'' Vermeil said, responding to a report that he was the leading candidate to replace Craig Morton as coach of the United States Football League team.

title: YANKS AND NIEKRO DEFEATED BY ROYALS
description: In a crisp game on a clear night, Phil Niekro, in his 19th season, threw his extraordinary knuckleball as well as ever. But Bud Black, a pitcher for the Royals in his second year, found better results with the ordinary pitches - a fastball and slider.

title: Minister Is Facing Trial In a Man's Suicide
description: A minister must stand trial for ''clergy malpractice'' because a young man shot himself to death despite being given spirtual and personal counseling, an appeals court ruled Thursday.

title: Harrelson Enjoys Life on the Farm
description: In the first managerial assignment of his 22-year-old professional baseball career, Bud Harrelson says he is experiencing ''dej a vu'' with the Little Falls Mets of the New York-Pennsylvania League, a Class A league filled with freshly signed high school and college athletes.

title: LTV-Republic
description: The LTV Corporation said it had completed its $770 million acquisition of the Republic Steel Corporation, a merger that creates the nation's second-largest steelmaker. Final closing and merger documents were filed with the secretaries of state in New Jersey and Delaware, making the merger official, said an LTV spokesman, Julie Price. The new company, LTV Steel, will be based in Cleveland and employ 46,000.

title: No Headline
description: What Else Europe Might Mend Crises in the European Common Market are so frequent it's become hard to get excited about them. Eventually they are resolved and the customs union is preserved. The budget crisis settled this week was no more critical than many others of the last 27 years. But it dragged on for so long it also conveyed a strong new message: If the union of Common Market nations intends to grow toward a political confederation, and perhaps even if it wants only to survive, it needs a new impetus.

title: THE TOILS OF THE DEMOCRATIC THRESHING MACHINE
description: The vanguard of the Democratic National Convention, about 600 of the 3,933 delegates who will gather in San Francisco in mid-July, spent the last two weeks on bivouac in Washington.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Reagan to Visit PicnicAnd Race on July 4
description: President Reagan will attend a family- oriented ''Spirit of America'' picnic in Decatur, Ala., and speak to campaign workers there on the Fourth of July, the White House announced today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Boston Ballet Seeks Head
description: The Boston Ballet has formed a national search committee for an artistic director to succeed Violette Verdy, who resigned last Sunday. Bruce Wells, the company's resident choreographer, will be interim artistic director. ''We are also considering him as a candidate,'' John Humphrey, chairman of the ballet, said Wednesday.

title: Torre's Hopes
description: Joe Torre is confident that he will return as manager of the Atlanta Braves next season.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DECLINED BY 0.7% IN JUNE
description: Prices farmers get for raw products dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in June but still averaged 7.5 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Jackson To Meet Mondale
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he planned to meet privately with Walter F. Mondale next week when both attend the annual convenation of the National Association For The Advancement Of Colored People.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Cardinals 5, Padres 0
description: Ricky Horton (4-1), making only his fourth major league start, had a no-hitter for 72/3 innings before finishing with a two-hitter. Kevin McReynolds got the first hit and Alan Wiggins had the other hit in the ninth.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The loss in the fourth quarter included a $1,006,000 provision for plant closing, reflecting the shutdown of the Comet Rice Houston Parboil facility late in the year.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $34,009, a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $174,000 and a tax credit of $504,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1 million and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $482,846.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
JAPAN WHALER SAYS HE'S NO BAD GUY
description: Wataru Kohama makes his living by harpooning whales.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Look Into the Future

title: Brazil Prices Up 9.2% in June
description: Brazilian prices jumped 9.2 percent in June, bringing the 12-month increase to 226.5 percent, the Getulio Vargas Foundation said today.

title: CITY ENDS FISCAL YEAR WITH $497 MILLION SURPLUS
description: New York City will finish its 1984 fiscal year today with a budget surplus of at least $497 million, Budget Director Alair A. Townsend said yesterday.

title: SLUMPING METS DROP 4TH IN A ROW
description: The sudden slide of the Mets steepened last night when they lost to the Atlanta Braves, 5-3, for their fourth consecutive defeat and the sixth in their last eight games.

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DRUG AGENT INSISTS DELOREAN PUT UP COLLATERAL FOR A DEAL
description: The drug trial of John Z. DeLorean returned to something approaching normal today, with a drug agent testifying rather poetically that ''drug deals are a rocky road'' and with the witness and a defense lawyer sparring over whether Mr. DeLorean had actually invested in a deal.

title: PRIVATE PUSH TO CLEAN CITY MOVES AHEAD
description: It was, David Rockefeller acknowledged, one of his ''smaller dreams,'' but one he had harbored for some time.

title: KOOL JAZZ FESTIVAL TODAY
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events. June 30 10:30 A.M., 1 and 3:30 P.M. South

title: Hinault Takes Tour Prologue
description: Bernard Hinault, the Frenchman who has won the Tour de France bicycle race four times, captured the prologue of this year's race in the eastern suburbs of Paris today.

title: German Trade Surplus
description: West Germany's merchandise trade surplus swelled in May to 4.83 billion marks, or $1.73 billion, from 2.56 billion marks in April and 3.64 billion marks a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The current account swung in May to a surplus of 2.7 billion marks, or $972 million, from a deficit of 400 million marks in April, but was down slightly from a year-earlier surplus of $1.72 billion marks. The current account includes trade in merchandise as well as services like finance and shipping.

title: CITY STREETS MEET COUNTRY CLUBS AS SUBURBIA BREAKS AND SHAKES
description: Seventeen suburbanites who had paid $60 for five dance lessons met for their first class here the other night, to learn how to writhe on the floor and shout, ''Yo, mama!''

title: Coast Peace Groups Stress Nonviolence
description: A coalition of groups taking part in a large peace rally on the opening day of the Democratic National Convention urged the police Thursday to respect their nonviolent stance and restrain special arrest squads.

title: L.I. CONTINUES WIMBLEDON MARCH
description: Paul Annacone knew that the stakes were high, for an unlikely reason, when he faced Christo Van Rensburg in the third round of Wimbledon today.

title: How the 'Mailed Fist' Saves Lives
description: Imagine a 19-year-old New Jersey resident who wants to enjoy a night of drinking with his friends. He'd have to be 21 to do that in his own state, but he can do it legally if he drives to New York. Now imagine him driving home. His chances of being involved in a fatal car accident are more than twice those of the average person.

title: TWO VIEWS AT ODDS ON VERMONT SECT
description: It was six years ago, just after a new religious order settled into this remote town beneath the Canadian border, that the townspeople took offense at what they saw. The men of the order, which has come to be called the Church of Island Pond, were whipping their children in the streets.

title: 2 TOP PUNJABI AIDES RESIGN IN SHUFFLE
description: The Governor of Punjab and a top police official in the northern state resigned today as part of a plan to overhaul the civil administration, the Government announced.

title: The Natural
description: In the late 1950's, Bill Walsh, Nort Thornton and Nick Biondi were roommates at San Jose State.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A roll-call yesterday of Wednesday's Senate vote to permit religious groups to use public high school facilities misstated the party affiliation of Senator Gary Hart of Colorado. He is a Democrat

title: Senate Backs Insider Bill
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would set stiffer penalities for the illegal use of insider information in the trading of securites.

title: AT SHELTER, THE SPIRITS ARE DOWN
description: When Helene Lowman first looked down from the balcony on the gymnasium where she was to live, she thought of a scene from ''The Snake Pit.'' The scene in the movie showed a horribly overcrowded dormitory in a mental institution, with the neglected inmates writhing like a group of snakes.

title: Suspended Archbishop Ordains 25 New Priests
description: Msgr. Marcel Lefebvre, the French traditionalist archbishop suspended from all priestly activities by Pope Paul VI in 1976, ordained 25 new priests of his movement today, urging them to help ''rebuild'' the Roman Catholic Church.

title: PERILS OF A TRAVELING COOK
description: Not much is gained by being a purist when you are cooking in unfamiliar surroundings if your primary aim is to get the food on the table.

title: JUDGE BARS CITY FROM ENFORCING BIAS ORDER
description: A state judge yesterday temporarily barred New York City from enforcing a policy designed to protect homosexuals from job discrimination by agencies holding city contracts.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. in Weaker Bracket
description: The United States Olympic basketball team was placed in Group B, considered the weaker

title: ISRAELIS INTERCEPT AND SEARCH LEBANON-BOUND FERRYBOAT
description: The Israeli Navy intercepted a ferryboat operating between Cyprus and Lebanon today and forced it to put in at the Israeli Mediterranean port of Haifa while the authorities checked the identities of some of the passengers.

title: PRIDE WITHOUT PAY
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.

title: Ex-Mexico Police Chief Arrested in Puerto Rico
description: The former Mexico City chief of police, Arturo Durazo, who is wanted by the Mexican Government for questioning on suspicion of embezzlement of public funds and extortion, was arrested tonight at San Juan airport, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: G.M. DEAL DESIGNED TO HOLD PEROT STAFF
description: When a company considers taking over a high-technology concern, it often fears that valuable employees will take their highly marketable skills elsewhere. Now the acquiring company has what may prove a helpful precedent in its effort to stem the exodus, Wall Street analysts said yesterday, in a new type of security to be offered as part of the General Motors Corporation's proposed acquisition of Electronic Data Systems Inc.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to May 31
American Stores
description: The American Stores Company said stock representing 67 percent of all common shares outstanding of the Jewel Companies had been tendered to it in an acquisition valued at up to $1.1 billion.

title: CONCERNS ON BANKRUPTCY LAW
description: Bankruptcy legislation approved by Congress today should have the nation's 227 bankruptcy judges back in business next week, according to Congressional lawyers who drafted the legislation's language.

title: MET MUSEUM CAMERAS PUTTING ART ON THE ROAD
description: Philippe de Montebello is one museum director who believes that a film about art is ''not to remove people from the direct experience of art, but to bring them to it.''

title: Article 036650 -- No Title
description: More than 100 families have moved into - and gained control of - a new $10 million housing development in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn without proper authorization.

title: NEWSPAPER CHIEFS IN DEBATE
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher whose newspapers include The New York Post, and Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, clashed Thursday night over Mr. Murdoch's contention that major news organizations were left of center.

title: 6 DIE IN DALLAS CLUB AS ENRAGED MAN FIRES WILDLY
description: An unemployed waiter who was rejected by a dance partner at a plush Dallas nightclub ''blew her a kiss'' before fatally shooting her and five other patrons early today, the police said.

title: Life-Size Hero
description: Inside the main gates of the All England Lawn Tennis Club, 75-year- old Fred Perry waits for a friend in front of a life-size statue of himself that was unveiled in May as part of the ceremonies commemorating the 50th anniversary of his three consecutive Wimbledon titles.

title: Determined Runner
description: Despite being banned by the New Zealand Amateur Athletic Association, Siegfried Bauer said that he would compete in the New York Six- Day Run beginning Monday at Randalls Island. Bauer, who won the event last year in 511 miles, was banned by the association after admitting that he received $2,420 for a race in New Zealand last November, at which he set the world record of 12 days 12 hours 36 minutes in the 1,000-mile run.

title: SHOULD TELEVISING OF RAPE TRIALS BE PERMITTED?
description: The image was one that no one who saw it would forget: the courtroom where six men were on trial for raping a woman on a pool table in a New Bedford, Mass., bar.

title: 37 Accused of Smuggling Federally Protected Birds
description: Wildlife officers arrested 37 people in 14 states and Canada today and accused them of taking part in a $750,000 international black market trafficking in federally protected birds of prey.

title: New Life
description: Jim Eisenreich , the former Minnesota Twins outfielder, forced into early retirement after 12 games this year because of a nervous condition, has apparently rediscovered a groove in a Minnesota amateur league in his hometown.

title: FUND SETS STAGE FOR PAYMENTS
description: A progress report from the International Monetary Fund to a steering group representing bank lenders to Argentina apparently set the stage for payment by Argentina of overdue interest on its debt, senior monetary officials said here today.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 30, 1984 International
description: Moscow offered to begin talks with the United States this fall on banning weapons in outer space. The Soviet leaders also offered a reciprocal moratorium on the testing and deployment of space weapons, to take effect with the opening of such talks, which they said could be held in September in Vienna. (Page 1, Col. 6.) The U.S. told Moscow it was willing to discuss a proposal for banning the militarization of outer space, but in the context of curbs on all missile systems. In its response to the Soviet leaders, the Administration sought to avoid an outright rejection of their proposal, while promoting its own desire to resume negotiations on medium-range missiles and strategic arms. (1:5.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Bridge column on June 5 about the Goldman Pairs incorrectly described the success of past husband-and-wife teams in the competition. The event was won by Jan and Tobias Stone in 1957.

title: PIN A TAIL ON THE FORECASTS
description: Just how reliable are the predictions about future budget and trade deficits, higher interest rates, economic ''overheating'' and resumed inflation that we read and hear about every day? Not very. Consider a few examples:

title: U.S. OFFICER CALLS NICARGUA 'MILITARIST BEHEMOTH'
description: The commander of United States military in Latin America said tonight that Nicaragua was ''a militarist behemoth threatening to its own people and to its neighbors alike.''

title: Multiple Injuries
description: Shirley Muldowney , three times a National Hot Rod Association Top Fuel dragster world champion, suffered fractures of both legs, broken ribs and a broken shoulder in an accident yesterday.

title: Bridge:Defender's Trumps Can Be
description: Those who think that one cannot have too much money may be right. Those who think that a defender cannot have too many trumps are certainly wrong.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Prices Ebb in Light Activity
description: Prices in the credit markets drifted lower yesterday in very light activity.

title: Florida Jury Convicts West German of Spying
description: A Federal jury convicted a West German automobile mechanic, Ernst Ludwig Wolfgang Forbrich, of two counts of espionage today.

title: Denial on Palmer
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have denied reports that they offered Jim Palmer , the former Baltimore Oriole right-hander, a tryout. A Baltimore newspaper said that Palmer, who was released by the Orioles earlier this season, had declined an invitation to try out with the Phillies on the ground that ''it's just the wrong time.'' But a spokesman for the Phillies said that a firm offer had never been made.

title: HOSPITAL IN MAINE TO RELEASE CAGNEY
description: James Cagney, who has been recovering from a heart attack at St. Andrew's Hospital here, is expected to be released Saturday, a spokesman for the actor said today.

title: CO-OP CONVERSIONS SERVING THE PUBLIC
description: To the Editor:

title: PICKETS CAN'T CURB THE PORN INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER BRACERO FIASCO?
description: To the Editor:

title: Polish Communists Oust Marxist Philosopher
description: The Polish Communist Party announced Thursday that it was expelling Adam Schaff, the Marxist philosopher, because his recent writings were incompatible with party membership.

title: Thomas O'Donnell, 79, Dies; Sat on State Supreme Court
description: Thomas J. O'Donnell, a New York State Supreme Court justice from 1962 until his retirement in 1975, died Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Buffalo. He was 79 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: REFORM FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE
description: Congress has responded to the near collapse of the Continental Illinois bank with measures that seek to restrict banks' ability to expand into other financial services. Such restrictions might be good banking policy but they do not address the primary problem raised by the Continental crisis. Instead, Congress must change the Federal deposit insurance system.

title: LOAN FROM STATE COMPLETES AID PLAN FOR YONKERS
description: Prospects for a balanced Yonkers budget for the fiscal year that starts Sunday were described as ''good'' today by Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello.

title: JACKSON LOBBIES FOR LATIN TALKS;TRIP CRITICIZED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson attempted today to rally support at the State Department and on Capitol Hill for intensified negotiations on Central America and Cuba.

title: PREFERENTIAL LIQUOR TAX OF HAWAII INVALIDATED
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated a Hawaiian tax law that gave preferential treatment to some locally produced alcoholic products.

title: Seattle Director Named
description: Gerard Schwarz, music adviser to the Seattle Symphony Orchestra and music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival in New York, has been named principal conductor of the symphony. He succeeds Rainer Miedel, who died in March 1983. Mr. Schwarz, 37 years old, is music director of the Waterloo Music Festival in New Jersey and the Y Chamber Orchestra of New York. He was born in New Jersey and educated at the High School of Performing Arts and the Juilliard School.

title: DEMOCRATS HAIL JACKSON SHIFT ON MUSLIM, BUT FEARS PERSIST
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's disavowal of the anti- Jewish statements made by Louis Farrakhan was regarded by Democratic leaders today as a major step toward redeeming his political standing in the party.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cost of Westway Hearings

title: GULF RAIDS:U.S. WEIGHS FFLEET BUILD-UP
description: Iraq's recent intensification of air attacks against oil tankers in the Persian Gulf may force a re-examination of the size and mission of the United States Navy squadron in the Indian Ocean, military and civilian analysts say. They feel that the Iraqi attacks - the latest was Wednesday, when a Swiss- owned supertanker was hit by a missile, causing the death of eight crewmen - could result in retaliatory Iranian action against Kuwait and other vulnerable Persian Gulf targets.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14.

title: COMPUTER INVESTORS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gain of $50,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain on early extinguishment of debt of $202,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income d-After extraordinary gain on settlement of litigation of $520,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and year. All shares and share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split of April 24, 1984.

title: DANCE:JACOB'S PILLOW POTPOURRI WITH 9 DANCERS
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival upheld its policy of eclecticism in two performances Thursday night. The principal attraction was a balletic potpourri featuring nine dancers from various companies called ''Ballet '84: New Views and Debuts.'' But dancelovers who came early could also have seen a performance of works-in- progress by two young modern dancers.

title: SHOPPING IN FREEPORT, ME.:MORE THAN JUST L.L. BEAN
description: If towns had an official color, this one's would be green.

title: MULLIN CAN LISTEN AS WELL AS SHOOT
description: He had demonstrated long ago that he was capable of shooting a basketball with remarkable accuracy. That had happened long ago, before the life of Chris Mullin was recorded up close and personal for America to watch this summer.

title: FERGUSON-MARSALIS BILL PLUS A NEW GUITARIST
description: A Kool Jazz Festival concert in Avery Fisher Hall Thursday evening promised a meeting between a long- established jazz trumpet star, Maynard Ferguson, and the latest trumpet sensation, Wynton Marsalis.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Poison, the Plane and the Pope
description: There are profound reasons for disliking the Soviet system and mistrusting the intentions of its leaders. It's a closed, militarized society that flouts its own laws, tyrannizes its neighbors and drives its best citizens into dissent or exile.

title: SMELTER PUTTING ARSENIC IN THE AIR IS SET TO CLOSE
description: The Asarco Copper Smelter, the nation's biggest source of arsenic pollution, will close by June 1985 because of losses caused by low copper prices and the high cost of environmental protection, the company has announced.

title: TAKING LIFE BY STORM
description: JAMES AGEE: A Life. By Laurence Bergreen. Illustrated. 467 Pages. Dutton.

title: 2 White South Africans Killed by Bomb in Angola
description: A South African white woman who opposed the country's racial policies was killed Thursday by a parcel bomb that exploded after being delivered to her home in Angola, the woman's father said today. Her 6-year-old daughter was also killed.

title: Night of Dameronia
description: The drummer Philly Joe Jones will lead Dameronia, which plays the music of Tadd Dameron, through tomorrow at Lush Life (228-3788), Bleecker and Thompson Streets. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight, and at 8:30, 10 and 11:30 P.M. tomorrow. There is an $8 cover and a $5 food or drink minimum.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
OUR STAKE IN POPULATION CONTROL ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTRUCTURING OF U.S. SCHOOLS URGED BY PANEL OF EDUCATORS
description: A study group of the National Education Association said yesterday that the nation's public schools ''must be totally restructured'' if they are to meet the needs of the future.

title: Danish Prices Rise 1.1%
description: An increase in housing expenses helped push consumer prices in Denmark up 1.1 percent in May from April for a 12-month increase of 6.5 percent, the Bureau of Statistics said today. In the year through May, Danish consumer prices rose at a slightly faster rate than a year earlier, but slower than in 1982 when prices rose at a rate exceeding 11 percent a year, the agency said.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHT BLOCKS LAND PLAN
description: The conservative majority in El Salvador's Legislative Assembly has voted to end the most important remaining part of the country's land redistribution program.

title: U.S. TELLS SOVIET IT WOULD TALK ABOUT ALL ARMS
description: The United States told the Soviet Union tonight that it was willing to discuss a proposal for banning the militarization of outer space, but in the context of curbs on all missile systems.

title: THE BOOM IN VIDEO CASSETTES
description: With sales of video cassette recorders rising beyond all expectations, the selling and renting of video cassettes, long the turf of small storefront merchants, has erupted in the past 18 months into a billion-dollar-a-year business.

title: Attendance Up
description: Attendance at major league baseball games this season passed 20 million Wednesday, the earliest date that mark has ever been reached. Previously, major league attendance reached 20 million on July 1 in both 1979 and 1982.

title: AN OLYMPIC DREAM IS ENDED
description: Craig Beardsley's Olympic dreams ended tonight, a month before the swimming competition begins in Los Angeles.

title: Rating Lower For U.S.F.L.
description: The 3.7 rating and 11 share last Sunday brought the United States Football League's final regular-season average on ABC-TV to 5.5 and a 15 share.

title: Dodd Criticizes Method Of Filling Party Ticket
description: Walter F. Mondale's method of searching for a Democratic running mate, through highly publicized interviews with prospective candidates, is turning into a liability, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said Thursday.

title: New U.S. Latin Maneuvers
description: The Pentagon announced today a series of ''small-scale'' military exercises in Central America, probably beginning in August. The announcement described the exercises as company-size - about 150 men - and officials said they were likely to involve training in counterinsurgency.

title: ; WILL NEW YORK CITY LOVE SIDNEY?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT MAN SUSPECTED OF SLAYING 6 WOMEN
description: A 24- year-old insurance agent, arraigned today on charges of murdering a 17-year- old girl, is a suspect in the slayings of five other young women in eastern Connecticut, the state police said.

title: Israel Radio-TV Strike Ends
description: Israel's state-run radio and television networks resumed regular broadcasting today after journalists ended a two-week strike. Israel Radio reported that the network's journalists signed a memorandum with the Israel Broadcast Authority on a new wage agreement, but the report gave no details of the pact. Broadcast journalists had been demanding parity with print journalists.

title: AN AMERICAN EVENING OF TORME AND SHEARING
description: In jazz, songs stand by themselves but also serve the performer. So it was Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, when Mel Torme presented ''Mel and George in an Evening of American Song.'' The evening was about songs, all right, but even more about Mr. Torme; his frequent collaborator George Shearing, the pianist; the guest singers Maureen McGovern and Rare Silk, the vocal quartet from Colorado, and the former Count Basie bandmembers Harry (Sweets) Edison, trumpet, and Marshall Royal, saxophone.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: LOOKING UP The face that appealed to the camera of Lewis W. Hine was the changing one of America in the first half of the 20th century. It was a workworn face that this photographer most often captured on his lens. His most famous pictures were of immigrants at Ellis Island and on the Lower East Side, of workers struggling under oppressive conditions, and even of the might of American industry in such ventures as the construction of the Empire State Building.

title: Kean Signs 1984-85 Budget Of $7.7 Billion, With Surplus
description: Governor Kean signed a $7.7 billion budget today after lopping about $150 million off the spending plan passed by the Legislature during a session that ended at 5 A.M.

title: THERESE LEWIS
description: Therese Lewis, a former radio and television scriptwriter, died of emphysema Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: WARNINGS ON KETTLES AND CRIBS
description: THE Consumer Product Safety

title: 70 INNINGS OF BASEBALL, THEN FREEDOM
description: Just before the Rev. Jesse Jackson came to visit the Cuban prison this week, officials reportedly hastily painted the cellblock walls.

title: A.C. NIELSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Both year-earlier periods were restated to reflect a change in accounting practices.

title: MONDALE IN SOUTH, CONTINUES ATTACKS ON REAGAN
description: ''I was the son of a Methodist minister in the small towns of Minnesota, and I used to dream of being an alderman someday,'' Walter F. Mondale said quietly this afternoon. ''And this country has been very good to me, as it has to millions and millions of others, and together we owe something to our nation and our children and our future.''

title: 104 Medals to U.S. as Games Close
description: Nancy Anderson of Lansing, Mich., set a world record of 17.78 seconds in the Cerebral Palsy 200-meter dash today as the third International Games for the Disabled closed at Mitchel Park.

title: Home Centers, K Mart Accord
description: The K Mart Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire Home Centers of America for $11 a share, or about $90 million.

title:
PATENTS;
ELECTRONIC CHECKER OF LANGUAGES
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation has developed a system to check spelling and hyphenation in documents that are written in more than one language.

title: LINKED I.R.A.'S: NOTE OF CAUTION
description: SOME people have opened a type of Individual Retirement Account known as either linked, tandem or Super I.R.A.'s. But these accounts are now under scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service and should be approached warily.

title: NEW BANKRUPTCY LAW TOUGHER ON CONSUMERS
description: The changes in the bankruptcy code that Congress approved today include some provisions that will make it more difficult for consumers to have their debts erased, a circumstance that its proponents say is good for creditors and borrowers alike.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dialing for Quarters

title: NO MORE PENCILS
description: We never had to consult the calendar to know that summer vacation was coming. We felt it in a hundred ways as the sun rose higher in the sky, altering the light that spilled across our scarred and pitted desks - first at P.S. 82 and later at Taft High School, in the Bronx. As the end of the school year approached, we grew noisier on line, slouched in our seats, didn't bother to cover our mouths when we yawned. We risked pink slips by talking during fire drills and passed notes openly in study hall, but, as the weather grew warmer, the teachers (whom we never imagined might also be impatient for vacation; we assumed they enjoyed making our lives miserable) seemed less inclined to notice our transgressions.

title: BILLING THE HOST
description: New Jersey's social life promises to become almost unendurable once people there begin adapting to this week's state Supreme Court ruling on who can be sued in drunken-driving cases.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I cannot talk about my feelings. To me, the job is a little special.

title: Toast to the Host in New Jersey
description: I hear Sam's being sued by a woman in Trenton who was involved in a car accident with Fred.

title: WHEN COKE THROWS A PARTY
description: In a swank ballroom of the Hyatt Regency Hotel, several Coke bottlers were hurling hoops toward stuffed Teddy bears, trying (and failing) to win prizes. Upstairs, bottlers were dancing to a lively country and western band. Some bottlers were petting the cow resting placidly in a makeshift pen on the second floor. Others were gawking at a 70-foot Coke hot-air balloon that had been squeezed into the lobby.

title: Debt Revamping By Dome Delayed
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it is running late in rescheduling its $6.2 billion (Canadian) of debt. The loan restructuring plan was to have been signed on Saturday but will now be delayed for ''10 days to two weeks,'' Dome's chairman and chief executive officer, Howard Macdonald, said at the annual meeting.

title: Sinatra Sues 2 Concerns For Radio-Package Sale
description: Frank Sinatra has filed a $1 million Federal Court suit against two companies marketing what he contends is an unauthorized radio package of his performances.

title: Mohawk Investor Holds 7% Stake
description: Asher Edelman, an investor, said he holds about a 7 percent stake in the common stock of the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: SCREEN:'BACHELOR PARTY'
description: It takes much longer than might be expected for ''Bachelor Party,'' which opened yesterday at the National and other theaters, to degenerate into a mindless mob scene. Until it takes that turn for the worse, the movie is actually funny. That is, it's as funny as ''Police Academy,'' which like this film was written by Neal Israel and Pat Proft. And it's certainly funnier than it has been made to look by its advertising campaign, which seems to feature the usual gang of suspects enjoying the usual sophomoric sex romp.

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP SETS MERGER
description: The Continental Group, which this week put itself up for sale to fend off a takeover offer by Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, yesterday agreed to merge with a corporation owned jointly by David H. Murdock, a West Coast financier, and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., a private mining and construction company.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: b-Includes pretax gain of $8.6 million from the sale of most of the company's supermarkets.

title: HOUSE PASSES WATER PROJECTS BILL IN 259-33 VOTE
description: The House of Representatives, in its last act before its Fourth of July recess, today voted to authorize water projects by the Army Corps of Engineers worth $18 billion over the next 10 years.

title: SOVIET ASKS TALKS ON THE OUTLAWING OF SPACE WEAPONS
description: Text of Soviet statement, page 4.

title: LEGAL AID EXECUTIVE AND DEMOCRATIC AIDE
description: Cissie Spiro Aidinoff, a vice president of the Legal Aid Society who held a number of posts in the Democratic Party, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old.

title: CONGRESS PLEA ON SAKHAROV
description: The House of Representatives today approved, on a 399-to-0 vote, a nonbinding resolution asking the Soviet Union for specific information about the health and legal status of the dissident scientist Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner. The resolution was introduced by Rep. Timonthy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado. The House approved it by a 399-0vote, and the Senate then approved it on a voice vote.

title: Metalworkers' Chief Sees Gains in German Pact
description: The head of the International Metalworkers Federation said today that a new 38 1/2-hour week for West German workers, achieved after a strike, would lead to a 30-hour week for most workers within 10 years.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The small coffee shop at South Ferry was shoulder to broad shoulder at 7 A.M. with construction workers from Locals 3, 825 and 1536. Most wore sleeveless undershirts that revealed tanned, muscular arms - arms that had never been hooked up to machines at health clubs, they will assure you; arms with plenty of latitude for tattooed panthers, hula dancers and snakes.

title: Article 037161 -- No Title
description: A $12 billion spending bill giveing the United States Customs Service more money to carry out the Reagan Administration's campaign against on drugs was passed Wednesday night be the House despite a veto threat by the White House.

title: SMUCKER, J.M. CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. JUDGE BACKS CURB ON POLLING AT VOTING PLACES
description: A Federal district judge today upheld a Washington State law that bans public opinion polling within 300 feet of voting places. But a lawyer for a number of news organizations said he would try to have the decision overturned before the November elections.

title: CONGRESS PASSES RISE IN DEBT LIMIT AND ADJOURNS
description: A weary House and Senate approved an increase in the limit on the national debt today and later adjourned for a three- week recess for the Fourth of July and the Democratic National Convention.

title: Frederick W. Howarth Dies; Led Hahne Stores in Jersey
description: Frederick W. Howarth, the former president and chief executive officer of Hahne & Company, a department store chain in New Jersey, died of cancer Tuesday at a nursing home in East Providence, R.I. He was 64 years old and lived in East Greenwich, R.I.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
Union Pacific Cable Accord
description: The Union Pacific System said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with four communications companies to install fiber optic cable along portions of its railroad right-of-way in 14 states.

title: TOM BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,262,000 for the quarter and $12,882,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,030,000 for the quarter and $4,824,000 for year.

title: FOYT OUT AT THE MEADOWLANDS
description: A. J. Foyt did not like his car, so he caught a plane today and went home.

title: No Headline
description: Healthdyne President Dismissed

title: Military Parts Ban Upheld
description: A Federal judge today refused to stop a Government ban on the National Semiconductor Corporation's sales of parts used in military products such as the F-18 fighter plane and the Space Shuttle.
